abstract: The artist has been challenging our notions of identity and selfhood for three decades, but her latest project feels uniquely pressing.
lead_paragraph: After the 2016 presidential election, the artist Catherine Opie began cutting up magazines and collecting images of political import: photographs of guns, senators, baby seals on shrinking ice caps. Today, in her studio in downtown Los Angeles, which occupies 5,000 square feet of a former brewery, a free-standing glossy black monitor plays these images as part of an animated collage. As digitized cutouts of ocean scenes and architectural landmarks inch upward on the screen, Opie explains, they illustrate a dire consequence of our rising seas: “Buildings are going to go underwater.”

headline: Cora Cahan Named President of the Baryshnikov Arts Center
abstract: Ms. Cahan previously served as the founding president of the New 42nd Street for 29 years.
lead_paragraph: Cora Cahan, a longtime New York arts administrator, will join the Baryshnikov Arts Center as its new president and chief executive, the organization announced on Tuesday. Ms. Cahan will begin her tenure in mid-October.

headline: Echoes of Benghazi Criticism and Anger Confront Pompeo in Ukraine Inquiry
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo once accused the Obama administration of obstructing a House inquiry and letting politics override national interests. He now faces similar charges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a member of Congress, Mike Pompeo drove the Republican inquiry into the killing of a United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and made clear there was no place for politics in American diplomacy. Nor, he said, would he tolerate “dithering” by an Obama administration State Department that he called “deeply obstructive of getting the American people the facts that they needed.”

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Peter Sarsgaard Reads ‘How 30 Blocks Became 30 Years’
abstract: The “Sound of Silence” actor reads an essay about disability in romantic relationships.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Donald Trump, M.L.B. Playoffs, Comets: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Christchurch Shooting Suspect Drops Bid to Move Trial to Auckland
abstract: The man accused of killing 51 people in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city where the shooting occurred, after his legal team withdrew a bid for a new venue.
lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — The Australian man accused of killing 51 people and wounding dozens more in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city of Christchurch, where the shooting occurred, after he told his legal team on Thursday to withdraw his application to have it moved to another city.

headline: El Chapo Said to Have Given $1 Million to Honduran President’s Brother
abstract: The president — who has not been charged in the case — has faced suspicion as United States prosecutors alleged recently he was part of the conspiracy in which his brother was charged.
lead_paragraph: United States prosecutors on Wednesday told a courtroom in New York that the Mexican drug kingpin known as El Chapo delivered $1 million to the brother of the Honduran president — money that had been intended to reach the president himself.

headline: ‘Dolemite Is My Name’ Review: Eddie Murphy, Raw and Cooking
abstract: Murphy, Wesley Snipes and an ensemble of accomplices elevate a not-bad biopic of an unlikely blaxploitation auteur.
lead_paragraph: “Dolemite Is My Name” starts out as a comedy of failure and foolish hope. When we first meet him, in Los Angeles in the early ’70s, Rudy Ray Moore is a multi-hyphenate might-have-been. As he slides toward middle age, popular culture seems to be running in the other direction. His novelty R&B singles can’t even get played in the record store where he works as assistant manager. His semi-naughty stand-up routine (“What did the elephant say to the naked man?”) is too corny for a generation discovering the matter-of-fact raunchiness of Redd Foxx.

headline: Philadelphia Supervised Injection Site Wins Legal Fight Against Justice Department
abstract: A plan to create a space where people can inject heroin and other drugs under medical supervision does not violate a federal law intended to crack down on drug houses, a federal judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia group’s plan to create a space where people can inject heroin and other drugs under medical supervision does not violate a federal law intended to crack down on drug houses, a federal judge ruled Wednesday in a case that could have far-reaching implications for other cities wanting to do the same.

headline: Shooting in Sydney Raises Questions About Gun Control
abstract: A gunman was shot dead by the police Wednesday after an hourlong shooting spree across western Sydney targeting a home and two police stations.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A gunman was shot dead by the police on Wednesday after an hourlong shooting spree across western Sydney that targeted a home and two police stations.

headline: American Diplomats Are Being Persecuted by Their Own President
abstract: Congress needs to repair the damage Trump has caused to the effectiveness and morale of the Foreign Service.
lead_paragraph: One of the first casualties of President Trump’s murky dealings with Ukraine has been the United States Foreign Service, the group of nonpartisan career professionals who serve as America’s primary point of contact with the world beyond our borders. While the House impeachment inquiry has rightly become a top priority, Congress must also act to repair the substantial damage Mr. Trump has caused to the effectiveness and morale of our diplomats and other State Department employees.

headline: Bill Bidwill, Dynastic Owner of N.F.L.’s Cardinals, Dies at 88
abstract: He moved the team from St. Louis to Arizona and presided over five playoff appearances, but never won a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: William V. Bidwill Sr., the longtime owner of the N.F.L.’s Arizona Cardinals, who moved the team from St. Louis to the Phoenix area, died on Tuesday in Phoenix. He was 88.

headline: New Scrutiny of Museum Boards Takes Aim at World of Wealth and Status
abstract: A recent protest at the Whitney that drummed out a vice chairman exposed the symbiotic, but potentially problematic, relationship that museums have with some trustees.
lead_paragraph: Warren B. Kanders, a vice chairman of the Whitney Museum of American Art, had just been driven out by a cascading protest over his company’s sale of law enforcement and military supplies. And his fellow trustee Kenneth C. Griffin was livid.

headline: Facebook Encryption Eyed in Fight Against Online Child Sex Abuse
abstract: The debate over privacy in the digital age increasingly pits tech companies against law enforcement agencies as explicit imagery explodes.
lead_paragraph: An explosion in reports of child sexual abuse imagery on the internet is prompting the authorities to step up pressure on technology companies over their use of encryption — and Facebook, which flags by far the largest amount of the material, is drawing outsize attention.

headline: Impeachment War Room? Trump Does It All Himself, and That Worries Republicans
abstract: The White House itself has no organized response to impeachment, and some aides doubt whether it even poses a serious threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was watching television in the White House on Wednesday morning when cable news channels started airing Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Representative Adam B. Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, warning at a news conference that any attempts by the president to stonewall their impeachment investigation would be viewed as obstruction.

headline: Impeachment Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: House Democrats offered a glimpse at how they plan to pressure the White House.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Impeachment Briefing, a special edition of the Morning Briefing that explains the latest developments in the House impeachment inquiry against President Trump. Sign up here to get the briefing by email every weeknight.

headline: Trump Denies Considering a Border Moat
abstract: The Times reported that the president considered the moat, to be infested with alligators and snakes, but Mr. Trump attributed the story to The Washington Post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday angrily denied a New York Times article that said he privately discussed fortifying barriers along the Mexican border with a reptile-filled moat to deter illegal border crossings.

headline: Harvard Won a Key Affirmative Action Battle. But the War’s Not Over.
abstract: More than 40 years after the Supreme Court first weighed in on race-conscious admissions, the fight remains as fractious as ever.
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 4: The plaintiff in the Harvard discrimination case, Students for Fair Admissions, filed a notice of appeal on Friday to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

headline: Jamal Khashoggi Is Still Owed Justice
abstract: The journalist’s savage murder exposed Saudi Arabia’s ruler as an enemy of a free press. His legacy should not stop there.
lead_paragraph: A year has passed since Jamal Khashoggi, the Saudi journalist and contributor to The Washington Post and Virginia resident, entered the Saudi Arabian Consulate in Istanbul to secure a document for his approaching marriage, only to be slain and cut to pieces, all recorded in sickening detail by Turkish secret services. Though the evidence is strong that he was killed with at least the knowledge of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler of the kingdom, in order to silence a sharp critic, the prince remains in the good graces of President Trump.

headline: Reporter’s Question, Repeated, Sets Trump on Latest Media Attack
abstract: After his profane tweet pushed CNN to allow an exception to its standards, the president trotted out his latest sobriquet: “corrupt news media.”
lead_paragraph: “Are you talking to me?” President Trump asked, his brow creased in disgust.

headline: Impeachment Bombshell That Wasn’t: Mysterious Packet Sends Rumor Mill Into Overdrive
abstract: Congress was expecting the State Department’s independent watchdog to deliver a bombshell. Instead, it got a package of opposition research mixing fact and speculation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cryptically worded request marked urgent from the State Department’s independent watchdog set Congress on edge.

headline: Is Age Only a Number, Even When You’re Running for President?
abstract: The top three Democratic candidates are 78, 76 and 70 years old and one of them, Bernie Sanders, went to the hospital with chest pain. Voters want experienced leaders, but exactly how much life experience do they want?
lead_paragraph: For months, Senator Bernie Sanders brushed off questions about his age, offering a simple, six-word mantra to those who doubt he’s energetic enough to run for president: “Follow me around the campaign trail.”

headline: Trump Tanks, Republicans Dither
abstract: See the senators shilly-shally.
lead_paragraph: Down with Republican wimps.

headline: Fact-Checking 4 of Trump’s Claims About the Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The president made a series of inaccurate claims as he sought to challenge the credibility of the investigation by House Democrats into his dealings with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Trump used two events at the White House with the president of Finland on Wednesday to challenge Democrats as they pressed ahead with their investigation into whether Mr. Trump had abused the power of his office in seeking political dirt from Ukraine.

headline: How Foreign Leaders Deal With an Unpredictable Trump
abstract: For a foreign ally standing next to President Trump, a placid expression and a willingness to expect the unexpected have become the price of admission.
lead_paragraph: For a foreign ally standing next to President Trump, a placid expression and a willingness to expect the unexpected have become the price of admission.

headline: For Finland’s President and Other Guests of Trump, Stoicism Is Key
abstract: A placid face and a willingness to expect the unexpected has become the price of admission for any foreign ally who hopes for a productive audience with President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An awkward handshake is really the least of their worries.

headline: Corrections: October 3, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, October 3, 2019.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL SECTION: DESIGN

headline: Ed Buck Is Indicted in Fatal Overdoses of Two Men at His Home
abstract: A federal grand jury charged Mr. Buck with two counts of methamphetamine distribution resulting in death. If convicted, he could face a sentence of life in prison without parole.
lead_paragraph: Ed Buck, a Democratic donor and activist already facing charges in the death of one of two men who fatally overdosed at his West Hollywood apartment, now faces charges in the other.

headline: Quotation of the Day: R.I.P. Ming, Bengal Tiger of Harlem
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 3, 2019
lead_paragraph: “We’re mostly a cemetery for cats and dogs so we’re excited to have Ming here.”

headline: Joe Biden Fires Back at Trump: ‘You’re Not Going to Destroy Me’
abstract: The counterattack, people close to Mr. Biden said, was intended to show that he would not let Mr. Trump “hijack” his campaign.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday night delivered his most forceful response yet to President Trump’s attacks on him and his son, accusing the Trump team of waging a campaign of “lies, smears, distortions and name calling” geared at knocking him out of the presidential race.

headline: ‘The New Englanders’ Review: Trying Too Hard to Be Special
abstract: Gay dads and their “woke genius” daughter face the limitations of life in a patchy new play by Jeff Augustin.
lead_paragraph: For the characters in Jeff Augustin’s “The New Englanders,” which opened on Wednesday at New York City Center’s Studio at Stage II, “basic” is quite the insult.

headline: ‘Freestyle Love Supreme’ Review: Hip-Hop Saves the World
abstract: This exultant evening of improvised rap — created by Thomas Kail, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Anthony Veneziale — turns out to be a perfect fit for Broadway.
lead_paragraph: And just as you were thinking that life has no rhyme nor reason these days, along comes “Freestyle Love Supreme” to pump you full of hope.

headline: Who’s the Fairest of Them All?
abstract: Ricky Cruz makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I know what you’re thinking. You’re thinking that the puzzle editors got the days mixed up again. You’re thinking that the Thursday puzzle was easier than the Wednesday puzzle, primarily because we had our rebus in the Wednesday puzzle. Whereas the Thursday puzzle by Ricky Cruz, who makes his New York Times debut, has no rebus at all.

headline: Donald Is Desperate
abstract: He will do and say whatever he can to avoid impeachment.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday I watched Donald Trump in the Oval Office, while seated next to the Finnish president, take questions from reporters in what can only be described as the unhinged rantings of a desperate man melting down, spiraling out of control and lashing out.

headline: Runaway Bull Corralled and Tranquilized After Roaming the Streets of Baltimore
abstract: This was the third time this year that a bovine has gotten loose in the city.
lead_paragraph: He had just finished a breeding session and was returning to the farm where he lives in western Maryland. But he apparently had other designs.

headline: Brexit, Italy, Impeachment: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: China, Where State Pomp Comes With Real Feeling
abstract: At the grand anniversary celebrations this week, attendees weren’t props but excited participants.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Attending China’s National Day celebrations over the years has been a bit like listening to different takes of a song, with the composer honing the themes and jettisoning the raw bits until the piece sounds just right.

headline: He Was Detained. That Didn’t Stop Them From Kidnapping Him.
abstract: In a major crackdown, Alaa Abd El Fattah and hundreds of other Egyptian activists or protesters have been arrested.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — My last text exchange with the Egyptian activist and software programmer Alaa Abd El Fattah was Saturday morning, less than 24 hours before he was kidnapped by government security agents. We shared messages about our personal relationships and made a plan to spend Monday together. I imagined that he would come over for breakfast; then we might go to the pool at our local sports club. It was there that we had last spent the afternoon together a couple of weeks ago, along with his son and my goddaughter.

headline: Late Night Wonders Who Was Called for a Quote on the Moat
abstract: “Yeah, they actually got a quote for the moat, which also sounds like the name of the most xenophobic Dr. Seuss book ever,” Trevor Noah joked Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Word + Quiz: sotto voce
abstract: This term has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Laurene Powell Jobs and Robin Hood Fund Give $16 Million for N.Y. Schools
abstract: The plan marks the first major expansion of schools since Mayor Bill de Blasio took office nearly six years ago.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has decided to use about $16 million in private funding from an education organization backed by Laurene Powell Jobs, the widow of Steve Jobs, and from Robin Hood, a philanthropic powerhouse favored by Wall Street executives, to help open a host of new and restructured public schools in New York City.

headline: The Braves, the Cardinals and an Infamous Infield Fly: An Oral History
abstract: The last time the Braves and the Cardinals faced off in the postseason, a seemingly routine pop-up transformed Turner Field into a caldron of rage and confusion.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Braves and the Cardinals will start their National League division series on Thursday, and just about all the two teams — and baseball officials — can hope for is that the matchup will avoid the chaos and controversy of their last playoff meeting.

headline: After Hospitals’ Donation to New York Democrats, a $140 Million Payout
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo raised payments to hospitals at a time when Medicaid spending was already drastically over budget.
lead_paragraph: With Medicaid costs soaring in New York, the Greater New York Hospital Association was pushing for the seemingly impossible: more state reimbursement money.

headline: Clayton Kershaw Steps Beyond Sandy Koufax’s Footprints
abstract: Kershaw has long been compared to Koufax, but he is still evolving at age 31, older than the elder Hall of Famer was when he retired.
lead_paragraph: There’s an urban legend about Sandy Koufax that has circulated for years in the Dodgers community. It goes like this: Before the 1978 World Series against the Yankees, Dodgers Manager Tommy Lasorda asked the retired Koufax, then 42, to throw batting practice to his team.

headline: Rams Head to Seattle for Clash With Seahawks
abstract: Fresh off a 55-40 disaster against Tampa Bay, Los Angeles has little time to figure out its issues.
lead_paragraph: The rest of Week 4’s picks can be found here.

headline: Rays’ Victory Sets Stage for a Pitchers’ Duel in Playoffs
abstract: The victory earned the Rays a trip to Houston’s Minute Maid Park, where the mighty Astros await in an American League division series that starts Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Major league hitters shattered the single-season record for home runs this year, so the start of the wild-card games was fitting. In both of them, a ball cleared an outfield fence before the first out.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Are People Protesting in Hong Kong?’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn more about the movement and compare it to others throughout history to answer the question: Are protests an effective way to bring about change?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Why Are People Protesting in Hong Kong?”

headline: Facebook Can Be Forced to Delete Content Worldwide, E.U.’s Top Court Rules
abstract: The decision that individual countries can order Facebook to take down posts globally sets a benchmark for the reach of European laws governing the internet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s top court said on Thursday that individual countries can order Facebook to take down posts, photographs and videos not only in their own countries but elsewhere, in a ruling that extends the reach of the region’s internet-related laws beyond its own borders.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Helping Yourself to Tea
abstract: If it’s O.K. to do during a solo visit, is it O.K. to do at a dinner party?
lead_paragraph: Rebecca writes: When my friend Oliver visits, he makes himself a cup of tea. I’m fine with this when it’s just the two of us. But on Friday, I held a dinner party for 11, including Oliver, who asked if he could make a cup of tea. I said no, because I was using all of my small kitchen. He made the tea anyway. Was I being too controlling?

headline: A Star of Y.A. Imagines a Supernatural Ivy League in Her Debut for Adults
abstract: Leigh Bardugo, the author of best-selling books like “Shadow and Bone” and “Six of Crows,” has written “Ninth House,” which features occult versions of the secret societies at Yale.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — There are many things that might attract a potential student to Yale, but the gloom of New Haven’s dead-of-winter aesthetic is not the first that springs to mind. Unless, perhaps, you come from California and you hate the sunshine and you are Leigh Bardugo, future fantasy novelist.

headline: The Middle-Class Crunch: A Look at 4 Family Budgets
abstract: Most Americans think of themselves as middle class. For many, the line between a stable life and a fragile one is thinning.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans think of themselves as middle class. For many, the line between a stable life and a fragile one is thinning.

headline: Scouring Manhattan for the Right Rental. Which Did She Choose?
abstract: To be closer to her new job, a young renter headed south with a tight budget and a couple of requirements. Here’s where she landed.
lead_paragraph: To be closer to her new job, a young renter headed south with a tight budget and a couple of requirements. Here’s where she landed.

headline: The Eve Babitz Revival
abstract: Nostalgia for 70s era bohemia runs high.
lead_paragraph: Eve Babitz doesn’t have a computer, and if you phone her, she is likely to hang up on you. Since the afternoon nearly two decades ago when she dropped a lighted match on her lap while driving home from lunch in her ’68 VW Bug, she has kept mostly to herself, holed up in her West Hollywood apartment with her cat and seeing select visitors. Now 76, Ms. Babitz is dimly aware of her surging popularity, particularly among young women, but aging hits burn victims even harder than it does the rest of us, and lately she has turned more inward. “All publicity is great,” she has told her sister, Mirandi Babitz, as Mirandi recalled recently, “but not really in your 70s.”

headline: Ben Lerner’s ‘The Topeka School’ Revisits the Debates of the ’90s
abstract: In his third novel, “The Topeka School,” Lerner revisits the precocious poet of his earlier work, this time as a morally confused Midwestern teenager.
lead_paragraph: THE TOPEKA SCHOOL By Ben Lerner

headline: Poem: Crossing
abstract: Succinct phrases and sentences pack a deep power of knowledge and conviction. One thing — but also everything else.
lead_paragraph: A poem may be deceptively small in size but no less mesmerizing. Read “Crossing” aloud a few times, and the mouth and lungs fall into a different rhythm and pacing. “The Tradition,” Jericho Brown’s stunning book, contains so many moments of utter hypnosis like this — a long stare, a conversation constructed of mesmerizing layers, many unspoken, but moving far, far beyond a moment. Succinct phrases and sentences pack a deep power of knowledge and conviction. One thing — but also everything else. Let’s dedicate this poem to the Bahamas and all the energy it’s going to take to put that beautiful world back together. Let’s dedicate it to every next day. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: New Imprint for Graphic Novels Aims to Increase the Presence of Queer Authors
abstract: The writer Mariko Tamaki will curate Surely Books, a new line from Abrams that will begin publishing in spring 2021.
lead_paragraph: They’re here! They’re queer! They’re graphic novels! The publisher Abrams is beginning a graphic novel imprint dedicated to expanding the presence in the medium of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex and asexual creators and stories.

headline: Clowns
abstract: Write the opening paragraph of a story — true or made up — with a clown in it.
lead_paragraph: The Style section recently pointed out that, right now, clowns are everywhere — on social media, in the movies, on television, and even on fashion runways.

headline: What Are Your Reactions to the Impeachment Inquiry of President Trump?
abstract: Congress has formally initiated an impeachment inquiry against the president. Do you think it is justified?
lead_paragraph: Note: Teachers might pair this with our recent Lesson of the Day, which can help students understand the impeachment process. For more context and information, students can watch the three-minute video above, take a look at this timeline, or scan Trump Impeachment Inquiry: Live Updates.

headline: All’s Well That Ends Well: Fall Romance Novels
abstract: Our columnist Jaime Green looks at new books by Kerrigan Byrne, Jane Ashford, Rachel Spangler and Rebecca Zanetti.
lead_paragraph: The happy ending — happily ever after, or at least happily for now — is the defining trait of romance. No love story, no happy ending? Not a romance. But nobody says they have to start happy — and they often don’t. The opening of Kerrigan Byrne’s HOW TO LOVE A DUKE IN TEN DAYS (St. Martin’s, paper, $7.99) tests how darkly a romance can begin.

headline: Stay-at-Home Parents Work Hard. Should They Be Paid?
abstract: The idea, a favorite of social conservatives, is now supported by several Democratic presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: It’s not uncommon in the United States for two parents to spend long hours working hard — but the one who works outside the home is paid for it, while the one who does housework and child care is paid nothing.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o Had a Guilty Pleasure on the Set of ‘12 Years a Slave’
abstract: The Oscar-winning actress, whose new children’s book is “Sulwe,” enjoyed “Fifty Shades of Grey” during filming: “I needed something light and inconsequential to take me out of the harshness of the world.”
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning actress, whose new children’s book is “Sulwe,” enjoyed “Fifty Shades of Grey” during filming: “I needed something light and inconsequential to take me out of the harshness of the world.”

headline: A Police Tesla Nearly Ran Out of Power During a Chase. It Wasn’t the Car’s Fault.
abstract: Gas or electric, all cars need to be refueled in some way, the police in Fremont, Calif., said.
lead_paragraph: A California police officer driving a Tesla Model S during a high-speed chase on a Bay Area freeway radioed to his colleagues that he was running low on battery. He needed someone else to take over.

headline: My Teen Lied to Me. Was I Right to Ground Him?
abstract: A psychologist’s advice for a parent whose teenager sneaks out of the house during the night to go to a party.
lead_paragraph: Our Adolescence columnist, the psychologist Lisa Damour, responds below to a question that was recently posted anonymously by a parent on the Facebook group of Grown & Flown, a site for parents of teenagers and young adults. The question is lightly edited and is being published with the consent of the person who posted it.

headline: Will the G.O.P. Turn Against Trump?
abstract: Whose armrest is it anyway? An airplane etiquette debate.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Jeffrey Epstein Raked In $200 Million After Legal and Financial Crises
abstract: A guilty plea and the recession dented Mr. Epstein’s wealth and reputation in 2008. But the financier bounced back in a big way in the Virgin Islands.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein’s biggest client had deserted him, his money management firm had lost more than $150 million during the financial crisis, and he was a registered sex offender. But after he started a new company with a wildly speculative business plan in 2012, Mr. Epstein had no problem pulling in cash.

headline: How Times Journalists Become Experts on a Subject
abstract: When starting a new job, journalists read and read and have coffee after coffee so that when news breaks, they’re ready.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Cars All but Banned on One of Manhattan’s Busiest Streets
abstract: Starting on Thursday, cars are no longer welcome on 14th Street, a major crosstown route for 21,000 vehicles a day.
lead_paragraph: Buses cruised along without getting trapped behind cars.

headline: Can Young Kim Help Turn Orange County Red Again?
abstract: She describes her life story as the “American dream” and would have been the first Korean-American woman in Congress. After losing a congressional race by a very thin margin, she is back for a rematch.
lead_paragraph: LA HABRA, Calif. — When newly elected members of Congress traveled to Washington for freshman orientation in late November, Young Kim, 56, flew from her Orange County home to join them. Not all of the ballots in California’s 39th Congressional District were counted, but Ms. Kim believed her narrow lead was solid. After shaking hands with other members at white-tablecloth lunches, she posed for her official portrait and a group photo of all new members. Ms. Kim was expected to be one of two Republican women of color and the first Korean-American woman in Congress.

headline: September’s Book Club Pick: The Upheaval in the American Workplace
abstract: Steven Greenhouse’s “Beaten Down, Worked Up” traces the modern history of American workers and their current condition.
lead_paragraph: BEATEN DOWN, WORKED UPBy Steven Greenhouse

headline: Parents Paid to Open College Doors. Now They’re Spending to Limit Prison Time.
abstract: Some parents who have pleaded guilty in the admissions fraud case are turning to consultants and doctors in an effort to secure lenient sentences.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One parent, hoping to avoid prison in the nation’s largest-ever college admissions fraud case, stood before the judge with an elaborate proposal for a community service project: He could make amends, the parent’s lawyers offered, by designing and raising funds for a “cutting-edge” collaboration between the Special Olympics and private schools.

headline: Why Pedro Almodóvar’s Newest Film Frightened His Friends
abstract: The director who surprised even friends with his confessional new drama, “Pain and Glory,” has turned inward, in life and on the screen.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Almodóvar is fun at parties, but parties aren’t always fun for Pedro Almodóvar.

headline: How the Law Protects Intelligence Whistle-Blowers, and Leaves Them at Risk
abstract: President Trump compared the whistle-blower to a spy. The complainant has some legal protections, but there are gaps in the law, too.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has threateningly targeted the whistle-blower who brought to light how he pressured Ukraine’s leader to open investigations that could benefit him politically, not only portraying the whistle-blower as a spy but also expressing a desire to “interview and learn everything about” him.

headline: Britain, Struggling With Brexit, Eyes Another Retreat. This One’s From Fossil Fuels.
abstract: The country, which led the industrial revolution, now aims to neutralize its carbon emissions by 2050.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the shadow of a noisy, turbulent Brexit, another epic transformation is underway in Britain.

headline: Can the N.B.A. Find a Basketball Superstar in India?
abstract: The league thinks India could be its next billion-dollar market. But first it needs to convince young Indians to fall in love with the game.
lead_paragraph: The soupy morning air in one of the world’s most polluted cities had all but cleared by the time Saturday morning’s outdoor practice ended for the men’s basketball team at Ramjas College. If players had to wait out New Delhi’s smog, they would never practice, because there are few indoor courts in India. Ankit Hooda, a 20-year-old student who is one of the team’s best players, lingered on the court and laughed as his friend showed off a right ring finger that was dripping blood. Moments before, his teammate, Navdeep Grewal, had sliced the finger on the metal rim while dunking the ball. For Grewal, who is 19, playing this sport is a joy. Grewal is the son of a military man, firmly ensconced in India’s middle class. Hooda, however, is not from the same class. To him, basketball means much more.

headline: Bipartisan Report Says Trump’s Abuse Has Pushed Federal Science to a ‘Crisis’
abstract: All presidents over the past two decades have nudged science to support their policies, but a report out of N.Y.U. said the Trump administration has driven federal science to a “crisis point.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a single month in 2017, the Trump administration’s Environmental Protection Agency blocked scientists from speaking at a climate change conference, its Interior Department forwarded a policy letter to U.S. Customs and Border Protection only after deleting concerns from biologists about a border wall’s effects on wildlife, and the F.B.I. issued a crime report that omitted dozens of tables of data on homicides and arrests.

headline: 36 Hours in Boone, N.C. (and Environs)
abstract: A lively Appalachian college town, a genteel resort spot and stops along the Blue Ridge Parkway offer a colorful fall weekend of music, crafts, beer and majestic views.
lead_paragraph: Asheville, N. C. — with its lively arts district, locavore food movement and over-the-top, Gilded Age mansion — attracts hordes of leaf peepers as soon as the temperatures start to drop. But a two-hour drive up the spine of the Blue Ridge Mountains, the less-visited Boone, a gem of a college town in the heart of Southern Appalachia, offers many of the same attractions, and plenty more besides. Come for the fresh air and majestic mountain views, but stick around to sample the local brews, enjoy live music and admire the fine crafts of the area’s talented artisans. The Blue Ridge Parkway is well worth the small detour for its historic sites and sweeping overlooks, while nearby Blowing Rock — a genteel resort town long favored by well-to-do Southern tourists — offers fine dining, swank boutiques and one of the most famous views in the state.

headline: He Grew Up on a Farm. Now, He Helps Protect Them.
abstract: Thomas Njeru is a co-founder of a microinsurance firm based in Kenya that covers small farms across Africa.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a new series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: The Hippest Trip in New York? It’s Soul Train Utica. Hop On.
abstract: This rolling dance party is off the hook but never off the rails.
lead_paragraph: “Soul Train,” the dance party that ran on television from 1971 to 2006, billed itself as the “hippest trip in America,” and on a good Saturday, it lived up to the billing. It changed the way America danced, dressed, coifed and sounded — sometimes within hours of its airtime.

headline: The New MoMA Is Here. Get Ready for Change.
abstract: The expanded Museum of Modern Art reopens this month, putting Picasso and Monet next to more recent, diverse artists. Will audiences embrace its new vision?
lead_paragraph: Picasso and Braque were looking a little forlorn: unsure of their new home, unsure of their new acquaintances.

headline: Hong Kong Police, Seen as ‘Hounds After Rabbits,’ Face Rising Rage
abstract: The shooting of a teenage protester has amplified anger at a police force that some see as a symbol of Beijing’s unchecked power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A woman was hit in the eye during a protest. Passengers were beaten on a subway train. A student was shot in the chest with a live round — and now is being charged with rioting.

headline: Hong Kong Takes Symbolic Stand Against China’s High-Tech Controls
abstract: The first major place in China to rebel against Beijing’s technologies of control is one of the last not yet fully under their thrall.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There’s no sign to mark it. But when travelers from Hong Kong cross into Shenzhen in mainland China, they reach a digital cutoff point.

headline: What to Know About the New 14th Street Busway
abstract: Thursday: New York's plan to speed up buses on the busy street is now in effect. Here are the new rules.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Egypt Is Using Apps to Track and Target Its Citizens, Report Says
abstract: A cybersecurity firm says evidence suggests the Egyptian government carried out cyberattacks on journalists, academics, lawyers and rights activists.
lead_paragraph: A series of sophisticated cyberattacks targeting Egyptian journalists, academics, lawyers, opposition politicians and human rights activists has been traced to Egyptian government offices, a cybersecurity firm has found.

headline: Adam Schiff, Facebook, Amber Guyger: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Is China Heading for Crisis?
abstract: The protests in Hong Kong accelerate the contradictions in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, Gordon Chang, an American lawyer who had spent many years in Hong Kong and Shanghai, published a book forebodingly titled “The Coming Collapse of China.” At the time, the thesis seemed improbable, if not preposterous.

headline: Ukraine’s Leader Has Jumped Into Trump’s Trap
abstract: And the winner is … Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: For some Europeans, the most embarrassing revelation of the now very public phone conversation between Donald Trump and Ukraine’s president on July 25 was not the attempt by Mr. Trump to interfere in the judiciary system of a foreign country for his own political benefit. Nothing the American president does could surprise any longer.

headline: How Rudy Giuliani’s Ukraine Operation Backfired
abstract: He was sent on a mission to clear the president’s name. In the process, he pursued a shadow foreign policy that led to an impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Only the ‘Most Hard-Core Women’ Go Off-Road for Rebelle Rally
abstract: The 10-day, 1,600-mile race in the desert, starting next week, challenges body and mind and helps competitors find themselves.
lead_paragraph: Over 10 days, they will drive across 1,600 grueling, off-road miles in the Nevada and California deserts, where the afternoons can reach 100 degrees and the nights can dip to 15. On their hunt for just under 200 hidden checkpoints, they will rely on map and compass skills, as well as driving prowess, physical stamina and more.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Europe Deals a Big Blow to Facebook
abstract: The E.U.’s top court ruled that an individual country can order the social network to take down content worldwide, adding new burden to global internet companies.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Vanity Fair just published its latest New Establishment list, and those riding high include Jeff Bezos, Susan Wojcicki of YouTube and Ted Sarandos of Netflix. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.).

headline: A Viewer’s Guide to ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
abstract: With the arrival of a franchise of the reality show in Britain, here are a few things to look out for as the queens compete for the crown.
lead_paragraph: “RuPaul’s Drag Race” has become such an international sensation that RuPaul Charles, the show’s creator and host, might as well have opened a United Nations mission.

headline: ‘The Parts You Lose’ Review: Talk to Me
abstract: Aaron Paul plays a violent fugitive whose life is saved by a lonely deaf boy in this downbeat thriller.
lead_paragraph: The central character in Christopher Cantwell’s small-scale thriller, “The Parts You Lose,” is a lonely 10-year-old named Wesley. As played by the deaf British actor Danny Murphy, Wesley is watchful and careful in his movements, as if hoping that the school bully won’t notice him. He always does.

headline: ‘Wallflower’ Review: The Scene Before a Crime
abstract: This film dubiously dramatizes the circumstances of a 2006 massacre in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Depiction doesn’t always indicate endorsement, but that doesn’t mean it’s necessarily enlightening. “Wallflower” dramatizes the circumstances of a March 2006 mass shooting in Seattle that left seven dead, counting the gunman, who committed suicide.

headline: ‘Low Tide’ Review: Jersey Boys to Jersey Men
abstract: A long summer on the New Jersey shore swerves disappointingly from coming-of-age drama to implausible crime caper.
lead_paragraph: In the small beach town on the New Jersey shore where “Low Tide” plays out, there’s not much for teenage boys to do except loiter at the fairground and pick fights with the summer visitors whose money is both needed and resented. From time to time, Alan (Keean Johnson) and his friends Red (Alex Neustaedter) and Smitty (Daniel Zolghadri) break into vacation homes and steal what they can. Yet we get the sense that these amateur raids are conducted as much to alleviate boredom as provide pocket money.

headline: ‘On the President’s Orders’ Review: Police Unleashed on the Philippines
abstract: In roundabout fashion, a documentary examines the sources of the wave of extrajudicial killings under President Rodrigo Duterte.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “On the President’s Orders” opens with a clip of President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines saying in 2016 that he would be “happy to slaughter” the country’s drug addicts. He approvingly compares taking that action to Hitler’s genocide of Jews.

headline: ‘Memory: The Origins of Alien’ Review: Extras on an Extraterrestrial
abstract: This documentary about Ridley Scott’s 1979 science-fiction classic often plays like a conventional making-of doc.
lead_paragraph: A specialist in documentaries about movies, the director Alexandre O. Philippe gave himself a tough act to follow: His 2017 film “78/52: Hitchcock’s Shower Scene” applied a variety of approaches — historical, theoretical, technical — to deconstructing a single sequence in “Psycho.”

headline: ‘Cuck’ Review: When Bigotry Meets Pornography. Yes, It’s That Bad.
abstract: A smarter group of filmmakers might have wrestled this repellent material into a decent black comedy.
lead_paragraph: The word “cuck” is short for “cuckold,” and up until recently was used most often to describe a subgenre of pornography in which a hapless husband is forced to not only watch his wife have sex with another man but — oh dear, I had better stop. In any event, its adoption as a political term — meaning a conservative of insufficient, er, conviction — is just one of the many ways American discourse was enhanced by the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: ‘Pretenders’ Review: A Little New Wave Love, a Lot of Misogyny
abstract: Directed by James Franco and featuring James Franco, this film indulges in a distasteful brand of nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: Remember that Monty Python sketch about the vicious gangsters the Piranha Brothers? It had this great line, “I’ve seen grown men tear their heads off rather than see Doug.”

headline: ‘Semper Fi’ Review: A Misty-Eyed Ode to Male Bonding
abstract: Henry-Alex Rubin’s film follows five longtime friends who behave like nitwits when one of their number goes to jail.
lead_paragraph: In Henry-Alex Rubin’s “Semper Fi,” men are men, women are props and brotherhood — whether literal or figurative — is everything.

headline: New Airbnb Excursions to Focus on Animals
abstract: Airbnb Animal Experiences will have an ethical focus; its announcement comes at a time of increased scrutiny of organizations offering animal interactions to tourists.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb Experiences, the activities arm of the home-sharing platform, offers travelers many things to do in Lima, Peru. They can learn to cycle around the capital on a bamboo bike ($32); make ceviche in the home of a local ($62); and spend 90 minutes with Otto, the skateboarding bulldog who set a world record for the longest human tunnel traveled through by a skateboarding dog (picture a line of participants standing with their legs wide, creating a passageway for the rolling canine).

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘High Life’ and the iHeartRadio Music Festival
abstract: Claire Denis’s “High Life” is streaming on Amazon. And performances from Chance the Rapper, Alicia Keys and more air on the CW.
lead_paragraph: HIGH LIFE (2019) Stream on Amazon; Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. The French director Claire Denis is known for making independent movies that tell intimate, personal stories. But on paper, her first English-language film, “High Life,” doesn’t necessarily shout “intimate.” It’s a sci-fi movie, for one thing, and it accordingly takes place in about the most vast setting possible: space. Robert Pattinson stars as Monte, a young man who has agreed to participate in an extraterrestrial mission in order to avoid the death penalty. He’s traveling on a spaceship as part of a small criminal crew, bound for a black hole in deep space. Also on the ship is a troubled doctor played by Juliette Binoche; other crew members are played by Lars Eidinger and the musician André Benjamin. Their mission is derailed, in part, by an unexpected birth. “As is often the case in Denis’s movies, ‘High Life’ vibrates with low-key erotic energy that can feel exciting, a little dangerous,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. “But,” she added, “too often the ideas here, visual and otherwise, feel haphazard — outer and inner space, Pattinson’s head, sexual taboo, apocalypse now or maybe then — more like material for a vision board than a fully realized vision.”

headline: Rapes and Killings of Children Haunt a Corner of Pakistan
abstract: Child sexual abuse cases keep surfacing in one eastern district, each more shocking. The police say a man has confessed to four recent killings.
lead_paragraph: CHUNIAN, Pakistan — When the 8-year-old Muhammad Faizan went missing on Sept. 16, he was the fourth child to mysteriously disappear in the eastern Pakistani city of Chunian since June. Three other boys had been missing for several weeks.

headline: Deny, Deflect, Deflate
abstract: The White House strategy.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Knife Attack at Paris Police Headquarters Leaves 4 Dead
abstract: The assailant, an administrative employee who had worked at Police Headquarters since 2003, was also killed, an official said. His motive was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A veteran police employee in France slipped a knife through security at the heavily guarded Police Headquarters in the heart of Paris on Thursday, killing four of his colleagues before being shot dead in the building’s vast courtyard.

headline: The Top Issues and Candidates for Californians in 2020
abstract: Thursday: A new state survey shows a three-way tie for Democrats. Also: The latest developments in the Trump impeachment inquiry, and a homestead in the high desert.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Looted Ethiopian Crown Resurfaces in the Netherlands
abstract: A Dutch civil servant says he hid the precious artifact away in his home for more than 20 years. Now, he hopes it can be returned to Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In 1998, Sirak Asfaw, a Dutch civil servant who was born in Ethiopia, noticed something shiny in the suitcase of a guest who was staying at his house. Curious, he opened the case to find a glittering gilded crown inside.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are in Syosset, N.Y., and Island Heights, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Syosset, N.Y., and Island Heights, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Hell’s Kitchen and Murray Hill.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Hell’s Kitchen and Murray Hill.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are in Syosset, N.Y., and Island Heights, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Hell’s Kitchen and Murray Hill.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Can You Afford to Buy a Home?
abstract: A new report offers a guide to the annual income that lenders will require you to have to qualify for a mortgage.
lead_paragraph: If you are you wondering whether you can afford to buy a home these days, HSH.com’s quarterly report might help. The report tells you how much annual income you’d need in order to qualify for a mortgage in the 50 largest metropolitan areas in the United States.

headline: Kim Shattuck, Musician Who Fronted the Muffs, Is Dead at 56
abstract: A singer, songwriter and guitarist, she was in the vanguard of punk bands crashing into the mainstream in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Kim Shattuck, the singer, songwriter and guitarist whose work with the Muffs made her a raucous role model and put her in the vanguard of punk bands crashing into the mainstream in the 1990s, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 56.

headline: My Mom Obsesses Over Her Love Life. She Couldn’t Care Less About Mine.
abstract: Is this what happens when you start dating again for the first time in 40 years? Or is it personal?
lead_paragraph: My father died two years ago. Since then, my mother began online dating. But she hasn’t dated in 40 years, and she’s reverted to acting like a teenager: falling in love too quickly, disclosing too much too soon. She recently met my partner for the first time, but she was so engrossed with her new love interest (and smartphone) that she made no effort to get to know him. I told my mother this was hurtful to me. I haven’t had a conversation with her in a year that hasn’t revolved around her dating life. She often calls me crying over weeklong flings. What’s a daughter to do? I’m the kid!

headline: DaBaby Blew Up. But Can He Settle Into Stardom?
abstract: The year’s inescapable, breakout rapper has just released “Kirk,” his third project in 12 months. Now comes the hard part.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Earlier this year, just as the North Carolina rapper DaBaby was hurtling into the hip-hop stratosphere with his hit single “Suge,” he was resting for a rare minute at home in Charlotte when he was awakened by a stream of calls and messages.

headline: Uffizi Director Rejects Vienna Job at Last Minute, Causing an Uproar
abstract: Just weeks before he was supposed to start at the Kunsthistorisches Museum, the German art historian Eike Schmidt said he wanted to remain in Florence.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Less than a month before Eike Schmidt was meant to leave his post as the director of the Uffizi Gallery in Florence to lead the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, the German art historian announced on Wednesday that he had changed his mind.

headline: She Was Raped by a Classmate. She Still Had to Go to School With Him.
abstract: The case jolted a working-class town, prompting a walkout by students and a debate over whether school officials are equipped to address sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: NIAGARA, N.Y. — She saw him when she got off the school bus, she recalled. She noticed him glaring at her from the doorway during theater class and track practice. Some days, he would walk so close to her in the corridors that their shoulders almost touched. She felt disgusted, she said, and then frightened.

headline: Robert De Niro and Ex-Aide Take Each Other to Court Over Office Behavior
abstract: Chase Robinson said the actor treated her as his “office wife,” while his company accused her of extravagant spending and binge-watching “Friends” while on the job.
lead_paragraph: Robert De Niro is in a legal battle with an ex-employee after his company filed a lawsuit accusing her of running up expenses and binge-watching Netflix during working hours. On Thursday, she fired back with her own accusations that the actor subjected her to “gratuitous unwanted physical contact” and saddled her with domestic tasks that male employees were not asked to do.

headline: Wisconsin Looks to Rise in a Big Ten Seeking Contenders
abstract: The Badgers started the 2018 season as a favorite. Then they stumbled in September and wound up going 8-5. This season is looking different — so far.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — When Michael Douglas starred in “The American President” in 1995, his character joked that his approval ratings drop “5 points when Wisconsin doesn’t make it to the Rose Bowl.”

headline: Trump Uses Health Care Announcement to Brand Democrats as Socialists
abstract: At the nation’s largest retirement community, the president announced an executive order that expands the benefits offered by private Medicare plans, contrasting it with “Medicare for all” plans.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — President Trump on Thursday delivered a campaign-style speech to an audience of elderly voters, pitching a new executive order that aims to improve private Medicare plans as the responsible alternative to the “Medicare for all” policies supported by some of his Democratic political opponents.

headline: Frieze London Shows the Art World Has Cottoned On to Weaving
abstract: A special “Woven” section at the fair celebrates an art form that was long undervalued as a result of sexism and snobbery.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Frieze London fair opened on Thursday, and art dealers from all over the world have gathered for what organizers are calling the most international edition in the fair’s history. In a huge white tent in Regent’s Park, more than 165 galleries have set up their stands, and on them, you can see art made from iron, found rocks, melted glass and old televisions, all fascinatingly inventive.

headline: They Risked All for America. Don’t Betray Them.
abstract: If President Trump’s hopes of withdrawing from war zones are realized, his government has a duty to protect the many foreigners who have helped U.S. forces there.
lead_paragraph: David Petraeus, a retired general and former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and more than 25 American generals and admirals recently wrote to President Trump supporting a robust refugee resettlement program — especially for people who have served American military and intelligence agencies in their native countries. But the Trump administration has decided to slash the overall number of refugees to be accepted in the coming year to 18,000 from 30,000, which increases pressure on already limited special programs for foreign friends who risk their lives to help America.

headline: In the Pancreas, Common Fungi May Drive Cancer
abstract: A new study found that certain fungi can settle in the pancreas, where they spur the growth of tumors.
lead_paragraph: By now, you’ve probably heard that your body is teeming with bacteria. Some 100 trillion of them live on your skin, in your mouth and in the coils of your intestines. Some protect against infections and help you digest food, while others can make you seriously ill.

headline: MGM Agrees to Pay Las Vegas Shooting Victims Up to $800 Million
abstract: The settlement would resolve claims that MGM was negligent in allowing the killer to stockpile weapons and ammunition at its Mandalay Bay hotel.
lead_paragraph: The company that owns the Las Vegas hotel where a gunman opened fire from his room onto a country music festival two years ago, killing 58 and wounding hundreds of others, agreed on Thursday to pay up to $800 million to settle lawsuits filed by victims.

headline: Boris Johnson, How Does It Feel?
abstract: Thanks to Brexit, for the first time in centuries Ireland has more power than its larger neighbor.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — When Boris Johnson visited Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, in Dublin last month as part of a last-minute scramble to reach some sort of Brexit deal, the two leaders began their day with a media briefing on the steps of one of Dublin’s grandest buildings. In the Edwardian Baroque style, it was built by the British authorities while the Irish were intensifying their struggle for independence. “Fortuitously,” the Heritage Ireland website snarkily notes, “the complex was completed in 1922 and was available immediately to be occupied by the new Irish Free State government.” Rarely has the word “fortuitously” elided so much.

headline: Trump Publicly Urges China to Investigate the Bidens
abstract: President Trump made a similar, but private, request of the president of Ukraine, an episode that has prompted an impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, already facing impeachment for pressuring Ukraine to investigate his political rivals, publicly called on China on Thursday to examine former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as well, an extraordinary request for help from a foreign power that could benefit him in next year’s election.

headline: Feeding the Soul With Art and the Artists With Persian Delights
abstract: Fatima and Eskandar Maleki host 150 collectors and creators at a time in their London home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Households with conspicuous art collections are not exactly rare in this global financial capital. But this one in Mayfair embraces a tradition of regular buffet dinners of Persian cuisine, a treat for artists and art lovers both.

headline: Chappelle
abstract: Comedy is changing — can Dave Chappelle keep up?
lead_paragraph: Comedy is changing. Dave Chappelle’s latest Netflix comedy special, “Sticks & Stones,” makes us wonder if he can keep up.

headline: ‘China Should Start an Investigation Into the Bidens,’ Trump Says in Extraordinary Request
abstract: President Trump’s public call on China for help that could benefit him in the 2020 election comes amid an impeachment inquiry into a similar request to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s public call on China for help that could benefit him in the 2020 election comes amid an impeachment inquiry into a similar request to Ukraine.

headline: The Authoritarian’s Worst Fear? A Book
abstract: Governments are spending a remarkable amount of resources attacking books — because their supposed limitations are beginning to look like ageless strengths.
lead_paragraph: Around the world, many authoritarian regimes — having largely corralled the internet — now have declared war on the written word, their oldest enemy. The received wisdom after the close of the Cold War was that physical books were outdated, soon to be swept aside in the digital age; and that the internet was instead the real threat to governments seeking to repress provocative thinking. A generation later, the opposite may be true.

headline: ‘I Have to Get That’: How Henry Chalfant Became a Graffiti Ambassador
abstract: The artist’s photographs, a major act of urban historical preservation, are on view at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.
lead_paragraph: When Henry Chalfant arrived in New York City from suburban Pittsburgh in 1973, as an aspiring sculptor, he found a place teetering on the verge of bankruptcy. This was “Ford to City: Drop Dead” New York. But amid the turmoil a new form of art making was taking shape — one that took up space where it could, which was mostly everywhere.

headline: You’re a Movie Star. Congrats, Here’s Your Space Movie.
abstract: A major film career isn’t complete without one. This year it was Brad Pitt and Natalie Portman’s turns. They’re part of a long Hollywood tradition. Here’s a look back.
lead_paragraph: That vast expanse. The glorious wonders of the universe. And Brad Pitt or Natalie Portman to take us there.

headline: Beyoncé’s Father, Mathew Knowles, on His Breast Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Mr. Knowles discovered he had breast cancer in July, and had a mastectomy that month.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Knowles, the father and former manager of Beyoncé and Solange, revealed this week that he received treatment for breast cancer this year, becoming one of the rare men to face the disease.

headline: Japan Wants to Prove Win Over Ireland Was No Fluke
abstract: Japan’s 19-12 victory over Ireland at the Rugby World Cup has people asking: How far can the Brave Blossoms go?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s stunning 19-12 victory last week over Ireland, one of the favorites to win the Rugby World Cup, made experts take notice and put a provocative question into circulation here: The upstart Brave Blossoms couldn’t actually win the tournament, could they?

headline: Todd McFarlane Talks Spawn Ahead of the Comic’s Milestone Issue 301
abstract: Spawn will soon become the longest-running creator-owned comic book series. The creator, Mr. McFarlane, is already thinking about Issue No. 600.
lead_paragraph: When the comic book writer and artist Todd McFarlane introduced readers to Spawn in 1992, he had little idea that he and the character would still be at it 27 years later. That longevity has come with an added perk: On Wednesday, Oct. 9, Spawn No. 301 will arrive in comic book stores and make Spawn the longest-running creator-owned comic book series.

headline: Mets Fire Mickey Callaway After Two Seasons as Manager
abstract: The team had a combined record of 163-161 over Callaway’s two seasons in charge and failed to reach the postseason.
lead_paragraph: After the Mets won the final game of their season with a walk-off home run in extra innings Sunday, Manager Mickey Callaway quickly transitioned to lamenting the fact that his team would again have to watch the playoffs instead of competing in them.

headline: Drag Is Exploding. What Does It Cost to Look Like Royalty?
abstract: An illustrated look at what two iconic New York performers spend on their acts.
lead_paragraph: Julia Rothman is an illustrator. Shaina Feinberg is a writer and filmmaker. They both live in Brooklyn.

headline: Influencers Face Criticism for Saudi Arabia Travel #Ads
abstract: The kingdom has invited popular internet personalities to visit, all expenses paid, in an effort to rehabilitate its global image.
lead_paragraph: A handful of popular Instagram influencers are facing backlash online after taking part in a sponsored ad campaign for Saudi Arabia.

headline: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Can Offend. Now Try Translating It Into Spanish.
abstract: Minefields abound when translating outdated, sometimes derogatory dialect for the Metropolitan Opera’s seatback titles.
lead_paragraph: “Happy dust,” the powdery white drug at the center of George Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess,” is rendered in Spanish as “perico,” and in German as “Schnee” — both maintaining the slanginess of the original. But “buckra,” a derogatory word for white men, becomes the more straightforward “blanco” and “die Weissen.”

headline: ‘In the Tall Grass’ Review: In the Heartland, a Field of Screams
abstract: Based on a novella by Stephen King and Joe Hill, this Netflix adaptation turns rural Kansas into an inescapable nightmare.
lead_paragraph: Originally published in two parts in Esquire, the novella “In the Tall Grass,” by Stephen King and his son Joe Hill, turns the uniform expanse of rural Kansas into a field that stretches to the horizon in every direction. The field itself has a malevolent presence, like the sentient vines in Scott Smith’s novel “The Ruins,” but just the idea of getting trapped in a sea of green, with the sticky heat and the buzzing flies and the six-foot-tall cuts of grass, is suffocating enough for a short-form shocker.

headline: How Trump Just Made Your Dinner More Expensive
abstract: A 15-year fight over airplane subsidies is going to raise the cost of Parmesan cheese, French wine and Scotch whisky.
lead_paragraph: American shoppers may not have paid close attention to a 15-year controversy involving generous subsidies that the European Union provided Airbus, its largest aircraft manufacturer.

headline: Bernie Sanders Will Participate in Next Debate, His Campaign Says
abstract: The Vermont senator’s wife said he is in good spirits and should be able to return home by the end of this coming weekend.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, recovering in a Las Vegas hospital from a procedure to treat a clogged artery, should be able to return home by the end of this weekend and will participate in the next Democratic debate, his wife, Jane Sanders, said Thursday.

headline: Boris Johnson’s Brexit Plan Hits a Wall in Brussels
abstract: In Parliament, the British prime minister’s plan won support from some who had voted against Theresa May’s deal. But it was greeted frostily by European Union diplomats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Thursday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson appeared to have accomplished what his long-suffering predecessor, Theresa May, never could. He rallied support among lawmakers for a plan to extricate Britain from the European Union and won praise from some of the same legislators who had tormented Mrs. May.

headline: Atlantic City Mayor Stole $87,000 From Youth Basketball Program
abstract: The mayor pleaded guilty and resigned. It’s the latest chapter in a long history of criminal behavior among the city’s top public officials.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Atlantic City had already been caught in an unflattering moment — surveillance cameras had recorded a late-night fistfight he was involved in outside a casino last November.

headline: ‘Mike’s Candyshop’: Behind the Overdose Death of HQ Trivia’s Colin Kroll
abstract: Six men were charged with running a cocaine-and-heroin delivery operation that was linked to the tech executive’s death in December.
lead_paragraph: When police officers entered Colin Kroll’s apartment in SoHo last December, they found the 34-year-old tech entrepreneur known for grinding out 100-hour work weeks, facedown on his bed. Nearby were the telltale signs of drug use: empty vials, glassine envelopes and a powdery mixture.

headline: ‘Batwoman’ and ‘Nancy Drew’ Reinvent Two Pop-Culture Heroines
abstract: CW adds a comic-book crime fighter and an iconic mystery-novel detective to its deep roster of female protagonists.
lead_paragraph: The fall broadcast-network premieres wrap up with a pair of dramas featuring pop-culture heroines with some years on them: Batwoman dates to 1956 and Nancy Drew to 1930. These thoroughly updated versions (“Batwoman” premieres Sunday, “Nancy Drew” Wednesday) continue a CW trend toward female protagonists — about 80 percent of the dramas it’s introduced the last two years have centered on women. But it’s also lost “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” and “Jane the Virgin,” so maybe the more significant trend is toward well-known franchises.

headline: Texts From Top Diplomat Described ‘Crazy’ Plan to Keep Aid From Ukraine
abstract: A text exchange given to Congress as impeachment investigators questioned their first witness shows an internal dispute over whether the president was seeking a quid pro quo from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top American diplomat in Ukraine repeatedly raised concerns with colleagues about the White House’s decision to withhold $391 million in security aid from Ukraine, describing it as a “crazy” plan to withhold security assistance “for help with a political campaign,” according to texts released Thursday as part of the impeachment inquiry into President Trump.

headline: Cory Booker Wants to Talk About Child Poverty
abstract: Mr. Booker’s presidential campaign rolled out a broad policy proposal that would offer a $300 monthly cash allowance to most families with young children.
lead_paragraph: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey rolled out a broad set of policy proposals on Thursday that seek to significantly reduce child poverty, including by offering a $300 monthly cash allowance to most families with young children.

headline: Why Lifesaving Drugs May Be Missing on Your Next Flight
abstract: Citing chronic shortages, airlines have received exemptions from regulations requiring that flights carry five drugs on board.
lead_paragraph: The flight was cruising over the Atlantic, bound for Tel Aviv, when Dr. Mikhail Varshavski heard the question over the intercom: “Is there a medical professional on board?”

headline: He Opposed Using Transgender Clients’ Pronouns. It Became a Legal Battle.
abstract: A British agency employee said a policy on pronouns went against his religious beliefs. A tribunal found his stance to be “incompatible with human dignity.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British government agency did not discriminate against an employee who refused to use transgender clients’ pronouns because he felt it violated his Christian beliefs, an employment tribunal has ruled.

headline: ‘Pain and Glory’ Review: Almodóvar’s Dazzling Art of Self-Creation
abstract: Antonio Banderas plays a filmmaker in crisis in Pedro Almodóvar’s movie about loss, love, imagination and memory.
lead_paragraph: Every so often in Pedro Almodóvar’s sublime “Pain and Glory,” Salvador Mallo (Antonio Banderas) closes his eyes and drifts away. A celebrated Spanish filmmaker, Salvador has lost his bearings. He’s gravely depressed, and his body seems to have permanently surrendered to his maladies, to his bad back, migraines, asthma and fits of terrifying, mysterious choking. When a friend offers him some heroin to smoke, Salvador readily lights up and disappears. His nagging pains suddenly give way to images from his childhood, idylls that brighten the screen like beacons in a fog.

headline: Flush With Cash, Pete Buttigieg Bets His Campaign on a Breakthrough in Iowa
abstract: The Midwest mayor is making an appeal to rural voters and hoping a massive ground game delivers a top-tier caucus finish.
lead_paragraph: CLINTON, Iowa — On the day House Democrats opened an impeachment inquiry of President Trump last week, Pete Buttigieg was being grilled by Iowa voters on other subjects: how to loosen the grip of the rich on government, how to restore science to policymaking, how to reduce child poverty.

headline: ‘Joker’ Review: Are You Kidding Me?
abstract: Todd Phillips’s supervillain origin story starring Joaquin Phoenix is stirring up a fierce debate, but it’s not interesting enough to argue about.
lead_paragraph: Since its debut a few weeks ago at the Venice Film Festival, where it won the top prize, Todd Phillips’s “Joker” has stirred up quite a tempest. Hands have been wrung about the movie’s supposed potential to inspire acts of real-life violence, and criticism of its brutal nihilism has been met with a counter-backlash, including from Phillips himself, who has been sounding off about the “far left” and “woke culture” and other threats to the ability of a murderous clown to make money unmolested. Meanwhile, the usual armies of skeptics and fans have squared off with ready-made accusations of bad faith, hypersensitivity and quasi-fascist groupthink.

headline: CNN Rejects 2 Trump Campaign Ads, Citing Inaccuracies
abstract: The network declined to run a pair of 30-second ads that express the president’s view of the impeachment inquiry, calling them “demonstrably false.”
lead_paragraph: The 2020 campaign ad wars have begun.

headline: Can ‘The Irishman’ Help Netflix Rule the Best-Picture Race?
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s new crime epic is one of three Netflix titles that have a strong shot at making the best-picture race.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood traditionalists blanched this year when the streaming juggernaut Netflix managed to crack the Oscars’ best-picture race.

headline: A ‘Chilling Message’: Trump Critics See a Deeper Agenda in California Feud
abstract: From Pennsylvania to New Mexico, the collateral damage to other states is mounting in President Trump's regulatory and environmental feud with California.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s political feud with California has spread collateral damage across more than a dozen other states, which have seen their regulatory authority curtailed and their autonomy threatened by a Trump administration intent on weakening the environmental statutes of the country’s most populous state.

headline: Vivek Ranadive Hopes for Kings 3.0
abstract: The team owner is a key figure in bringing the N.B.A. to India and reshaping Sacramento’s downtown. Does all that matter if the Kings continue to miss the playoffs?
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Vivek Ranadive, the controlling owner of the Sacramento Kings, is a true believer.

headline: High Medical Bills Are at Center of Hospital Group’s Trial
abstract: California has accused Sutter Health, the big hospital system, of abusing its market power to charge higher prices.
lead_paragraph: Updated on Oct. 10

headline: How a Fringe Theory About Ukraine Took Root in the White House
abstract: A false tale about a cybersecurity firm called CrowdStrike and a Democratic conspiracy to undermine the 2016 election has formed the background of President Trump’s impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: In an April 2017 interview with The Associated Press, President Trump suddenly began talking about the hack of the Democratic National Committee a year earlier, complaining that the F.B.I. had not physically examined the compromised server.

headline: Wait — Do You Live for Petty Drama?
abstract: And, is there anything else to live for?
lead_paragraph: [This is the weekly Styles newsletter. You can sign up for “Wait —” right here.]

headline: ‘Lucy in the Sky’ Review: Bad Romance, Astronaut Edition
abstract: A story that captured the public imagination (it’s the one with the diapers) makes for a messy movie.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to know why anyone thought “Lucy in the Sky,” a drama about an astronaut’s fall, would make a good movie. Was it the appeal of outer space, with its beauties, mysteries and infinite possibilities? Or was it the faintly exotic if rather basic romance that blows up so many lives? Was it the diapers?

headline: Barr Pushes Facebook for Access to WhatsApp Messages
abstract: The Justice Department has long sought access to encrypted messages, alarming privacy experts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has renewed its fight for access to encrypted communications, arguing that it is a vital crime-fighting tool even as technology companies and advocates have countered that it will threaten individual privacy.

headline: The Truth About Refugees
abstract: The Women’s Refugee Commission, on the Trump administration’s “cruelty.” Also: Restorative justice for juveniles; the allure of autumn; old-fashioned choices.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Caesar & Cleopatra,’ Dressed Down Yet Wised Up
abstract: George Bernard Shaw gets sensitively streamlined in a briskly entertaining production with winning performers at its center.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Cleopatra seems every inch an ordinary teenager. In a ponytail and sneakers, her white pants rolled up below her knees, she’s hiding from Caesar’s approaching army. A stranger appears, and she urges him to save himself.

headline: Let’s Fill Our Cities With Taller, Wooden Buildings
abstract: Trees are some of our best allies in solving the climate crisis.
lead_paragraph: Across North America, trees stand ready to help us solve the climate crisis. Trees remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and store it in their wood. One way to respond to a challenge from the United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, to seek “bold action and much greater ambition” on climate change is to protect forests from development, improve forest management and use sustainably harvested wood to build tall buildings. This will allow us to pump carbon from the atmosphere and store it both in forests and in cities. It will also support rural economies, improve wildlife habitat and create more affordable housing.

headline: Anna Sui, Fashion’s Favorite Daughter, Gets Her Day in the Sun
abstract: With a museum retrospective that looks back at her four decades in fashion, the designer recalls the early influences in her storied career.
lead_paragraph: Like some kind of industrious magpie, the designer Anna Sui has spent decades assiduously gathering up shiny oddments from the pop culture landscape and shaping them into a singular career in fashion design. Her deeply researched collections — 84 of them to date — exploit a welter of tweaked archetypes (surfer meets Kawai schoolgirl) and the giddy mash-ups of incongruous archetypes (pirate encounters pre-Raphaelite) that are her specialty.
