headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: School is back in session, which for some people means packing lunchboxes and anguishing over outfits in the morning dark, and for other people means muttering about the bus traffic snarling Main Street on the way to the gym. For us, though, back-to-school time is just one more reason to celebrate good books. This week, that includes books about school: Robert Pondiscio’s “How the Other Half Learns,” about a year in the life of the impressive but polarizing charter school network Success Academy, and Paul Tough’s “The Years That Matter Most,” looking at college through the lens of a class system that reinforces its own rigid hierarchy. There’s also Samantha Power’s memoir, “The Education of an Idealist,” which is less about school than about Power’s on-the-job evolution as President Obama’s ambassador to the United Nations. Two books this week tackle prejudice head-on — Ibram X. Kendi’s “How to Be an Antiracist” and Bari Weiss’s “How to Fight Anti-Semitism” — while Corey Robin’s “The Enigma of Clarence Thomas” upends some conventional wisdom about the Supreme Court justice. Finally, in fiction, we recommend new novels from some old favorites: Ann Patchett, Jacqueline Woodson and the British master Andrew Miller. Don’t think of them as required reading — nobody likes a syllabus — but maybe sneak one of them inside your calculus textbook and enjoy.

lead_paragraph: Larry Willis, a prolific pianist who nimbly traversed genres over a five-decade career, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 76.

headline: Here Comes the Trump Slump
abstract: And he has only himself to blame.
lead_paragraph: When he isn’t raving about how the deep state is conspiring against him, Donald Trump loves to boast about the economy, claiming to have achieved unprecedented things. As it happens, none of his claims are true. While both G.D.P. and employment have registered solid growth, the Trump economy simply seems to have continued a long expansion that began under Barack Obama. In fact, someone who looked only at the past 10 years of data would never guess that an election had taken place.

headline: Get Your Digital Accounts Ready In Case of Death
abstract: In case of death: how to set up a list of important digital account info for simple and secure information sharing with family members and trusted friends
lead_paragraph: On March 7, 2019, Myrna M. DeLeon passed away, days before her 65th birthday. “Her death was completely unexpected,” said her daughter and my brother-in-law’s wife, Casey. In the emotional aftermath for the family, one thing made the grieving process less stressful: Myrna’s “in case of death” preparations. She had filed important documents in a safe and kept a categorized “little black book of information.”

headline: An Artist Who Pushes the Borders of His Studio Into the Streets
abstract: Robin Rhode uses city walls as his canvas, challenging the idea of creation as a solitary, private act.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, the South African-born artist Robin Rhode, whose interdisciplinary practice blends drawing, performance and photography, converted a 19th-century alcohol distillery in Berlin into a vast 16,000-square-foot work space, split across two floors. Still, he continues to make much of his work outside its bounds. While he produces most of his preparatory drawings in Berlin, his primary site of creation has remained in Westbury, a suburb of Johannesburg. There, using the plastered concrete wall of a vacant building as his canvas, he makes fleeting paintings (a shoal of small geometric shapes for the 2012 series “School of Fish,” a spiral staircase for the 2017 work “Principle of Hope”), and invites a performer wearing a mask — oftentimes the dancer Kevin Narain, a collaborator of eight years — to interact with the work, contorting his body to echo its shapes. He captures the dancer’s actions in a sequence of photographs and then scrubs the wall clean in less than 24 hours (although he leaves the vacant building as he found it, he also gives its owner a bottle of whiskey whenever he’s in town). For Rhode, the ephemerality of the movements and the reactionary nature of graffiti art underline the overlooked poverty and injustice permeating urban slums in cities; often he will work with more than a dozen local collaborators on a single piece. “My community are my studio assistants,” he says.

headline: Brain Stimulation Shows Promise in Treating Severe Depression
abstract: Years ago, more than two dozen patients received an electrical implant to counter their depression. They’re still feeling better, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, doctors have been using brain-stimulating implants to treat severe depression in people who do not benefit from medication, talk therapy or electroshock sessions. The treatment is controversial — any psychosurgery is, given its checkered history — and the results have been mixed. Two major trials testing stimulating implant for depression were halted because of disappointing results, and the approach is not approved by federal health regulators.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘The Blacklist’ and ‘Raising Dion’
abstract: “The Blacklist” returns for a seventh season on NBC. And a series about a young superhero debuts on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: THE BLACKLIST 8 p.m. on NBC. If you want to end your TV show’s season on a cliffhanger, having the main character get abducted isn’t a bad way to do it. That’s what happened at the end of the previous season of this popular thriller. The show stars James Spader as a criminal mastermind who goes by the name Raymond Reddington and who begins working with the F.B.I. to help them bag high-profile lawbreakers. Season 6 concluded with a former K.G.B. agent (played by Laila Robins) plunging a syringe into Reddington, watching as her associates put him into the back of a van and made off with one of Reddington’s characteristic fedoras for good measure. The seventh season kicks off Friday, and picks up from there. “There will be an episode of ‘The Blacklist’ that is just fun and another that is very intense and then another that is rather ruthless and brutal,” Spader told The New York Times last year. “I still love the element of surprise, even for myself.”

headline: Under Pressure, New Zealand Ends a Refugee Policy Branded Racist
abstract: The revoking of restrictions on Middle Eastern and African refugees lifted a political millstone from around Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern’s neck.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — After months of growing pressure, the government of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand abolished on Friday a policy restricting refugees from Middle Eastern and African countries, a curb imposed by the previous government that refugee advocates called discriminatory and racist.

headline: Word + Quiz: surfeit
abstract: This word has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Hong Kong Banned Masks at Protests. Masked Crowds Protested the Ban.
abstract: Thousands protested, many wearing masks, as the clock ticked toward the ban taking effect, and clashes broke out around the city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s embattled leader invoked emergency powers on Friday to ban face masks, deploying a rarely used law that triggered another wave of violent protests and threatened to erode confidence in a city that depends heavily on international business and tourism.

headline: Trump Just Blew the Whistle on Himself, Seth Meyers Says
abstract: “Trump’s like a mobster who instead of throwing a body in the trunk, throws it in the passenger seat so he can use the car pool lane,” Meyers said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Pet Pampering
abstract: Do you regard your pets as family members?
lead_paragraph: Do you have any pets? Do you like to pamper them? Perhaps you buy them special treats or toys? Maybe you take them to a salon once in a while? Or perhaps you let them ride in their own limousine? What is the most extravagant thing you have ever done for a pet?

headline: How a Midseason Revelation Revived James Paxton’s Season
abstract: Paxton, the Yankees’ starter for their postseason opener on Friday, was struggling until the team’s brain trust delivered a message: Stop using your fastball so much.
lead_paragraph: It was late July when James Paxton was nearing his breaking point — as was the Yankees hierarchy. The towering left-hander, acquired from the Seattle Mariners last off-season, was supposed to be one of the starting rotation’s guardians, blessed with an oversize windup and a high-90s fastball that could overwhelm even elite hitters.

headline: Aaron Boone: The Savage in the Yankees’ Dugout
abstract: In his second year as the team’s manager, Boone has learned from his missteps and complemented his upbeat demeanor with bursts of intensity.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Boone, the Yankees manager, can’t escape his now-infamous tirade at an umpire. It follows him everywhere, even though he isn’t proud of some of the language that on-field microphones caught him using during that July 18 game. His parents wear T-shirts printed with “Savages in the Box,” the phrase he repeatedly yelled. His players and fans do, too. The name plates in the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium now include the words “October Savages.”

headline: This Week’s News Quiz: Harvard, India, Alberto Salazar
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: BP Chief Executive Bob Dudley Is to Retire
abstract: Mr. Dudley was credited with steadying the oil company after a deadly blowout in the Gulf of Mexico. Bernard Looney will replace him in February.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Bob Dudley, the chief executive of BP, will retire in February after nearly a decade in the job, the oil company announced Friday. The company’s chairman, Helge Lund, said in a statement that the move came at a “logical time for a change,” with BP charting its course through a global “energy transition.”

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘What Does Having a Boyfriend Have to Do With Sleep?’
abstract: In this lesson, students will discover Owen Dennis Riley, 17, who has half a million followers on YouTube. Why are young people tuning into his videos to help them go to sleep? Are these videos a fad or part of a growing cultural trend?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What Does Having a Boyfriend Have to Do With Sleep?”

headline: Hiring Slowed in September as Unemployment Rate Fell to a 50-Year Low
abstract: Job growth was steady last month. The economy  lost some momentum, though, as the trade war hurt manufacturing and global growth cooled.
lead_paragraph: The cavalcade of payroll gains continued for the 108th month in September, pushing down the jobless rate to a half-century low and countering anxieties that had been piqued by slowing global growth, declining factory orders and a jittery stock market.

headline: How a Teen Rapper With Braces Took Over the Streaming World
abstract: He was only 16 when an out-of-the-blue tweet brought him to Los Angeles to record what would become his breakthrough hit, “Ransom.” In our latest Diary of a Song video, see how the internet stars aligned to make Lil Tecca a new king of streaming.
lead_paragraph: He was only 16 when an out-of-the-blue tweet brought him to Los Angeles to record what would become his breakthrough hit, “Ransom.” In our latest Diary of a Song video, see how the internet stars aligned to make Lil Tecca a new king of streaming.

headline: The Dictator’s Playbook: How Sisi Stifled Dissent in Egypt
abstract: Rare protests broke out against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, where demonstrations are effectively banned and forced disappearances are common. Our video takes a look at the violent crackdown that followed.
lead_paragraph: Rare protests broke out against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, where demonstrations are effectively banned and forced disappearances are common. Our video takes a look at the violent crackdown that followed.

headline: Big Sins and Small Atonements: Marilyn Stasio’s Crime Column
abstract: A guilt-ridden female sheriff polices a Southern town while a bad-boy bruiser ventures into Minnesota’s academia. And two sleuths tussle over a London corpse.
lead_paragraph: Just listen to this: “The days march by and extraordinary things happen all around us. Small miracles, haphazard events, bursts of joy, revelations. … We hunker down in our daily lives, in the shelter of routines and assumptions. We miss so much.” That gorgeous authorial voice belongs to James Sallis, who seizes on such moments in SARAH JANE (Soho Crime, $23.95) and shows us what makes them precious in the eyes of his title character, Sarah Jane Pullman. She’s the daughter of a chicken farmer in Selmer, a small town on the border between Alabama and Tennessee, and the subject of this spellbinding character study.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Revisiting Emma Donoghue’s ‘Room’
abstract: In Emma Donoghue’s 2010 novel, 5-year-old Jack is held captive in a small room with his mother. Aimee Bender reviewed it.
lead_paragraph: Megan O’Grady reviews Emma Donoghue’s latest novel, “Akin,” in this week’s issue. In 2010, Aimee Bender wrote for the Book Review about “Room,” Donoghue’s novel about a 5-year-old held captive in a small room with his mother.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Big Fella’ and ‘Identity’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE BIG FELLA: Babe Ruth and the World He Created, by Jane Leavy. (Harper Perennial, $18.99.) This detail-packed biography of the baseball legend recounts his eventful life and tracks the machinations behind his rise to an unprecedented kind of celebrity in the United States. Our reviewer, John Swansburg, said Leavy “captures Ruth’s outsize influence on American sport and culture.”

headline: Regeneration: A Miracle, Against the Odds
abstract: Months after I’d shaved my head for cancer treatment, my old hair dropped out of the sky.
lead_paragraph: “What should I be for Halloween when I’m bald?” I asked my 7-year-old, casually tossing a long, gray-streaked handful of my hair to the ground. Sitting across from me under the trees, my daughter took videos with my phone while I clipped and shaved and attempted silly banter.

headline: How Should We Understand Clarence Thomas?
abstract: Two new books, Corey Robin’s “The Enigma of Clarence Thomas” and Myron Magnet’s “Clarence Thomas and the Lost Constitution,” offer vastly different interpretations of the Supreme Court’s only black justice.
lead_paragraph: THE ENIGMA OF CLARENCE THOMASBy Corey RobinCLARENCE THOMAS AND THE LOST CONSTITUTIONBy Myron Magnet

headline: Sasheer Zamata Finds Humor at the A.C.L.U.
abstract: The former “S.N.L.” comedian is a volunteer spokeswoman for women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: Sasheer Zamata, the actress, stand-up comedian and former “Saturday Night Live” player, doesn’t think of herself as a political comedian. “I talk about my life, and being a woman, and being a black woman in America,” she said.

headline: Can We Trust Economists?
abstract: Binyamin Appelbaum’s “The Economists’ Hour” and Janek Wasserman’s “The Marginal Revolutionaries” examine the impact of economic ideas on modern politics.
lead_paragraph: THE ECONOMISTS’ HOURFalse Prophets, Free Markets, and the Fracture of SocietyBy Binyamin AppelbaumTHE MARGINAL REVOLUTIONARIESHow Austrian Economists Fought the War of IdeasBy Janek Wasserman

headline: Lil Tecca’s Parents Let Him Pursue Rap. Now He’s a Star (With Braces).
abstract: He was only 16 when an out-of-the-blue tweet led to the recording session that yielded his breakthrough hit, “Ransom.” See how the internet stars aligned to make Lil Tecca a new king of streaming.
lead_paragraph: Lil Tecca was 16, unsigned and living with his parents on Long Island when he spotted the Twitter post that changed his life.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Flu, Dogs and Brain Boosters
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: The Secret Jailhouse Garden of Rikers Island
abstract: When the notorious New York penal colony closes, few will miss it. But an innovative sanctuary for prisoners will also be lost.
lead_paragraph: Set incongruously in the middle of Rikers Island’s post-apocalyptic landscape of low-slung jail blocks and razor wire is a lush garden, teeming with birds and butterflies, that seems to have been teleported down from some happier planet.

headline: California Tells the N.C.A.A. to Share, and It Pitches a Fit
abstract: The state’s new law, which lets college athletes profit from endorsements, sends the defenders of a failed model of amateurism to the ramparts.
lead_paragraph: The pooh-bahs who run college sports know little shame.

headline: How Nico Tortorella of the Television Series ‘Younger’ Spends Sundays
abstract: The actor and writer (who identifies as nonbinary and uses “they”) can often be found in upstate New York, raiding the farmer’s market, relaxing in the sauna and listening to country music.
lead_paragraph: Since Nico Tortorella landed the role of Josh on TV Land’s “Younger” in 2015, they’ve been juggling creative projects while using the platform to be vocal about sex, sexuality and LGBTQ+ advocacy. Last year, Tortortella released a collection of poetry, entitled “All of It Is You,” just weeks before marrying their longtime partner, the fitness instructor Bethany Meyers.

headline: Egypt’s Harsh Crackdown Quashes Protest Movement
abstract: One of the largest waves of arrests in decades has overcrowded Egyptian jails and put President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi back in control. For now.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A group of teenagers arrested on their way to buy new school clothes. An illiterate shoeshiner picked up from the street. Eight people stopped while they were eating from a street food cart. And a 28-year-old financial auditor, who was walking to his car after dinner when police officers ordered him to stop.

headline: For Churches, a Temptation to Sell
abstract: Religious leaders ponder whether selling their buildings to developers is really the best way to protect their congregations.
lead_paragraph: The sight of old spires squeezed between new towering high-rises suggests the ability of churches and other houses of worship to hang on through block-altering building booms.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Lawsuits Raise Fears Over Baby Powder
abstract: Thousands of people who trusted Johnson’s Baby Powder for decades are suing the company after developing cancer. Our reporters investigate their allegations.
lead_paragraph: You’d recognize that distinctive fragrance anywhere. It’s the smell of innocence. Johnson & Johnson has touted its signature baby powder as gentle enough for a baby’s bottom for more than a century. And though its talcum powder represents only a fraction of the pharmaceutical and cosmetic giant’s modern business, it’s been a cornerstone of the company’s reputation.

headline: Medicare Shopping Season Is Here
abstract: Every fall, the 60 million Americans who use the health plan can compare options and save money. Here’s what to consider.
lead_paragraph: If you’re enrolled in Medicare but worry about the cost of health care, your chance to do something about it is here.

headline: After the Niger Ambush, I Trusted the Army to Find Answers. Instead, I Was Punished.
abstract: Four of my men were killed in Niger in 2017. I thought the Army would make some institutional changes. That didn't happen.
lead_paragraph: It was the best week ever. It was the worst week ever. I welcomed new life, and saw how quickly life can be taken.

headline: ‘We Were Wiped Out’: New Yorkers Preyed on Chicago Cabbies
abstract: After seizing control of the market, New Yorkers used tactics that helped leave the taxi industry in tatters and hundreds of immigrant drivers on the edge of ruin.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2006, Chicago held an auction to sell taxi medallions, the permits that let people own and operate cabs. Hundreds of bids poured in, including some offering to pay much more than expected. The city raised millions of dollars. Officials declared the sale a success.

headline: 5 Stops on Germany’s Whiskey Trail
abstract: Germany may be known for its beer, but it is also home to some 250 whiskey producers, almost twice as many as in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Among drinks enthusiasts, Germany is famous for producing some of the world’s best beers. And a few of the country’s valleys have attained cult status among wine lovers — in particular, Mosel, Rheingau and the Ahr. German schnapps are pretty much a known quantity, while the country’s herbal bitters have an even broader recognition, or at least the standout brand Jägermeister does.

headline: How Does It Feel to Be Impeached? These Mayors Can Tell You All About It.
abstract: “All I was trying to do was make things better, or as Trump would say, make America great again,” said a mayor who was accused of improperly selling a police cruiser to settle a city debt.
lead_paragraph: Not many Americans can tell you what it feels like to be impeached, but Dana Williamson knows. And along with the rest of the country, Mr. Williamson, a former mayor of Raceland, Ky., has had impeachment on his mind a lot recently.

headline: Was WeWork Ever Going to Work?
abstract: Tech investors are often the last to see what’s so problematic about the disrupters.
lead_paragraph: Imagine for a moment that Adam Neumann, the co-founder of WeWork and until several days ago its chief executive, came to you looking for a job. He is barefoot (he has been photographed walking around Manhattan this way), he talks about his ambition to live forever, to lead the free world and to “solve the problem” of “150 million orphans” through the growth of a desk-rental company seeking to “to elevate the world’s consciousness.”

headline: Facebook, ‘Joker,’ Rick Perry: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Did Vandals Steal Gandhi’s Ashes From an Indian Memorial?
abstract: Vandals attacked a Gandhi memorial and may have stolen some of his ashes. They also scrawled “traitor” on his picture, placing suspicion on Hindu nationalists.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — He is the revered father of Indian independence, and it was what would have been his 150th birthday. And yet, on Wednesday, vandals attacked a memorial to Mohandas K. Gandhi, painted “traitor” in lurid green across his picture, and may have stolen some of his ashes.

headline: What My Father Taught Me About Race
abstract: He set out to show that regardless of the barriers, he could fulfill his God-given potential. Struggle by struggle, he did.
lead_paragraph: My father, Emmett Rice, was drafted into military service at the height of World War II and spent four and a half years in uniform, first as an enlisted man and ultimately as an officer with the rank of captain. Called up by the Army Air Force, he was sent to a two-part officer training program, which began in Miami and was completed at Harvard Business School — where he learned “statistical control” and “quantitative management,” a specialized form of accounting in an unusual program designed to build on his business background.

headline: On Again, Off Again, and With a Nudge, Now On Forever
abstract: For Jessica Muscio and Doug Davis, the journey down the aisle was nine years in the making. Along the way came children, a house, and a new perspective about commitment.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Muscio and Doug Davis took a less traditional route to marriage.

headline: Free Speech Is Killing Us
abstract: Noxious language online is causing real-world violence. What can we do about it?
lead_paragraph: There has never been a bright line between word and deed. Yet for years, the founders of Facebook and Twitter and 4chan and Reddit — along with the consumers obsessed with these products, and the investors who stood to profit from them — tried to pretend that the noxious speech prevalent on those platforms wouldn’t metastasize into physical violence. In the early years of this decade, back when people associated social media with Barack Obama or the Arab Spring, Twitter executives referred to their company as “the free-speech wing of the free-speech party.” Sticks and stones and assault rifles could hurt us, but the internet was surely only a force for progress.

headline: Donald Trump’s Invitation to the World
abstract: Soliciting foreign interference sets a precedent. Here’s what that looks like.
lead_paragraph: Nations of the world, take heed.

headline: Whistle-Blower? A Half-Century Ago in N.Y.C., It Was Serpico
abstract: Friday: The current scenario in Washington is “so parallel to my situation,” said Frank Serpico, who in the 1970s spoke up about widespread corruption in the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: When #MeToo Went on Trial
abstract: One year ago, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford shared her story. We look at how her testimony came to embody a culture at a crossroads — and at what’s changed since then.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Rory Stewart, U.K. Politician, Will Run for Mayor of London
abstract: Mr. Stewart, one of 21 insurgent lawmakers cut loose by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, said he was quitting the Conservative Party to campaign as an independent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three months ago, Rory Stewart was the darling of the pro-compromise wing of the Conservative Party, or at least what was left of it, traveling Britain on a quixotic mission to take over the party and end its enchantment with a cliff-edge split from Europe.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Will the Jobs Report Lift the Gloom From the Economy?
abstract: Analysts expect employers to have created 147,000 jobs last month. If that estimate comes true, it’d be a bright spot in a week full of bad economic news.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Jeff Koons Inaugurates His Tulip Sculpture in Paris. Finally.
abstract: The colorful installation pays homage to the victims of terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — They took three years to blossom, but Jeff Koons’s tulips are finally in full bloom.

headline: Do Films Like ‘Joker’ Endorse (or Even Promote) Violence?
abstract: Do movies that offer a sympathetic portrayal of violent criminals have the potential to promote violent acts in real life?
lead_paragraph: In creating the new film “Joker,” Warner Bros. set out to make a boundary-pushing production. The early reaction has included critical praise, but also deep unease about the film’s violence and message.

headline: Owner of Firm Tied to Hunter Biden Will Be Subject of Ukraine Prosecutor’s Review
abstract: The development came amid an impeachment inquiry against President Trump linked to a request that Ukraine investigate the former vice president and his son.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s top prosecutor said on Friday he would audit several important cases previously handled by his predecessors, including a criminal case involving the owner of a natural gas company that employed a son of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: The Week in Arts: ‘Madam Secretary’ Returns; a Master Takes On Macbeth
abstract: Téa Leoni is president in her series’ final season; and the Shakespeare veteran Corey Stoll tackles the Scottish king.
lead_paragraph: Oct. 10-Dec. 15, classicstage.org.

headline: Trump Is in Trouble
abstract: For now, he’s losing the battle for public opinion.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Average Weekly Allowance? It’s $30, a New Survey Finds
abstract: The survey also found that children are putting little aside for savings and instead mostly spending it on things like outings with friends or digital devices.
lead_paragraph: If you think an allowance is a dollar bill or two handed to your child each week, think again.

headline: A Duplex at a Candela-Designed Building Closes for $53 Million
abstract: The Upper East Side took the spotlight in September with three of New York City’s largest closings — albeit at markdown prices.
lead_paragraph: The property spotlight was on the Upper East Side in September, where three of New York City’s largest closings took place, albeit at markdown prices.

headline: The Week in Tech: Facebook Fights Back
abstract: A remarkable leak from an internal meeting shows the company is gearing up to fight government intervention.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Can You Go Home Again?
abstract: Revisiting your childhood home can be a happy trip down memory lane, but it may also be a little unnerving for you and the current owners.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I visited the house where I grew up. I hadn’t been back since I was 15, but there I was on a day trip with my parents and my husband, and wouldn’t it be fun to pop in and take a look around?

headline: N.F.L. Week 5 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Red-hot backup quarterbacks will battle in Carolina, Patrick Mahomes gets a spotlight in prime time, and something has to give when hapless Cincinnati hosts winless Arizona.
lead_paragraph: The offensive revolution has hit a snag or two thanks to injuries and a few teams that have not lived up to expectations. But some surprising contenders have emerged in the N.F.L., and it’s getting deep enough into the season where we can take them seriously. This week offers a matchup of teams thriving with backup quarterbacks, a Friends of Sean McVay Bowl, a chance for Green Bay or Dallas to rebound from last week’s losses and a Sunday night showdown between the undefeated Chiefs and the plucky Colts.

headline: How Young Kim Is Trying to Reclaim Orange County for the G.O.P.
abstract: Friday: She’s back for a rematch against Gil Cisneros in a bid to be the first Korean-American woman in Congress. Also: The safest driver in L.A.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Denies Quid Pro Quo for Ukraine, but Envoys Had Their Doubts
abstract: While President Trump has denied any quid pro quo in pushing Ukraine to investigate his foes, text messages indicate that his own team saw it otherwise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump denied again on Friday that there was any quid pro quo attached to his pressure on Ukraine to investigate his political enemies, but text messages and testimony collected by congressional investigators indicated that his own representatives saw it differently.

headline: For Low-Polling Democratic Candidates, It’s All Within the Margin of Error
abstract: Qualifying for a presidential debate can be make-or-break for candidates with support in the single digits. But what do numbers that low actually tell us?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our new weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Abortion Case From Louisiana
abstract: The case will test the constitutionality of an admitting-privileges law that could reduce the number of clinics in the state one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to hear a challenge to a Louisiana law that its opponents say would leave the state with only one doctor in a single clinic authorized to provide abortions.

headline: Jobs Numbers for the Optimists, the Pessimists, and Everybody in Between
abstract: Parts of the American economy are in trouble, but the unemployment rate (3.5 percent) is at a five-decade low.
lead_paragraph: The September jobs numbers have something for everybody.

headline: Natalie Portman Shoots for the Stars and Loses Her Mind
abstract: The actor finally fulfills a childhood dream, sort of, by climbing into a spacesuit to play a tormented astronaut in “Lucy in the Sky.” And soon she’ll wield the hammer as female Thor.
lead_paragraph: As a kid with a precocious mind for science — she made it to the Intel competition semifinals in high school, after all — Natalie Portman dreamed of becoming an astronaut. But acting eventually grounded her among less celestial stars.

headline: The Jokers, Ranked
abstract: How does Joaquin Phoenix measure up to the actors who have played the Joker before?
lead_paragraph: By donning the white greasepaint to play the title character of Todd Phillips’s “Joker,” the three-time Oscar nominee Joaquin Phoenix has joined a surprisingly elite squad of actors to tackle the role. There’s clearly something about the character’s heady mixture of theatricality, bleak humor, and good old-fashioned psychopathy that attracts thespians of note. Phoenix’s performance has drawn praise from critics and film festivals alike, but how does he measure up to the previous Jokers of the big and small screen? Here, we offer our rankings of who laughed it best.

headline: Nancy Drew and the Mystery of Her Enduring Relevance
abstract: Why is Nancy Drew still prowling around popular culture? And why is she so hard to adapt successfully?
lead_paragraph: Nancy Drew, the girl detective who could pick a lock, play the bagpipes, tap Morse Code in high heels and drive her blue roadster like a Daytona champ, turns 90 next year.

headline: A Spectrum of Spice at Birds of a Feather
abstract: In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, this Sichuan spot expands upon the offerings at its sister restaurant, Cafe China.
lead_paragraph: In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, this Sichuan spot expands upon the offerings at its sister restaurant, Cafe China.

headline: Sichuan Food, Bracing and Measured, in Brooklyn
abstract: The chef at Birds of a Feather, in Williamsburg, is classically trained but willing to experiment beyond the mainstays.
lead_paragraph: At Birds of a Feather in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a bowl of slippery, feather-light pork won tons in chile oil has a red ring suspended around its edge that, to the spice-averse, may look like a warning. But the heat arrives gently, the oil used sparingly in a special sauce that’s more sweet and tangy than it is fiery. The chef, Ziqiang Lu, sprinkles the dish with a confetti of stir-fried dried chiles ground together with rattan peppercorns, a type of green Sichuan peppercorn so floral that it smells as if it’s in the process of blooming.

headline: Read the Text Messages Between U.S. and Ukrainian Officials
abstract: The messages reveal new details about President Trump’s efforts to use American foreign policy to benefit himself.
lead_paragraph: The messages reveal new details about President Trump’s efforts to use American foreign policy to benefit himself.

headline: Take It to 11
abstract: Set yourself up for some epic weekend eating, whether it’s roast pork with maduros, rice and beans, or a bowl of farro with mushrooms, a skillet brownie to finish.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve spent the week making like Danny Meyer, the restaurateur, who many nights makes it his business to visit the dining rooms he maintains across the city, even as his Shake Shack empire expands across the nation.

headline: Baratunde Thurston’s Work Diary: At the Intersection of Tech, Race and Society
abstract: “Part of my job,” says the author of “How to Be Black,” is to be “a sponge for stuff that’s happening in the world.”
lead_paragraph: Since publishing “How to Be Black,” his best-selling 2012 satirical memoir about black identity in America, Baratunde Thurston has built himself into a one-man multimedia company. In recent years, his thoughts on race and technology have powered email newsletters (“Recommentunde,” with tips about what to read and stream), podcasts (“Spit,” about the surprising implications of DNA testing), TV shows (“The Daily Show With Trevor Noah”) and a regular magazine column (“One More Thing,” in Fast Company).

headline: That Music You’re Dancing To? It’s Code
abstract: Collectives in cities around the world are bringing computer languages to the club.
lead_paragraph: On a computer, Sonic Pi looks like any other coding language. It’s a mess of numbers, parentheticals, punctuation marks and keywords, splattered over an LCD screen. But offscreen — and through a set of quality speakers — those keystrokes produce music you might dance to on a Friday night.

headline: PCOS Is More Than a Fertility Issue
abstract: This condition can cause many compounding issues and should be treated independent of pregnancy plans.
lead_paragraph: I was recently diagnosed with PCOS, though I’ve had symptoms for 20 years, and I’m wondering why PCOS is looked at as a fertility issue and not an overall women’s health issue. PCOS predisposes me to all sorts of health problems. Why didn’t anyone care until I tried to get pregnant?

headline: Who Is Gordon Sondland, and What Was His Mission to Ukraine?
abstract: The U.S. ambassador to the European Union says he was given a ‘‘special assignment’’ to handle Ukraine relations, a role now under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Gordon D. Sondland, the blunt-spoken hotelier who is President Trump’s ambassador to the European Union, was boasting on Ukrainian television that Mr. Trump had honored him with a “special assignment” — “overseeing” relations between the two countries “at the highest levels.”

headline: Cars Are Death Machines. Self-Driving Tech Won’t Change That.
abstract: The best way to make streets safer? Fewer cars.
lead_paragraph: The best way to make streets safer? Fewer cars.

headline: Pope Francis Is Fearless
abstract: His papacy has been a consistent rebuke to American culture-war Christianity in politics.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. James Martin, one of America’s most prominent Catholic priests, is a best-selling author, film consultant to Hollywood producers and a prolific tweeter with a digital pulpit that reaches more than 250,000 followers. Father Martin is also a hero to many L.G.B.T. Catholics for challenging church leaders to recognize the full humanity of gay people. His advocacy has made him a target of vicious online campaigns from far-right Catholic groups. Archbishop Charles Chaput of Philadelphia last month warned that Father Martin “does not speak with authority on behalf of the church.”

headline: Warren and Sanders, and Their Messages of Change, Dominate the Money Race
abstract: Elizabeth Warren raised nearly as much money as Bernie Sanders over the past three months. They have both shunned wealthy donors, yet they are way ahead of everyone else.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With Senator Elizabeth Warren’s announcement on Friday that she raised $24.6 million in the past three months, the fund-raising picture for the leading Democratic presidential contenders has come into focus: Ms. Warren and Senator Bernie Sanders are in strong position to fund their campaigns over the long haul.

headline: Adam Schiff Is the Right Man for the Moment
abstract: A clinical and focused approach is called for in the face of Trump’s theatrics and distraction.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and House Republicans are trying to cast the House Intelligence Committee chairman, Adam Schiff of California, as the lead villain in a partisan impeachment reality show. The president has road-tested some nicknames, called for Mr. Schiff’s resignation and accused him of treason, and is now trying to spin out a new conspiracy theory, suggesting that Mr. Schiff “probably helped write” the whistle-blower complaint. House Republicans have indicated that they intend to force a vote to condemn Mr. Schiff when they return from recess.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: September 2019
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: The September edition of Teenagers in The Times is always bursting at the seams, thanks to the many back-to-school pieces across sections.

headline: Brexit? What Brexit? The Art World Carries On Unfazed at Frieze London
abstract: Strong gallery shows and a weak pound attracted plenty of international visitors to the event.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain might be convulsed by Brexit, but the contemporary art world, and the 0.1 percent of the population that makes it go around, carries on as normal. At least, so it seems.

headline: Volker Gives New Details on Giuliani’s Role in Ukraine Policy
abstract: During private testimony, Kurt D. Volker, the special envoy, said Rudolph W. Giuliani rejected a generic anticorruption statement Ukraine planned to release.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former State Department special envoy for Ukraine told congressional investigators that Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, demanded that Ukraine specifically commit to investigate involvement in the 2016 election and a firm tied to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Review: After Ambitious Operas, the Philharmonic Exhales
abstract: Under Jaap van Zweden, war horses by Sibelius and Berlioz brought some old-fashioned pleasures.
lead_paragraph: After the adventure of last week’s ambitious staging of “Erwartung” and “Bluebeard’s Castle,” two operas the New York Philharmonic doesn’t dust off every day, the orchestra and its music director, Jaap van Zweden, exhaled.

headline: How Well Do You Know the Joker’s Laugh?
abstract: Joaquin Phoenix is the latest actor to play Batman’s cackling archnemesis, Joker. His predecessors include Cesar Romero, Jack Nicholson, Heath Ledger, Mark Hamill and Jared Leto. Can you tell whose devious laugh is whose?
lead_paragraph: Joaquin Phoenix is the latest actor to play Batman’s cackling archnemesis, Joker. His predecessors include Cesar Romero, Jack Nicholson, Heath Ledger, Mark Hamill and Jared Leto. Can you tell whose devious laugh is whose?

headline: Boris Johnson Will Ask for a Brexit Delay, Court Papers Say
abstract: The British government is following a law seeking to avert a no-deal departure, but the back-room maneuvering is far from over.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After vowing for weeks that Britain would leave the European Union on Oct. 31 with or without a deal easing the transition, the government said in documents released on Friday that Prime Minister Boris Johnson would ask for another delay if he failed to secure an agreement by mid-October.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Officer’s Funeral Brings Commissioner and Comrades to Tears
abstract: They came by the thousands to mourn Officer Brian Mulkeen, who was killed by “friendly fire” during an arrest in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: MONROE, N.Y. — They came by the thousands — officers in ceremonial uniforms, officials in somber suits and navy dresses, friends, family members and strangers, dressed as much in grief as in actual fabric. They converged on a church in this small upstate town on Friday to mourn the untimely death of a young New York City police officer, described as a selfless hero who gave up a life of comfort for one of service.

headline: Sam Darnold Out of Jets Game
abstract: The quarterback has missed the team’s last two games because of mononucleosis.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Quarterback Sam Darnold, who missed the Jets’ last two games because of mononucleosis, will not play this Sunday against the Eagles.

headline: Sanders Said He Had a Common Heart Procedure. So Why the Mystery?
abstract: For three days, Mr. Sanders did not disclose pertinent health details, stirring questions about his condition. On Friday evening, doctors confirmed he had suffered a heart attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “None of us know when a medical emergency will affect us,” Senator Bernie Sanders wrote in a tweet from Desert Springs Hospital Medical Center on Wednesday, hours after the 78-year-old Democratic candidate for president experienced one.

headline: Impeachment Investigators Subpoena White House and Ask Pence for Documents on Ukraine
abstract: House Democrats sent a subpoena to the White House requesting a vast range of documents about President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine and efforts to cover up his actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House impeachment investigators widened the reach of their inquiry on Friday, subpoenaing the White House for a vast trove of documents and requesting more from Vice President Mike Pence to better understand President Trump’s attempts to pressure Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.

headline: Here’s How to Type Faster on Your Phone
abstract: Get those index fingers off your screen.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, our approach to typing on a smartphone is something we stumble upon. Unlike composing words on a typewriter or computer keyboard, there is no widely taught, proper way.

headline: Fry Some Eggplant Before the Season Is Done
abstract: Crisp-edged, golden, soft-centered and thoroughly appealing, this fried eggplant is also easy enough to make on a weeknight.
lead_paragraph: Roasted and grilled eggplants are all well and good, but nothing beats the crisp skin and burnished flesh of eggplant that’s been fried.

headline: Read T a Poem | Colman Domingo
abstract: The actor reads Ed Bok Lee’s “Summer Open Window” (2019).
lead_paragraph: The actor reads Ed Bok Lee’s “Summer Open Window” (2019).

headline: The Actor Colman Domingo Reads T a Poem
abstract: The multitalented star of the new movie “Lucy in the Sky” recites a work by Ed Bok Lee.
lead_paragraph: The actor, writer and director Colman Domingo, 49, has always loved poetry. “I grew up on poems by E.E. Cummings, Langston Hughes, Maya Angelou, Nikki Giovanni and Paul Laurence Dunbar,” he says. In addition to starring alongside Natalie Portman in the new film “Lucy in the Sky,” which follows an astronaut’s struggle to readjust to life on Earth after traveling into space, Domingo recently appeared on HBO’s “Euphoria” and is a co-writer of the acclaimed “Summer: Donna Summer the Musical,” which is currently on tour across the U.S. When he’s crafting narratives for any of his projects, whether he’s in front of the camera or behind the scenes, he often returns to the words of his favorite writers. “Poems influenced my love of craftsmanship in telling a story,” he says, “whether in short prose or long form.” The works he revisits again and again have in common “rich language, impeccable phrasing, soul stirring images, and wit,” he says, and so it makes sense that for T’s video series “Read T a Poem,” he chose to recite a work by the South Korean-born American writer Ed Bok Lee, whose insightful, exacting poems reflect the intimate ways globalization is transforming our culture and our lives. Domingo’s selection, “Summer Open Window,” is from Lee’s latest collection, “Mitochondrial Night,” which uses DNA as a central theme in its lyrical exploration of genealogy, geography and time.

headline: Terrorism Motive Eyed in Paris Police Stabbing Attack
abstract: As antiterrorism prosecutors took over the inquiry, officials did not say whether the decision was guided by an interview with the attacker’s wife or analysis of his phone and computer.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French antiterrorism prosecutors on Friday took over the investigation into the killing of four people the day before at Paris Police Headquarters, suggesting investigators were considering a possible terrorism motive.

headline: Come One, Come All!
abstract: At this literary festival, a library card is the only ticket you need.

headline: Ben Lerner’s New Novel and the Politics of Language
abstract: Garth Risk Hallberg discusses Lerner’s “The Topeka School,” and Bari Weiss talks about “How to Fight Anti-Semitism.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Getting the Joker’s Laugh Just Right
abstract: Joaquin Phoenix’s predecessors on TV and video say that cackle takes strenuous effort. The voice actor they revere? Mark Hamill.
lead_paragraph: For years, Andrea Romano gave a crucial note to actors who voiced the Joker on “Batman: The Animated Series”: Do not wear noisy shirts. “It was rare that someone would come in to do the Joker voice for more than 20 minutes who didn’t end up bathed in sweat. It requires a tremendous amount of energy,” said Romano, who served as the voice and casting director for that show, “Justice League” and other animated series. “You want to flail your arms around and not have a take ruined by the sound of clothing.”

headline: What Happened After the Joke: A Stand-Up’s Harrowing Tale
abstract: Gary Gulman has always avoided hack comedy. In a new special, he finds himself in territory other comics have staked out involving depression. The results are fascinating.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing comics want besides laughs, it’s to avoid being hack, which means, essentially, cliché. But defining hack can be tricky. It varies from room to room and changes with the times, a moving target that requires vigilance and alertness to track. No one dodges it with as much persistence as Gary Gulman.

headline: More Unrest as Hong Kong Protesters Defy Mask Ban
abstract: People took to the streets of Hong Kong to protest the government’s decision to invoke emergency powers to ban face masks in an attempt to quell mass demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: People took to the streets of Hong Kong to protest the government’s decision to invoke emergency powers to ban face masks in an attempt to quell mass demonstrations.

headline: Scientists Solve a Puzzle: What’s Really in a Fatberg
abstract: The grisly results of an autopsy in the U.K. were made public on Friday, and they were not pretty. But they did hold a few surprises.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When a giant fatberg was discovered in the sewer of a small coastal town in southwestern England last year, the company that manages the pipes was so mystified by the greasy mass of solidified fats and waste materials that it enlisted the help of scientists to discover what it was made of.

headline: Demi Moore Shares a Peek Behind the Scenes of Her No. 1 Best Seller
abstract: The Hollywood legend gets real — really real — on fame, family, love and what it was like to write a book.
lead_paragraph: Chances are, you’ve seen Demi Moore on a screen — a big one at the multiplex or a little one in your best friend’s basement. If you’re a moviegoer of a certain age, you might trace your journey from adolescence to adulthood by the release dates of Moore’s greatest hits, from “St. Elmo’s Fire” to “G.I. Jane.”

headline: Diahann Carroll, Actress Who Broke Barriers With ‘Julia,’ Dies at 84
abstract: In addition to being a sitcom pioneer, she sang on television, in nightclubs, on recordings and on Broadway, where she won a Tony Award.
lead_paragraph: Diahann Carroll, who more than half a century ago transcended racial barriers as the star of “Julia,” the first American television series to chronicle the life of a black professional woman, died on Friday at her home in West Hollywood, Calif. She was 84.

headline: Afghan Town’s First Female Mayor Awaits Her Assassination
abstract: Zarifa Ghafari expects to die in office. But in the meantime, she intends to do something about the litter problem.
lead_paragraph: MAIDAN SHAR, Afghanistan — Zarifa Ghafari, who at 26 became one of Afghanistan’s first female mayors, has said that she fully expects to be assassinated.

headline: The Chicken That May Sweep the Internet
abstract: See what all the excitement is about, and make Alison Roman’s vinegar chicken with crushed olive dressing.
lead_paragraph: I have a short running list of cooking projects in my head, the things I would do if I were living the long-baked lifestyle as opposed to the fast-cook one. At the top of the list, alongside pastries, is sourdough bread — good bread being a true love of mine. This is why our new guide to making sourdough bread is crying out to me and really is not to be missed. It’s written by the extraordinary Claire Saffitz (of Bon Appétit test kitchen video fame), and it is thorough and helpful and approachable and sane. I also ate some of the test loaves, and frankly they were amazing.

headline: The Myth of the Frivolous Female Spender
abstract: Women buy shoes, men buy power — or so goes the trope. Here’s why that myth persists.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox. Let us know what you think at inherwords@nytimes.com.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: October 2019
abstract: At least 401 pro-government forces and 161 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
lead_paragraph: At least 76 pro-government forces and 18 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. The deadliest attack took place Jowzjan Province, where a Taliban Red Unit attacked the Bala Hisar military base in Aqcha District, killing 20 soldiers, three pro-government militia members and one police officer. An additional five soldiers were taken prisoner, and 10 security forces were wounded in the course of the three-hour battle. The Taliban also seized four Humvees and 29 weapons from the base, which was recaptured after reinforcements arrived. In Takhar Province, insurgents attacked two security outposts in the villages of Qorogh and Khwaja Bandkasha, killing five police special forces and five pro-government militia members. Local authorities claimed that 12 Taliban members were also killed in the clash.

headline: The Playlist: The Who’s Defiant Postscript, and 14 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Robert Glasper, Gucci Mane and Megan Thee Stallion, Sleater-Kinney and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Trump, Facing Farmers’ Discontent, Plans Help for Ethanol
abstract: Amid rising political pressure from trade-war fallout, the Trump administration is moving to increase purchases of domestic grain to make ethanol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Agriculture jointly proposed new rules on Friday that would increase ethanol consumption at the expense of oil refineries to help corn and soybean farmers buffeted by President Trump’s trade wars.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker, Kelly Ripa and Ryan Seacrest at the Ballet
abstract: Galas were held for the New York City Ballet, Carnegie Hall and the City Parks Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Galas were held for the New York City Ballet, Carnegie Hall and the City Parks Foundation.

headline: Stunt Aimed at Ocasio-Cortez Over Climate Change: ‘Start Eating Babies’
abstract: The congresswoman was criticized by President Trump and other Republicans for her measured response to a woman’s suggestion to “eat the children.”

headline: A Night at the Ballet
abstract: Galas were held for the New York City Ballet, Carnegie Hall and the City Parks Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Ballet held its fall fashion gala on Sept. 26 at Lincoln Center. Carnegie Hall held its opening night gala on Oct. 3. And the City Parks Foundation, which provides activities and concerts in public parks, held its 30th anniversary gala on Sept. 26 in Central Park.

headline: Iranian Hackers Target Trump Campaign as Threats to 2020 Mount
abstract: The news, according to two people with knowledge of the attacks, followed a Microsoft report that said hackers had targeted a campaign, U.S. officials and journalists.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The 2020 presidential election is still 13 months away, but already Iranians are following in the footsteps of Russia and have begun cyberattacks aimed at disrupting the campaigns.

headline: Man Kills Estranged Wife With Car and Machete in the Bronx, Police Say
abstract: The police are searching for the estranged husband of Noelia Mateo, 58, who was attacked outside her Bronx home, in front of her grandchildren.
lead_paragraph: A man ran over his estranged wife with her car and then repeatedly slashed her with a machete in broad daylight on Thursday morning in the Bronx, the police said.

headline: Britain Once Held All the Cards With Ireland. Brexit Turned the Tables.
abstract: Ireland, which developed a bustling economy within the European Union, commands support from other member states as it deals with the potential effects of Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson presented his plan to lead Britain out of the European Union — a dense farrago of details about customs unions, regulatory zones and borders running in two directions — Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, offered a simple response: Why not just vote again?

headline: Skateboarding’s ‘Anti-Olympics’
abstract: For amateurs and professionals, this annual event captures the spirit of the sport ahead of its debut at the 2020 Tokyo games.
lead_paragraph: “It’s crazy high-level skateboarding,” said Evan Eden, a member of the crowd at this year’s “Live at Olympic Stadium” in Montreal. He had traveled from New Jersey to see the annual spectacle, which in the last five years has become known as one of the most innovative and exciting events in the sport.

headline: How the Yankees Became Baseball’s Hardest-Hitting Team
abstract: They missed several of their top batters for much of the season, but still sent balls flying faster than any team in the majors. It wasn’t an accident.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees were dethroned as the home run kings of Major League Baseball this year, barely ceding the title to their divisional-round playoff opponents: The Minnesota Twins, who smashed a record 307 blasts to the Yankees’ 306.

headline: An Outtake From ‘The Daily’: The Fear Facer
abstract: Julia Longoria, a producer for “The Daily,” consults 9-year-old Ella Maners about how to tackle a fear.
lead_paragraph: Julia Longoria, a producer for “The Daily,” consults 9-year-old Ella Maners about how to tackle a fear.

headline: Scientist Who Discredited Meat Guidelines Didn’t Report Past Food Industry Ties
abstract: The lead researcher, Bradley C. Johnston, said he was not required to report his past relationship with a powerful industry trade group.
lead_paragraph: A surprising new study challenged decades of nutrition advice and gave consumers the green light to eat more red and processed meat. But what the study didn’t say is that its lead author has past research ties to the meat and food industry.

headline: October Dreams, and Nightmares, Have Kept Nelson Cruz Coming Back
abstract: Eight years after a World Series title slipped away from him, Cruz remains one of the majors’ best power hitters, in a surprisingly powerful Minnesota Twins lineup.
lead_paragraph: A ring sailed right over his head, and eight years later, Nelson Cruz is still trying to grab it.

headline: Disney Bars Netflix TV Ads in Battle for Streaming Supremacy
abstract: ABC, Freeform and other Disney-owned entertainment networks will no longer accept Netflix ads in another sign of how the streaming wars are intensifying.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dear Netflix: Keep your money.

headline: On the Menu: Is It Really O.K. to Eat Meat?
abstract: Readers discuss a new study that further muddies the water on what constitutes healthful eating.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What to Wear to a World-Class Horse Jumping Show
abstract: Saddling up for the Longines Global Champions Tour in New York.
lead_paragraph: Fun fact about show jumping: While the sport may never shake its elitist reputation, it’s the rare Olympic event where men and women compete against one another. Also true: Admission to last weekend’s Longines Global Champions Tour, which was on Governors Island in New York City and showcased some of the world’s top-ranked jumpers, was free.

headline: Misty Copeland Leads the Charge at Fall for Dance
abstract: Ms. Copeland, Caleb Teicher and the Mark Morris Dance Group were highlights of the popular, eclectic festival’s first two programs.
lead_paragraph: Misty Copeland inched toward the front of the stage with her powerful back leading the way. It wasn’t the only time that Ms. Copeland, one of ballet’s brightest stars, showed her fans a different side of herself in “Ash,” a new solo by Kyle Abraham. But it set the tone.

headline: The Veterinarian Will See Your Dinosaur Now
abstract: We asked a pet doctor how he’d treat the fossilized injuries found to have affected some of prehistory’s most fearsome reptiles.
lead_paragraph: Dinosaurs loom large in the human imagination, towering above the treetops, bringing down prey and reigning over the ancient land, sea and sky.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: A.O. Scott on “The Joker.” A look at four family budgets. Pedro Almodóvar. Rachel Maddow. DaBaby. Farewell, Jessye Norman. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. With so much going on in the news, you may have missed these excellent articles. You won’t regret spending some time reading them.

headline: Yannick Nézet-Séguin Leads a Revelatory ‘Turandot’
abstract: Mr. Nézet-Séguin’s first performance of the Metropolitan Opera this season offers a glimpse into the company’s artistic future.
lead_paragraph: Last season, when Yannick Nézet-Séguin’s tenure as the Metropolitan Opera’s music director began, audiences had to wait more than two months for him to actually conduct something. It was worth the wait. He led a fresh, elegant and gripping account of Verdi’s “La Traviata.”

headline: F.D.A. Approves New H.I.V.-Prevention Drug, but Not for Everyone
abstract: Citing a lack of evidence, the agency will require Gilead to conduct additional trials in individuals ‘who have receptive vaginal sex.’
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved a new drug, Descovy, for prevention of infection with H.I.V., only the second drug approved for this purpose.

headline: Prince Harry Goes to Battle With Tabloids, Rupturing an Old Relationship
abstract: He has begun legal proceedings against The Sun and The Daily Mirror, accusing them of phone hacking. The case is an extraordinary break from the royal practice, “Never complain, never explain.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry has started legal proceedings against the owners of two British tabloids over accusations that they hacked his phones, Buckingham Palace confirmed on Friday, opening a new front in a remarkable crusade against the British press.

headline: Introducing Love Letter, a Newsletter About Love and Relationships
abstract: In which we give you all the stories that will make you feel things.
lead_paragraph: [This is the very first installment of the Love Letter newsletter. Sign up here to receive it in your inbox. ]

headline: Scientists on Arctic Expedition Choose Ice Floe That’ll Be Home for a Year
abstract: The Mosaic mission has picked the ice floe it will be frozen into for the next year, to learn more about global warming's effects on the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after leaving northern Norway for the Central Arctic, and with the polar darkness settling in, an icebreaker carrying climate researchers settled next to an ice floe on Friday, putting itself at the mercy of the drifting ice for a planned yearlong expedition to better understand the changing Arctic climate.

headline: Treasury Inspector General to Review Handling of Trump’s Tax Returns
abstract: House Democrats requested an inquiry after a whistle-blower complaint from an Internal Revenue Service employee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department’s inspector general is investigating how the department handled a congressional request for President Trump’s tax returns, which Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has refused to turn over.

headline: When My Louisiana School and Its Football Team Finally Desegregated
abstract: In 1969, 15 years after Brown v. Board of Education, a Japanese-American football coach and an African-American player formed a bond that resonates today.
lead_paragraph: EUNICE, La. — Before two-a-day football practices began in August 1969, Coach Joe Nagata gathered some of his white senior players at Eunice High School. He told them to prepare for workouts more difficult than usual in heat and humidity that felt like damp clothes inside a dryer.

headline: Mordicai Gerstein, Illustrator of Magical Worlds, Dies at 83
abstract: He wrote and illustrated more than 40 children’s books, many of which dealt with the messy business of being human.
lead_paragraph: Mordicai Gerstein, a writer, illustrator and master storyteller whose books created magical worlds where young readers could ponder big questions, died on Sept. 24 at his home in Westhampton, Mass. He was 83.

headline: Former Italian Prime Minister Says He’s Suing Trump Aide for Slander
abstract: A far-right conspiracy theory promoted by members of the Trump administration has created a headache — and opportunity — for Italy’s bickering leaders.
lead_paragraph: FERRARA, Italy — What was once a conspiracy theory on America’s far-right fringe has developed into a furtive international investigation by the Trump administration and a political headache, and opportunity, for Italy’s bickering leaders.

headline: Trump Claims Texts Prove No ‘Quid Pro Quos of Any Kind’ With Ukraine. But His Ambassador Suspected One.
abstract: Speaking to reporters, President Trump also said his requests for information on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son Hunter Biden don’t “pertain to anything but corruption.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump insisted on Friday that there was nothing inappropriate about his administration’s dealings with Ukraine, playing down a series of texts between American diplomats and a Ukrainian official that were released Thursday night that outlined his attempt to tie a possible White House meeting and military aid to investigating former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Australia Just Had a Bad Flu Season. That May Be a Warning for the U.S.
abstract: In 2017, a terrible flu season in Australia presaged an American outbreak in which 79,000 died. Experts advise getting the shot soon.
lead_paragraph: Australia had an unusually early and fairly severe flu season this year. Since that may foretell a serious outbreak on its way in the United States, public health experts now are urging Americans to get their flu shots as soon as possible.

headline: Old Masters and Fresh Surprises at the New York Film Festival
abstract: A subjective tour of the difficult and the delightful, including our critic’s favorite entry. (Hint: It’s by a beloved French documentarian.)
lead_paragraph: The New York Film Festival, now at its midpoint, is a grand, institutional affair. What the selection committee agrees is the best of world cinema — work from established masters and up-and-coming auteurs — assembles at Lincoln Center, along with judiciously selected documentaries, repertory offerings and experimental films. (Tickets are still available at Filmlinc.org.) That’s the big picture, anyway, or the comprehensive version of the story. It began last week with Martin Scorsese’s “The Irishman” and ends next weekend with Edward Norton’s “Motherless Brooklyn,” with Noah Baumbach’s “Marriage Story” as the designated centerpiece.

headline: How the Yankees Won Game 1 of the A.L.D.S.
abstract: The Yankees open their 2019 postseason with a comfortable win over the A.L. Central champion Minnesota Twins.
lead_paragraph: Yankees fans, spoiled by 27 World Series trophies, might be frustrated by their team’s decade-long drought without adding another title. But consider the plight of Minnesota Twins fans when they learned of their team’s first-round postseason opponent.

headline: Trump Administration Unveils More Cuts to Food Stamp Program
abstract: The administration’s proposal, the third food-stamp rule change since December, would reduce spending by $4.5 billion over five years and cut benefits for one in five families.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Agriculture Department moved again this week to cut spending on food stamps, this time proposing changes that would slice $4.5 billion from the program over five years, trimming monthly benefits by as much as $75 for one in five struggling families on nutrition assistance.

headline: Su Beng, a Father of Taiwan Independence, Dies at 100
abstract: He ran underground operations to liberate the island from colonial rule and wrote the foundational book “Taiwan’s 400-Year History.”
lead_paragraph: Su Beng, a revolutionary widely known as the father of Taiwan independence for his efforts to liberate the island from colonial rule, died on Sept. 20 in Taipei, the capital. He was 100.

headline: Flash Drought in the South Brings Record Heat Without Rain
abstract: Autumn is here, and it’s still hot. Here is what we know about the record-breaking temperatures and low precipitation across much of the American South.
lead_paragraph: It was a hot summer in the American South, and droughts have affected tens of millions of people there after one of the driest and hottest Septembers on record.

headline: Karel Gott, Pop Singer Called ‘Sinatra of the East,’ Dies at 80
abstract: His crooning in Czech and several other languages brought him great popularity, especially in countries behind the Iron Curtain.
lead_paragraph: Karel Gott, a romantic Czech crooner whose popularity behind the Iron Curtain helped earn him the nickname “Sinatra of the East,” died on Tuesday  at his home in Prague. He was 80.

headline: Melissa Barrera Goes from Mexican Telenovelas to ‘Vida’ Star
abstract: The Mexican actress landed the lead role in “Siempre Tuya Acapulco” when she was 23.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Barrera

headline: North Korea Blocks Windows of Tall Buildings in Pyongyang to Prevent Spying, Reports Say
abstract: North Korea blocks the windows of high-rise apartments in Pyongyang to prevent their residents from looking down, or spying, on the party and government buildings, a news report says.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has blocked the windows of high-rise apartments in Pyongyang, its showcase capital city, to prevent residents from looking down, or spying, on the party and government buildings where its top leader, Kim Jong-un, conducts business, a news report said Friday.

headline: Podcasts for Horoscopes, Adulting and Phish Fans: Here’s What’s New
abstract: Our monthly selection of the most interesting shows.
lead_paragraph: Several new podcasts have quickly earned popularity on podcast charts. Top of the Apple charts this month is NBC News’s newest venture into audio, “The Thing About Pam,” from Keith Morrison and the “Dateline” team, which demonstrates corporate media’s continued experimentation with the audio-only form. But here are some other newcomers that could be worth your time — whether you’re a musical kid, a lover of mafia history, a cosmic believer, curious about classical music, concerned about gentrification and the environment or a Phishhead.

headline: The Trump Era: ‘Something New and Ugly Every Day’
abstract: Readers react to the president’s overture to China to investigate the Bidens and a so-called perfect phone call with Ukraine’s leader.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Diahann Carroll’s Tony Award Acceptance Speech
abstract: Diahann Carroll won the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for her role in “No Strings,” playing an American fashion model living in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Diahann Carroll won the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for her role in “No Strings,” playing an American fashion model living in Paris.

headline: With P.K. Subban, Devils Seek Wins on the Ice and in the Ticket Office
abstract: The team hopes the acquisitions of Subban and Jack Hughes will make the Devils successful and relevant again.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — P.K. Subban played against the Devils 22 times over his first nine N.H.L. seasons, but he knew virtually nothing about New Jersey before he arrived in July, one month after being traded here by the Nashville Predators.

headline: Twin Births in the U.S. Are Dropping, and Experts Have a Theory
abstract: Researchers believe that the decline may be connected to advances in embryo transfers during in vitro fertilization.
lead_paragraph: The twin birthrate has declined in the United States after rising for years, a new report said this week. One theory researchers have put forward to explain the change is that fertility therapies that previously involved transfers of multiple embryos are less common.

headline: A Different Kind of Guest
abstract: We made some episodes for kids. (But grown-ups, we’ll let you listen, too.)
lead_paragraph: Our first-ever episode for kids told the story of Elsa and Clio Moock, 10-year-old twin sisters at an unexpected crossroads. Both were enrolled in the Girl Scouts. Elsa wanted to leave to join the Boy Scouts, a sudden possibility because of major changes the organization was making. Clio wanted to stay in the Girl Scouts.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Campaign Fires Staff Member for ‘Inappropriate Behavior’
abstract: Richard McDaniel, Ms. Warren’s national organizing director, was let go from the campaign after it “determined that his reported conduct was inconsistent with its values.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts fired her national organizing director after “multiple complaints regarding inappropriate behavior,” according to a statement released Friday by her communications director.

headline: PayPal Pulls Out of Libra, Facebook’s Cryptocurrency Project
abstract: The move deals a blow to the heavily criticized effort, which Facebook unveiled in June.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — PayPal said on Friday that it had pulled out of the coalition of companies involved in a Facebook-backed cryptocurrency initiative, in the latest headache for the social network’s effort.

headline: T Suggests: A Pioneering French Designer, a New All-Day Cafe and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: Over a century after her birth, the French designer Charlotte Perriand is finally getting her due. A retrospective of the pioneering avant-garde architect, who changed the course of 20th-century design with her elegant, industrial-inspired interior design and furniture, is now open at the Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris. “Charlotte Perriand: Inventing A New World” features 200 of her designs, alongside the work of 15 artists from her time (for example, the French modernist Fernand Léger, whose artwork she sometimes featured in her interiors) and seven designers from her era, including the self-taught architect and metal worker Jean Prouvé. While Perriand may be best known for the Chaise Longue Basculante B306 — an adjustable steel lounge chair that she created in 1928 while working at Le Corbusier’s studio in her 20s — her contributions also include a prefabricated mountain resort in Savoie, France, asymmetrical wooden bookcases that call to mind paintings by Piet Mondrian and a necklace made of oversize ball bearings. “People keep thinking she’s a woman who designed just a few chairs with Le Corbusier,” says Sébastien Cherruet, a co-curator of the exhibition. “It’s not fair and doesn’t do justice to her work.”

headline: A New History Celebrates Brooklyn’s Heights, and Depths
abstract: Thomas J. Campanella, a fourth-generation Brooklynite, traces the borough’s vibrant past and comments on the hipster heyday happening there now.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYNThe Once and Future CityBy Thomas J. Campanella

headline: Impeachment, Prince Harry, Diahann Carroll: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: You Will Be Shocked by This Article
abstract: The two biggest companies behind an internet subgenre — the “chumbox ad” — have joined forces to form a company that will generate $2 billion a year.
lead_paragraph: On many websites, readers who scroll to the very end of an article are likely to encounter rows of small advertisements belonging to a weird subgenre of digital marketing known as chumbox ads.

headline: 10 Tips to Avoid Leaving Tracks Around the Internet
abstract: Some of these suggestions are more aggressive, and make using the web less convenient, but they’ll definitely protect your privacy.
lead_paragraph: Google and Facebook collect information about us and then sell that data to advertisers. Websites deposit invisible “cookies” onto our computers and then record where we go online. Even our own government has been known to track us.

headline: Trump’s Call to China to Investigate Biden Could Complicate Trade Talks
abstract: The U.S. and China are trying to reach agreement, but President Trump’s request is likely to increase scrutiny of any trade pact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s public call for the Chinese government to investigate a political rival could complicate next week’s trade talks, which are set to resume Thursday when American and Chinese negotiators meet in Washington to see if they can find a path to a trade deal.

headline: In the Land of Self-Defeat
abstract: What a fight over the local library in my hometown in rural Arkansas taught me about my neighbors’ go-it-alone mythology — and Donald Trump’s unbeatable appeal.
lead_paragraph: CLINTON, Ark. — Inside Washington, there’s a sense that this scandal really is different. Even the White House’s memorandum of the phone conversation President Trump had with the Ukrainian president in July makes it clear that Mr. Trump asked a foreign country to help him undermine a political rival. But while national polls show support for impeaching him is growing, it’s still divided sharply along partisan lines. Democrats strongly favor it, while Republicans tend to oppose it.

headline: Dalilah Muhammad Breaks Her Own World Record in the 400-Meter Hurdles
abstract: With her performance at the world track and field championships, Muhammad, a 29-year-old American, bested a record she set in July.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Dalilah Muhammad had no idea whether she had even won when she crossed the finish line on Friday night at Khalifa International Stadium. She had to look at the scoreboard to learn the results, she said, and it was only then that she realized what she had accomplished.

headline: Andrew Scheer Has Fans. Can They Make Him Canada’s Prime Minister?
abstract: Mr. Scheer, Canada’s conservative leader, is polling neck-and-neck with Mr. Trudeau. Can he translate that into victory in the Oct. 21 elections?
