lead_paragraph: BRAMPTON, Ontario — Canada’s Conservative Party leader arrived in his campaign bus for a rally in the Toronto suburb of Brampton as a sparse crowd of about 150 milled about the venue, a largely empty parking lot.

headline: Osaka vs. Andreescu: Tennis Rivalry in the Making?
abstract: Naomi Osaka beat Bianca Andreescu in Beijing on Friday in the first of what tennis fans hope will be many matches between the young stars.
lead_paragraph: Women’s tennis has so much going for it: new stars from different continents, week-to-week suspense, and grande dame Serena Williams’s ongoing quest for a 24th major singles title.

headline: For Rocco Baldelli, Managing the Twins Is a Team Effort
abstract: The Twins’ hierarchy is more democracy than monarchy, with Baldelli leaning heavily on the bench coach Derek Shelton, and Thad Levine sharing front-office duties with Derek Falvey.
lead_paragraph: Derek Shelton knows midges. Twelve years ago, Shelton, now the Minnesota Twins’ bench coach, stood in Cleveland’s home dugout as the Indians’ hitting coach when the winged insects swarmed in off Lake Erie, disrupting Game 2 of an American League division series. Yankees reliever Joba Chamberlain couldn’t handle the infestation, and the Yankees lost the game and ultimately the series.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: House committees request documents from Vice President  Pence. Plus, text messages raise questions of quid pro quo.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Impeachment Briefing, a special edition of the Morning Briefing that explains the latest developments in the House impeachment inquiry against President Trump. Sign up here to get the briefing by email every weeknight.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Iran Make Quiet Openings to Head Off War
abstract: Weeks after the Middle East seemed on the verge of war, Saudi Arabia and Iran are seeking ways to ease tensions. A warming relationship could have far-reaching consequences.
lead_paragraph: After years of growing hostility and competition for influence, Saudi Arabia and Iran have taken steps toward indirect talks to try to reduce the tensions that have brought the Middle East to the brink of war, according to officials from several countries involved in the efforts.

headline: Pierre Le-Tan, Illustrator With a Quiet Touch, Dies at 69
abstract: His work appeared in galleries, museums and books, in collaborations with fashion brands, and, 18 times, on the cover of The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: The moon shines through a window, its light falling on a chair and a table holding a bottle and three tomatoes.

headline: Bernie Sanders Had Heart Attack, His Doctors Say as He Leaves Hospital
abstract: “After two and a half days in the hospital, I feel great, and after taking a short time off, I look forward to getting back to work,” Mr. Sanders said.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders had a heart attack this week, his presidential campaign said on Friday as he left a Las Vegas hospital, following three days of near silence from the candidate and his advisers about his health.

headline: Atlanta Asks Google Whether It Targeted Black Homeless People
abstract: City officials asked Google to verify a report that its contractors sought to scan the faces of black homeless people to improve facial-recognition software.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta officials are seeking answers from Google after a news report said that company contractors had sought out black homeless people in the city to scan their faces to improve Google’s facial-recognition technology.

headline: Inequality in School Sports, and Beyond
abstract: Readers react to an article about a football team that can’t compete with richer suburban schools.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Testimony and Evidence Collected in the Trump Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The status of the documents and witness testimony being collected by congressional investigators.
lead_paragraph: The status of the documents and witness testimony being collected by congressional investigators.

headline: At the Bronx Zoo, She Taunted a Lion. Now She’s Taunting Police.
abstract: A viral video of a woman seemingly inside the zoo’s lion exhibit has sparked a weeklong search for her. She’s not exactly lying low.
lead_paragraph: In its miniature savanna in the Bronx on Friday, a lion basked in both the sunshine and his newfound fame.

headline: Amber Guyger’s Judge Gave Her a Bible and a Hug. Did That Cross a Line?
abstract: After a high-profile murder trial, Judge Tammy Kemp ignited a debate about the limits of compassion.
lead_paragraph: The trial was over at last. After days of emotional testimony in a case that gripped and divided the nation, a white former Dallas police officer had been sentenced to 10 years in prison for murdering a black man in his own apartment. The shouts of protest that had filled the courthouse hallways had quieted. Everyone was getting ready to go home.

headline: Paul Badura-Skoda, Who Could Make a Piano Sing, Dies at 91
abstract: With an admired tone, he excelled at the heart of the classical repertory and was, with more than 200 discs, one of the most-recorded pianists.
lead_paragraph: Paul Badura-Skoda, an Austrian pianist who was known for insightful interpretations of classical era repertory and who had one of largest discographies of any major pianist, more than 200 recordings, died on Sept. 25 in Vienna. He was 91.

headline: Trump Governs by Grudge in California
abstract: Californians don’t vote for Trump, and he’s showing them what he can do about it.
lead_paragraph: In 1961, at a news conference three years before he became the Republican presidential nominee, the right-wing Arizona senator Barry Goldwater, surveying the progressive tendencies of voters in New York and its neighbors, was moved to observe: “Sometimes I think this country would be better off if we could just saw off the Eastern Seaboard and let it float out to sea.”

headline: What They Left Behind: Colorama, ‘Body Parts’ and Earth Works
abstract: Some gems from the life’s work of people remembered in obituaries in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Obituaries in The New York Times give account of the lives of the people around us — what they accomplished and how they lived — and reading them can be an exercise in discovering, or rediscovering, the marvelous things they created.

headline: Facing Fresh Revelations, Republicans Struggle to Mount a Defense of Trump
abstract: Top Republicans have labored to find a unified message to push back against the rapidly expanding inquiry and break through a cascade of damaging information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders are struggling to settle on a clear message and effective strategy for responding to Democrats’ aggressive and fast-moving impeachment investigation of President Trump, thrown off by early stumbles and a chaotic White House that have upended efforts to set a steady tone.

headline: Hundreds Arrested in Ecuador Unrest
abstract: Anger over the elimination of fuel subsidies was the catalyst for protests by transport workers and others that have paralyzed Quito and much of the country.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Angry demonstrations over Ecuador’s elimination of fuel subsidies widened on Friday, paralyzing much of the country for the second consecutive day as protesters in the capital clashed with riot police officers who used tear gas and armored cars to disperse them. Hundreds of people were reported arrested.

headline: The Rays Got ‘Verlandered.’ Join the Club.
abstract: Justin Verlander set the record for wins in the division series, improving to 8-0 after Houston’s 6-2 victory over Tampa Bay on Friday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Justin Verlander loomed over the American League wild card game on Wednesday night, and his Houston Astros did not even play in it. The Tampa Bay Rays did, in Oakland, and their victory earned them a date with Verlander, who is only the greatest pitcher in the history of the division series.

headline: Trump and His Henchmen in the Flames
abstract: Is this Trump’s public suicide or his genius for survival?
lead_paragraph: We all know President Trump couldn’t find Ukraine on a map, let alone find Finland, that happy country (the world’s happiest, according to a United Nations agency) whose happiness Trump this week attributed to the following: “You got rid of Pelosi, and you got rid of shifty Schiff.”

headline: Elaine Feinstein, Poet, Novelist and Biographer, Dies at 88
abstract: Prolific and multifaceted, she took inspiration from her Jewish heritage and the Russian women whose work she translated.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Feinstein, a multifaceted British poet, novelist and biographer who found inspiration in her Jewish heritage and the work of female Russian poets, died on Sept. 23 in London. She was 88.

headline: 2nd Official Is Weighing Whether to Blow the Whistle on Trump’s Ukraine Dealings
abstract: The official, a member of the intelligence community, was interviewed by the inspector general to corroborate the original whistle-blower’s account.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A second intelligence official who was alarmed by President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine is weighing whether to file his own formal whistle-blower complaint and testify to Congress, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Who will be Canada’s next prime minister? Look to the lawn signs
abstract: The lawn sign has proved to be remarkably resilient, and campaigns continue to spend time and money designing and distributing them.
lead_paragraph: I spent part of this week watching Andrew Scheer, the Conservative leader and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s top rival. And it was a week during which it became Mr. Scheer’s turn to be caught in this election’s seeming obsession with party leaders’ past lives, rather than the issues. Most Canadians probably now know more than they want about Saskatchewan’s licensing requirements for insurance brokers.

headline: Trump’s Future and the Clinton Precedent
abstract: Can Democrats and Republicans learn from the mistakes of 1998?
lead_paragraph: I came of age as a conservative in an era when Republicans were keen on matters of private virtue and public probity. Then Bill Clinton became president, and his behavior exemplified neither.

headline: Trump Will Deny Immigrant Visas to Those Who Can’t Pay for Health Care
abstract: Visa applicants will have to prove they have insurance or the financial resources for medical costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will deny visas to immigrants who cannot prove they will have health insurance or the ability to pay for medical costs once they become permanent residents of the United States, the White House announced Friday in the latest move by President Trump to undermine legal immigration.

headline: Triumphant Cry
abstract: Trenton Charlson’s puzzle takes its own advice.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The funniest thing about today’s Trenton Charlson grid is that it’s only a couple of letters shy of a pangram — seems that “X” and lowly little “F” could have been “sneaked” in someplace. If you’re a letter person who notices such things, then you recognize Mr. Charlson as a kindred spirit, and you’re probably exulting over the diagonal run up the middle today. But there are also two excellent spans and a number of interesting juxtapositions.

headline: Corrections: October 5, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 5, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS

headline: Quotation of the Day: Afghan Town’s First Female Mayor Awaits Her Assassination
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 5, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t believe I could get this job, because I am a person with neither political power nor gold. But when I did, I knew I wanted to be here and try to change society.”

headline: Episode 5: The Land of Our Fathers, Part 1
abstract: More than a century and a half after the promise of 40 acres and a mule, the story of black land ownership in America remains one of loss and dispossession.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Stitcher

headline: British Man and Filipino Woman Abducted in Philippines
abstract: The police said gunmen took a British man and his Filipino wife from a resort in the southern Philippines, where Islamic militants have been known to kidnap foreigners.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A British businessman and his Filipino wife have been abducted in the southern Philippines, where Islamic militants have been known to seize foreigners and missionaries for ransom, the police and the military said on Saturday.

headline: Five-Alarm Fire at Bronx Apartment Building Injures 10
abstract: Two people, including a firefighter, were seriously injured in the blaze on the Grand Concourse, which took more than three hours to bring under control.
lead_paragraph: A five-alarm fire engulfed the top floor of a Bronx apartment building on Friday night, injuring 10 people — two of them seriously — and prompting more than 200 firefighters to respond, the authorities said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Austin City Limits’ and ‘The Talented Mr. Ripley’
abstract: Gary Clark Jr. opens the 45th season of the live concert series. And Matt Damon plays the infamous literary grifter in the 1999 film, which is available to stream.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN CITY LIMITS 11 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). The blues guitarist and Austin native Gary Clark Jr. opens the 45th season of this long-running live concert series, performing music from his latest album, “This Land,” which was a New York Times Critic’s Pick. Later on in the season, music fans can catch hourlong performances from Maggie Rogers, H.E.R. and Vampire Weekend.

headline: An Eerie Quiet and Dread as Hong Kong Face-Mask Ban Takes Effect
abstract: After a night of arson and vandalism, the financial hub braces for more unrest and ponders the future with anxiety.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With its subways paralyzed and its shopping malls shuttered, Hong Kong was anxious and eerily quiet on Saturday.

headline: China Masters Political Propaganda for the Instagram Age
abstract: Leveraging celebrities, the know-how of tech companies and images built for social media, the Communist Party can effectively stir patriotism among the youth.
lead_paragraph: Lu Yingxin has been singing “My People, My Country” for the past week. An earnest propaganda anthem from 1985, the song typically wouldn’t stand a chance against Taylor Swift, K-pop and other modern tunes the 18-year-old college student and her friends like to listen to.

headline: Australian Couple Detained in Iran Are Released, Authorities Say
abstract: Last month, the Australian government confirmed that the couple were among three of its citizens detained in Iran. The third has been sentenced to prison.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — An Australian couple detained in Iran for several months have been released and are being reunited with their families after charges against them were dropped, the Australian authorities confirmed on Saturday.

headline: China Loves News About Trump’s Controversies. Not This Time.
abstract: Since President Trump called for China to investigate the Bidens, Chinese media and officials have been notably muted. They have reason for caution, said experts.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Since a trade war broke out with the United States, China’s state-run media has not held back from commenting on the swirl of political controversies around President Trump. At least, not until now.

headline: Why French Montana Wears Robes and Slathers on Baby Oil
abstract: “I’m still jet-lagged from last year,” said the rapper and producer, who is about to release a new studio album.
lead_paragraph: French Montana, 34, knows how to hustle. Born in Morocco, raised in the South Bronx and now living in Calabasas, Calif., he made a name for himself with self-released mixtapes, before he collaborated with rappers including Rick Ross, P. Diddy and Drake. On the eve of the release of his third studio album, “Montana,” he talked about how he stays fit and healthy, both mentally and physically.

headline: New Yorkers Will Have to Wait for an East River Pool
abstract: Turns out public projects are hard to complete. For now, enjoy this light sculpture.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, media outlets began heralding a fantastical urban design project to be built in New York. A group of young designers and architects had dreamed up plans for a floating, self-filtering swimming pool on the East River, allowing New Yorkers to swim legally and safely in the polluted waterway for the first time in 70 years. The pool would be roughly Olympic size (164 feet by 164 feet) and shaped like a giant plus sign. It would be named Plus Pool, rendered as +POOL.

headline: Help! I’m Stuck on a Train and My Plane Is Leaving Without Me
abstract: In a new Travel column, Sarah Firshein aims to help travelers resolve their thorniest travel disasters. This week, she investigates a flight that got away.
lead_paragraph: Sadly, you’re right — you did lose the value of your Icelandair ticket. But despite what you were told, it’s not because you checked in online. You could theoretically check in from Mars and still change your flight afterward. What matters most is your whereabouts — and ticket status — when the plane actually departs.

headline: Playing Catch a Killer With a Room Full of Sleuths
abstract: At a forensic conference in California, law enforcement officials grappled with how to avoid destroying one of the field’s biggest innovations in decades.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — On a recent afternoon, under two giant chandeliers, some of the key people responsible for the future of crime and privacy tried to solve a murder.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has a Heart Attack: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Here are seven things that happened in the presidential campaign this week.
lead_paragraph: It was another busy week in Washington and on the campaign trail. Here is our quick rundown of what happened in the 2020 race.

headline: ‘A Caricature of the Patriarchy’: Argentine Feminists Remake Tango
abstract: A group of activists is trying to make tango less dogmatic about traditional gender roles, and more assertive about rooting out sexual harassment and assault.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Liliana Furió’s ruby red flat shoes glided across the dance floor in swift, assured moves, making her baggy pants sway gently.

headline: Hurricane Chasers: An Immigrant Work Force on the Trail of Extreme Weather
abstract: Itinerant, largely undocumented workers devoted to hurricane recovery in the U.S. have endured shabby housing and haphazard payments.
lead_paragraph: CALLAWAY, Fla. — They arrived by the hundreds last year after Hurricane Michael sliced through the Florida Panhandle, packing 160-mile-per-hour winds that snapped pine trees in half, mangled steel posts, ripped off roofs and upended people’s lives. Without electricity, potable water or reliable accommodation, a rapid-response labor force got to work carting away the wreckage.

headline: Taliban and U.S. Envoy Meet for First Time Since Peace Talks Collapsed
abstract: The discussions, in Pakistan, came after Afghan elections during which the insurgents mounted widespread attacks aimed at derailing the electoral process.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban officials have met in Pakistan with the top American diplomat who recently led peace negotiations with them, current and former members of the insurgent group said on Saturday.

headline: A Classical Duo ‘Nerding Out’ on the Cosmos
abstract: So many overtones were there when they met backstage at the Blue Note jazz club.
lead_paragraph: Larisa Martinez and Joshua Bell were married Oct. 5 at their home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. David Brooks, a friend of the couple and a New York Times columnist based in Washington who is a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: They Believed in Each Other
abstract: They clicked on their first date. But broke up after a second date when they began discussing her Christianity and his atheism. But their connection was obvious.
lead_paragraph: Demetrice Deshay Elmore and Joseph Joy LeMieux are to be married Oct. 6. Grady D. King, a minister of the Church of Christ, is to officiate at the San Sophia Overlook, an events space at the Telluride Ski and Golf Resort in Telluride, Colo.

headline: ‘Magical Chemistry’ Quick-Brewed in a Coffee Shop
abstract: They sat alone at different tables in a neighborhood coffee shop. Their connection was immediate when he walked over to her.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Angulo and Staff Sgt. Maxamillian Alexander Dutton were married Oct. 2 at Waterfront Park in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Jeffrey L. Maszal, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: He Was Canada’s ‘Clark Kent.’ Then Police Say He Went Rogue.
abstract: Cameron Ortis, a veteran of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, was accused of passing on or offering secrets in 2015, and then gathering information last year with the intent to do it again.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The trail that led investigators to one of Canada’s elite cybercrime experts, a quiet analyst in the national police, began with an email.

headline: Garden of Solace
abstract: I found a place to help me process decades of hidden grief.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, during my family’s third move in six years, I felt like I was slowly unraveling. My husband had lost his job in Austin, Tex., and was offered a new one in the Philadelphia suburbs, so we trucked our two children, two cats and an embarrassing amount of stuff cross-country to start our lives over from scratch. I tried to sound optimistic to our new neighbors: Moving is hard, but we’re excited to put down roots here. I’ve never lived in suburbia, but I love the giant trees. Inwardly, I howled: What have we done? I’ve lost all my friends! Screw the trees!

headline: In Chinatown, Rampage Against Sleeping Homeless Men Leaves 4 Dead
abstract: A fifth victim was in critical condition in the Manhattan attack, and a 24-year-old suspect was in custody.
lead_paragraph: The killer first struck just before 2 a.m. on Saturday on a quiet spot on East Broadway in Chinatown, sneaking up on three homeless men as they slept on a sidewalk and bludgeoning them to death with a rusty, three-foot metal bar, the police said.

headline: For Braves and Cardinals, the Managers Are Company Men
abstract: Brian Snitker has been in Atlanta’s system since the Carter administration, and Mike Shildt has never worked for another pro baseball organization — rarities in the modern game.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For just a few moments on Thursday afternoon, in a makeshift room of microphones and klieg lights and portable air-conditioners, the baseball men’s voices seemed to catch.

headline: Deaths Mount as Protests Catch Iraqi Government Off Guard
abstract: Protesters demanded an end to widespread corruption. The Iraqi government’s response was to call in security forces, who killed at least 91 people.
lead_paragraph: When peaceful protesters poured into the Iraqi streets this past week, demanding an end to widespread government corruption, unemployment and a lack of basic services, the government was caught off guard.

headline: The Sexist Undertones of Wedding Marketing
abstract: Many brides, not so much grooms, see a presumptive and sexist slant on social media and online marketing, before and after their wedding.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Vazquez, a 36-year-old marketing manager in New York City, had decided to keep her last name after she got married in June. But not everyone seemed to be on board with these plans.

headline: Is 100 gecs the End of Pop, or a New Beginning?
abstract: One of the year’s most unlikely breakthroughs is a duo that makes disorienting, genre-jumbling music.
lead_paragraph: One of 2019’s unlikeliest underground-music breakthroughs has been 100 gecs, the duo of Dylan Brady and Laura Les, who make high-energy, quasi-slapstick, genre-jumbling electro-pop with shards of screamo, dubstep, glitch and big-room club music. It’s fascinating and disorienting, and also some of the savviest pop music of the year.

headline: A Provocateur of the Hong Kong Protests Gains Growing Stature
abstract: In a city roiled by political animus, Junius Ho, a pro-Beijing lawmaker, is gleefully fueling the divide by praising the police and demonizing the protesters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — From afar, the red brick sidewalk along King’s Road in Hong Kong appears to be covered with a mottled white carpet that stretches for dozens of yards. Closer up, the white reveals itself to be a mosaic made up of sheets of paper glued to the pavement, each featuring a bespectacled man with a self-confident smile.

headline: Can I Make My Co-op Change the Bad Lobby Art?
abstract: A co-op board can choose whatever décor it wants. But it would be wise to get a second opinion.
lead_paragraph: Q: Our Upper West Side co-op decided that we should have a rotating display of art in our lobby, with works chosen by a committee of three. We’re a large co-op with hundreds of residents. While some of the pieces have been O.K., others have been awful. Bad art isn’t just an affront to the senses, it’s bad business. Many of us would prefer to have permanent décor, but neither the board nor the managing agent seem willing to listen, and I was told I couldn’t circulate a petition. What can we do to make our voices heard?

headline: In Qatar, Track and Field’s Championships Limp to the Finish
abstract: Overwhelming heat and underwhelming crowds have created a memorable world championships, but not for the right reasons.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — There are at least 30 million reasons to explain how Qatar persuaded global track and field’s governing body to hand over its most prized event, the biennial world championships, to a tiny Persian Gulf state with the world’s largest natural gas reserves.

headline: Jumbo Shrimp and Lobster Tails: D.C.’s Fund-Raising Hot Spots
abstract: Political campaigns spend a small fortune on food, drink, staff and other fees when they raise money in the nation’s capital. These are the top 11 spots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Night after night in Washington, you can find lobbyists and deep-pocketed donors plowing through chafing-dish chow at political fund-raisers held at the city’s hot spots, like James Beard-awarded outposts and waterfront behemoths. Filings with the Federal Election Commission, in which federal candidates report campaign financial activity, show what a big business it is.

headline: Alison Roman’s Tangy Sheet-Pan Chicken Is #1
abstract: Make her recipe for vinegar chicken with crushed olive dressing.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, make Alison Roman’s vinegar chicken with crushed olive dressing (above) — our most popular recipe right now — Parmesan white bean soup, linguine with clam sauce or any of recipes in the collection below.

headline: These Republicans May Not Endorse an Impeachment Inquiry. But They Aren’t Saying No.
abstract: Republicans like Representative Mark Amodei of Nevada are balancing the risk of President Trump’s wrath and the knowledge that history will hold them accountable for their actions.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Representative Mark Amodei was not prepared for the backlash from his fellow Republicans when he said Congress needed to “follow the facts” and look into whether President Trump should be impeached.

headline: Diahann Carroll Embodied Glamour and Substance
abstract: Early in her career the “Dynasty” star was criticized for being oblivious to issues facing everyday black Americans. This couldn’t have been further from the truth.
lead_paragraph: I am an ’80s kid. I grew up in a New Jersey suburb that, to my mind’s eye, bore more than a passing resemblance to the fictional town in “Stranger Things.” While I enjoyed shows like “Square Pegs” and movies like “The Breakfast Club,” I was perplexed by how homogeneous they were, especially since my high school had nearly an even balance of black and white kids.

headline: Max Scherzer Stifles the Dodgers in a Rare Relief Outing
abstract: The Nationals treated Game 2 of their National League division series as a must-win, calling on their 35-year-old starter to pitch out of the bullpen and help tie the series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Max Scherzer said he had not even worked up a sweat when he trotted out of the Washington Nationals’ bullpen late Friday night. He’s used to warming up when the sun is still out, after all.

headline: The ‘Never Trump’ Coalition That Decided Eh, Never Mind, He’s Fine
abstract: They signed open letters, dedicated a special magazine issue to criticism of him and swore he would tear at the fabric of this nation. Now they have become the president’s strongest defenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2016, Erick Erickson could not have been clearer. Donald Trump was “a racist” and “a fascist.” It was no wonder, Mr. Erickson wrote, that “so many people with swastikas in their Twitter profile pics” supported him. “I will not vote for Donald Trump. Ever,” he insisted, adding his voice to the chorus of Never Trump Republicans.

headline: You Don’t Have to Give Until It Hurts
abstract: Adam Grant on why we need to rethink “The Giving Tree,” and more from NYT Parenting this week.
lead_paragraph: This week, Adam Grant and Allison Sweet Grant told us we need to talk about “The Giving Tree.” Why? Because “if you assume the story is about generosity, it’s easy to learn the wrong lessons: that it’s O.K. for a child to take selfishly, and that adults should give until it hurts — and keep giving until they literally have nothing left to offer.” Welp. Speaking of giving all of yourself to all of the things, we published our guide to time management for new parents who go back to work.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop stomps out some bugs in today’s Split Decisions puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — This species of Sunday Variety puzzle is growing on me, I guess, like a fungus. It is gratifying to encounter something in life and realize after several iterations that somehow you are getting better at it, without really “putting your shoulder into it,” as it were. Like moving to a walk-up apartment and realizing after a few months that you do not even notice the hike upstairs. Anyway, consider this encouragement if you are struggling with today’s Fred Piscop construction — trust me, if you keep at it you will get the hang of it too.

headline: Biden Faced His Biggest Challenge, and Struggled to Form a Response
abstract: As Trump made unfounded allegations about Biden and his son, the former vice president was torn over what to do. He now looks more vulnerable than at any point in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign was under attack, and he and his advisers were torn over what to do.

headline: Pieces of the Health Care Puzzle
abstract: Readers discuss private insurance, price transparency and regulations affecting doctors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Happened in the Trump Impeachment Inquiry This Week
abstract: Trump requests China’s help. Read the whistle-blower complaint at the heart of the inquiry. See who’s been subpoenaed. Ukraine, Ukraine, Ukraine. And more.
lead_paragraph: Developments in the House impeachment inquiry were fast and furious this week. It was hard to keep up, even for those of us who are paid to do it. Here’s a breakdown of important articles you may have missed.

headline: The Greening of Paris Makes Its Mayor More Than a Few Enemies
abstract: As Anne Hidalgo declares war on the car, drivers rage at the disruptions, but supporters credit her with preparing Paris for a hotter future.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — All over Paris, streets have been dug up and cut in two, and old paving stones overturned to build dozens of miles of bike lanes. A major urban highway has been closed to cars and turned over to pedestrians. Paris is readying feverishly for an emergency that, in the minds of the city and its mayor, is already here.

headline: Senior Border Patrol Agent Faces Charges of Sexually Assaulting Colleague
abstract: The assault accusation is at the center of a #MeToo moment for the nation’s border-security force.
lead_paragraph: The Border Patrol has struggled for years to recruit more women and help them advance through the agency’s ranks, which have long been dominated by men. Only about 5 percent of the nation’s nearly 20,000 Border Patrol agents are women, and it was not until 2017 that a woman was named the Border Patrol’s acting chief, a first in the agency’s nearly century-long history.

headline: The Ukrainian Ex-Prosecutor Behind the Impeachment Furor
abstract: President Trump’s allies sought help from a prosecutor with no formal legal training and a long history of wielding the law in personal battles.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As soon as he got the invitation from Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, it was abundantly clear to him what Mr. Trump’s allies were after.

headline: The W.N.B.A. Finals’ Biggest Star May Be on the Sun: Jonquel Jones
abstract: Jones is stacking points for Connecticut, hitting 3s and calling into question what some expected to be a coronation for Elena Delle Donne and the Washington Mystics.
lead_paragraph: Jonquel Jones smiled mischievously when asked if she and Curt Miller, head coach of the Connecticut Sun, had discussed her paltry eight shot attempts in the team’s loss to the Washington Mystics the day before in the first game of the W.N.B.A. finals.

headline: Earthquake in Bay Area Shakes San Francisco
abstract: The quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 3.5 and originated about five miles below the earth’s surface, struck just southwest of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The Bay Area was jolted Saturday morning when a minor earthquake struck about 10 miles from San Francisco.

headline: ‘Harvey Weinstein Told Me He Liked Chinese Girls’
abstract: Why it took me more than 20 years to tell my #MeToo story.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein told me he liked Chinese girls. He liked them because they were discreet, he said — because they knew how to keep a secret. Hours later, he attempted to rape me.

headline: World Leaders Once Made Miracles, and Can Again
abstract: Global programs founded in the 2000s have saved tens of millions of lives. We need new efforts today.
lead_paragraph: We need a little uplift, a reminder that although world leaders today from Washington to London to Beijing may be dishonest vandals, it doesn’t have to be that way.

headline: Now the Rich Want Your Pity, Too
abstract: If the wealthy are so stressed out, whose fault is that?
lead_paragraph: Seems like it’s getting tough at the top. The winners in America’s meritocracy are suffering. Children in affluent homes are being hothoused through childhood, stress-tested into elite schools and colleges, and pushed to the brink of suicide or breakdown. Their highly educated mothers and fathers are putting in long hours in their chosen professions: money-rich, perhaps, but time-poor.

headline: Touch of Evil
abstract: Donald Trump drags us down to Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Forget it, America. It’s Chinatown.

headline: Rudy Giuliani Welcomes You To Eastern Europe
abstract: So much about the Trump administration seems pulled from the playbook of a post-Soviet kleptocracy.
lead_paragraph: The message of much of Kremlin propaganda is not to showcase Russia as a beacon of progress, but to prove that Western politics is just as rotten as President Vladimir Putin’s. We may have corruption, the argument goes, but so does the West; our democracy is rigged, but so is theirs.

headline: When Trump Gets His Alligator
abstract: In the Ukraine scandal, the guardrails protecting the president from his worst impulses broke down.
lead_paragraph: If Watergate became, for Richard Nixon, a cancer on his presidency, then Donald Trump’s Ukraine scandal is shaping up as something different: It’s an alligator in his White House.

headline: How to Sell Your Soul to Donald Trump
abstract: Mike Pompeo is just the latest lackey to teach a master class in moral surrender.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way that Mike Pompeo actually venerates Donald Trump. I doubt he even likes the president much.

headline: Watch Out, America — The Supreme Court Is Back in Session
abstract: And conservatives could be the big winners.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Supreme Court will begin hearing cases in its first complete term since the retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy, and the confirmation of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, gave the court a newly emboldened right-wing majority.

headline: Pompeo Defends Trump’s Ukraine Conspiracy Theory
abstract: In Athens, the American secretary of state dismissed the House Democrats’ impeachment inquiry and the political drama that it has sparked as a “silly gotcha game.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo defiantly insisted on Saturday in Greece that the Trump administration was right to ask Ukrainian officials to investigate claims of election interference in the 2016 American presidential campaign, bolstering a widely debunked conspiracy theory that had already been dismissed by his own diplomatic envoy.

headline: Kurt Volker, Ukraine and a Turbulent End in the Trump Administration
abstract: Friends say that Mr. Volker, who was President Trump’s envoy to Ukraine, was in an impossible situation. But they also say he was papering over his role.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Please don’t publish this letter,” Kurt D. Volker, a former career foreign service officer, pleaded in 2016 with Eliot A. Cohen and Eric Edelman, two former Republican officials leading a “Never Trump” letter-writing movement.

headline: In Paris Knife Attack, Police Ask How They Missed a Killer in Their Midst
abstract: Angry calls for a shake-up emerged after prosecutors said a Muslim police technician who killed four colleagues had left a trail of warning signs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Evidence that the Paris police department missed warning signs about an employee who slashed four colleagues to death at its headquarters on Thursday is prompting demands for a leadership shake-up.

headline: Woman ‘Consumed’ by Columbine and Oklahoma City Killings Had 24 Pipe Bombs, Police Say
abstract: The authorities also discovered numerous guns, knives and material on mass killings in the Florida home of Michelle Kolts, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida woman obsessed with the Columbine High School massacre and the Oklahoma City bombing was arrested after her parents discovered two dozen pipe bombs in her bedroom, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Hard Times Have Pakistani Hindus Looking to India, Where Some Find Only Disappointment
abstract: As Prime Minister Narendra Modi recasts India as a Hindu nation, Pakistani Hindus are migrating there in greater numbers. But many find hardship once they arrive.
lead_paragraph: JODHPUR, India — By the time an angry Muslim mob stormed the local Hindu school and ransacked an adjacent temple a few weeks ago, many members of Pakistan’s dwindling Hindu minority had already been wondering whether it was worth trying to stay in a country where they felt increasingly unsafe.

headline: Texas Stays Execution of Jewish Man After Judge Is Accused of Anti-Semitism
abstract: A member of the “Texas Seven” received the stay after the judge was accused of using racist and anti-Semitic language about the defendants.
lead_paragraph: For more than 15 years on death row, Randy Halprin filed challenge after challenge to his sentence. The denials began to stack up.

headline: A.L.D.S. Game 2: How the Yankees Beat the Twins
abstract: Didi Gregorius broke out of his slump with a grand slam and Masahiro Tanaka was dominant on the mound as the Yankees cruised to a two-games-to-none lead in the A.L.D.S.
lead_paragraph: From 2016 to 2018, Didi Gregorius was a cornerstone for the Yankees. He played slick defense at his demanding shortstop position, improved his plate discipline and smashed at least 20 home runs each year, a crucial left-handed counterbalance in a Yankees’ lineup heavy on right-handers.

headline: First All-Female Spacewalk Is Back On, NASA Says
abstract: The mission was canceled in March after the agency said it did not have two properly fitted spacesuits readily available.
lead_paragraph: The first spacewalk to be conducted entirely by women is scheduled for Oct. 21, NASA announced, nearly seven months after an all-female spacewalk was canceled because two properly fitted spacesuits were not readily available.

headline: U.S. Nuclear Talks With North Korea Break Down in Hours
abstract: The State Department says the United States brought “creative ideas’’ to the talks. The North Koreans say the Americans arrived “empty-handed.”
lead_paragraph: The first negotiations in eight months between the Trump administration and North Korea aimed at breaking the logjam over dismantling the North’s nuclear program broke down only hours after they began in Stockholm on Saturday, the North Koreans said.

headline: Initial Public Offerings
abstract: Howard Barkin and Victor Barocas play the market.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — All work and no play makes a crossword columnist punchy and weird, and I’m about to go on my first real vacation this year, so if you are here because you are looking for something sub rosa and complex about this very gorgeously engineered Barkin/Barocas grid, well, come sit by me. I spent the good part of a sunny weekend afternoon trying to connect all the dots, and now I think I might have lost my mind completely.

headline: Top Biden Donors Gather Amid Storm Clouds Over Campaign
abstract: Now fourth in the Democratic money chase and under fire from President Trump, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is increasingly dependent on his top donors, many of whom met in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Leading donors for Joseph R. Biden Jr. convened this weekend for their first donor retreat since he announced his candidacy and struck a determined posture as Mr. Biden’s campaign found itself under assault from President Trump, losing its clear front-runner status and lapped in the money chase by multiple Democratic rivals, most notably Senator Elizabeth Warren.

headline: Mar-a-Lago Won’t Host Anti-Muslim Group’s Gala, Trump Organization Says
abstract: The group, ACT for America, is considered the largest anti-Muslim group in the United States. It had planned its annual banquet at the president’s club in Florida.
lead_paragraph: An anti-Muslim organization had planned to host its annual gala next month at Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club in Palm Beach, Fla., before an apparent reversal on Sunday, a day after news reports appeared about the event.

headline: Universal Resort Costumed Character Made White Supremacy Sign, Family Says
abstract: The actor, who was dressed as a “Despicable Me” character and posed for photographs with two biracial children, made an upside-down “O.K.” sign with his fingers.
lead_paragraph: Meeting the costumed characters of the animated movie franchise “Despicable Me” could have been a highlight of a family’s visit to Universal Orlando Resort.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tango: Passionate, Slinky, Sexist. And Changing.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 6, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Tango is a reflection of what is happening in our culture, and for a long time our culture has allowed men to touch you when they want to and if you complain you’re dismissed as crazy.”

headline: Corrections: October 6, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, October 6, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS & LEISURE

headline: Calli Higgins, Lucas Hafeli
abstract: The bride is a software engineer and the groom is an architect. They met through a mutual friend in New York and were married in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Calli Erin Higgins and Lucas Paul Hafeli were married Oct. 4 at Race and Religious, an events space in New Orleans. Ashleigh Ide, who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Ashley Puscas, Gregory Hildebrand
abstract: The couple met at a Halloween fund-raiser in New York in 2015, and two years later, she started to look at him differently.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Kathryn Puscas and Gregory Ryan Hildebrand were married Oct. 5 in Killington, Vt. Canon Lee Alison Crawford performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour, where she is the vicar, with Victor E. Puscas Jr., an uncle of the bride who is a Roman Catholic deacon, taking part.

headline: Carly Daitch, Andrew Lemchen
abstract: The couple met at Lehigh University, from which they graduated. the bride is a structural engineer. The groom is an orthodontist.
lead_paragraph: Carly Eve Daitch and Dr. Andrew Taylor Lemchen were married Oct. 5 at Granite Links, a golf club and events space in Quincy, Mass. Cantor Hollis Schachner officiated with Rabbi Andy Vogel taking part.

headline: Alice Rha, Robert Ames
abstract: The couple met at Brown University, from which both graduated.
lead_paragraph: Alice Desdemona Rha and Robert Landau Ames were married Oct. 5 in Manhattan. Lily S. Axelrod, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries for this event, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York City.

headline: McKell Forbes, Enrique Lopez Salazar
abstract: The couple met briefly in 2018 at the Latter-day Saints church in New York, and then matched on a dating app for members of the faith.
lead_paragraph: McKell Lyn Forbes and Enrique Xavier Lopez Salazar were married Oct. 4. David O. Sutton performed the sealing ceremony and officiated at the Hartford Connecticut Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Farmington, Conn.

headline: Heidi Howland, Cameron Akbari
abstract: The couple, who met two years ago in Washington, D.C., were married at the Mayflower Inn in Washington, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Lauri Howland and Dr. Cameron Akbari were married Oct. 5 at the Mayflower Inn in Washington, Conn. The Rev. Melinda Keck, a retired minister of the First Congregational Church of Kent in Kent, Conn., officiated

headline: Natalie Cappello, Robert Agresta
abstract: The couple were introduced four years ago by a mutual friend in New York. They married in a church on the banks of Lake Como in Lombardy, Italy.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Marie Cappello and Robert Anthony Agresta were married Oct. 4 at Chiesa di San Lorenzo in Lombardy, Italy. The Rev. Luca Giansante, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Grace Eubank, Ryan Beck
abstract: They met at the Great GoogaMooga, a music and food festival in Brooklyn in 2013, and bumped into each other several more times over the next year.
lead_paragraph: Grace Harriette Eubank and Ryan Joseph Beck were married Oct. 4 in Brooklyn. Ahri Findling, a friend of the couple ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at the Picnic House in Prospect Park.

headline: Christa Heavey, Timothy Yeskoo
abstract: The couple met seven years ago in graduate school at Stanford.
lead_paragraph: Christa Colleen Heavey and Timothy Wolf Yeskoo were married Oct. 5 at the Lake Placid Club, a resort and golf club in Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. Laurin C. McArthur, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, with Dmitriy V. Burdzhalov, a friend of the couple, taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Hannah Ferenchick, Rohan Policherla
abstract: The couple met four years ago when both were medical residents at Detroit Receiving Hospital. They also married in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Hannah Ruth Baker Ferenchick and Dr. Rohan Krishna Policherla were married Oct. 5 at the Westin Book Cadillac hotel in Detroit. Richard C. Preston, a Universal Life minister, officiated. Later that day, at the hotel, the couple took part in a ceremony incorporating Hindu wedding traditions, led by Purohit Achary, a Hindu priest.

headline: Patrick Roberts, Jose Del Real
abstract: Mr. Roberts, a political scientist, and Mr. Del Real, a reporter, eloped in a ceremony in Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Soren Roberts and Jose A. Del Real were married Sept. 30 in Leidig Meadow at Yosemite National Park in California. Autrey Nassar, a Universal Life minister, officiated on the banks of the Merced River in Yosemite Valley.

headline: Melanie DeFiore, Jeremy Gibbs
abstract: The couple met in 2013 through a mutual friend at a bar in New York. The bride thought the groom was cute, and after an introduction, he asked her out on a date.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Elise DeFiore and Jeremy Cramer Gibbs were married Oct. 5 at Second, an events space in Manhattan. Cantor Nancy Bach officiated.

headline: Tony Frouge, Brian Streater
abstract: The couple met eight years ago in Manhattan through a mutual friend.
lead_paragraph: Tony Michael Frouge and Brian Douglas Streater were married Oct. 5 at the Hoxton, Williamsburg, a hotel in Brooklyn. Judge Deborah A. Batts of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

headline: Katherine Cunningham, Mark Rutledge
abstract: The couple met in 2017 through the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel and married in Garrison, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Marie Cunningham and Mark Anthony Rutledge were married Oct. 4 at the Garrison, an events space in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. David F. Telfort, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Johanna Paine, Andrew Buchan
abstract: The couple, who met in New York in 2012, were married at the home of the groom’s parents in Sharon, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Johanna Adams Paine and Dr. Andrew John Buchan were married Oct. 5. Maureen Abi Ghanem, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the groom’s parents in Sharon, Conn.

headline: Rebecca Tanenbaum, William Lacey IV
abstract: The couple, both from South Carolina, met a year ago on Bumble. She is in public relations; he is a barbecue pitmaster.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Jonas Tanenbaum and William Henry Lacey IV were married Oct. 5 at the Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, S.C. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

headline: Anna Meacham, Said Nashashibi
abstract: The couple met through the League, a dating app, in 2016. They were married at the Museum of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: Anna Weedon Meacham and Said Labib Nashashibi were married Oct. 5 at the Museum of the City of New York. Adani Illo Almoustapha, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

headline: Caitlin O’Toole, Hazel Payne
abstract: Their New York-South Australia romance took off after they met on a dating app, and they said it was “love at first type.”
lead_paragraph: Caitlin O’Toole and Hazel Ann Payne were married Oct. 5 in Jefferson Market Garden in New York. Suanne Bonan, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Mark Munro, Chirag Chotalia
abstract: The couple matched on three different dating apps in October 2016 and had their first date on Halloween night at bar in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Mark Stanford Munro and Chirag Rajesh Chotalia were married Oct. 5 at a private residence in Marfa, Texas. Geetanjali Dhillion, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Jessica DiRocco, Rocco Sainato
abstract: The couple met through Hinge, a dating app, and had their first date in 2015 at a bar in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Susan DiRocco and Rocco Michael Sainato were married Sept. 30 at Brooklyn Borough Hall. Huiling Zheng, a staff member of the city clerk’s office, officiated. On Oct. 5, Jake D. Bertanza, a friend of the couple, led them in a ceremony that included an exchange of vows and rings in an events space at Grouse Mountain Resorts in North Vancouver, British Columbia.

headline: Witness in Amber Guyger’s Trial Is Fatally Shot, Lawyer Says
abstract: Officials have not publicly identified a motive or suspect in the shooting of Joshua Brown, who provided key testimony about the 2018 killing of Botham Jean by a Dallas police officer.
lead_paragraph: A witness who delivered key testimony in the trial of Amber Guyger — the white former Dallas police officer convicted this past week in the murder of an unarmed black man, Botham Jean — was fatally shot on Friday night, a lawyer for Mr. Jean’s family said.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Mr. Robot’ and ‘Peaky Blinders’
abstract: Elliot Alderson prepares to bring down a shadowy mastermind in the final season of “Mr. Robot.” And the criminally enterprising Shelby family returns for a new season of “Peaky Blinders.”
lead_paragraph: MR. ROBOT 10 p.m. on USA. After tanking the world’s economy, and then attempting to undo that hack with a bit of code, Elliot Alderson (Rami Malek) has set his sights on taking down Whiterose, the shadowy leader of the Dark Army who has been manipulating him and his gang of vigilantes for her own gain. At the end of Season 3, “characters who thought they were smashing capitalism, winning back their family, bringing back their dead parent or fighting the good fight against cyberterrorism, learned that they were essentially pawns being pushed around a chessboard,” Jeremy Egner wrote in his finale recap for The New York Times. Armed with that information, and a hunger for retribution, the hooded hacker will reunite with his other half, Mr. Robot, working in tandem to destroy “the top one percent of the top one percent.”

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’: Matthew Broderick Joins the Trump Team
abstract: The actor portrayed Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in this week’s episode, which was hosted by Phoebe Waller-Bridge and featured Taylor Swift as musical guest.
lead_paragraph: Given time, “Saturday Night Live” will eventually find a celebrity impersonator to play every member of the Trump administration. This weekend, “S.N.L.” spun its wheel of fortune (a.k.a. Lorne Michaels’s Rolodex) and landed on Matthew Broderick, who appeared as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a sketch about the White House’s ongoing response to the Ukraine affair and the impeachment inquiry into President Trump.

headline: ‘I Sat and Sketched Matisse’s Sculpture of a Woman Named Jeannette’
abstract: Skipping school to go to Manhattan, help with untied laces and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Extinction Rebellion Takes Aim at Fashion
abstract: XR says it is the fastest growing direct action climate movement in history. And it has the fashion business in its sights.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month, on the final day of London Fashion Week, hundreds of black-clad demonstrators gathered in Trafalgar Square to embark on what they called “a funeral march for fashion.”

headline: Hong Kong Rallies Turn Violent After Thousands Defy Face Mask Ban
abstract: The rallies were the first significant public gatherings since the ban took effect the day before, and a test of the government’s resolve to stop months of protests.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A jittery Hong Kong was again engulfed by clashes between protesters and the police on Sunday, hours after tens of thousands of people marched in a largely peaceful show of force against a contentious ban on face masks.

headline: The Amazon Is Still Burning. Blame Beef.
abstract: Welcome to the lawless heart of the Brazilian Amazon. Here, cattle ranchers and loggers — emboldened by President Jair Bolsonaro — are clearing and burning huge swaths of rainforest every day in the name of progress.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the lawless heart of the Brazilian Amazon. Here, cattle ranchers and loggers — emboldened by President Jair Bolsonaro — are clearing and burning huge swaths of rainforest every day in the name of progress.

headline: Threats and Promises in Brazil’s Lawless Amazon
abstract: In Brazil’s state of Pará, cattle ranchers and loggers — emboldened by President Jair Bolsonaro — are clearing and burning huge swaths of rainforest every day. All in the name of progress.
lead_paragraph: NOVO PROGRESSO, BRAZIL — In early August, Adecio Piran wrote an article for this Amazon town’s news website announcing a “Day of Fire,” to be started on August 10. The post suggested a coordinated criminal effort among local landowners and cattle ranchers to burn newly cleared rainforest — much of it on public land. The unnamed organizers of the collective action, Mr. Piran wrote, wanted to draw the attention of President Jair Bolsonaro.

headline: The Phones Are Alive, With the Sounds of Katie Couric
abstract: Instagram! iHeartRadio! Email! The veteran television personality is back with a desire for your little screens.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Beyond a thicket of dahlias, Katie Couric climbed through a tangle of vines to pick a squat little eggplant. Each week during the summer in this beach hamlet, she takes inventory of her vegetable garden, and on a mid-September Saturday, the patch of soil was bursting with shishitos, jalapeños, and cherry tomatoes.

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: Ben Lerner’s new novel, Lupita Nyong’o’s reading habits and more.
lead_paragraph: We take the weekend to highlight recent books coverage:

headline: ‘Slop It On!’: Unicorn Spit Beguiles the Etsy Crowd
abstract: Ready to go beyond bedazzling? Here’s an iridescent scented paint substance.
lead_paragraph: BONNER SPRINGS, Kan. — “There’s no such thing as perfect,” said Michelle Nicole, wearing a light-up unicorn headband and standing behind a white table with rainbow-colored balloons arching above her. On a balmy morning not long ago, in an art studio about 10 minutes outside Kansas City, 120 attendees from as far away as Canada were gathered. They had each snagged a ticket to the second annual Unicorn Spit Extravaganza.

headline: Italy’s Connection to the Russia Investigation, Explained
abstract: A Trump adviser met a professor in Rome whose actions figured into the opening of the Russia inquiry in 2016. Now the attorney general is reviewing it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr has said he is reviewing the origins of the Russia investigation. As part of the review, Mr. Barr met recently with officials in Italy, where in 2016 a Trump campaign adviser met Joseph Mifsud, a professor whose actions figured prominently into the F.B.I.’s rationale for opening the Russia inquiry.

headline: Barr and a Top Prosecutor Cast a Wide Net in Reviewing the Russia Inquiry
abstract: The attorney general and a veteran prosecutor, John H. Durham, have charted an unusual course that could bolster President Trump’s pet theories about the Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a jet carrying Attorney General William P. Barr touched down in Rome last month, some diplomats and intelligence officials at the American Embassy were unsure why he had come. They were later surprised, two officials said, to discover that he had circumvented protocols in arranging the trip, where he met with Italian political and intelligence officials.

headline: Why This Ex-Con Mayor Is Running Away From Reporters
abstract: Joe Ganim, the mayor of Connecticut’s largest city, won a disputed primary. Now the state is investigating possible voting irregularities.
lead_paragraph: [Read the election results from Bridgeport and elsewhere.]

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Big Challenge: Winning Black Voters
abstract: African-Americans were essential to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton winning competitive primaries like Ms. Warren faces in 2020. For now, Joe Biden has far deeper support.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — For her most recent rally in South Carolina, Senator Elizabeth Warren chose Clinton College, a historically black institution in this racially diverse city. Her campaign handed out signs reading, “African Americans With Warren.” And in smaller print: “Black issues are American issues.”

headline: Traveling to the Rhythm of Cuba, and Trying to Keep Up
abstract: A reporter and a photographer explain how they picked their stops for a travel article exploring the island nation through its music.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Portugal Prime Minister Is Re-Elected as Socialists Solidify Position
abstract: The Socialists appeared likely to fall short of a majority in Parliament, but Prime Minister António Costa has plenty of leeway to negotiate an alliance with smaller parties and form a new government.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Prime Minister António Costa of Portugal won Sunday’s national election, as voters rewarded his Socialist party for returning the country to robust growth and budgetary health.

headline: Philippine Leader Rodrigo Duterte Says He Has Neuromuscular Disease
abstract: The president revealed that he has a chronic autoimmune ailment that leads to skeletal muscle weakness, and that the disease runs in his family.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has revealed that he has a neuromuscular disease that has led to a slew of medical problems, including making his eye droop.

headline: As the Supreme Court Gets Back to Work, Five Big Cases to Watch
abstract: In its first full term since the arrival of Justice Kavanaugh, the court could issue a number of blockbuster decisions on divisive issues in an election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to start a term that will be studded with major cases on gay and transgender rights, immigration, abortion, guns and religion. The rulings will arrive by June, in the midst of an already divisive presidential campaign.

headline: Impeachment, Supreme Court, Tango: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ginger Baker, Superstar Rock Drummer With Cream, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Teamed with the guitarist Eric Clapton and the bassist Jack Bruce in the band Cream, Mr. Baker helped redefine the role of the drums in rock.
lead_paragraph: Ginger Baker, who helped redefine the role of the drums in rock and became a superstar in the process, died on Sunday in a hospital in southeastern England. He was 80.

headline: The Week in Business: The Markets and Impeachment
abstract: A changed Supreme Court hears a new gay rights case, protests escalate in Hong Kong and new Brexit maneuverings.
lead_paragraph: Before we get started, if you’re craving impeachment updates, you can get the latest with our new Impeachment Briefing newsletter. We’ve got more on the economic impact below — plus news on a victory for college athletes and what to expect from a new term for the Supreme Court.

headline: Kansas City Shooting: 4 Killed and 5 Others Wounded at Bar
abstract: The attack occurred at a small bar in Kansas overnight Sunday, the police said. The motive was not clear and a search for the assailant or assailants was underway.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — One week after he had angrily barged into a small neighborhood bar, seething and belligerent, the man returned, cursing and shouting about gangs. He threw a plastic cup at a bartender who refused to serve him, witnesses said, and fought with a customer before he was escorted out, just as he had been the week before.

headline: In Hong Kong’s Crackdown on Protests, Face Mask Ban May Be the Start
abstract: The ban, punishable by up to a year in prison, was a measured approach. It avoided for now the more extreme options, like a curfew or running courthouses 24 hours a day.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Hong Kong’s leader invoked emergency powers to ban face masks during protests, she went to great lengths to explain that the city wasn’t in a state of emergency. Rather, she declared, after months of unrest, the city was in a “very critical state of public danger.”

headline: The Twist in a Yankees-Astros A.L.C.S. Rematch? Houston Is Even Better This Time
abstract: Both teams are cruising past opponents toward a rematch of the 2017 league championship series the Astros won on their way to their first World Series win.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The favorites are wasting no time, eager to get on with it already.

headline: 6 Elephants Die After Plunging Over a Waterfall in Thailand
abstract: One of the herd, a 3-year-old, was swept away and the others drowned when they tried to save it, national park officials said.
lead_paragraph: Six wild elephants fell over a treacherous waterfall in Thailand and died after one of the herd, a 3-year-old, was swept away by the river and the others tried to save it, national park officials said on Sunday.

headline: Addicted to Screens? That’s Really a You Problem
abstract: Nir Eyal, who wrote the industry manual for hooking people on tech, now has a recipe to free you — even though it was your fault to begin with.
lead_paragraph: Nir Eyal does not for a second regret writing Silicon Valley’s tech engagement how-to, “Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products,” even as he now has a new book out on how to free ourselves of that same addiction.

headline: North Korea Rules Out Quick Resumption of ‘Sickening’ Talks with U.S.
abstract: The North said that it would not meet with American negotiators again until after Washington took a step toward “complete and irreversible withdrawal of hostile policy.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Sunday that it had no desire to engage in “sickening negotiations” with the United States anymore, rejecting Washington’s suggestion that negotiators from both countries meet again in Stockholm in two weeks.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn or No-Deal Brexit? The U.K. Might Have to Choose
abstract: In the face of a potentially chaotic departure from the E.U., the socialism of Labour’s Jeremy Corbyn is beginning to look like a relatively reasonable option.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He is the bane of bankers, a bearded, teetotaling socialist often derided in the British press and in Parliament for his efforts to suppress dissent inside the Labour Party and his radical plans to remake the British economy.

headline: Legal Team Says It Represents a Second Whistle-Blower Over Trump and Ukraine
abstract: The new whistle-blower, who is said to have firsthand knowledge of the president’s dealings, has been interviewed by the intelligence community’s inspector general’s office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An intelligence official with “firsthand knowledge” has provided information related to President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine and is now protected from retaliation as a whistle-blower, lawyers representing the official said on Sunday, confirming that a second individual has come forward in the matter.

headline: Ginger Baker’s Essential Songs: Listen to 15 Tracks
abstract: The musician who helped define the role of the superstar rock drummer has died at 80.
lead_paragraph: Ginger Baker, who died Sunday at the age of 80, was an architect of rock drumming, spilling across tom-toms with both power and nuance. His work in the 1960s with the bands Cream and Blind Faith made him a defining figure of many basic rock band concepts: the “power trio,” the “supergroup,” the “drum solo,” “jamming,” “double-kick drumming” and — much to his trademark chagrin — an early thruway for “heavy metal.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make a poundcake with a surprise ingredient: lemon-lime 7Up.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ll get dragged all over the farm for saying so, but sometimes I like to cook with soda pop. I’ve braised ribs in Dr Pepper. I make a barbecue sauce with Coke. Lately, as I wrote for The New York Times Magazine this week, I’ve been making poundcake with lemon-lime 7Up.

headline: Kosovo Voters Want a New Future, but Old Problems Linger
abstract: Voters on Sunday are being asked to pick its first female leader or stay with a cast of politicians who have dominated a government long accused of corruption.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Kosovo ended its war with Serbia two decades ago, most of its dominant political figures have been men who rose to prominence as fighters and held onto power despite failing to secure a lasting peace and presiding over a floundering economy.

headline: Fighting Online Child Sex Abuse
abstract: Readers react to an article about the skyrocketing number of images of abuse on the internet, more than 45 million last year.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Flawed Legislation to Protect the 2020 Vote
abstract: Readers cite shortcomings in a bill that gives states $250 million to promote election security. Also: Loving cats; knitting at the ballpark.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kamala Harris Has Settled on an Iowa Strategy. Now What?
abstract: Ms. Harris has seen her stock fall in the presidential race. As she goes all in on Iowa, will voters respond?
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Kamala Harris of California kicked off perhaps the most important month of her stalled presidential bid in the shadow of America’s casino capital, a fitting start to an October in which she and her campaign staff will finally put their chips on the table.

headline: Tunisia’s Presidential Runoff: Two Candidates, and One Is in Jail
abstract: The businessman, television boss and presidential contender Nabil Karoui has been held on corruption and money-laundering charges since August. That poses problems, whether he wins or loses.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s young democracy has endured many shocks since it emerged from the Arab Spring protests of 2011. But its presidential runoff this month may pose a new and embarrassing question: What happens if the winner is in jail?

headline: Robert Indiana’s Island Home Still Grapples With His Legacy
abstract: The artist has been dead for more than a year, but the plans for the museum he outlined in his will are still far from certain.
lead_paragraph: VINALHAVEN, Me. — Forty-one years ago, when Robert Indiana, the artist, came to this remote island spotted with idle granite quarries, he fell in love with the place, and with a Victorian confection that he would make into his home.

headline: Six Russians Whose Money Has Made Art and Friends in the West
abstract: As individuals or leaders of foundations and companies, some rich Russians have become patrons of the arts and sponsor events that celebrate Russian culture abroad.
lead_paragraph: These men, personally or through foundations or companies they control, have given to arts organizations in the West and sponsored events that celebrate Russian culture abroad.

headline: Oligarchs, as U.S. Arts Patrons, Present a Softer Image of Russia
abstract: Museums, the performing arts and historical sites like Fort Ross in California, where an old Russian company flag flies, have been the beneficiaries of their gifts.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir O. Potanin, a Russian billionaire who made his fortune in banking and natural resources, has been a donor and board member of the Guggenheim Museum since 2002. More recently he gave $6.45 million to the Kennedy Center in Washington, which used some of the money to install the “Russian Lounge,” a meeting space, in the performing arts complex created, in part, by Congress. His name is now inscribed on a wall there.

headline: How Boeing vs. Airbus Became Trump vs. Europe
abstract: Boeing won a long-running trade dispute with Airbus, but it came with complications for a company still dealing with the fallout from two deadly accidents.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after his inauguration, President Trump toured Boeing’s factory in North Charleston, S.C., holding a rally with workers, admiring a new 787 Dreamliner and calling on the company to bring down the cost of new Air Force One planes.

headline: Overwhelmed or Ill Informed, 70,000 Wildfire Victims May Get Nothing
abstract: Lawyers say PG&E’s bankruptcy process in California is pre-empting the claims of tens of thousands who suffered losses in fires linked to its equipment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a succession of devastating wildfires in the last four years, tens of thousands of Californians — many with broken spirits, many homeless — may now lose out on compensation from the company that was to blame.

headline: Murderous Rampage Reveals Perils for the City’s Street Homeless
abstract: The brutal killing of four men occurred in a Manhattan neighborhood where the street homeless problem has long persisted.
lead_paragraph: A police van idled and a single piece of yellow caution tape flapped from a nearby tree as Benjamin Vanbrackle pulled his shirt down to show the fresh scar that wrapped around his neck to the top of his chest.

headline: ‘We Are Inside the Fire’: An Oral History of the War in Afghanistan
abstract: Afghans have endured four decades of conflict, with little prospect of peace. This is the story of the last 18 years since the American invasion, as told by the men and women who’ve lived it.
lead_paragraph: Afghans have endured four decades of conflict, with little prospect of peace. This is the story of the last 18 years since the American invasion, as told by the men and women who’ve lived it.

headline: Diahann Carroll, Indelible Fixture of My Childhood
abstract: Ms. Carroll was part of my extended family, that fabulous aunt who commanded attention by simply walking into the room.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday I was devastated by a headline on my social media timeline: “Diahann Carroll, Pioneering Actress on ‘Julia’ and ‘Dynasty,’ Dies at 84.” Born in the Bronx in 1935 and raised in Harlem, Ms. Carroll not only blazed a trail for black actresses, but also gave audiences of all races iconic characters with depth and poise. She was the first black woman to win a Tony Award for best actress, in 1962, for her role in the Broadway musical “No Strings,” and the first black woman to star in a nonstereotypical role in a television series in “Julia.”

headline: Review: Carnegie Hall’s Season Opens With Two Faces of Cleveland
abstract: Franz Welser-Möst led the Cleveland Orchestra in a pair of virtually flawless concerts. Yet only one of them showcased the ensemble at its best.
lead_paragraph: Programming matters: What an orchestra plays can be just as important as the quality of the playing. It can even be the difference between a concert that feels endless, and one you don’t want to ever end.

headline: For Salazar Whistle-Blowers, a Long Wait for a Satisfying Outcome
abstract: They lost money, jobs and friendships. Yet they said they had to speak up about the running coach now suspended for doping violations.
lead_paragraph: For the men and women in the Nike Oregon Project who became whistle-blowers in the case against Alberto Salazar, it has been a long 10 years.

headline: Talks to End G.M. Strike Take ‘Turn for the Worse,’ U.A.W. Says
abstract: After reports of progress between the automaker and the striking United Auto Workers, the company’s plants in Mexico are reportedly a sticking point.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and the striking United Auto Workers hit a roadblock in contract talks on Sunday over the question of moving production from Mexico to plants in the United States, two people close to the talks said.

headline: Bill de Blasio Needs to Get to Work
abstract: It isn’t too late for the mayor to deliver for New York City.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, Mayor John Lindsay came home to New York in April after winning just 7 percent of the vote in the Wisconsin Democratic presidential primary, the stench of failure following close behind.

headline: Police Rescued by Drug Suspects They Were Chasing After Collision at Sea
abstract: When three Spanish police officers fell into the ocean in the middle of a high-speed pursuit, the people they were chasing — suspected of trafficking drugs — were asked to pick them up.
lead_paragraph: The chase took them to the dark blue waters off southern Spain: three officers of the national police, pursuing four people suspected of trafficking drugs.

headline: Teacher Put on Leave After ‘Sniper Rifle’ Comment About Greta Thunberg, District Says
abstract: An Iowa school district said it was investigating the teacher’s Facebook comment about a rally led by the young climate activist.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa chemistry teacher was placed on administrative leave after saying on Facebook that he would not attend a rally featuring the climate activist Greta Thunberg because he didn’t “have my sniper rifle,” according to school officials and reports.

headline: ‘Joker’ Opens Strong at Box Office, Despite Controversy
abstract: The supervillain story has been the subject of intense debate. That didn’t stop it from bringing in about $93.5 million at domestic theaters this weekend.
lead_paragraph: With some cheering it on and others anxiously holding their breath, Hollywood’s latest comic book movie, “Joker,” laughed its way to the bank this weekend, opening to robust ticket sales and signaling to Warner Bros. that a risky move had paid off.

headline: Marcello Giordani, Tenor Who ‘Sang Like a God,’ Dies at 56
abstract: A former bank employee, the Italian singer appeared more than 240 times with the Metropolitan Opera, in 27 roles.
lead_paragraph: Marcello Giordani, a heartfelt, stalwart and, at his best, inspired tenor who was a fixture at the Metropolitan Opera and other major houses around the world, died on Saturday at his home in Augusta, Sicily. He was 56.

headline: New York Democrats Balance Impeachment Issue With Local Concerns
abstract: In three distinct enclaves of New York, lawmakers found that voters were curious about impeachment, but far more preoccupied with regional issues.
lead_paragraph: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — Even before Peter Plavchan Sr. asked about “the exact crimes” President Trump had committed to prompt his congressman to reverse course and embrace an impeachment inquiry, Representative Antonio Delgado was ready with a detailed answer.

headline: Nissan’s Crisis Goes Much Deeper Than Carlos Ghosn
abstract: Two insiders who brought down Carlos Ghosn were involved with improper payments, an inquiry found. The company’s full board never heard about it.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — An outside law firm investigating problems at Nissan, the troubled Japanese automaker, this summer discovered some potentially explosive information.

headline: Whistle-Blower, Hong Kong, Nissan: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A new whistle-blower emerges.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: N.B.A. Executive’s Hong Kong Tweet Starts Firestorm in China
abstract: Daryl Morey, the general manager of the Houston Rockets, posted a tweet supporting protesters in Hong Kong, upsetting the Chinese Basketball Association led by the Hall of Famer Yao Ming.
