lead_paragraph: The general manager of the Houston Rockets sought to quell an outcry in China on Sunday night after the support he expressed on Twitter for pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong upset sponsors, media outlets and basketball officials in a country that invests billions in the N.B.A.

headline: Filming the Show: Pardon the Intrusion? Or Punish It?
abstract: A seized phone. A stopped concert. A text from Rihanna. All are new fuel for a heated debate about theater etiquette in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Henry, the star of a new Off Broadway musical called “The Wrong Man,” had tried repeatedly to signal his disapproval to the man in the onstage seating who was using his smartphone to capture his performance, but he wasn’t getting through.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 7, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: Our next “What’s Going On in This Picture?” live-moderated discussion will take place on Oct. 21, 2019.

headline: Hot Tub Displays at State Fair Eyed as Link to Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak
abstract: More than 100 people in North Carolina were sickened with Legionnaires’ disease and Pontiac fever last month. One person died.
lead_paragraph: The hot tub exhibits at a state fair might be to blame for North Carolina’s recent outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease and Pontiac fever, which sickened more than 100 people and killed at least one, health officials said.

headline: Down in This Puzzle
abstract: Keiran King tests our mettle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Keiran King, he was making his New York Times Crossword debut with a puzzle that made sure we enunciated our words and knew our musical compositions.

headline: Jimmy Carter Needed Stitches After Falling at His Home
abstract: The oldest living former president, who is 95, “feels fine,” the Carter Center said.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter required stitches after falling at his Plains, Ga., home on Sunday, the Carter Center said.

headline: New York City Wants to Put a Climate Change ‘Laboratory’ on Governors Island
abstract: The island, which has an unusual history and considerable real estate potential, could host a complex devoted to climate policy under the plan, which is in its early stages.
lead_paragraph: Governors Island, a 172-acre patch of land near southern Manhattan that is vaguely shaped like an ice cream cone, has been many things over time: An outpost of the Dutch West India Company, a Civil War prison for Confederate soldiers, a Coast Guard command center, and even a meeting place for President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev near the end of the Cold War.

headline: Amid Trade War, Farmers Lean on a New Crop: Hemp
abstract: With the rising popularity of CBD products, farmers are growing hemp. Some see it as a way to ride out President Trump’s fight over trade. Others fear it may not last.
lead_paragraph: ROSEVILLE, Ill. — Surrounded by waist-high hemp plants, Andy Huston, a sixth-generation farmer in Illinois, stopped to admire one of the ridged green leaves.

headline: Video Shows Deer Crashing Through Hair Salon Window
abstract: Security camera footage captured the moment when the animal jumped through the front window of a hair salon in Lake Ronkonkoma, N.Y., on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Security camera footage captured the moment when the animal jumped through the front window of a hair salon in Lake Ronkonkoma, N.Y., on Saturday.

headline: Video Shows Deer Crashing Through Window of Salon
abstract: The startling video underscored the dangers of surging deer populations that are encroaching on populated areas of the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: When Jenisse Heredia, a hair stylist, first heard the sound of breaking glass at her Long Island salon on Saturday afternoon, she thought a car had struck the building.

headline: Giants’ Improvement Plan Hits a Snag
abstract: The rookie quarterback Daniel Jones has one learning curve. The team’s defense has another.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Daniel Jones was in high school, his mother, Becca, would ask him what he was going to do that day.

headline: The Rich Really Do Pay Lower Taxes Than You
abstract: The 400 wealthiest Americans now pay a lower rate than the middle class.
lead_paragraph: The 400 wealthiest Americans now pay a lower rate than the middle class.

headline: Why America Needs Whistle-Blowers
abstract: They are not partisans but stewards of our constitutional democracy.
lead_paragraph: In accusing the intelligence community whistle-blower of partisanship and treason, President Trump has redefined whistle-blowing to serve his private interests rather than the rule of law. In the American tradition, whistle-blowers expose illegal or unconstitutional acts that the powerful want to keep secret.

headline: A Momentous Week in May: Book Details Early Days of Russia Inquiry
abstract: After James B. Comey was ousted as the F.B.I. director in 2017, there were anguish and alarm at the bureau and the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Are you O.K.?” Andrew G. McCabe, the acting F.B.I. director, asked Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general.

headline: Impeach Trump, Repeatedly
abstract: A president should not be able to stonewall and run out the clock.
lead_paragraph: When the Democratic leadership was finally forced to formally back an impeachment inquiry, they faced a choice: focus broadly on all of Donald Trump’s corruption and unfitness, which could drag on for a long time, or focus narrowly on the new revelations about Trump and Ukraine and do so quickly. They chose the latter.

headline: Delle Donne Returns; Mystics Are on Cusp of W.N.B.A. Title
abstract: The league M.V.P., playing with a herniated disk, took only six shots, but made five, putting the Mystics one win from the W.N.B.A. title.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — Mike Thibault, the coach of the Washington Mystics, carefully watched his star player, the W.N.B.A.’s 2019 most valuable player, Elena Delle Donne, as she shot around about 90 minutes before Game 3 of the W.N.B.A. finals on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Disney World Skyliner Gondola Abruptly Stops, Stranding Passengers in Air
abstract: The gondola system, which connects Epcot, Hollywood Studios and several Disney World resorts, opened on Sept. 29. It has now been shut down.
lead_paragraph: Vacationers riding a new aerial gondola system at Walt Disney World in Florida on Saturday night were stranded in the air for several hours after a malfunction brought some of the gondolas to a halt.

headline: Rip Taylor, Flamboyant Comedian, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Known as the ‘King of Confetti,’ he was a familiar face on television during his more than 50 years in show business.
lead_paragraph: Rip Taylor, a flamboyant mainstay of the comedy circuit who was known for his gags involving confetti, for his brand of self-deprecating humor, which included removing his toupee, and for his voice work, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: ‘We Absolutely Could Not Do That’: When Seeking Foreign Help Was Out of the Question
abstract: In every other modern White House, enlisting foreign powers to obtain a political advantage at home was seen as unwise and politically dangerous, if not wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day in October 1992, four Republican congressmen showed up in the Oval Office with an audacious recommendation. President George Bush was losing his re-election race, and they told him the only way to win was to hammer his challenger Bill Clinton’s patriotism for protesting the Vietnam War while in London and visiting Moscow as a young man.

headline: Review: ‘Slave Play,’ Four Times as Big and Just as Searing
abstract: Jeremy O. Harris’s Off Broadway hit about race and sex in America shakes things up on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s mild, paradoxical and perhaps a bit prurient to say so, “Slave Play” is a happy surprise.

headline: Review: Love Among the Shadows in Edgar Oliver’s ‘Victor’
abstract: In this haunting memoir of his relationship with a homeless man, Mr. Oliver confirms his status as a poet laureate of New York’s dispossessed.
lead_paragraph: Among the vast and sacred realm of idolized love objects — the one inhabited by Dante’s Beatrice and Elizabeth Barrett Browning’s Robert — the title character of Edgar Oliver’s “Victor” stands tall. Not that he was, particularly — tall, I mean.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2, Episode 9 Recap: Culture of Exploitation
abstract: This week revealed a lot about how seriously the megawealthy and the politically connected take government oversight.
lead_paragraph: Given what’s been going on in Washington the past couple of weeks, this latest “Succession” episode isn’t just gripping, it’s fairly illuminating. When the pattern of sexual harassment and cover-ups at Waystar’s cruise division is exposed by a popular network TV news program, the United States Congress gets involved, with Shiv’s old boss Gil Eavis (Eric Bogosian) leading an inquiry. The Roy family sees a legacy-killing scandal expand beyond their capacity to contain it; and Roman’s first reaction — like those of a lot of people in power these days — is to wonder if they can just duck Congress. (But he doesn’t say “duck.”)

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 7 Recap: Killer Twist
abstract: Joanie tries to catch her mother’s killer as Noah tries to catch a break.
lead_paragraph: Joanie, Joanie, Joanie. What are we going to do with your share of “The Affair”? The grown-up daughter of Cole and Alison Lockhart dominates this episode — which, given the strength of Noah Solloway’s segment, ought to be a compliment. But when Joanie seeks out and finds her mother’s killer, what happens manages to upend the show’s narrative apple cart so completely that it’s hard to appreciate anything that came before.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 4 Premiere Recap: E for Vendetta
abstract: The final season premiere opened with a bang — and was a return to form after some strange misfires last season.
lead_paragraph: It starts with the death of a main character. It seems, at first, to end with the death of the main character. In between, it plays out like an eerie paranoid thriller against a backdrop of international corruption and capitalism run amok. Written and directed by the series’s creator, Sam Esmail, the fourth and final season premiere of “Mr. Robot” plays to all the show’s strengths and none of its weaknesses.

headline: North Koreans Thrown Overboard as Fishing Ship Hits Japanese Patrol Boat
abstract: The collision came less than a week after North Korea launched a missile that landed in Japan’s exclusive economic zone.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A large North Korean fishing trawler collided with a Japanese patrol ship within Japan’s exclusive economic zone on Monday, throwing dozens of North Korean crew members overboard and drawing renewed warnings from Tokyo about illegal fishing in its waters.

headline: The Best and Brightest? Not Always for E.U. Leadership Jobs
abstract: Parliamentary hearings of proposed European commissioners reveal legal, ethical and competence problems for many.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — One official wore blackface. Another could not answer basic questions about his portfolio. A third has been accused of misusing public funds while in office, and is still being investigated.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Salazar Accusers Validated After Long, Grueling Wait
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 7, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Not doing it is not an option because what was going on goes against everything I believe in in sport.”

headline: Impeachment, Brexit, Harvey Weinstein: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Corrections: October 07, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 07, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 07, 2019.

headline: President Endorses Turkish Military Operation in Syria, Shifting U.S. Policy
abstract: The operation would sweep away American-backed Kurdish forces near the border in Syria. The White House said U.S. forces “will no longer be in the immediate area.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major shift in United States military policy in Syria, the White House said on Sunday that President Trump had given his endorsement for a Turkish military operation that would sweep away American-backed Kurdish forces near the border in Syria.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Spoor’ and ‘Retro Report’
abstract: Agnieszka Holland’s ecological thriller is available on Mubi until Oct. 11. And a new PBS series connects current events with the past.
lead_paragraph: SPOOR (2017) Stream on Mubi. Rent on Amazon. The New York Times critic Manohla Dargis called “Spoor” one of the best titles of the 2017 New York Film Festival. It never received distribution, but it’s available on the streaming service Mubi until Oct. 11. Kasia Adamik and Agnieszka Holland’s ecologically inclined film is about Janina (Agnieszka Mandat), a pensioner with a passion for animal rights whose dogs disappear near her home in the Polish hinterlands. While searching for them, she is brought in contact with the violent deaths of several local hunters. According to Dargis, Janina’s trajectory is “a weird, occasionally funny and increasingly violent journey into assorted hearts of darkness — hers and others’ — that is as emotionally powerful as it is political.”

headline: Word + Quiz: neophyte
abstract: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Britain Demands Return of American Woman Who Fled After Fatal Crash
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson called on the suspect to return, and said he would ask President Trump to intervene if the impasse was not resolved.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson called on Monday for the wife of an American diplomat involved in a crash that killed a teenager to return to Britain, saying he would ask President Trump to intervene if the impasse was not resolved through diplomatic channels.

headline: Hong Kong’s Mask Ban Reveals Carrie Lam’s True Face
abstract: The city’s leader announced an emergency law to restore order. It was a deliberate provocation.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — This city has long prided herself on respecting the rule of law — the ultimate guarantee of Hong Kongers’ freedoms, human rights and way of life. It is one of the attributes that make Hong Kong stand apart from cities on the Chinese mainland. Our practice of common law, together with an independent judiciary served by high-caliber judges, has earned us the trust and the confidence of friends and trading partners all over the world. Our legal system’s predictability and its freedom from political interference guarantee that no one will fall victim to the arbitrary exercise of power by government authorities.

headline: After Three Starts, Yankees’ Luis Severino Says, ‘I Am My Best’
abstract: A shoulder injury kept the former staff ace out for nearly all of 2019, but he can help close out the division series against the Twins on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have been too smart and too respectful of the Minnesota Twins to state the obvious about their American League division series: So far, it has just been calisthenics for the showdown everyone has been waiting for since opening day.

headline: In Kashmir, a Race Against Death, With No Way to Call a Doctor
abstract: Medical personnel in Kashmir say preventable deaths are happening because of blocked streets, medicine shortages, and a phone and internet blockade by India.
lead_paragraph: HEEVAN, Kashmir — Saja Begum was cooking dinner when her son walked into the kitchen with a stricken look on his face. “Mom,” he said. “I have been bitten by a snake. I am going to die.”

headline: In ‘Antisocial,’ How the Alt-Right Went Viral
abstract: Andrew Marantz weaves together profiles of online extremists with his memorable and often surreal reporting experiences.
lead_paragraph: For a journalist, reporting about people whose views you might share can be tricky enough, but reporting about people whose views you find completely abhorrent can be even trickier. Andrew Marantz started covering what he calls the “bad-guys-on-the-internet beat” for The New Yorker before the surprising result of the 2016 presidential election made those same guys rejoice.

headline: Relief for Children’s Migraine Headaches
abstract: New guidelines for therapies for children and adolescents can reduce or eliminate attacks of migraine and greatly shorten their duration.
lead_paragraph: My grandson Stefan was about 8 years old when he began to get migraine headaches. As soon as he could after getting home from school, he would lie down and go to sleep, awakening an hour or two later, usually with the headache gone. But before the pain abated, he sometimes vomited, prompting him and his relatives to keep barf bags handy at all times.

headline: The Disruptive World of Edward Norton
abstract: The actor on why he has (mostly) ditched Hollywood for the tech world.
lead_paragraph: The actor on why he has (mostly) ditched Hollywood for the tech world.

headline: Why Evangelicals Support Donald Trump
abstract: “Who Is an Evangelical?,” by Thomas S. Kidd, and “The Immoral Majority,” by Ben Howe, examine the politics of the religious right.
lead_paragraph: WHO IS AN EVANGELICAL?The History of a Movement in CrisisBy Thomas S. KiddTHE IMMORAL MAJORITYWhy Evangelicals Chose Political Power Over Christian ValuesBy Ben Howe

headline: A Novel That Riffs on Sex Dolls, Mary Shelley and Brexit
abstract: Jeanette Winterson’s “Frankissstein,” a nod at the 19th-century classic, fizzes with ideas and originality.
lead_paragraph: FrankisssteinA Love StoryBy Jeanette Winterson

headline: Is Your Child Struggling in School? Talk to Your Pediatrician
abstract: A new report advises pediatricians to give academic failure the same attention as any other complex problem affecting a child.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics has just issued a report on what pediatricians can — and should — do to help “school-aged children who are not progressing academically.”

headline: Pushed by Security Concerns and Trump, Germany Weighs a New Fuel
abstract: The country’s first liquefied natural gas terminal could bring imports from shale fields in the United States and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: WILHELMSHAVEN, Germany — A jetty here juts out nearly a mile into the Wadden Sea from Germany’s low-lying northern coast. Now used by a chemical plant, the pier could become the site of the country’s first liquefied natural gas terminal.

headline: M.T.A. Pledges $5 Billion for Subway Elevators. Guess How Many.
abstract: Disabled and older riders say they are long overdue. Transit advocates question the price tag.
lead_paragraph: Across large swaths of New York City, it is impossible to take the subway without using the stairs. People who rely on wheelchairs are simply out of luck.

headline: Electric Roads Could Be a Path to a Driverless Future
abstract: Israel and Sweden experiment with a new way to increase the uses of electric cars.
lead_paragraph: BEIT YANNAI, Israel — Electric vehicles can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, at least in theory. But challenges to wide acceptance remain significant: Batteries are expensive, charging stations are few and far between, and recharging takes far more time than a fill-up at the pump.

headline: Oil Companies Ponder Climate Change, but Profits Still Rule
abstract: They are caught between investors who want greener energy and those who simply want a strong return on their investments.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, John Browne rocked the oil industry by saying that the  “possibility cannot be discounted” of a link between man-made carbon emissions and global warming, and that it was time for “action.” In 1997, Mr. Browne, then chief executive of BP, the London-based oil company, was a lonely voice among his peers.

headline: From the Rooftops, Big Box Stores Are Embracing Solar
abstract: Target and Walmart are trying to out-green each other in proving to customers they are environmentally responsible businesses.
lead_paragraph: Target’s famous bull's-eye is so cosmically linked with the brand that it’s hard to imagine the retail behemoth ever messing with the logo’s red color. But over the past decade — under pressure from customers, shareholders and employees — Target’s retail future is morphing into a very different hue: eco-green.

headline: Forged by Volcanoes, Kamchatka Offers Majestic, Magnetic Wilds
abstract: Roaming bears hunt wild Pacific salmon among alpine meadows on this Russian peninsula, a compact, volcanic Eden.
lead_paragraph: “If you can find me a better place than Kamchatka on this earth, I will argue with you!” exclaimed Alexei Ozerov, the exuberant chief volcanologist on the entrancing peninsula hanging off Russia’s Pacific Coast.

headline: Do Works by Men Implicated by #MeToo Belong in the Classroom?
abstract: Two years after the rise of the #MeToo movement, educators continue to grapple with how to deal with writers and artists accused of abuse.
lead_paragraph: For Martina Myers, a high school English teacher on the Navajo reservation in Arizona, Sherman Alexie’s novel “The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian” seemed too good to be true: funny, well-crafted and focused on Native American youth.

headline: Pipelines From Russia Cross Political Lines
abstract: Critics say the Nord Stream 2 project would make Germany too dependent on Russian natural gas and economically punish Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Trump said “it really makes Germany a hostage to Russia.” Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, said it would encourage Russian “military adventurism.” Radoslaw Sikorski, the former Polish defense minister, compared it to the infamous 1939 Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact that allied the Nazis with Stalin’s Soviet Union.

headline: Seeking New Energy, an English Town Digs Deep
abstract: The county of Cornwall hopes that tapping an underground rock formation will bring electricity, economic stimulus and year-round swimming.
lead_paragraph: It was never an ordinary swimming pool. Built in 1935 to celebrate the anniversary of a king, the Jubilee Pool is filled with more than a million gallons of seawater, making it one of the United Kingdom’s largest lidos, as the public outdoor swimming areas are called.

headline: ‘I Gave the Other Guy a Shot’
abstract: After taking a chance on Donald Trump in 2016, a swing county in western Pennsylvania is up for grabs again.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: Dec. 6, 2019After this article was published, local news media reported that Mark Graham did not vote in the 2016 election. The Times has confirmed that Mr. Graham did not vote in the election.While Mr. Graham acknowledged misspeaking about his voting record, he said the article accurately reflects his feelings about the 2016 race and President Trump’s performance in office.

headline: Shopping for Doormats
abstract: A doormat isn’t just a place to wipe your shoes — it should welcome visitors with some style and personality.
lead_paragraph: Does it matter which doormat you choose? Actually, it does — because a doormat does more than just scrub the bottom of your shoes.

headline: The Chefs Reinventing the Midwestern Supper Club
abstract: Once a mainstay of midcentury dining, the convivial establishments have reappeared, even as the meaning of “all-American” has become more complicated.
lead_paragraph: THE LIGHTS ARE dim, set to eternal dusk. You enter and blink. If there are booths, they should be plush: Naugahyde or brocade limned in gold. Napkins are linen, tables likely cloaked. Maybe a Persian rug lies underfoot. Taxidermied animal heads peer from the walls. From your seat, you might see a living white-tailed deer out the window; like you, it is ready to feed.

headline: After a Caribbean Hurricane, the Battle Is Where, or Even Whether, to Rebuild
abstract: When Hurricane Irma crushed St. Martin two years ago, the French state vowed swift assistance. Aid has flowed in, but a fight has followed about recovery plans, exposing racial and class tension.
lead_paragraph: When things go wrong, those in power often promise to make it right. But do they? In this series, The Times investigates to see if those promises were kept.

headline: Jokers at Every Turn at Comic Con, but They Were on Their Best Behavior
abstract: At the New York convention, fans donned green wigs and smeared on clown face paint for the opening weekend of the “Joker” film.
lead_paragraph: At Comic Con, where attendees show off meticulously prepared costumes inspired by their favorite fictional characters, one generally does not dress up as the Joker without knowing which Joker they are.

headline: How Much Do You Know About the Czech Republic?
abstract: Can you find the Czech Republic on a map? What else do you know about this Central European nation with about 10.7 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find the Czech Republic on a map? What else do you know about this Central European nation with about 10.7 million people?

headline: How New York’s Taxi Titans Roiled Cities Hundreds of Miles Away
abstract: Monday: New Yorkers seized control of several markets, driving up the price of medallions and leaving the industry in tatters.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Opium-Smuggling Taliban Leader’s Release From Prison Raises Questions
abstract: Among the 11 Taliban prisoners freed, in what some reported was a swap for Indian hostages, was a U.S.-designated terrorist figure who had been caught with a haul of opium.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Eleven Taliban commanders have been released from a high-security prison in Afghanistan, according to Taliban officials, in an apparent deal that included a prominent regional leader caught five years ago personally escorting a shipment of nearly a ton of opium.

headline: What We Learned in N.F.L. Week 5
abstract: The Packers got a big win in Dallas, the Patriots and the Texans were dominant and the Chiefs finally lost. But Sunday offered some reminders of what’s wrong with the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: It was not a week to showcase the best the N.F.L. has to offer. There were fumbles galore, a particularly ugly injury in Pittsburgh, multiple blowouts and a sense that we already know who the real contenders are, which would make the bulk of the regular season a formality.

headline: Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded for Research on How Cells Manage Oxygen
abstract: The prize was awarded to William G. Kaelin Jr., Peter J. Ratcliffe and Gregg L. Semenza for discoveries about how cells sense and adapt to oxygen availability.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was jointly awarded to three scientists — William G. Kaelin Jr., Peter J. Ratcliffe and Gregg L. Semenza — for their work on how cells sense and adapt to oxygen availability.

headline: Syria, Houston Rockets, Nobel Prize: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Don’t Be Fooled. Chief Justice John Roberts Is as Partisan as They Come.
abstract: He says he is concerned about the Supreme Court’s legitimacy in the eyes of the public. He should worry.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s new term that begins on Monday could prove momentous, with cases involving gun control, abortion, L.G.B.T. rights and immigration. The term is likely to signal how far the court’s conservative majority will go to block the agenda of the next Democratic president and Congress.

headline: Your Visitors Deserve to Know They’re on Camera
abstract: Technology allows us to do it. Should we?
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, my garage was broken into while I was in the house. I heard footsteps and ran out to find someone trying to steal a bike. Cue some yelling, and the would-be thief was quickly gone, but I was so anxious I ordered a security camera within an hour. Since then, the camera has picked up nothing more than my comings and goings, mail delivery and the occasional rat. I recently decided to take it down.

headline: The Last Hummingbird
abstract: These small flying jewels still take their cue from the quiet October light, just as they always have.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — From inside my air-conditioned house, the light through my windows looks the way October light is supposed to look — mild, quiet, entirely unlike the thin light of winter or the sparkling light of spring or the unrelenting light of summer. In normal years, October is a month for open windows in Middle Tennessee. For cool, damp mornings. For colored leaves that quake in the wind before letting go and lifting away. For afternoon shadows so lovely they fill me with a longing I can’t even name.

headline: A ‘Crazy’ Plan: How U.S. Diplomats Discussed the Pressure on Ukraine
abstract: House Democrats called their first witness in the impeachment inquiry, and he came with dozens of pages of text messages.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: What It’s Like to See ‘Slave Play’ as a Black Person
abstract: Experiencing Jeremy O. Harris’s provocative Broadway debut feels fraught, but invigorating.
lead_paragraph: One evening last month, the John Golden Theatre in Times Square — once the Broadway home for “Avenue Q” and, more recently, “A Doll’s House Part 2” — looked as though it had been transformed into Harlem’s Magic Johnson Theater. Or that’s the way at least one attendee described it, observing the near-full house made up almost entirely of black audience members, who were still humming over the astounding performance we had just witnessed.

headline: How a Tweet Put the NBA in Hot Water in China
abstract: A quickly deleted post by a Houston Rockets executive opened the league, which has had huge success in China, up to blowback in a vital overseas market.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Joker’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Todd Phillips narrates a sequence from “Joker.”
lead_paragraph: Todd Phillips narrates a sequence from “Joker.”

headline: Watch Joaquin Phoenix Do a Creepy Dance in ‘Joker’
abstract: The director Todd Phillips narrates a scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Hong Kong’s Hard-Core Protesters Take Justice Into Their Own Hands
abstract: A breakdown in trust in Hong Kong’s government and the police force has driven some protesters to retributive violence. Some wonder if they are crossing a line.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When protesters in Hong Kong this weekend came upon an older, shirtless man who was threatening a crowd, they pounded him to the ground with a stick. When a taxi swerved into a group of protesters nearby, some dragged the driver out and beat him until he was covered in blood.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘That Music You’re Dancing To? It’s Code’
abstract: In this lesson, students learn about an approach to music-making that is derived from code. Then they make predictions about how this might shape the future.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “That Music You’re Dancing To? It’s Code”

headline: The Government Says Rainbow Crosswalks Could Be Unsafe. Are They Really?
abstract: Ames, Iowa, is only the latest city to be chided for pavement painted in pride colors, but some experts say the available research doesn’t support the Federal Highway Administration’s concerns.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of an annual L.G.B.T.Q. festival in Ames, Iowa, members of the City Council decided to liven up a pedestrian crosswalk near the downtown shopping district by painting stripes in colors evoking the gay, nonbinary and transgender pride flags.

headline: Redskins Fire Jay Gruden
abstract: An 0-5 start ends the coach’s tenure in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Five games into a winless season, the Washington Redskins on Monday fired their coach, Jay Gruden. The change came one day after Washington lost, 33-7, to the New England Patriots to go to 0-5.

headline: Why Is It Important for People With Different Political Beliefs to Talk to Each Other?
abstract: What can we learn by interacting with people who have completely different life experiences than we do?
lead_paragraph: Would you want to spend a few days sitting down with people and talking about issues that are important to voters in the United States? What if the people came from all corners of the political spectrum?

headline: Hong Kong Protests Put N.B.A. on Edge in China
abstract: A tweet from the Houston Rockets general manager prompted a backlash in China, making things uncomfortable for a league used to its players and representatives speaking out on politics.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The N.B.A. superstar LeBron James has routinely insulted President Trump. Two of the league’s most successful coaches, Steve Kerr and Gregg Popovich, have repeatedly slammed American lawmakers for inaction on gun legislation. And other basketball stars regularly speak out on social and political issues — police shootings, elections and racism — without fear of retribution from the league.

headline: 2 Outs? 2 Strikes? No Problem for Dodgers
abstract: The Dodgers seized Game 3 of their series with the Nationals by scoring seven times in the sixth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first inning of their first World Series game, in 1916, the Brooklyn Robins went down in order against the Red Sox at Braves Field in Boston. A young right fielder named Casey Stengel made the third out.

headline: Tina Tchen, Ex-Obama Aide, Will Take Over Time’s Up
abstract: The group was founded by powerful women in Hollywood in the wake of the #MeToo movement. It aims to fight sexual harassment and assault in all industries.
lead_paragraph: Time’s Up, the advocacy organization founded by powerful women in Hollywood as the #MeToo movement roiled the nation, announced on Monday that it had appointed Tina Tchen, a lawyer and former chief of staff to Michelle Obama, as its new chief executive.

headline: How a Health Care Trial Could Have a Chilling Effect
abstract: Monday: The Sutter system could be liable for more than $2 billion under state law. Also: A deadline for wildfire damage claims, and the Eve Babitz revival.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Taxes: President Ordered to Turn Over Returns to Manhattan D.A.
abstract: A judge rejected the president’s argument that he was immune from criminal investigations.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday rejected President Trump’s effort to shield his tax returns from Manhattan state prosecutors, calling the president’s argument that he was immune from criminal investigation “repugnant to the nation’s governmental structure and constitutional values.”

headline: How Kurds Could Be Affected by Trump’s Syria Shift
abstract: Kurdish fighters in northern Syria partnered with the United States to fight the Islamic State, but may find themselves facing Turkey’s military alone.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Trump’s decision on Sunday to step aside and let Turkish forces come into northern Syria instantly cast into doubt the fate of ethnic Kurds there who have been the United States’ closest allies in the fight against the Islamic State, and who had worked to achieve a degree of self-rule in that stretch of Syria.

headline: Quartz Editor in Chief Steps Down in Shake-Up
abstract: Kevin Delaney co-founded the digital publication in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Delaney, the editor in chief of Quartz and one of the digital publication’s co-founders, is stepping down as part of a shake-up of the company’s leadership.

headline: Hypertension in Pregnancy May Portend Cardiovascular Ills in Mothers
abstract: Pre-eclampsia was tied to a higher risk of stroke, heart attacks and other problems in mothers.
lead_paragraph: High blood pressure during pregnancy increases a mother’s risk for future cardiovascular disease and death, a new study has found.

headline: What You Get for $1 Million in California
abstract: A 1922 home in the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles; a two-story townhouse in Irvine; and a 1880s Victorian in Duncans Mills, in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: A 1922 home in the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles; a two-story townhouse in Irvine; and a 1880s Victorian in Duncans Mills, in Sonoma County.

headline: Trump Throws Middle East Policy Into Turmoil Over Syria
abstract: After criticism that he was allowing a Turkish incursion into northern Syria, the president pivoted, saying he would prevent Turkey from going too far.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump threw Middle East policy into turmoil on Monday with a series of conflicting signals after his vow to withdraw American forces from the region touched off an uprising among congressional Republicans and protests by America’s allies.

headline: Cook Like It’s Still Summer
abstract: Stretch the season a little longer with avocado toast, and one last tomato sandwich.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s dark when I get up now and trudge toward the ferry, the scooter, the bus or the bicycle, and it’s dark again when I leave work for home. The season’s not quite right, but I long for caramelized citrus over yogurt after dinner, a reminder of summer or at any rate the weekend, when I can be an adult outdoors in the sun.

headline: $1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1922 home in Laurel Canyon, a two-story townhouse in Irvine and a 1880s Victorian in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: This house with its swooping gable is in Laurel Canyon, a longtime haven for bohemians and rock stars in the Hollywood Hills. The Rolling Stones are rumored to have played in the garage. Pace, an Italian restaurant with a peace sign on its facade, is two minutes away. Downtown Los Angeles is about 10 miles southeast.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: When you sit down to a flavorful Indian meal, one of the best ways to sop up all that saucy goodness is with a flat bread. There are a few from which to choose, and two — NAAN and ROTI — appear fairly frequently in the New York Times Crossword.

headline: 20 Years After ‘The Perks of Being a Wallflower,’ Stephen Chbosky Has a New Novel
abstract: “Imaginary Friend,” a mash-up of horror, fairy tales and the Bible, takes us inside the mind of a very good 7-year-old boy surrounded by darkness.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINARY FRIENDBy Stephen Chbosky

headline: A Linguist’s Guide to Quid Pro Quo
abstract: The Trump-Zelensky dialogue could be used in a textbook chapter on conversational analysis.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago the impeachment of a president hinged on what the meaning of “is” is. This time it may depend on the semantics of “I would like you to do us a favor though.”

headline: New York City: Are We an Empire in Decline?
abstract: The city was built on big ideas, but lately the vision seems smaller.
lead_paragraph: The city was built on big ideas, but lately the vision seems smaller.

headline: Trump: ‘I’m Using Mexico’
abstract: The country itself has become the wall. This has to change.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — “I’m using Mexico to protect our border.” Millions of Americans didn’t even notice this recent remark made by President Trump. But Mexicans certainly did. They thought Mr. Trump’s words were a blatant attack on their nation’s sovereignty.

headline: New York City: Are We an Empire in Decline?
abstract: The city was built on big ideas, but lately the vision seems smaller.
lead_paragraph: New York City was built on big, bold ideas. The vision of past leaders kept New Yorkers in town and captured the imaginations of millions from around the world who came here to “make it.” In the Video Op-Ed above, Mara Gay, a native New Yorker who has reported on the streets of this city for seven years, questions where all that vision is today. She argues that New York’s current leaders need to bring big ambition and hustle to serve their residents. She supplies ideas of what vision could look like to a mayor whose reluctant homecoming offers dim hope for the city. New Yorkers, she says, deserve more.

headline: The Huge Waste in the U.S. Health System
abstract: A study finds evidence for how to reduce some of it, but also a large blind spot on how to remove the rest.
lead_paragraph: Even a divided America can agree on this goal: a health system that is cheaper but doesn’t sacrifice quality. In other words, just get rid of the waste.

headline: What Happened to Rudy Giuliani?
abstract: The man I worked for in 1993 is not the man who now lies for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 8, 1994, my wife Liz Bruder and I were married in City Hall by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. For 25 years, I carried a wallet-size photo of the three of us from that day.

headline: N.F.L. Players Association Files Grievances on Behalf of Antonio Brown
abstract: The union will try to help the receiver recoup over $40 million in salary from the Patriots and the Raiders.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Brown is no longer catching passes this season.

headline: It’s 2040. We Need to Keep Abortion Legal in New York.
abstract: Thanks to a landmark ruling that overturned Roe v. Wade, abortion is now illegal everywhere except New York (and Hawaii). But a new bill threatens the legal status of abortions.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: This is part of the Op-Eds From the Future series, in which science fiction authors, futurists, philosophers and scientists write Op-Eds that they imagine we might read 10, 50 or even 200 years from now. The challenges they predict are imaginary — for now — but their arguments illuminate the urgent questions of today and prepare us for tomorrow. The Opinion piece below is a work of fiction.

headline: Turkey’s Plan to Move Refugees to Syria Is Dangerous
abstract: Ankara’s plan is a perfect recipe for enduring ethnic tensions and instability.
lead_paragraph: The ambitious plan of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to resettle at least one million Syrian refugees within a “safe zone” along the Turkish-Syrian border has come a step closer to being realized. On Sunday President Trump endorsed a Turkish military operation to carve out the “safe zone” in northeastern Syria, currently controlled by the United States-supported, Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.

headline: The Women Fliers Who Kept Their Heads in the Clouds
abstract: In Steve Sheinkin’s thrilling “Born to Fly,” the mechanical hurdles seem hard enough. Then comes the nonstop scolding.
lead_paragraph: “They were the kinds of kids who jumped off the roofs of buildings,” begins Steve Sheinkin’s stirring account of the 1929 Air Derby, BORN TO FLY: The First Women’s Air Race Across America (Roaring Brook, 288 pp., $19.99; ages 8 to 12), without a hint of hyperbole. Future participants in the first women’s cross-country air race did indeed spend their childhoods leaping from outlandish heights with umbrella parachutes, greasing the tracks of rickety homemade roller coasters and building honest-to-goodness airplanes in the backyard. Asked why she’d taken to the skies, Florence “Pancho” Barnes once retorted, “To keep from exploding — that’s why I fly!”

headline: The Deadly 1918 Flu Epidemic Gets a Fresh Treatment
abstract: Don Brown’s graphic nonfiction book “Fever Year” skillfully brings young readers directly into the (gruesome) action.
lead_paragraph: Middle school students often tell me that history is boring. “We just memorize facts about dead people,” they say. Already, these 12- and 13-year-olds have come to see historical knowledge as little more than a list of names and dates. All breadth and no depth, the history they’ve encountered has been stripped of meaning. Where are the specific people? Where are the personal stories? No wonder so many kids are indifferent to our past.

headline: Mark Sanford - Executive Power
abstract: The Times sent a survey to the 2020 candidates about their understanding of the scope and limits of the presidential authority they would wield if elected.
lead_paragraph: The Times sent a survey to the 2020 candidates about their understanding of the scope and limits of the presidential authority they would wield if elected.

headline: What We Know About the Suspect in the N.Y.C. Homeless Killings: Randy Santos
abstract: Randy Rodriguez Santos, 24, had a history of violence and strange behavior before he was charged with murder on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of bludgeoning four homeless men to death on Saturday had a history of violence and strange behavior leading up to the horrific attacks, which have shaken the homeless community and renewed awareness of the dangers faced by people living on the street.

headline: DaBaby and the Beatles Shake Up the Album Chart
abstract: The North Carolina rapper’s “Kirk” debuted at No. 1 on the strength of streaming, and a 50th-anniversary reissue of “Abbey Road” was a big seller.
lead_paragraph: Streaming hits dominate the top of the Billboard chart this week, with the North Carolina rapper DaBaby taking No. 1. But the biggest winner may be the Beatles.

headline: It’s Not Entertaining. It’s Having People Over.
abstract: Alison Roman’s philosophy of cooking for others: Make it about unfussy food and unfussy vibes. Here’s a full menu for a meal.
lead_paragraph: “Roasting a nice chicken for people is such a good way to say ‘I love you.’” I recently found this note to myself scrawled on the back of an electric bill I had probably forgotten to pay, written one night after a dinner party. There was most likely a lot of wine that night (the best ideas always come from a lot of wine), which explains my poor penmanship and well-intentioned but fragmented deep chicken thought.

headline: Impeachment Fight May Help a New NAFTA Deal
abstract: As a delegation of Democrats heads to Mexico, the impeachment battle could be a plus when it comes to ratifying a new North American trade agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The escalating impeachment drama between Congress and the White House that has all but doomed hopes of most legislative progress this fall has instead enhanced the prospects for approval, within weeks, of one major initiative: a sweeping new trade agreement among the United States, Canada and Mexico.

headline: Seeking Ukraine Aid Records, House Subpoenas White House Budget Office and Pentagon
abstract: Democrats are looking for information that could reveal whether President Trump’s decision to withhold security aid from Ukraine was tied to his bid to pressure its government to investigate rivals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Monday expanded its sprawling impeachment inquiry, issuing subpoenas to the Defense Department and the Office of Management and Budget for documents that could solve lingering mysteries about whether President Trump’s decision to withhold security aid for Ukraine was tied to his efforts to pressure the government there to investigate his political rivals.

headline: NBCUniversal Shakes Up Leadership at Peacock, Its Streaming Service
abstract: A new leader was announced for the company’s competitor to Netflix and Disney Plus, which is scheduled for an April debut.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month ago, NBCUniversal announced that it would enter the streaming wars with a new service named after its colorful NBC logo-slash-mascot.

headline: Ruling on Trump’s Tax Returns: 5 Takeaways
abstract: A judge ordered President Trump to turn over eight years of tax returns, but the case raises constitutional issues that could end up in the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, a federal judge issued a ruling that effectively ordered President Trump’s accountants to turn over eight years of his personal and corporate tax returns to the Manhattan district attorney.

headline: A Trump Policy Shift Gives Farmers in Key 2020 States ‘Exactly What We Wanted’
abstract: Midwestern farmers criticized President Trump’s ethanol policy. After weeks of lobbying, the administration changed course.
lead_paragraph: PRIMGHAR, Iowa — In measured but increasingly impatient tones, Midwestern farmers and politicians delivered a message to President Trump: Fix the policies hurting corn prices and prompting ethanol plants to close, or risk alienating one of the most loyal parts of your political base.

headline: Acting Homeland Security Chief Shouted Off Stage at Georgetown Law
abstract: Protesters shut down a speech by Kevin K. McAleenan, the latest effort by opponents of the Trump administration’s hard-line immigration policies to let their grievances be known to policymakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kevin K. McAleenan, the acting secretary of homeland security, was forced offstage at Georgetown University’s law school by demonstrators who shut down his planned keynote address as they protested the Trump administration’s immigration policies.

headline: A Message From the Gods: Keep ‘Lightning Thief’ Fans Happy
abstract: The creators of the Broadway musical may have added songs to the Percy Jackson story, but they’re not about to make the movie’s mistakes.
lead_paragraph: There’s one thing the team behind “The Lightning Thief: The Percy Jackson Musical” wants to make abundantly clear. “Maybe you’ve heard of a movie with a similar title,” the show’s Twitter account warns. “We’re not that.”

headline: Jeffrey Katzenberg’s Mobile Start-Up, Quibi, Makes a Deal With ESPN
abstract: With $1 billion to work with, the veteran Hollywood executive finds more material for his short-form video platform.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Quibi’s latest partner is ESPN.

headline: Taking On the Tortilla Industry
abstract: Kernel of Truth Organics, in Los Angeles, is one of several producers trying to get a better, traditionally made tortilla into supermarkets, restaurants and home kitchens.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Ricardo Ortega wants to convince someone of the unparalleled deliciousness of nixtamalized corn, he hands them a hot tortilla right off his clanking production line in the Boyle Heights neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: Gary Busey Is Playing God. Seriously.
abstract: At 75, the actor is trying his hand at musical theater in an Off Broadway show called “Only Human.” It kind of makes sense.
lead_paragraph: Describing an interview with Gary Busey is nearly impossible. On one hand, the experience is exactly what you might think: Frenetic. Unfocused. The works. His sentences are sprinkled with what he calls “Buseyisms”: acronyms he’s spelled out for decades that hint at his philosophy on life. B.I.B.L.E., for example, is “Basic Instructions Before Leaving Earth,” and partially the title of his memoir.

headline: Players With C.T.E. Doubled Risk With Every 5.3 Years in Football
abstract: A new study is the first to quantify the number of years linked to measurable brain disease.
lead_paragraph: Former tackle football players with chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, doubled their risk of developing the worst forms of the disease for each 5.3 years they played, according to a new study.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Heart Attack: Should He Stay in the Race?
abstract: Readers disagree about whether he should withdraw for the sake of his health or whether it is a “nonissue.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Günter Kunert, 90, Searingly Satirical German Author, Dies
abstract: In his poems, essays, short stories and novels, he highlighted the differences between East and West Germany, even after the Berlin Wall fell.
lead_paragraph: Günter Kunert, a German writer who rose to prominence in the 1960s with satirical and increasingly critical works about the repressive Communist government in East Germany before fleeing to the West, died on Sept. 21 at his home in the village of Kaisborstel, in northern Germany. He was 90.

headline: Whitney Museum Chooses Curators for Its Next Biennial
abstract: David Breslin and Adrienne Edwards are paired up for the museum’s next exhibition, in 2021, after a year filled with controversy over the 2019 Biennial.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art has again reached within its ranks to select a pair of curators to steward its  Biennial exhibition in 2021, which aims to reflect the current social, political and cultural moment through art.

headline: America’s Risky Approach to Artificial Intelligence
abstract: We need to stop pretending that Silicon Valley can compete with China on its own.
lead_paragraph: The brilliant 2014 science fiction novel “The Three-Body Problem,” by the Chinese writer Liu Cixin, depicts the fate of civilizations as almost entirely dependent on winning grand races to scientific milestones. Someone in China’s leadership must have read that book, for Beijing has made winning the race to artificial intelligence a national obsession, devoting billions of dollars to the cause and setting 2030 as the target year for world dominance. Not to be outdone, President Vladimir Putin of Russia recently declared that whoever masters A.I. “will become the ruler of the world.”

headline: How We Went From ‘Soup Nazis’ to Real Nazis
abstract: And why ‘yadda, yadda, yadda’ won’t cut it anymore.
lead_paragraph: If you watch “The Handmaid’s Tale” on basic-subscription Hulu, the fraught dystopian narrative is periodically interrupted with advertisements, one of which promotes “Seinfeld” episodes available on the company’s streaming service. The ad is a rapid-fire montage of famous clips from “Seinfeld,” and it marks the show’s 30th anniversary. Jerry, George, Elaine and Kramer laugh, quip and bounce with manic energy for a dizzying 30 seconds, and we even learn that Hulu has included a “yadda yadda yadda” feature that will play a randomly selected episode. The tonal contrast between the euphoric zaniness of the 1990s sitcom and the stark sincerity of “The Handmaid’s Tale” is a striking illustration of either how far we have come in the last 30 years, or how far we have fallen.

headline: Edible Whisky Pods Cause ‘a Bit of a Stir’ With Scotch Fans
abstract: Glenlivet’s new cocktail capsules come in small pouches, and you can eat them like grapes. But all people can think about is laundry detergent.
lead_paragraph: Glenlivet, one of the venerable names in Scotch whisky, experimented with something new this month: a tiny whisky cocktail that comes in a clear, edible packet instead of a glass.

headline: Supreme Court Opens New Term With Argument on Insanity Defense
abstract: The justices, who drew on law, moral philosophy and history, appeared to find the question tangled and difficult.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first argument of its new term, the Supreme Court on Monday considered whether states may abolish the insanity defense, a question that seemed to puzzle several of the justices, who drew conflicting lessons from history, moral philosophy, constitutional law and the brutal crimes at the heart of the case.

headline: How Will Bernie Sanders’s Heart Attack Affect His Campaign?
abstract: As a leading candidate in an extremely tight race, Mr. Sanders will inevitably face questions about the viability and intensity of his campaign going forward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senator Bernie Sanders recuperates from the heart attack he suffered while campaigning last Tuesday in Las Vegas, he will inevitably face questions in the coming days as to whether he will continue his presidential campaign and, if so, at what pace.

headline: Review: ‘Dublin Carol’ Gets Lost in Its Drink
abstract: Set in a funeral parlor on Christmas Eve, this revival at the Irish Repertory Theater plays alcoholism for drama without resorting to boozy histrionics.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a single line of dialogue to feel the bone-deep malaise that pervades Conor McPherson’s “Dublin Carol”: The play’s set practically screams exhausted shabbiness, drenched in an orange-brown palette Pantone might call Tragic Rust — a monochromatic approach that is representative of the limited emotional landscape to follow.

headline: The Trump-Biden Imbroglio Over Ukraine
abstract: Readers offer Joe Biden a succinct response to accusations against him, discuss the significance of “though” and suggest the term “Trumpwashing” to describe the president’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Walter Hood Wins the Gish Prize
abstract: The landscape designer, public artist and MacArthur fellow will receive a cash award of about $250,000.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after being announced as the winner of a MacArthur fellowship, the landscape designer and public artist Walter Hood is adding another award to his shelf: the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize.

headline: What Happened Today in Trump Impeachment Inquiry News
abstract: The House has issued more subpoenas and a second person is now being protected as a whistle-blower.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to get the Impeachment Briefing in your email inbox every weeknight.]

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The N.B.A. hits a 'third rail' in China.
lead_paragraph: First, a Houston Rockets official tweeted in support of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, inflaming officials and basketball fans in China. Then the N.B.A.’s apology enraged American fans.

headline: ‘Betrayal in Berlin’ Recaptures a Golden Era for Espionage
abstract: Steve Vogel discusses his new book, about the digging of a tunnel under Berlin to intercept communications to and from Moscow in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1950s, the divided city of Berlin teemed with intelligence agents, all trying to keep a leg up for their side in the Cold War. In the midst of this activity, American and British operatives planned to dig a tunnel underneath the city, to intercept communications headed to and from Moscow. In “Betrayal in Berlin,” Steve Vogel, a former longtime reporter for The Washington Post, tells the story of the tunnel’s creation. He also delves into the life of George Blake, a British spy who became a double agent for the Soviets, reporting to them about, among other things, the progress of the tunnel project. Born in the Netherlands, Blake lived an outsize life of both great bravery and great deception. Below, Vogel talks about being inspired by his father’s work for the C.I.A., the similarities between spies and journalists, and tracking down Blake for an interview.

headline: When Biking and Bears Don’t Mix
abstract: Conservationists worry that the popularity of recreational mountain biking and e-bikes in public lands leads to unsafe conditions for humans, as well as for bears and other wildlife.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — The death of a ranger, Brad Treat, in 2016 was a wake-up call for grizzly bear biologists.

headline: Chris Collins Found a Constitutional Protection for Congress Goes Only So Far
abstract: A judge rejected Mr. Collins’s argument that the “speech or debate” clause shielded materials in his insider-trading case from a Justice Department inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Representative Chris Collins pleaded guilty to federal securities fraud charges last week, just weeks after the judge handed his defense a setback on whether the government had violated the Constitution’s “speech or debate” clause.

headline: ‘Joker’: What to Read About the Divisive New Film
abstract: The movie earned roughly a quarter of a billion dollars its opening weekend. It also earned some polarized reviews and an F.B.I. warning. Here’s what people are saying.
lead_paragraph: Is “Joker” a definitive movie of our time? Is it incel propaganda? Might it even be dangerous? The film arrived in theaters last week accompanied by F.B.I. warnings about the threat of related gun violence, but by Monday its international box office had already reached about a quarter of a billion dollars. Meanwhile, the debates over its politics and artistic merit raged on. Here are some of the many reviews, interviews and features that have been prompted by this dark and divisive movie.

headline: Climate Protesters Take to Streets of Cities Worldwide
abstract: Extinction Rebellion, the British-based activist group, shut down parts of central London for the second time in six months.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The climate group Extinction Rebellion blocked all major roads around Britain’s Parliament on Monday in protests the organization said would last two weeks.

headline: Layoffs and Canceled Shows at WBAI-FM, a New York Radio Original
abstract: The foundation that owns the station abruptly scrapped local voices on Monday while also laying off 10 of 12 employees.
lead_paragraph: For decades, WBAI-FM has remained a proudly scrappy alternative in New York’s radio market, a bastion of left-wing political commentary and community voices rarely heard elsewhere on the dial.

headline: Juul Is Sued by School Districts That Say Vaping Is a Dangerous Drain on Their Resources
abstract: The lawsuits accuse Juul of endangering students and forcing educators to divert time and money to fight an epidemic of nicotine addiction among teenagers.
lead_paragraph: With school districts across the United States scrambling to reverse the rise of vaping among teenagers, three of them on Monday filed suit against Juul, the e-cigarette manufacturer, accusing it of endangering students and forcing educators to divert time and money to fight an epidemic of nicotine addiction.

headline: U.S. Blacklists 28 Chinese Entities Over Abuses in Xinjiang
abstract: The companies and security bureaus were barred from buying American products because of their roles in human rights violations against Muslim minorities, the Trump administration said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said Monday that it had added 28 Chinese organizations to a United States blacklist over concerns about their role in human rights violations, effectively blocking those entities from buying American products.

headline: Ohio State vs. Michigan State Brings an Uncomfortable Undercurrent
abstract: For some, the matchup on Saturday brought to mind the massive sexual assault scandals at the two universities, and their problematic responses to them.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The bond between the Ohio State football team and this city extends beyond the 104,797 fans who packed the Horseshoe this weekend, dressing dutifully in black to match the Buckeyes’ made-for-marketing alternate jerseys.

headline: Want to Learn More About Breast Cancer? Read This Book
abstract: A 35-year-old journalist responded to her diagnosis with questions — lots of them. In “Radical,” she delivers the facts and the story of her treatment.
lead_paragraph: RADICALThe Science, Culture and History of Breast Cancer in AmericaBy Kate Pickert

headline: Two Candidates, Two Investigations, One Deeply Flawed Agency
abstract: With “Deep State,” James B. Stewart adds his voice to the conversation about the 2016 election. His scapegoat: the F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: DEEP STATETrump, the FBI, and the Rule of LawBy James B. Stewart

headline: Do You Really Need a Straw With That?
abstract: As plastic alternatives proliferate, some choose to sip instead of suck.
lead_paragraph: “It was never just about the straw,” said Christine Figgener, 35, who was calling from Texas A&M University, where she is finishing a Ph.D. in marine biology. Her voice got stronger the more she ranted. “The straw was supposed to be a symbol, a poster child. It’s a low-hanging fruit.”

headline: Savory and Sweet Snacks From Spain
abstract: Manchego cheese and anise flavor the new mini tortas from Ines Rosales.
lead_paragraph: Ines Rosales, a Spanish company founded in 1910, has recently introduced mini versions of its sweet and savory tortas. The Manchego is savory: buttery and mild. Pair it with a dry fall cider or a spread of fig jam. The original anise is sweet. It smells crisply of licorice, which does not overwhelm the flavor of the cracker. Try it with a lighter white wine.

headline: In Berlin, a Creative Paradise That’s Easiest to Reach by Boat
abstract: Along the Spree River, artists are reviving sprawling industrial buildings in which to let their imaginations run wild.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, when the Berlin Wall came down, the city was left with huge swaths of empty buildings in the former East: old German Democratic Republic embassies and factory complexes, some still riddled with toxic waste. It was both a daunting and heady opportunity for Berlin to reinvent itself and start over. Artists and musicians moved into abandoned breweries, warehouses and basements and slowly brought new life to neighborhoods like Mitte, Prenzlauer Berg and Pankow, which in turn attracted people from around the world. But now, thanks to rising rents, Berlin’s gentrified areas have become too expensive for many of its creative residents, and people have begun to move to farther-flung corners of the city. Three such neighborhoods are the historically industrial areas of Treptow-Köpenick, Rummelsburg and Oberschöneweide, 10 or so miles southeast of the city center, where some of Berlin’s most pioneering artists now occupy a string of former industrial buildings along the Spree River. It is in Oberschöneweide, too, that the Berlin gallerist Johann König, who represents several artists who have moved their studios to the area, is currently negotiating to take over and revive an old cable factory that will host artist studios and residencies. Although the area’s landscape may look post-apocalyptic, with its giant weeds and empty power plants, strangely, the future here can seem positively Arcadian: Real estate is still cheap enough that artists are able to buy, rather than rent, their spaces. Here, four artists discuss how their work is shaped by the Spree.

headline: The Education of Fanatical Centrists
abstract: Will they finally admit what the G.O.P. has become?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that barely three weeks have passed since Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, issued a mysterious subpoena to the acting director of national intelligence, demanding that he produce a whistle-blower complaint filed by someone in the intelligence community.

headline: Trump’s No. 1 Obsession (No, It’s Not Impeachment)
abstract: In their new book, our colleagues write about the issue the president is sure to focus on in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox.

headline: Syria, N.B.A., Nobels: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why a Judge Says She Gave Amber Guyger a Bible, a Hug and Hope of Redemption
abstract: Judge Tammy Kemp said she turned to her faith when a former Dallas police officer asked her for advice and a hug in the courtroom. Not everyone is happy with that.
lead_paragraph: Judge Tammy Kemp is a woman of faith. For more than 25 years, she has attended the same church in Dallas, where she serves as a deaconess. She keeps a Bible in her chambers, positioned on top of her laptop to remind herself to start her day with prayer. And she believes in redemption: In her courtroom, she encourages defendants to use their time in prison to remake their lives.

headline: When ‘Get Out’ Is a President’s National Security Strategy
abstract: President Trump has demonstrated that in his pursuit of ending America’s “endless wars,” no troop presence abroad is too small to escape his desire to terminate it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is once again pursuing a national security strategy at odds with the official position of his government, ordering a pullback of American forces just inside the Syrian border. It is a move that his own senior advisers have warned would risk new chaos throughout the region.

headline: Stephen Lukasik, 88, Who Pushed Tech in National Defense, Is Dead
abstract: He oversaw the Defense Department’s research division in the 1960s and ’70s, when it made great early strides in nuclear-device detection, artificial intelligence and computer networking.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Lukasik, a physicist who oversaw crucial work on national security and computer networking as director of the Defense Department’s research division in the late 1960s and early ’70s, died on Thursday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 88.

headline: Mourning Humble ‘Uncle Kwok,’ 83, Killed in Chinatown Rampage
abstract: He was among four homeless men beaten to death on Saturday. “Our friend and brother,” read a note left at a memorial.
lead_paragraph: For years, he lived outside, sleeping in a small alcove in a storefront on the southern end of the Bowery. For meals, he often ate at modest restaurants in the neighborhood, always ordering inexpensive, filling meals — a pork chop or roast duck over rice.

headline: Pulling of U.S. Troops in Syria Could Aid Assad and ISIS
abstract: Analysts said the redeployment would betray America’s Syrian Kurdish allies, decrease American leverage in Syria and open a void that could benefit Iran, Russia and the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Before dawn on Monday, at a military base in northeastern Syria, an American general delivered the bad news to his Syrian counterpart.

headline: Trump’s Green Light to Turkey Raises Fears About ISIS Detainees
abstract: Thousands of Islamic State prisoners of war from around the world are being detained by the Syrian Kurd forces whom Turkey plans to target.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s sudden blessing of a Turkish military operation in northern Syria and his announcement of an American troop withdrawal from that region raised questions about the fate of thousands of Islamic State detainees that the Turks’ targets, American-backed Syrian Kurds, have been holding in makeshift wartime prisons.

headline: U.S. Using Trade Deals to Shield Tech Giants From Foreign Regulators
abstract: The push is the latest salvo in a global fight over who gets to set the rules for the internet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has begun inserting legal protections into recent trade agreements that shield online platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube from lawsuits, a move that could help lock in America’s tech-friendly regulations around the world even as they are being newly questioned at home.

headline: What Trump’s Aggressive Trade Tactics Have Achieved
abstract: How do the president’s claims about tariffs and trade deficits stack up to reality?
lead_paragraph: Debating trade issues with President Trump’s anti-trade supporters is a constant game of goal shifting. If you point out that the Trump tariffs are raising revenue for Uncle Sam on the backs of American consumers, they reply that China is hurting the most. If you note that the trade war is the main reason the stock market is losing its mind, not actions by Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, they reply that China is “a brutal Communist police state that abuses its own people and steals from the world.”

headline: Caught Between Trump, Turkey and Kurds, Pentagon Struggles to Piece Together Syria Strategy
abstract: The Pentagon is scrambling to respond to the words of a president who views Syria and the fight against ISIS as a battle largely won and done for American troops.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nine months, the Pentagon played down the presence of its 1,000 troops in Syria, hoping that President Trump would not focus on the extent to which the American military was continuing to fight the Islamic State despite his order in December to pull out.

headline: U.S. Pastor Arrested in Rwanda Has Criticized Government for ‘Heathen Practices’
abstract: The Rev. Gregg Schoof is one of several outspoken evangelical pastors who have criticized the Rwandan government for allowing access to abortion and birth control, and for teaching evolution.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — An American missionary who ran a conservative evangelical church and radio station in Rwanda was arrested in Kigali, the country’s capital, on Monday before he could hold a news conference to denounce the government for clamping down on churches like his.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Ending Non-Unanimous Jury Verdicts in Criminal Cases
abstract: A confusing 1972 decision allowed convictions by split verdicts in state courts, though not federal ones. The justices struggled with whether to overrule it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost every part of the Bill of Rights applies to both the federal government and to the states, but the Supreme Court on Monday wrestled with whether to tolerate a rare exception for non-unanimous jury verdicts in criminal cases. Such verdicts are forbidden in federal trials under the Sixth Amendment but permitted in ones held in state court.

headline: Angela Dimayuga’s 10 Essential Filipino Recipes
abstract: The creative director for food and culture at the Standard hotels and former Mission Chinese Food chef chooses the dishes that define the cuisine for her.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in Northern California — where Filipino migrant farm workers started settling in the 1920s, and which today is home to one of the country’s largest populations of Filipino-Americans — the scent of rice, still steamy and warm in the rice cooker, was the steady backdrop to my days. It was so constant from one house to the next, so dependable, that’s how I knew: Wherever I found myself, I was home.

headline: Climate Change Protests: With Fake Blood, Extinction Rebellion Hits N.Y.
abstract: The provocative climate group is trying to disrupt the city, hoping for the success it has had in London and elsewhere in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Tourists and workers on Wall Street on Monday were met by a jarring spectacle: protesters, some lying in pools of fake blood outside the New York Stock Exchange, some dancing and others chanting, all to call attention to people killed by climate-related disease and disaster.

headline: Colliding With China, the N.B.A. Retreats With a Bruised Spine
abstract: Daryl Morey’s tweet, quickly deleted, caused a stir mostly because it rattled the league’s access to a billion-dollar market.
lead_paragraph: I got off a plane Sunday afternoon and checked my phone and saw a statement from the N.B.A. apologizing to China for something that Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey had tweeted. What line, I wondered, had Morey transgressed? Had he slurred a player? A team?

headline: Samuel Little Is Most Prolific Serial Killer in U.S. History, F.B.I. Says
abstract: Mr. Little, 79, has confessed to 93 murders, and the agency believes “all of his confessions are credible.”
lead_paragraph: After years of painstaking investigation into the grisly confessions of a graying man in a wheelchair inside a Los Angeles County prison cell, the F.B.I. announced on Sunday that Samuel Little, who has admitted to strangling vulnerable women across the country for decades, is the most prolific known serial killer in American history.

headline: 12 Men Charged With Raping 2 Girls on or Near University Campus
abstract: Several of the defendants are students at Jacksonville State University in Alabama, school officials said.
lead_paragraph: A dozen men in Alabama, including several Jacksonville State University students, have been charged with rape or sodomy after being accused of having sexual encounters with two minors on or near the campus.

headline: Rays Top the Astros and, for Once, Fill Their Stadium
abstract: Tampa Bay has struggled to pack Tropicana Stadium despite success on the field, but their first home postseason game in six years drew a lively crowd.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Baseball is not dead in the Tampa Bay area, not just yet.

headline: Falwell Settles Court Case Over ‘Pool Boy’ Business Deal
abstract: The settlement concludes a case that drew national attention over its connections to Michael Cohen, President Trump’s former fixer.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A settlement has been reached in a Florida court case over a disputed business deal that resulted from an unusual friendship that Jerry Falwell Jr. and his wife struck with a former pool attendant at a Miami Beach hotel, court records show.

headline: PopSugar Acquired by Group Nine Media in Latest Digital Media Deal
abstract: Group Nine, run by Ben Lerer, adds a brand with an audience of young women to its roster of websites.
lead_paragraph: If three’s a trend, then digital media mergers are officially a thing.

headline: Battle for PG&E Hinges on Rival Plans and Uncertain Costs
abstract: As the utility defends its bankruptcy plan against a challenge from bondholders and wildfire victims, its liabilities are still being calculated.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California’s biggest utility is battling for its future. And it’s not a simple fight.

headline: Cardinals Even Series With Braves Behind Another Late Rally
abstract: Six outs from being eliminated, St. Louis tied Monday’s game and then won in the 10th inning, pushing Atlanta to a deciding Game 5 on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — With all of their late drama over five days — a ninth-inning rally on Sunday, nine runs in the final two innings a couple of nights before that — perhaps it was predictable that the Atlanta Braves and the St. Louis Cardinals would push one of their postseason duels beyond the constraints of nine innings.

headline: Remember When Bill Clinton Was Accused of Trading White House Access for Political Favors?
abstract: Republican lawmakers were incensed. Yet President Trump has actually warped foreign policy for political reasons and they defend him.
lead_paragraph: “Heard from White House — Assuming President Z convinces trump he will investigate/‘get to the bottom of what happened’ in 2016, we will nail down date for visit to Washington.”

headline: Highlights From The New York Times Food Festival
abstract: Watch panel discussions with cooking experts and Times journalists as they tackle the biggest food issues of today.
lead_paragraph: Past and present Times restaurant critics tell all in this discussion with Frank Bruni, Ruth Reichl, Sam Sifton and Pete Wells, moderated by Kim Severson.

headline: Nets Owner Joe Tsai Didn’t Seem Political. Until Now.
abstract: In response to an N.B.A. executive’s Twitter post, Tsai called pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong a “separatist movement,” further inflaming a geopolitical controversy.
lead_paragraph: The owners of major American sports franchises generally do not dive headlong into geopolitical firestorms.

headline: How the Yankees Won Game 3 to Sweep the Twins
abstract: The Yankees continued their postseason dominance of Minnesota, clinching their series with a win in Minneapolis and advancing to the American League Championship Series.
