lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Yankees established themselves as one of the best teams in baseball during the regular season using a specific formula: a potent offense, a starting rotation that could deliver solid but not particularly long outings, and stout relief. To cruise past the Minnesota Twins in their American League division series, the Yankees stuck with that pattern.

headline: The Hot Topic Is the Future of Food
abstract: Les Dames d’Escoffier New York hosts its annual look at emerging food trends.
lead_paragraph: Do you have 2020 vision when it comes to what you’ll be eating and drinking next year? Les Dames d’Escoffier New York, a women’s culinary organization, plans to help, with a panel discussion next week. Among the eight experts will be Justin Chapple, a culinary director at large for Food & Wine magazine; Jake Cohen of the Feedfeed, an online food platform; Deb Perelman of the blog Smitten Kitchen; Gaby Dalkin, a cookbook author and blogger; and the food historian, Jessica B. Harris.

headline: 3 Babies Die at a Pennsylvania Hospital After Bacterial Infections
abstract: The premature babies were being treated in a neonatal intensive care unit when they were infected. Five other babies were also sickened.
lead_paragraph: Three premature babies have died after being infected by bacteria while in a neonatal intensive care unit at a hospital in central Pennsylvania, where five other babies were also sickened, hospital officials said on Monday.

headline: The Beatrice Inn Gets a Cookbook
abstract: In “Butcher + Beast,” the chef Angie Mar tells the restaurant’s story through meaty recipes and flashy photography.
lead_paragraph: The Beatrice Inn in the West Village has been on New York’s dining map since the 1920s, when it started as a speakeasy. Angie Mar, its chef, butcher and now an owner, tells its story in a new cookbook, which features a seasonal roster of meaty recipes to tempt big appetites and cooks who might not be daunted by provocative photos of whole raw livers, swaths of honeycomb tripe and high-fashion footwear. After decades as a nightclub and celebrity haunt, the restaurant became Graydon Carter’s vision of a chophouse. Then Ms. Mar brought it back into the limelight. (Pete Wells awarded it two stars in 2016.) Chicken liver pâté, lovely quince tarte Tatin and buttermilk fried chicken are among the least challenging recipes in the book. At the opposite end, you have beef aged in whiskey that must occupy the far-reaches of your fridge for a good five months, smoked meats and complex meat pies.

headline: An Amaro From a Spice Master
abstract: The spice shop La Boîte adds a food-friendly amaro to the spirits it makes.
lead_paragraph: Those who have yet to embrace amari — the hyper-trendy bitter aperitifs originally from Italy but now concocted far and wide — might consider starting with the new one from La Boîte, the New York spice specialists, made by Cardinal Spirits of Bloomington, Ind. Lior Lev Sercarz, the owner of La Boîte, developed this amaro to be food-friendly, using culinary spices (his métier) in a base of distilled red wine. The result is mellower than most and can be sipped on its own, though a fortifying splash of gin or vodka would not be a mistake. The reddish-amber spirit, 40 proof, is slightly smoky and tinged with orange zest and anise.

headline: Own a Piece of Katz’s Deli
abstract: For the pastrami superfan, a carving board made from the famed deli’s wooden countertop.
lead_paragraph: From time to time, the wooden countertops at Katz’s Delicatessen on the Lower East Side require replacing. The owners have now hit upon a way to recycle the used ones. They’re chopping them up and selling them, stamped with the Katz’s logo, as carving and serving boards for the home. Each one is 14 inches by 10 inches, one and a half inches thick and heavy.

headline: This Dinner Helper Has a Pedigree
abstract: These new frozen breaded pork cutlets are made from heritage pork and prepared by a local butcher.
lead_paragraph: Heritage Foods has come up with an easy, high-quality item for dinner: breaded pork cutlets (scaloppine), ready to sizzle in a pan and serve. (They come frozen but defrost in no time.) The results are tasty, quite tender and could be finished with a tangle of arugula salad, used Parm-style or topped with sautéed peppers and onions. The meat is cut from heritage pork porterhouse steaks, something you’re not likely to find in your neighborhood supermarket or even most butchers, and prepared by Pepe Giocoli, who owns Parma Sausage in Paterson, N.J.

headline: Does Donald Trump Know What His Syria Policy Is?
abstract: Another round of contradictory signals from the White House shakes allies’ trust and puts lives at risk.
lead_paragraph: American diplomats thought they had negotiated a solution to a seemingly intractable problem. The United States needed Kurdish-led forces in northern Syria to face off against remnants of the Islamic State. But Turkey, a NATO ally, saw those same Kurds as terrorists, allied with separatists inside Turkey.

headline: Swine Fever? Trade War? China Turns to Strategic Pork Reserve
abstract: The tariff fight has added to Chinese shoppers’ grocery bills. How is the government coping? By tapping its gigantic stockpile of emergency meat.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When supplies of China’s favorite meat run low, Beijing calls upon its strategic pork reserve, a name that brings to mind vast piles of sausages, bacon and spareribs housed in secret underground vaults across the country.

headline: When It Comes to China, Silence Is Golden
abstract: The N.B.A., like other American businesses, has shown that it’s willing to play by China’s rules in exchange for China’s money.
lead_paragraph: “Fight for freedom. Stand with Hong Kong.”

headline: Hong Kong Stock Market Retracts Offer to Buy London Exchange
abstract: Regulatory concerns would have made a deal difficult. Still, both exchanges and their home cities face difficult questions about their future.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Hong Kong’s stock exchange will no longer proceed with its nearly $37 billion offer  to buy its London competitor, it announced on Tuesday morning, in a setback for the exchange’s long-running effort to build a closer connection to European markets.

headline: The World’s Wokest Sports League Bows to China
abstract: The N.B.A. apologizes on behalf of Daryl Morey, a general manager who voiced support for democracy.
lead_paragraph: The national editor of this newspaper last year asked the commissioner of the N.B.A. at a conference how it felt “to be the wokest professional sports league.” It was a fair description: While Colin Kaepernick has been unable to find a job in the N.F.L. after kneeling during the national anthem to protest police brutality, basketball stars like LeBron James, Derrick Rose and Kobe Bryant have freely expressed their support for the Black Lives Matter movement, even on the court.

headline: Review: In ‘Heroes of the Fourth Turning,’ a Red-State Unicorn
abstract: An astonishing new play by Will Arbery risks a rare stage subject: Christian conservatism.
lead_paragraph: They would not at first seem so different from you and me.

headline: Guided by Brooms
abstract: Ross Trudeau throws us a curveball.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I will freely confess that I am a bit biased toward this crossword by Ross Trudeau, and it’s not just because it was an entertaining puzzle.

headline: Rick Perry’s Focus on Gas Company Entangles Him in Ukraine Case
abstract: The energy secretary pushed for changes at Naftogaz with Ukraine’s new president as President Trump sought inquiries into political opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Energy Secretary Rick Perry led an American delegation to the inauguration of Ukraine’s new president in May, he took the opportunity to suggest the names of Americans the new Ukrainian government might want to advise and oversee the country’s state-owned gas company.

headline: Ryan Zimmerman and Max Scherzer Lift Nationals Past Dodgers
abstract: The teams will return to Dodger Stadium to decide their division series after Zimmerman hit a three-run homer and Scherzer delivered a strong seven innings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ryan Zimmerman was the first player ever drafted by the Washington Nationals, with the fourth overall choice in 2005. He had starred at the University of Virginia, but this was more than a hometown selection. It was a sound baseball pick that gave the team its first homegrown star.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, October 8, 2019.

headline: He Served 10 Days in Jail for Missing Jury Duty. Now the Judge Has Cleared His Record.
abstract: A Florida judge declared Deandre Somerville “totally rehabilitated” and rescinded his finding of criminal contempt.
lead_paragraph: When Deandre Somerville overslept and missed jury duty in August, Judge John S. Kastrenakes was not impressed. He held Mr. Somerville in contempt, scolded him in court and slapped him with a 10-day jail sentence and one year of probation — Mr. Somerville’s first criminal offense.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: BET’s Hip Hop Awards and ‘On the President’s Orders’
abstract: Cardi B is up for 10 awards at the 2019 Hip Hop Awards. And PBS airs the documentary “On the President’s Orders.”
lead_paragraph: HIP HOP AWARDS 8 p.m. on BET. The comedian and actor Lil Duval will host BET’s Hip Hop Awards, welcoming the genre’s biggest names to the Cobb Energy Center in Atlanta. After taking home four awards at last year’s ceremony, Cardi B received 10 nominations this year, more than any other artist. The rapper Lil’ Kim will be honored with the “I Am Hip Hop Award,” and Megan Thee Stallion, Offset and Anderson .Paak will perform.

headline: Late Night Suggests Kurdish Forces Dig Up Dirt on Joe Biden
abstract: “Or as I like to call it, a Kurd pro quo,” Trevor Noah joked Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Word + Quiz: fatuous
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: These Women Say a Trusted Pediatrician Abused Them as Girls. Now They Plan to Sue.
abstract: State officials stripped Stuart Copperman of his medical license almost 20 years ago. Armed with a new law, his former patients hope to file civil lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Copperman was, to all appearances, an old-fashioned pediatrician. For 35 years, he ran a bustling practice in Merrick, Long Island, where he was revered by parents as an authority on everything from colic to chickenpox. Well-dressed, affable and tan year-round, he was always available in an emergency, and even made house calls.

headline: ACT Change Will Allow Students to Retake Individual Sections
abstract: Starting next September, high schoolers won’t need to repeat the entire ACT exam to improve their score.
lead_paragraph: High school students will find the intense pressure to present their best efforts on the ACT exam a bit easier next year as they buckle down to the competitive college admissions process.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How to Develop an Appetite for Insects’
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the stigma against eating bugs — plus how and why scientists think we should undo it.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How to Develop an Appetite for Insects”

headline: ‘South Park’ Creators Offer Fake Apology After Show Is Erased in China
abstract: “Like the N.B.A., we welcome the Chinese censors into our homes and into our hearts,” the show’s creators said in a tongue-in-cheek response. “We too love money more than freedom and democracy.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “South Park,” the long-running Comedy Central cartoon whose mockery has spared few touchy topics, was erased from major platforms in China after an episode last week taunted Chinese censors and the far-reaching effect they often have on American entertainment.

headline: Vision Quest
abstract: How going temporarily blind led me to see my life more clearly.
lead_paragraph: Early one summer morning, I was awakened by a hammering on the inside of my skull. It felt as if a prisoner were trying to Shawshank it out through my left eye socket. When I sat up in bed to reach for the Advil on my nightstand, I became panic-stricken. Both eyes were open, but I could see through only one.

headline: Pregnant? Try Not to Sleep on Your Back
abstract: Pregnant women who slept on their backs were more likely to have babies with low birth weight.
lead_paragraph: During pregnancy, sleeping on your back may be a bad idea.

headline: Dating While Ob-Gyn
abstract: When a romantic prospect learns what I do for a living, things often get interesting. And weird.
lead_paragraph: When you first meet someone and she tells you what she does for a living, it’s not uncommon to think about what that means for you.

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Flannery O’Connor to Cigarettes
abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THREE FLAMES, by Alan Lightman. (Counterpoint, $25.) Set in Cambodia, Lightman’s first novel in almost a decade follows three generations of a rural farming family as they struggle to adjust to changing values and the steady encroachment of the modern world.

headline: At 5, She Protested Homosexuality. Now She Protests the Church That Made Her Do It.
abstract: In Megan Phelps-Roper’s “Unfollow,” a former member of the Westboro Baptist Church relives her extremist childhood.
lead_paragraph: UNFOLLOW A Memoir of Loving and Leaving the Westboro Baptist ChurchBy Megan Phelps-Roper

headline: A Place of Solace
abstract: Where is yours?
lead_paragraph: Where do you go when you need to get away from it all?

headline: Supreme Court Considers Whether Civil Rights Act Protects L.G.B.T. Workers
abstract: The court seemed divided along predictable lines, with a possible exception: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, a member of the conservative majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of exceptionally hard-fought arguments on Tuesday, the Supreme Court struggled to decide whether a landmark 1964 civil rights law bars employment discrimination based on sexual orientation and transgender status.

headline: Taking Dickens to the Dark Side
abstract: Jon Clinch’s new novel, “Marley,” is a noirish prequel to “A Christmas Carol,” revealing just how Scrooge became, well, Scrooge.
lead_paragraph: MARLEY

headline: How Donald Trump’s Obsession With Immigrants Has Shaped His Presidency
abstract: “Border Wars,” by Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear, details the administration’s draconian immigration policies.
lead_paragraph: BORDER WARSInside Trump’s Assault on ImmigrationBy Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear

headline: Statins May Affect Your Bone Health
abstract: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs may affect osteoporosis risk, depending on the dose.
lead_paragraph: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs may have an added benefit, or risk, depending on the dose. New research suggests that a low dose of statins may protect against osteoporosis, but that high doses may increase the risk for the bone-damaging condition.

headline: G.M. Strike’s Economic Toll Is Showing: ‘I Might Lose the Business’
abstract: Much of the pain from the strike, now in its fourth week, is concentrated in the northern Midwest, which was already contending with a manufacturing slowdown.
lead_paragraph: The truck drivers at Phoenix Transit & Logistics in Dearborn, Mich., are long gone. Around three dozen of the trailers they once ferried between auto plants — packed with dashboards, engine components, lights and other parts for General Motors — are sitting in a lot with nowhere to go.

headline: A Critic Considers the ‘Ecstasy and Terror’ of Today With the Help of a Few Ancients
abstract: Daniel Mendelsohn’s essays examine subjects across the millenniums, from Sappho and Euripides to “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: ECSTASY AND TERROR From the Greeks to “Game of Thrones”By Daniel Mendelsohn

headline: The Power and Hurt of Growing Up Black and Gay
abstract: In “How We Fight for Our Lives,” the poet Saeed Jones recalls a coming-of-age marked by sexual violence and bigotry as well as tenderness.
lead_paragraph: HOW WE FIGHT FOR OUR LIVESBy Saeed Jones

headline: The Pioneering British Socialist Who Revolutionized Children’s Literature
abstract: “The Life and Loves of E. Nesbit,” a new biography by Eleanor Fitzsimons, is an admiring portrait of the author of “The Railway Children” and dozens of other books.
lead_paragraph: THE LIFE AND LOVES OF E. NESBIT

headline: Zadie Smith Experiments With Short Fiction
abstract: In her first story collection, “Grand Union,” the British novelist moves beyond traditional narrative into the surreal, the essayistic, the pointillist.
lead_paragraph: GRAND UNION StoriesBy Zadie Smith

headline: Expect Higher Prices on Lighter Wines
abstract: Some European wines with less than 14 percent alcohol will be subject to new U.S. tariffs on Oct. 18.
lead_paragraph: The coming 25 percent American tariff on certain European foods, drinks and other products will hit a lot of people hard, but few harder than Jon-David Headrick.

headline: He Was Trump’s First Fan in Congress. Now He’s a Felon.
abstract: Chris Collins’s sudden rise and fall from presidential cheerleader to admitted liar is a tale of money, family ties and murky ethics.
lead_paragraph: The South Lawn of the White House was decked out in New York City paraphernalia for President Trump’s first congressional picnic: food carts, boat racing and a Central Park-like carousel, all in honor of the president’s hometown.

headline: Julián Castro’s Mom Always Wanted Him to Be This Outspoken
abstract: It took Donald Trump to help get him there.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — When Rosie Castro’s sons, Julián and Joaquin, were still in elementary school, she took them to countless political meetings in San Antonio, hoping they would learn to see the world as she did: a place that needed Mexican-American voices, like theirs, fighting for representation in the upper echelons of power. A place that needed them to speak with urgency about civil rights and racism.

headline: Paul Rudd, the One-Man Double Act
abstract: The star of “Ant-Man” and “Avengers: Endgame” confronts himself, quite literally, playing both an imperfect man and his perfect clone in “Living With Yourself.”
lead_paragraph: Like many other moviegoers, Paul Rudd emerged from “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood” thinking a lot about Brad Pitt. Having spent a couple of hours this summer in a darkened theater, where he watched the effortlessly self-assured Pitt spar with Bruce Lee, pal around with Leonardo DiCaprio and strip off his shirt to fix a television antenna, Rudd left feeling slightly bedazzled and slightly intimidated, but also feeling that his own place in the cultural hierarchy had been clarified.

headline: Miss Subways Is Back. This Year, a New Wave Rocker Takes the Crown.
abstract: The storied “beauty” pageant, revived two years ago, now rewards those who most creatively vent their frustration at public transit.
lead_paragraph: Last week in Brooklyn, Miss Subways 2019 was crowned with a wreath of plastic rats, troll dolls, and rhinestone unicorns.

headline: Stress Can Make You Sick. Take Steps to Reduce It.
abstract: In his new book, “The Stress Solution,” Dr. Rangan Chatterjee offers advice on countering the damaging effects of chronic stress.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago Dr. Rangan Chatterjee had a patient with Type 2 diabetes who was struggling to lower his blood sugar levels despite following an intense diet and exercise program.

headline: 5 Haunts With Haunts
abstract: This Halloween season, why not spend a night or two at a hotel frequented by the dearly departed?
lead_paragraph: Halloween and haunted houses go together like costumed children and epic sugar highs. This year, perhaps you would like to spend Oct. 31 with an overnight stay at a house or hotel frequented by the dearly departed. In the United States, there’s no shortage of rumored haunted accommodations, and the five options here celebrate their haunted histories with Halloween festivities, ghost encounter-filled guest books and more.

lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Sebastian Modak, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2019 list. He arrived in France from Germany, where he visited Munich and Dessau in search of culture and history.

abstract: Moderators of an online forum called Black People Twitter have caused an uproar by requiring participants to submit a photograph proving they are not white.

headline: Online Map Leads Archaeologist to Maya Discovery
abstract: Lidar has transformed the study of ancient civilizations, but maps made with the technology are expensive. Takeshi Inomata found a great one for free.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, archaeology was limited by what a researcher could see while standing on the ground. But light detection and ranging, or lidar, technology has transformed the field, providing a way to scan entire regions for archaeological sites.

headline: A General Store Stopped Selling The Times. A Young Entrepreneur Stepped In.
abstract: Oliver Szott, 14, sells newspapers from his porch to a group of loyal customers in Barnard, Vt.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: In Phillipsport, N.Y., a “Perfectly Unfinished” Project
abstract: The 1823 church was untouched by time — maybe a little too untouched. And solving the plumbing problem wasn’t going to be easy.
lead_paragraph: The 1823 church was untouched by time — maybe a little too untouched. And solving the plumbing problem wasn’t going to be easy.

headline: It Was the Ideal Antique Building. Who Needs Bathrooms, Anyway?
abstract: The 1823 church was untouched by time — maybe a little too untouched. And solving the plumbing problem wasn’t going to be easy.
lead_paragraph: The first time Matthew Bremer saw the listing for the church he would eventually buy in Phillipsport, N.Y., it arrived like so many unwanted emails, as inbox-clogging spam. But rather than immediately hitting delete he scrolled down the email while eating lunch and was intrigued by what he saw: a simple white clapboard church dating to 1823 that was so untouched by time its only bathroom was an outhouse.

headline: As Sea Levels Rise, So Do Ghost Forests
abstract: Saltwater is killing off woodlands all along the mid-Atlantic coast, sometimes surprisingly far from the sea.
lead_paragraph: Saltwater is killing off woodlands all along the mid-Atlantic coast, sometimes surprisingly far from the sea.

headline: Nobel Prize in Physics Awarded for Studies of Earth’s Place in the Universe
abstract: The cosmologist James Peebles split the prize with two astronomers, Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz, for work the Nobel judges said “transformed our ideas about the cosmos.”
lead_paragraph: This year’s Nobel Prize in Physics went to an astrophysicist who came up with sweeping ideas to explain how matter in the young universe swirled into galaxies, and to two astronomers who showed that other stars similar to the sun also possess planets.

headline: Beware of Automated Hiring
abstract: It won’t end employment discrimination. In fact, it could make it worse.
lead_paragraph: Algorithms make many important decisions for us, like our creditworthiness, best romantic prospects and whether we are qualified for a job. Employers are increasingly using them during the hiring process out of the belief they’re both more convenient and less biased than humans. However, as I describe in a new paper, this is misguided.

headline: Republicans Stand by Trump Because They Like What He Does
abstract: Sometimes, the simplest explanation is the correct one.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is probably the weakest he’s been since becoming president.

headline: Will the Supreme Court Hand Trump Even More Power?
abstract: The justices could take up a case on whether the president can fire the heads of independent agencies like the Fed.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s 2019-20 term started on Monday, but one of the biggest cases, on expanding presidential power, isn’t on the docket — yet. It will probably be soon, though, because President Trump’s Justice Department and other plaintiffs took remarkable steps in September to get the Supreme Court to take cases presenting the issue squarely about the reach of the president’s firing authority over independent agency heads, and Justice Brett Kavanaugh invited these audacious challenges to settled precedents when he was on the appellate court in Washington.

headline: How to Save Iraq
abstract: The prime minister has improved relations with the Sunni minority and the Kurds. But he can’t meet the demands of the protesters without fixing the economy.
lead_paragraph: Iraqis have had enough. After years of poor governance, the Iraqi people have run out of patience with the failures of their governing elites to deliver basic services or to reduce unemployment and corruption. Tens of thousands have come out in protests in Baghdad and parts of southern Iraq since last week. More than 100 protesters have been killed and thousands have been injured by security forces. Broadcasting stations have been attacked and social media platforms and the internet have been blocked.

headline: The N.B.A.’s China Problem Is Getting Worse
abstract: Fallout from a tweet by a Houston Rockets executive about the Hong Kong protests has led to blowback by China’s state broadcaster and American lawmakers.

headline: For Gymnasts, Getting a Grip Is Sweeter Than … You Know
abstract: Honey will be a critical tool for many of the gymnasts at the world championships this week. Do you know how it became an essential part of the sport?
lead_paragraph: Sam Mikulak, a six-time American national champion in gymnastics, always follows the same honeying technique before he mounts the parallel bars.

headline: Twins Don’t Know What Hit Them. (Hint: It Was the Yankees Again.)
abstract: Minnesota improved from 59 wins three years ago to 101 this year. It wasn’t enough.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — There was a mellow quality to conversations with the Twins after their postseason finale with the Yankees on Monday night, a wistful pride at what they had accomplished before that 18-wheeler from New York City flattened them.

headline: White House Declares War on Impeachment Inquiry, Claiming Effort to Undo Trump’s Election
abstract: President Trump’s lawyer denounced the House investigation as an illegitimate exercise, and declared that the executive branch would not participate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House declared war on the House impeachment inquiry on Tuesday, announcing that it would not cooperate with what it called an illegitimate effort “to overturn the results of the 2016 election” and setting the stage for a constitutional clash with far-reaching consequences.

headline: Syrian Rebels See Chance for New Life With Turkish Troops
abstract: Turkey’s plans to create a safe zone in northern Syria will increase the standing of its Syrian allies, who still dream of revolution.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Amid the criticism over President Trump’s Syria policy, there is one former American ally that has welcomed his decision to pull back Kurdish-led forces and allow Turkish troops to create a safe zone in northern Syria: the rebel Free Syrian Army.

headline: China Is a Minefield, and Foreign Firms Keep Hitting New Tripwires
abstract: The N.B.A. and others are finding it difficult to stay neutral in an increasingly politicized, and punitive, China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For international companies looking to do business in China, the rules were once simple. Don’t talk about the 3 T’s: Tibet, Taiwan and the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

abstract: Mr. Uchida takes over a company facing its biggest challenges in nearly two decades in the wake of Carlos Ghosn’s ouster as chairman.

headline: City Parks Piggyback on Infrastructure
abstract: With land scarce, green space is being built into needs like transit hubs and power stations. But the projects come with challenges.
lead_paragraph: Salesforce Park is a lush landscape that stretches four city blocks atop a transit center in San Francisco. With lawns, hillocks, lavender beds, leafy trees and a walking path, it gives commuters a relaxing place to wait for their bus and attracts people who live and work nearby looking for respite in the middle of a busy city.

headline: What Is Middle Class in California?
abstract: Tuesday: You asked, and we found an answer. Also: Pacific Gas & Electric’s complicated bankruptcy proceedings; and a virtual tour of Yosemite.

headline: Joshua Brown, Witness in Amber Guyger Trial, Was Killed in a Drug Deal, Police Say
abstract: Botham Jean’s former neighbor, who testified for prosecutors at Ms. Guyger’s murder trial, was shot to death two days after it ended, fueling widespread speculation.

headline: Top Secret Russian Unit Seeks to Destabilize Europe, Security Officials Say
abstract: Known as Unit 29155, the group is skilled in subversion, sabotage and assassination and has only recently become known to Western intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: First came a destabilization campaign in Moldova, followed by the poisoning of an arms dealer in Bulgaria and then a thwarted coup in Montenegro. Last year, there was an attempt to assassinate a former Russian spy in Britain using a nerve agent. Though the operations bore the fingerprints of Russia’s intelligence services, the authorities initially saw them as isolated, unconnected attacks.

headline: ‘Mister America’ Review: The Returns Are In: Diminishing
abstract: Tim Heidecker plays a bumbling candidate for district attorney in this satire with inspired moments but not much momentum.
lead_paragraph: The jury is still out on whether 21st-century politics has reached a point beyond parody, but the one-note satire “Mister America” proves that it’s still possible to get laughs out of a single gag — and just as possible to belabor the joke.

headline: Ten Years Later, Adam Gwon Is Looking to Kill
abstract: The composer broke out with his touching musical “Ordinary Days.” He’s back with his biggest show yet, the ’70s-set tale of a treacherous burger cook with more than a resemblance to Macbeth.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the composer Adam Gwon emerged.

headline: 5 More Dead Elephants Found at Thailand Waterfall, Officials Say
abstract: Park officials say evidence at the scene suggested the 11 animals had died after a calf slipped in rushing waters, and the others tried to save it.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of five more wild elephants have been discovered below a steep waterfall in Khao Yai National Park in central Thailand, officials said on Tuesday, bringing to 11 the number believed to have been swept away over the weekend after a calf slipped and the others tried to save it.

headline: ‘Not a Commander-in-Chief’
abstract: A former Trump official speaks out. More should.

headline: Ecuador’s President Moves Seat of Government to Escape Protests
abstract: The move came after six days of protests against austerity measures, including the end of a fuel subsidy. Demonstrators clashed with the police and looted businesses.
lead_paragraph: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador — President Lenín Moreno of Ecuador moved the seat of his government from Quito, the capital, to a coastal city more than 150 miles away late Monday in an attempt to protect his government from the large protests against austerity that have racked the country over the past week.

headline: National Book Awards Names 2019 Finalists
abstract: Books by Marlon James, Sarah M. Broom, Yoko Ogawa and Jason Reynolds are among this year’s finalists.
lead_paragraph: Marlon James’s novel “Black Leopard, Red Wolf,” an epic fantasy about a bounty hunter on the trail of a mysterious boy, on Tuesday was named one of the five fiction finalists for the National Book Award.

headline: No One Needs a Superyacht, but They Keep Selling Them
abstract: Billionaires won’t stop buying superyachts. You can even thank Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The end of summer is a nervous time for superyacht designers, and not because they fear that the owners of their latest creations may be disappointed with the first outings in the Mediterranean.

headline: Arrest Us, Please! Extinction Rebellion’s Path to Success
abstract: In barely a year, the group’s tactics have propelled it from a handful of members to worldwide protests. But can it keep that momentum as its actions get more disruptive?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In February 2015, Simon Bramwell climbed into a tree near Bristol, in southwest England, to prevent workmen from cutting down a whole row of trees for a bus lane.

headline: John Bolton Tried to Unseat a Dictator. He Failed.
abstract: Nicolás Maduro remains in power despite U.S. sanctions and attempts to oust him. There’s no more room for improvisation.
lead_paragraph: During John Bolton’s recently ended tenure as national security adviser, he convinced President Trump that the Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro was on the verge of losing power. Mr. Bolton is reported to have been the architect of the several failed attempts to unseat President Maduro, a frequent target of Mr. Trump’s bluster.

headline: Cash, Credit or Painting? How, and Why, Artists Exchange Work
abstract: The shadow economy of trades is both a holdover from the past and a vital practice that keeps artists honest — or at least competitive with their peers.
lead_paragraph: IN 1966, BOB DYLAN visited Andy Warhol’s Factory studio in Midtown Manhattan and sat — saturnine, gnostic, impossibly young — for a Screen Test, one of the short film portraits Warhol started making in 1964 of a number of celebrities, including Dennis Hopper and Edie Sedgwick. Star-struck by his subject, Warhol offered Dylan a painting: a 1963 silk-screened portrait of Elvis Presley, of whom Dylan once said, “Hearing him for the first time was like busting out of jail.” (The portrait, ironically, is taken from a publicity still of Elvis from the Western film “Flaming Star,” in which he looks very sheriff-like.) Dylan accepted the painting — but was then faced with the problem of maneuvering the nearly seven-foot-long canvas into his station wagon. Finally, he tied it to the roof with the help of his friend, the filmmaker Barbara Rubin. Later, when the artist asked Dylan about the painting, the musician admitted that he’d given it to his manager. “But if you gave me another one, Andy, I wouldn’t make that mistake again,” Dylan reportedly said. Only later did Warhol find out that Dylan had traded the canvas for a sofa. The painting now hangs in New York’s Museum of Modern Art. The last so-called “Ferus Type” Elvis to appear at auction — Warhol made 23 of them in total — was sold at Christie’s for $53 million in May. On the fate of the sofa, the record is silent.

headline: How to Stop Superhuman A.I. Before It Stops Us
abstract: The answer is to design artificial intelligence that’s beneficial, not just smart.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of superhuman machine intelligence will be the biggest event in human history. The world’s great powers are finally waking up to this fact, and the world’s largest corporations have known it for some time. But what they may not fully understand is that how A.I. evolves will determine whether this event is also our last.

headline: Adam Silver Commits to Free Speech as Chinese Companies Cut Ties With N.B.A.
abstract: China’s state-run television canceled broadcasts of two preseason games scheduled to be held in the country this week.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A.’s decades-long push to develop China into its biggest overseas market appeared increasingly in jeopardy on Tuesday as the league’s commissioner stood firm in the face of criticism from Beijing and the Chinese threatened financial repercussions.

headline: Lil Peep’s Mother Sues Managers Over His Death
abstract: The emo-rapper overdosed on a tour bus in 2017. His mother says those responsible for his welfare pushed him to perform and plied him with drugs.
lead_paragraph: Before the rising emo-rapper Lil Peep was pronounced dead from an overdose on a tour bus in Tucson, Ariz., almost two years ago, he was “stressed, overwhelmed, burnt out, exhausted and physically unwell,” according to a lawsuit filed on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Lang Lang Returns, Rehabilitated and Almost Reformed
abstract: The superstar pianist made his first concerto appearance in New York since injuring his left hand in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Lang Lang, piano superstar and Billy Joel jam partner, is back on the gala circuit.

headline: Was Heidi the Octopus Really Dreaming?
abstract: They’re far from us on the tree of life, and their brains are very different, and some scientists say we should take care before we assume that cephalopods sleep like we do.
lead_paragraph: Heidi the octopus is sleeping. Her body is still, eight arms tucked neatly away. But her skin is restless. She turns from ghostly white to yellow, flashes deep red, then goes mottled green and bumpy like plant life. Her muscles clench and relax, sending a tendril of arm loose.

headline: Running to the Wedding. Any Wedding.
abstract: Wearing custom tuxedo shirts and sneakers, the Wedding Hashers race to join the wedding photo shoots.
lead_paragraph: When Danielle and James Ellerby show off photos from their 2018 wedding, they have a bit of explaining to do. It’s not because the couple, who live in Halifax, England, eloped while on vacation in New York City. It’s because their witnesses were two strangers in T-shirts and running shoes.

headline: By Taking Aim at Chinese Tech Firms, Trump Signals a Strategy Shift
abstract: In blacklisting surveillance companies, the United States is the first major government to punish China for its crackdown on Muslims.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The world has largely sat by for nearly two years as China detained more than one million people, mostly Muslims and members of minority ethnic groups, in internment camps to force them to embrace the Communist Party.

headline: Beleaguered English National Opera Announces New Artistic Director
abstract: Annilese Miskimmon, of Norway’s National Opera, is joining the troubled company, after Daniel Kramer’s resignation in April.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The English National Opera has in recent years been a company in turmoil, suffering resignations, funding cuts and negative headlines.

headline: Famous in Pittsburgh, a Pizzeria Relocates to New Jersey
abstract: After its Roman-style pizzas and other cooking won national attention, Bread and Salt suddenly closed. Recently it reopened in Jersey City, N.J.
lead_paragraph: After its Roman-style pizzas and other cooking won national attention, Bread and Salt suddenly closed. Recently it reopened in Jersey City, N.J.

headline: Chasing the Perfect Slice, Bread and Salt in Jersey City Looks to Rome
abstract: The restaurateur Rick Easton bakes Roman-style pizza al taglio.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, the seriousness of a pizzeria could be gauged by a simple yes-or-no question: Did it sell pizza by the slice? The ones that cared the most about upholding traditions, maintaining quality and so on — like Totonno’s, John’s of Bleecker Street, Kesté, Lucali, Una Pizza Napoletana — emphatically did not.

headline: Silicon Valley Is Trying Out a New Mantra: Make a Profit
abstract: Start-up investors are warning of a reckoning after the stumbles of some high-profile “unicorns.” Now turning a profit is in.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Fred Wilson, a venture capitalist at Union Square Ventures, recently published a blog post titled “The Great Public Market Reckoning.” In it, he argued that the narrative that had driven start-up hype and valuations for the last decade was now falling apart.

headline: Compassion in Action: Humanizing Politics and Inspiring Global Change
abstract: A Florida teacher offers a framework based on resources from The New York Times to teach students how to “think globally and act locally.”
lead_paragraph: While scrolling through social media, watching the news, or in class, students are bombarded with humanitarian crisis after humanitarian crisis. Without guidance in how to navigate these issues, young people can be left feeling helpless and overwhelmed.

headline: Witness Ordered Not to Speak Is ‘Evidence of Obstruction’ Schiff Says
abstract: Rep. Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, criticized the Trump administration for blocking a top American diplomat from meeting with House investigators in the impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Rep. Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, criticized the Trump administration for blocking a top American diplomat from meeting with House investigators in the impeachment inquiry.

headline: Sam Darnold Cleared to Return for Jets
abstract: The Jets said Darnold would start Sunday when his 0-4 team faces the Dallas Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Sam Darnold has been medically cleared to return to games by the winless Jets and will start on Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, the team announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Meaty American Menu on the Upper West Side
abstract: A branch of a San Francisco Champagne bar, an appetizing shop from Black Seed Bagels, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Stretches of pale wood, often slatted, soften the industrial look of black steel at this handsome Upper West Side newcomer. Larry Bellone and Will Tracy, the owners of Tessa, on Amsterdam Avenue, have opened this sibling (the name is Tessa spelled backward) about a block away. As longtime residents of the neighborhood, they remember when the space housed Memphis, a 1970s celebrity magnet. This new restaurant has a long stretch of bar with 24 seats, banquettes for two and intimate areas, with tables, that can double as private dining rooms. Upstairs is a big dining room and bar. The executive chef, John Schafer, has created a menu that’s more American and somewhat meatier than the one he offers at Tessa, which skews Mediterranean. Pigs in a blanket, roasted bone marrow, clams in white wine, and a grain bowl are some of the appetizers. There are a few pastas, and main dishes include Berkshire pork tenderloin, king salmon with corn pudding, sea scallops with whipped celery root and asparagus, and a burger. Some meat and seafood selections can be ordered grilled simply. “Lots of our customers want no sauces and no vegetables, so we decided to serve some items like that,” Mr. Bellone said.

headline: When the Performance Is Marred by the Phones
abstract: Readers discuss the conflict between long-held expectations of audience behavior and changing times. Also: #MeToo in teaching; the failure of our prisons.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Far-Right Dilemma for Europe’s Mainstream: Contain It or Join It?
abstract: Traditional parties are increasingly working with the far right at a local level, fraying a taboo. Will the cooperation defuse or enable a disruptive force?
lead_paragraph: FRANKENSTEIN, Germany — They called it the Frankenstein coalition, and not just for the location.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Details Her Account of Losing Teaching Job Because of Pregnancy
abstract: Ms. Warren said she had grown more comfortable talking about her experience over the years, explaining why her description of the 1971 episode in her stump speeches differs from how she discussed it in the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is one of Elizabeth Warren’s signature anecdotes in her stump speech: By the end of her first year as a public-school teacher, she was “visibly pregnant,” and the principal wished her luck and hired another teacher to replace her.

headline: Dean & DeLuca Closes Its Flagship Store, at Least for Now
abstract: Signs at the SoHo location, which opened in 1977, say the closing is only temporary, but the company is mum.
lead_paragraph: Dean & DeLuca has closed its flagship store in SoHo, after months of financial turmoil in which it shuttered all its other New York City stores. Two notices on its locked and grated front doors Monday announced the store’s “temporary closing,” and said it “will reopen soon.”

headline: Trump’s Trade War Could Put Swiss-Size Dent in Global Economy, I.M.F. Warns
abstract: The International Monetary Fund is the latest global organization to warn of growing economic fallout from President Trump’s trade war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The new head of the International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that America’s trade war with China could cost the global economy around $700 billion by 2020 — a loss equivalent to the size of Switzerland’s entire economy.

headline: Pregnant Women Should Get Flu and Whooping Cough Shots, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Millions do not, and they may be endangering their babies as well as themselves. Only 35 percent of pregnant women get both vaccines; about half get one.
lead_paragraph: Millions of pregnant women in the United States are not getting two vital vaccines that protect not only their health, but their babies, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Tuesday.

headline: Militia Commander Says It Will Attack Turkish Forces if They Enter Syria
abstract: Turkey’s president said a Syrian operation was imminent but confusion remained over President Trump’s Syria policy.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The commander of the American-backed militia in Syria said Tuesday that it would attack Turkish forces if they entered northeastern Syria, while Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, indicated that such an operation was imminent.

headline: Dick’s Sporting Goods Destroyed $5 Million Worth of Guns
abstract: While promoting his new book, the chief executive said the retailer was reviewing gun sales chainwide. “If we do these things and it saves one life, don’t you think it’s worth it?” he said.
lead_paragraph: Edward W. Stack, the chief executive of Dick’s Sporting Goods, said in an interview this week that his company had destroyed over $5 million in military-style, semiautomatic rifles and was reviewing whether it would continue to sell guns in its more than 720 stores.

headline: Ally of Al Qaeda Killed in Afghanistan Raid, Officials Say, but Taliban Deny It
abstract: U.S. and Afghan officials say commandos killed Asim Umar, head of a Qaeda affiliate that has recruited many militants. The Taliban denied the claim.
lead_paragraph: KABUL — American and Afghan commandos killed the head of an affiliate of Al Qaeda in a southern Afghanistan raid last month, according to a statement released Tuesday by Afghanistan’s intelligence agency.

headline: For All Their Slugging, Twins-Yankees Came Down to Pitching
abstract: The teams combined to hit 613 home runs in the regular season, but the Twins’ relievers failed in key spots during their division series.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — In the days before the Rule 5 draft last fall, Minnesota Twins officials made a choice that would ultimately influence their recent American League division series, and not in a good way. They decided against putting Nick Anderson, a 28-year-old right-hander with a live fastball and not much else, on the 40-man roster.

headline: Is Trump Betraying the Kurds?
abstract: Readers worry that America is putting the Kurds, who have helped us fight ISIS, at the mercy of Turkey, and that bloodshed will follow.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I’m Glad I Never Listened to Him’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: When Juliette was born, I didn’t want to meet her. A year passed before I fell in love with her piercing brown eyes looking up at me from our grandmother’s carpet. “Your half sister,” people say, until I correct them: “My sister.” Endless games and embraces dissolve our 29-year age difference. “Why leave?” she asks now, at 2, following me into the hallway of our father’s home. When I go, a little part of my heart breaks, until we see each other again and she makes it whole. — Audrey Guttman

headline: Mysterious Oil Spill Becomes New Environmental Crisis for Brazil
abstract: Brazil’s president said the government had a theory of what led to the spill, adding that a foreign country was on “the radar.”
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A mysterious oil spill that has polluted shores along a vast area of Brazil’s northeast may have resulted from unspecified criminal activity, and a foreign country could be responsible, President Jair Bolsonaro said Tuesday.

headline: Israelis Watch U.S. Abandon Kurds, and Worry: Who’s Next?
abstract: President Trump’s abrupt order to withdraw American troops from Syria set off alarm bells among Israeli officials who fear the United States might stop standing up for Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s national security does not immediately depend on who controls the border of Turkey and northern Syria, more than 500 miles from its own territory.

headline: He Sings. He Dances. He Creates a Sense of the Otherworldly.
abstract: The genre- and gender-bending French choreographer François Chaignaud wants the audience to have a more intense relationship to dance.
lead_paragraph: François Chaignaud’s introduction to dance came when he was a child growing up in Rennes, France. At a young age — around 7 — he found himself on the conservatory track, immersed in ballet and contemporary dance. While that approach teaches “strength and discipline and builds a lot of skills in the body,” he said in a phone interview, it’s “blind to the fact that dance can be something else.”

headline: Trump Criticizes Minneapolis Over Rally Security Costs
abstract: A $530,000 fee for security at a rally planned for Thursday is too high, President Trump and his campaign said. “Welcome to Minneapolis where we pay our bills,” the city’s mayor said in response.
lead_paragraph: Add the mayor of Minneapolis to President Trump’s long list of Twitter enemies.

headline: Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver and Laura Dern at ‘Marriage Story’ Screening
abstract: And “Slave Play” opens on Broadway with a starry audience.
lead_paragraph: And “Slave Play” opens on Broadway with a starry audience.

headline: In Trump, Turkey’s Erdogan Keeps Finding a Sympathetic Ear
abstract: The Turkish leader has repeatedly talked the president around to his view of the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three times over the past year, President Trump has spoken with Turkey’s leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and told Mr. Erdogan what he wanted to hear.

headline: Scarlett Johansson Spills Secret to Her ‘Marriage Story’
abstract: And stars flock to the opening of “Slave Play” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a story on one hand about divorce, but it’s really a love story and the story of marriage,” said Noah Baumbach, whose film “Marriage Story,” was shown at the New York Film Festival last Friday. The film follows the uncoupling of two characters played by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver.

headline: Fed Chair Powell Signals Balance Sheet Will Grow Soon After Recent Market Turmoil
abstract: The central bank’s vast security holdings, which it had been shrinking until August, will soon expand again.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, said on Tuesday that the central bank would again begin expanding its portfolio of government-backed securities and continued to leave the door open to another interest rate cut this month.

headline: Why You Shouldn’t Believe Tech Companies
abstract: The surveillance state is not inevitable.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.

headline: Diahann Carroll Was the Only Mother I Knew
abstract: My real mother left me when I was a toddler. And then, at age 5, I was cast as Corey Baker on “Julia.”
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, when I woke up to 97 new notifications on Facebook, I knew something was up. They turned out to be condolences over the death of actress Diahann Carroll, who played my mother on the TV show “Julia.” She was the only mother I had ever really known.

headline: Beverly Watkins, Fiery Blues Guitarist, Is Dead at 80
abstract: She performed in relative obscurity for many years, but she made up for lost time after recording her first solo album at the age of 60.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Watkins, a rare woman among blues guitarists, who cleaned homes when music did not pay her enough and did not record her first solo album until she was 60, died on Oct. 1 in Atlanta. She was 80.

headline: How to Decorate a Dinner Table Like a Professional
abstract: Six ideas for creating imaginative tablescapes from interior designers, florists, artists and more.
lead_paragraph: In our modern age, when meals are often shared not only with our immediate guests but with a whole cohort of friends on Instagram, dressing the dinner table has become a ritual that invites both artistic flourish and forensic precision. To simplify the process, T asked a host of creative types — from a husband-and-wife design duo to an artist and a team of florists — to share their tricks for creating a memorable table setting.

headline: Can a Jean Jacket Revive Wearable Technology?
abstract: Lessons have been learned from the unpopularity of Google Glass.
lead_paragraph: There is absolutely no reason I need a jean jacket to tell me my Uber is arriving, but I’m always amused when it does. Thanks, coat. So considerate.

headline: Trump’s Ukraine Call Was ‘Crazy’ and ‘Frightening,’ Official Told Whistle-Blower
abstract: The whistle-blower wrote a memo describing an official who heard the call as “visibly shaken” by it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House official who listened to President Trump’s July phone call with Ukraine’s leader described it as “crazy,” “frightening” and “completely lacking in substance related to national security,” according to a memo written by the whistle-blower at the center of the Ukraine scandal, a C.I.A. officer who spoke to the White House official.

headline: G.O.P.-Led Senate Panel Affirms Russia Attacked Election, and Urges Action
abstract: A report called for steps by Congress, the Trump administration and tech firms, and reiterated a conclusion the president has resisted: Russia interfered in the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump amplifies unsubstantiated claims of Ukrainian interference in the 2016 election, the Republican-led Senate Intelligence Committee reaffirmed on Tuesday that Russian operatives engaged in a widespread social media campaign to improve his chances in the race.

headline: Trump and Tehran Shake Up the Middle East
abstract: Iran’s airstrike on Saudi oil sites exposed vulnerabilities around the region.
lead_paragraph: I’m sure I’m not the only one who finds it bizarre that the Republican leadership is (rightly) going nuts over President Trump’s betrayal of the Kurds in Syria while it’s ignoring his betrayal of the U.S. Constitution at home. If only Lindsey Graham & Co. were as eager to defend our democracy as they are the Kurds. But I digress.

headline: Russian Spies, N.B.A., Trump Defiance: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The White House defies impeachment investigators.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bronx Teenager’s Death Is the Youngest Vaping Fatality in U.S.
abstract: The 17-year-old who died last week is the youngest of 23 people to die nationwide of a vaping-related lung illness.
lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old Bronx boy whose death was disclosed by New York State officials on Tuesday is the first teenager in the United States to die of a vaping-related illness, according to federal and state data.

headline: In Jason Reynolds’s Powerful New Book, Stories Stitch Together a Neighborhood
abstract: The kids in “Look Both Ways,” a National Book Award finalist, share hustles, jokes, video games, board tricks, secret messages and private dreams.
lead_paragraph: The dismissal bell rings at Latimer Middle School and sixth graders spring from their classrooms. We can all imagine the scene: crowded corridors, lockers flung open and shut, a skateboarder weaving past, kids gathering on benches outside, school buses lined up and a teacher at the door to “tell everyone what not to do.” At the corner a crossing guard waits in the same place every day. But in the very first lines of LOOK BOTH WAYS: A Tale Told in Ten Blocks (Simon & Schuster, 188 pp., $17.99; ages 10 to 14), Jason Reynolds’s inspired new novel for middle-grade readers — a National Book Award finalist — we’re reminded to take a closer look. “This story was going to begin … With a school bus falling from the sky. But no one saw it happen. No one heard anything.”

headline: Punches, Rages: Before Chinatown Killings, Suspect Grew Ever More Violent
abstract: Randy Santos is accused of going on a murderous rampage, killing four homeless men, after years of erratic behavior.
lead_paragraph: Randy Rodriguez Santos was unemployed and living in an abandoned building, so in recent weeks he was eager to do odd jobs for the Segarras, a couple who lived next door to his mother in the Bronx.

headline: Leigh Bardugo Brews a Witchy Tale of Ghosts, Dark Magic and Murder
abstract: “Ninth House,” her first adult novel, is set at Yale, where something has gone wrong — very wrong — with the university’s secret societies.
lead_paragraph: NINTH HOUSEBy Leigh Bardugo

headline: In Paris Knife Attack, Missed Signals and Calls for Vigilance
abstract: Police officials did not act on concerns by a killer’s co-workers, but President Emmanuel Macron called on the French to “be on the lookout.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When 12 people were killed at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris in January 2015, Mickaël Harpon — a future killer himself — declared, “serves them right.” A shocked colleague in the city’s Police Department heard him, and a sharp argument ensued.

headline: Prove You’re Not White: For an Article About Race-Verification on Reddit, I Had an Unusual Request
abstract: Asking interviewees who said they were black to show me their faces filled me with discomfort. That was the point.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: I Won Olympic Gold. Now a Word From My Sponsor.
abstract: A new interpretation of a much-loathed marketing rule will allow American athletes to thank their sponsors during the Tokyo Games.
lead_paragraph: American Olympians could find it easier to promote products and sponsors during the Games after the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee loosened some of its strict marketing rules on Tuesday.

headline: Michael Coe, Maya Scholar and Codebreaker, Is Dead at 90
abstract: He authenticated the oldest written manuscript in the Americas and proved that the Maya written language was surprisingly complex.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Coe, a Yale anthropologist who devoted his career to proving that the ancient Maya incubated an elaborate written language that had previously been undervalued by many scholars, died on Sept. 25 in a hospital in New Haven. He was 90.

headline: Sexually Transmitted Disease Cases Rise to Record High, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia in the United States jumped last year, and an alarming number of newborn deaths were linked to congenital syphilis.
lead_paragraph: The number of combined cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia in the United States rose to a record high last year, including an alarming jump in the rate of newborn deaths caused by congenital syphilis, according to figures released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday.

headline: Read the White House Letter in Response to the Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: In a letter to House Democratic leaders, the White House counsel called the House’s impeachment inquiry illegitimate.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to House Democratic leaders, the White House counsel called the House’s impeachment inquiry illegitimate.

headline: F.B.I. Practices for Intercepted Emails Violated 4th Amendment, Judge Ruled
abstract: Newly declassified files reveal a secret court fight over the F.B.I.’s procedures for searching for Americans’ messages within a warrantless surveillance program’s repository.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge secretly ruled last year that the F.B.I.’s procedures for searching for Americans’ emails within a repository of intercepted messages that were gathered without a warrant violated Fourth Amendment privacy rights, newly declassified files showed.

headline: El increíble viaje de Rosalía: de cantante de flamenco a superestrella
abstract: Antes de que sus videos acumularan millones de vistas en YouTube, la artista pasó más de una década estudiando uno de los géneros musicales más antiguos y complejos.
lead_paragraph: Read in English

headline: Did Trump Just Backstab Our Kurdish Allies for Turkey?
abstract: Withdrawing troops in Syria pleases Turkey but endangers Kurds fighting the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: November Debate Will Be in Georgia, With 8 Democratic Candidates So Far
abstract: The Democratic National Committee announced that the debate would be held in the Atlanta area on Nov. 20, hosted by MSNBC and The Washington Post.
lead_paragraph: The fifth Democratic presidential debate of the 2020 campaign will be held in the Atlanta area on Wednesday, Nov. 20, the Democratic National Committee announced on Tuesday. MSNBC and The Washington Post will host it.

headline: Rosalía’s Incredible Journey From Flamenco to Megastardom
abstract: Before her videos were racking up millions of views on YouTube, the artist spent more than a decade training in one of the world’s oldest and most complex musical art forms.
lead_paragraph: Before her videos were racking up millions of views on YouTube, the artist spent more than a decade training in one of the world’s oldest and most complex musical art forms.

headline: ‘I Want to Explore the Wonder of What It Is to Be a Black American’
abstract: Simone Leigh, Amy Sherald and Lorna Simpson talk about the expectations faced by black women in an art world obsessed with identity.
lead_paragraph: Simone Leigh, Amy Sherald and Lorna Simpson talk about the expectations faced by black women in an art world obsessed with identity.

headline: Impeachment, Supreme Court, Octopus: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: To Decode White Male Rage, First He Had to Write in His Mother’s Voice
abstract: How Ben Lerner reinvented the social novel for a hyper-self-obsessed age.
lead_paragraph: How Ben Lerner reinvented the social novel for a hyper-self-obsessed age.

headline: How Susan Sontag Taught Me to Think
abstract: The critic A.O. Scott reflects on the outsize influence Sontag has had on his life as a critic.
lead_paragraph: The critic A.O. Scott reflects on the outsize influence Sontag has had on his life as a critic.

headline: Marshall Efron, Funny Cog in the PBS ‘Dream Machine,’ Dies at 81
abstract: In the 1970s he was part of a much-talked about prime-time TV series as well as a somewhat subversive Sunday morning Bible show for children.
lead_paragraph: Marshall Efron, an actor and humorist who was a core figure in two of the quirkiest television shows of the 1970s, “The Great American Dream Machine” and the children’s program “Marshall Efron’s Illustrated, Simplified and Painless Sunday School,” died on Sept. 30 at the Lillian Booth Actors Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 81.

headline: A Journalist Says He Was Hounded by a U.S. Customs Agent
abstract: According to the journalist’s account, an official at Dulles International Airport repeatedly asked: “You write propaganda, right?”
lead_paragraph: For five years, Ben Watson served in the United States Army, spending part of that time in public affairs in Kandahar, Afghanistan, writing news releases, working as a combat cameraman and accompanying a reporter who was embedded with the troops. Now he is on the other side of the divide, working as the news editor at Defense One, a digital publication owned by Atlantic Media that covers military issues and global security.

headline: Gleyber Torres Has Been Preparing for This Since December
abstract: The Yankees’ 22-year-old infielder delivered big hits and highlight-reel defensive stops in a sweep of the Twins. His improvement started with grueling off-season workouts.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The phone call came in early December, in the dead of baseball’s off-season, when players are on vacation and recovering from the grueling season. Yankees infielder Gleyber Torres, though, was ready to start training.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says He Will Slow His Campaign Pace After Heart Attack
abstract: The Vermont senator said he would “change the nature” of his campaign. He also acknowledged that voters would take his health into account when deciding whether to support him.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders, in a striking concession for a leading presidential candidate, said on Tuesday that he planned to slow down his pace on the campaign trail after suffering a heart attack a week ago, and acknowledged that voters would likely consider his health when deciding whether to support him.

headline: Alec Baldwin Gripes About Tour Boat ‘Scam,’ and N.Y.C. Cracks Down
abstract: Mr. Baldwin complained that he had been victimized by a company that offered tickets to see the Statue of Liberty.
lead_paragraph: Alec Baldwin considers himself a consummate, “savvy” New Yorker, and like most, he is not exactly bashful about expressing his views.

headline: The Agonizing Imperfection of Pete Buttigieg
abstract: So talented yet so vulnerable — like all the leading contenders for the Democratic nomination.
lead_paragraph: If I dreamed up an ideal Democratic opponent for President Trump in 2020, I’d locate that candidate in the industrial Midwest. That’s where Hillary Clinton lost the last election, and it’s where the next one could very well be decided.

headline: Volodymyr Zelensky, Man in the Muddle
abstract: The young Ukrainian leader is jammed between the rock of Vladimir Putin’s aggression and the hard place of President Trump’s demands.
lead_paragraph: In April, Ukrainian voters took a desperate gamble and elected as their president a television performer who played a humble 30-something schoolteacher, Vasyl Petrovych Holoborodko, on a show called “Servant of the People.” On the show, a rant by Mr. Holoborodko against Ukraine’s culture of corruption had gone viral, capturing the mood of a young country profoundly frustrated by the state of affairs and ready for change.

headline: U.N. Report Bolsters Theory That Hammarskjold Plane Was Downed
abstract: Four nations — Britain, Russia, South Africa and the United  States — may be withholding information that could help solve the mystery, a prominent jurist concluded.
lead_paragraph: A prominent jurist investigating the mysterious 1961 plane crash that killed the United Nations secretary general, Dag Hammarskjold, in southern Africa has concluded that the aircraft may have been attacked, and that four nations — Britain, Russia, South Africa and the United States — may be withholding information that could solve the puzzle.

headline: How Did a Serial Killer Escape Notice? His Victims Were Vulnerable and Overlooked
abstract: The families of women killed by a man the F.B.I. has described as America’s most prolific serial killer say their cases went unnoticed for years. “It just tears me up,” one relative said.
lead_paragraph: When Martha Cunningham was found dead near Knoxville, Tenn., in January 1975, her body was bruised, her clothes had been pulled off and she was missing her purse.

headline: For Once, Republicans Break With Trump, but Not on Impeachment
abstract: Foreign policy is one area where congressional Republicans have felt free to criticize the president, and they have bombarded him with public complaints over his decision to pull back in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, an unsparing critic of President Trump before he entered the White House, rarely if ever questions him anymore, even after the president urged foreign governments to investigate his political rivals.

headline: Facebook’s Hands-Off Approach to Political Speech Gets Impeachment Test
abstract: The company’s handling of a Trump campaign ad with unsubstantiated accusations about Joseph Biden foreshadows a continuing fight over misinformation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 30-second video ad released by the Trump campaign last week is grainy, and the narrator’s voice is foreboding. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., it says, offered Ukraine $1 billion in aid if the country pushed out the man investigating a company tied to Mr. Biden’s son.

headline: Trump Betrays an Ally at the Turkish Border
abstract: An American withdrawal from northern Syria will leave Kurds who helped us against the Islamic State to fend for themselves.
lead_paragraph: The last time I saw my friend Abed, he was in the mood to celebrate. It was about a year ago and the two of us met for dinner in Fatih, a district in Istanbul where many Syrian refugees had settled.

headline: California Man Is Convicted of Cyberstalking Parkland Victims’ Families
abstract: Over three weeks, the man impersonated Nikolas Cruz, the confessed gunman, on social media to threaten and taunt.
lead_paragraph: A California man was convicted on Tuesday of cyberstalking and threatening to kidnap relatives of those killed in the 2018 mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., federal prosecutors said.

headline: Montgomery, Ala., Elects Steven Reed, Its First Black Mayor
abstract: Voters chose Mr. Reed, a probate judge, to lead a majority-black city almost 200 years after it was incorporated.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — On the cusp of celebrating 200 years as a city, Montgomery does not have too many “firsts” remaining. But on Tuesday night, the black-majority city and capital of Alabama elected Steven L. Reed as its first African-American mayor.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Hit With $8 Billion Jury Verdict in Risperdal Suit
abstract: A Philadelphia jury found that a subsidiary downplayed the risks that the anti-psychotic drug could lead to breast growth in boys.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia jury on Tuesday hit Johnson & Johnson with an $8 billion verdict over its marketing of the anti-psychotic drug Risperdal, siding with a Maryland man who argued that the health care giant downplayed risks that the drug could lead to breast growth in boys.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Secret Spy Unit in Russia Aims to Jolt Europe
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 9, 2019
lead_paragraph: “I think we had forgotten how organically ruthless the Russians could be.”

lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle by Alan Arbesfeld made for an interesting solving experience. It felt like I had solved two different puzzles, and I enjoyed the second part more than the first. Your mileage may vary.

headline: The Rays Bullpen Their Way Past Justin Verlander and the Astros
abstract: Tampa Bay’s committee of relievers — with help from one starter — outdid the Houston ace, forcing a decisive Game 5 in this division series.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Houston Astros were the kings of the regular season, winning 107 games, the most in baseball. Then they opened their division series against the Tampa Bay Rays with two more wins, enhancing their standing as the favorites to capture the American League pennant, if not win the World Series.

headline: Justin Trudeau Heads North, Fighting for Every Seat in a Tight Race
abstract: Behind the scenes of a journalist’s brief tour to northern Canada with a leader fighting for every seat in a close race.
lead_paragraph: This is a special Canada Letter for the 2019 Canadian election. Sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Nancy Drew’ and ‘Goliath’
abstract: Nancy Drew is reimagined in a new CW series. And a new season of the legal drama “Goliath” is streaming on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: NANCY DREW 9 p.m. on the CW. Sex, darkness and a dash of the supernatural are added to the Nancy Drew formula here, in a series that reimagines that classic young sleuth for a contemporary audience. The hourlong drama raises Drew’s age to 18, and it relocates the action to Maine. The show also gives Drew (played by Kennedy McMann) a tough back story: In this show, she has a strained relationship with her father, and her mother has recently died. There are also ghosts, an element that factors into the show’s first major case, which involves the murder of a socialite. “At the core is the idea of a young woman who believes in righting wrongs and finding the truth,” Stephanie Savage, a creator of the series, said in a recent interview with The New York Times.

headline: Word + Quiz: insouciance
abstract: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Trump’s Just Defending His Street Cred, Trevor Noah Says
abstract: President Trump stopped an ambassador from testifying in the impeachment inquiry because he was afraid the man would “exonerate him too much,” Noah said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: 500,000 in California Are Without Electricity in Planned Shutdown
abstract: Pacific Gas & Electric is cutting electricity as a precaution against sparking wildfires in high-wind conditions.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A deliberate power outage that spanned large parts of Northern California on Wednesday sent hundreds of thousands of people scrambling for gasoline and other essentials as strong, gusty winds and months of dry weather put the state on alert for wildfires.

headline: With a $450 Million Expansion, MoMA Is Bigger. Is That Better?
abstract: The museum added 47,000 square feet of gallery space, a spiffy new canopy and a restaurant. “It’s smart, surgical, sprawling and slightly soulless,” our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: In 1939, the Museum of Modern Art opened its first purpose-built home on West 53rd Street, a taut, rectangular, six-story International Style palazzo clad in Thermolux glass and panels of milky white marble.

headline: In New Memoirs, Two Whistle-Blowers Offer Details From Inside Cambridge Analytica
abstract: Christopher Wylie’s “Mind____” and Brittany Kaiser’s “Targeted” tell of how the company harvested data from millions of Facebook users and attempted to influence voter behavior.
lead_paragraph: The voter-profiling firm Cambridge Analytica, which filed for insolvency last year, looked like the stuff of liberal nightmares. Enumerating its salient features was like playing a game of cartoon-villain bingo. There was the pretentious and slightly ridiculous name, redolent of a Bond-movie syndicate; there was mysterious funding from the right-wing billionaire Robert Mercer and his family, along with deep ties to Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist; and there was a chief executive, Alexander Nix, who was caught on hidden camera bragging about the unsavory lengths the company would be willing to go to sway an election — a political gun for hire in a Savile Row suit.

headline: The Future Teen Stars of America Live on TikTok
abstract: They’re goofy and fun and brands want in.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s been quite a year for Noen Eubanks.

headline: Liz Phair Still Doesn’t Care What We Think
abstract: In her bracing new memoir, “Horror Stories,” the rock star focuses on small, intense, un-rock-star moments.
lead_paragraph: HORROR STORIES

headline: Escaping the Nazis by Way of Iran
abstract: Mikhal Dekel’s “Tehran Children” tells the story of the extraordinarily hazardous journey made by hundreds of Jews from Poland to Iran to Palestine.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN CHILDRENA Holocaust Refugee OdysseyBy Mikhal Dekel

headline: Behind Amazon’s Sudden Change in Its Film Strategy
abstract: After poor box-office numbers for Mindy Kaling’s “Late Night,” the company shrank its ambitious release plan for a big fall movie, “The Aeronauts.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Aeronauts,” an adventure film about swashbuckling 19th-century hot-air balloonists, was built for the big screen. Led by an Oscar winner, Eddie Redmayne, and a “Star Wars” star, Felicity Jones, it has real cinematic sweep, with sequences that take place miles above sea level. In May, Amazon Studios announced that the movie would play exclusively on IMAX screens for a one-week engagement before “a full theatrical run.”

headline: 8 Tips for Hotels, From a Hotel Guest
abstract: Easy additions that can make hotel stays more pleasant.
lead_paragraph: These are not tips for travelers. They are tips for hotels and inns on how to make a guest (me, to be specific) happy. My wife, Jane, and I travel a lot and stay in a variety of accommodations, from a sleep-on-the-floor desert oasis in Iran to landmark hotels in Europe to jungle eco-lodges in Nicaragua. Wherever we are, though, it’s easy to see things that could be changed to make our stay more pleasant.

headline: What Rules, if Any, Should There Be About Phone Use During Live Performances?
abstract: Several recent incidents are new fuel for a heated debate about theater etiquette in the digital age. Do you think it’s time for change?
lead_paragraph: What was the last live performance you saw? Did you or others in the audience use your phones during the show? Were you allowed to?

headline: What Apes Can Teach Us About Our Heart Health
abstract: If gorillas and chimpanzees were born to clamber and climb, humans were born to walk and run.
lead_paragraph: No chimpanzees or gorillas are in training for a fall marathon — a reflection, perhaps, of the ways in which the hearts of apes and men look and function as they do, according to a major new study of the health and evolution of cardiac muscles.

headline: The Heroic Ideal
abstract: Do fictional superheroes have any meaning in your real life?
lead_paragraph: Superheroes, whether on the printed page or a movie screen, are larger-than-life depictions of strength, resilience and honor. Are you inspired by superheroes? If so, which ones, and what about them resonates with your life and values?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Hong Kong Protests Put N.B.A. on Edge in China’
