headline: Does Your Toothbrush Have an App Yet?
abstract: New technology is creating some excitement in the formerly ho-hum world of dental care.
lead_paragraph: When Theresa Gucciardo-Perry discovered a cracked crown in her mouth in April, she dreaded the idea of going to a dentist to get it replaced.

headline: Please Take Them Home. Please Just Take Them Home.
abstract: Pubs and police and problems: sometimes the worst thing about England hitting the road for matches in Europe is that its fans go along.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to receive Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer, delivered to your inbox every Friday.

headline: Lang Lang, Bradley Cooper and Alec Baldwin at New York Philharmonic
abstract: Also, galas were held for Bronx Museum of the Arts and Americares.
lead_paragraph: Also, galas were held for Bronx Museum of the Arts and Americares.

headline: Bradley Cooper and Lang Lang Bond Over Beethoven
abstract: Galas were held for the New York Philharmonic, the Bronx Museum and Americares.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Museum of the Arts held a new charity dinner to support free admission on Oct. 3. The New York Philharmonic opened its new season on Oct. 7 with the pianist Lang Lang. And Americares held a benefit on Oct. 5 at the JPMorgan Chase hangar at the Westchester County Airport.

headline: Support for Impeachment Has Grown but Also Slowed
abstract: Many of the voters who back an inquiry have not reached the same conclusion on removal.
lead_paragraph: Public support for impeaching President Trump — and also for removing him from office — surged after Nancy Pelosi announced the House impeachment inquiry more than two weeks ago.

headline: ‘Jexi’ Review: When a Smartphone Calls You Dumb
abstract: Rose Byrne voices a very aggressive virtual phone assistant who roasts Adam Devine in this comedy from the writers of “The Hangover.”
lead_paragraph: “Jexi,” a comedy written and directed by Jon Lucas and Scott Moore, does not explicitly position itself as a parody of “Her,” the poignant 2013 love story of a man and a very empathetic piece of software. But this movie’s clear play on the premise helps it get off to a fast start.

headline: Britain and E.U. Step Up Last-Ditch Brexit Talks
abstract: After days of gloom, a breakthrough seems possible. But diplomats remain cautious, and time is short.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union agreed on Friday to “intensify” Brexit talks, building on fresh optimism that has kept alive the possibility of an agreement that could allow Britain to make a smooth exit from the bloc this month.

headline: 2020 Presidential Debate Schedule Announced for General Election
abstract: The presidential debates will be held in Indiana, Michigan and Tennessee, and a vice-presidential debate will be held in Utah.
lead_paragraph: The nonpartisan commission that governs presidential debates announced on Friday the dates and sites for the three presidential debates and one vice-presidential debate during the 2020 general election.

headline: Review: Dance Heginbotham and Robert Walser, Nervous Together
abstract: “Herz Schmerz” is the modestly funny collaboration between the choreographer John Heginbotham and Maira Kalman.
lead_paragraph: If someone insists to you that he is not very nervous, only a little nervous — that he is only a little bit over the hill, but certainly not old and used up — and keeps insisting this, with compulsive loquacity, you quickly recognize whistling in the dark. But what if four people are doing that at once?

headline: Early Snowstorm Blows Across the Northern Plains
abstract: An unusually early snowstorm is crippling parts of the Northern Plains as temperatures plummet across the region.
lead_paragraph: An unusually early snowstorm is crippling parts of the Northern Plains as temperatures plummet across the region.

headline: Dying Languages Cry Out in ‘Last Whispers’
abstract: Lena Herzog’s mixture of enigmatic film and immersive sound evokes a global crisis of linguistic disappearance.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The earth spins onscreen amid an eerie, uncomfortable sound, like a building rush of air. It’s an ominous, galactic vision that swiftly condenses into an intimate one: A dot of flickering light in the middle of darkness; a woman’s voice singing, her fragile intakes of breath audible; an electric guitar strumming with spare, melancholy sweetness.

headline: Love Letter: Dating is Hard, Especially if You’re an Ob-Gyn
abstract: Plus: How to train a stubborn but lovable species, the American husband.
lead_paragraph: [This is the Love Letter newsletter. Sign up here to receive it in your inbox. ]

headline: Questions About ‘Gemini Man?’ We Have Answers
abstract: If you’re wondering how they made Will Smith look like the Fresh Prince again, or are curious about the movie’s high frame rate (and what that is), read here.
lead_paragraph: The poster for Ang Lee’s “Gemini Man” has a youthful Will Smith staring down a much older, gray-hair-speckled Will Smith, with a 26-year movie career seemingly filling the space between them. The film navigates some complicated technology to pit a man against his younger, “Bad Boys”-ier self. Just how complicated? And why does it look hyperrealistic? We offer a little bit more clarity on both below.

headline: Storm Bringing ‘Historic’ Snowfall to Northern Plains
abstract: Blizzard conditions closed roads and schools in parts of North Dakota on Friday, as temperatures plummeted across the region.
lead_paragraph: An unusually early snowstorm crippled parts of the Northern Plains on Friday, bringing heavy gusts of wet snow and plummeting temperatures across the central United States, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: White House Threatens Turkey With Crippling Sanctions
abstract: The warning comes after Turkey launched military operations against the American military’s Kurdish allies in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday belatedly threatened new sanctions against Turkey that officials said could cripple Turkey’s economy in response to its military offensive against Kurds in northern Syria.

headline: Mastering Middle School Friendship Drama
abstract: In new graphic novels (one by Kristen Gudsnuk, the other by Shannon Hale and LeUyen Pham), the key to middle school relationships is being true to yourself. If that fails, try magic.
lead_paragraph: Normal girls in their tween years are self-conscious. They worry in equal measure about being seen and not being seen. They worry about their clothes and whether they’re listening to the right music. But cool girls, ah, the cool girls. They seem to exist without being concerned about what anybody else thinks. They seem to fit in without trying and, most irritatingly, without caring.

headline: Botched Medical Procedures May Have Led to Death of U.S. Soldier
abstract: Staff Sgt. Alex Conrad, 26, died from wounds he received during a militant attack on a small outpost in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: A complex and difficult medical procedure that ultimately failed might have contributed to the death of an American Special Forces soldier killed last year in a firefight in Somalia, according to an investigation into the episode obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Poland’s State Media Is Government’s Biggest Booster Before Election
abstract: With state television firmly under the control of the ruling party, it has proved itself more valuable than any billboard or advertising campaign.
lead_paragraph: After the climate change activist Greta Thunberg testified at the United Nations, urging world leaders to take action, the presenters on Polish state television said viewers needed some context.

headline: Judges Strike Several Blows to Trump Immigration Policies
abstract: Judges in three states ruled against a policy that would withhold green cards to immigrants who receive public assistance such as Medicaid. Another judge ruled on border wall funding.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s immigration agenda ran into legal blockades in courts around the country on Friday as judges in four states barred his administration from trying to withhold green cards from people who use public benefits and rejected his plan to divert funds to erect a border wall.

headline: With ‘Lucy in the Sky,’ Noah Hawley Expands His Universe
abstract: The director explains how his approach to the show he’s known for,  “Fargo,” was very different for the astronaut tale starring Natalie Portman.
lead_paragraph: Noah Hawley may be the first director who has ever had to narrow his focus to do a movie set in outer space.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: A detailed auto emissions map. Reviews of the new MoMA and Ronan Farrow’s book. Will Smith and Ang Lee. The headless horseman industrial complex. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Snow in the Northern Plains, a superstorm in Japan, fighting in Syria and a fast-paced impeachment inquiry — so much to keep up with. Here are some other amazing stories you may have passed right by during this busy week.

headline: Actor Charged Racism Over Statue. N.Y. Politics Took It From There.
abstract: The actor Chazz Palminteri called the mayor’s wife racist over a decision to not honor a saint with a statue. Then the governor stepped in.
lead_paragraph: If Mayor Bill de Blasio and the actor Chazz Palminteri got into a dispute, which side do you think Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo would be on?

headline: No Drop in Vaping Cases, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Health officials say the flu season may complicate diagnosis of the lung damage from vaping, masking symptoms.
lead_paragraph: As illnesses and deaths linked to vaping continue to rise, health experts on Friday updated their advice to doctors on how best to recognize symptoms and treat patients, and warned that the start of the flu season would make it harder to arrive at the right diagnosis.

headline: Candidates Grow Bolder on Labor, and Not Just Bernie Sanders
abstract: Ambitious moves to shift power to workers are being embraced by several Democratic presidential contenders.
lead_paragraph: When Bernie Sanders ran for president in 2016, his campaign was strikingly pro-labor. He proposed a $15-an-hour minimum wage, which was much further than most mainstream Democrats, including Hillary Clinton, were willing to go. He denounced a trans-Pacific trade deal that was anathema to many unions. He endorsed an organizing method, known as card check, that would allow workers to unionize without holding a secret-ballot election.

headline: A New Owner, and Layoffs, for amNewYork
abstract: The newsroom at the tabloid intended for subway reading loses more than half its employees as Schneps Media, a New York publisher, takes over.
lead_paragraph: A change of ownership at amNewYork, a free New York tabloid meant for subway reading, went into effect on Friday. Along with the change, there were layoffs, with the number of newsroom employees cut to seven from 16.

headline: Shepard Smith, Fox News Anchor, Abruptly Departs From Network
abstract: The chief news anchor at Fox News, who stood apart from the network’s commentators, announced his departure at the close of his regular broadcast.
lead_paragraph: To critics who accuse Fox News of being uniformly pro-Trump, the network often points to the blunt-truth reporting of Shepard Smith, its veteran chief news anchor, whose coverage of the Trump White House stood out on a channel known best for conservative opinion.

headline: Are Cheap Clothes Ruining the Planet?
abstract: Dana Thomas discusses “Fashionopolis,” and Steven Greenhouse talks about “Beaten Down, Worked Up.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Facing ‘Cash-Flow Crisis,’ the U.N. Cuts Hiring, Heating, Escalators and the A.C.
abstract: The organization said it was quickly running out of cash largely because a number of countries, chiefly the United States, have not paid all their annual assessments.
lead_paragraph: No new hiring, after-hours meetings or late-night receptions at the United Nations headquarters. No more optional travel. No new furniture or replacement computers unless absolutely necessary.

headline: The Story of Three Town Halls
abstract: We followed a congresswoman who supports the impeachment inquiry as she talked to voters who disagree.
lead_paragraph: The story of the impeachment inquiry has largely played out in Washington as a historic showdown between the legislative and executive branches. Every day, there are committee hearings, news conferences, depositions and subpoenas (some honored, others ignored).

headline: Padres Pitcher Charged After Trying to Enter Wrong Home Through Doggy Door
abstract: Jacob Nix was charged with criminal trespassing after being kicked and tased for trying to climb through the door of someone else’s home in a Phoenix suburb, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A pitcher for the San Diego Padres was arrested Sunday after he tried to climb through a doggy door of a home in Peoria, Ariz., and was kicked in the face and tased, according to the authorities.

headline: Facebook’s Libra Cryptocurrency Faces Exodus of Partners
abstract: Stripe, Mastercard, Visa and eBay said they were dropping out of the effort, a week after PayPal pulled out.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s troubled cryptocurrency initiative, Libra, suffered new blows on Friday as the departures of key partners became an exodus.

headline: WNYC Is Dropping ‘New Sounds’ After 37 Years. Musicians Are Mourning.
abstract: The eclectic radio program that has influenced New York’s music scene since 1982 is going off the air.
lead_paragraph: For your expanding “New York isn’t as cool as it used to be” file: WNYC-FM told its staff this week that it would end “New Sounds,” a genre-defying radio program that has played an outsize role in the city’s new music scene for nearly four decades.

headline: Michal Rosenoer, Patrick Massaro
abstract: The couple met in August 2014 on the bride’s first day at Conservation Colorado, where the groom was already working.
lead_paragraph: Michal Lauren Rosenoer and Patrick Byrne Massaro were married outdoors on Oct. 5 at Turner Farm in Buena Vista, Colo. Nicholas Massaro, an uncle of the groom and a retired chief justice for Mesa County, Colo., officiated.

headline: Kansas Student Charged With Felony After Making Gun Shape With Fingers
abstract: School officials in Overland Park, Kan., were made aware of the threat by a student through the district’s website, which allows students to report safety concerns, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A Kansas middle school student was arrested after making the shape of a gun with her fingers and pointing it at others. That student now faces a felony charge, an official said.

headline: Trump and China Have a ‘Phase One Deal.’ The World Economy Is Still at Risk.
abstract: A perpetual state of aggression on trade has been a drag on business decision-making, especially in manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: Financial markets are downright exuberant about the arrival of some trade peace — at least for now — between the United States and China.

headline: Robert Goelet, New York Grandee and Naturalist, Dies at 96
abstract: The scion of a 17th-century New York family, he headed major cultural institutions and became a steward of Gardiners Island, which his wife’s family had owned since 1639.
lead_paragraph: Robert G. Goelet, a civic leader, naturalist and philanthropist whose marriage merged two families that date to 17th-century New Amsterdam and made the couple stewards of Gardiners Island, a storied sanctuary off the tip of Long Island, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: N.B.A.-China Spat Shows Sports Isn’t (and Shouldn’t Be) Just About Games
abstract: The idea of sports being mainly about what happens on the courts and fields has always been a myth.
lead_paragraph: The myth of sports sticking to sports died this week, from self-inflicted wounds and a global outbreak of compromised values.

headline: A Spice Company Spent $92,000 on Pro-Impeachment Facebook Ads in a Week
abstract: A Wisconsin-based purveyor of pepper, paprika and poppy seeds spent more on impeachment-related Facebook ads than any entity besides President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Candidates, campaigns and companies have unleashed a flood of Facebook advertisements related to impeachment, and it might come as no surprise that President Trump and his re-election campaign are far outspending everyone else.

headline: In the Sea, Not All Plastic Lasts Forever
abstract: Polystyrene, a common ocean pollutant, decomposes in sunlight much faster than thought, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: A major component of ocean pollution is less devastating and more manageable than usually portrayed, according to a scientific team at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on Cape Cod, Mass., and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: China’s Political Correctness: One Country, No Arguments
abstract: The Communist Party has spent decades preparing the people to defend a united homeland. Hong Kong’s protests show it has paid off.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s protests have disrupted Yang Yang’s family life. Though the 29-year-old lives in mainland China, he was inspired by the demonstrations to write a song about freedom and upload it to the internet. When censors deleted it, he complained to his family.

headline: Anna Quayle, British Character Actress, Is Dead at 86
abstract: She bantered with John Lennon in “A Hard Day’s Night” and won a Tony for playing four women in “Stop the World — I Want to Get Off.”
lead_paragraph: A young John Lennon is hiding out in a backstage hallway in “A Hard Day’s Night” (1964), and only one woman — a mod Londoner with short, dark hair, a slouchy sweater and eyeglasses on a chain — seems to recognize him. But after some sexy Beatles banter, she concludes, “You don’t look like him at all.”

headline: Trump Taxes: Justice Dept. Asks Judges to Block Subpoena
abstract: But the department did not agree with President Trump’s lawyers that a sitting president is immune from criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department asked a federal appeals court on Friday to stop the release of President Trump’s tax returns to the Manhattan district attorney’s office, arguing that local prosecutors should have to meet a very high legal bar before investigating a sitting president.

headline: Masaichi Kaneda, Japan’s ‘Emperor’ of Baseball, Dies at 86
abstract: A swaggering player with a quirky warm-up routine, he set pitching records for wins (400), strikeouts (4,490), innings (5,526⅔) — and losses (298).
lead_paragraph: Masaichi Kaneda started each of the thousands of innings he pitched during his illustrious career in Japan the same way. He walked to the mound, dropped his glove, grabbed the rosin bag, tossed it a few times, dropped it and then picked up his glove. Then he walked to second base, where he threw the first of eight warm-up pitches to the catcher. After each throw, he moved a few steps closer to the mound, until by the eighth pitch he was standing on the pitching rubber.

headline: Carlos Celdran, 46, Philippine Activist and Performance Artist, Dies
abstract: He received widespread attention for his dramatic protest against the Roman Catholic Church after it blocked the passage of a reproductive health bill.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Celdran, a Philippine cultural activist and performance artist who received national attention for his dramatic protest against the Roman Catholic Church’s stance on reproductive health, died on Tuesday in Spain, where he had been living in exile. He was 46.

headline: Goodbye, America. Goodbye, Freedom Man.
abstract: Under Trump, the U.S. becomes the world’s fair-weather friend.
lead_paragraph: The time is the early 1980s. The place is the South China Sea. A sailor aboard the U.S.S. Midway, an aircraft carrier, spots a leaky boat jammed with people fleeing tyranny in Indochina. As he helps bring the desperate refugees to safety, one of them calls out: “Hello, American sailor — Hello, Freedom Man.”

headline: Impeachment, Trade, Witches: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Teacher Resigns After ‘Sniper Rifle’ Comment About Greta Thunberg
abstract: The Iowa educator was placed on administrative leave last week as the school district investigated his Facebook comment about the climate activist.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa high school teacher who was placed on administrative leave last week after he posted a threatening comment on social media about the climate activist Greta Thunberg has resigned, the school district confirmed on Friday.

headline: The Haves and Have-Nots of (Electrical) Power in California
abstract: The economic impacts of the state’s power shut-off were especially acute in rural, northern towns.
lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — The intentional blackout by California’s largest utility this week put Forest Jones out of work and his son out of school. On Friday morning Mr. Jones, a handyman and single father, sat in his apartment above a tattoo parlor waiting for the power to come back on and for school to reopen.

headline: Two Years After Hurricane Harvey, One Group Says It Has Been Overlooked: Renters
abstract: Renters affected by Hurricane Harvey in Texas are criticizing the recovery effort, saying that state and federal officials cut them out of $5 billion in aid and focused instead on homeowners.
lead_paragraph: VICTORIA, Texas — The State of Texas has been disbursing $5 billion in federal dollars to help repair homes, businesses and infrastructure damaged in Hurricane Harvey in August 2017.

headline: Philip Gips, Creator of Celebrated Film Posters, Dies at 88
abstract: In the imagery he devised to promote “Alien,” “Rosemary’s Baby” and other movies, he strove to capture their essence without giving too much away.
lead_paragraph: Philip Gips, a graphic artist who created many celebrated movie posters, including those for “Rosemary’s Baby” and “Alien,” which hinted at the terror audiences would experience but gave away nothing of the films’ plots, died on Oct. 3 in a hospital in White Plains. He was 88.

headline: Man Convicted in Murder of Law Professor Locked in Family Feud
abstract: A jury found Sigfredo Garcia guilty of first-degree murder in the 2014 killing of Dan Markel.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The killing shook Florida’s capital and stunned the international legal community: A prominent law professor locked in a rancorous battle with his ex-wife and in-laws was gunned down in his garage, in what prosecutors depicted as a murder-for-hire plot.

headline: A Big Step by Coco Gauff, Huge Leaps for a Tennis Youth Movement
abstract: On Friday, Gauff reached her first singles semifinal, and the next generation upset Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer.
lead_paragraph: Youth ruled tennis on Friday in Shanghai, where Stefanos Tsitsipas upset No. 1 Novak Djokovic and Alexander Zverev beat his new mentor, Roger Federer.

headline: Saddleridge Fire Map: Tracking the Spread
abstract: Several fires were burning in the Los Angeles area on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Several fires were burning in the Los Angeles area on Friday.

headline: An Admissions Scandal Parent Got Probation. His Argument? Not Rich or Famous.
abstract: The California father avoided prison time, receiving the lightest sentence for a parent so far in the sweeping scandal.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a case known for Hollywood celebrities and powerful business executives, Peter Jan Sartorio was different, his lawyer argued. The founder of a natural food company, he was neither rich nor famous, the lawyer said. When he was arrested on charges that he had paid $15,000 to cheat on his daughter’s ACT exam, he quickly told the court that he would plead guilty. And unlike some of the nearly three dozen parents swept up in the nation’s largest admissions prosecution, Mr. Sartorio issued no statements or news releases, his lawyer said, because “he doesn’t have a public image to maintain.”

headline: How to Invest When the Market Can’t Make Up Its Mind
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s rate cuts have buoyed stocks, but the economy shows signs of a slowdown. What should an investor do?
lead_paragraph: Stocks have been even more fickle than usual.

headline: Judge Obstructed Justice in $10 Million Corruption Case, U.S. Says
abstract: The Brooklyn judge was accused of destroying text messages and emails during a fraud inquiry at a major credit union.
lead_paragraph: When the former chief executive of the Municipal Credit Union pleaded guilty last year to stealing nearly $10 million from the 500,000-member financial institution, federal prosecutors said he had gone to some lengths to hide his long-running embezzlement scheme.

headline: Porn Producers Accused of Fooling Women Get Sex Trafficking Charges
abstract: Young women say that they responded to ads seeking models and were tricked into performing.
lead_paragraph: In a case that could test the online pornography industry, the owners and two employees of two popular pornographic websites were charged this week in San Diego with sex trafficking and other crimes, accused of coercing several women to engage in sex videos that were posted on the internet.

headline: Trump Orders Troops and Weapons to Saudi Arabia in Message of Deterrence to Iran
abstract: The announcement came five days after Mr. Trump said his desire to end America’s “endless wars” led him to pull back troops from the Syria-Turkey border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is sending about 3,000 additional troops to Saudi Arabia in the latest military response by the Trump administration after it accused Iran of attacks last month on Saudi oil facilities, the Pentagon said on Friday.

headline: Jane Fonda Arrested During Climate Protest Outside U.S. Capitol
abstract: The 81-year-old actress was charged with unlawful demonstration and was later released on her own recognizance, Capitol Police said.
lead_paragraph: Jane Fonda was arrested outside the United States Capitol on Friday as part of a climate change protest, a high-profile act of civil disobedience by the Oscar-winning actress and Vietnam War objector, who said that she planned to reprise her role every Friday for the rest of the year.

headline: Those Foreign Business Ties? The Trump Sons Have Plenty Too
abstract: The Trumps have criticized Hunter Biden for doing business overseas while his father was vice president. Last month, the Trumps won approval in Scotland to build 500 homes.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Trump family business received approval from a local government in Scotland for a major expansion of its golf resort near Aberdeen, marking the largest real estate development financed by the Trump Organization since the 2016 election.

headline: We Are All at the Mercy of the Narcissist in Chief
abstract: To say that we find ourselves in a dysfunctional relationship is an understatement.
lead_paragraph: If, by some grievous misfortune, you should happen to have a pathological narcissist in your life — a drain on your soul, a bottomless chute of need, a roaring outboard motor of jealousies and delusions and self-regard — there’s no shortage of literature offering advice, and most of it preaches the same thing: Never take the bait. If you can disengage, by all means do; if you cannot, keep clear boundaries. Even if it means building an alligator-filled moat.

headline: Judge Orders Pause in Opioid Litigation Against Purdue Pharma and Sacklers
abstract: The stay is only until Nov. 6. During that time, the parties must negotiate a plan for disclosing the details of the Sacklers’ wealth and Purdue’s role in the opioid epidemic.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — Citing mounting costs of litigation that are siphoning funds that could otherwise go to abate the opioid crisis, a bankruptcy judge on Friday ordered a pause in legal action by states against Purdue Pharma and its owners, the Sacklers.

headline: Kevin McAleenan Resigns as Acting Homeland Security Secretary
abstract: Mr. McAleenan oversaw a border security agency that grappled with the most crossings at the southwestern border in more than a decade, prompting the ire of the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced Friday the resignation of Kevin K. McAleenan, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security who spent his six-month tenure trying to curb a surge of asylum seekers at the southwestern border while managing a turbulent relationship with a president intent on restricting immigration.

headline: The Free World at 30
abstract: “If you don’t fight for democracy, you don’t deserve it.”
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Perhaps you know the story of the parrot in Soviet Russia that escapes from its cage and flies out the window. Its owner rushes out and hurries down to the Ministry of State Security.

headline: In Chicago, Salazar’s Runners Stick to a Script
abstract: Galen Rupp, Mo Farah and Jordan Hasay trained with Alberto Salazar. In Chicago to run the marathon there, they didn’t want to talk much about the banned coach.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — During the stretch run leading up to a major marathon, Jordan Hasay could expect to start receiving multiple phone calls per day from her Nike Oregon Project coach, Alberto Salazar, who would guide her through her final days of training.

headline: “A Pretty Dirty Campaign” That’s Left Voters Unimpressed
abstract: As Canada’s election campaign heads into its final week, neither of the country’s major parties have managed to shift the vote.
lead_paragraph: In this year’s election campaign, millions of dollars have been spent, thousand of kilometers traveled and hundreds of speeches made. And the result? Just as they were on the first day of campaigning the Liberals and the Conservatives remain deadlocked in a tie for the popular vote.

headline: All the President’s Henchmen
abstract: Mr. Trump has assembled a colorful cast of characters who are having trouble keeping their stories straight.
lead_paragraph: It has often been noted that President Trump holds a vision of his job more befitting a Latin American caudillo than the leader of the world’s oldest democracy. His geopolitical idols trend toward the autocratic — Kim Jong-un, Rodrigo Duterte, Mohammed bin Salman, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Vladimir Putin. He suffers delusions of grandeur, proclaiming himself “the Chosen One” and having “great and unmatched wisdom.” He accuses those who challenge him of treason, and he regularly wipes his feet on the constitutional principle of checks and balances.

headline: At Louisiana Rally, Trump Lashes Out at Impeachment Inquiry and Pelosi
abstract: The president denounced the impeachment inquiry and condemned what he called the “unholy alliance of corrupt Democrat politicians, deep-state bureaucrats and the fake news media.”
lead_paragraph: LAKE CHARLES, La. — President Trump left a dizzying trail of developments behind him in Washington on Friday evening, swapping the confines of the capital for a fiery rally where he used foul language, fierce political attacks and personal grievances to light up his supporters for the second day in a row.

headline: Giuliani Is Said to Be Under Investigation for Ukraine Work
abstract: Prosecutors are investigating whether the president’s lawyer broke laws meant to prevent covert foreign influence on the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are investigating whether President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani broke lobbying laws in his dealings in Ukraine, according to two people familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Kitchen Drawers
abstract: Andrew J. Ries opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Greetings! Caitlin Lovinger is taking a well-deserved weekend off, which means that I got to see if I could still solve the notorious Saturday puzzle, the most difficult crossword of the week.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Envoy to Ukraine Blames ‘False Claims’ for Ouster
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 12, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Although I understand that I served at the pleasure of the president, I was nevertheless incredulous that the U.S. government chose to remove an ambassador based, as best as I can tell, on unfounded and false claims by people with clearly questionable motives.”

headline: Corrections: October 12, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 12, 2019.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Episode 5: The Land of Our Fathers, Part 2
abstract: In the finale of the podcast, we hear the rest of June and Angie Provost’s story, and its echoes in a past case that led to the largest civil rights settlement in American history.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Stitcher

headline: Was It the Hummus or the Familiarity?
abstract: They realized they had much in common. Her name was Erica, and his was Eric, each had red hair, was 6 feet tall and Jewish.
lead_paragraph: Erica Lynn Kilbride and Eric Ronald Obenzinger were married Oct. 12 at the Prospect Park Boathouse in Brooklyn. Gabriel Hernandez, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Mighty Boosh’ and ‘Meeting Gorbachev’
abstract: Revisit the absurdist comedy of Noel Fielding and Julian Barratt, and catch Werner Herzog’s conversations with the former Russian leader.
lead_paragraph: THE MIGHTY BOOSH Stream on Hulu and Amazon. Before Noel Fielding was serving up baking banter and an impressive array of kitschy shirts on “The Great British Baking Show,” he was one half of the outlandish comedy duo behind The Mighty Boosh. Fielding and his counterpart Julian Barratt created a colorful roster of characters and original skits and songs that became the basis for this BBC Three television series named after the troupe. The show, which aired for three seasons in the early 2000s, follows the misadventures of Vince Noir (Fielding) and Howard Moon (Barratt) as they investigate mutant science experiments at a zoo’s secret lab, save the world from a demonic little old lady and explore another planet for the Fountain of Youth. Along the way, they stumble across new friends and foes, like a beast made of sandpaper, a terrifying green-skinned cockney man with a mint over his eye and a Baileys-drinking, lovelorn merman known as Old Gregg.

headline: Robert Forster, Oscar Nominee for ‘Jackie Brown,’ Dies at 78
abstract: Before his 1997 comeback, his career was at a low point. “I went 21 months without a job. I had four kids. I took any job I could get.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Forster, a journeyman actor whose comeback role as a bail bondsman in Quentin Tarantino’s “Jackie Brown” earned him an Oscar nomination, and who drew acclaim for his tough-guy performances on the television series “Breaking Bad” and the reboot of “Twin Peaks,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 78.

headline: Typhoon Hagibis Slams Into Japan After Landslides, Floods and a Quake
abstract: The storm made landfall Saturday evening. Record rainfall flooded rivers and tested dams as almost four million people were urged to evacuate.

headline: Pitchers’ Duel: Yankees and Astros Meet in a Series Both Saw Coming
abstract: “I heard it from Day 1,” Houston’s manager said about predictions of a playoff showdown against the Yankees. Now it’s here, and many expect this rematch to be decided on the mound.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — All year long, the narratives of the Houston Astros and the Yankees have been intertwined. Entering the season, both were among the favorites to win the World Series. As they plowed through their schedules, quickly emerging as the best teams in their league, a collision in the best-of-seven American League Championship Series — which begins Saturday night at Minute Maid Park — seemed inevitable.

headline: The Only Women’s Pro Hockey League in America Plays On
abstract: Olympians and other top stars are boycotting the N.W.H.L. this season, but that has made the league more accessible for those who thought pro hockey was not an option.
lead_paragraph: During her first five years playing professional women’s hockey, Kaleigh Fratkin built relationships with dozens of teammates whom she knew shared a common ideology about their sport.

headline: Nationals Pitching Puts an Old-School Tactic on the Cutting Edge
abstract: Washington, now 2-0 against St. Louis in the N.L.C.S., has shown that durable starters can still be a reliable route to winning in October.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — For all the new wisdom in baseball, some theories stay timeless. One in particular guides Mike Rizzo in building annual contenders for the Washington Nationals.

headline: Eliud Kipchoge Breaks Two-Hour Marathon Barrier
abstract: In Vienna, the Kenyan achieved a milestone once believed to be unattainable. But his time, 1:59:40, will not be recognized as a world record.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — On a misty Saturday morning in Vienna, on a course specially chosen for speed, in an athletic spectacle of historic proportions, Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya ran 26.2 miles in a once-inconceivable time of 1 hour 59 minutes 40 seconds.

headline: Which 2020 Candidates Have the Ground Game Lead in Early Primary States
abstract: Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are dominant, with more campaign offices in the first four states than any other 2020 Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are dominant, with more campaign offices in the first four states than any other 2020 Democrat.

headline: Great Draft, Dad. I Have Some Notes.
abstract: Should an author’s family have a say in what the author chooses to write about them?
lead_paragraph: From the very beginning my daughter asserted her editorial rights over the memoir I was writing about our family. Early in our yearlong trip around the world, I told Lyra I was including a detail she disagreed with, and she replied, resolutely, “When I edit the book to cut out all the things about me you’re not allowed to write, I’ll change it.”

headline: Orville Peck, a Masked Gay Country Star, Rides Into Brooklyn
abstract: “The masks exist as a point of discussion,” Mr. Peck said.
lead_paragraph: The enigmatic country singer known as Orville Peck is riding high these days. He is on the cover of British GQ Style, wearing star-spangled boots and a black mask that obscures his face.

headline: How Well Off Is Ohio, Site of Democratic Debate? It’s Debatable
abstract: Unemployment is down and wages are inching up. But in a state becoming less dependent on manufacturing, people wonder where the well-paying jobs will come from.
lead_paragraph: MANSFIELD, Ohio — When they gather near Columbus for their fourth debate, Democrats will be coming to a state that, if not “great again,” is by many accounts doing quite O.K., certainly much better than a decade ago.

headline: Tinker, Tailor, Writer, Spy
abstract: John le Carré takes aim at Brexit and Boris Johnson in his new novel, “Agent Running in the Field.”
lead_paragraph: When John le Carré was running agents for the British secret intelligence service MI6 in the early 1960s, there were certain qualities he looked for in a candidate. Gregariousness, cocktail party charm, the ability to hold one’s drink — all of that mattered, of course. But above all, what le Carré wanted was “a sense of larceny,” as he explains during an interview at his north London home. “Somebody who enjoys the adventure and is not scrupulous about small stuff.”

headline: What, Exactly, Is Tulsi Gabbard Up To?
abstract: As she injects chaos into the 2020 Democratic primary by accusing her own party of “rigging” the election, an array of alt-right internet stars, white nationalists and Russians have praised her.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist, is impressed with her political talent. Richard B. Spencer, the white nationalist leader, says he could vote for her. Former Representative Ron Paul praises her “libertarian instincts,” while Franklin Graham, the influential evangelist, finds her “refreshing.”

headline: Can Mayors Save the World From Climate Change?
abstract: Australia’s northern coast is a case study on the impacts of a warming planet. Small-town leaders there are struggling with constituents who doubt reality.
lead_paragraph: BUCASIA BEACH, Australia — Mayor Greg Williamson crunched through the dead branches and kicked the sand. His government had planted trees near the shore to protect this northern Australian beach community from the effects of climate change, but someone had cut them down, apparently for a better view.

headline: Biden on Impeachment, L.G.B.T.Q. Forum: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Here are seven things that happened on the presidential campaign trail this week.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our rundown of what happened in the Democratic primary this week, as the candidates gear up for Tuesday’s debate in Ohio.

headline: James Comey Would Like to Help
abstract: The former F.B.I. director wants an end to the Trump presidency. And yes, he knows you might think he caused it.
lead_paragraph: James Comey slumps strategically in restaurants — all 6-foot-8 of him, drooping faux-furtively with his back to the room — and daydreams about deleting the civic-minded Twitter feed where a bipartisan coalition pronounces him a national disgrace.

headline: Why Won’t Anyone Buy the Most Famous Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas?
abstract: The great American institution of the Las Vegas wedding is in trouble.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On Las Vegas Boulevard, nestled between a motel and tattoo parlor, sits what may be the most famous marriage site in the world: A Little White Wedding Chapel.

headline: What Happened in the Trump Impeachment Inquiry This Week
abstract: The White House says the impeachment inquiry is invalid. Joe Biden says impeach. Ukraine, Syria and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine, but this seemingly fast-moving impeachment inquiry may actually be in a “lull” because Congress has been on recess. Well, Congress is back in session on Tuesday, so read on and get educated before things really take off.

headline: Xi Jinping Comes to Nepal Bearing Investments, and India Is Watching
abstract: The Chinese leader’s visit is a further display of his ambitious aims — both economic and strategic — on India’s doorstep.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Xi Jinping touched down in Nepal on Saturday, the first visit by a Chinese president to the country in more than two decades, underscoring Beijing’s increasing interest in South Asia as a strategic hub for defense and transit projects.

headline: Kipchoge’s Inspiring Marathon Run, Just in Time for Chicago
abstract: Between the breaking of the two-hour barrier and the Chicago Marathon, it’s a big weekend in running.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: In Seoul, Crowds Denounce a Divisive Politician. Days Later, Others Defend Him.
abstract: Vast rallies have called for the ouster of South Korea’s justice minister. But huge counterprotests have assailed the prosecutors who are investigating him.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For weeks, huge crowds have been gathering in Seoul to denounce a man named Cho Kuk — or to defend him.

headline: Brooklyn Shooting: 4 Killed at Crown Heights Social Club
abstract: The motive was not clear, but illegal dice and card games were occurring at the club when the shooting started, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Neighbors had often complained about an unlicensed social club that operated on the first floor of a battered frame townhouse in Brooklyn. The space had a purple sign — “Triple A Aces Private & Social Event Space” — but it was being used as an illegal gambling den that attracted patrons in expensive cars, investigators and residents said.

headline: Syrian Arab Fighters Backed by Turkey Kill Two Kurdish Prisoners
abstract: The killings, one of them caught on video, raised the specter of wider sectarian warfare as fighting in Syria escalates.
lead_paragraph: Turkish-backed Syrian Arab fighters killed at least two Kurdish prisoners on Saturday, one of them lying on the ground with his hands bound behind his back, in a powerful illustration of the forces unleashed by President Trump’s decision to pull back American troops shielding former Kurdish allies in northern Syria.

headline: A Reporter’s Journey to the Heart of Flamenco
abstract: For the cover of The New York Times Magazine’s annual culture issue, a reporter traveled to Spain understand  the rise of the singer Rosalía.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How Italians Became ‘White’
abstract: Vicious bigotry, reluctant acceptance: an American story.
lead_paragraph: Vicious bigotry, reluctant acceptance: an American story.

headline: ‘The Beacon Has Gone Out’: What Trump and Giuliani Have Wrought
abstract: Once upon a time, we spread ideals of democracy and rule of law. Now? We send Rudy.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In 2014, Ukraine’s wildly corrupt president, Viktor Yanukovych, fled to Russia after mass protests on the Maidan, Kiev’s central square. During what Ukrainians call the Revolution of Dignity, police snipers killed dozens of demonstrators. In the revolution’s aftermath, a number of young idealists decided to plunge into politics, hoping to reform their troubled country from the inside. One of them was Serhiy Leshchenko, at the time perhaps the country’s most famous investigative journalist.

headline: 68 Soups and Stews for Sweater Weather
abstract: Vegetarian tortilla soup, old-fashioned beef stew and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Cozy up with a bowl of Susan Spungen’s one-pot French onion soup (above), Alison Roman’s vegetarian tortilla soup or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: Scenes of Destruction as Typhoon Hagibis Strikes Japan
abstract: As the storm reached Japan, it brought landslides, flooding and violent winds.
lead_paragraph: As the storm reached Japan, it brought landslides, flooding and violent winds.

headline: In 1919, an Opera Tried to Heal a Broken Europe
abstract: “Die Frau ohne Schatten” imagined an enlightened, democratic empire.
lead_paragraph: The Viennese writer Stefan Zweig was a political pacifist during World War I and moved to neutral Switzerland, abandoning his own country, the Hapsburg Empire of Austria-Hungary, which was fighting in alliance with Germany. In 1919, with the war over and Austria a republic, Zweig came home.

headline: Fact-Checking 5 Claims About the Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: President Trump and his defenders have inaccurately attacked the impeachment inquiry for what they say are procedural and constitutional violations, a faulty premise and a lack of support.
lead_paragraph: Defenders of President Trump have employed a number of arguments to back up their assertion that the impeachment inquiry begun by House Democrats last month amounts to a “kangaroo court.” They have cited historical precedent, the Constitution and public polling among other arguments against the inquiry. Here’s a fact check of some of their most-invoked claims.

headline: Understanding Trump’s Appeal in Rural America
abstract: Readers discuss a writer’s portrayal of political attitudes of residents in her Arkansas hometown.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: India Vows to Restore Mobile Service in Kashmir
abstract: The Indian authorities said many cellphones would begin working on Monday in the disputed region after two months of a communications blackout.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After imposing a sweeping communications blackout in Kashmir two months ago, the Indian authorities announced on Saturday that cellphone service would be partly restored within days in the disputed Himalayan region, though the internet will remain blocked.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon make me wonder why I even bother to drive a car.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — It has been a while since I wrote about the acrostic puzzle, and I honestly wondered if I would remember how to solve it as I sat down in front of my computer. Fortunately, it was a lot like riding a bicycle, which is to say that you never really forget.

headline: Cory Booker’s Unique Strength: 80-Plus Relatives in Iowa
abstract: As the senator from New Jersey enters a final sprint to relevance in Iowa, he has the backing of dozens of family members in the Des Moines area, with roots that date back more than a century.
lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Travel with Senator Cory Booker and it will quickly become apparent that he has family in nearly every politically important state for a presidential candidate. His mother lives in Nevada. There’s the uncle from North Carolina, and a cousin in Florida.

headline: Impeachment Support Grows, but So Does the Public Divide
abstract: Americans are as divided over impeachment as they are over President Trump. But support for the Democrats’ inquiry is building even in places Mr. Trump won, and among politically crucial independents.
lead_paragraph: CULPEPER, Va. — Over lunch at the Frost Cafe, a corner diner in a picturesque pocket of Virginia that President Trump won handily in 2016, opinion over his impeachment is as varied as anywhere in the country.

headline: Typhoon Hagibis in Photos
abstract: Raging rivers, monstrous waves and submerged buildings: we'll keep you updated with the latest pictures from the typhoon.
lead_paragraph: As of Monday, dozens of people had been killed, more were missing and hundreds of thousands had been forced to abandon their homes after Japan was lashed by Typhoon Hagibis, the most powerful storm to strike the country in decades.

headline: 2 Shot at Wedding in New Hampshire Church, Police Say
abstract: “A coward walked into my family’s church today” and shot a bishop, a relative posted on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: A Saturday morning wedding at a church in a small New Hampshire town came to a bloody and abrupt halt when a gunman barged in and opened fire, wounding a bishop and the bride before he was “gang tackled,” the authorities said.

headline: Collapse of a Future Hard Rock Hotel Leaves Two Dead, and New Orleans Reeling
abstract: At least 19 others were injured and one person remains unaccounted for after a building collapse at a construction site steps from the city’s historic French Quarter, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A cascade of metal and debris rained onto a New Orleans street on Saturday as portions of a hotel under construction collapsed, killing two people and setting off a precarious rescue effort  inside the dangerously unstable building, the authorities said.

headline: ‘This Did Not Go Well’: Inside PG&E’s Blackout Control Room
abstract: As the utility turned off power to millions of Californians, its website went down and it struggled to communicate with local officials and inform residents.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was a problem that California had come to dread. Weather models were signaling extreme winds and dry conditions from one end of the state to the other. The risk of wildfires was high.

headline: Bill Gates Met With Jeffrey Epstein Many Times, Despite His Past
abstract: Mr. Gates has minimized his ties to Mr. Epstein. But a Times investigation reveals they had a closer relationship than previously known.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who committed suicide in prison, managed to lure an astonishing array of rich, powerful and famous men into his orbit.

headline: Hard Rock Hotel Collapses in New Orleans
abstract: Parts of the Hard Rock Hotel that were under construction collapsed on Saturday. The wreckage led to one death and at least 18 injuries.
lead_paragraph: Parts of the Hard Rock Hotel that were under construction collapsed on Saturday. The wreckage led to one death and at least 18 injuries.

headline: 5 Rappers Dropped From New York Music Festival at Police Request
abstract: The performers were removed from this weekend’s Rolling Loud festival at Citi Field after the N.Y.P.D. said they had “been affiliated with recent acts of violence citywide.”
lead_paragraph: Five rappers with New York roots were removed from the local edition of the traveling hip-hop festival Rolling Loud, scheduled for this weekend in Queens, at the behest of the New York Police Department, representatives for the concert said on Saturday.

headline: Cuban Women Await Their #MeToo Moment
abstract: Cubans are still living under a patriarchy shaped by the revolution.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — I was six when I saw my mother sitting on a stretcher at a psychiatric hospital in Cienfuegos, half-naked with a blank stare. She was bent over, her hands groping the ground, when a male nurse, humming a popular song, grabbed her hair and forced her to throw up into a bucket, which he then emptied into the toilet.

headline: What if the Supreme Court Had an L.G.B.T. Justice?
abstract: There might be fewer arguments about bathrooms, for starters.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of this year’s hit Broadway show “What the Constitution Means to Me,” the audience hears a scratchy old recording of an oral argument at the Supreme Court. The year is 1965, and the justices are debating the topic of married women’s right to birth control. Or that’s the idea, anyway; for what feels like an eternity, the nine black-robed men do little but stammer and clear their throats.

headline: Should We Soak the Rich? You Bet!
abstract: And they’ll still be loaded.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump promised struggling working-class voters that he heard their frustrations and would act.

headline: Are School Debate Competitions Bad for Our Political Discourse?
abstract: They can be a good credential for aspiring leaders, but they favor a closed-minded and partisan style of argument.
lead_paragraph: What do conservative political figures like Ted Cruz, Steve Bannon, Karl Rove and Richard Nixon have in common with liberal politicians like Elizabeth Warren, Andrew Yang, Kamala Harris and Bill Clinton? They all honed their skills of rhetoric, reasoning and persuasion on school debate teams.

headline: A Healthy Fear of China
abstract: As the N.B.A. defers to Beijing, a little more Western paranoia might be advantageous.

headline: Trump’s Politics Aren’t Pretty. That’s How His Voters Like It.
abstract: He’s a tireless catalyst of conflict with the right’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution depends on rivalry and jealousy. It may not be an engine of perpetual conflict, but the separate branches of government and chambers of Congress are supposed to be wary of encroachments on their authority. James Madison hoped that the multitude of interests represented in the legislature would prevent a single will, embodied in a unified majority, from exercising unlimited power.

headline: Fire, Floods and Power Outages: Our Climate Future Has Arrived
abstract: The most urgent imperative now is to turn our fear and frustration into votes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Now we suffer the consequences.

headline: Democrats Have a Politeness Problem
abstract: In this next debate, they should take the gloves off.
lead_paragraph: Twice near the start of the last Democratic presidential debate, George Stephanopoulos of ABC News tried to pin Elizabeth Warren down on whether her vision for Medicare for All would require a middle-class tax increase. Twice she didn’t answer him. It was the perfect opening for one of the other contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination to charge her with evasiveness and force her to reckon fully with the costs of her ambitious plans and the profound difficulty of enacting them. None of them took advantage of it.

headline: The Perilous Power of the Preacher’s Wife
abstract: She may not run the church. But she can still rule the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Women like Victoria Osteen live their entire ministerial careers under megaministry’s bright spotlight. To America’s largest house of worship, the 40,000-member Lakewood Church, she is the statuesque blonde who spearheaded the megachurch’s ministry for women and preached weekly sermonettes about the divine good life. To the seven million weekly viewers of the television show she does with Lakewood’s pastor, Joel Osteen, she is a celebrity and life coach, the author of spiritual chick lit like her New York Times best-selling “Love Your Life.” Blogs debate everything from her likability to the height of her heels. When she sat down for an interview with Oprah in the Osteen family’s Texas mansion, there was little doubt that, loved or hated, she was a new kind of pastor’s wife. Tucked into Joel’s arm, she rules as one of evangelicalism’s first ladies. This is the presumed order of Christian megaministry, the Adam and the Eve.

headline: Making America Worse
abstract: As impeachment commands the spotlight, the Trump administration continues to gut the rule book to hurt millions.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail in 2015, Donald Trump said it was “disgusting” that a big corporation could escape taxation by using bookkeeping tricks to shift profits out of the United States.

headline: Warren Dares Facebook With Intentionally False Political Ad
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate bought the ad to goad Facebook into removing misinformation in political ads, escalating her feud with the social network.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elizabeth Warren is playing a game of dare with Facebook.

headline: Turkish-Backed Rebel Group Executes Kurdish Prisoners
abstract: A video shows a Turkish-backed rebel group executing Kurdish prisoners Saturday in northeastern Syria.
lead_paragraph: A video shows a Turkish-backed rebel group executing Kurdish prisoners Saturday in northeastern Syria.

headline: Trump’s Abrupt Shifts in Middle East Unnerve U.S. Allies
abstract: President Trump’s acquiescence to a Turkish raid on the Kurds in northern Syria alarmed allies for its unpredictability as much as its betrayal.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s surprise acquiescence to a Turkish incursion into northern Syria this week has shaken American allies, and not just because it was a betrayal of a loyal partner. What alarmed them even more was his sheer unpredictability.

headline: Racists Are Recruiting. Watch Your White Sons.
abstract: Parents need to understand how white supremacists prey on teen boys, so they can intervene.
lead_paragraph: Raising teenagers can be terrifying. Our squishy little babies become awkward hormonal creatures who question our authority at every turn.

headline: How a Few Grams of Pot Turned an American-Israeli Into a Geopolitical Pawn
abstract: Naama Issachar, a yoga student arrested at the Moscow airport, has found her fate linked to that of a little-known Russian held in Israel and facing extradition to the United States.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Naama Issachar was boarding a connecting flight at the Moscow airport on her way home to Israel last April when the authorities found a few grams of marijuana in her luggage, an amount so small her lawyer predicted it would draw a slap on the wrist.

headline: For Both Trump and Xi, Trade Deal Comes Amid Growing Pressures at Home
abstract: President Trump and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, agreed to a compromise on trade in recent days as they feel political pressures at home and face weakening economies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The interim trade pact announced Friday between the United States and China came together as both countries’ leaders faced mounting political pressures and rising economic worries at home.

headline: Real or Imagined, Baseball Spying Causes Angst in the Playoffs
abstract: There will always be suspicions when one team seems to know too much about what the other has planned.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Carlos Beltran has not played in a Major League Baseball game for two years, since he helped the Houston Astros win the 2017 World Series. Now he works for the Yankees, and in an odd twist, the Astros could be preparing for him just as they prepare for Aaron Judge and Gleyber Torres, two of the Yankees’ best uniformed personnel.

headline: How the Yankees Won Game 1 of the A.L.C.S.
abstract: Gleyber Torres drove in five runs to lead the Yankees to an easy win over the Astros, while Masahiro Tanaka continued his pitching brilliance in the postseason.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Since he was a young child in his native Venezuela, Gleyber Torres has displayed a preternatural ability to defy his age. Baseball scouts would often tell Torres’s father that his son, 12 at the time, was playing more like a 16-year-old. It was surprising because it reinforced a hunch that Eusebio Torres was developing while watching his son play in tournaments.

headline: ‘Our River Was Like a God’: How Dams and China’s Might Imperil the Mekong
abstract: A river system that feeds millions of people is in danger of being starved of the nutrients needed to sustain its life.
lead_paragraph: ON THE MEKONG RIVER — When the Chinese came to the village of Lat Thahae, perched on a muddy bend of a Mekong River tributary, they scrawled a Chinese character on the walls of homes, schools and Buddhist temples.

headline: Lines of Work
abstract: Erik Agard’s puzzle is the height of professionalism.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — You need to devote a good portion of your day to tackling a Sunday crossword, unless you are one of those freakish speed solvers.

abstract: The younger brother of Harvey Weinstein is returning to Hollywood, a move that brought condemnation from the advocacy group Time’s Up.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — While Harvey Weinstein awaits trial on five felony charges related to allegations of sexual abuse, his brother, Bob, has announced his re-entry into Hollywood.

headline: China Conflict Mutes N.B.A.’s New-Season Buzz
abstract: Games that count are days away, but the political and financial fallout of a preseason clash with China threatens to reshape the league’s future.

headline: In a High-Tech State, Blackouts Are a Low-Tech Way to Prevent Fires
abstract: One approach is a microgrid — creating a small power source that can keep the lights on in a small area when the main grid isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on Oct. 12. It has been updated to reflect the latest developments.

headline: California Is Trying to Prevent Fires. No One Expected a Smoking Garbage Truck.
abstract: Despite extensive precautions, a deadly blaze this week was caused by burning trash dumped on the side of a road, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A utility shut off power to hundreds of thousands of customers. Municipalities prohibited people from burning debris. Fire departments called in reinforcements amid dry and windy weather.

headline: Fort Worth Officer Fatally Shot Woman Inside Her Home, Police Say
abstract: Body camera footage shows the officer peering into a window and shouting, “Put your hands up! Show me your hands!” Then he fired his weapon.
lead_paragraph: A Texas police officer responding to a call about an open front door early on Saturday shot into a woman’s home from outside her window, killing her in her bedroom, officials said.

headline: Typhoon, Cyclone or Hurricane? Different Names for the Same Storms
abstract: Powerful tropical storms occur all around the world, but what they’re called depends on where they form.
lead_paragraph: When a tropical storm pummeled Japan on Saturday with gusts of up to 135 miles per hour, forcing millions to evacuate their homes, it was called Typhoon Hagibis. But the storm that carved a path of destruction across the Bahamas in September was Hurricane Dorian. And when the most powerful storm to hit Bangladesh in years destroyed thousands of homes in May, it was called Cyclone Fani.

headline: Trump Defends Giuliani Amid Deepening Ukraine Criminal Probe
abstract: The president said on Twitter that Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and one-time federal prosecutor, was the target of a “witch hunt.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump bristled at accounts on Saturday that his personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, had become a focus of a widening criminal investigation into his dealings in Ukraine, insisting that Mr. Giuliani was a “crime buster” and target of a “witch hunt.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘I Feel Stuck’: Citizen Comey Frets Over Vote
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 13, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I have a fantasy about on January 21, 2021, deleting my Twitter and moving on to something else. But until then, I can’t.”

headline: Bringing Grievances to His Conservative Base, Trump Assails Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: For the third night in a row, the president delivered a version of his combative response to the start of the impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Saturday night took his post-impeachment message of grievance and political warfare directly to the religious right, telling a group of social conservatives that Democrats were trying to undo the results of the 2016 campaign and “stop our movement and impose their agenda by any means necessary.”

headline: Amid Show of Support, Trump Meets With Giuliani Over Lunch
abstract: The president’s multiple shows of support for his personal lawyer on Saturday seemed meant to tamp down questions about Mr. Giuliani’s standing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump had lunch on Saturday with Rudolph W. Giuliani amid revelations that prosecutors were investigating Mr. Giuliani for possible lobbying violations, and speculation that his position as the president’s personal lawyer was in jeopardy.

headline: Helicopters and Boats Rescue the Stranded After Typhoon Hits Japan
abstract: Here’s what we know about the super typhoon that struck Japan, causing levees to break and cities to flood.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan woke on Sunday morning to flooded rivers and burst levees, as emergency workers used helicopters and boats to rescue stranded residents from their homes in the wake of Typhoon Hagibis, the largest storm to hit the country in decades.

headline: 11 Hospitalized After a Car Crashes Into a Hayride in Illinois
abstract: All of the passengers were adults and three were in serious condition, emergency responders said.
lead_paragraph: A rite of October turned treacherous on Saturday when a car plowed into the back of a hayride carrying 12 adults about 50 miles west of Chicago, sending 11 people to local hospitals, three of them with serious injuries, the authorities said.

headline: Cristina O’Brien, Philip Pietrowski
abstract: The couple met through the dating app Bumble. They married in Harrodsburg, Ky.
lead_paragraph: Cristina Eubanks O'Brien and Philip Edwin Pietrowski Jr., were married Oct. 12 at Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill, in Harrodsburg, Ky. Jessica Golden Royko, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the bride, officiated.

headline: Christine Dalton, Jackson Kamine
abstract: The bride and groom met at Cornell and were married at Sage Chapel on the university’s campus.
lead_paragraph: Christine Alice Dalton and Jackson Jenssen Kamine were married Oct. 12 at Sage Chapel on the Cornell campus in Ithaca, N.Y. Robert A. Ramin, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Emily Motayed, Chase Lancaster
abstract: The couple met as students at Penn, from which each received an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Emily Motayed and Chase Richard Lancaster were married Oct. 12 in Andalusia, Pa. Lindsay M. Costello, a Universal Brotherhood Movement minister, officiated at the Andalusia Historic House and Gardens. On Oct. 11, the couple had a ceremonial Hindu wedding that was led by Kamanshish Chakravorty, a friend of the bride’s family, at the Logan Hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: Leslie Mayes, Kerwin Low
abstract: Three years ago, a mutual friend provided an introduction, and the couple went on a blind date in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Adriel Mayes and Kerwin Richard Low were married Oct. 12 in Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dion J. Watkins, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art.

headline: Jane Flegal, Eric Dougherty
abstract: The couple met in 2013 on a camping trip to Point Reyes National Seashore that was part of orientation for their doctoral program at UC Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Jane Alissa Flegal and Eric Robert Dougherty were married Oct. 12 at Colony 29, an events space in Palm Springs, Calif. Mary H. Russo, an aunt of the bride, solemnized the marriage, having been designated a deputy commissioner of marriages in Riverside County.

headline: Allegra Kirkland, Daniel Graf
abstract: The couple met in 2014 at a mutual friend’s birthday party at Legion Bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Allegra Elizabeth Kirkland and Daniel Chapman Graf were married Oct. 12 at the Bridgehampton Tennis and Surf Club, a beach club and events space in Bridgehampton, N.Y. Megan Lovallo, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Gov. Edwards of Louisiana Forced Into Runoff With Republican
abstract: Republicans mounted an aggressive campaign to unseat Gov. John Bel Edwards, one of the few Democratic governors in the South. He was forced into a runoff scheduled for next month.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — In a bid to recapture the governor’s mansion, Republicans in Louisiana mounted an aggressive challenge to Gov. John Bel Edwards, and on Saturday, the party succeeded in forcing the incumbent Democrat into a runoff election against a businessman who has never held political office.

headline: Barbara Zack, Norman Rubin
abstract: The couple met in October 2017 at Congregation Shaarey Zedek in Southfield, Mich., and they were married there.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Newman Zack and Norman Joel Rubin are to be married Oct. 13 at Congregation Shaarey Zedek in Southfield, Mich. Rabbi Aaron Starr is to officiate, with Hazzan David Propis to take part.

headline: Kimberly Harris, Gilbert Campbell III
abstract: The couple, who were introduced through a mutual friend, met three years ago in Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Aylin Harris and Gilbert Godfrey Campbell III are to be married Oct. 13 at the JW Marriott Resort and Spa in Las Vegas. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert G. Campbell Jr., a Baptist minister and father of the groom, is to officiate.

headline: Hillary August, Mitchell Suter
abstract: The couple met in 2017, when they were seated next to each other on a flight from Chicago to Vail, Colo., where each had planned a ski vacation.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Eve August and Mitchell Andrew Suter were married Oct. 12 in Chicago. Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow of the Federal District Court in Chicago, for whom the bride served as a law clerk from 2013-14, officiated at S.K.Y., a restaurant.

headline: Kristin Lawlor, Erik Cuello
abstract: The couple met in 2015 on Tinder, the dating app, and had their first date at Buddha Beer Bar in Washington Heights.
lead_paragraph: Kristin S. Lawlor and Erik Jose Cuello were married Oct. 12 in Nyack, N.Y. James Freeman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at the Nyack Seaport, an events space.

headline: Colleen Brogan, William Miner
abstract: The couple met in the New York office of 2U, an educational technology company, in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Colleen Marie Brogan and William George Miner were married Oct. 12 at Rimrock Ranch in Pioneertown, Calif. William G. Miner, the groom’s father, officiated, having become a Universal Life minister for the event.

headline: Steven Mazzola, Jeffrey Akman
abstract: They couple married at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian American Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: Steven Scott Mazzola and Dr. Jeffrey Scott Akman were married Oct. 12 at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington. Dr. Jehan El-Bayoumi, a friend of the couple and authorized to officiate by the District of Columbia, led the ceremony.

headline: Andrew Bernis, Seth Rogin
abstract: The couple met in May 2016 in the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood of New York, where they both lived.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Joseph Bernis and Seth Adam Rogin were married Oct. 12 at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Josh Rogin, a cousin of Mr. Rogin who became a Universal Life minister for the event, performed the ceremony.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: The ‘Succession’ Season Finale and ‘Schitt’s Creek’
abstract: The Roy family weighs its options in the “Succession” season finale, while the Rose family’s small-town saga continues in Season 5 of “Schitt’s Creek.”
lead_paragraph: SUCCESSION 9 p.m. on HBO. “Time for a blood sacrifice.” That’s the ominous message Logan Roy, the Waystar Royco chief executive and family patriarch, left viewers with in the final minutes of Season 2’s penultimate episode. Having testified before Congress following an explosive whistle blower allegation against his company, Logan, his family and his close associates head to the family’s Mediterranean yacht to plot their next steps. But who will take the fall to preserve the company? Logan will have to weigh which one of his children or loyal cronies is expendable, even as some suggest that it’s his head that may have to roll.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Gives Julián Castro His Moment
abstract: The cold open was a highlight of this week's episode, which got some help from several A-list stars.
lead_paragraph: Cameos! Cameos! Cameos everywhere! Billy Porter, Woody Harrelson and Lin-Manuel Miranda all showed up in this week’s “Saturday Night Live” cold open, which sent up this week’s CNN town hall on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues featuring Democratic presidential candidates. Porter played an M.C. of sorts who introduced the candidates with his typical energy.

headline: ‘As He Walked Toward Me, I Knew Instinctively That I Was in Trouble’
abstract: Recalling a thwarted childhood prank, help moving a car and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Russia Bombed Four Syrian Hospitals. We Have Proof.
abstract: The Times obtained thousands of air force recordings, which reveal for the first time that Russia repeatedly bombed hospitals in Syria.
lead_paragraph: The Times obtained thousands of air force recordings, which reveal for the first time that Russia repeatedly bombed hospitals in Syria.

headline: How Times Reporters Proved Russia Bombed Syrian Hospitals
abstract: We recreated a day of airstrikes using video evidence, flight logs, witness reports and thousands of previously unheard Russian Air Force communications.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: 12 Hours. 4 Syrian Hospitals Bombed. One Culprit: Russia.
abstract: The Russians saved Bashar al-Assad’s government. A trove of Russian Air Force recordings obtained by The Times shows how bombing Syrian hospitals helped them do it.

headline: Poland Election: Law and Justice Party Holds on to Power, Early Returns Show
abstract: The party’s twinned platform of aggrieved nationalism and government largess appeared to have secured it a new term in office.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s populist ruling party appeared to have swept back into power on Sunday, as voters dismissed concerns about the autocratic drift of the government and rewarded the party for its generous social welfare programs.

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: Ronan Farrow’s “Catch and Kill,” the Nobel Prize for Literature and more.
lead_paragraph: We take the weekend to highlight recent books coverage in The Times:

headline: Cars Were Banned on 14th Street. The Apocalypse Did Not Come.
abstract: Despite the lawsuits and predictions of gridlock, restricting a single Manhattan street to buses has been a success. Why stop there?
lead_paragraph: Recently, I wandered around the vicinity of 14th Street and encountered a quiet that was almost eerie. I was unnervingly reminded of the days after 9/11, when cars were prohibited from making their way downtown. No one going to Cafe Cluny (on the corner of West 12th and West Fourth Streets) would have heard a single honking horn.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: How ‘White Guilt’ in the Age of Trump Shapes the Democratic Primary
abstract: The changing racial attitudes of white liberals are changing how 2020 candidates try to win votes.
lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — When Donald Trump was elected, John Olsen felt enraged by the racial tension that fueled his rise, the silence of his white neighbors and the stories of racial discrimination he heard from his nonwhite friends.

headline: The Democratic Debate Is Coming to Ohio, Where a Party Battle Is Already Underway
abstract: Morgan Harper is challenging Representative Joyce Beatty in a solid blue Ohio district, the latest front in the Democratic clash between left and far left.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As Morgan Harper campaigned at the Prestige Cuts & Styles barbershop here, Joe Copeland, a retired school principal, said he had never heard of the young woman mounting an insurgent primary challenge of a Democratic member of Congress. But he thought of a comparison.

headline: Get to Know the Politics Reporters Covering the 2020 Election for The Times
abstract: Hailing from across the United States, these 21 journalists bring a range of backgrounds and experience to our coverage of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Police Officer Is Stabbed in Hong Kong During Flash-Mob Protests
abstract: The rallies were spread across much of the city and reflected continuing anger over a ban on wearing face masks at public gatherings.
lead_paragraph: A police officer was stabbed in Hong Kong on Sunday, police officials said, in what appeared to be an escalation of the street violence that has gripped the city for months, as flash-mob gatherings unfolded across town.

headline: Impeachment, Syria, M.L.B. Playoffs: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Facebook’s Role in Impeachment
abstract: Plus, the N.B.A.’s multibillion-dollar relationship with China hits a snag.
