lead_paragraph: I get it: Your attention span has been consumed by impeachment news all week. But important stuff is happening in the business and tech worlds, too. Here’s what you should know heading into Monday.

headline: Lights. Camera. Prayer. A Mini-Hollywood Grows in Utah.
abstract: Movies made by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are an important part of a film and TV ecosystem in northern Utah. And there’s not an R-rating in sight.
lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — In the heavy quiet of the Utah desert, past fields of alfalfa and fruit trees, past the Goshen trailer park and a big, sprawling dairy farm, the domes of Jerusalem rise up from the patchy grass.

headline: Abandoned by U.S. in Syria, Kurds Find New Ally in American Foe
abstract: Under fire by Turkish forces, the militia that battled ISIS threw in its lot with Syria’s Russian-backed government.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Kurdish forces long allied with the United States in Syria announced a new deal on Sunday with the government in Damascus, a sworn enemy of Washington that is backed by Russia, as Turkish troops moved deeper into their territory and President Trump ordered the withdrawal of the American military from northern Syria.

headline: Hunter Biden to Leave Chinese Company Board, Addressing Appearance of a Conflict
abstract: As next debate approaches, Joseph R. Biden’s son also said he would not work for foreign-owned companies if his father became president.
lead_paragraph: ALTOONA, Iowa — Hunter Biden, whose overseas business dealings have drawn relentless attacks from President Trump and posed a threat to the candidacy of his father, Joseph R. Biden Jr., intends to step down from the board of a Chinese company, BHR, by the end of the month, his lawyer said on Sunday, a move his father later lauded in a forceful defense of his son’s integrity.

headline: Simone Biles Becomes World Championships’ Most Decorated Gymnast
abstract: Golds in the balance beam and floor exercise Sunday gave Biles 25 career world championship medals, the most among men and women.
lead_paragraph: Simone Biles on Sunday became the most decorated gymnast in world championship history, winning gold medals in the balance beam and the floor exercise to increase her career medal total in the championships to 25.

headline: Emotional Support Animals vs. a Co-op That Bans Dogs
abstract: When it comes to support animals and disabilities, the law is clear.
lead_paragraph: Q: My sister and her husband recently moved into a co-op in the Bronx with rules that prohibit dogs larger than 30 pounds. I have a 70-pound Labrador retriever that is my emotional support animal. At the board interview, my sister asked if I could bring my dog along when I visit her. The board denied her request because of his size. Can the board keep a shareholder’s brother from temporarily bringing an emotional support pet into the building because it exceeds a weight limit?

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: It may be the day to make a quick vegetable paella, chickpea harissa soup or miso chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This might be the day to make Kay Chun’s recipe for vegetable paella with chorizo (above), but I’ve been cooking on a pellet grill recently, essentially a souped-up electric smoker that burns hardwood sawdust kibble, and it’s occupying all my thoughts. At low temperatures, it’s pretty cool, a machine that cooks ribs the way wave machines deliver three-footers to bodysurfing vacationers in Vegas: so reliably as to be kind of strange.

headline: How Did Eliud Kipchoge Break the Marathon Record So Soon?
abstract: You could call his epic sub-two-hour race a branding stunt. But it was also a run for the ages.
lead_paragraph: That was fast.

headline: Pullback Leaves Green Berets Feeling ‘Ashamed,’ and Kurdish Allies Describing ‘Betrayal’
abstract: As Turkish forces cross into Kurdish areas of northern Syria, the orders from Washington to U.S. troops are simple: Stand back. Let the Kurds fight for themselves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American commandos were working alongside Kurdish forces at an outpost in eastern Syria last year when they were attacked by columns of Syrian government tanks and hundreds of troops, including Russian mercenaries. In the next hours, the Americans threw the Pentagon’s arsenal at them, including B-52 strategic bombers. The attack was stopped.

headline: Is Date Night a Scam?
abstract: A roundup of new guidance from NYT Parenting.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard the conventional advice for couples who want to stay connected after  kids: “Plan a date night!” While we have nothing against date nights, our reporter, Christina Caron, asked experts for some different ways to maintain intimacy, for the long-term. We also want to hear from you. If you’re married or in a relationship, what do you do to stay close to your partner, despite the stresses of parenthood? Drop us a line, and we may feature your story in an upcoming piece.

headline: No, Kurds and Turks Are Not ‘Natural Enemies,’ Mr. Trump
abstract: What they need is American leadership to help them make peace.
lead_paragraph: In the days just before Turkey’s military incursion into Syria, for which the stated aim includes purging a Kurdish militia that has been allied with the United States in the fight against the Islamic State, President Trump made a comment on the history of the two conflicting sides. He defined Kurds as Turkey’s “natural enemy,” adding, “one historian said they’ve been fighting for hundreds of years.”

headline: U.K. Says Immunity of U.S. Diplomat’s Wife ‘No Longer Relevant’
abstract: Anne Sacoolas fled Britain after she was suspected of being involved in a road crash that killed Harry Dunn, a British teenager.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The diplomatic immunity of Anne Sacoolas, the American woman who is a suspect in a road crash that killed Harry Dunn, a British teenager, is “no longer relevant” in the case, Britain’s foreign secretary has said.

headline: New York’s Fight Against AIDS
abstract: A reader recalls the painful early days of the epidemic that led her to a career curing disease. Also: The pitfalls of “they”; women in the building trades; small campaign donors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Columbus Day or Indigenous Peoples’ Day? Depends Where You Are
abstract: More states and towns have joined a long list of places to formally recognize Indigenous Peoples’ Day.
lead_paragraph: Since 2015, several Council members in the District of Columbia have attempted to rename Columbus Day to Indigenous Peoples’ Day. On four different occasions, the measure petered out and died.

headline: Review: Partying to End the Patriarchy in a Dionysian ‘Girls’
abstract: This head-tripping play from Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, inspired by Euripides’ “The Bacchae,” allows women past and present to find catharsis in one truly wild bash.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — Please don’t call him a D.J. Really, I mean it, just don’t. This is one guy you should never, ever tick off. But you have to say that Deon, the feral young man at the center of Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “Girls” at the University Theater here, sure knows how to play the right music.

headline: Richard Jackson, Who Had an Ear for Children’s Books, Dies at 84
abstract: As an editor he championed writers, like Judy Blume, who changed the landscape of literature for young people. He later became a writer himself.
lead_paragraph: Richard Jackson, an editor who published books by Judy Blume, Paula Fox, Virginia Hamilton and other award-winning authors that broadened the scope of children’s literature, then late in life became a children’s author himself, died on Oct. 2 in Towson, Md. He was 84.

headline: Trump Orders Withdrawal of U.S. Troops From Northern Syria
abstract: The decision effectively cedes control of the area and could allow a resurgence of ISIS, but the defense secretary argued American forces would not have deterred a Turkish invasion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper said Sunday that President Trump ordered a withdrawal of American forces from northern Syria, a decision that will effectively cede control of the area to the Syrian government and Russia, and could allow a resurgence of the Islamic State.

headline: Grim Facts: Deaths Involving Cars
abstract: Readers discuss the harm done in a driving culture.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the 2020 Democrats Responded to a Gun Policy Survey
abstract: We asked all 19 Democratic presidential candidates for their views on assault weapons, gun licensing and other policies.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked all 19 Democratic presidential candidates to complete a survey on gun policy. Following are the full responses we received, unedited except for corrected typos and punctuation.

headline: We Surveyed the 2020 Democrats on Gun Control. Here Are the New Dividing Lines.
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidates agree on many gun control measures, like an assault weapons ban. But they’re split on other ideas, like a federal gun registry.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 Democratic presidential candidates are far more forceful and united on gun control than their predecessors, endorsing a wide range of policies that past nominees sidestepped or rejected, according to a New York Times survey of the 19 campaigns.

headline: A Play About God and Trump, From a Writer Raised on the Right
abstract: Will Arbery has brought the world of ultraconservative Catholic intellectuals to the stage in “Heroes of the Fourth Turning.” He’s pleased that they appreciate being seen, not judged.
lead_paragraph: For a young playwright in New York, it’s one thing to draw buzz from critics and theater fans. It’s quite another to have your dense and boundary-pushing Off Broadway play become a talking point among religious conservatives — and not because they hate it.

headline: After Typhoon Hagibis, Dramatic Rescues of Residents Trapped by Floods
abstract: Japan, which prides itself on its robust infrastructure and disaster preparedness, was humbled by the storm that hurt major metropolitan areas.
lead_paragraph: KAWAGOE, JAPAN — One by one, the boats arrived, having crossed a lake that did not exist the day before. They carried precious cargo: old-age patients rescued from a flooded nursing home in an exurb of Tokyo.

headline: A Debate Can Make or Break a Campaign. Here’s How.
abstract: Over the years, televised debates have yielded turning points for presidential contenders. We look at some pivotal moments from past debates and explain how they shaped the race.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, televised debates have yielded turning points for presidential contenders. We look at some pivotal moments from past debates and explain how they shaped the race.

headline: How the Pitfalls of Past Debates Inform 2020 Candidates’ Playbooks
abstract: A pivotal debate moment can make or break a campaign. We asked Times reporters to analyze some famous — and infamous — ones from the past.
lead_paragraph: The 12 Democratic candidates taking the debate stage on Tuesday night will all try to achieve a standout moment.

headline: WeWork Planned a Residential Utopia. It Hasn’t Turned Out That Way.
abstract: Adam Neumann, the company’s ousted founder, once said there would be WeLive apartments around the globe. But now, it has only two sites and has been under investigation.
lead_paragraph: After first pledging to upend the way people worked, WeWork vowed to change how they lived: WeLive, a sleek dormitory for working professionals with free beer, arcade games in the laundry room and catered Sunday dinners, would spread around the world.

headline: Kenya’s Brigid Kosgei Breaks Marathon World Record
abstract: A record that seemed untouchable for years fell in 2:14:04. The run whacked 81 seconds off the previous women’s mark.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This city lived up to its billing as host of America’s fastest major marathon on Sunday as Brigid Kosgei of Kenya set a women’s world record.

headline: Review: ‘Madama Butterfly,’ Without Its Flesh-and-Blood Intensity
abstract: Hui He and Piero Pretti star in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of the film director Anthony Minghella’s production.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Minghella’s Metropolitan Opera production of “Madama Butterfly” survives for a few reasons. It’s popular. And it remains a bookmark for the moment when Peter Gelb’s tenure as general manager of the company began, back in 2006.

headline: Cardinals’ Hit or Miss Offense Is Missing Again
abstract: St. Louis heads to Washington after scoring a total of one run on four hits in the first two games of the N.L. Championship Series.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The baseball schedule is so unforgiving that most teams, by the end, know just who they are. The St. Louis Cardinals are still searching, and they are running out of time.

headline: They Crossed an Ocean to Butcher Pigs. It Was No American Dream.
abstract: 200 Pacific Islanders recruited to work at an Iowa pork plant ended up in a tangled migration dispute with accusations of mistreatment and broken promises.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Anthony Pretrick was scraping by as a fisherman in his Pacific island homeland of Micronesia when he met a job recruiter with an irresistible offer: There was a fortune to be made slaughtering hogs in a faraway place called Iowa.

headline: With No End to Unrest in Sight, Hong Kong’s Economic Pain Deepens
abstract: An unmistakable sense of alarm is spreading among both small business owners and corporate executives who see no way out of the impasse.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was the second day of Golden Week, usually one of Hong Kong’s busiest shopping periods, and Matthew Tam and his co-workers at a jewelry store were looking as lonely as a band of Maytag repairmen, surrounded by display cases of luxury watches with nary a customer in sight.

headline: Rebels Dressed as Soccer Players Abduct Bus Passengers in Myanmar
abstract: Gunmen stopped the vehicle on a highway outside the town of Mrauk U and seized 31 people, most of them firefighters, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — Gunmen dressed in soccer uniforms halted an express bus on a main highway in Myanmar’s troubled Rakhine State and kidnapped 31 people, most of them firefighters, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: Bruce LeFavour, ‘a Good Cook,’ Dies at 84
abstract: As a restaurateur, he was in the vanguard of moving from rich French fare to more fish and seasonal, locally sourced fresh produce.
lead_paragraph: Bruce LeFavour, an eclectic, self-taught American cook who, on nothing more than three years in Europe and an innate appreciation of perfect ingredients, helped created the early California cuisine movement, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Port Townsend, Wash. He was 84.

headline: Review: William Forsythe Takes Dance to a Quiet, Uneven Place
abstract: Mr. Forsythe’s evening at the Shed has rigor and charm but not enough transcendence.
lead_paragraph: One of the pleasures of a life filled with dance is the way, at the end of the day, a performance can force the mind to change course, to quiet down. William Forsythe’s program at the Shed, “A Quiet Evening of Dance,” which opened on Friday, takes that to another level.

headline: Your Paycheck May Impact Your Heart Health
abstract: The risk for cardiovascular disease may increase when a person’s income goes down, and decrease when it goes up.
lead_paragraph: Fluctuations in earnings may affect your heart health.

headline: How to Close Rikers Island
abstract: Smaller jails, built in different boroughs, are good investments in a safer future.
lead_paragraph: The decline in crime over the past three decades in New York City is one of the most striking examples of how a community can change the way it behaves. New Yorkers today are not as violent toward their neighbors as they were in the 1990s and commit fewer crimes. The police make fewer arrests. Prosecutors and judges divert more offenders to alternatives to jail.

headline: ‘Addams Family’ Climbs Box Office, but ‘Joker’ Stays on Top
abstract: “Joker” left room for the arrival of another, less violently somber movie (with similarly strong Halloween costume potential): “The Addams Family.”
lead_paragraph: It was a good weekend for gloom.

headline: Inside Boeing, a C.E.O. Stripped of Power and a Top Executive Under Fire
abstract: The decision to strip Dennis Muilenburg of his chairman title culminated months of internal debate over whether to hold top executives accountable after the 737 Max crashes.
lead_paragraph: Early Friday morning, Boeing’s board gathered on a conference call that had been hastily arranged the day before. Dennis A. Muilenburg, the company’s chief executive and the chairman of the board, was not invited.

headline: American Basketball vs. Chinese Hardball: Guess Who Won
abstract: The N.B.A. is the latest entertainment giant to incite nationalist anger in China, where political submission has become the price of admission to a market of 1.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Back in the Cold War, the sclerotic Soviet system proved no match for the lure of American soft power: bluejeans, jazz, rock ’n’ roll, Coca-Cola, Hollywood. All became symbols of American freedom and prosperity that no amount of communist prohibitions could stop.

headline: Trudeau’s Tough Fight Could Make Canada’s Small Parties Kingmakers
abstract: As Canada’s election campaign heads into its final week, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is locked in a tie with his Conservative challengers. But smaller parties could end up in a powerful position.
lead_paragraph: GRAVENHURST, Ontario — When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s image as a liberal reformer crumbled during the lead-up to Canada’s national election, an opportunity opened for competing left-wing parties to attract disaffected voters.

headline: Typhoon Hagibis, Islamic State, Hong Kong: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: ISIS families escape as Turkey attacks in Syria.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Afghans Demanded a Fair Election. They Could Be Waiting a While for Results.
abstract: Measures meant to prevent a repeat of fraudulent elections resulted in delays that will likely mean an Oct. 19 deadline for announcing the winner will be missed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two weeks after Afghans braved deadly Taliban attacks in order to vote for a new president, both front-runners have essentially claimed victory but the country’s Election Commission appeared unlikely to meet its own deadline for announcing preliminary results.

headline: Woman Was Playing Video Game With Her Nephew When Shot by Fort Worth Police
abstract: A police officer fired the shot that killed Atatiana Jefferson from outside her bedroom window. A neighbor had reported two doors ajar.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Minutes before she was shot and killed by a Fort Worth police officer, Atatiana K. Jefferson was playing video games in her bedroom with her 8-year-old nephew, a lawyer for her family said Sunday.

headline: The Kurds’ Prisons and Detention Camps for ISIS Members, Explained
abstract: As the Turkish invasion leads to deteriorating security in northern Syria, the custody of about 11,000 captive ISIS fighters — and many thousands more detained ISIS women and children — is in doubt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The escalating chaos in northern Syria as Turkey presses forward with its attack on the United States’ erstwhile Kurdish allies is raising fears about the fate of thousands of Islamic State detainees that the Kurds have been holding in makeshift wartime prisons.

headline: Coco Gauff, 15, Wins Her First Singles Title
abstract: Gauff, the American tennis phenom, defeated Jelena Ostapenko, 6-3, 1-6, 6-2, in Linz, Austria, to add another highlight to her breakout season.
lead_paragraph: Coco Gauff put her hands on her face in disbelief, then pumped her arms in triumph on Sunday, celebrating the one thing her breakout season had been missing: a singles title.

headline: Astros Beat Yankees as Bullpen Battle Ends With One Swing
abstract: Houston evened the A.L.C.S. when Carlos Correa’s home run in the 11th ended a long battle between two bullpens.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Carlos Correa stopped halfway to home plate as his Houston Astros teammates bounced around in delight. As J.A. Happ and the rest of the Yankees trudged off the field after Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, Correa tossed his helmet like a basketball into the circle of delirious Astros and charged into the celebration.

headline: Survive Elimination
abstract: Gary Cee opens our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — A nice, smooth, easy-to-complete crossword puzzle, that’s what we need on Mondays. It’s a fine transition into the week, and Gary Cee’s puzzle fits the bill.

headline: John Giorno, Who Moved Poetry Beyond the Printed Page, Dies at 82
abstract: He starred in an Andy Warhol movie, “Sleep,” but was best known for his efforts to bring poetry into the modern age.
lead_paragraph: John Giorno, who turned to the world of art and the mechanisms of mass media to shake poetry loose from the page and embed it more deeply in the fabric of everyday life, died on Friday at his home in Lower Manhattan in a building that he had made into a gathering place for practically everyone from the avant-garde of his time. He was 82.

headline: Man Hurt in Florida Mall Panic, but No Sign of Shooting, Police Say
abstract: Shoppers fled the Town Center mall in Boca Raton, Fla., after hearing a loud noise in the food court.
lead_paragraph: Panicked shoppers fled a South Florida mall on Sunday after believing they heard gunshots, prompting police S.W.A.T. teams and federal agents to lock down the commercial center for several hours — but the authorities later said there was no evidence of a shooting.

headline: The Should-Be Solution to the Student-Debt Problem
abstract: Income-driven repayment programs cover eight million borrowers, but they could be helping more if they were simpler and reached the people who needed them.
lead_paragraph: With more than 7.5 million student loan borrowers in default and nearly 2 million others seriously behind on their payments, there’s little question that the handful of federal programs designed to help struggling borrowers pay what they can afford aren’t working for everyone.

headline: 111-Year-Old ‘Sturgeon King’ Barney Greengrass Is Closed by Health Department
abstract: The shop and restaurant were ordered to clean up violations, including mouse droppings and roaches. The owner hopes to reopen soon.
lead_paragraph: The metal gates were pulled shut on Sunday, and confused patrons, some thumbing New York City guidebooks, had to look elsewhere for their smoked-fish fix. A bright yellow sign that said “Closed by the order of the commissioner of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene” was placed prominently in the window.

headline: Brooklyn Shooting: Poker Player Opened Fire and Was Killed by Bouncer
abstract: The 37-year-old man was among the four people killed at an unlicensed social club in Brooklyn, a police official said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Chester Goode might have been holding a grudge after a fight last year at an unlicensed social club tucked in a row of townhouses in Brooklyn. Or perhaps he was losing a game of poker and wanted to rob other gamblers at the illicit operation that drew patrons in flashy cars — and complaints from neighbors.

headline: The Clinton Legacy: Impeachment Hurts the President
abstract: The 1998 trial damaged Democrats more than Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom holds that the Republican Party suffered a big political penalty for impeaching Bill Clinton in 1998. But that’s not quite right. Republicans paid a modest, short-term penalty, while the costs to the Democratic Party appear to have been larger and longer-lasting.

headline: Suburbanites in Louisiana Vote to Create a New City of Their Own
abstract: The referendum to establish a largely white city called St. George on the edge of Baton Rouge, which is racially diverse, grew out of frustration over schools and local control.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Residents of a largely white suburb of Baton Rouge voted on Saturday to incorporate a new city of their own — to be called St. George — and take away control of the community’s taxes, schools and other services from the less affluent, more diverse surrounding parish.

headline: Miami Out-Bungles Washington in Race to the N.F.L.’s Bottom
abstract: The two winless teams met and anyone who watched lost.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — It was necessary on Sunday to remember, despite six weeks of conflicting evidence, that the players on the Miami Dolphins and the Washington Redskins are not actually bad at football. Really, they are among the best in the world at what they do.

headline: Fox News Is Trump’s Chief TV Booster. So Why Is He Griping About It?
abstract: A phone call from the president to the Fox News chief executive suggests a crack in the alliance between him and his favorite news network.
lead_paragraph: Fed up with the coverage on his favorite cable news station, President Trump decided late this summer that a direct intervention was needed. So he telephoned the chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, and let loose.

headline: 47 Arrested in Drag Races That Can Reach 100 M.P.H.
abstract: Officers in New Haven staged a sting operation at a McDonald’s parking lot known for its raucous drag-racing gatherings.
lead_paragraph: During a typical weekend night at a McDonald’s parking lot in New Haven, Conn., car engines rev, spectators scream and amateur drivers tear into the street for late-night drag races.

headline: WeWork Is Said to Be Weighing 2 Financial Rescue Plans
abstract: One would effectively hand control of the business to SoftBank of Japan, its top shareholder, and another would raise billions in debt via JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of WeWork is at a crossroads as it tries to keep itself afloat after its failed initial public offering and the ouster of its longtime chief executive.

headline: Review: A Son Mourns in ‘Notes on My Mother’s Decline’
abstract: Intimate but distant by design, Andy Bragen’s play takes us on a journey many are likely to face with an aging parent.
lead_paragraph: The title of Andy Bragen’s new autobiographical show, “Notes on My Mother’s Decline,” forecasts exactly what’s in store: It is just as collected, fatalistic and grief-stricken as you might expect. Perhaps those first two qualities, with their suggestion of emotional detachment, are what helped the playwright cope with the third. Or maybe that’s what Bragen (“This Is My Office,” “Don’t You _______ Say a Word”) would like us to think.

headline: Deal Struck in Ecuador to Cancel Austerity Package and End Protests
abstract: Under the agreement, the president pledged to withdraw from an I.M.F.-backed program that raised fuel prices, and Indigenous leaders agreed to call off more protests.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Thousands of Indigenous and student protesters celebrated their victory over the government of Ecuador on Monday by clearing the streets of the capital of debris, following an agreement to cancel an economic austerity package that had ignited 11 days of protests that left at least seven dead and more than 1,000 injured.

headline: Sam Darnold’s Comeback Rescues the Jets’ Offense
abstract: In his return from mononucleosis, the quarterback led the Jets to their first win of the season, against the Dallas Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Before Sunday, no one would have called him a superhero, but to a depleted Jets team in search of any semblance of offense, Sam Darnold might as well have worn a cape in a 24-22 win over the Dallas Cowboys (3-3).

headline: Inside Trump’s Botched Attempt to Hire Trey Gowdy
abstract: The hiring of Mr. Gowdy and its quick reversal offer a public glimpse into the turmoil in the White House as it struggles to decide how to respond to impeachment.
lead_paragraph: For 24 hours last week, Trey Gowdy, the former South Carolina congressman best known for leading congressional investigations of Hillary Clinton, was the new face of President Trump’s outside legal defense and a symbol of a streamlined effort to respond to a fast-moving impeachment inquiry.

headline: Trumpism’s Infinite Vulgarities
abstract: Republicans have come to accept what they once professed to abhor.
lead_paragraph: The terrains of acceptability and respectability have shifted under the American conservative.

headline: Macabre Video of Fake Trump Shooting Media and Critics Is Shown at His Resort
abstract: The video was shown at a conference attended by Donald Trump Jr. and Sarah Huckabee Sanders. They said they did not see it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A video depicting a macabre scene of a fake President Trump shooting, stabbing and brutally assaulting members of the news media and his political opponents was shown at a conference for his supporters at his Miami resort last week, according to footage obtained by The New York Times.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 8: He Said, She Said, She Said, She Said
abstract: Noah’s troubled past with women is coming back to haunt him several times over. Whose perspective are we meant to believe?
lead_paragraph: “I work, I write, I see my kids, and I try to be a good person.” That’s Noah Solloway, taking stock of his life as it now stands. “You can’t just invent reality. Certain things happen, other things don’t.” That’s also Noah Solloway, defending his version of many of the events that led to his life as it now stands.

headline: 2 Ohio Teenagers Charged After Log Fell Off Cliff, Killing Woman
abstract: The 16-year-olds were charged with reckless homicide after the authorities got a tip.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Schafer stood in Hocking Hills State Park in Ohio on Sept. 2, taking portraits of six high school seniors near Old Man’s Cave.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 4, Episode 2 Recap: Deus Ex Machina
abstract: Elliot and Mr. Robot get a lesson about who’s really running the show.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a powerful group of people out there that are secretly running the world. I’m talking about the guys no one knows about. The guys that are invisible. The top 1 percent of the top 1 percent. The guys that play God without permission.”

headline: ‘The Righteous Gemstones’ Season Finale: Danny McBride Testifies
abstract: The creator and star of the HBO comedy talked about the Season 1 finale, struggling with church as a child and an interesting query he received from Kanye West.
lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for the Season 1 finale of “The Righteous Gemstones.”

headline: No Corrections: October 14, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 14, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 14, 2019.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Taking Stock as Typhoon Moves Away From Japan
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 14, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Recently, a girl made a speech about global warming, and as she was crying she said, ‘We have no future.’ She is absolutely right.”

headline: Syria, Brexit, Simone Biles: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Case of Thailand’s Disappearing Dissidents
abstract: The military is still in power but is more insecure than ever.
lead_paragraph: At 4:45 a.m. on July 8, a man wearing black and a mask broke into my apartment in Kyoto. He walked into my bedroom, attacked me and my partner with a chemical spray and escaped. Nothing was stolen. The Japanese police arrived quickly. The investigation is ongoing; the perpetrator has not been apprehended.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: The Finale of ‘The Terror: Infamy’ and Franju’s ‘Judex’
abstract: The second season of the historical horror show wraps up. And Georges Franju’s tribute to early film serials arrives on the Criterion Channel.
lead_paragraph: THE TERROR: INFAMY 9 p.m. on AMC. The dark side of history mingles with the supernatural in surprising and sometimes ambiguous ways in this anthology horror series. Season 2, which will conclude tonight, is particularly focused on the banal evil of politics and otherworldly malevolence. Set mostly in a Japanese internment camp during World War II, it follows Chester (Derek Mio) and his family in the aftermath of the Pearl Harbor attack. They are shadowed by Yuko (Kiki Sukezane), a mysterious being who has some designs on the child Chester’s wife, Luz (Cristina Rodlo), is carrying. Yuko, it turns out, is connected to Chester’s past. She is also a tormented shape-shifting spirit. The season’s penultimate episode resolved some of its central mysteries, including why Yuko wants Chester’s son, but it remains to be seen how Chester will try to vanquish her.

headline: E-Cigarettes Went Unchecked in 10 Years of Federal Inaction
abstract: A decade after Congress gave the F.D.A. the power to regulate tobacco products like e-cigarettes, the federal government has repeatedly delayed or weakened efforts that could have protected teenagers.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, not long after Dr. Margaret Hamburg became commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, a package arrived at her home. Inside was a clunky device called an e-cigarette.

headline: $200 Million, Jailed Immigrants and a Democratic Bastion Under Fire
abstract: A New Jersey county in one of the bluest regions of the country faces mounting pressure to stop housing detained immigrants in its jail.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, lawmakers in Essex County, N.J., agreed to house detained immigrants at the local jail in exchange for what would eventually add up to around $200 million from the federal government. Across the country, hundreds of other local communities were shoring up their budgets with similar deals.

headline: Read the Polls. Debate Them. Definitely Don’t Count on Them.
abstract: The first College Football Playoff ranking is still three weeks away. Players and coaches say the other polls are intriguing, but mostly potentially season-crippling distractions.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Around the time the University of Oklahoma’s spirit squad, the Ruf/Neks, fired its shotguns, it was possible to catch the hoarsely hollered words of two men clad in crimson and cream.

headline: Wall Street’s Sky-High Expectations Are About to Collide With Reality
abstract: As companies start reporting quarterly earnings this week, what they say about the future could jolt the stock market.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s eternally optimistic forecasters are expecting corporate profit growth to surge by the middle of next year — views that are about to collide with reality as hundreds of companies report financial results and update investors on their prospects.

headline: He Tried E-Cigarettes to Quit Smoking. Doctors Say Vaping Led to His Death.
abstract: Months after John Steffen died in Nebraska, officials said his death was part of a mysterious outbreak of vaping-related deaths and illnesses.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — In the spring, Kathleen Fimple buried her husband, John, and by the fall, she had reluctantly settled into her new life as a widow.

headline: Catalan Separatist Leaders Get Lengthy Prison Terms for Sedition
abstract: Spain’s Supreme Court gave the former deputy leader of Catalonia, Oriol Junqueras, 13 years. A Spanish judge also issued a new European arrest warrant for Carles Puigdemont.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish Supreme Court on Monday sentenced former leaders of the Catalan independence movement to lengthy prison terms after finding them guilty of sedition for their botched attempt to break away from Spain in 2017.

headline: The Syrian War: Today’s Top Developments
abstract: Hours after reaching an agreement with Kurdish forces, the Syrian Army entered a key town near the Turkish border — a significant shift in the power dynamic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said  Monday that he was halting trade negotiations with Turkey and doubling tariffs on imports of Turkish steel as relations between the countries continued to deteriorate.

headline: South Korean Politician Resigns After Weeks of Protests
abstract: Ever since the appointment of Cho Kuk as justice minister, South Korea has been rocked by huge rallies for and against him.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A key ally of President Moon Jae-in of South Korea on Monday stepped down as justice minister, handing a victory to South Koreans who have been holding enormous rallies for weeks demanding his removal.

headline: How The Times Covers the United States Ahead of a Pivotal Election
abstract: With one of the largest teams of national correspondents in the business, we help the country to understand itself. Watch with us on Tuesday as we co-sponsor the Democratic debate.
lead_paragraph: With one of the largest teams of national correspondents in the business, we help the country to understand itself. Watch with us on Tuesday as we co-sponsor the Democratic debate.

headline: Facebook Political Ads: What the 2020 Candidates’ Campaign Spending Reveals
abstract: Candidates have spent more money on Facebook than TV this year. See what coalitions they are trying to build through Facebook ads.
lead_paragraph: Candidates have spent more money on Facebook than TV this year. See what coalitions they are trying to build through Facebook ads.

headline: Staying on Guard Against Skin Cancer
abstract: If you see something on your skin that is new, changing, not healing or doesn’t seem right, get it checked out as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: “If you see something, say something,” a catchy warning from the Department of Homeland Security about possible terrorist threats, applies as well to skin lesions that, if ignored, could become fatal.

headline: Helping Teenagers Quit Vaping
abstract: As vaping deaths rise, quitting has a new urgency. But experts say withdrawal can be even more challenging than from conventional cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: For many years, my lead-in question with adolescents, after I asked the parent to leave the room at pediatric appointments, was whether the kid had ever tried smoking cigarettes. It made a reasonable lead-in because it felt less highly charged than asking about marijuana or other substances, and in recent decades, the answer was very often no. Youth tobacco smoking in the United States was on the decline.

headline: How Moving to France and Having Children Led a Black American to Rethink Race
abstract: “Self-Portrait in Black and White,” by Thomas Chatterton Williams, is the author’s searching account about what it means to embrace a racial identity — and then to cast it off.
lead_paragraph: SELF-PORTRAIT IN BLACK AND WHITEUnlearning RaceBy Thomas Chatterton Williams

headline: ‘Faithless Electors’ Could Tip the 2020 Election. Will the Supreme Court Stop Them?
abstract: A new petition asks the justices to rule quickly, before the next election, on whether members of the Electoral College may vote their consciences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Dec. 19, 2016, a little more than a month after the presidential election, members of the Electoral College gathered around the nation to cast their votes. Ten of them went rogue.

headline: Five Reasons the Diet Soda Myth Won’t Die
abstract: Repeated studies on a health bogeyman help explain wider problems with food research.
lead_paragraph: There’s a decent chance you’ll be reading about diet soda studies until the day you die. (The odds are exceedingly good it won’t be the soda that kills you.)

headline: Prosecutors Re-examine Killing After Missouri Deputy Is Charged in Another Shooting
abstract: The deputy was awarded a medal of valor after she shot and killed a man outside a Walmart in 2017.
lead_paragraph: When a Missouri deputy said she fatally shot a man in 2017 because he was reaching for her Taser, the sheriff’s department awarded her a medal of valor. But after the deputy used the same defense for shooting a woman in the back in August, the county prosecutor pressed charges last week and promised to look into the 2017 shooting again.

headline: A Rent-Stabilized Apartment on Central Park? Of Course He’s Staying
abstract: Ian Jarvis was told that his building was going condo and that he would have to move. Happily, that wasn’t the end of the story.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Ian Jarvis — along with many of his neighbors at 360 Central Park West — received some unwelcome news. He got a letter from the landlord, Argo Real Estate, informing him that Argo would not be renewing his lease. The building, an elegant prewar rental on the park, was going condo, and he would have to leave.

headline: The Immigrants Trump Denounces Have Helped Revive the Cities He Scorns
abstract: Two of the president’s oft-cited problems have been solutions to each other throughout American history.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has turned repeatedly throughout his tenure and his re-election campaign to two targets: immigrants whom he has described as “invading” the country, and American cities he has called out of control.

headline: Missing From Elizabeth Warren’s 2020 Surge: Democratic Endorsements
abstract: Despite Ms. Warren’s upward momentum in polls and fund-raising, she lacks the support of a single governor, big-city mayor or fellow senator outside Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren has built her following in part by taking pictures with thousands of voters deep into evening after campaign events, but her dinner audience here one night last month was far smaller. And Ms. Warren’s guests were more interested in hearing, and politely challenging, her campaign pitch than eagerly capturing the moment for posterity on their iPhones.

headline: Fly Fishing Is the New Bird-Watching
abstract: It’s the latest “old timey” hobby to gain a dedicated new following.
lead_paragraph: Step aside, goat yoga. The chic way to unwind now is fly fishing.

headline: Who Is Marc Lacey? Meet the Times Editor Moderating the Democratic Debate
abstract: Marc Lacey, the National editor, will be onstage with the CNN anchors Anderson Cooper and Erin Burnett at the first  debate The Times has hosted in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center has started an interview series, Behind the Byline, to introduce you to Times journalists. Is there a reporter, photographer or editor whom you would like to get to know? Tell us in the form below.

headline: The Bar That Has Fed SoHo for Almost a Century
abstract: Fanelli’s, on the corner of Mercer and Prince Streets, is a bastion of old New York beloved by artists and tourists alike.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Back in Action at the Debate, Has Much to Prove
abstract: Two weeks after his heart attack, the Vermont senator will be trying to convince voters he has the strength to run a forceful campaign.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders and his advisers were not anxious before the first three televised primary debates, confident in his ability to champion his ideas and dubious that the debates would dramatically change how voters regarded him.

headline: Vashti Harrison Lets the Light In
abstract: The best-selling author and illustrator shows us around her Brooklyn studio.
lead_paragraph: Vashti Harrison is the writer and illustrator behind best-selling children’s books such as “Little Leaders: Bold Women in Black History.” The picture book she made with the Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong’o, “Sulwe,” is out this week, telling the story of a little girl who learns to love her “skin the color of midnight.” Earlier this year, Harrison worked with the writer and filmmaker Matthew A. Cherry on “Hair Love,” a picture book that grew out of a short film about an African-American girl whose father does her hair while her mother is in the hospital.

headline: Jane Smiley on What St. Louis Tells Us About America
abstract: The author finds her hometown perhaps the most enlightening spot in America for exploring what America really is.

headline: Capturing a Portrait of the Electorate
abstract: Over three days in Texas, the photographers Chad Batka and Celeste Sloman photographed a representative sample of American voters.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: A Guide to the Queen’s Speech: Crown Jewels, Black Rod and a Mace
abstract: Proceedings in the British Parliament on Monday are a nod to hundreds of years of history. But Brexit loomed over the ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A “hostage,” a search for explosives, heaps of royal jewels and a five-foot silver gilt mace. Welcome to the reopening of Britain’s Parliament, replete with ancient traditions and elaborate rituals, and infused with tension over the country’s looming exit from the European Union.

headline: What We Learned in N.F.L. Week 6
abstract: Lamar Jackson rolled over Cincinnati, the 49ers stayed undefeated, and the Jets, Redskins and Cardinals all, somehow, won.
lead_paragraph: The Jets, Cardinals and Redskins all won, the Chiefs lost a second consecutive game at home, and the backup quarterbacks for Carolina and New Orleans improved to a combined record of 8-0. Week 6 saw the Patriots and 49ers both stay undefeated, but it was filled with lots of surprises.

headline: Syria, Economics Nobel, Houston Astros: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Columbus Day: Racism Charge in Debate Over Monuments
abstract: Actor Chazz Palminteri apologized for calling the mayor's wife a racist. Then he asked again for a statue honoring Mother Cabrini.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Rome University at Heart of Trump Inquiry Becomes a Vortex of Intrigue
abstract: Italian newspapers that have depicted Link University as either a shady diploma mill or den of spies, unfairly tarnishing its reputation, its president says.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Officials at Link Campus University, a small Rome college lined with courtyards and gravel paths, like to point out the Renaissance balcony where Pope Pius V prophesied the decisive naval victory of the Holy League over the Ottoman Empire.

headline: Nobel Economics Prize Goes to Pioneers in Reducing Poverty
abstract: Three professors, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, both of M.I.T., and Michael Kremer of Harvard, were honored.
lead_paragraph: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo of M.I.T. and Michael Kremer of Harvard have devoted more than 20 years of economic research to developing new ways to study — and help — the world’s poor.

headline: The Story of a Kurdish General
abstract: The Americans promised they would protect his people. Now, one Kurdish leader is forced to turn to former foes for help.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Kanye West and the Cult of Personality
abstract: The artist’s Sunday Service concerts have afforded him grace in the face of controversy. But a lot has changed since he made “Jesus Walks.”
lead_paragraph: When Kanye West’s “Jesus Walks” was released in 2004, the song was praised for boldly bringing discussions of faith into hip-hop. Fifteen years later, Mr. West’s contemporaries continue to speak of its impact. In the first episode of “Hip-Hop: The Songs That Shook America,” an AMC docu-series that premiered Sunday, the singer-songwriter John Legend said, “Kanye made it O.K. to talk about your faith in songs that weren’t Christian songs.”

headline: Turning Off the Lights in California
abstract: The state faces enormous challenges to prevent the catastrophic wildfires of recent years.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The New Normal is the phrase many use to describe the ways our world is evolving as the climate changes. As we have seen in recent years in the American West, and especially in California, it means dealing with more frequent and more devastating wildfires.

headline: I Almost Flipped a Deep Red District. Here’s What I Learned.
abstract: Lead with values. Promote common-sense policies. And don’t give up on rural voters.
lead_paragraph: In a special election on Sept. 10, my campaign came an inch short of flipping a deep red congressional seat in North Carolina. We lost, but we showed how Democrats can win nationwide in 2020.

headline: It’s Time to Talk to Iran
abstract: With tensions rising in the Middle East and Iran suffering under sanctions, this may be the last best opportunity to walk back from the brink.
lead_paragraph: This month, six years ago, we were in the midst of secret talks with Iran that led to the comprehensive nuclear agreement. It was a moment when diplomacy carried considerable risk, and considerable promise. Today, the promise has faded, and the risk is accelerating.

headline: Marc Benioff: We Need a New Capitalism
abstract: The current system has led to profound inequality. To fix it, we need businesses and executives to value purpose alongside profit.
lead_paragraph: Capitalism, I acknowledge, has been good to me.

headline: Homemade Bomb Detonated for First Time in Hong Kong Protests
abstract: The explosive device, set off with a mobile phone, indicated an escalation in the street-level arms race between police officers and the protesters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A homemade bomb was detonated in Hong Kong on Sunday amid violent protests, the police said on Monday, indicating an escalation in the street-level arms race between police officers and the protesters.

headline: WeWork Has to Pick Its Bailout
abstract: The co-working company’s board is expected to meet as soon as this afternoon to choose a financial lifeline, after its I.P.O. fell apart last month.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday! This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers like Dennis Muilenburg, Boeing’s C.E.O. Andrew will ask him about the company’s crisis and the news on Friday that he was stripped him of his chairman title. Apply to attend here. ( Sign up here to get this in your inbox each morning.)

headline: The Amelia Earhart Mystery Stays Down in the Deep
abstract: Robert Ballard’s expedition to a remote island in the South Pacific found no evidence of the vanished aviator’s plane. But the explorer and his crew haven’t given up.
lead_paragraph: For two weeks in August, a multimillion-dollar search from air, land and sea sought to solve the 80-year mystery of Amelia Earhart’s disappearance.

headline: How Investigators Could Pursue a Case Against Juul
abstract: The rise of vaping-related illnesses and deaths has put the e-cigarette maker squarely in the sights of the government.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Is Rihanna’s ‘Visual Autobiography’ a Triumph or a Tease?
abstract: A fashion critic and a music critic debate.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna has a new release. But it’s not a single, or a new Fenty collection, or another Amazon Prime underwear show. It’s a “visual autobiography,” out on Oct. 24. Just over a foot wide and about one and a third feet tall, 15 pounds and full of glossy pictures, with a few gatefolds and special inserts.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Sails Out, Nails Out
abstract: Logan seems to think he is the only member of the Waystar leadership team who isn’t expendable. Not everyone agrees.
lead_paragraph: For about 10 minutes in the middle of the “Succession” Season 2 finale, the show briefly becomes a bit like the reality series “Survivor.” The Roy family and their top Waystar executives have a kind of tribal council on a super yacht, sitting around a breakfast table with Logan, discussing whom to sacrifice over the scandal in the company’s cruise division. The argument turns into a fascinating study of human nature as these people try to save their jobs — and their senses of self — with a combination of strategic shade-throwing and personal appeals.

headline: Cell Service Returns to Kashmir, Allowing First Calls in Months
abstract: After imposing a complete communications blackout two months ago, the Indian government on Monday partially restored cellphone service in the Kashmir Valley.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — When the cellphone started to ring, after 71 days of silence, the crowd erupted into a loud cheer.

headline: Democratic Debate: Tulsi Gabbard, After Threatening Boycott, Will Participate on Tuesday
abstract: The Hawaii congresswoman has railed against what she sees as a “rigging” of the election by Democratic Party leaders and corporate media.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tulsi Gabbard, one of 12 Democratic presidential candidates who have qualified for this week’s televised debate, said on Monday that she would participate in the forum after raising the possibility of boycotting it to protest what she sees as a “rigging” of the election.

headline: Setback for Orban as Opposition in Hungary Gains Ground in Elections
abstract: The governing Fidesz party lost the mayoralty of Budapest and 10 other cities in a campaign dominated by sex tapes and corruption accusations.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Voters in Budapest and other Hungarian cities handed a stinging defeat on Sunday to the country’s populist leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban, and his political machine, sending a wave of opposition candidates to victory in local elections.

headline: How California’s ‘Demonized’ Winds Shape Wildfire Season
abstract: Monday: Santa Ana and Diablo Winds have caused havoc across the state. Also: Updates on wildfires; and a statewide snooze button for students.
lead_paragraph: By Jill Cowan

headline: What You Get for $2 Million in California
abstract: A beach house in Watsonville; a duplex loft in San Francisco; and a Craftsman-style home with a guest cottage in Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: A beach house in Watsonville; a duplex loft in San Francisco; and a Craftsman-style home with a guest cottage in Santa Barbara.

headline: $2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A beach house in Watsonville, a duplex loft in San Francisco and a Craftsman-style home with a guest cottage in Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: This vacation home is in the front, ocean-facing row of the Pajaro Dunes resort community, a collection of beach houses and rental properties along 1.5 miles of Monterey Bay, about 21 miles southeast of Santa Cruz and 30 miles northeast of Monterey, as the road runs. The architect, William Logan, of Palo Alto, Calif., designed the redwood-plywood-sided building to offer ocean views and access to outdoor decks from most of the rooms, while screening the neighbors. The sellers are the second owners of the house.

headline: Bolton Objected to Ukraine Pressure Campaign, Calling Giuliani ‘a Hand Grenade’
abstract: John R. Bolton, then the national security adviser, ordered an aide to report the machinations by the president’s personal attorney to a White House lawyer, House investigators were told.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The effort to pressure Ukraine for political help provoked a heated confrontation inside the White House last summer that so alarmed John R. Bolton, then the national security adviser, that he told an aide to alert White House lawyers, House investigators were told on Monday.

headline: Trump Followed His Gut on Syria. Calamity Came Fast.
abstract: All the warnings were there. But President Trump’s reliance on his instincts, and his relationships, led him to ignore the consequences of a move that has emboldened Russia, Iran and the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s acquiescence to Turkey’s move to send troops deep inside Syrian territory has in only one week’s time turned into a bloody carnage, forced the abandonment of a successful five-year-long American project to keep the peace on a volatile border, and given an unanticipated victory to four American adversaries: Russia, Iran, the Syrian government and the Islamic State.

headline: Notorious Pedophile Found Dead in U.K. Prison
abstract: Richard Huckle, 33, who may have sexually abused up to 200 children, was said to have been stabbed to death in his cell.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Richard Huckle,  who was serving 22 life sentences after admitting to the sexual abuse of scores of children, was found dead under “suspicious” circumstances in prison, according to the police, who said on Monday that they were investigating.

headline: Violent Video Was Product of Right-Wing Provocateurs and Trump Allies
abstract: The clip underscores how the president’s escalating war on what he calls the “fake news” media has encouraged media-savvy members of the far-right fringe to defend Mr. Trump with extreme language and images.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The creator of a gruesome video that showed a fake President Trump killing journalists and political opponents and that was played at a meeting of a pro-Trump group over the weekend  is part of a loose network of right-wing provocateurs with a direct line to the White House.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: The latest witness in the inquiry, and why so much testimony is happening behind closed doors.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Hill, like other witnesses in the impeachment investigation, testified privately — meaning it will take time to see a verbatim version of what she told investigators, if we see it at all. My colleague Nick Fandos, who was on Capitol Hill today, explained to me why Democrats are doing so much out of public view:

headline: Your New Monday Dinner
abstract: Yewande Komolafe has an amazing new recipe for baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice that may just earn a place on your weekly rotation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The great cook and recipe wunderkind Yewande Komolafe returns to NYT Cooking this week with an amazing new recipe, for baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice (above). I think that ought to be your dinner tonight, and for at least a month or two of Mondays beyond it.

headline: NBC News Hits Back Against Ronan Farrow’s ‘Catch and Kill’ Book
abstract: The president, Noah Oppenheim, in a detailed memo to employees, described the book as a “smear” and a “conspiracy theory.”
lead_paragraph: NBC News pushed back against the investigative journalist Ronan Farrow on Monday, denying his allegations that the network tried to conceal complaints about the former “Today” host Matt Lauer and obstruct Mr. Farrow’s reporting into the film mogul Harvey Weinstein.

headline: You’re Swabbing a Dead Gorilla for Ebola. Then It Gets Worse.
abstract: Carrion flies inside your hood. Sweat turns your gloves into water balloons. This is tough work, but it could predict disease outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: The worst part of sampling a dead gorilla for Ebola, said Dr. William B. Karesh, is the flies.

headline: A Warming Climate Is Changing Sukkot
abstract: In our town, fall weather has always meant the harvest holiday was near. Now, I fear that connection will be lost.
lead_paragraph: There are not many wholly natural things left where I live.

headline: Air Pollution Is Linked to Miscarriages in China, Study Finds
abstract: A new study published on Monday adds to growing evidence of the negative health effects of air pollution on pregnant women and their fetuses.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Researchers in China have found a significant link between air pollution and the risk of miscarriage, according to a new scientific paper released on Monday.

headline: The Case Against Doing Nothing
abstract: Taking a fatalist approach to climate change — or anything else — merely plays into conservative hands.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — If you’re reading this, you’re probably among the Americans who don’t get their news from conservative echo chambers, so you’ve probably made some changes in your habits of late. Chances are you feel pretty good about them. You won’t save the planet all by yourself, or make the country a more equitable place, but, hey, doing something is always better than doing nothing.

headline: Where the ‘Loony Libs’ Are Self-Destructing, Not Trump
abstract: To conservatives in this part of rural Iowa, the president is a beleaguered hero who is always Making America Great Again.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — To understand what many Iowans are thinking about President Trump and the impeachment investigation, first you have to know about Carson King.

headline: What the World Loses if Turkey Destroys the Syrian Kurds
abstract: A radical political experiment is in peril.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2015, the only semiofficial way to enter the Kurdish-controlled areas of northern Syria, referred to by Kurds as Rojava, was by boat across the narrow Tigris River from Iraqi Kurdistan. The boats were small and rusty. Weighed down with migrants and supplies, they moved with the urgency of sunning water buffalo. It was a trip for desperate people — I shared the boat with an elderly couple headed for Islamic State-held areas hoping to save their family home from occupation — taken at a tourist’s pace.

headline: Sulli, South Korean K-Pop Star and Actress, Is Found Dead
abstract: Sulli, 25, was known for being outspoken. She was found in her home on Monday, the authorities said, with no signs of foul play.
lead_paragraph: The actress, singer and former K-pop band member Sulli, 25, was found dead in her home on Monday, the police said.

headline: An 18th-Century Opera, Supercharged for Our Time
abstract: The Paris Opera’s new production of “Les Indes Galantes” has freshness and energy that elude its “La Traviata.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The play that became Verdi’s “La Traviata” was, its composer wrote in 1853, “un soggetto dell’epoca”: a story of our times. He bristled when censors insisted that the setting of the opera, with its inflammatory tale of a high-end prostitute’s death from tuberculosis, be shifted from the present day to a less threatening “circa 1700.”

headline: Fortnite Is Back, Ending Gamers’ Long Nightmare
abstract: After a black hole consumed everything in the game this weekend, the popular game was back online Tuesday, featuring a new map.
lead_paragraph: If you had an inconsolable gamer in your life, here’s why: Fortnite, one of the world’s most popular video games, went quiet.

headline: What to Watch for in the CNN/New York Times Debate
abstract: What time is the Democratic debate and how to watch it? The next Democratic debate, hosted by The Times and CNN, will be held October 15, 2019, at 8 p.m. E.T.
lead_paragraph: What time is the Democratic debate and how to watch it? The next Democratic debate, hosted by The Times and CNN, will be held October 15, 2019, at 8 p.m. E.T.

headline: Inside a Brazen Scheme to Woo China: Gifts, Golf and a $4,254 Wine
abstract: Confidential documents detail Deutsche Bank’s influence campaign and hiring practices in China. More than 100 relatives of top Communist Party officials got jobs.
lead_paragraph: It was a brazen campaign to win business in China by charming and enriching the country’s political elite.

headline: How Deutsche Bank Hired Its Way to the Top in China
abstract: Confidential documents reveal the troubled German bank’s brazen campaign to win business in China by charming and enriching the political elite. Here are six key takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Foreign companies have long clamored for access to China, the world’s most populous country and second-biggest economy. But when Germany’s biggest lender, Deutsche Bank, set its sights on China nearly two decades ago, it was late to the game and faced fierce competition.

headline: Fondue Flavor, but Make It Pie
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi’s love of wine and cheese leads to a pie inspired by fondue parties from long ago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The combination of wine and cheese is one that I particularly cherish. Often, instead of dinner or as a bedtime snack, I see my day off with a glass of Chianti and chunk of Parmesan or mature pecorino. I am obviously not the first to discover the power couple that is wine and cheese, but it works particularly well for me because, after a day of testing recipes, all I want is to tickle my taste buds without overloading my stomach.

headline: John Hodgman on the Two Celebrity Corgis That Shattered His World
abstract: After a decade and a half of semi-fame, the writer and performer thought he had things figured out. Until he met two dogs more famous than he was.
lead_paragraph: The moment I stopped understanding how entertainment worked anymore happened when I was invited to a party in Adam Savage’s secret workshop. Adam Savage used to be a MythBuster on the show “MythBusters,” but his passion has always been prop replication. This means he would take his mythbusting money and funnel it into, say, building a perfect replica of the Maltese falcon from “The Maltese Falcon,” using the actual materials they would have used in 1941 to make actual Maltese falcons. I don’t know what those materials are. Vintage falcon malt, I guess. I don’t know. Ask him.

headline: The Mystery of the Melanistic Manta Rays
abstract: Scientists are trying to work out why some manta rays have black blotches on their skin, which is uncommon in the oceans.
lead_paragraph: Spanning up to 25 feet from wing to wing, manta rays look like U.F.O.'s from below. If you ever get a chance to dive with them, look up. Lights won’t beam down and abduct you, but something about their bellies may surprise you. Most are white, but some are splattered with unique black blotches.

headline: The Many Shades of Wednesday Addams
abstract: With a new “Addams Family” movie in theaters, a look back at the portrayal of one of its most popular family members over the years.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-six years after their last big-screen outing, the Addams Family is back in theaters. And yes, still creepy, kooky, mysterious and spooky (now also digitally animated). The family, created by the cartoonist Charles Addams, has been featured across magazines, films, television and a stage musical over the last 80 years, but no character has been portrayed quite as differently as the daughter, Wednesday — from a cherubic little girl in the 1960s to a stern and frightening adolescent in the 1990s to a lovesick teenager in the 2010s. Here’s a closer look at how Wednesday has been depicted in many variations by those writing, drawing and playing her.

headline: Fort Worth Officer Charged With Murder for Shooting Woman in Her Home
abstract: Aaron Dean, who killed Atatiana Jefferson while she was home with her nephew, resigned hours before he was going to be fired.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — A former Fort Worth police officer who fatally shot a woman while she was at home playing video games over the weekend was arrested and charged with murder on Monday, the latest development in a case that has sparked national outrage and renewed demands for police accountability.

headline: K-Pop Group SuperM Takes a Rare Path to No. 1: CD Sales
abstract: The boy band’s “The 1st Mini Album ‘SuperM’” arrived with packaging variations and bundles, resulting in a strong debut sales week, but modest streaming numbers.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, music fans bought hundreds of millions of CDs each year, fueling lavish industry profits. Nowadays, with streaming the dominant format — but with each click bringing infinitesimal royalties — artists and their record companies must come up with all sorts of gimmicks to sell those gleaming plastic discs, which can help boost an album’s position on the weekly Billboard chart.

headline: Epstein Estate’s First Legal Bill in Fight Against Accusers: $90,000
abstract: The financier Jeffrey Epstein died two months ago while awaiting trial on sex-trafficking charges, and the court actions involving his estate are getting into gear.
lead_paragraph: The federal criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein ended with his death two months ago, but the legal battles by his estate are poised to go on for months to come.

headline: Tossing and Catching Rhythms on Stages and City Streets
abstract: Jumatatu M. Poe and Jermone Donte Beacham share their 10-year exploration of J-Sette, a call-and-response dance form.
lead_paragraph: One day about 10 years ago, the dancer Jermone Donte Beacham received a message from a stranger on YouTube. He ignored it, but the stranger kept trying to contact him. Finally he decided to write back.

headline: ‘The Pout-Pout Fish’ Review: A Grouch Gets Back in the Swim
abstract: TheaterWorksUSA has brought a best-selling children’s book series to the stage in a bubbly, puppet-filled musical.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows a pouter or two. But even if those individuals are cold fish, they probably aren’t the kind that lives in the sea.

headline: House Tour | Nayland Blake
abstract: The artist and collector Nayland Blake invites T into their Brooklyn home.
lead_paragraph: The artist and collector Nayland Blake invites T into their Brooklyn home.

headline: An Artist’s Personal Museum in Brooklyn
abstract: Nayland Blake’s one-bedroom apartment is filled from floor to ceiling with personal treasures and works by their community of queer artists.
lead_paragraph: When Nayland Blake’s ever-expanding vinyl collection threatened to take over their railroad-style one-bedroom apartment in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn, the artist and educator, who uses “they” and “them” pronouns, transformed the 2,500 or so records into an immersive installation. Blake, whose work explores the fluidity of race and gender, has long been an accumulator as much as a creator. The resulting multimedia assemblage, “Ruins of a Sensibility 1972-2002,” is currently installed at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles within the exhibition “No Wrong Holes,” the largest survey of the artist’s three-decade career to date, where it functions as an interactive self-portrait of sorts. There is a D.J. booth where visitors can sign up to play records from the collection, including rare albums from the likes of the Afrofuturist Sun Ra Arkestra.

headline: ‘The White Chip’ Review: Day-Drunk and Careening Toward Rock Bottom
abstract: In Sean Daniels’s grim autobiographical comedy, a charming stage director tries, and tries again, to sober up.
lead_paragraph: It’s the alcohol that almost kills him, but the charisma doesn’t help. Steven, the high-functioning, hard-core alcoholic at the center of Sean Daniels’s harrowing comedy “The White Chip,” is the kind of guy whose abundant scruffy charm allows him to get away with far too much.

headline: Hey, Look! Nonna and Her Pasta Are on YouTube
abstract: A filmmaker is trying to preserve the art of handmade pasta by turning Italy’s Pasta Grannies into video stars.
lead_paragraph: Vicky Bennison, a 60-year-old British woman with a background in international development, never intended Pasta Grannies to become a minor YouTube hit or to make stars of a handful of Italian nonnas who couldn’t care less about their influencer status.

headline: Former Georgia Officer Who Killed a Black Man Is Convicted, but Not of Murder
abstract: The former officer, Robert Olsen, was acquitted of murder charges, but was found guilty on lesser counts after the fatal shooting of Anthony Hill, an unarmed Air Force veteran.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — A former Georgia police officer was convicted on Monday in connection with the shooting death of an unarmed black man whom the officer had found wandering naked outside an apartment complex in 2015.

headline: Fired for Being Pregnant? It Can Still Happen
abstract: Readers react to Senator Elizabeth Warren’s account of the loss of a teaching job in 1971 because she was pregnant.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ohio Was Set to Purge 235,000 Voters. It Was Wrong About 20%.
abstract: When Ohio released a list of people it planned to strike from its voting rolls, around 40,000 people shouldn’t have been on it. The state only found out because of volunteer sleuthing.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The clock was ticking for Jen Miller.

headline: The Violent Trump Video Is Dumb, and That’s the Point
abstract: The absurdity of memes like the one shared widely on Sunday evening gives cover to their creators.
lead_paragraph: A good rule of thumb for politics in 2019 is that everything is both far darker and far more ridiculous than our imaginations can ever predict.

headline: For Sondheim, Raúl Esparza Protects His Voice. For ‘Seared,’ His Fingers.
abstract: The actor, best known for “Company” and “Law & Order,” cooks, chops and sautés onstage as a finicky chef in Theresa Rebeck’s play.
lead_paragraph: Wherever Raúl Esparza goes, it seems, people expect him to sing “Being Alive,” the heart-rending Stephen Sondheim ballad from “Company,” for which he earned a lead actor Tony Award nomination in 2007.

headline: Is the Trump Impeachment Saga Kavanaugh 2.0? Some Republicans Hope So
abstract: Republicans who cast the impeachment inquiry as yet another partisan character assassination may find it difficult to rally the same kind of unified support that helped Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of President Trump’s most relentless defenders are expressing a sense of déjà vu over the impeachment inquiry currently underway.

headline: Rolling Loud Brings Melting Rap Songs and Moshing Crowds to New York
abstract: The touring multiday rap festival arrived at Citi Field with a vision of the genre that’s no longer rooted in the city.
lead_paragraph: Playboi Carti — slender as a string bean, flexible as a yogi, his dreads dyed almost the same beige as his cropped jacket — bounded onto the main stage at the Rolling Loud festival Saturday night to rile up his faithful. Carti is an impressionist rapper, slurring together syllables and murmurs into cloudy chant-along mantras. But onstage, he was a dynamo — jumping wildly, curling his body into a parabola as he shouted to the sky, and inciting his tens of thousands of fans to mosh.

headline: Democratic Candidates Need to Listen to These Voters
abstract: Undecided voters in Ohio are focused on urgent bread-and-butter issues.
lead_paragraph: A dozen candidates for the Democratic presidential primary will debate on Tuesday in Westerville, Ohio. They will go back and forth on whether policies should be centrist or progressive and how much to talk about President Trump in an effort to balance appeals to primary voters now and a broader coalition later.

headline: Message of Unity Is Resonating for Argentines
abstract: In the midst of a deep economic recession, the front-runner for the presidency has little relief to offer except to reunite a sharply polarized society.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Street nomenclature can be a subtle way of expressing political loyalties here. A small street near the Argentine congress is officially named Presidente Teniente General Juan Domingo Perón, after the late populist leader. But his die-hard opponents insist on using its former name, Cangallo, a quiet refusal to honor the man they blame for ruining the country.

headline: One Environmentalist’s Warning: Think Globally, Act Accordingly
abstract: In “Erosion,” Terry Tempest Williams delivers a clarion call for decency, humanity and preservation.
lead_paragraph: EROSIONEssays of UndoingBy Terry Tempest Williams

headline: For ‘Erin Brockovich’ Fans, a David vs. Goliath Tale With a Twist
abstract: Robert Bilott was a corporate defense lawyer when a stranger shared a theory about why his cows were dying. “Exposure” is his story of what happened next.
lead_paragraph: EXPOSUREPoisoned Water, Corporate Greed, and One Lawyer’s Twenty-Year Battle Against DuPontBy Robert Bilott with Tom Shroder

headline: At New York City Ballet, the Good, the Bad and the Ruby
abstract: Our critic highlights important partnerships and debuts of the season. The crown jewel? Mira Nadon in “Rubies.”
lead_paragraph: Didn’t New York City Ballet’s fall season, which ended Sunday, feel like a whirlwind? As the company passes the baton over to American Ballet Theater — the David H. Koch Theater is home to both companies this fall — it’s a good time to take stock of what left an imprint. The happiest sight was the debut of Mira Nadon in George Balanchine’s “Rubies.” The most distressing was the return of Marc Happel’s costumes for Balanchine’s “Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2” (1941).

headline: Uber’s Layoff Total Rises Past 1,000 With Latest Cuts
abstract: A third round targeted 350 workers on Monday as the company struggles to reduce costs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber laid off 350 employees on Monday, in the latest indication that the ride-hailing company is trying to respond to concerns among investors that it is losing too much money.

headline: Harold Bloom, Critic Who Championed Western Canon, Dies at 89
abstract: Called the most notorious literary critic in America, Professor Bloom argued for the superiority of giants like Shakespeare, Chaucer and Kafka.

headline: Stay Close
abstract: One man’s unlikely path to fencing glory.
lead_paragraph: One man’s unlikely path to fencing glory.

headline: How Climate Change Impacts Wine
abstract: The accelerating effects of climate change have forced the wine industry to take decisive steps to counter or adapt to the shifts.
lead_paragraph: The accelerating effects of climate change have forced the wine industry to take decisive steps to counter or adapt to the shifts.

headline: Stay Close
abstract: One man’s unlikely path to Olympic glory.
lead_paragraph: “Stay Close” is one of 10 films shortlisted for the 92nd Academy Awards in the Documentary Short Subject category.

headline: Deutsche Bank, Syria, Britain: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Deutsche Bank's brazen China campaign.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Queen Speaks, but Is Overshadowed by Brexit
abstract: By tradition, the queen’s speech is when the governing party lays out its legislative agenda. But Parliament is preoccupied with other matters just now.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II formally opened Parliament on Monday and promptly found herself in the thick of Britain’s roiling Brexit drama, setting out a legislative agenda for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government that began with his vow to leave the European Union by the end of this month.

headline: L.S.U., Known for Defense, Riding Offense for Title Hopes
abstract: The Tigers, with the best scoring offense in the game, leapfrogged Ohio State and Clemson to No. 2 in the country after an impressive dismantling of Florida.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — When the quarterback Joe Burrow visited Louisiana State in the spring of 2018 as he considered where to transfer from Ohio State, he came well prepared. His mother, Robin, met with an academic adviser to map out a graduate studies program, while Burrow visited with the Tigers coach, Ed Orgeron, and two offensive assistants.
