Burrow brought along his father, Jimmy, a 30-year college coach, and an older brother, Dan, who like their father played at Nebraska.

headline: California Tells Schools to Start Later, Giving Teenagers More Sleep
abstract: A new law pushed back start times at most public middle and high schools, citing research that says attendance and performance will improve if teenagers get more sleep.
lead_paragraph: California students can look forward to extra sleep in the morning once a new law takes effect.

headline: Rx for Doctors: Stop With the Urine Tests
abstract: The tests often are positive in people without symptoms, particularly older patients. The result: overtreatment with antibiotics.
lead_paragraph: It’s such a common routine in a doctor’s office or clinic or hospital that patients tend to comply without thinking: Step on the scale, roll up your sleeve for the blood pressure cuff, urinate into a cup.

headline: America’s Biggest Sports Rivalries? You Might Be Surprised
abstract: Which rivalries are most intense? Can a team have more than one rival? What if the hatred isn’t returned? Two professors wanted answers.
lead_paragraph: When the Eagles face the Cowboys on Sunday and the Patriots face the Jets on Monday night, two fierce N.F.L. rivalries will be renewed. But where do they rank among all the bitter rivalries in North American sports?

headline: Kurds’ Feelings of Betrayal by the U.S.
abstract: Readers discuss possible reasons behind the president’s abandonment of the Kurds and the consequences of that action.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The New Makers of Plant-Based Meat? Big Meat Companies
abstract: Tyson, Smithfield, Perdue and Hormel have all rolled out meat alternatives, filling supermarket shelves with an array of plant-based burgers, meatballs and chicken nuggets.
lead_paragraph: Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods, scrappy start-ups that share a penchant for superlatives and a commitment to protecting the environment, have dominated the relatively new market for vegetarian food that looks and tastes like meat.

headline: Who Are the Kurds, and Why Is Turkey Attacking Them in Syria?
abstract: Why did Turkey invade? Why did America leave? How did the Kurds gain so much land? We answer 10 key questions about the Turkish invasion of northern Syria.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish invasion of Kurdish-held territory in northern Syria has complicated an already chaotic war.

headline: 14 Police Officers Killed in an Ambush in Mexico
abstract: The attack, in an area drug gangs have battled over for decades, is a reminder of the challenges facing the president, who may end his first year with a record number of killings.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Gunmen killed 14 police officers Monday after ambushing a convoy, federal officials said, in a bloody setback to the Mexican government’s efforts to curb the country’s spiraling violence.

headline: It All Started in Omaha
abstract: In “Rusty Brown,” Chris Ware spans lives, generations and even universes. But somehow all roads lead back to Nebraska, where he grew up.
lead_paragraph: For the graphic novelist Chris Ware, God is in the details. In 2004, he edited a special comics issue of McSweeney’s Quarterly, and as with his own titles, even the unfoldable dust jacket teemed with extra texts and gags. Here, on what normally functions as decoration, Ware concealed a story in which God wonders what happened to “that planet where I made everyone in my own image. Drolly rendered as a stack of colored circles with stringlike limbs, the supreme creator goes on to muse that Earth had some good things — including comic strips — which leads him to pity the sad lives of the slobs who drew them: “I wonder why other people couldn’t see the virtues of an innately democratic pictographic poetry, grounded in a transdimensional metaphysic, anyway?”

headline: Margaret Atwood and Bernardine Evaristo Share Booker Prize
abstract: The judges rebelled against the literary prize’s rules and awarded it to “The Testaments” and “Girl, Woman, Other.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Margaret Atwood and Bernardine Evaristo have both won this year’s Booker Prize, it was announced at a ceremony on Monday, after the judges for the literary award rebelled against its rules.

headline: Russia Savors U.S. Missteps in Syria, and Seizes Opportunity
abstract: President Trump’s erratic moves are letting Russia seize the role of peacemaker — and deal-maker — in Syria.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — These have been disastrous weeks for American foreign policy, a popular presenter on Russia’s state television told viewers on Sunday night with an I-told-you-so smirk.

headline: Trump Imposes Sanctions on Turkey as Syria Conflict Intensifies
abstract: President Trump also said he was doubling tariffs on imports of Turkish steel in response to Turkey’s incursion into Syria, an invasion for which he himself had cleared the way for.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Monday that he was imposing sanctions on Turkish government agencies and officials in response to Turkey’s incursion into Syria, an invasion that he himself had cleared the way for by withdrawing American troops.

headline: John Giorno on His Most Precious Possession
abstract: The artist, poet and activist, who died on Friday at 82, spoke to T last week about a Buddhist statue he kept at his home in New York.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. Here, the artist, poet and activist John Giorno, who spoke to Spivack several days before he died on Friday at 82, describes a Buddhist statue that sits in a shrine in his New York City home on the Bowery, where he had lived since 1962.

headline: Indigenous Peoples’ Day: The Unofficial, Columbus-Free Celebration
abstract: No governor. No mayor. But plenty of activism, food, dancing and fun in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Roughly five miles from the nation’s largest Christopher Columbus celebration, hundreds gathered Sunday and Monday on Randalls Island to celebrate indigenous people at an event that has become part of a larger conversation about how New York City should honor controversial historical figures.

headline: Failed Notre-Dame Plot Leads to Shame, Regret and Heavy Sentences
abstract: The trial has shed new light on the role of women in homegrown terrorism in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The two women sat side by side in the courtroom over the past three weeks, each blaming the other for what they had done, and both expressing shame and regret over what they had become: “The face of female jihad” in France, according to a state prosecutor.

headline: Assad Forces Surge Forward in Syria as U.S. Pulls Back
abstract: Syrian government forces streamed into the country’s northeast, filling a vacuum opened up by President Trump’s decision to pull back in Syria.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Syrian government forces streamed into the country’s northeast on Monday, seizing towns where they had not set foot in years and filling a vacuum opened up by President Trump’s decision to abandon the United States’ Syrian Kurdish allies.

headline: ‘Succession’: Jesse Armstrong on the Season Finale’s Stunning Twist
abstract: The Emmy-winning creator discussed when he knew how the season would end and his response to early critics who called the characters unsympathetic.
lead_paragraph: This article contains plot details about the second season of “Succession.”

headline: The California Fur Ban and What It Means for You
abstract: Is this the beginning of the end of the mink coat? Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: So California has become the first state to ban fur. This sounds draconian. What does that actually mean?

headline: AMC Theater Chain Gets Into Streaming With On-Demand Movies
abstract: AMC Entertainment dominates the cineplex business. Now it also wants to be a major player in home viewing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a sign of just how much streaming is changing Hollywood, movie fans will soon be able to rent and buy films for viewing at home — from a movie theater chain.

headline: Can Joe Biden Deliver the Debate Performance He Needs?
abstract: Mr. Biden in recent days has been more forceful in defending his family and denouncing the president. Some voters and Democratic officials think he should do more.
lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — In the last few days, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has unveiled a new government ethics plan and vowed that his family members would do no business overseas during a Biden presidency. His son, Hunter Biden, said he would step down from his role with a Chinese investment firm, and sat for his first television interview of the campaign. And in Iowa, the elder Mr. Biden delivered a fist-pounding diatribe against President Trump, casting him as the embodiment of public corruption.

headline: Syria, Fiona Hill, Trump Video: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Russian Doping Chief Says Thousands of Drug Tests Were Manipulated
abstract: An admission by the top Russian antidoping official could complicate his country’s bid to avoid severe penalties from the World Anti-Doping Agency.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Russia made thousands of changes to the drug-test results of an unspecified number of its athletes, the head of the country’s own antidoping agency said this week, confirming the suspicions of global officials who are considering severe penalties against Russian sports programs.

headline: 3 Books to Read by Indigenous Writers
abstract: Tommy Orange, the award-winning author of “There, There,” recommends his favorite books by Native writers.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several years, states and cities across the United States have been adopting Indigenous Peoples’ Day, in some cases making a point to celebrate it instead of Columbus Day on the same day. (Hundreds of people gathered on New York City’s Randalls Island Sunday and Monday, although the city hasn’t formally designated it as a replacement for Columbus Day.)

headline: God Is Now Trump’s Co-Conspirator
abstract: Bigotry, both racial and religious, is the last refuge of a scoundrel.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the speech William Barr, the attorney general, gave last week at the University of Notre Dame Law School, I found myself thinking of the title of an old movie: “God Is My Co-Pilot.” What I realized is that Donald Trump’s minions have now gone that title one better: If Barr’s speech is any indication, their strategy is to make God their boss’s co-conspirator.

headline: You’re Invited to This Questlove Party
abstract: In his new cookbook, “Mixtape Potluck,” the musician shares recipes from some of his celebrity friends.
lead_paragraph: The multifaceted career of Questlove (Ahmir Thompson), the musician and entertainer, includes food salons, where chefs cook for high-profile guests. With his new book “Mixtape Potluck,” he has turned things around and has guests do the cooking. Recipes, usually enough to feed a dozen or more, have been contributed by 57 of his friends. Zooey Deschanel’s bok choy and cucumber salad, JJ Johnson’s sticky ribs, Lilly Singh’s mother’s chicken curry, Eric Ripert’s salmon rillettes, Shep Gordon’s Maui onion and ginger soup, and Natalie Portman’s Greek spinach pie, using phyllo like a pie crust, are some worth serving. He has created a list of songs, inspired by the various contributors, for the cook to play while preparing each dish. Prince’s “Joint 2 Joint” is a suggestion for Ms. Deschanel. Questlove also shares party-hosting advice.

headline: The Wild World of Natural Wine
abstract: The Wild World Fermentation Festival lands in Brooklyn with wines, ciders and beer from more than 50 producers.
lead_paragraph: The trial run for Wild World Fermentation Festival, a natural wine fair, took place last spring in Austin, Texas. Success of the fair, which also featured wild-fermented ciders and beers, has led to a repeat in Brooklyn on Oct. 28. In addition to samples of wines, beers and ciders from more than 50 producers, there will be some fermented foods, talks and panel discussions.

headline: Cook Dinner Like a Warrior
abstract: These new oven mitts from the Metropolitan Museum of Art look like the armor of a 16th-century duke.
lead_paragraph: Arm yourself as you light the grill, pull a sheet-pan dinner from the oven or baste the Thanksgiving turkey in its roasting pan with these amusing oven mitts. They’re printed with images of steel and gilded gauntlets of the 16th-century Duke of Saxe-Weimar, as displayed in the new exhibition “The Last Knight: The Art, Armor and Ambition of Maximilian I” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Kee’s Chocolates Opens a Shop on the Upper West Side
abstract: After shuttering its garment district shop, the chocolate company has a sliver of a storefront uptown.
lead_paragraph: Kee Ling Tong, who started her chocolate company in SoHo in 2002, is now selling her treats from a sliver of a storefront on the Upper West Side. These include her lovely handmade bonbons; sleek dark and milk chocolate bars with flavorings like almonds, bergamot, jasmine and hibiscus; and nut-studded bark and macarons. She has closed her shop in the garment district, but she still has an outlet in the HSBC Bank at 452 Fifth Avenue (40th Street).

headline: Pumpkin Seeds, Made in America
abstract: Stony Brook WholeHeartedFoods and Autumn Seed sell their pumpkin seeds to a variety of specialty food purveyors.
lead_paragraph: Those pumpkin seeds you might buy to nibble, use in cooking or mix into granola probably come from China, the world’s largest producer of pumpkins. Two American producers of pumpkin seeds — Stony Brook WholeHeartedFoods in Geneva, N.Y., and Autumn Seed in Corvallis, Ore. — estimate that at least 75 percent of the seeds sold in the United States are imported from China, where cheap labor for hulling the seeds keeps the price well below what American producers charge.

headline: Faced With a Drug Shortfall, Doctors Scramble to Treat Children With Cancer
abstract: A critical chemotherapy medication is in short supply, and physicians say there is no appropriate substitute.
lead_paragraph: A critical drug that serves as the backbone of treatment for most childhood cancers, including leukemias, lymphomas and brain tumors, has become increasingly scarce, and doctors are warning that they may soon be forced to consider rationing doses.

headline: Democratic Debate Preview: The ‘On Politics’ Guide
abstract: There are bound to be some fireworks at the CNN/New York Times debate. Here’s what we’ll be watching Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox.

headline: Americans Will Pay a Price for State Privacy Laws
abstract: The modern data economy is too big to regulate at the state level.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has yet to act, and states are rushing to pass their own data privacy legislation, creating a patchwork of laws from coast to coast. Many of these laws are well-meaning, but their proliferation creates a real risk and a real cost.

headline: In Ecuador and Beyond, Indigenous Groups Are Fighting to Be Seen
abstract: We spoke to a New York-based activist about the movement for indigenous rights throughout the Americas.
lead_paragraph: El Espace is a column dedicated to news and culture relevant to Latinx communities. Expect politics, arts, analysis, personal essays and more. ¿Lo mejor? It’ll be in Spanish and English, so you can forward it to your tía, your primo Lalo or anyone else (read: everyone).

headline: Ukraine Has Become a Vibrant Democracy. No Wonder Trump Hates It.
abstract: As America joins the axis of autocrats, Ukrainians fear being left alone to face Russia.
lead_paragraph: When the Ukrainian autocrat Viktor Yanukovych fled to Russia after a popular uprising in 2014, thousands of citizens poured into Mezhyhirya, his 340-acre estate on the outskirts of Kiev.

headline: For Yankees, Extended Game 2 Showed Limits of Their Bullpen
abstract: Unlike the Astros and their workhorse starters, the Yankees are leaning heavily on relievers — a strategy that was tested as their second A.L.C.S. game went to extra innings.
lead_paragraph: Before Carlos Correa even stepped to the plate in the bottom of the 11th inning to clobber his walk-off homer to end Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, the Houston Astros had already gained an upper hand. By taking advantage of Yankees starter James Paxton’s uneven command and forcing his early exit on Sunday, the Astros triggered a chain of events that eventually led to the decisive J.A. Happ-Correa matchup.

headline: ABC Apologizes for Showing Video From U.S. Gun Range in Report on Syria
abstract: The video appeared in a report on Turkish attacks in northern Syria. ABC News did not specify how the error had occurred.
lead_paragraph: ABC News apologized Monday for mistakenly running a video that apparently was taken at a gun range in Kentucky with a report about Turkish attacks in northern Syria.

headline: Trump Just Created a Moral and Strategic Disaster
abstract: As desperate Kurds ally with Assad in Syria, the specter of the Islamic State threatens again, and American power dims.
lead_paragraph: The roughly 1,000 American troops stationed in Syria find themselves in an impossible situation, by order of their commander in chief. They are now caught between the Syrian forces of President Bashar al-Assad, an unrepentant war criminal who has used poison gas against his own people, and the Turkish military — a NATO ally — which has already rained down artillery shells near positions held by American soldiers.

headline: 12 Things to Know About Ohio Before 12 Candidates Debate There
abstract: The 2020 Democratic hopefuls will debate in a state that has voted for the winning presidential candidate every time since 1944, with one exception.
lead_paragraph: As the 2020 Democratic candidates descend Tuesday on Westerville, Ohio, a northern suburb of Columbus, for the fourth presidential debate, here are 12 fast facts about politics and the economy in the Buckeye State that could help shape the upcoming election.

headline: Holder of the Contents
abstract: Julie Bérubé tells us a very old story.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Spoiler alert: I’m going to talk about the theme of Julie Bérubé’s puzzle up front, because I want to make what I believe is an important point about solving.

headline: He Acquitted 5 Men of Murder, Then Shot Himself
abstract: A judge’s dramatic act drew attention to his accusations that he was being pressured to unfairly convict five Muslims in Thailand’s insurgency-plagued south.
lead_paragraph: YALA, Thailand — The Thai judge’s verdict was not guilty, five men spared the death penalty or life imprisonment. Then the judge reached into his robes, pulled out a gun and shot himself in the courtroom.

headline: California Man Drives Body to Police and Admits to Killing 3 Others, Authorities Say
abstract: “I have never had someone come in with a body and turn themselves in here,” Sgt. Robert Gibson of the Mount Shasta Police Department said.
lead_paragraph: A man drove up to a police station in a small town in Northern California on Monday and told officers that he had killed four of his relatives — including one person whose body was in the car just outside, the authorities said.

headline: WeWork Warns Tenants That 2,300 Phone Booths May Be a Hazard
abstract: The booths could have high levels of formaldehyde, said the company, which is coping with a failed I.P.O. and a corporate shake-up.
lead_paragraph: WeWork, the shared-office company already coping with a failed public offering and a corporate shake-up, disclosed a new problem on Monday: possible formaldehyde contamination of hundreds of phone booths at some of the buildings it leases.

headline: After Daryl Morey Tweet Backlash, LeBron James Says Executive Was Misinformed on China
abstract: The Lakers star said the Houston Rockets executive could have endangered traveling players with his pro-Hong Kong tweet. The comments prompted widespread backlash, including from protesters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — LeBron James on Monday night sharply criticized Daryl Morey, the general manager of the Houston Rockets, for his recent tweet in support of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy protesters. The tweet set off a furor for the N.B.A. last week while James and the Los Angeles Lakers were in China.

headline: Nationals Bowl Over the Cardinals Again in the N.L.C.S.
abstract: Washington won Game 3 to pull within one victory of its first National League pennant and a trip to the World Series.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first League Championship Series game held in Washington, D.C. was a party for most of the 43,675 fans who attended on Monday night. The second one could be a long-awaited coronation.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Arrow’ and ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’
abstract: The Green Arrow prepares to hang up his bow in his series’s final season, and John Cameron Mitchell struts his stuff in “Hedwig.”
lead_paragraph: ARROW 9 p.m. on the CW. This superhero saga based on DC Comics’ hooded vigilante archer, Green Arrow, debuted back in 2012, and has since spawned an entire shared universe of shows centered on other DC heroes like “The Flash” and “Batwoman.” The ability to tell crossover stories is just one aspect of this series’s success. To keep longtime fans happy, “the episodes are peppered with references from the comic books — adversaries with names like Deathstroke and Count Vertigo — but not so many as to confuse viewers who might not know the source material,” Joe Rhodes wrote in The New York Times. But the time has come for Oliver Queen (Stephen Amell) to hang up his bow. As the show enters its eighth and final season, Queen has left his home of Star City to protect the multiverse from impending crisis.

abstract: This term has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Kickstarter Calls Itself Progressive. But About That Union.
abstract: A contentious organizing drive at the Brooklyn tech company has drawn in high-profile figures like the actor David Cross, the author Neil Gaiman and the cartoonist Matt Bors.
lead_paragraph: Kickstarter, the Brooklyn-based crowdfunding site, has long tried to stand apart from Silicon Valley, seeking to portray itself as a socially responsible enterprise that cares more about improving the world than putting money in wealthy shareholders’ pockets.

headline: Fukushima, Beaten Down by Nuclear Disaster, Takes Big Typhoon Hit
abstract: Some facilities that had been damaged in 2011 were hit again over the weekend in a region of Japan that can never seem to catch a break.
lead_paragraph: KORIYAMA, Japan — For Hiroyoshi Yaginuma, the typhoon may well be the straw that breaks his back.

headline: Trump Is the ‘Gollum of Presidents,’ Trevor Noah Says
abstract: The president’s evolving position on Rudy Giuliani reminded Noah of a “Lord of the Rings” character: “We haven’t spoken to Rudies. We speak to Rudies all the time!”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

abstract: In this lesson, students learn about this victory, the preparation that led to it, as well as what makes it complicated in the eyes of marathon officials.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Eliud Kipchoge Breaks Two-Hour Marathon Barrier”

headline: Peter Jackson Has a Lot of Power in New Zealand. Some Say Too Much.
abstract: The filmmaker’s intervention in a  mayoral race, part of an effort to block a housing plan, was unheard-of in a country where money and fame are usually wielded lightly.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Peter Jackson, the film director behind the “Lord of the Rings” series, is a towering figure in his native New Zealand, admired as both a down-to-earth titan of the box office and a one-man income generator for the country’s moviemaking and tourism industries.

headline: How Myanmar Covered Up Ethnic Cleansing
abstract: Officials insist the persecution of Rohingya Muslims never happened. Our correspondent visited Rakhine State and found a different story.
lead_paragraph: Officials insist the persecution of Rohingya Muslims never happened. Our correspondent visited Rakhine State and found a different story.

headline: Can I Quit Trying to Teach Ethics to Ill-Behaved Children?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to keep doing volunteer work you promised to do but aren’t good at and more.
lead_paragraph: I volunteer at my child’s elementary school teaching ethics once a week. In my public-school system in Australia, parents can opt for ethics classes for their children instead of religious instruction from volunteers of various faiths; parents can also choose “nonscripture,” a class period during which a child does his or her homework. Ethics teachers follow a set script, approved by the department of education, and cannot depart from it. The job of the ethics teacher is to facilitate discussion and encourage the children to disagree and listen respectfully.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Souvenir Photo Viewers
abstract: Immerse yourself in a memory from a simpler, pre-Instagram time.
lead_paragraph: This past spring, I spent two months subletting an apartment in Amsterdam, where tourists not infrequently outnumber residents. The day I arrived, I was struck by how many American accents I heard and how many selfie sticks jutted out onto the narrow sidewalks near the canals in the Nine Streets. Nothing made tourists more visible than their fervent Instagramming and ever-present iPhones. Jogging in the Vondelpark, I saw a tourist crash a bike while videoblogging. From a hotel lobby on Keizersgracht, I watched someone climb onto a locked bike near the canal, take a photo on it and then go about her afternoon. Ask a local about the tourism in Amsterdam, and you’re likely to receive an eye roll and a comment about how it’s “out of control,” as one cafe owner told me during my first week there. Last year, the city attracted almost 20 million visitors, but there are fewer than one million residents. In December, locals became so frustrated by tourist congestion that the city removed the “I amsterdam” sign near the Rijksmuseum, which reportedly generated upward of 6,000 photographs per day. Many of these photos very likely ended up on Instagram, where the hashtag #iamsterdam has been used 1.54 million times and counting.

headline: Have You Ever Encountered Racist or Extremist Content Online?

lead_paragraph: Have you noticed when YouTube suggested videos that promoted a certain ideology? Have you ever encountered racist or extremist content online? Did you ever feel that someone or some group on the internet was trying to persuade you to believe a certain way?

abstract: Lycopene, a red plant pigment found in tomatoes, watermelons and pink grapefruits, improved some measures of sperm quality.

headline: New & Noteworthy Poetry, From Yale to Nick Flynn and More
abstract: A selection of recent poetry books; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: FIRSTS: 100 Years of Yale Younger Poets, edited by Carl Phillips. (Yale University, $35.) After a fitful first decade, the Yale prize began anointing major American talents: Joan Murray, Adrienne Rich, W. S. Merwin, John Ashbery. This book gathers work from each winner.

abstract: Deborah Levy’s latest novel, “The Man Who Saw Everything,” experiments with time travel, history and the endless complications of love.
lead_paragraph: THE MAN WHO SAW EVERYTHING By Deborah Levy

abstract: The narrator of Edna O’Brien’s novel “Girl” is kidnapped by jihadi fighters in northeastern Nigeria. She returns home bearing a jihadi’s child.

headline: The Journalist vs. the President, With Life on the Line
abstract: Maria Ressa, editor of a popular news site in the Philippines, has incurred President Duterte and his supporters’ wrath by investigating his extrajudicial killing campaign.
lead_paragraph: Early in the afternoon of May 7, Maria Ressa sat before a couple of hundred people in the lobby of Palma Hall, the dilapidated social-sciences and philosophy building at the University of the Philippines in Quezon City, just north of Manila. The attendees, many of them students, had packed themselves shoulder to shoulder on yellow chairs; hand-held fans stirred the torpid air as a drizzle fell on the palm trees in the courtyard. It was six days before the Philippines’ midterm elections, and the country’s usual mix of soap-opera politics and melodramatic conspiracy theories had reached a new intensity.

abstract: Ashley Wurzbacher’s debut, “Happy Like This,” is among this fall’s standout story collections.

headline: Improve Your Bedtime Routine With These Five Luxurious Tips
abstract: I don’t know who needs to hear this but stop scrolling on Instagram at night and start meditating.
lead_paragraph: When my better angels are in charge of my schedule — instead of the insatiable gremlin that won’t get off Instagram — I end the day by starting my bedtime routine: lighting candles; eating early, (three-ish hours before going to sleep, in a knockoff version of intermittent fasting, it makes for better digestion and for me, fewer nightmares); molting daytime clothes and obligations (no screens, so no social media, no texting, no email), and then floating around for 20 minutes of Vedic meditation; some at-home hypnotherapy; a little journaling; reading a book that asks nothing of me; and listing five “happinesses,” just some small things that I want to keep close.

headline: 5 Tips for Keeping It Together as a Digital Nomad
abstract: Sure, being able to work remotely and travel nonstop is a blast. But it’s not without downtime and difficult moments.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last five years I’ve lived as a digital nomad, working while traveling for months at a time across dozens of countries and five continents. For the most part, this is as fun as it sounds. It isn’t, however, an unbroken chain of big beach umbrellas, little drink umbrellas and a few scattered minutes spent working. You have the occasional bad day. Working in a humid hostel with dial-up internet speeds, worrying about deadlines and that meeting scheduled for 4 a.m. can take the glamour out of it all.

headline: It Had the Biggest Antlers Ever Found. Were They Weapons?
abstract: Scientists devised “virtual crash testing” to see if an extinct deer’s colossal headgear was just for show.
lead_paragraph: The antlers of the prehistoric deer Megaloceros giganteus inspire awe and bemusement in equal measure. They were the largest the world has ever known — up to 12 feet wide and five feet high — atop the head of a creature otherwise no taller than a modern moose.

headline: She Warned a School About Her Armed Son, but Now She Faces Charges
abstract: Prosecutors said Mary York prematurely removed her son from a mental health facility and did not report that he had fired a gun in their home before a standoff at a school ended in his suicide.
lead_paragraph: An Indiana woman who called the police in December and told them that her 14-year-old son had threatened to shoot up his former school will face criminal charges if prosecutors have their way.

headline: CBD or THC? Common Drug Test Can’t Tell the Difference
abstract: Those cannabidiol-laced gummy bears may be entirely legal, but they could still get you arrested on marijuana possession charges.
lead_paragraph: In June of 2018, Mark Pennington received troubling news from his ex-girlfriend, with whom he shared custody of their 2-year-old son. She had taken a hair follicle from the boy, she said, and had it analyzed at a lab. A drug test had returned positive for THC, the intoxicating compound in marijuana; evidently their son had been exposed to it, presumably in Mr. Pennington’s presence. He was told that, from then on, he would be permitted to see the child only once a week, and under supervision.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth’s Private Stage
abstract: The Broadway and TV star’s decorating style? Art Deco meets Hollywood Regency, with a bit of the 1960s thrown in.
lead_paragraph: For a dozen years, the Tony and Emmy Award-winning actress and singer Kristin Chenoweth lived just off the Hudson River on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Hard by a pier, the location was grand in the summer, but left something to be desired in the winter. The winds were such that every time the petite Ms. Chenoweth ventured outdoors she was just one stiff gust away from making like Mary Poppins.
