headline: In Democratic Fund-Raising, Joe Biden Falls Far Behind
abstract: In the past three months, Mr. Biden spent more on his campaign than he raised. He begins an aggressive phase of the primary race with far less cash on hand than top rivals.
lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign began October with less than $9 million in the bank as the 2020 Democratic primary race entered a new and more aggressive phase, barely more than a third as much cash as that of his leading rival, Senator Elizabeth Warren, and nearly $25 million behind the race’s money leader, Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Despite Their Promises, Giant Energy Companies Burn Away Vast Amounts of Natural Gas
abstract: Exxon, Marathon, BP and others are flaring natural gas, a wasteful practice with  consequences in the fight against climate change, at a record pace.
lead_paragraph: When leaders from Exxon Mobil and BP gathered last month with other fossil-fuel executives to declare they were serious about climate change, they cited progress in curbing an energy-wasting practice called flaring — the intentional burning of natural gas as companies drill faster than pipelines can move the energy away.

headline: Matthew Shepard’s Parents Assail Trump Administration on Transgender Rights
abstract: Their criticisms were read aloud in their absence during a ceremony at the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The parents of Matthew Shepard, the gay college student whose murder led to the passage of a groundbreaking federal law that expanded the definition of violent federal hate crimes, harshly criticized the Trump administration’s record on civil rights in a letter read aloud in their absence during a Justice Department ceremony on Wednesday.

headline: Son of Ron Ely, ‘Tarzan’ Actor, Kills Mother Before Police Shoot Him Dead, Officials Say
abstract: The killings took place at the Santa Barbara home that the actor shared with his wife.
lead_paragraph: The son of the actor Ron Ely, who starred in the 1960s television series “Tarzan,” killed his mother on Tuesday in Santa Barbara, Calif., before being fatally shot by sheriff’s deputies when he threatened them, the authorities said Wednesday.

headline: One Thing You Can Do: Consider a Heat Pump
abstract: Also this week, rising emissions on America’s roads
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

headline: Chipotle Has a Plan to Pay Tuition. Will it Actually Help?
abstract: Turnover is high, unemployment low. So the chain is offering to pay full tuition costs for some business and technology programs.
lead_paragraph: As fast-food companies across the United States struggle to recruit and retain low-wage workers, Chipotle Mexican Grill said this week that it would offer a new benefit designed to keep employees at the chain longer: free tuition at a group of colleges and universities.

headline: ‘The Lighthouse’ Review: Dark Nights, Troubled Souls, Hairy Men
abstract: Robert Pattinson and Willem Dafoe play antagonistic lighthouse keepers in a twisted tale of men and loneliness.
lead_paragraph: Willem Dafoe and Robert Pattinson have two of the most mesmerizing — and pleasurably unnerving — physiognomies in movies. In “The Lighthouse,” a sly American Gothic set in the late 19th century, the director Robert Eggers lights and frames the actors to emphasize every bony plane, every facial crease, hollow and pinprick of stubble. The stark black-and-white cinematography deepens the film's shadows and unease, but it also throws these grizzled faces into relief, sharpening their cheekbones and revealing the death’s head under each man’s grimace.

headline: Sandy Hook Father Is Awarded $450,000 in Defamation Case
abstract: The award comes several months after a Wisconsin judge ruled that Leonard Pozner had been defamed by an author of a book promoting claims that the 2012 school shooting was a government-led hoax.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Wisconsin has awarded $450,000 to the father of a 6-year-old killed in the 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn., after a judge ruled that the man had been defamed by the publication of a book denying that a shooting even took place.

headline: 8.3 Million Watched Ohio Democratic Debate on Television
abstract: Tuesday’s event drew an audience significantly smaller than the one for last month’s candidate forum in Houston.
lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — The Democratic debate stage is getting bigger, but television ratings are getting smaller.

headline: Drug Giants Close In on a $50 Billion Settlement of Opioid Cases
abstract: The nation’s three largest drug distributors, as well as two manufacturers, are in intense negotiations to settle thousands of cases before a trial set to begin on Monday.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The nation’s three largest drug distributors and two manufacturers have agreed with multiple states on a framework to resolve thousands of opioid cases with a settlement worth nearly $50 billion in cash and addiction treatments, according to three people familiar with the negotiations.

headline: Under New Rule, Chinese Diplomats Must Notify State Dept. of Meetings in U.S.
abstract: State Department officials said the new measures were ordered in reciprocity for China’s strict limits on the actions of American diplomats there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has begun requiring Chinese diplomats to notify the State Department before any meetings they plan to have with local or state officials and with educational and research institutions, the State Department said Wednesday.

headline: Read Trump’s Letter to President Erdogan of Turkey
abstract: Trump said he’d written the “very powerful” letter to warn the Turkish leader.
lead_paragraph: Trump said he’d written the “very powerful” letter to warn the Turkish leader.

headline: Trump Administration Delays Cuts to Food Stamps and School Meals
abstract: Under fire for rule changes that could cut millions off food assistance, the Trump administration is extending the comment period on food-stamp changes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amid widespread condemnation, the Trump administration may be softening on a proposal to toughen access to food stamps and free school meals, reopening public comment on a regulatory change that would deprive food assistance to millions of Americans.

headline: For Yankees, Rainout Complicates the A.L.C.S. Pitching Plan
abstract: With Wednesday’s Game 4 postponed a day, the Yankees and Astros could end up playing on four straight days — a stretch that could test the Yankees’ reliance on their bullpen.
lead_paragraph: With heavy rain falling in New York on Wednesday afternoon and more expected at night, Game 4 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and Houston Astros was postponed a day, until 8 p.m. on Thursday. Game 5, originally scheduled for Thursday, was pushed back to Friday, which was once a day off for travel — and the ripple effects of that shift will resonate throughout the rest of the series.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Says She Won’t Run for Congress in 2020
abstract: In her first public comments since Representative Nita Lowey announced her retirement, Ms. Clinton said she was not considering running to replace her.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Clinton won’t be following in her parents’ political footsteps just yet.

headline: American Prosecutor Is Fatally Shot in Micronesia After Her Daily Run
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating the death of a lawyer who was shot three times outside her home.
lead_paragraph: When Rachelle Bergeron graduated from law school, she knew she wanted to help people who did not have a voice. That passion took her first to India, where she represented women and children who had been trafficked, and for the last four years to the Pacific nation of Micronesia, where she was the acting attorney general for Yap State.

headline: Peter Navarro Invented an Expert for His Books, Based on Himself
abstract: President Trump’s trade adviser frequently cited Ron Vara, a fictional source who was a critic of China, in his writings.
lead_paragraph: Peter Navarro, a top White House trade adviser, has developed a reputation in Washington as a Rasputin-like China hawk who whispers anti-China musings in President Trump’s ear.

headline: Under Scrutiny for Wealth, Powerful Boss of Mexico’s Oil Workers Union Resigns
abstract: The resignation of Carlos Romero Deschamps, who is under investigation for his unexplained wealth, is an important step for President Andrés Manuel López Obrador in his fight against corruption.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The longtime leader of Mexico’s oil workers union, a powerful figure who had become emblematic of graft in the state-owned oil company and yet seemed untouchable, resigned on Wednesday in a symbolic victory for Mexico’s president in his fight against corruption.

headline: Russia Stops U.S. Diplomats en Route to a Nuclear Accident Site
abstract: The diplomats were intending to travel to a remote town in the Russian Arctic, where a mysterious nuclear accident killed seven people in August, releasing radiation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities removed three American diplomats from a train heading to an Arctic town near the site of a recent nuclear accident, Russian news agencies reported on Wednesday.

headline: Adam Schiff Is the Congressman Trump Wants You to Hate
abstract: Relentless, yes. But “radical left” and “lowlife”? Not at all.
lead_paragraph: The paradox of Adam Schiff is this: He is depicted by some Republicans as a fanatical partisan, with President Trump suggesting that he is a “radical left” “lowlife” who should be arrested for treason, yet in real life Schiff is a cerebral and mild-mannered moderate.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump on Syria, Erdogan and the Kurds
abstract: The president wrongly claimed that a violent Kurdish separatist group was “more of a terrorist threat” than ISIS, among other inaccurate claims.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Wednesday defended his abrupt decision to withdraw American troops from northern Syria, seeking to counter international and bipartisan criticism as Turkey continued its offensive against the Kurds.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Case of Lee Malvo, Sniper Who Terrorized D.C.
abstract: The justices weighed whether Mr. Malvo, who was 17 when he and his partner killed 10 people in the Washington area, is entitled to a new sentencing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost two decades after two men terrorized the Washington region in the fall of 2002 in a series of deadly sniper attacks, the Supreme Court considered on Wednesday whether one of them, Lee Malvo, may challenge his sentences of life in prison without the possibility of parole.

headline: Elaine Chao, Mitch McConnell and Questions of Conflict
abstract: Congress wants answers from the transportation secretary, wife of the Senate majority leader, about the apparent mixing of public and family business.
lead_paragraph: Self-dealing, nepotism, conflicts of interest: Donald Trump campaigned on ending that kind of corruption in Washington, then, once in office, threw open the doors of his administration to it.

headline: John Lithgow: Trump Is a Bad President. He’s an Even Worse Entertainer.
abstract: The performer in chief is forcing us to live in a B-movie horror.
lead_paragraph: Readers of this page have every reason to be suspicious of the political musings of an actor. I’m suspicious of them myself. But consider this: Our politics and our press are completely dominated by an entertainer president. In recent weeks we’ve even read about our ex-reality-show host president discussing foreign policy over the phone with the ex-TV comedian president of Ukraine.

headline: Court Blocks Trump’s Plan to Ease Bird Protections on Oil Lands
abstract: A federal judge has blocked the Trump administration's plans to ease protections on an iconic western bird's habitat — and open it to oil and gas exploration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the Trump administration’s plan to ease protections for an iconic bird that makes its home on millions of acres of oil and gas-rich sagebrush lands, dealing a blow to government efforts to allow more drilling, mining and logging in the west.

headline: Two-Person Race? Moderates, and Bernie Sanders, Say Not So Fast
abstract: Amy Klobuchar and Pete Buttigieg are vying to become the pragmatic alternative to Joe Biden. Mr. Sanders is trumpeting endorsements to compete with Elizabeth Warren.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — For months, the Democratic presidential race has seemed to move inexorably toward a confrontation between former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. As Ms. Warren gathered financial support and strength in the polls, Mr. Biden steadily slid on both fronts while the rest of the Democratic field stagnated with voters. A jumbled primary appeared on the verge of becoming a contest between two front-runners.

headline: Inside the Derailed White House Meeting
abstract: “I hate ISIS more than you do,” President Trump said. “You don’t know that,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi replied. Here’s the rest of their exchange.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — You know a White House meeting has gone off the rails when the president of the United States and the speaker of the House cannot agree over the precise insult one called the other.

headline: Gordon Sondland Elbowed His Way Into Ukraine Policy. It Could Cost Him.
abstract: Mr. Sondland was to tell impeachment investigators that President Trump placed a condition on any meeting with Ukraine’s president — the opening of an investigation that could benefit Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To foreign policy experts, it is no mystery why President Trump’s national security adviser tried in May to block Gordon D. Sondland from becoming a player in United States diplomacy with Ukraine.

headline: Settlement Talks for Bank Followed Pressure on Trump by Turkey’s Leader
abstract: Before indicting a state-owned Turkish bank, the Justice Department sought to negotiate a deal following calls by Turkey’s president to the White House.
lead_paragraph: After repeated appeals to President Trump by Turkey’s president to avoid charges against a state-owned Turkish bank, Attorney General William P. Barr oversaw an effort earlier this year to negotiate a settlement with the bank, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Democrats, Dream Big but Tell the Whole Truth
abstract: Big moves come with hitches. But that’s no reason not to go big and bold.
lead_paragraph: I am not one of the nervous Nellies who believe that Democratic candidates shouldn’t dream big and pitch big, transformational ideas. I’m not one of those who believe that Democrats should negotiate with themselves, in advance of submitting a proposal, so that they present only incremental half measures in the name of practicality and perceived ability to implement.

headline: Trump’s Impeachment Blockade Crumbles as Witnesses Agree to Talk
abstract: After vowing not to cooperate with a “kangaroo court,” the president has largely failed to prevent current and former administration members from spending hours with Democrats seeking to impeach him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House’s trenchant declaration to House impeachment investigators last week was unequivocal: No more witnesses or documents for a “totally compromised kangaroo court.”

headline: Review: ‘The Lightning Thief,’ a Far Cry From Olympus
abstract: A musical adaptation of the popular fantasy novel comes to Broadway and goes to Hades.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an idea for a Broadway musical: An awkward boy with an absent father and an overwhelmed mother gets involved with friends in a dubious scheme that spins out of control and almost undoes him.

headline: Patrick Day, Boxer, Dies After Suffering Brain Injury in the Ring
abstract: The 27-year-old Long Island native had been in a coma after he was knocked out by Charles Conwell, a 2016 Olympian.
lead_paragraph: Four days after being knocked unconscious in a super welterweight title fight, Patrick Day, a former New York Golden Gloves champion and Long Island native, died on Wednesday.

headline: ‘I’m Worried That I Will Die:’ Hong Kong Protesters Write Final Goodbyes
abstract: As violence escalates between demonstrators and the police in Hong Kong, protesters have started writing “last letters” to their loved ones, in case they don’t return. These notes chronicle the mental and emotional state of frontliners coming to terms with risking death for their beliefs.
lead_paragraph: As violence escalates between demonstrators and the police in Hong Kong, protesters have started writing “last letters” to their loved ones, in case they don’t return. These notes chronicle the mental and emotional state of frontliners coming to terms with risking death for their beliefs.

headline: He Defied a Code. His Neighbors Turned Him In for Murder, Police Say.
abstract: A 20-year-old is charged in a shooting that left a rival dead and 11 wounded at a neighborhood reunion in Brooklyn, the police say.
lead_paragraph: The crowd of thousands that had gathered for the 56th annual Brownsville Old Timers Day in July had dwindled down to hundreds — it was nearly 11 p.m. — when trouble started.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: A Toni Morrison Doc and ‘Fractured’
abstract: A recent documentary about Toni Morrison hits Hulu. And a Hitchcockian thriller with Sam Worthington is on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: TONI MORRISON: THE PIECES I AM (2019) Stream on Hulu; Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. When her novel “Paradise” was banned in Texas prisons in the 1990s because of the perception that the book had been written to disrupt prison life and could potentially cause strikes or riots,  Toni Morrison had a response that the authorities likely didn’t anticipate. Morrison recalls in this documentary: “I thought, ‘How powerful is that?’” A lengthy interview with Morrison is the ballast of this movie about her, which steers away from telling a typical, straight-ahead story of Morrison’s life and instead offers a kind of meditation on the significance of her work. That is achieved through interviews with, in addition to Morrison, figures like Oprah Winfrey, Angela Davis, Fran Lebowitz, Sonia Sanchez and Robert Gottlieb. “If you want a thorough documentation of everything Morrison has done and everyone she knows, there’s always Wikipedia,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. “But if you’d prefer an argument for her importance and a sense of her presence, then you won’t be disappointed.”

headline: Abiy Ahmed Won the Nobel Peace Prize. Now He Needs to Earn It.
abstract: The Abyssinian spring in Ethiopia has entered a critical phase.
lead_paragraph: Some honors come too late; others too early. Others still risk scuttling the efforts they are rewarding.

lead_paragraph: The rest of Week 7’s N.F.L. matchups will be published on Friday.

headline: A Brexit Deal in Hand, Boris Johnson Faces an Uphill Struggle in Parliament
abstract: Britain’s prime minister cited a “great new deal that takes back control,” hours after a Northern Irish party rejected the agreement.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Britain and the European Union agreed on a Brexit deal Thursday, setting the stage for a fateful showdown in the British Parliament, where Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces an uphill struggle to marshal enough votes for his plan after three years of anguished, politically corrosive debate.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How a Prison Play Goes on Tour’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the question of whether prison should be for rehabilitation or punishment?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How a Prison Play Goes on Tour”

headline: Why the Protests in Hong Kong May Have No End in Sight
abstract: Influential local allies of Beijing, the group most likely to be able to resolve the impasse, are divided on a range of issues, including the protesters’ demand for full democracy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Resolving the increasingly violent protests in Hong Kong will most likely fall to an influential group of Beijing’s local allies.

headline: Female Playwrights Are on Form (for the Most Part)
abstract: Whether it’s finishing what Jane Austen started, imagining the private conversations of first ladies or inserting the personal, on London stages female playwrights are mixing things up.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Call it an act of homage, authorial daring or simply a playwright having a bit of fun, but Laura Wade’s “The Watsons” is one of this year’s smartest plays so far, and also among the sweetest. Picking up where Jane Austen left her unfinished novel of the same name, Ms. Wade brings these Regency-era characters to the stage accompanied by her modern-day self.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Famous Toilet Seat Debate
abstract: Should men be expected to put the seat back down when they’re done?
lead_paragraph: Evangeline writes: I currently live with my boyfriend, Nate. We have had an ongoing argument about the toilet seat. He believes that he should not put the seat down after he uses the toilet. I, on the other hand, believe it is the man’s responsibility to put the toilet seat down after he uses it. To this day, we still cannot agree as to who is right and who is wrong. He still leaves the seat up, and it still drives me nuts. Please help!

headline: How to Pick Up a Syringe
abstract: Never use bare hands. Carry the supplies needed in case of an accidental poke.
lead_paragraph: “No exposed flesh,” says Mayia Ogbebor, the syringe-disposal program manager for the San Francisco AIDS Foundation, which runs a 12-person, 12-hours-a-day, 7-days-a-week needle-pickup crew funded by the city’s public health department. Since the program started in June 2018, the team has collected 275,000 used syringes left by intravenous-drug users in gutters and doorways; jammed in car tires; even stuck, birthday candle-like, in feces. Wear long pants, covered shoes and latex gloves to fetch needles. Never use your bare hands. Carry a trash picker or tongs and a medical-grade sharps container. If you spot a used syringe, place your container on the flat ground, grasp the needle with your picker, then push it into the sharps bin, needle side first.

headline: You’re Only as Old as You Feel
abstract: Simply asking people how old they feel may tell you a lot about their health and well-being.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Stephanie Heller, a New Jersey realtor, was leaving her gym after a workout when she noticed a woman in the parking lot struggling to bend down. “I don’t know if she dropped something and had to pick it up, or if her shoe was untied,” Ms. Heller said, but she eagerly bounded over to help. The woman blamed old age for her incapacity, explaining that she was 70. But Ms. Heller was 71.

headline: Starting Chemotherapy, When You’re Ready
abstract: It’s better if you start cancer treatment when you can jump in wholeheartedly and without regrets.
lead_paragraph: First thing Monday morning my patient, a man in his early 60s, showed up to start chemotherapy. It had not been a smooth road for him over the past few months.

headline: The Jean-Georges Recipe for Restaurants
abstract: In the era of the auteur chef, Jean-Georges Vongerichten has figured out how to create high-end restaurants by the dozen. How — and why — does he do it?
lead_paragraph: On Monday, May 13, Jean-Georges Vongerichten got into a car outside his apartment in the West Village and asked to be taken to the airport. It would have been an odd time to leave town: The next day he was opening a new restaurant, the Fulton, in Lower Manhattan, on the waterfront facing Brooklyn. But Vongerichten wasn’t flying anywhere. He was going to check in on another restaurant, this one opening on Wednesday, inside the new TWA Hotel at J.F.K.

headline: Elton John’s Bookshelves Are Meticulous. Just Ask Him.
abstract: “I’m a very organized bloke.”
lead_paragraph: “I hate seeing things lying on the floor in a horrible state,” says the singer and songwriter, whose new memoir is “Me.” “I’m a very organized bloke.”

headline: Poem: Taking Leave
abstract: David Romtvedt’s poems  often contain a tangible moment or two, then something startling or surprising drops in.
lead_paragraph: One of poetry’s most appealing elements can be its mixture of observations. How do these things go together? someone might ask. David Romtvedt’s poems in “Dilemmas of the Angels” often contain a tangible moment or two, then something startling or surprising drops in. These poems of layering counterpoint feel a lot like the world — a person standing on a street corner watching others move by, each in his or her own universe, and then there are the plants, and the ants, and the birds, and the machines, and objects that give the people gravity — and the intentions — where will the people pause next? Why did the birds fly too soon?

headline: Does the Future of Robots Get You Excited, or Fill You With Dread?
abstract: Machines are learning how to complete more complex tasks. Is this a good thing?
lead_paragraph: Last week, a robotic hand successfully solved a Rubik’s Cube. While that feat might seem like a fun parlor trick, it’s a sign that robots are being programmed to learn and not just memorize.

headline: Jack Quaid Loves a Haunted House
abstract: The star of the Amazon show “The Boys” likes to be scared.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jack Quaid is that guy — we all know someone like him — who convinces you that the haunted house will be fun. “You can be very prepared” for the scares around each corner, he’ll say, reassuringly. It’s an “immersive experience,” he’ll say.

headline: A Couple Trades Up in the Financial District. Which Apartment Did They Choose?
abstract: When their Crown Heights purchase fell through, Alex Wong and Michael Thomas thought they might find better space in lower Manhattan. Here’s what happened next.
lead_paragraph: When their Crown Heights purchase fell through, Alex Wong and Michael Thomas thought they might find better space in lower Manhattan. Here’s what happened next.

headline: Why Don’t Rich People Just Stop Working?
abstract: Are the wealthy addicted to money, competition, or just feeling important? Yes.
lead_paragraph: “Billionaires should not exist,” Senator Bernie Sanders said last month. And, at the Democratic presidential debate this week, he said that the wealth disparity in America is “a moral and economic outrage.”

headline: When a Mortgage Is Part of Your Retirement Plan
abstract: Eliminating debt is a great goal. But is it the best option for you?
lead_paragraph: There is no mistaking how Eric Markowitz feels about borrowing money: “I hate debt,” he said. Dr. Markowitz, a dentist in Washington, D.C., took out a mortgage to buy a home for his family, but that’s the extent of his borrowing. And he fully intends to have it paid off by the time he retires in 15 years or so. “I sleep better knowing I have limited debt,” he said. “I just don’t like owing people.”

headline: Signs of Discord as U.A.W. Locals Consider G.M. Deal
abstract: Union leaders are meeting in Detroit to discuss a tentative contract agreement that could end a monthlong strike. The closing of the Lordstown plant remains a sore point for workers.
lead_paragraph: After a monthlong strike that has idled General Motors plants across the Midwest and South, union leaders are gathering on Thursday in Detroit to consider a deal that could send workers back to the assembly lines.

headline: Why Brian Quinn of ‘Impractical Jokers’ Craves a 19th-Century Beer
abstract: The comedian is reviving one of Staten Island’s most iconic brands. Beer fans are starting to notice.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this fall, the comedian Brian Quinn spent the day cemetery hopping in Staten Island.

headline: The Other Candidates Are Coming for Warren
abstract: And happy birthday to “The Argument”!
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Wheels Up on More Flights to the African Continent
abstract: New nonstop flights are dramatically cutting travel time and linking more African cities to the Eastern Seaboard of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Want to plan a trip to Africa but are intimidated by the flight time? Your concern is reasonable.

headline: Famous Iwo Jima Flag Photo Had Another Misidentified Man, Marines Say
abstract: In 2016, the Marine Corps said it had wrongly identified another of the men in the famous photograph.
lead_paragraph: It’s among the best-known photographs in American military history: six United States Marines raising an American flag over the Japanese island of Iwo Jima during World War II.

headline: About The Neediest Cases Fund
abstract: The New York Times’s Fund traces its history to 1911. Since then, it has raised over $300 million.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to those who are less fortunate. In its first year, 1912, readers contributed $3,630.88. These days, The Fund regularly raises over $5.5 million annually, and over the years, The Fund has raised more than $300 million.

headline: What Can Robert Pattinson Do to Keep You Guessing?
abstract: After “Twilight,” the actor reinvented himself in art-house films. How will he follow “The Lighthouse” and his wildest role so far? With yet another swerve: He’s playing Batman.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Pattinson signed on to play the antagonistic Dauphin of France in Netflix’s medieval epic “The King,” he knew it was a juicy role that would give him the pleasure of taunting Timothée Chalamet. Still, Pattinson hadn’t quite figured out his character until he saw hair-and-makeup photos of his co-star Lily-Rose Depp, who was cast as a royal ingénue.

headline: Donte Colley, the Hope We Need on Instagram
abstract: Mr. Colley, who has collaborated with Ariana Grande, animates his choreographed videos with emoji and positive affirmations.
lead_paragraph: Name: Donte Colley

headline: A Scotch Maker’s Challenge: First Brexit. Now Tariffs.
abstract: The 25 percent U.S. tariffs to be imposed Friday are causing headaches for single malt distilleries, already struggling with Brexit.
lead_paragraph: ISLAY, Scotland — Britain’s planned departure from the European Union has turned distiller Anthony Wills’s workdays into a marathon of logistics.

headline: What Does It Cost to Open a Coffee Shop?
abstract: Get ready to buy eight cases of $12-per-gallon oat milk per week.
lead_paragraph: Julia Rothman is an illustrator. Shaina Feinberg is a writer and filmmaker. Both live in Brooklyn.

headline: Betye Saar at MoMA: Prelude to a Revolutionary Breakthrough
abstract: A new exhibition concentrates on the artist’s early years, tracking the experiments in printmaking and assemblage that led to her pivotal work “Black Girl’s Window.”
lead_paragraph: In 1969, Betye Saar made an artwork that would prove pivotal in her career.

headline: How a Band of Surfer Dudes Pulled Off the Biggest Jewel Heist in N.Y. History
abstract: For a few months in 1964, “Murph the Surf” and his crew became folk heroes when they looted the Hall of Gems from the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: For its 150th anniversary, the American Museum of Natural History is celebrating its many historic moments, from its 1869 founding, to the 1902 discovery of the first T-Rex skeleton, to the creation of the Teddy Roosevelt statue erected out front in 1940.

headline: Facebook Finally Has a Good Idea
abstract: The company’s latest plan to police toxic social media content is intriguing — and even laudable.
lead_paragraph: I would like to formally apply to be judge and jury over Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: 36 Hours in Yokohama
abstract: Rugby and Olympics fans have a good reason to visit the second-largest city in Japan, as do those in search of gardens, temples and the largest Chinatown in the country.
lead_paragraph: Yokohama resides in the perpetual shadow of its more prominent neighbor. Less than half an hour by train from Tokyo, the sprawling port city is the second-largest in Japan, yet registers as barely a blip among most tourists to the region. But that may soon change, at least among sports fans. This fall, Yokohama is hosting the final and semifinal matches of the Rugby World Cup. And during the 2020 Tokyo Summer Olympics, the city will host spillover sporting events, including baseball, softball and soccer. Beyond the stadiums, visitors will find much to praise around town, from traditional gardens and temples to only-in-Japan night life and Chinatown cuisine worth a weekend detour from the capital.

headline: A Photographer’s Arduous Climb to the Roof of the Jungle
abstract: A technologist works in rainforest canopies to track illegal logging. To document that work, you can’t take pictures from the ground.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Lending a Hand, in New York and Beyond
abstract: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund kicks off its 108th annual campaign, adding Feeding America as a beneficiary.
lead_paragraph: On a brisk Saturday morning this month, William Lugo gathered dozens of volunteers around him at a playground at a public housing complex in Queens. The farmers’ market was about to open, and it was time for a pep talk.

headline: This Investigator Used to Stake Out Women. Now, She Tails Men Online.
abstract: In her 30 years, the sleuth trade has gone from disguises to digging for data.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tale as old as love itself, or at least as old as the internet. Girl meets boy. Girl falls for boy. Girl starts to suspect that boy may secretly be a married father of two in Buffalo.

headline: In Washington, a Fight to Decriminalize Prostitution Divides Allies
abstract: Supporters say a bill being considered by the District of Columbia Council would protect prostitutes in the nation’s capital. Critics say it would be a boon to sex traffickers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tamika Spellman, who is in her 50s, has worked as a prostitute since she was 14. The job, she said, is the most stable work she has had and helped put her son through college.

headline: Working to Benefit Society, Not Just Companies
abstract: Andrew Kassoy and the other two co-founders of B Lab are encouraging businesses to focus on more than just profits.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a new series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: 1,713 Mammoth Boilers, and Winter Weeks Away
abstract: Families shivered last year as NYCHA experienced repeated heat outages. Now workers are scrambling to keep residents warm.
lead_paragraph: The seven steel boilers should have been replaced years ago.

headline: Duterte Is Injured in Motorcycle Accident in Philippines
abstract: The fall, which left the president bruised, came amid questions about his health and recent absences from public view.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines suffered bruises after falling off a motorcycle, his aides said on Thursday, amid mounting public concern about his health.

headline: Elijah Cummings, Brexit, Chicago: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why Ocasio-Cortez Is Endorsing Sanders
abstract: Thursday: She was a relatively unknown organizer on his 2016 campaign. This weekend, she'll star at his campaign rally in Queens.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Elijah Cummings, Powerful Democrat Who Investigated Trump, Dies at 68
abstract: A son of sharecroppers, he fought tirelessly for his hometown, Baltimore, and became a key figure in the impeachment investigation of President Trump.

headline: These Apps Are an Uber Driver’s Co-Pilot
abstract: Gridwise, Mystro and others help drivers predict where to get the best routes, and also manage the nitty-gritty for tax purposes.
lead_paragraph: Driving for ride-sharing companies is a juggling act. To maximize their income, drivers often keep Uber on one screen and Lyft on another.

headline: A Foreseen Calamity in Syria
abstract: President Trump’s troop withdrawal ignited a predicted outburst of chaos and carnage in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Remaining Silent About Corruption Should Not Be an Option
abstract: New York City requires its employees to blow the whistle on wrongdoing, and that approach is working.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, the country has been riveted by the news of a whistle-blower within the intelligence community who filed a formal complaint alleging wrongdoing by President Trump. In turn, we have watched the whistle-blower defamed by the president and his allies, even accused of treason, despite his having meticulously followed the lawful process to report possible criminal conduct. This took remarkable courage. There was no legal obligation to report it, and there were serious risks to career, reputation and even personal safety for doing so.

headline: Taking Ayahuasca When You’re a Senior Citizen
abstract: Some older adults are dabbling in this powerful psychedelic, which is mostly illegal in the United States.
lead_paragraph: At 74, the venture capitalist George Sarlo might not have seemed an obvious candidate for an ayahuasca experience. Mr. Sarlo, a Hungarian Jewish immigrant who arrived in the United States in 1956, has had great professional success as the co-founder of Walden Venture Capital. He lives in an upscale San Francisco neighborhood, in a large house with an unobstructed view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: When Latinx People Use the N-Word
abstract: Many of us assume our proximity to black people makes it O.K. for us to say the word. It’s not.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the actress Gina Rodriguez found herself the subject of social media shaming after posting a short clip of herself using the N-word while singing along to a Lauryn Hill rap verse. The “Jane the Virgin” star quickly deleted the clip and responded with a pat “sorry if you were offended” video, followed by another apology, this time as a note on Instagram, sharing vague promises of near-future self-reflection.

headline: The Scandal of a Nobel Laureate
abstract: We live in an age that is losing the capacity to distinguish art from ideology and artists from politics.
lead_paragraph: When I was about 8 years old I wrote my first fan letter, to Roald Dahl, for “Danny, the Champion of the World.” Not knowing where to find the author, I addressed the envelope to “Roald Dahl, England,” and added extra postage stamps.

headline: Unpacking the Trade Deficit
abstract: Tariffs don’t work the way Trump seems to think they do.
lead_paragraph: Eager to shore up weakening markets and economic data, President Trump has unveiled the first phase of what he calls the “greatest and biggest deal ever made” with China.

headline: When a Ferrari’s in a Fender-Bender
abstract: Cars that were handcrafted nearly a century ago require a hard-to-find mix of skills to restore them to their former glory.
lead_paragraph: A dented fender from a run-of-the-mill car crash is easy to fix. The task becomes vastly more complicated when that fender belongs to an elegant creation with a name like Ferrari, Bugatti or Delahaye.

headline: Investors Get Excited Over the Brexit Deal
abstract: The British pound surged this morning after Britain and the E.U. reached an agreement on Brexit. But there are still serious hurdles to overcome.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers like Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, Dara Khosrowshahi of Uber and Brian Chesky of Airbnb. Apply to attend here. ( Sign up here to get this in your inbox each morning.)

headline: ‘Cyrano, My Love’ Review: A Nose for Romance
abstract: This superficial take on the writing and initial staging of “Cyrano de Bergerac” is a whirlwind of soapy declarations and backstage chaos.
lead_paragraph: Fizzy and flouncy and oh, so talky, “Cyrano, My Love” imagines the creation of Edmond Rostand’s blockbuster French play, “Cyrano de Bergerac.”

headline: ‘Tell Me Who I Am’ Review: Twin Brothers Face an Awful Truth
abstract: This documentary about siblings and irrevocable memory loss is sad and eerie to the extent that you wish it were fiction.
lead_paragraph: The story of the British twin brothers Alex and Marcus Lewis in the documentary “Tell Me Who I Am” might have been concocted by the novelist Ian McEwan in one of his more unforgiving moods. Indeed, for the sake of the brothers themselves, one wishes their story were a fiction.

headline: ‘By the Grace of God’ Review: A Devastating Film About Survivors of Abuse
abstract: The often irreverent French director François Ozon gets serious with a fact-based story about a group of men who were childhood victims of a pedophile priest.
lead_paragraph: For a member of the clergy to sexually violate a child is one of the most stark and cruel betrayals imaginable. That an institution would prevaricate and dissemble about these betrayals rather than take immediate, decisive action to pursue justice and provide restitution creates a greater betrayal. After years of such actions, betrayal reaches a near-unimaginable level.

headline: ‘The Cave’ Review: Do No Harm, for as Long as Possible
abstract: Feras Fayyad’s new documentary takes viewers into a subterranean Syrian hospital, as warplanes rumble overhead and bombings rattle the walls.
lead_paragraph: Entering theaters at a timely moment, “The Cave” is a frightening immersion in life under siege in Syria that, as difficult as it often is to watch, can’t come close to replicating how harrowing it must have been to film.

headline: ‘#Female Pleasure’ Review: Fighting the Patriarchy
abstract: Barbara Miller’s humane profile of five women fighting back against sexism and misogyny is a hopeful, clearheaded confessional.
lead_paragraph: Sexism and oppression wear many guises in “#Female Pleasure,” Barbara Miller’s illuminating if one-sided overview of the myriad ways in which women’s sexuality is controlled and subjugated.

headline: ‘Greener Grass’ Review: Life Is (Not) Beautiful
abstract: Burying itself in weirdness and absurdity, this oddball movie follows two soccer moms through a surreally competitive suburban hell.
lead_paragraph: Like a “Saturday Night Live” sketch that doesn’t know when to dial back the weird, “Greener Grass” can be painful to watch. A deadpan take on suburban hell — I hesitate to call it a comedy, black or otherwise — the movie takes competitiveness to such excruciatingly surreal lengths that every would-be joke feels agonizingly strained.

headline: ‘Serendipity’ Review: Turning a Cancer Diagnosis Into Art
abstract: In her new documentary, the sculptor Prune Nourry explores how her work evolved after a breast cancer diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: After the artist Prune Nourry received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2016 at age 31, her experiences of treatment began to inform her art. “Serendipity” is both a document and an extension of that process — a self-portrait in which Nourry showcases past projects and explores how her artistic impulses evolved.

headline: ‘The Elephant Queen’ Review: Magnificent Images of Majestic Animals
abstract: In footage shot over several years, this documentary follows a herd of elephants across the Kenyan savanna.
lead_paragraph: Gentle and hopeful, “The Elephant Queen” sometimes shies away from tough truths. But this documentary aims to celebrate these creatures rather than stir rage over their peril. Considering its intended young audience, that’s a smart strategy.

headline: Key Moments as E.U. Leaders Endorsed a Brexit Deal With Boris Johnson
abstract: Support for the deal from Parliament and Northern Irish lawmakers is far from assured.
lead_paragraph: Britain and the European Union announced on Thursday that an agreement on the draft text of a Brexit deal had been reached, a last-minute breakthrough for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as he works to map out Britain’s departure from the bloc.

headline: China Detains 2 Americans Amid Growing Scrutiny of Foreigners
abstract: Two Americans who ran an English-language teaching company are being held on charges of organizing illegal border crossings, a Chinese government spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities in southern China have detained two Americans who led an Idaho-based English-language teaching company, the latest sign of the Chinese government’s growing scrutiny of foreigners working and traveling in the country.

headline: Chicago Teachers’ Strike: Citywide Scramble as Classes Come to Halt
abstract: A walkout in the nation’s third-largest school district canceled instruction across Chicago. It was uncertain how long the strike might last.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tens of thousands of public school teachers joined picket lines on Thursday as a strike in the nation’s third-largest school district canceled classes across Chicago and left its new mayor, Lori Lightfoot, grappling with her most significant crisis to date.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: A remarkable news conference seemed to confirm a central premise of the House’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: Impeachment investigators have been gathering evidence for weeks to prove what Mr. Mulvaney freely admitted to reporters in the White House Briefing Room. I talked to my colleague Maggie Haberman about why he said something so stunning.

headline: I Went Blind. I Still Owned Manhattan.
abstract: After a lifetime of poor vision, a woman learned to navigate the blur of New York City by memory and mental tricks. Then things got worse. And then, miraculously, better.
lead_paragraph: It was when I could no longer read street signs that I started to panic.

headline: Commuters Drag Climate Activists From London Trains
abstract: Video of one episode, filmed during disruptive action by the Extinction Rebellion group, illustrated the inflamed passions on both sides.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A bearded man wearing a suit walks on the roof of a London Underground train as a crowd of clearly infuriated commuters yell and point at him.

headline: Who Are the 10 Lawmakers Who Might Scupper the Brexit Deal?
abstract: Final approval for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s deal with the European Union could rely on 10 lawmakers from Northern Ireland. How can so few wield so much influence?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After years of debate, false starts and just plain confusion, the news that Britain had reached a deal to leave the European Union seemed like a moment for a weary nation to exhale.

headline: Ojai Feels the Aftershock of Los Angeles Philharmonic Upheaval
abstract: With Chad Smith leaving to lead that orchestra, Ara Guzelimian will return as artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Ara Guzelimian first attended the Ojai Music Festival, the laboratory of musical innovation in Southern California, as a teenager. In 1974, as a college student, he performed at the festival as a member of U.C.L.A.’s a cappella choir. And from 1992 to 1997, he was Ojai’s artistic director.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and Short Hills, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and Short Hills, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Gramercy Park, Brooklyn Heights and Spuyten Duyvil.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Gramercy Park, Brooklyn Heights and Spuyten Duyvil.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and Short Hills, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Gramercy Park, Brooklyn Heights and Spuyten Duyvil.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: How Does Homelessness in California Compare With Other States?
abstract: Thursday: Another look at the crisis. Also: A tentative settlement in the Sutter Health antitrust case; and an important quilt collection finds a home in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Civilian Casualties Reach Highest Level in Afghan War, U.N. Says
abstract: July was the deadliest month for noncombatants in Afghanistan since the organization began tracking such figures a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Civilian casualties caused by the long and intensifying conflict in Afghanistan reached a record number in the third quarter of 2019, the United Nations said on Thursday as it reiterated a call for an urgent cease-fire.

headline: The Tiniest Tiny Apartments
abstract: A new study shows where the very smallest studio rentals are.
lead_paragraph: Tiny living is all the rage. In New York City, developers are producing some of the smallest apartments ever seen there, including one new building in the Brooklyn Cultural District that rents units with no more than 384 square feet. While people seek out small spaces to save on rent, reduce their carbon footprints or simplify their lives, those in expensive markets sometimes find themselves living the tiny life by default, even if they rent the largest place they can afford.

headline: Gordon Sondland, E.U. Envoy, Testifies Trump Delegated Ukraine Policy to Giuliani
abstract: Mr. Sondland said in his testimony to House impeachment investigators that he was disappointed the president involved his personal lawyer in diplomacy with Kiev.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gordon D. Sondland, the United States ambassador to the European Union, told House impeachment investigators on Thursday that President Trump delegated American foreign policy on Ukraine to his personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani, a directive he said he disagreed with but nonetheless followed.

headline: Interrogation Company Insists That ‘When They See Us’ Got It Wrong
abstract: Ava DuVernay’s Netflix series about the Central Park jogger case refers to harsh interrogation practices as the “Reid technique.” Now the company behind that technique is suing for defamation.
lead_paragraph: In “When They See Us,” a Netflix series that dramatizes the Central Park jogger case, five black and Hispanic teenage boys are interrogated by investigators in scenes that show them bewildered, scared and alone.

headline: Northeast ‘Bomb Cyclone’: Powerful Winds Knock Out Power to 500,000
abstract: Meteorologists were describing the storm as a “bomb cyclone,” in which masses of warm and cold air meet, creating a cyclonic effect.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Utility poles snapped, cruise ships sought shelter, boats broke from their moorings, trees were uprooted, and more than 500,000 customers in New England were without power at times on Thursday as a storm packing winds gusting  to 90 miles an hour swept up the East Coast.

headline: How to Reduce Abortion
abstract: Clues from the state with the biggest recent decline.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Addiction Is the Stuff of High Drama. In These Plays, So Is Sobriety.
abstract: With recovery no longer so secret, a new wave of plays dealing with its realities has started to emerge. Some of the playwrights have drawn from their own lives.
lead_paragraph: You can barely swing an empty bottle in an American theater without hitting a classic tale of the perils of tippling and other bad habits.

headline: Netflix’s Top 10 Original Movies and TV Shows, According to Netflix
abstract: The streaming giant had been hush-hush about how many people watch its original content. Until now.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Netflix started doing something it had not done since it began streaming shows of its own in 2012: disclosing viewership figures for its original series and movies.

headline: Booker T. Jones, Soul’s Ultimate Sideman, Takes the Lead at Last
abstract: In a new memoir, “Time Is Tight: My Life, Note by Note,” the Stax studio wizard and acclaimed producer tells his own story and finds his voice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Blocks from the ocean-misted mountain views of Venice Beach, Booker T. Jones was hard at work on a late-summer afternoon. The 74-year-old musician, dressed in a black baseball hat and a bright-blue athletic pullover, sat behind his customary Hammond B-3 organ with his chin angled up slightly, like an emperor, as his current road group, which includes his son Ted on lead guitar and the longtime Tom Petty drummer Steve Ferrone, helped rerecord the various classics that provide the names for each chapter in his new memoir.

headline: Herman Cornejo: A Ballet Hero’s Milestone
abstract: Celebrating his 20th anniversary at American Ballet Theater, Mr. Cornejo stars in a new work by Twyla Tharp.
lead_paragraph: “Yo, Herman,” Twyla Tharp calls out across a large, crowded studio. Rehearsal is about to begin, and dancers are milling around, chatting and stretching. But not Herman Cornejo. He’s in a corner, sketching out small movements as he runs through a sequence of steps in his mind. Seeing him lost in thought, Ms. Tharp walks over, placing a hand on his shoulder. The two confer quietly, like confidants.

headline: Turkey Agrees to Pause Fighting, but Not to Withdraw Forces From Northern Syria
abstract: After talks in Ankara, Vice President Mike Pence said the agreement would ‘‘save lives,’’ while Turkey said ‘‘we got what we wanted.’’
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Vice President Mike Pence on Thursday agreed to a deal with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan that accepted a Turkish military presence in a broad part of northern Syria in exchange for the promise of a five-day cease-fire, completing an abrupt reversal of American policy in the Syrian conflict.

headline: We Flew All the Way Here for This?
abstract: A stepmother wonders whether traveling to visit her partner’s daughters — and fight with his ex for their time — is worth it.
lead_paragraph: My partner’s ex-wife throws up roadblocks to seeing his two daughters when we go to visit them. It’s a two-hour flight, so it’s not a small thing to visit. But his ex occupies all the girls’ time when we’re there. They are in their early 20s and live on their own. They complain about how demanding their mother becomes when we’re in town. I am the mom of their two young half sisters. It’s important to us to foster good relationships among the siblings. Does it make sense to continue these trips when we see so little of the girls? (It’s hard for them to get time off from work to visit us.)

headline: Tech Companies Are Destroying Democracy and the Free Press
abstract: Ad revenue that used to support journalism is now captured by Google and Facebook, and some of that money supports and spreads fake news.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential election approaches, the cracks in the digital facade are once again showing.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 23, 2019
abstract: What happens to shelter dogs and cats has changed considerably over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: This graph originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. Dallas Animal Services operates a city shelter and has an “open admissions” policy, which means the agency is required to take in any animal, regardless of its health or behavior. Animals that are “adopted” are adopted directly from the shelter. “Transferred to rescue” means the animal has been transferred to an independent rescue agency.

headline: Braving MoMA: What to Know Before You Enter
abstract: The museum is bigger and more demanding, but there’s more fun, and a sense of serendipity.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been asked many questions about how to visit the newly-expanded Museum of Modern Art. Based on roughly a dozen visits, I’ve figured out some of the answers.

headline: We Don’t Need to Raise Taxes to Have ‘Medicare for All’
abstract: We can find billions of dollars to pay for universal health care if we look in the right places.
lead_paragraph: We can find billions of dollars to pay for universal health care if we look in the right places.

headline: What Is in the New Brexit Deal?
abstract: Northern Ireland’s border controls and its ability to make trade rules are among the central issues covered in the latest agreement between the E.U. and Britain.
lead_paragraph: The knotty details of Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s new Brexit deal with the European Union are contained in 64 pages of revisions to the old withdrawal agreement, and an accompanying road map to future relations.

headline: Trilobite Fossils Show Conga Line Frozen for 480 Million Years
abstract: The orderly collection of ancient arthropods suggests that complex social behavior goes way back in the history of life on Earth.
lead_paragraph: You probably don’t think twice when you queue up at the grocery store or join a conga line at a wedding. But this type of single-file organization is a sophisticated form of collective social behavior. And as suggested by the children’s song “The Ants Go Marching One-By-One,” humans are not the only animals that appreciate the value of orderly lines.

headline: A Nazi Version of DDT Was Forgotten. Could It Help Fight Malaria?
abstract: Scientists have rediscovered a compound developed by German researchers during World War II. It appears to be more effective and perhaps safer than DDT.
lead_paragraph: What if, after the Allies won World War II, world health officials had employed a Nazi version of DDT against mosquitoes that transmit malaria? Could that persistent disease, which still infects more than 200 million people a year and kills 400,000 of them, have been wiped off the planet?

headline: Can Personality Affect Dementia Risk?
abstract: Extroversion, an energetic disposition, calmness and maturity were associated with a lower risk of dementia 50 years later.
lead_paragraph: Your personality in high school may help predict your risk of dementia decades later.

headline: Review: ‘Watchmen’ Is an Audacious Rorschach Test
abstract: Damon Lindelof’s entertaining comic-book rethink takes on the Big Bad of white supremacy, explosively and sometimes unsteadily.
lead_paragraph: Many a superhero origin story involves exposure to a volatile substance — something dangerous, radioactive, caustic — that can be powerful if mastered, ruinous if uncontrolled.

headline: Can the Left Save Liberalism From Trump?
abstract: America’s dual faith in individual liberty and democracy is under attack by the president’s populism.
lead_paragraph: As the author of a recent book titled “What Was Liberalism?,” I have been chided by critics for joining a chorus of doomsayers. The stock of liberalism certainly looked low in 2016, when I began my research: Donald Trump was elected president and the British decided to leave the European Union. But Mr. Trump’s approval ratings have never climbed above the mid-40s, while the British seem to be regretting their rash decision. The popularity of nativist and reactionary parties in Europe has receded from its high-water mark of two or three years ago. So many liberal Democrats have decided to run against Mr. Trump that they can’t fit in one room.

headline: Woman Who Said Officer Removed Her Tampon Will Receive $205,000
abstract: San Antonio approved the payout to Natalie Simms, 40, who said in a lawsuit that the officer violated her rights during a cavity search on the street in 2016.
lead_paragraph: A police officer searching Natalie Simms for illegal drugs told her to spread her legs on the side of a San Antonio street. To Ms. Simms’s shock, she said in a federal lawsuit, the female officer then shined a flashlight into her underwear, reached in and pulled out her tampon.

headline: ‘Maleficent: Mistress of Evil’ Review: Sleep, Sleep, My Lovelies
abstract: Angelina Jolie returns as the powerful, dangerous fairy in this tame, disappointing follow-up to the 2014 revisionist hit.
lead_paragraph: The happily ever after delivered by Disney’s “Maleficent” has vanished like a puff of bilious smoke, as its unhappy, reactionary sequel makes depressingly clear.

headline: How Guilty Should You Feel About Flying?
abstract: Frequent fliers are responsible for two-thirds of all air travel, and therefore aviation emissions, in the United States, according to a new analysis.
lead_paragraph: Frequent fliers are responsible for two-thirds of all air travel, and therefore aviation emissions, in the United States, according to a new analysis.

headline: Film Club: ‘How Do You Rewrite the ABCs? The Secrets of Songwriting on ‘Sesame Street’’
abstract: How can music be a powerful tool for learning?
lead_paragraph: How can music be a powerful tool for learning?

headline: France’s Far Right Wants to Be an Environmental Party, Too
abstract: Rooted in the idealization of the land and French identity, the National Rally’s approach focuses on the local and dovetails with its push to strengthen borders.
lead_paragraph: HÉNIN-BEAUMONT, France — All of the lighting in the city’s streets and buildings is being changed to environmentally friendly LED bulbs. City workers will come to your house to plant trees — for free — as a natural way to keep cool against the kind of heat waves that swept across Europe over the summer.

headline: Union Says G.M. Strike Won’t End Until Workers Vote on Deal
abstract: The United Automobile Workers said the tentative contract agreement would provide wage increases and improve the prospects of temporary employees.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The longest strike against General Motors in half a century isn’t over yet.

headline: J.Lo
abstract: With the success of “Hustlers,” is Jennifer Lopez finally getting her due?
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez is having a triumphant 2019.  From her Motown tribute at the Grammys to the success of “Hustlers” to the announcement that she’ll be performing at the Super Bowl halftime show, she seems to be enjoying the fruits of her labor from about three decades in show business.  So we want to know: is Jennifer Lopez finally getting her due?

headline: Trump Will Host Next G7 Summit at His Doral Resort
abstract: “It’s almost like they built this facility to host this type of event,” the acting White House chief of staff said, dismissing questions over the propriety of the president’s picking his own hotel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has decided to host the Group of 7 meeting next June at the Trump National Doral near Miami, Mick Mulvaney, the president’s acting chief of staff, said Thursday, a decision that prompted immediate questions about whether it was a conflict of interest for him to choose one of his own properties for a diplomatic event.

headline: Elijah Cummings ‘Lived the American Dream,’ Pelosi Says
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi honored Representative Elijah E. Cummings, describing him as a “revered and respected” colleague. Mr. Cummings, one of the most powerful Democrats in Congress, died on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi honored Representative Elijah E. Cummings, describing him as a “revered and respected” colleague. Mr. Cummings, one of the most powerful Democrats in Congress, died on Thursday.

headline: Bank Regulators Present a Dire Warning of Financial Risks From Climate Change
abstract: The San Francisco Fed  warned that banks, communities and homeowners face significant financial risk from climate change and offered proposals for  banks to do more to help.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Home values could fall significantly.

headline: ‘Kinetta’ Review: Cryptic Seeds of Yorgos Lanthimos’s Imagery
abstract: Set around a Greek seaside resort, the now-acclaimed director’s 2005 movie bears inklings of ideas he would explore more fully later.
lead_paragraph: Before he directed Olivia Colman to an Oscar in “The Favourite” (2018), even before “Dogtooth” won an award at Cannes in 2009 and cemented his reputation as a filmmaker to watch, the Greek-born director Yorgos Lanthimos made “Kinetta,” his solo debut feature. The movie has made scattered appearances in the United States since it premiered in 2005 but is only now receiving its first weeklong run in New York, at the Museum of the Moving Image.

headline: Stephen Colbert Signs a New ‘Late Show’ Deal Through 2023
abstract: The contract extension for the late-night leader keeps him on the job beyond the next election.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert has dominated late-night television during the Trump presidency. Now he’ll get a shot at staying on top well past the 2020 election.

headline: Defiant Zuckerberg Says Facebook Won’t Police Political Speech
abstract: In an address at Georgetown University, the Facebook chief executive called for more free speech — not less — as his company has been assailed for allowing lies and falsehoods to appear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren recently accused Facebook of being a “disinformation-for-profit machine.” Marc Benioff, chief executive of the online software maker Salesforce, said the social network “needs to be held accountable for propaganda on its platform.” And regulators around the world are examining whether to break the company up or clip its power.

headline: Review: A New Opera Pays Poetic Tribute to the Creative Process
abstract: Hannah Lash’s “Desire,” an allegorical chamber work for three singers and the JACK Quartet, had its world premiere in New York.
lead_paragraph: The nature of creativity is an elastic theme: stretched to the length of Fellini’s “8 1/2,” or as succinct as Sondheim’s lyric “Look, I made a hat where there never was a hat.” Like a demon to be exorcised, it seems to appear in every artist’s output, from Plato to the novels of Ben Lerner — often autobiographical, and almost always philosophical.

headline: How the Astros Beat the Yankees in Game 4 of the A.L.C.S.
abstract: The Yankees failed to come up with crucial hits against Zack Greinke and the Astros’ relievers, and Houston took a commanding three-games-to-one lead in the series.
lead_paragraph: Gary Sanchez returned to the dugout to a rain of boos after striking out with the bases loaded. Edwin Encarnacion stared off at nothing in the dugout after producing the same result. Even Gleyber Torres looked to the ground after doing the same.

headline: Born to Trot
abstract: The best-selling author of “Born to Run” thought he knew almost everything about running. Then he met a donkey named Sherman.
lead_paragraph: We had a sick donkey and a ticking clock, so there wasn’t time to fool around. Our friend Tanya McKean, a horse trainer and veterinary assistant, clicked a rope to the donkey’s halter, then looped it under her butt and swayed way back, using her full body weight to persuade the donkey to place his hoof — just one hoof, just for a second — on the road in front of our house.

headline: N.Y.C. Votes to Close Rikers. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: The City Council approved a sweeping $8 billion plan to close the troubled jail complex and replace it with four smaller jails by 2026, an aggressive timeline that will prove challenging.
lead_paragraph: One 886-bed jail will tower over shops and restaurants in Downtown Brooklyn. Another will be next to a subway yard in Queens. In the Bronx, a jail will replace a Police Department tow pound. And another jail will rise in the shadow of City Hall in Manhattan.

headline: Alicia Alonso, Star of Cuba’s National Ballet, Dies at 98
abstract: A ballerina of unusual range and power, she continued to dance into her 70s despite chronic vision problems.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Alonso, who overcame near-blindness to become a charismatic ballerina of unusual range and power, and who helped found what became, with Fidel Castro’s support, the National Ballet of Cuba, died on Thursday in Havana. She was 98.

headline: ‘Jojo Rabbit’ Review: The Third Reich Wasn’t All Fun and Games
abstract: Taika Waititi’s new film mixes farce, fantasy and drama in a Nazi-era coming-of-age story.
lead_paragraph: According to a child psychologist cited in a recent article in The Atlantic, “little boys’ imaginary friends are frequently characters who are more competent than they are, such as superheroes or beings with powers.” That more or less describes the case of 10-year-old Johannes (Roman Griffin Davis), who has dreamed up a powerful pal to boost his confidence at anxious moments, always ready with a fist pump or a shout of “you got this!” Perfectly normal, and even kind of adorable, even though Johannes’s imaginary friend is Adolf Hitler.

headline: François Halard’s Intimate Photographs of Artists’ and Designers’ Living Spaces
abstract: In a new book, the photographer revisits his images of properties owned by Ugo Rondinone, Rick Owens and Dries Van Noten.
lead_paragraph: In a new book, the photographer revisits his images of properties owned by Ugo Rondinone, Rick Owens and Dries Van Noten.

headline: A Look Inside the Homes of Dries Van Noten, Rick Owens and More
abstract: The photographer François Halard’s new book documents the private spaces of some of the world’s most influential creative forces.
lead_paragraph: To understand François Halard’s vision, you need look no further than his own home in the Provençal city of Arles. The French interiors and architecture photographer, who has spent more than 40 years documenting the private spaces of artists and designers, has had a residence in the city since the ’90s. Formerly inhabited by a single aristocratic family, Halard’s early 18th-century hôtel particulier has become a living record of his own tastes and obsessions. With its original hand-painted canvas wall coverings depicting the goddess Athena, displays of African masks, Picasso lithographs, Giacometti plaster lamps and Brassaï prints, it’s a fascinating footnote to his vast body of photographic work. “It was totally decaying when I first saw it,” he says of the building. “It had the same sensibility as the photographs I’d seen of Cy Twombly’s house as a teenager. I fell in love with it.”

headline: Review: At Ballet Theater, Premieres More Pale Than Ghostly
abstract: The fall gala featured two new works: a baffler by Twyla Tharp and a piece d’occasion by Jessica Lang.
lead_paragraph: At American Ballet Theater’s fall gala on Wednesday, along with premieres by Jessica Lang and Twyla Tharp, there was much talk of women. The honoree, Lisa Lutoff-Perlo, the president and chief executive of Celebrity Cruises, drew a parallel between the fight against gender imbalances in her industry and in ballet. Just as she congratulated herself for hiring the first and so far only female captain, so she praised Ballet Theater for its Women’s Movement initiative supporting female choreographers.

headline: Juul Suspends Online Sales of Flavored E-Cigarettes
abstract: Facing multiple inquiries into its marketing practices and its role in the rise of teenage vaping, the company suspended internet access to mango, cucumber and other pods.
lead_paragraph: Juul Labs announced on Thursday that it would temporarily halt online sales of flavored e-cigarettes like mango, products the company had already stopped distributing to retail stores as public outrage mounted over the soaring rate of teenage vaping.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Pay for Stay-at-Home Parents, Getting an Allowance, and Finding Solace
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Our writing prompts often give students a chance to weigh in on the policies, practices and ideas that directly affect teenagers and children. And, whether it’s banned books, free college, active-shooter drills or handling sibling conflicts, we can always count on them to offer invaluable insight.

headline: Charles Jencks, 80, Dies; Helped Define Postmodern Architecture
abstract: His writings announced the death of Modernism, and the public spaces he designed were full of adventurous shapes and ideas.
lead_paragraph: Charles Jencks, whose writing on architecture helped define the field after Modernism, and who put his ideas into practice both in memorable landscape architecture and in overseeing the creation of Maggie’s Centers, buildings specifically designed for cancer patients, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 80.

headline: Remembering U.S Representative Elijah Cummings
abstract: Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the son of sharecroppers, rose to become one of the most powerful Democrats in Congress and a central figure in the impeachment investigation of President Trump. He died on Thursday in Baltimore at 68.
lead_paragraph: Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the son of sharecroppers, rose to become one of the most powerful Democrats in Congress and a central figure in the impeachment investigation of President Trump. He died on Thursday in Baltimore at 68.

headline: What Happens When Employers Can Read Your Facial Expressions?
abstract: The benefits do not come close to outweighing the risks.
lead_paragraph: Facial recognition technology, once a darling of Silicon Valley with applications for policing, spying and authenticating identities, is suddenly under fire. Conservative Republicans like Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio and liberal Democrats like Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York have strongly criticized the technology. San Francisco, Oakland, Berkeley and Somerville, Mass., have barred all of their government agencies, including the police, from using it. And several Democratic candidates for president have raised deep concerns about it, with one, Senator Bernie Sanders, calling for an outright ban for policing.

headline: Our Republic Is Under Attack From the President
abstract: If President Trump doesn’t demonstrate the leadership that America needs, then it is time for a new person in the Oval Office.
lead_paragraph: Last week I attended two memorable events that reminded me why we care so very much about this nation and also why our future may be in peril.

headline: Where Creaminess Is Celebrated
abstract: At Dua Kafe, in the East Village, a parade of dishes embody an enveloping, voluptuous richness that is as much an embrace of life as it is of food.
lead_paragraph: At Dua Kafe, in the East Village, a parade of dishes embody an enveloping, voluptuous richness that is as much an embrace of life as it is of food.

headline: Embracing Life, Love and Rich Fare at Dua Kafe
abstract: This homey East Village restaurant that opened last fall in a former tailor’s shop, showcases the cuisine of the owners’ native Albania.
lead_paragraph: The simpler the dish, the more it demands of the cook. Every gesture counts, even the smallest, like the way Aida Demce, the chef of Dua Kafe in the East Village, places an earthen casserole into the oven while still empty, so it will be hot when the ingredients go in.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: My dentist yesterday asked me how everything is going, and since I had a sharp steel pick jammed into my mouth at the time I just shrugged and gave him a little gesture, hands up. “Same old, same old?” he asked, nodding. “You know what I always say about that. I don’t mind same old same old so long as I’m confident it will continue for the next 40 or 50 years.”

headline: Jerry Brown: Improving U.S.-Russia Relations
abstract: The former California governor objects to an article about Russian patrons of the arts. Also: Freedom of religion; value of the humanities; fashion choices of (female) public figures.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The G.M. Strike Was the Best and the Worst of the Labor Movement
abstract: Despite widespread corruption in the union’s top ranks, the workers made the fight their own.
lead_paragraph: United Automobile Workers leaders voted Thursday on a tentative agreement to end a monthlong walkout by 50,000 workers at General Motors over wages, health insurance premiums and the use of temporary and “tiered” contracts. The accord includes raises and a large ratification bonus and gives temps a path to permanent status — but it also locks in the closing of a beloved factory in Lordstown, Ohio, and two others. Rank-and-file members across the country will now vote on whether to accept the deal and return to work.

headline: Venezuela to Join U.N. Human Rights Council, Despite Track Record
abstract: Activists had urged the General Assembly to vote for Costa Rica instead, citing Venezuela’s political, economic and humanitarian crises.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations General Assembly on Thursday voted to add Venezuela to its 47-member Human Rights Council, despite stringent opposition from activists denouncing the country’s human rights record under its president, Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Senate Fails to Override Trump’s Veto, Keeping Border Emergency in Place
abstract: The vote fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to override President Trump’s veto, allowing him to continue circumventing Congress to fund the border wall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday failed to overturn President Trump’s veto of a resolution that would have terminated the national emergency he declared at the southwestern border. The defeat allows Mr. Trump to continue to defy Congress and divert federal funds to the construction of a border wall, his signature campaign promise.

headline: The Trump Question: What to Do About an Erratic President?
abstract: Readers find the president’s recent actions and statements involving Syria and Ukraine increasingly unsettling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: N.B.A. Commissioner: China Asked Us to Fire Daryl Morey
abstract: Adam Silver, the N.B.A. commissioner, also said the financial fallout from Morey’s tweet supporting Hong Kong protesters has been “substantial.”
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Brexit, Impeachment Inquiry, Syria: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Brexit, Trump, Syria: A lot going on today.
lead_paragraph: Britain and the E.U. agreed on the draft text of a Brexit deal on Thursday, clearing a major hurdle in Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s plan to leave the E.U. by Oct. 31. The agreement sets up a fateful showdown on Saturday, when British Parliament is set to vote on the plan.

headline: Mulvaney Says, Then Denies, That Trump Held Back Ukraine Aid as Quid Pro Quo
abstract: Conflicting comments by the acting White House chief of staff threw  Washington into turmoil.
