abstract: The couple met two years ago through a mutual friend from their respective running groups.
lead_paragraph: Christina Noelle Timoldi and Thomas Dante Visicaro were married Oct. 19 at Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen in Morristown, N.J. Pastor Chris High, who was ordained by Skyline Community Church in Bloomfield N.J., officiated.

headline: Smitha Ramakrishna, Durgesh Das
abstract: The couple met at a wine bar in Washington in June 2015. They were married in Scottsdale, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: Smitha Ramakrishna and Durgesh Das were married Oct. 19 at the JW Marriott Desert Ridge in Scottsdale, Ariz. Kiran Kumar, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Miranda Joseph, Erin Durban
abstract: The couple, both now on the faculty of the University of Minnesota, met in 2006, at the University of Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Miranda Joseph and Erin Leigh Durban were married Oct. 19 at the Campus Club at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Rabbi Michael Adam Latz officiated.

headline: Christopher Ceccolini, Jordan Gratch
abstract: The couple met in Middletown, Conn., at Wesleyan University, from which each graduated.
lead_paragraph: Christopher James Ceccolini and Jordan David Gratch were married Oct. 19 at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass. Joseph Krasinski, an Episcopal priest and friend of the couple, officiated, with Mr. Gratch's uncle, Ariel Gratch, taking part. Their ceremony incorporated Episcopal and Jewish elements.

headline: Nicole Ofeno, Raef Payne
abstract: Her friend, a former high school sweetheart, introduced the bride and groom.
lead_paragraph: Nicole René Ofeno and Raef Payne are to be married Oct. 20 at Union Pool, a bar in Brooklyn. Katie Aldhizer, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

headline: Marichal MacDonald, Aman Gupta
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a campus recruiting event at N.Y.U., when both worked for the Boston Consulting Group.
lead_paragraph: Marichal Lynn MacDonald and Aman Gupta were married Oct. 19. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Mandarin Oriental in New York.

headline: Tegest Saunders, Tyler Bighum
abstract: The couple met in 2014 at the Made in America music festival in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Tegest Lois Saunders and Tyler Brandon Bighum were married Oct. 19 in Philadelphia. The Rev. Michael K. Bighum, the groom’s father and a Baptist minister, officiated at the Liberty View, an events space at the Independence Visitor Center.

headline: Joshua Ghaffari, Mark Tyndall
abstract: The couple met at a holiday party in Washington in 2016, and had their first date the following weekend
lead_paragraph: Joshua Javid Ghaffari and Mark Anthony Tyndall were married Oct. 19 in Washington. Sharon H. Yuan, a friend of the couple who was authorized as a temporary marriage officiant by the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated at President Lincoln’s Cottage.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Watchmen’ and ‘Limetown’
abstract: Damon Lindelof’s take on the comic book series airs on HBO. And Jessica Biel stars in a new sci-fi thriller based on a fiction podcast.
lead_paragraph: WATCHMEN 9 p.m. on HBO. When the 12-part comic book series “Watchmen” came out in 1986 and 1987, it upended the traditional idea of what a superhero could be. In looking back at that comic for The New York Times, Adam Sternbergh wrote that “Watchmen” “felt entirely new, given it meant considering heroes as fallible and complex humans, prone to the array of ugly and shameful emotions recognizable from the real world.” Now, with superhero stories dominating the box office, this new series from the “Lost” and “The Leftovers” creator Damon Lindelof offers a new take on that comic, trading the original’s Cold War themes for those of white supremacy. Regina King stars as Angela Abar, who works with the police as her masked alter ego, Sister Night, while Jeremy Irons and Jean Smart play older versions of original “Watchmen” characters Adrian Veidt and Laurie Juspeczyk.

headline: In a Deeply Split Israel City, Both Sides Urge Unity
abstract: Rosh Haayin almost perfectly reflects the political divide paralyzing Israel, with the religious right on one side and the secular left on the other. But its residents are ready for compromise.
lead_paragraph: ROSH HAAYIN, Israel — On one side of town, it’s falafel and observing Shabbat. On the other, it’s sushi and the yearning for a Saturday morning coffee at a local cafe. Both sides can be guilty of insularity and snobbery.

headline: ‘The Doors Remained Open as a Man’s Voice Came Over the Speaker’
abstract: Confusion over where the F will stop next, going to the game and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Trump Campaign Floods Web With Ads, Raking In Cash as Democrats Struggle
abstract: That campaigns are now being fought largely online is hardly a revelation, yet only one political party seems to have gotten the message.
lead_paragraph: On any given day, the Trump campaign is plastering ads all over Facebook, YouTube and the millions of sites served by Google, hitting the kind of incendiary themes — immigrant invaders, the corrupt media — that play best on platforms where algorithms favor outrage and political campaigns are free to disregard facts.

headline: Jimmy Butler and Neymar: a Bromance Among Superstars
abstract: Butler, new to the Miami Heat this season, has found in soccer a new friend and inspiration for his game in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: After an off-season in which it seemed like the N.B.A. never took a break, The New York Times talked to a few of the league’s stars about some of the other important things in their lives — anything but basketball.

headline: With Room at the Top of the East, the 76ers Could Soar
abstract: Toronto lost Kawhi Leonard, Milwaukee lost Malcolm Brogdon, and Philadelphia lost Jimmy Butler. But Ben Simmons could be the key to The Process giving way to The Finals.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Raptors lost Kawhi Leonard and Danny Green, the Philadelphia 76ers lost Jimmy Butler, the Boston Celtics lost Kyrie Irving and Al Horford, and the Milwaukee Bucks lost Malcolm Brogdon.

headline: The Center of the N.B.A. Universe Moves to Los Angeles
abstract: The Golden State Warriors’ reign is challenged by the Lakers and Clippers and their collection of superstars who could take over the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: It has been six years since a team other than the Golden State Warriors won the Western Conference, and eight since a team other than the Warriors or the San Antonio Spurs won it, but that appears almost certain to change.

headline: As U.S. Leaves Allies in Syria, Kurdish Commander Struggles With Fallout
abstract: Mazlum Kobani, whose Kurdish-led force fought the Islamic State in Syria, fears that a complete United States withdrawal could endanger his people and allow the jihadists to regroup.
lead_paragraph: QAMISHLI, Syria — As United States troops continued their withdrawal from Syria on Sunday, a line of cars carried their routed former allies, terrified civilians and dead bodies out of a pulverized border town that had been besieged by Turkish forces for more than a week.

headline: Swiss Voters Appear to Deliver ‘Green Wave,’ Rebuking Far Right
abstract: In parliamentary elections on Sunday, two Green parties had historic successes, according to projections based on preliminary results. “We expected a Green wave but it’s a tsunami, almost,” one political scientist said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Switzerland’s Green parties appear to have made historic gains in parliamentary elections on Sunday as Swiss voters rebuked the country’s long-dominant right-wing party after a campaign dominated by fears of climate change.

headline: Reframing Negative Self-Talk, One Video at a Time
abstract: Daphne Javitch, who runs the Instagram account Doing Well, gives tips on how you can improve your life.
lead_paragraph: Name: Daphne Javitch

headline: In Hong Kong, Gasoline Bombs, Masks and … Goodbye Letters
abstract: Preparing for the worst, protesters have started writing “last letters” to their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: “When you find this letter, I might have already been arrested or killed.”

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Their Land Became Part of Central Park. They’re Coming Back in a Monument.
abstract: A new sculpture will honor the Lyons family, black activists and property owners who once lived in Seneca Village, a community destroyed by the creation of the park.
lead_paragraph: In Central Park, about a mile from land that was once home to Seneca Village, a mostly black community forced out by the park’s creation in the 1850s, the city is planning a privately funded monument to a revered black family from that time.

headline: He Spent 14 Years in Foster Care. Now He Hopes to Inspire Others.
abstract: After settling in his own apartment, Alexander Santana is working toward a career in motivational speaking.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Santana has wanted to be on his own since he was a child.

headline: Brexit, Syria, Hong Kong: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: A Brexit Battering, and Mark Zuckerberg Plays Defense
abstract: Plus, the monthlong strike at General Motors may be over soon.
lead_paragraph: Need a break from impeachment season? Here’s a quick catch-up on what happened this week on the business and tech fronts, and the news to know heading into Monday.

headline: Indonesian President Is Sworn In Amid High Security and Protest Ban
abstract: Joko Widodo took the oath of office for a second term as he faces public opposition over his willingness to limit personal freedoms and weaken the corruption fight.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The president of Indonesia, Joko Widodo, was sworn in for a second term on Sunday with little public fanfare as security forces were on high alert and protests were prohibited in a sign of mounting public frustration with his government.

headline: A 6-Year-Old Asks Why There Are No Female Toy Soldiers. Now, There Will Be.
abstract: A letter written by Vivian Lord drew a flurry of news media attention and prompted one toymaker to develop, for the first time, a pack of the classic toy soldiers designed to be women.
lead_paragraph: Since their debut in the 1930s, toy soldiers have, at their core, hardly changed. They stand two to three inches tall. They are made of plastic. They carry lethal weapons. And they have been, almost without exception, male.

headline: Pentagon Chief Makes Unannounced Visit to Afghanistan, and Pelosi Does the Same
abstract: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper and the House speaker arrived as the U.S. considers reviving peace talks with the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper traveled to Afghanistan on Sunday, in his first visit to the country since being confirmed as Pentagon chief amid uncertainty about the administration’s strategy following the collapse of peace talks with the Taliban.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make like Gabrielle Hamilton, and make zhug, a vibrant green Yemeni sauce that’s as at home atop hard-boiled eggs as it is on lamb and tofu.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton has been cooking European and Mediterranean food at her restaurant, Prune, in New York for 20 years now, and if her home cooking is free of what she calls “equatorial or hemispheric confines,” she has definitely maintained them at work. “It has just been a nonnegotiable outline of territory on a map,” she wrote for The Times this week, “so that we all know how far we can go and what we are meant to be doing as we cook menu after menu after menu, season after season, six new menus a year.”

headline: On ‘Island’ in Russian Arctic, Arrival of Fast Internet Shakes Political Calm
abstract: Residents of Norilsk long felt isolated from their country’s turbulence. Then a mining company strung a fiber-optic cable across 600 miles of tundra.
lead_paragraph: NORILSK, Russia — On a screen, the California sun beams through the palm fronds and the Walk of Fame gleams underfoot. This island of mines and smokestacks in the tundra has high-speed internet now, so Andrei Kurchukov watches videos about America.

headline: For the Yankees, Good Is Not Good Enough in the Age of the Astros
abstract: The 2010s will end without a pennant for the Yankees, the first time that has happened since the 1910s.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It happened so gradually that it was easy to miss. But when Jose Altuve’s searing drive crashed off the facade above left field here late Saturday night, it was finally official: The mighty Yankees, the most successful team in baseball history, have lost in the postseason more often than they have won.

headline: Fort Worth Police Have More Violence to Answer For, Residents Say
abstract: Black residents of the city complained about mistreatment by the police long before Atatiana Jefferson’s death. “I never was supposed to be arrested,” said one woman. “I was the caller.”
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Before there was Atatiana Jefferson, there was Jackie Craig, a black woman who called the police to report that her white neighbor had grabbed her son — and found herself pinned to the ground by the officer who responded.

headline: Bolivia’s Evo Morales Faces Runoff, Early Election Returns Show
abstract: A once wildly popular leader faced broad opposition as he sought to stay in office until 2025.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia —  President Evo Morales of Bolivia on Sunday appeared to fall short of  outright victory in his quest for a fourth consecutive term, giving the opposition a viable chance to defeat him in a December runoff.

headline: Review: Christopher Rouse Leaves a Haunting Final Symphony
abstract: The composer died last month. But not before finishing his Sixth Symphony, which premiered on Friday in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — “I am known for writing very dark, disturbing music,” the composer Christopher Rouse, who died last month at 70, once said. “It just happened that every time I had a piece to write, somebody died whose death had a big effect on me.”

headline: 3 Soldiers Killed in Training Accident at Fort Stewart in Georgia
abstract: The soldiers were in a Bradley Fighting Vehicle that rolled over into water. Three other soldiers were hurt.
lead_paragraph: Three soldiers were killed and three others injured in a training accident at an Army base in Georgia on Sunday, an official said.

headline: Nick Tosches, 69, Fiery Music Writer and Biographer, Dies
abstract: He brought a brash style to coverage of the rock world in the late 1960s and ’70s, then applied similar skills to novels and books on Dean Martin and Sonny Liston.
lead_paragraph: Nick Tosches, who started out in the late 1960s as a brash music writer with a taste for the fringes of rock and country, then bent his eclectic style to biographies of figures like Dean Martin and Sonny Liston and to hard-to-classify novels, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69.

headline: Is Trump a Pathological Narcissist?
abstract: Readers offer their answers. One jokes that “he gives narcissism a bad name.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Women Breaking the Silence on Miscarriages
abstract: Three women who lost babies discuss their experiences and the emotions they felt. Also: Don’t give up on urine tests.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mick Mulvaney Struggles to Explain Comments on Ukraine
abstract: The acting White House chief of staff admitted he did not have a “perfect press conference,” but said the administration did not tie military aid to investigating Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, tried again on Sunday to back off assertions he made to reporters last week that the Trump administration had held up an aid package to Ukraine because the president wanted the country to investigate Democrats, acknowledging he did not have a “perfect press conference.”

headline: FIFA Set to Reward China With World Cup for Clubs
abstract: Overcoming European opposition, world soccer’s governing body plans to send the first edition of its expanded world club championship to China in 2021.
lead_paragraph: FIFA plans to grant China the rights to host the inaugural version of its expanded Club World Cup, a 24-team tournament scheduled for 2021 that will feature some of the world’s biggest club teams and provide a significant cash infusion for world soccer’s governing body.

headline: Vacant: 600-Year-Old Job With Top Pay. Perks Include Monarch’s Bed.
abstract: As speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow won fame and helped lawmakers shape Brexit. Now he’s quitting, and nine lawmakers want his job.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For more than 600 years, it has been one of the top jobs in Britain. Perks include an apartment next to Big Ben and better pay than the prime minister. And, if you like the sound of your own voice — as the incumbent seems to — there is the added bonus of hearing it broadcast, sometimes around the globe.

headline: Review: Susanna Malkki Returns to the New York Philharmonic
abstract: In her third appearance with the orchestra, she proved once again why she’s one of the most exciting and in-demand conductors of her generation.
lead_paragraph: Susanna Malkki is one of the most exciting and in-demand conductors of her generation. So it was discouraging, when she returned to the New York Philharmonic’s podium on Friday night — after a belated debut in 2015 and a second engagement last year — to see so many empty seats in David Geffen Hall.

headline: Review: Helen Mirren Wears the Crown (This Time, Russia’s)
abstract: An actress with extensive experience playing female rulers takes on one of the most powerful in HBO’s “Catherine the Great.”
lead_paragraph: Helen Mirren won an Oscar, deservedly, for playing Elizabeth II in “The Queen” in 2007. Beginning Monday on HBO, she plays another misunderstood woman occupying a throne — though a notably less lonely one this time — in the mini-series “Catherine the Great.”

headline: For 24 Hours Onstage, Alia Shawkat Felt Great to Feel ‘Shameless’
abstract: The “Arrested Development” actress made quite the New York stage debut, repeating one fiery scene opposite about 100 different actors in “The Second Woman.”
lead_paragraph: The five-minute scene Alia Shawkat had to perform in her New York theater debut, “The Second Woman,” was fairly straightforward.

headline: Dramatic Footage Shows Coach Disarming and Then Hugging Student
abstract: A security expert said of the coach’s actions: “I think it says a lot about his character. It’s a remarkable feat.”
lead_paragraph: The shotgun was hidden under a garment bag as the student entered the school.

headline: In Maine, a Celebrity Domestic Violence Case Continues to Send Out Ripples
abstract: Patrisha McLean, whose singer-songwriter husband, Don McLean, faced charges of domestic violence, is organizing Maine women to tell their own stories. And he is protesting.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Maine — When the audience had gotten settled in their chairs, balancing Ritz crackers and Styrofoam cups on their laps, Patrisha McLean got to her feet and began to talk about what went on behind closed doors during the 29 years when she was married.

headline: Despite Litany of Failures, Boris Johnson Is in Striking Distance of Brexit Success
abstract: The prime minister will try again this week to get his draft deal through Parliament. He has one key thing going for him: a divided opposition.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He suspended Parliament and was rebuked by Britain’s top court. He purged his party and lost a string of votes. After trying to strong-arm lawmakers into supporting his new Brexit plan, Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to ask for a delay for withdrawal from the European Union, a request he had vowed never to make.

headline: Mark Esperanto? Trump Misnames His Defense Secretary in Tweet
abstract: Even for a president who often lards his online missives with typos, caps-lock abuses and errant exclamation points, Sunday’s Twitter missive on Syria contained an outsize number of errors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump shared an update on Sunday from his defense secretary that outlined “minor skirmishes” between Turkish and Kurdish fighters in northern Syria as American troops make their way out of the area. It might have passed by with little notice in the rushing current of Mr. Trump’s Twitter stream, but for one thing.

headline: Paul Polak, Entrepreneur for Those Living on $2 a Day, Dies at 86
abstract: A former psychiatrist and real-estate speculator turned to helping the poor make money by selling foot pumps, charcoal and clean water.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul Polak, a former psychiatrist who became an entrepreneur and an inventor with a focus on helping the world’s poorest people create profitable small businesses, died on Oct. 10 in Denver. He was 86.

headline: Will the U.K. Ever Get Closure on Brexit?
abstract: A lack of trust in Boris Johnson has delayed proceedings, once again.
lead_paragraph: “Super Saturday” was to have been the decisive moment for Brexit, the first Parliament session to be held on a Saturday since the Falklands War. Members of Parliament were to cast a “meaningful vote” on the surprise deal Prime Minister Boris Johnson brought back from Brussels last week. Proponents of Brexit sensed closure, while opponents took to the streets outside Westminster by the hundreds of thousands to demand a new referendum.

headline: Which Way to ‘Starry Night’? A Reimagined MoMA Opens to the Public
abstract: Drawn by free admission on Sunday, nearly 10,000 visitors let themselves get lost in the Museum of Modern Art’s larger, reorganized spaces.
lead_paragraph: Tania Thomas, one of the first visitors to see the renovated and expanded Museum of Modern Art, had the new floor map in hand and an audio guide. It wasn’t enough.

headline: Beaten and Left in Solitary Confinement, He Thought He Would Die
abstract: Transferred off Rikers Island, he was among four young men who won a $980,000 settlement after a lawsuit described brutal beatings at an Albany jail.
lead_paragraph: Davon Washington thought he was going to die last year while handcuffed and shackled inside a small, dark cell in an upstate jail more than a hundred miles north of Rikers Island in New York City.

headline: Yankees Are Left to Wonder How to Clear That Final Hurdle
abstract: The franchise’s bullpen-centric formula and plans at other positions could face review this off-season as the team decides on players like Aroldis Chapman, Brett Gardner and Didi Gregorius.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The visitor’s clubhouse at Minute Maid Park just before midnight here on Saturday was so quiet that sniffles and hugs made up the only sounds.

headline: ‘Maleficent’ Sequel Disappoints at Box Office
abstract: While Disney’s “Maleficent: Mistress of Evil” led in ticket sales, its earnings didn’t do much to offset its considerable costs.
lead_paragraph: Though Disney’s fantasy sequel “Maleficent: Mistress of Evil” claimed the top spot at the box office this weekend, it fell below expectations.

headline: U.S.A. Triathlon Embraces CBD
abstract: The national governing body for triathlon will become the first organization of its type to sign a deal with a company that sells products containing cannabidiol.
lead_paragraph: The sports industry’s embrace of cannabis products is continuing to evolve as U.S.A. Triathlon has become the first national governing body of an American sport to make a sponsorship deal with a company that sells products containing cannabidiol, or CBD.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Says She Will Release a Plan to Finance ‘Medicare for All’
abstract: Ms. Warren had been criticized for sidestepping questions about whether she would raise taxes on the middle class to help finance “Medicare for all.”
lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts said on Sunday that she would release a plan to finance “Medicare for all” in the coming weeks, bowing to critics who have pressed her to explain how she would pay for a single-payer health care system.

headline: Biggest Late-Night Guests Now Bring a News Angle, Not a Movie Clip
abstract: Stormy news cycles, and an audience thirsty for political commentary, have changed what works on TV at 11:35 p.m.
lead_paragraph: The formula for success on the big late-night network television shows used to be simple. Keep it light, keep it moving and book a major star, preferably one in the news.

headline: Brexit, Hong Kong, Cryptocurrency: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Brexit Deja Vu.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What to Know About the Landmark Opioid Trial Starting Monday
abstract: Here’s a guide to the first federal case in which local governments seek redress for the financial toll of a 20-year epidemic.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Two decades after the onset of an opioid epidemic that led to the deaths of 400,000 Americans, the first landmark federal opioid trial is set to begin Monday, after furious, last-minute settlement talks between two powerful groups of plaintiffs and five drug industry defendants faltered.

headline: Estate Tax Can Pay Off for States, Even if the Superrich Flee
abstract: New research shows that even if wealthy residents move away, the revenue at death from those who stay outweighs any loss in income taxes.
lead_paragraph: Arkansas reaped a windfall when a Walmart founder, James L. Walton, known as Bud, died in 1995 with a fortune estimated by Forbes at $1.65 billion in today’s money. The next year, state estate tax receipts jumped 425 percent, to about $183 million in current dollars.

headline: Emmett Till Memorial Has a New Sign. This Time, It’s Bulletproof.
abstract: The sign, which is the fourth to replace others that were vandalized, is made of steel and weighs 500 pounds.
lead_paragraph: Emmett Till’s family stood on the shore of the Tallahatchie River just outside of Glendora, Miss., on Saturday. It was there, that, it is believed, the body of 14-year-old Emmett was pulled from the water after he had been kidnapped, tortured and lynched nearly 65 years ago.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 21, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: Thomas D’Alesandro, 90, Ex-Mayor of Baltimore and Pelosi’s Brother, Dies
abstract: He was elected president of the Baltimore City Council in 1963 before serving as mayor from 1967 to 1971.
lead_paragraph: Thomas J. D’Alesandro III, a former Baltimore mayor, City Council president and the brother of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, died on Sunday at his North Baltimore home. He was 90.

headline: Want Trump to Go? Take to the Streets
abstract: Another moment for public protest has arrived.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 9, 2016, the day after Donald Trump’s election, Obamacare looked to be doomed. Millions of Americans, it seemed, were going to lose their health insurance.

headline: ‘There Is No Hope’: Crisis Pushes Haiti to Brink of Collapse
abstract: Haitians say the violence and economic stagnation stemming from a clash between the president and the opposition are worse than anything they have ever experienced.
lead_paragraph: LÉOGÂNE, Haiti — The small hospital was down to a single day’s supply of oxygen and had to decide who would get it: the adults recovering from strokes and other ailments, or the newborns clinging to life in the neonatal ward.

headline: They Are Not the Resistance. They Are Not a Cabal. They Are Public Servants.
abstract: Let us now praise these not-silent heroes.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is right: The deep state is alive and well. But it is not the sinister, antidemocratic cabal of his fever dreams. It is, rather, a collection of patriotic public servants — career diplomats, scientists, intelligence officers and others — who, from within the bowels of this corrupt and corrupting administration, have somehow remembered that their duty is to protect the interests, not of a particular leader, but of the American people.

headline: Bases Loaded
abstract: Joe Deeney pitches us the first puzzle of the week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Joe Deeney’s crossword marks his fifth appearance in The New York Times, and he is shaping up to be a constructor who lives on both ends of the solving week. This will be his second Monday puzzle; he has a Tuesday, and he also has two Saturday puzzles under his belt.

headline: Erdogan’s Ambitions Go Beyond Syria. He Says He Wants Nuclear Weapons.
abstract: A month before invading Kurdish areas in Syria, Turkey’s president said he “cannot accept” the West’s restrictions that keep him from a bomb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, wants more than control over a wide swath of Syria along his country’s border. He says he wants the Bomb.

headline: Pelosi Has History and the Constitution at Her Back
abstract: When the president runs amok, the House has a congressional duty to step in and provide oversight.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Republicans have insisted that House Democrats take a vote to open a formal impeachment inquiry before engaging in thoroughgoing oversight of the administration’s activities related to Ukraine. This is a political calculation — relying on faulty analysis of the Clinton impeachment — that a formal inquiry will backfire on Democrats.

headline: G.M. Contract Terms May Be a Tougher Fit for Its Rivals
abstract: General Motors made cost concessions to get the union to accept the shutdown of three plants — a priority that Ford and Fiat Chrysler don’t have.
lead_paragraph: The tentative contract that General Motors has worked out with the United Automobile Workers union is going to raise the automaker’s cost of labor and require a significant cash outlay.

headline: After Soldiers Surrender El Chapo’s Son, a Shocked Mexican City Sighs With Relief
abstract: Though the Mexican authorities have been criticized for releasing one of El Chapo’s sons back to gunmen, residents of Culiacán say the decision saved lives.
lead_paragraph: CULIACÁN, Mexico — In the days following the siege of the city of Culiacán by the Sinaloa cartel, residents were overcome with relief: Relief that the terror is over. That more people did not die. And that government forces, which had captured the son of the former cartel leader Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as “El Chapo,” handed back their target rather than keep waging  a bloody battle.

headline: Justice Department Distances Itself From Giuliani
abstract: In an unusual statement, a spokesman said department officials would not have met with President Trump’s personal lawyer had they known his associates were under investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department distanced itself on Sunday from Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, declaring that department officials would not have met with Mr. Giuliani to discuss one of his clients had they known that federal prosecutors in New York were investigating two of his associates.

headline: Trump Said to Favor Leaving a Few Hundred Troops in Eastern Syria
abstract: The president appears to be trying to balance competing impulses: bringing troops home while ensuring that efforts to contain ISIS will continue — and answering withering criticism for his Syria policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is leaning in favor of a new Pentagon plan to keep a small contingent of American troops in eastern Syria, perhaps numbering about 200, to combat the Islamic State and block the advance of Syrian government and Russian forces into the region’s coveted oil fields, a senior administration official said on Sunday.

headline: No, We Won’t Just ‘Get Over It’
abstract: We dare not fail this test of our constitutional government.
lead_paragraph: For weeks Donald Trump and his defenders have insisted that his decision to hold up aid to Ukraine was not dependent on that nation investigating Trump’s political opponents in the United States. They all insisted that there was no quid pro quo.

headline: Why Trump Dropped His Idea to Hold the G7 at His Own Hotel
abstract: He knew Democrats would criticize him. When Republicans started doing so, he changed his mind.
lead_paragraph: He knew he was inviting criticism by choosing his own luxury golf club in Miami for the site of a gathering of world leaders at the Group of 7 summit in June, President Trump told his aides opposed to the choice, and he was prepared for the inevitable attack from Democrats.

headline: Explosives Fail to Take Down Crane at Site of Collapsed Hard Rock Hotel
abstract: One crane came down completely, but a second one remained dangling over the side of a building in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: The demolition of two construction cranes that were in danger of falling didn’t go exactly as planned on Sunday at the site of a building collapse in New Orleans: One was left dangling high above a city street.

headline: Review: ‘American Utopia’ Is David Byrne’s Neighborhood
abstract: This jubilant production, choreographed by Annie-B Parson, transforms an icon of alienation into a cosmically cozy senior statesman.
lead_paragraph: Won’t you be his neighbor?

headline: ‘Watchmen’ Series Premiere Recap: Exhilarating Confusion
abstract: The pilot is a profoundly destabilizing experience for newcomers and fans of the original alike, delivering on ideas and spectacle in equal measure.
lead_paragraph: In the lead-up to “Watchmen,” Damon Lindelof’s “remix,” as he has described it, of the graphic novel by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, the question on many viewers’ minds has been, “Should I read the book?” Judging by the explainers and pocket histories in culture pages across the media — including this excellent one by The Times’s Adam Sternbergh — there’s some agreement that the context is helpful, since the events in that book are fully integrated into the TV show.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 9: Wildfire
abstract: Noah’s career is going up in flames, just like parts of California.
lead_paragraph: To borrow a term from the work of Noah Solloway, his career as a writer is experiencing a descent. A calamitously rapid one, in fact, given the years of bad behavior he got away with until now.

headline: Chile Unrest Spreads, With 15 Deaths Reported in Violence
abstract: The protests started over a small transit fare increase, but have gained momentum over stagnant wages despite economic growth.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO — The Chilean capital was virtually paralyzed on Monday as streets were blocked by protesters out for the fourth day in a row, subway stations that were ransacked remained shut, and stores, banks and schools were also shuttered.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 4, Episode 3: ’Twas the Night Before Christmas
abstract: This week’s episode offered a whole new level of insight into Whiterose. It was also extremely sexy.
lead_paragraph: Risk is the essence of romance. A wise woman told me that once; I live with her now, so I’m inclined to believe she knew what she was talking about. Exposed and vulnerable, we reach out to another person and hope they’ll reach back. We put ourselves at their mercy in hopes of connection. In some cases, we put ourselves at the mercy of a world that will punish us for that connection should it be discovered. There is some pain we suffer gladly because it’s the vessel in which pleasure comes.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Condemnation by Republicans Drove Reversal on Meeting Site
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 21, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “It is really just about him ordering the country to pay him money. It is just indefensible.”

headline: No Corrections: October 21, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 21, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 21, 2019.

headline: Brexit, Swiss Elections, Russia: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Dallas Tornado Leaves Trail of Damage; Storm Causes Panic at Memphis Airport
abstract: A tornado destroyed buildings in Dallas and cut electricity to tens of thousands of people. The storm system is moving east, and has killed a man in Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: A dangerous storm system, with damaging winds and large hail, cut a destructive path across part of the southeastern United States on Monday, after spawning a tornado that barreled through the Dallas-Fort Worth area late Sunday, and others in rural areas of Oklahoma and Missouri. The violent weather was blamed for at least four deaths.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Cosmos’ and ‘Catherine the Great’
abstract: Andrzej Zulawski’s final film is streaming on Kanopy. And a mini-series starring Helen Mirren makes its debut.
lead_paragraph: COSMOS (2015). Stream on Kanopy. Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. The final film directed by the great Polish director Andrzej Zulawski adapts Witold Gombrowicz’s 1965 ontologically unsettling novel. “Mr. Zulawski, following Gombrowicz’s lead, blithely discards narrative logic, and delights in finding images that will do justice to this writer’s manic inventiveness,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. “Some images are hauntingly grotesque — like the dead birds hanging across paths in a forest — while others seem to pulse with occult, Buñuelian sexual and religious significance.” The film’s images revolve around Witold (Jonathan Genet) and Fuchs (Johan Libéreau), two young law students, and their encounters with various residents of a Lisbon boardinghouse.

headline: Mitt Romney Admits to Having a Secret Twitter Account, ‘Pierre Delecto’
abstract: The senator acknowledged that he had an account, which he used to monitor political conversations online and defend himself.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, the senator from Utah, former Republican presidential candidate and former Massachusetts governor, is also, apparently, the man behind a Twitter account that uses the moniker “Pierre Delecto.”

headline: How to Give People Advice They’ll Be Delighted to Take
abstract: Evaluate, collaborate and support.
lead_paragraph: A friend recently approached me in distress saying she wasn’t sure if she should dump her boyfriend or not. With wide, wet eyes, she asked what I think she should do. It gave me pause. Of course, I thought she should get rid of the guy, but I didn’t want to put our relationship at risk in case she stayed with him after I shared my opinion.

headline: Word + Quiz: tactile
abstract: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: In the N.F.L., Change Is Inevitable. Just Not Atop the Standings.
abstract: Many of last season’s division winners are leading yet again after reinventing themselves.
lead_paragraph: The Vikings’ offense was on the verge of mutiny, but then Kirk Cousins threw eleventy zillion touchdown passes (O.K., 10, after throwing only three in Minnesota’s first four games). The Dallas Cowboys had the most complete offensive roster in the N.F.C., but then they imploded in three consecutive losses. The Miami Dolphins seemed destined to earn the No. 1 overall draft pick, but then the Cincinnati Bengals started playing, too.

headline: Inside the Last, Desperate Days of de Blasio’s 2020 Campaign
abstract: “We both knew that this was a Don Quixote mission,” said one donor who was solicited by Mayor Bill de Blasio as the end drew near.
lead_paragraph: As the end of his presidential bid beckoned last month, Mayor Bill de Blasio furiously worked the phones, trying to forestall the inevitable.

headline: Will Canada Forgive Justin Trudeau?
abstract: Buffeted by controversy, Canada’s prime minister is seeking a second term in a tight race.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has crisscrossed his vast country from the Pacific to the Atlantic coasts, and all the way up to the Arctic, shaking hands, cradling babies and posing for his signature selfies — sometimes doing all three at once.

headline: Our Predictions for the 2019-20 N.B.A. Season
abstract: For once, it’s hard to gauge what is possible and who — Ben Simmons? Anthony Davis? Russell Westbrook? — will wow us all.
lead_paragraph: No one word is sufficient to describe the happenings in the N.B.A. over the past six months. From the crowning of an unexpected champion to an off-season of stunning free agency moves, the league has upended so much of what we had come to know to be true.

headline: Marijuana and Vaping: Shadowy Past, Dangerous Present
abstract: A technology initially promoted to help cigarette smokers has transformed marijuana use, too. Now, with cases of severe lung illness rising, health investigators are warning people to stop vaping cannabis.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, a divisive debate has raged in the United States over the health consequences of nicotine e-cigarettes. During the same time, vaping of a more contentious substance has been swiftly growing, with scant notice from public health officials.

headline: How the Louvre’s Leonardo Blockbuster Shows a Master’s Progress
abstract: Eight highlights from the exhibition plot Leonardo da Vinci’s trajectory as an artist and show the breadth of his talents.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — No institution in the world owns more Leonardo da Vincis than the Louvre. There are five paintings in its collections — including, most famously, the Mona Lisa, which the Renaissance artist had with him, along with two other masterpieces, when he died in France in 1519.

headline: Coddling of ‘Gold-Spoon’ Children Shakes South Korea’s Political Elite
abstract: Students angered over accusations of favoritism helped set off large protests that forced President Moon Jae-in to apologize and his justice minister to resign.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The biggest political crisis for President Moon Jae-in of South Korea — weeks of large protests that have tarnished his image and forced his justice minister to resign — started with an obscure medical research paper.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘When the Student Newspaper Is the Only Daily Paper in Town’
abstract: In this lesson, we learn about how student journalists across the country have stepped in to help fill a void after local newspapers have closed.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “When the Student Newspaper Is the Only Daily Paper in Town”

headline: Australian Media Redact Their Front Pages to Protest Secrecy Laws
abstract: Print, online and on-air news outlets joined together in a concerted campaign to pressure the Australian government to soften its restrictive secrecy laws.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian news outlets from across the political spectrum, including Rupert Murdoch’s tabloids, united on Monday to protest the country’s encroaching secrecy laws. Newspapers ran redacted articles on their front pages in a show of solidarity, and online and on the air, prominent journalists called for change.

headline: Patti LuPone on Getting Bullied by Broadway. And Why She Keeps Coming Back.
abstract: The actress on her hard-won tough-as-nails reputation, “Evita” and the changing nature of celebrity.
lead_paragraph: The actress on her hard-won tough-as-nails reputation, “Evita” and the changing nature of celebrity.

headline: The Return of the 'Blob': Hawaii's Reefs Threatened by Marine Heat Wave
abstract: A researcher likened the current heat wave to one that formed in 2014 and caused the first known mass bleaching of corals around Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: A researcher likened the current heat wave to one that formed in 2014 and caused the first known mass bleaching of corals around Hawaii.

headline: Your Tales of Subway Escalator Hell
abstract: It can sometimes feel like the escalators and elevators in your subway station are never working properly. Here’s what it looks like when your escalator breaks down during your commute.
lead_paragraph: It can sometimes feel like the escalators and elevators in your subway station are never working properly. Here’s what it looks like when your escalator breaks down during your commute.

headline: The Silent Heart Attack You Didn’t Know You Had
abstract: Millions of people are unaware that they have had a silent myocardial infarction and are at risk of having another attack that could cause severe damage or death.
lead_paragraph: When my Aunt Gert suffered a heart attack in her mid-70s, the examining doctor told her that it was not her first. Tests done to assess the damage to her heart revealed a section of dead muscle from a previous unrecognized heart attack. Sometime in the past, she had had what doctors call a “silent myocardial infarction,” or S.M.I., silent in that any symptoms she might have had at the time did not register as related to her heart and were not brought to medical attention.

headline: Are Some Youth Sports Too Intense?
abstract: Should there be limits on how much time students devote to sports each week?
lead_paragraph: Do you know children or teenagers who are on sports teams so competitive that they spend several days a week nearly every week of the year playing?

headline: Steps to Prevent Dementia May Mean Taking Actual Steps
abstract: Brain-training apps can’t match the several ways that exercise benefits the mind, research shows.
lead_paragraph: To ward off age-related cognitive decline, you may be tempted to turn to brain training apps. Last year, consumers spent nearly $2 billion on them, some of which claim to improve cognitive skills.

headline: She Made Thinking Exciting: The Life and Work of Susan Sontag
abstract: “Sontag,” Benjamin Moser’s new biography, is a skilled, lively book that works hard to capture a severely complex person.
lead_paragraph: SONTAG

headline: 5 Monday Must-Reads
abstract: Is the G7 going to meet at Trump’s Florida resort? Nope. Chinese protesters write final goodbyes. Tensions rise in Fort Worth. Memories of a dangerous New Jersey amusement park. And more.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. It just seems to sneak up on you. Here are a few great articles you might have missed while you were out having fun this weekend. So sit with your #saddesklunch and read them.

headline: When Teen Drinking Becomes a Disorder
abstract: Why are some adolescents more vulnerable than others to excessive and risky alcohol use?
lead_paragraph: It’s a pretty safe bet that most of our children, in high school and in college, will be in social situations in which people drink in unwise and sometimes downright dangerous ways.

headline: Discovering Mumbai’s Art Deco Treasures
abstract: The city has the world’s second-largest collection of the buildings, second only to Miami. But even as they gain attention, they are threatened.
lead_paragraph: Every evening, crowds swarm Marine Drive, the iconic waterfront on the southern tip of Mumbai, India’s financial capital.

headline: With ‘Joker’ a Box-Office Sensation, Can Joaquin Phoenix Win the Oscar?
abstract: The three-time nominee has a strong chance at finally winning, but there are a lot of factors at play, including a strong rival.
lead_paragraph: “Joker” was the first big winner of this year’s award season, but will it have the last laugh?

headline: ‘Get Over It’? Why Political Influence in Foreign Policy Matters
abstract: Readers have asked The New York Times why asking another nation for help ahead of an election is such a serious issue. Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A July 25 call between President Trump and the president of Ukraine is the basis for an impeachment inquiry into whether Mr. Trump withheld American military aid until Ukrainian officials investigated former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son, Hunter.

headline: Why Black Homeowners in Brooklyn Are Being Victimized by Fraud
abstract: Deed theft, or stealing the title to a house, has become a worrisome crime in Brooklyn, targeting rapidly gentrifying communities of color.
lead_paragraph: Broadies Byas’s home is a hidden gem. From the outside, it looks unassuming, if somewhat neglected.

headline: Shopping for Bathroom Sconces
abstract: Because the most important source of light in your bathroom isn’t the ceiling fixture.
lead_paragraph: Of all the light sources in a bathroom, the sconces over the sink are the most important.

headline: Canada’s Election Is Today. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces the political battle of his life in a tight race.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has canoed to a campaign event, taken countless selfies and braved town halls with sometimes angry voters. One opponent — Jagmeet Singh — hopped on an orange tractor in northern Ontario at a plowing competition; his chief rival — Andrew Scheer — smiled with babies at a ribfest in Prince Edward Island.

headline: Meet the Man Who Draws Love Notes for The Times
abstract: Brian Rea has illustrated the Modern Love column for the Styles section for nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: In Search of Hilma af Klint, Who Upended Art History, But Left Few Traces
abstract: In and around Stockholm, the secretive painter — whose bold abstract works predated Kandinsky’s — lived a life of spiritual yearning that shaped her artistic career.
lead_paragraph: It seemed a daunting challenge to follow in the footsteps of a secretive artist who destroyed all her correspondence more than a decade before her death in 1944. Someone who, between 1906 and 1915, had created an astonishing cache of nearly 200 novel paintings — bold abstract compositions as large as 10 by 8 feet — mostly in a small, shared studio in the heart of a major European city, with virtually no record of anyone seeing or discussing the work.

headline: Quantum Computing Is Coming, Bit by Qubit
abstract: With transmons and entanglement, scientists strive to put subatomic weirdness to work on the human scale.
lead_paragraph: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y. — A bolt from the maybe-future struck the technology community in late September. A paper by Google computer scientists appeared on a NASA website, claiming that an innovative new machine called a quantum computer had demonstrated “quantum supremacy.”

headline: The Army Is Looking for a Few Good Art Experts
abstract: A new reserve group, inspired by the Monuments Men of the World War II era, will aim to protect antiquities and important cultural sites in war zones.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that the war-ravaged nations where American soldiers have been enmeshed in conflict for nearly two decades are home to many of civilization’s oldest and most prized antiquities and cultural treasures.

headline: Be Humble, and Proudly, Psychologists Say
abstract: Humility is not the boldest of personality traits, but it’s an important one, studies find. And it’s hard to fake.
lead_paragraph: In their day jobs, research psychologists don’t typically need safety goggles, much less pith helmets or Indiana Jones bullwhips. There’s no rappelling into caves to uncover buried scrolls, no prowling the ocean floor in spherical subs, no tuning of immense, underground magnets in the hunt for ghostly subatomic particles.

headline: Can Colleges Police Sports Betting? Some Are Trying
abstract: Purdue, St. Joseph’s and Villanova have banned students from betting on their schools’ teams, but other universities are seeking more of a middle ground. No one is sure whose approach is right.
lead_paragraph: In Mississippi, university officials sent state gambling regulators names for a “watch list” for big bets. Iowa colleges have simply kept teaching their athletes longstanding, narrowly applied rules on sports wagering. And in Indiana and Pennsylvania, some universities flatly banned students and employees from betting on their school’s athletics events.

headline: As Homelessness Surges in California, So Does a Backlash
abstract: Tent encampments across California are testing residents’ tolerance and compassion as street conditions deteriorate.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California here.]

headline: Desperate Pleas to Free Women and Children From ISIS Camps in Syria
abstract: The violence that has followed an American pullback has intensified questions about what duty nations have to citizens detained abroad, even those affiliated with a terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — When Kamalle Dabboussy learned this month that President Trump was removing troops from northeastern Syria, he pulled over in his car and wept.

headline: MoMA Reopening: Everything You Need to Know
abstract: Monday: MoMA is bigger and more demanding. It's also more fun, says our art critic.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Much Do You Know About Oman?
abstract: Can you find Oman on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with more than 4.6 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Oman on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with more than 4.6 million people?

headline: What We Learned in N.F.L. Week 7
abstract: Aaron Rodgers and the Packers exploded against the Raiders, the 49ers stayed undefeated and Lamar Jackson outplayed Russell Wilson in the Ravens’ huge win.
lead_paragraph: Even as the San Francisco 49ers improved to 6-0, matching New England for the best record in the N.F.L., Aaron Rodgers and the Green Bay Packers made it clear that they should be in the conversation as one of the league’s best teams. Week 7 offered quite a bit of scoring — outside of San Francisco’s nearly unwatchable win over Washington.

headline: Justin Trudeau, Opioid Trial, N.F.L.: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Canada Isn’t So Different. It Could Go Populist Too.
abstract: How long can politicians avoid real talk about how globalization has failed the middle class?
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It has become taboo in Canada’s established political circles to question what the world trading order has done to the country’s vaunted middle class. Vocally criticizing free trade deals, such as the recently negotiated United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, and denouncing them as harmful to middle-income workers, risks being ridiculed as “nativist” or “retrograde.” Problem is, trade liberalization has been at the root of decline for millions of Canadians over the past 30 years.

headline: How Florida Republicans Are Talking About Impeachment
abstract: Working-class Republicans see Donald Trump as a white businessman who made a lot of money. The investigations only strengthen their kinship with him.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — A few weeks ago, I sat on a park bench, watching my 11-year-old twins pass a soccer ball and push their friends on a tire swing. I turned to the mother of my daughters’ classmate to talk about the second whistle-blower coming forward about President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine.

headline: Trapped in Syria, Part 1: A Father’s Fight
abstract: He says his daughter was tricked by her husband into joining ISIS. We hear about one man’s battle to bring his family home from a war zone.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: This Is the True End Of Pax Americana
abstract: Mr. Trump is taking a wrecking ball to the world order.
lead_paragraph: The sudden decision to pull about 1,000 American troops out of northern Syria, and leave Kurdish allies in the lurch after they did so much to fight off the Islamic State, has already had terrible consequences. The Kurds have been forced to make a deal with the murderous regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, hoping it will protect them against being massacred by incoming Turkish troops who regard them as mortal enemies. Russia and Iran, without whose support Mr. Assad’s government would not have survived, are quick to benefit from America’s sudden retreat. Violence in an already ghastly Syrian civil war could get a great deal worse.

headline: As Support for Trump’s Impeachment Grows, His Base Digs In Its Heels
abstract: Republicans remain almost unanimously opposed to removing President Trump from office, leaving him with a loyal but shrinking core of supporters.
lead_paragraph: A new survey of the country’s cultural and political landscape found that support for impeaching and removing President Trump from office is rising among most Americans, but that Republicans remain almost unanimously opposed, leaving Mr. Trump with a loyal but shrinking core of supporters.

headline: What if the Real Act of Holiness Is Rest?
abstract: After all, that is the Sabbath’s chief requirement.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — My great-grandmother was a lifelong Baptist who spent the last four decades of her life worshiping with the Methodists because by then there was only one church left in that tiny farming community in Lower Alabama. Mother Ollie gladly attended Mass at my family’s Catholic church in Birmingham, too, but she never drifted from her quiet adherence to the King James ways of her Baptist youth.

headline: Boeing’s Board Confronts Further 737 Max Scandal
abstract: Company directors are meeting today after the revelation that a top pilot had warned about a flight system now suspected of a role in two fatal crashes.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday. New: Gwyneth Paltrow just confirmed that she will be a speaker at the DealBook Summit on Nov. 6. She’ll talk with Andrew about how she built Goop into one of the biggest wellness brands around. Apply to attend here. ( Sign up here to get this in your inbox each morning.)

headline: U.S. Is Quietly Reducing Its Troop Force in Afghanistan
abstract: The reduction, which officials say could gradually drop the number of troops by several thousand, is happening even without any deal with the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States has been quietly reducing its troop strength in Afghanistan despite the lack of a peace deal with the Taliban, weakening its hand in any future negotiations with the insurgents.

headline: Eat, Pray, Kevin Love
abstract: Coming off a losing season with the Cleveland Cavaliers, Love found what he had been missing: time to travel.
lead_paragraph: After an off-season in which it seemed like the N.B.A. never took a break, The New York Times talked to a few of the league’s stars about some of the other important things in their lives — anything but basketball.

headline: U.S. Withdrawal From Syria Gathers Speed, Amid Accusations of Betrayal
abstract: More than 100 American military vehicles entered Iraq on Monday, accelerating a pullout that greatly reduces American clout in Syria.
lead_paragraph: QAMISHLI, Syria — Heckled by Kurds who feel betrayed, a long convoy of United States troops crossed into Iraq early Monday, accelerating a withdrawal of American forces from northern Syria that set the stage for the Turkish invasion of Kurdish-controlled land.

headline: ‘It’s Hard’: Prince Harry and Meghan Speak of Strain of Royal Life in New Documentary
abstract: During a recent trip to Africa, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex offered a candid look into the struggles of dealing with the tabloid spotlight.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, have spoken of their struggle in coping with the spotlight and offered an unusually intimate look inside the British royal family in a series of interviews for a new documentary.

headline: More Parents Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
abstract: Douglas Hodge, one of the most prominent business executives charged in the case, said, “I acted out of love for my children, but I know that this explanation for my actions is not an excuse.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One father conspired to pay bribes to get two children admitted to the University of Southern California — one as a recruit in soccer, the other in football. A couple plotted to cheat on college entrance exams for their two daughters. A mother worried that her daughter might figure out she was trying to get her a fake ACT score, saying, on a call that turned out to be recorded by the authorities, “She already thinks I’m up to, like, no good.”

headline: Northern Ireland Set to Legalize Abortion and Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: The collapse of local government allowed Parliament to step in and bring the territory’s laws in line with Britain’s principles of human rights.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — Traditionally conservative Northern Ireland is about to legalize both abortion and same-sex marriage, a head-snapping about-face that was imposed on the territory by the British Parliament.

headline: Add ‘Pseudo Thumb’ to the Aye-Aye Lemur’s Bizarre Anatomy
abstract: Hiding in the weird creature’s palm was something that scientists had missed.
lead_paragraph: Madagascar’s aye-aye lemur is an endearing aberration of an animal.

headline: The Arts Are Shunning Big Oil. The Salzburg Festival Isn’t.
abstract: As some institutions shy away from oil and gas money, the prestigious music event has a new sponsor: Gazprom.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In July, the opera director Peter Sellars gave a stark speech about climate change to open the Salzburg Festival in Austria, one of classical music’s most glittering events.

headline: $260 Million Opioid Settlement Reached at Last Minute With Big Drug Companies
abstract: The deal involves large pharmaceutical distributors and Teva, resolving cases that sought redress from the devastation caused by two decades of opioid abuse.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The three major drug distributors and an opioid manufacturer have reached a $260 million settlement with two Ohio counties to avoid the landmark first federal opioid trial that was set to begin here Monday.

headline: Warren’s Education Plan Promises Billions for Low-Income Schools and Desegregation
abstract: The long-awaited proposal breaks from Obama-era Democratic priorities by critiquing charter schools and testing.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts had released dozens of policy plans before tackling K-12 education, making her the last leading Democratic primary contender to do so.

headline: Pixel 4 Review: Google Needs to Do More to Stand Out
abstract: The new Pixel 4 is a solid higher-end phone. But dollar for dollar, it pales against the latest iPhones and Galaxy devices. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Google’s new Pixel 4 phones will reach stores this week. Apple’s new iPhone 11s debuted last month. The question is: Will you be able to tell the difference between the smartphones?

headline: What You Get for $550,000 in California
abstract: A studio apartment in the Castle Green in Pasadena; a modernist retreat at Sea Ranch; and a bungalow and guesthouse in the Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: A studio apartment in the Castle Green in Pasadena; a modernist retreat at Sea Ranch; and a bungalow and guesthouse in the Bay Area.

headline: $550,000 Homes in California
abstract: A studio apartment in the 1898 Castle Green in Pasadena, a modernist retreat at Sea Ranch and a bungalow with a guesthouse in the Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: This unit is in Castle Green, a seven-story building in Old Town Pasadena, half a block north of Central Park. Castle Green was built as a hotel annex, with lavish public rooms in Moorish, Spanish and Victorian styles, to which residents have access. It is on the National Register of Historic Places and has been featured in movies and television series, including “Wild at Heart,” “The Grifters” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Peter Tolan, a writer and producer, formerly used the apartment as his writing studio.

headline: A Leader of Farmworkers, and Filipinos’ Place in American History
abstract: Monday: Shedding light on Larry Itliong. Also: The benefits of immigrants to cities, and withering criticism of PG&E.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Scenes of Destruction After Tornado Hits Dallas
abstract: A tornado destroyed buildings and left thousands without power in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: A tornado destroyed buildings and left thousands without power in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Sunday night.

headline: ISIS Reaps Gains of U.S. Pullout From Syria
abstract: The troop withdrawal ends American operations against the terrorist group conducted jointly with a Kurdish-led militia.
lead_paragraph: American forces and their Kurdish-led partners in Syria had been conducting as many as a dozen counterterrorism missions a day against Islamic State militants, officials said. That has stopped.

headline: What Our Poll Shows About Impeachment Views in 6 Swing States
abstract: With core supporters and opponents dug in, a crucial sliver of people support the inquiry but not necessarily removal.
lead_paragraph: Voters in the states likeliest to decide the 2020 presidential election support the impeachment inquiry that House Democrats began last month, but a majority still opposes impeaching President Trump and removing him from office, according to a New York Times/Siena College survey.

headline: The Greatest Fish Recipe
abstract: Julia Moskin’s pan-roasted fish with herb butter may just teach you a technique that you’ll use for the rest of your life.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The autumn migration continues along the East Coast, with striped bass and false albacore oozing south to the Carolinas, feasting on bait. Here are Bluefin tuna in close to shore, whales, gannets divebombing in formation. It’s wild. They’re harvesting Canada geese in western Nassau County, a bag limit of eight a day. Some sharpies I know pile the breasts into smokers, make what amounts to avian ham.

headline: In Iowa, Amy Klobuchar Gets a Second Look After Debate
abstract: Mired in the polling doldrums, the Minnesota senator drew crowds and new donors after attacking Elizabeth Warren for a “pipe dream.”
lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa — Before last week, Beth Kundel Vogel was undecided when it came to the Democratic presidential hopefuls.

headline: The Tulsa Race Massacre Happened 99 Years Ago. Here’s What to Read About It.
abstract: Last year, the HBO series ‘Watchmen’ depicted the Tulsa Race Massacre, one of the worst outbreaks of racial violence in American history, in its series premiere.
lead_paragraph: The Tulsa Race Massacre receives scant mention in most history textbooks and some facts remain hazy — mystery persists about, for example, exactly how many people were killed and where they were buried. But there’s no question that it was one of the worst outbreaks of racial violence in American history: a horrific spree of murder, arson and looting inflicted by white residents upon the prosperous African-American community of Greenwood, followed by a shameless cover-up.

headline: Why Lindsey Graham and Rand Paul Fight for Trump’s Favor
abstract: The sparring between these two senators and presidential allies is helping to shape conservative foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s on-the-fly decision to pull United States troops out of Syria is the latest flash point in the Republican battle to shape and define a “conservative” foreign policy. Increasingly, that term means very different things to very different people, all bearing the Republican mantle.

headline: What Causes a Mysterious Paralysis in Children? Researchers Find Viral Clues
abstract: In one study, nearly 70 percent of children with the disease had antibodies to common enteroviruses that usually produce mild effects but can sometimes cause neurological problems.
lead_paragraph: About 10 days after what seemed like a garden-variety cold, Luca Waugh, a healthy 4-year-old, developed troubling symptoms.

headline: Boris Johnson to Hold Tuesday Showdown After New Brexit Setback
abstract: The speaker of the House of Commons effectively delayed by a day a possibly decisive vote on the prime minister’s withdrawal agreement with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s latest  showdown with Parliament over Brexit was pushed back 24 hours on Monday after a ruling by John Bercow, the speaker of the House of Commons and a perennial thorn in the British leader’s side.

headline: Amazon’s First Fully Automated Factory Is Anything But
abstract: Keeping the “human free” facility running requires the work of third-party contractors, who are often put into dangerous situations.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: This is part of the Op-Eds From the Future series, in which science fiction authors, futurists, philosophers and scientists write Op-Eds that they imagine we might read 10, 50 or even 200 years from now. The challenges they predict are imaginary — for now — but their arguments illuminate the urgent questions of today and prepare us for tomorrow. The Opinion piece below is a work of fiction.

headline: The First Arabic Novel to Win the International Booker Prize
abstract: Jokha Alharthi’s inventive multigenerational tale, “Celestial Bodies,” is also the first novel by an Omani woman to be translated into English.
lead_paragraph: CELESTIAL BODIES

headline: A Romantic Comedy So Dark It Makes You Cry
abstract: The narrator of Lara Vapnyar’s “Divide Me by Zero” uses her dying mother’s unfinished math project to cope with two lovers, a husband and a stalled novel.
lead_paragraph: DIVIDE ME BY ZERO

headline: As a Father Lies Dying, His Family Reckons With Their Troubled Legacy
abstract: Jami Attenberg’s new novel, “All This Could Be Yours,” explores the lasting consequences of bad behavior.
lead_paragraph: ALL THIS COULD BE YOURS By Jami Attenberg

headline: Turkey’s Border Towns Pay Deadly Price for Erdogan’s Syria Incursion
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s campaign against the Kurdish militia in Syria has led to at least 20 deaths at home and has reopened old wounds in southeast Turkey’s traumatized population.
lead_paragraph: NUSAYBIN, Turkey — Smears of fresh black asphalt covered the blood stains from a deadly mortar strike on a quiet neighborhood in Nusaybin, Turkey, just two blocks from the Syrian border.

headline: Carl Safina Is Certain Your Dog Loves You
abstract: Animals have rich emotional lives, the ecologist argues. The evidence is “right in front of your eyes.”
lead_paragraph: Carl Safina, 64, an ecologist at Stony Brook University on Long Island and a “MacArthur genius” grant winner, has written nine books about the human connection to the animal world. Coming next spring is “Becoming Wild,” on the culture of animals, and a young adult version of “Beyond Words,” on the capabilities of dogs and wolves.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The amino acid L-dopa, also known as levodopa, is best known as a treatment for the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. It has appeared in the New York Times Crossword 20 times.

headline: Philadelphia Shootings Kill Girl, 2, and Wound Boy, 11 Months, Police Say
abstract: The police said the shootings, which also left two adults wounded, might be linked. A motive was unknown.
lead_paragraph: Two separate shootings over the weekend in Philadelphia that the authorities believe might be linked left a 2-year-old girl dead and an 11-month-old boy in very critical condition, the police said.

headline: Rescuing Native Americans From the Imaginative Prison of the Past
abstract: Finally, there is a critical mass of children’s picture books about Indigenous people living vibrant, diverse, contemporary lives.
lead_paragraph: Native people, if we are encountered at all, are encountered during childhood. From the dull art of crafting Thanksgiving turkeys out of handprints to the bad politics of making headdresses out of turkey feathers, the point of contact between Indians and non-Indians begins and ends (for the most part) in grade school. It could be said that the primary place where Natives continue to exist for most Americans is in childhood imagination. It is no accident that Peter Pan’s tribe of Lost Boys who refuse to grow up, refuse to grow up with Indians as allies and enemies. Michael Chabon, writing in 2009, amplified the relationship among childhood, Indians, the past and the imagination. “When I was growing up,” he writes, “our house backed onto woods, a thin two-acre remnant of a once-mighty wilderness. … There were no Indians in those woods, but there had been once. We learned about them in school. Patuxent Indians, they’d been called. Swift, straight-shooting, silent as deer. Gone but for their lovely place names: Patapsco, Wicomico, Patuxent.”

headline: Scotty Bowers, Who Wrote of Providing Sex to Stars, Dies at 96
abstract: His 2012 book, “Full Service,” told scandalous tales about Katharine Hepburn, Spencer Tracy and countless others using his sexual referral business.
lead_paragraph: Scotty Bowers, who challenged the genteel image of studio-system Hollywood with a startling 2012 book in which he claimed to have arranged sexual liaisons for a long list of gay and bisexual stars and other show business figures, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 96.

headline: How Raina Telgemeier Faces Her Fear
abstract: The graphic novelist behind “Guts” shows how she works and talks about why she opened up about her anxiety.
lead_paragraph: The graphic novelist behind “Guts” shows how she works and talks about why she opened up about her anxiety.

headline: She Jumped a Turnstile. The Fine Pushed Her to the Breaking Point.
abstract: Reeling from her father’s death, a single mother finds a pathway to stability through a job training program.
lead_paragraph: Jasmín Perez was on her way home to the Bronx from a job training program in Queens when, having exhausted her biweekly stipend for subway fare, she jumped a turnstile.

headline: Meatballs Like You Haven’t Seen Them
abstract: Alison Roman likes them nicely crisped, without the sogginess that comes from tomato sauce or gravy.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to food, I will forever favor crispy over saucy, because saucy is the enemy of crispy, and crispy is the best and most pleasant thing about food. For example, I can’t stand when people squeeze lemon over my fried calamari or schnitzel, and think eggplant Parm is a waste of a crunchy piece of eggplant. (I have privately critiqued certain restaurants and dishes by describing them as “overwhelmingly saucy” or “too sauce-forward.”)

headline: Facebook Finds New Disinformation Campaigns and Braces for 2020 Torrent
abstract: The company also announced several new steps to reduce the spread of false information, including an effort to label posts from state-sponsored media.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Monday that it had recently found and taken down four state-backed disinformation campaigns, the latest of dozens that it has identified and removed this year and a sign of how foreign interference online is increasing ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Sam Bobrick, ‘Saved by the Bell’ Creator, Is Dead at 87
abstract: A television mainstay, he was also a playwright. His best-known play, “Norman, Is That You?,” flopped on Broadway but went on to international success.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bobrick, who created the enduring NBC high school sitcom “Saved by the Bell,” and whose play “Norman, Is That You?” reached audiences around the world after it fizzled on Broadway in 1970, died on Oct. 11 in Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Helen Mirren Plays Catherine II in the Years That Made Her ‘the Great’
abstract: In HBO’s “Catherine the Great,” Mirren portrays the 18th-century Russian empress at the height of her powers.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of the HBO mini-series “Catherine the Great,” the empress of Russia is hunched over her desk writing about her political ambitions while her jealous lover stares into a hand mirror, primping for a cross-dressing masquerade at the palace.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière, Poster Boy for Fashion-Against-Trump
abstract: LVMH’s splashy ribbon cutting with the president spurs an angry Instagram post — by one of the company’s own stars.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Ghesquière, the artistic director of Louis Vuitton women’s wear and one of the designer jewels in the LVMH crown, has spoken out — or posted anyway — to dissociate himself with his company’s new association with President Trump.

headline: A Church Service Inspired by Beyoncé, No Halo Required
abstract: The Beyoncé Mass explores how issues of race and gender impact the lives, voices and bodies of black women. (It’s not, however, about worshiping Beyoncé.)
lead_paragraph: In April 2018, 900 people turned out for a midweek evening church service that typically draws 50 participants at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. Days later, a YouTube video of the proceedings went viral, followed by invitations clamoring for the event to be reprised in cities from Los Angeles to Lisbon.

headline: Stella Abrera of American Ballet Theater to Retire in Spring
abstract: Ms. Abrera, a luminous principal dancer, will leave after 24 years with the company.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago Stella Abrera danced the lead in “Giselle” for the first time at American Ballet Theater. For her farewell performance with the company, on June 13, she will take on the role again at the Metropolitan Opera House. Her retirement, after 24 years with the company, was announced on Monday.

headline: Ex-Nazi Bunker Will Soon House Hotel Guests
abstract: An air raid shelter in Hamburg, built by forced laborers during World War II, will become a “design and lifestyle” hotel.
lead_paragraph: A former Nazi bunker in Hamburg, built by forced laborers to shelter tens of thousands of Germans during Allied air raids in World War II, will soon house hotel guests.

headline: As Netanyahu Fails to Form a Government, Benny Gantz Gets a Chance to Try
abstract: The former army chief will have 28 days to assemble a coalition government for the fiercely divided country. Otherwise, a third election could follow.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel abandoned his latest attempt to form a government on Monday, clearing the way for his chief rival to take a shot but leaving a divided country no closer to knowing who its next leader would be.

headline: Facebook Lays On the Charm for Its Libra Cryptocurrency Plan
abstract: Executives fanned out in Washington to court lawmakers and regulators. Mark Zuckerberg is expected to testify about Libra this week before the House.
