lead_paragraph: It was a challenge unlike any other the chef-turned-graduate student had faced: Vayu Maini Rekdal had to create a menu where every ingredient could be eaten either raw or cooked. No pickling was allowed, nor fermented toppings like soy sauce or miso. Nothing could be processed in any way, so things like tofu were out. And the more sweet potatoes he could serve up, the better.

headline: Lawyer for Man Who Worked With Giuliani Ties Case to Trump
abstract: The connection was made as two associates of Rudolph W. Giuliani pleaded not guilty in federal court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: One of the two indicted associates of President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, on Wednesday tied the case to the president himself, saying that some of the evidence gathered in the campaign-finance investigation could be subject to executive privilege.

headline: The T List: The Perfect Jeans, Rice-Cake Queso Fundido and More
abstract: What to wear, eat and know about this week, from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing five things we are eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

headline: An Envoy’s Damaging Testimony Against Trump
abstract: Readers discuss a diplomat’s account of the Trump administration’s dealings with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Think He’s a Jerk? Then He’s Doing His Job
abstract: As the self-involved, self-lacerating womanizer in the play “Linda Vista,” Ian Barford aims to offer the audience just enough reasons not to give up on him.
lead_paragraph: Ian Barford can tell when the audience turns against him. It begins with a kiss, and escalates during a breakup scene. By the time he hobbles through a door, desperate to reconcile, “they’re just hissing at me, practically throwing things at me,” Barford said.

headline: Russia Doping Decision Faces Delay After WADA Cancels Meeting
abstract: Russia’s voluminous response to a list of 31 questions about manipulated drug tests is said to have overwhelmed investigators.
lead_paragraph: A key meeting of a group of World Anti-Doping Agency investigators that could have led to significant new punishments for Russia was canceled Wednesday after Russia’s voluminous response overwhelmed investigators.

headline: Can One LED Light Give You Perfect Skin?
abstract: One day, shining light on your face may be the most important part of your skin care routine. We take a look at the newest devices.
lead_paragraph: The MMSphere, a ring of LED lights, casts a red glow over my face. It sits adjacent to my laptop so that as I write, research and procrastinate, I can simultaneously calm a fiery constellation of acne on my left cheek.

headline: Finding Amado in Queens, and Going With Him to Mexico
abstract: In New York, thousands of immigrants dwell in illegal basement apartments. One man let Times journalists into his life.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Bigger Story Behind the Humiliating Release of El Chapo’s Son
abstract: After the recent spate of violence, President López Obrador should advise the U.S. that the war on drugs is not the focus of his agenda.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, the United States ambassador to Mexico, Carlos Pascual, became the first American ambassador forced to resign. A series of cables sent by Mr. Pascual to Washington, and published by WikiLeaks, revealed that when the American authorities detected the location of a high-value target, they were made to choose between several unpalatable alternatives: Notify the Mexican Army, which might tip off the target and was risk-averse; notify the federal police, which was essentially paralyzed; or notify the United States-trained Navy, which was effective but exceedingly violent.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Plan to End Private Health Insurance
abstract: Readers discuss whether Senator Warren should be more willing to compromise on her “Medicare for all” stand. Also: President Trump dismisses the Constitution; humility in its guises.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kenneth Fisher Ruled Investing. Then He Made a Sexist Joke.
abstract: Mr. Fisher compared the wooing of wealthy clients to “trying to get into a girl’s pants.” Investment funds have since pulled nearly $2 billion from his firm.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Fisher, a billionaire money manager, is known for aggressively marketing his firm and attaching his name to books, columns and TV ads.

headline: An Election Is the Only Answer for Britain
abstract: Boris Johnson, having failed in his do-or-die mission, must take Brexit back to the public.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fail. Fail again. Fail worse. Britain is now close to a primal scream: Save us from Brexit any way, by any means! Usher us from this hell! Deliver us from this nightmare! Give us back the country we had before the B-word began bombarding our brains.

headline: David Ross Is Said to Be Cubs’ Next Manager
abstract: Ross, who helped Chicago to its first World Series title in 108 years in 2016, will replace Joe Maddon, who parted ways with the club after this season.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Cubs will name David Ross as their manager, succeeding Joe Maddon, according to multiple news media reports Wednesday morning.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg, Have You Considered Retirement?
abstract: You’re everyone’s favorite political punching bag, for good reason. Why not take the decade off?
lead_paragraph: If I were Mark Zuckerberg — newfound defender-to-the-death of liberal free expression even if it includes outright lying except if there are female nipples, a would-be curer of all the world’s disease, side-gig education reformer, immigration crusader, quirky dad, fifth-wealthiest person in the world, hobnobber to pundits and politicians and all-around do-gooder digital hegemon who is also now vying to run the world’s money supply, I mean my God, Mark, where does all this end? — I’d be packing a go bag right about now.

headline: One Family Built Forever 21, and Fueled Its Collapse
abstract: The retailer’s bankruptcy filing, and interviews with former employees, give a rare glimpse into a family controlled, intensely secretive operation.
lead_paragraph: When Forever 21 filed for bankruptcy last month, the fast fashion chain described its history in documents that read, at times, like a pitch for a memoir or a Netflix special.

headline: Leonardo da Vinci, Maestro of Change, Shines at the Louvre
abstract: The marvelous survey of 160 works, including paintings, drawings and notebooks, shows the great artist’s hand and mind in constant action.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — To judge by the marketing hullabaloo, the Leonardo da Vinci retrospective that opens here Thursday at the Louvre should be the visual equivalent of a 21-gun salute and a trumpet-and-trombone choir. Blockbuster’s plastered all over it, and rightly so. Timed-ticket sales for its one-stop run are moving right along.

headline: Republicans Grind Impeachment Inquiry to Halt as Evidence Mounts Against Trump
abstract: House Republicans staged a protest in the secure suite on Capitol Hill where the impeachment inquiry is proceeding, seeking to shift the focus away from damaging revelations about the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans ground the impeachment inquiry to a halt for hours on Wednesday, staging a protest at the Capitol that sowed chaos and delayed a crucial deposition as they sought to deflect the spotlight from the revelations the investigation has unearthed about President Trump.

headline: Trans Fats, Bad for the Heart, May Be Bad for the Brain as Well
abstract: People with high levels of trans fats in the blood were at higher risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
lead_paragraph: Trans fatty acids, known to increase the risk for heart disease, stroke and diabetes, have now been linked to an increased risk for dementia.

headline: Ray Santos, a Pillar of Latin Jazz, Is Dead at 90
abstract: After playing saxophone with Machito, Tito Puente and Tito Rodriguez, he wrote arrangements for Linda Ronstadt and the movie “The Mambo Kings.”
lead_paragraph: Ray Santos, who played saxophone with the biggest stars in Latin jazz and went on to write arrangements renowned for their economy and clarity, died on Oct. 17 at a hospital near his home in the Bronx. He was 90.

headline: Rocket Attack Wounds at Least 5 Marines in Afghanistan
abstract: The high number of casualties came a day after Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper visited the country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least five Marines were wounded on Tuesday during a Taliban rocket attack on a military base in southern Afghanistan, according to three defense officials. The high number of casualties came a day after Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper visited the country.

headline: Steve Bannon Has Some Impeachment Advice for Trump
abstract: A new radio show featuring Mr. Bannon and some Trump loyalists aims to add to the messaging in defense of the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s been more than a year since any sort of war room has been run out of the basement of Stephen K. Bannon’s Capitol Hill townhouse. And it’s been even longer since Mr. Bannon, who was pushed out as White House chief strategist in August 2017, ran a war room for President Trump.

headline: Lizzo Sues Over ‘Truth Hurts’ Songwriting Credits
abstract: The musician also added the author of a tweet that inspired the song’s signature “DNA test” line to the track’s credits.
lead_paragraph: Who wrote Lizzo’s hit “Truth Hurts”? That question may now be settled in a court of law.

headline: Youth Marketing Consultant Gets 3 Weeks in Admissions Scandal
abstract: Jane Buckingham, who also wrote a “Modern Girl’s Guides” series, told the judge who set her sentence, “I know that I’ll never be able to forgive myself.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Jane Buckingham, a youth marketing consultant who has written advice books including “The Modern Girl’s Guide to Life,” was sentenced by a federal judge on Wednesday to three weeks in prison for paying to have a test expert take the ACT exam in place of her son.

headline: World Series: Nationals Stun Astros in Game 2 to Seize Control
abstract: A pitching duel turned into a blowout thanks to Washington’s six-run seventh inning, and the Nationals cruised to their eighth straight postseason win.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — First came silence from the shocked Houston Astros fans, then some grumbling, and finally a round of sarcastic claps and whistles when the home team finally converted a routine play. The way their team was playing, there was little else to cheer.

headline: You Got a Brain Scan at the Hospital. Someday a Computer May Use It to Identify You.
abstract: In a disturbing experiment, imaging and facial recognition technologies were used to match research subjects to their M.R.I. scans.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people have received brain scans, as well as cognitive and genetic tests, while participating in research studies. Though the data may be widely distributed among scientists, most participants assume their privacy is protected because researchers remove their names and other identifying information from their records.

headline: ‘Paradise Hills’ Review: Caged Birds Singing, Maybe Escaping
abstract: In this dystopian tale, a private treatment center turns privileged young women into smilingly compliant stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: By turns puckish and grim, “Paradise Hills” is just the latest female-driven dystopian story to hit screens. Maybe it’s the times, and these chronicles of peril and resistance represent a mood (or a game plan). Whatever the reason, the bad times keep coming for women, who have battled odds, other people and sometimes monsters in modest fairy tales like “Endzeit” and “Into the Forest” as well as in larger-scaled apocalyptic fictions like “The Hunger Games,” “Divergent” and “The Handmaid’s Tale.”

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Ben Platt Reads ‘Words With (I Wish We Were More Than) Friends’
abstract: “The Policitian” star reads an essay about a fleeting but meaningful online relationship.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Hildegard Bachert, 98, Dies; Championed Klimt, Schiele and Grandma Moses
abstract: In her 78 years at the Galerie St. Etienne in Manhattan, she promoted German and Austrian Expressionists as well as the celebrated American folk artist.
lead_paragraph: Hildegard Bachert, who fled the Nazis as a teenager and joined a New York art gallery where, over a 78-year career, she helped introduce and popularize the works of German and Austrian Expressionists and the folk art of Grandma Moses, died on Oct. 17 in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 98.

headline: Tesla Reports Profit for Quarter, Sending Shares Soaring
abstract: The electric-car maker’s revenue declined, but it said it had removed “substantial cost” from its operations.
lead_paragraph: Just months ago, Tesla was mired in turmoil. It was scrambling to raise capital, closing stores and reeling from a sudden slump in sales.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Should Prime Minister Boris Johnson persuade Parliament to pass his Brexit deal — to “get Brexit done,” as he promised — it would seem to bring a successful end to the most difficult chapter of his career.

headline: Two Strains of Polio Are Gone, but the End of the Disease Is Still Far Off
abstract: Only polio virus Type 1 persists, and only in Pakistan and Afghanistan. But now mutant vaccine viruses are paralyzing some unvaccinated children.
lead_paragraph: In another milestone on the long, expensive and sometimes discouraging road to wiping out polio, global health officials announced Wednesday that two of the three strains of wild polio virus have officially been eliminated.

abstract: Does the Los Angeles F.C. star take soccer seriously enough? His critics, his former teams and even some of his rivals aren’t sure. Vela says he will win, or lose, on his terms.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Carlos Vela joined Los Angeles F.C. with a reputation. A couple, actually. The first was as a goal scorer, a forward possessing the sort of talent that makes defenders shudder.

headline: Trump’s War on the ‘Deep State’ Turns Against Him
abstract: The impeachment inquiry is in some ways the culmination of a battle between the president and the government institutions he distrusted and disparaged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nameless, faceless and voiceless, the C.I.A. officer who first triggered the greatest threat to President Trump’s tenure in office seemed to be practically the embodiment of the “deep state” that the president has long accused of trying to take him down.

headline: Lebanon Protests Unite Sects in Demanding New Government
abstract: Lebanon’s protests, the largest since its independence, have moved from fury over the economy and corruption to demands for a new political system.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The two new protesters smiled for the camera on a rooftop over downtown Beirut, marking what felt like history with a selfie. The view was  new to them: Hundreds of thousands of Lebanese of every sectarian affiliation danced and chanted in the street below, the little-seen Lebanese flag suddenly everywhere.

headline: Colorado Report Accuses 43 Catholic Priests of Child Sex Abuse

lead_paragraph: Investigators in Colorado released a report on Wednesday on child sex abuse by Roman Catholic priests that chronicled the abuse of 166 children at the hands of 43 priests across the state since 1950, with most of the acts committed by just five priests who abused 102 children.

abstract: Casting holes in a Trump conspiracy theory, Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte revealed details of two visits to Rome by Attorney General William P. Barr.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy said his country’s intelligence services had informed the American attorney general, William P. Barr, that they played no role in the events leading to the Russia investigation, taking the air out of an unsubstantiated theory promoted by President Trump and his allies in recent weeks.

lead_paragraph: Animal cruelty would become a federal offense with a penalty of up to seven years in prison  under a proposed expansion of an animal welfare law that won unanimous approval this week in the House of Representatives.

headline: Kyrie Irving Scores 50 Points in Nets’ Season-Opening Loss
abstract: Irving, the All-Star guard who joined the Nets in the off-season, was brilliant, but the Timberwolves got the win.
lead_paragraph: Kyrie Irving delivered the kind of superstar performance that Nets fans dreamed of when he announced he was signing with the team this summer. Chants of “Kyrie’s home!” rang out around Barclays Center during the Nets’ season opener on Wednesday night. There were “M.V.P.” chants and loud roars when he touched the ball on his way to 50 points.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Will & Grace’ and a New David Chang Series
abstract: The final season of “Will & Grace” begins on NBC. And a new food travel show with David Chang is on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: WILL & GRACE 9:30 p.m. on NBC. “Will & Grace” is ending — again. The sitcom, built on the friendship between its title characters, who are a lawyer and an interior designer, pushed boundaries and helped normalize gay characters in prime time TV during its original run in the late 1990s and 2000s. It was revived for a season that debuted in 2017 and aged up the characters, but left the show’s formula largely untouched: Will (Eric McCormack) and Grace (Debra Messing) were once again roommates. The 2006 original finale that saw the pair married (separately) with children was explained away as, in part, a dream that never happened. NBC has said that the latest season, the 11th, which debuts Thursday night, is going to be the show’s last. But whatever happens in the new finale may not carry the same stakes as that first one: In theory, it could all be a dream, too.

headline: In Characters Ancient and Contemporary, Women Discover Their Power Onstage
abstract: In Paris, the mythological Greek character Electra can once again be found in a theater, while the heroine of a quirky new play is inspired by “Rocky III.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Twenty-five centuries after they first appeared onstage, the mythological siblings Electra and Orestes are capturing theatermakers’ imaginations all over again. Last spring, the Belgian director Ivo van Hove applied a thick coat of mud to two Euripides plays about their family saga at the Comédie-Française; Milo Rau took the pair to Iraq for “Orestes in Mosul,” a production created in part with local actors. Now, Electra has found a new home in “Électre des Bas-Fonds” (“Electra in the Underworld”), presented here at the Théâtre du Soleil. The update? She discovers sisterhood in a brothel as she plots to avenge her father’s murder.

headline: ‘The State Kind of Dumped This On Us:’ Early Voting Stirs Anxiety in N.Y.
abstract: Think of the perils of an Election Day: broken voting machines, endless lines, frantic calls to extend voting hours. Now, imagine nine days of that.
lead_paragraph: At long last, New York on Saturday will join the 38 other states that already allow some form of early voting. But with the anticipation comes an almost equal dose of concern over an array of possible problems.

headline: Trump’s Syria and Ukraine Moves Further Alienate America’s Already Wary Allies
abstract: American allies in Europe have largely priced in President Trump’s tantrums and fixed ideas, but are increasingly worried about their dependency on an undependable president.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders have long understood that President Trump is an unreliable ally, subject to loud tantrums, abrupt shifts and sudden whims. They have worried about his ambivalence toward NATO, resented his personal attacks and bristled at his use of trade policy and economic sanctions to restrict their companies and markets.

headline: Franco’s Remains Are Exhumed and Reburied After Bitter Battle
abstract: The removal of the dictator’s remains from a basilica near Madrid, weeks before a national election in Spain, was denounced by some for stirring painful memories.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish government on Thursday exhumed the remains of the former dictator Gen. Francisco Franco from the underground basilica that he built after winning his country’s civil war. The move had prompted criticism that, coming just two weeks before a national election, it would reopen old rifts in Spanish society.

headline: Carlos Ghosn Wants to See Prosecutors’ Files. Nissan Says No.
abstract: Defense attorneys say prosecutors won’t share records that might help their client, citing the automaker’s fears that company secrets could be revealed.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the year since the Japanese authorities arrested Carlos Ghosn, the fallen Nissan boss, prosecutors have seized laptops, hard drives and reams of files from the automaker and its executives as they build their case against him.

headline: ‘We Will Bring Back a New Caliphate’: Wives of ISIS Fighters Speak
abstract: We traveled to Al Hol camp in northeast Syria to meet wives of ISIS fighters held there. With fewer Kurdish-led forces guarding the camp because of the U.S. withdrawal and the Turkish invasion, the question of what will happen to these women and their children becomes more pressing than ever.
lead_paragraph: We traveled to Al Hol camp in northeast Syria to meet wives of ISIS fighters held there. With fewer Kurdish-led forces guarding the camp because of the U.S. withdrawal and the Turkish invasion, the question of what will happen to these women and their children becomes more pressing than ever.

headline: After Turkish Incursion, ISIS Wives Speak Out
abstract: We traveled to the notorious Al Hol camp in northeastern Syria to speak with the wives of ISIS fighters. Some remained radicalized, while others said they regretted joining the militant group.
lead_paragraph: Now that Turkey’s military offensive has weakened Kurdish control in northeastern Syria, the question of what will happen to thousands of detained Islamic State fighters and their families is more pressing than ever.

headline: How to Return a Tribal Item
abstract: Call the tribe or a museum, especially for human remains and ceremonial artifacts.
lead_paragraph: “When in doubt, call,” says Richard M. Begay, director of the Navajo Nation Historic Preservation Department. If you are in possession of an artifact from a tribe or people not your own, offer to return it, especially if it appears to be old and you’re not sure of its origin story. You will be asked to describe it, and often to submit a photo. The Navajo Nation is most interested in repatriating human remains, funerary objects and ceremonial items known as jish, which might include buckskin bags, masks, medicinal plants, carved wood and anything with eagle, blue bird, owl or turkey feathers attached.

headline: ‘Unspeakable Acts’ Revisits a Pivotal Moment in the Art World’s Treatment of Sexual Violence
abstract: Nancy Princenthal’s new book is about how women in the 1970s took an experience that had been artistically mined by men for millenniums and found ways to convey it in their own terms.
lead_paragraph: In “Unspeakable Acts,” a new book about how artists have made sense (or not) of sexual violence against women, Nancy Princenthal draws a subtle but crucial distinction: Just because an act was long deemed “unspeakable” didn’t necessarily mean that it wasn’t shown. In art as in life, abuse has been a constant; what changed in the 1970s, Princenthal says, is who depicted the experience, and how it was consequently understood.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Gifting Dumpster Chocolate
abstract: Can you give sweets you found in the garbage to your co-workers without telling them where they came from?
lead_paragraph: Meridith writes: My friend obtained a significant quantity of chocolate from a dumpster outside a beloved local chocolate factory. He then shared it with his co-workers without disclosing the source. I believe he should have let his co-workers know that the chocolate came from a dumpster. He contends that he did nothing wrong. Who’s right?

headline: How Mary-Kay Wilmers Became Britain’s Most Influential Editor
abstract: As newspapers and magazines flounder, The London Review of Books has flourished by championing intellectual debate.
lead_paragraph: On an unusually sunny, cool summer day in London, Mary-Kay Wilmers, 81, was at work in a large, light-filled loft in Bloomsbury, home to the offices of what she calls “the paper” and its readers call the L.R.B.: The London Review of Books. Petite, silver hair cut distinctively in a short bob, Wilmers had brought a copy of the latest issue — Volume 41, Number 13 — to a bright back room and a desk laden with current British newspapers and magazines. On the cover of The Sun, a photo of Taylor Swift adjoined the headline “Migrant’s 3,500-ft Plunge: Falling Jet Stowaway Lands 3ft From Sunbather.” On the cover of The Times, next to a close-up of a young woman delighting in a rainbow ice pop, ran the headline “Oxfam Staff Still Offering Aid for Sex, Report Claims.” Wilmers’s copy of the L.R.B. featured no photos of women on its cover. Instead, a painting, unblemished by text, depicting an early summer evening in London: dirty pink twilight dissolving behind a stand of trees, deep, unnatural blue overtaking the sky, two silhouetted birds coursing above overground wires. Pretty, striking and, when read with the hot pink headline incised above it — “The Sun Sets on Britain” — a different picture altogether.

headline: He Scoured the Bronx on a Budget. Which Home Did He Choose?
abstract: A longtime Manhattan renter migrated north to find a comfortable home for about $150,000. Here's where he wound up.
lead_paragraph: A longtime Manhattan renter migrated north to find a comfortable home for about $150,000. Here's where he wound up.

abstract: The uptick reverses a decades-long trend in America’s progress toward cleaner air.
lead_paragraph: The uptick reverses a decades-long trend in America’s progress toward cleaner air.

headline: Is the Impeachment Inquiry a Teachable Moment? Or Should Politics Stay Out of the Classroom?
abstract: How do you want your teachers to deal with the political issues of our day?
lead_paragraph: Is the impeachment inquiry underway in the House of Representatives an extraordinary opportunity for civics education, a rare chance to study history unfold before our very eyes and see the Constitution and its framework of checks and balances in action?

headline: Something Wicked This Way Comes
abstract: The latest crop of horror fiction — some new, some reissued — is truly the stuff of nightmares.
lead_paragraph: What to do when you discover that your favorite author (or comedian, or filmmaker, or actor) is a bigot? For some, it inspires a total rejection of the artist, whose work becomes suddenly intolerable. Others reassess their taste, wondering how they were ever able to enjoy a novel with pedophilia at its center, or the stand-up routine filled with misogyny. Still others try to quarantine the art from the artist, as if one might be spared the contagion of the other. And for some — like the horror writer Victor LaValle, who discovered his childhood hero H. P. Lovecraft to be a racist — it’s a long process of soul-searching that ends in compromise.

headline: The Day a Sniper Shattered My Marine Unit’s Innocence
abstract: On deployment in Iraq, we were lucky at first. Two weeks later, we became the first company in our battalion to lose a Marine.
lead_paragraph: We had all been dodging bullets and shrapnel like young matadors, twisting and gyrating our hips, whipping our flak jackets to the side like capes as the superheated shards of metal charged at us. Most of the rounds fired at our forward operating base were so poorly placed that they had to have a dash of luck to even hit a guard post. They were the untrained shots of amateurs, taken by fathers and brothers who were thrust into war by either circumstance or their ideas about the sacred duty of jihad, neither of which involved the training of a professional soldier. It was our brief age of innocence during Second Battalion, Third Marines’ deployment to Iraq in 2006. We had been largely unscathed by the true essence of war. Roadside bombs had left marks on a few of us. Concussions caused by grenades were joked about. Shrapnel left in the fleshy tissue of camouflaged buttocks were a source of hilarity. A Marine named Gabriel Odum had been shot on his first patrol, the bullet passing through his right hand and one lung, but a few lucky centimeters away from fatal. We believed we were invincible. The casualties were serious, but everyone would walk away, bearing the kinds of scars that would make them celebrities at their respective V.F.W. cantinas.

headline: He’s Played Churchill and Lear. But for John Lithgow, Audiobooks Test His Mettle.
abstract: “Stamina is the real challenge: a hoarse voice, a tired brain and a sore ass. But as with all the spoken arts, the only bad experience is bad writing.”
lead_paragraph: “Stamina is the real challenge: a hoarse voice, a tired brain and a sore ass,” says the actor and author, whose latest book is “Dumpty: The Age of Trump in Verse.” “But as with all the spoken arts, the only bad experience is bad writing.”

headline: How Drinking Less Solved a Lot of Problems
abstract: I don’t have a drinking problem, but cutting down on alcohol was an eye opener.
lead_paragraph: Though I come from a family of beer drinkers, I was never much into drinking. I rarely drank as a teenager, and even into my 20s, drinking didn’t play a big part in my life, other than the fruity cocktails I enjoyed on occasion.

headline: Using A.I. to Transform Breast Cancer Care
abstract: Just as computers can predict your shopping habits, researchers are using them to map the medical history of cancer patients to predict and treat the disease, and possibly to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: How could a researcher in computer science improve future cancer care, I wondered, when a trip to Boston afforded me the opportunity to converse with Regina Barzilay, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the recipient in 2017 of a prestigious MacArthur Fellowship, known as a “genius grant.” After a breast cancer diagnosis in 2014, Dr. Barzilay, who has a doctorate in computer science, began directing her work in artificial intelligence toward helping other patients.

headline: 200 Dispatches: Odd Animals, Offbeat Childhoods, Celebrity Origins and Extreme Sports
abstract: Each of our Dispatches so far has offered a unique take on an often fleeting moment in a highly particular place. But common themes like sex and migration have emerged, too.
lead_paragraph: Suicidal dogs, homicidal crocodiles and très chic bees. The hometowns of Melania Trump, Stalin and the (very) remote village where Andy Warhol’s parents met. Icy marathons across Siberian lakes, bare-chested wrestling on horseback and nude badminton (in thankfully balmy weather).

headline: How to Get a Better Deal From a Real Estate Agent
abstract: The economist Justin Wolfers saved a hefty sum by offering an hourly fee instead of a commission, thwarting a system that is often inefficient and uncompetitive.
lead_paragraph: When I bought a home a few months ago, my real estate agent handed me a check worth tens of thousands of dollars — a rebate on his commission. Windfalls like that could become more common if home buyers demand better deals.

headline: Wegmans Has Come to Brooklyn. Why Are New Yorkers Losing Their Minds?
abstract: The wholesome and enormous grocery store has achieved a cultlike status in the city.
lead_paragraph: When I was in my 20s and visiting friends who had left New York, I was often taken to supermarkets as a cultural tourist.

headline: C.E.O.s Are Anxious About the Economy. That’s Bad for Stocks.
abstract: Companies have binged on share buybacks in recent years, pumping up prices, but their appetite could wane as economic uncertainty rises.
lead_paragraph: American companies spent more than $800 billion on their own shares last year, taking a windfall from deep corporate tax cuts to try to bolster their share prices and improve the look of their quarterly earnings reports.

headline: He Made the Longest Ocean Voyage in History, and Turned It Into Art
abstract: Reid Stowe once hung out with Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring. But the sea was his true passion.
lead_paragraph: Along a Hudson River pier in 2010, a sailor docked his battered schooner as a crowd watched in quiet anticipation. When he wearily stepped onto land, he had finished a remarkable human journey: Reid Stowe had been at sea for 1,152 days, the longest nonstop ocean voyage in recorded history.

headline: It’s Campaign Season in Football, With the Heisman Trophy on the Line
abstract: A look at a ground game that plays out away from the field, yet is important for universities chasing college football’s top award.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — The website befits a candidate for Congress.

headline: Men, Your Bald Spot Looks Great
abstract: The wellness industry takes on hair loss.
lead_paragraph: The embarrassment many men feel about losing their hair doesn’t diminish over the generations. What changes are the available treatments and the coping strategies.

headline: You Too Can Play the Handbag Stock Market
abstract: Don’t think of those totes and saddle bags as just pretty accessories. They could also be an investment portfolio.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year Kylie Jenner, the beauty mogul and Kardashian-Jenner family member, gave one of her patented home tours to Architectural Digest.

headline: De Niro and Pacino Have Always Connected. Just Rarely Onscreen.
abstract: “The Irishman” is officially only the third time they’ve collaborated, but over the years they often turned to one another. Who else could understand?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There’s no plaque to honor the encounter, and neither of its central participants can pinpoint the exact date it occurred, but somewhere on a stretch of 14th Street in Manhattan’s East Village is the spot where, in the late 1960s, two rookie actors named Robert De Niro and Al Pacino first crossed paths.

headline: Poem: Songs and Stones
abstract: This poem's haunted contradictions  feel familiar as cadences of the everyday, yet more bearable.
lead_paragraph: A poem springing from contradictions or opposites can be satisfying in its succinctness. The haunted mixtures of Jacqueline Saphra’s “Songs and Stones” feel familiar as cadences of the everyday, yet more bearable. Her poem’s questions are human-size, not a tidal wave: How do we do this? How do we absorb all these elements with which we are continually confronted and move on? There are so many chords and notes to be struck, but how do we cry tears springing from so many sources? The poem ends on a note of mystery that feels comforting in its acknowledgment, despite all we do not know.

headline: In an Explosive Honduras Drug Case, It Was a Trial by Twitter
abstract: A narco-trafficking case implicated the Honduran first family, including the president. I got used to seeing them tweeting at me — along with ordinary Hondurans grateful for straightforward coverage.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: When Did Everybody Become a Witch?
abstract: Witch parties, witch protests and a bevy of new books: We have reached peak witch.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-one years ago, a group of protesters calling themselves W.I.T.C.H. staged a Halloween “hex” on Wall Street. Dressed in all black, with long peaked hats, the women sneaked through the narrow streets of downtown Manhattan late into the night, making their way to the entrance to the New York Stock Exchange, where they oozed glue into the latches of its doors. The next morning, the male bankers couldn’t get in — and the Dow reportedly fell 13 points.

headline: When the Urge to Write Is a Life Sentence
abstract: Ahmet Altan, author of the new book “I Will Never See the World Again,” has been imprisoned for life. I’m being treated for a brain tumor. We’re both determined to keep going.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish novelist and journalist Ahmet Altan is serving a life sentence in prison in his home country, allowed to see his children only occasionally and his writing, in theory, limited to short notes to his family and lawyers. Earlier this month, however, Other Press published the English translation of his memoir, “I Will Never See the World Again,” which was written behind bars, defiantly, and smuggled out to that world he will never see.

headline: 36 Hours in Rijeka, Croatia
abstract: In this appealingly gritty port city you’ll find seafood, Austro-Hungarian architecture and, next year, a full roster of events celebrating Rijeka’s turn as a European Capital of Culture.
lead_paragraph: If Croatia’s seaside locales have become tourism starlets, then Rijeka, a working-class port city on the Adriatic, is the country’s gritty understudy. So, it came as some surprise when this town, whose skyline merges Hapsburgian decadence with shipyard cranes, was named European Capital of Culture for 2020 over other Croatian candidates like Dubrovnik and Split. “No one believed we would win,” said Ivan Sarar, Rijeka’s head of culture, about the award. “Being noble underdogs is our cool.”

headline: The Student Vote Is Surging. So Are Efforts to Suppress It.
abstract: The share of college students casting ballots doubled from 2014 to 2018, a potential boon to Democrats. But in Texas and elsewhere, Republicans are erecting roadblocks to the polls.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — At Austin Community College, civics is an unwritten part of the curriculum — so much so that for years the school has tapped its own funds to set up temporary early-voting sites on nine of its 11 campuses.

headline: How to Win Impeachment
abstract: And what can be done about “deaths of despair”?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Using Technology to Close the Autism Job Gap
abstract: Adults on the autism spectrum often have difficulty finding employment. Entrepreneurs and advocates are working to fix that by pairing companies with a pool of candidates.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: A French Wine From China? This $300 Bottle Is the Real Thing
abstract: A Rothschild estate in Shandong Province has released its first vintage. It was 10 years in the making.
lead_paragraph: PENGLAI, China — In China, the stories about Château Lafite Rothschild are as notorious as the Bordeaux wine estate is legendary.

headline: No Wind. No Problem. The Sailing Race Must Go On.
abstract: The suspense mounted at the world’s largest regatta in Trieste, Italy: Which boat would come in last?
lead_paragraph: TRIESTE, Italy — The Bora wind blows so fiercely through Trieste, a melancholic port town on the Adriatic Sea, that some sidewalks are lined with handrails. The wind maddens pedestrians, but it also fills the sails of skippers who come from all over to compete in Italy’s aquatic equivalent of the New York City Marathon.

headline: The Cost of Trump’s Aid Freeze in the Trenches of Ukraine’s War
abstract: As President Trump froze military aid to Ukraine and urged it to investigate his rivals, the country was struggling in a bare-bones fight against Russian-backed separatists.
lead_paragraph: ZOLOTE, Ukraine — Lt. Ivan Molchanets peeked over a parapet of sand bags at the front line of the war in Ukraine. Next to him was an empty helmet propped up to trick snipers, already perforated with multiple holes.

headline: Why Trump Signs Are Vanishing
abstract: Thursday: The Trump Organization recently removed the Trump name from signage at Central Park. The next day, the name had made a slight comeback at one ice rink.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Facebook, California, World Series: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Racketeering Law Makes Its Return to Wall Street
abstract: The RICO charges filed against three JPMorgan traders indicate that prosecutors may be resurrecting that law to target white-collar defendants.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: A Victim of the Shadow Government
abstract: How one cabinet secretary discovered a White House back channel for political appointees — and their plot to remove him from office.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: The S.E.C.’s Clayton Turns Oversight Partisan
abstract: What is happening at the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board should alarm everyone. The Trump administration is eroding its independence.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, they often say that personnel is policy. When the president appoints someone to lead and staff a department, agency or board, that is often the surest way for him to control it.

headline: Will the Supreme Court Stand Up for an Unarmed Mexican Teenager Shot by a Border Agent?
abstract: At stake is whether people will still be able to sue federal officials for violating the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, aides to President Trump, who was raging in frustration at his inability to control the country’s border with Mexico, talked him out of the notion of simply shooting migrants. That would be illegal, the aides pointed out.

headline: Why Quiet Cars Are Getting Louder
abstract: All electric vehicles in the U.S. will soon be required to make warning sounds so pedestrians can hear them coming.
lead_paragraph: Driving an electric vehicle in near silence can be a joy for those who don’t relish the rumble and whine of an internal combustion engine. But this hushed operation can be difficult to hear from more than a few feet away, making it a deadly problem for the vision-impaired who can’t see a vehicle approaching.

headline: Data for the Public Good
abstract: Data tells important stories about our country. We should treat it with more respect.
lead_paragraph: These days, the very word “data” elicits fear and suspicion in many of us — and with good reason. DNA-testing companies are sharing genetic information with the government. A firm hired by the Trump campaign gained access to the private information of 50 million Facebook users. Hotels, hospitals, and a consumer credit reporting agency have admitted to major breaches. But while many of us are rightfully concerned about the misuse of our personal data by private entities, we should be just as worried about the important national stories that aren’t told when our fellow citizens don’t feel secure enough to share theirs with researchers.

headline: What Does It Mean to Lose Power on a Farm?
abstract: For many California farmers, it means potentially losing everything.
lead_paragraph: GUINDA, Calif. — Less than a year ago, while my husband and I were picking lettuce, a hot dry wind brought a cloud of smoke over my farm here in the Capay Valley. The wind didn’t die down, and neither did the smoke. For weeks afterward, we harvested produce while covered in the ashes of California’s most deadly wildfire. We cried for the dead, gave thanks for our own survival, and adjusted to a new California reality: Fire will always be knocking at our door.

headline: Will Democrats Become Born-Again Neocons?
abstract: Trump’s foreign policy disasters should lead liberals to rediscover the perils of geopolitical retreat.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s abrupt withdrawal of U.S. forces from Syria has drawn widespread scorn from Republicans and Democrats alike, and with good reason: The U.S. has betrayed an ally and ceded influence to a gallery of rogues — Bashar al-Assad, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Vladimir Putin and Qassim Suleimani, to name a few — in exchange for a hollow talking point about ending endless wars.

headline: A Hard-Fighting Indonesian Lawyer’s Death Has Colleagues Asking Questions
abstract: The police say Golfrid Siregar crashed his motorcycle. Environmentalists and human rights advocates doubt it.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The environmental lawyer from North Sumatra battled palm oil plantations, sand miners and a company building a dam that threatens a newly discovered species of orangutan.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Tried to Charm Congress. He Got Slammed.
abstract: The Facebook C.E.O. attempted to win lawmakers’ support for his cryptocurrency project. They seemed unimpressed, and also grilled him on a range of issues.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers like Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, Dara Khosrowshahi of Uber and Gwyneth Paltrow. Apply to attend here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: 39 Bodies Found in Truck Are Likely Chinese, U.K. Police Say
abstract: The driver, identified as Morris Robinson, 25, remained under arrest on suspicion of murder. Investigators were also at work in Belgium and Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The 39 people found dead in a refrigerated truck trailer in southeastern England were believed to be Chinese citizens, the police said on Thursday, shedding new light on what appeared to be the latest case of human trafficking leading to tragedy.

headline: ‘Portals’ Review: Snoozing Through Another Dimension
abstract: In this science fiction anthology, encounters with interdimensional beings prove to be a complete a waste of time.
lead_paragraph: The cheap-looking, undercooked horror anthology movie “Portals” takes place in August 2020, when we can apparently look forward to the creation of the universe’s first man-made black hole. For reasons left obscure, this occurrence coincides with power failures and the appearance of inky black monoliths all over Earth. The monoliths — “doors,” in the film’s parlance, because people can walk through them — variously drive people insane, entice them to enter by showing them the lives they desire and otherwise steal the objectives of monoliths from better science fiction movies.

headline: ‘The Gallows Act II’ Review: The Play’s the Thing (That Kills)
abstract: Life gets a bit too dramatic for a high school drama student in this horror film.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary horror films, often ruthless in their eagerness to deliver the ostensible scary goods, frequently decline to adhere to their own internal logic. “The Gallows Act II,” a thoroughly undistinguished follow-up to the 2015 film “The Gallows,” seems, for much of its running time, not to have any internal logic to begin with.

headline: ‘The Current War’ Review: Edison vs. Westinghouse, Down to the Wire
abstract: The film, which follows the race to bring electricity to American cities, stars Benedict Cumberbatch and Michael Shannon.
lead_paragraph: A bucket of Oscar bait that’s been sitting around for some two years, “The Current War” may still find an audience. And it should: The film certainly doesn’t reek of failure. But as its energetic early scenes give way to a sluggish second half, you start to sense how much better this good-enough movie might have been.

headline: ‘The Great Alaskan Race’ Review: A Historic Sled Rescue Turned to Mush
abstract: Brian Presley’s film squanders the dramatic ingredients of the early-20th-century sledding adventure it’s based on.
lead_paragraph: In 1925 a diphtheria outbreak in Nome, Alaska, led to what became a legendary sled race for lifesaving serum. For five and a half days in the dead of winter, a team of mushers and their dogs rushed from Nome and back, covering hundreds of miles to deliver medicine to the beleaguered, icebound city. The historic serum run combined dogs, sports and life-or-death stakes, a seemingly perfect setup for cinematic adaptation that “The Great Alaskan Race” fumbles.

headline: ‘Burning Cane’ Review: Poverty and Despair in Rural Louisiana
abstract: The director Phillip Youmans completed this, his first feature, while still in his teens. It feels like the work of an older, and fully formed, artist.
lead_paragraph: “Reflections From Damaged Life” was the subtitle the philosopher Theodor Adorno gave his book “Minima Moralia.” It is an apt description, too, of “Burning Cane,” the debut feature from a young filmmaker, Phillip Youmans. The movie begins with a voice-over from one of its central characters, Helen Wayne, describing in excruciating detail her beloved dog’s mange, and the seemingly dozens of ineffectual cures she has tried on it.

headline: Why Isn’t There a Diet That Works for Everyone?
abstract: Obesity is a population-size crisis in Western countries — but it’s a problem that may resist population-wide solutions.
lead_paragraph: In the United States and other Western countries, diet and nutrition researchers face an urgent imperative: Figure out how to solve the crisis of obesity. About 40 percent of the adults and 19 percent of the children and adolescents in the United States have obesity, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. More and more of them face the increased risks of suffering from diabetes, cardiovascular disease and countless other negative health effects. This situation looks like a single problem from a population standpoint — one that simple guidelines for balancing calorie consumption and expenditure should be able to solve. Instead, a seeming infinitude of variables influence what each of us eats and how the body responds.

headline: As Putin Era Begins to Wane, Russia Unleashes a Sweeping Crackdown
abstract: A wave of arrests against journalists, opposition activists, doctors and religious believers raises a question: Is this a police state in the making or just a highly dysfunctional one?
lead_paragraph: PSKOV, Russia — After a teenager blew himself up inside a branch of Russia’s secret police near the Arctic Circle late last year, a freelance journalist hundreds of miles to the south drew what she thought was “an obvious and banal” conclusion in her weekly radio commentary.

headline: Happy as a Crab That Just Finished a Maze
abstract: Crustaceans experienced in running a labyrinth made it to the finish line — and their prize — without wrong turns.
lead_paragraph: To the rippling sound of an aquarium pump, a small crab comes around the corner. It moves sideways, sticking close to the walls. But when it catches sight of a mussel — laid as a reward at the end of the maze it has just walked — the crab breaks into a skipping run, throwing itself on the treat with abandon.

headline: ‘Is This a Room’ Review: Why’d She Blow the Whistle?
abstract: Tina Satter’s remarkable docudrama recreates the bizarrely banal interrogation that led to the arrest of the intelligence contractor Reality Winner.
lead_paragraph: A lot of what’s being said on the stage of the Vineyard Theater these days is maddeningly ordinary — the kind of friendly, vapid conversation you might exchange with a stranger in a grocery store line. Yet every word spoken, no matter how banal, seems to stretch your nerves closer to snapping.

headline: As Mario Draghi Departs, the E.C.B. Is Divided Over His Policies
abstract: The central bank president oversaw his last monetary policy meeting. Christine Lagarde, his successor, may face a revolt by opponents of his easy-money policies.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi led his last monetary policy meeting as president of the European Central Bank on Thursday, his legacy as savior of the eurozone clouded by divisions among the bank’s policymakers that have burst into the open in the final months of his tenure.

headline: In China, FIFA’s Focus Is Soccer, Not Human Rights
abstract: After faulting the United States and Canada last year, FIFA is more muted as it brings a new tournament to China.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — FIFA, the international body governing global soccer, has come under heavy criticism in recent years for awarding two World Cups in a row to authoritarian countries, Russia in 2018 and Qatar in 2022.

headline: What Do We Want?
abstract: What we already have!
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Government Loophole Gave Oil Companies $18 Billion Windfall
abstract: A 1990s effort to encourage drilling in the Gulf of Mexico has cost the government $18 billion in lost revenue from oil royalties, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: The United States government has lost billions of dollars of oil and gas revenue to fossil-fuel companies because of a loophole in a decades-old law, a federal watchdog agency said Thursday, offering the first detailed accounting of the consequences of a misstep by lawmakers that is expected to continue costing taxpayers for decades to come.

headline: What to Know About the Power Shut-Offs — Again
abstract: Thursday: As utilities around the state prepared to cut power, firefighters battled the explosive Kincade Fire in Sonoma County. Also: Soccer in L.A.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tuckahoe, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Ridgefield, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tuckahoe, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and the Sutton Place neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and the Sutton Place neighborhood.

abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tuckahoe, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: In Northern Ireland, Brexit Deal Is Seen as ‘Betrayal’
abstract: Enraged by the deal’s plan to effectively put a border in the Irish Sea, hundreds of members of loyalist paramilitary groups met this week to discuss how to respond.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — They call it “the Betrayal Act.”

headline: Kincade Fire in Sonoma County: Residents Flee as 10,000 Acres Burn
abstract: The largely uncontained blaze damaged dozens of structures on Thursday, but there were no reports of injuries.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire driven by strong winds has torn through 16,000 acres in Sonoma County, north of San Francisco, prompting the county sheriff’s office to issue evacuation orders for hundreds of residents.

headline: Bangladesh Sentences 16 to Death for Young Woman’s Burning
abstract: After Nusrat Jahan Rafi accused a teacher of touching her, she was murdered in a case that shook the country.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Having accused a teacher of touching her inappropriately, Nusrat Jahan Rafi was lured to the rooftop of her Islamic school in eastern Bangladesh.She faced intense pressure to withdraw the accusations. When she refused, she was doused with kerosene and set on fire.She managed to flee, and on the way to the hospital her brother recorded her naming her attackers. She died four days later, and her killing sent a shock wave across the country.On Thursday, a Bangladeshi court sentenced 16 people, including the head teacher she had accused of touching her, to death for her murder.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Occupy Alcatraz: Native American Activism in the Modern Era’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about Native American protest and activism — past and present.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Occupy Alcatraz: Native American Activism in the Modern Era”

headline: The Most Popular Properties of September
abstract: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in September are in New York, California, Kansas and Nova Scotia.
lead_paragraph: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in September included homes in Kansas, California and New York City (all also on August’s list), as well as a home in Canada overlooking the Atlantic.

headline: ‘Farming’ Review: A Young Life of Self-Loathing
abstract: Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje looks at the impact of a British system that placed the children of African immigrants with Caucasian foster families.
lead_paragraph: If the story told in “Farming” hadn’t been taken from the experiences of its writer-director, Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje, you might think it too outlandish to be plausible.

headline: Wendell Pierce: ‘I Still Have Fear, But Now I Have Courage’
abstract: Starring as Willy Loman in “Death of a Salesman” in London has whetted Wendell Pierce’s appetite to take on all the big roles.
lead_paragraph: Wendell Pierce is having a very good year.

headline: Twyla Tharp Wants You to Move
abstract: In her new book, “Keep It Moving,” the choreographer applies the lessons of a lifetime in dance to an ordinary body. Yours.
lead_paragraph: Take up space. Stretch. Move your body.

headline: Flea Had a Wild Life. Then He Joined Red Hot Chili Peppers.
abstract: In a new memoir, the bassist describes how he expanded his consciousness, found his muse and landed in a storied rock band.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — On a Thursday in mid-October, Flea sat in a patio chair he’d dragged down to the lawn, looking out at the green lake in his backyard. As the late-morning sun beat down on his graying skull and the tattoo-dotted arms under his Vin Scully T-shirt, he curled his battered bare toes in the grass just centimeters from an ashy fossil that was once a piece of dog waste, and began reckoning with the unanswerable:

headline: What We Know About the U.K. Truck Deaths
abstract: The police say that the victims are believed to be from China, and that investigators have found out how the truck and container entered Britain, but there are still far more questions than answers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thirty-nine people were found dead in a refrigerated truck container about 25 miles east of London early Wednesday, and the authorities have said that all of the victims are believed to be Chinese citizens.

headline: In India, Release of Hate Crime Data Depends on Who the Haters Are
abstract: Officials chose to disclose figures about attacks committed by left-wing extremists but not religious-based crimes or violence against journalists.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When India released its annual crime report this week, more than a year behind schedule, certain pieces of data were conspicuously missing.

headline: Kincade Fire Burns in Sonoma County
abstract: A wildfire in Sonoma County, Calif., has forced hundreds of residents to evacuate. Strong winds are driving the fire, which has burned at least 10,000 acres.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire in Sonoma County, Calif., has forced hundreds of residents to evacuate. Strong winds are driving the fire, which has burned at least 10,000 acres.

headline: Trump Mentions a Wall in Colorado, Then Says He Was Kidding
abstract: “We’re building a wall in Colorado,” the president said on Wednesday. “We’re building a beautiful wall.” On Thursday, he said he had mentioned the state “kiddingly.”
lead_paragraph: During a speech at an energy conference on Wednesday, President Trump listed Colorado as one of several states where he wanted to build a wall.

headline: Staring Into the Soul of the Catskills Through a Pinhole
abstract: With his camera obscura, Shi Guorui reinterprets the landscapes of the Hudson River School painter Thomas Cole.
lead_paragraph: PALENVILLE, N.Y. — Sometime last summer, a rectangular tent appeared in the woods off a trail in the Catskills. Sheathed in plastic and cordoned off with yellow caution tape, it looked more like a crime scene than a camp site. But if anyone dared approach it, one small clue gave away its real function: a hole smaller than a pencil eraser facing Kaaterskill Falls, whose perilous double cascade is one of the region’s most cherished attractions.

headline: M.L.B. Will Investigate Umpire’s Tweet About Trump Impeachment
abstract: In a tweet that was deleted, the umpire said he planned to buy a firearm because he believed the impeachment inquiry into President Trump could lead to a new American civil war.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball will look into a tweet sent by Rob Drake, an umpire, that mentioned the possible impeachment of President Trump, firearms and the specter of an American civil war, a spokesman said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Making Waves’ Review: How Sound in Cinema Moves Us
abstract: A documentary provides vivid examples of the power of audio in a motion picture.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about film technology, at least those that aspire to reach some portion of a mainstream audience, have to make wonkiness ingratiating. “Making Waves: The Art of Cinematic Sound,” a cogent and winning picture directed by Midge Costin, does this in a variety of ways.

headline: Review: ‘Mrs. Fletcher’ Tracks an Empty-Nester’s Sexual Awakening
abstract: The HBO limited series, based on the Tom Perrotta novel, stars Kathryn Hahn in a familiar story of self-actualization.
lead_paragraph: Porn: It’s both good and bad. College: good and bad. Raising children: good and bad. Horniness: good and bad. The suburbs: good and bad. Cellphones, aging, dating, coffee, parties, threesomes, change — all together now: good and bad.

headline: At the Met, Heavy Metal on a Continental Scale
abstract: For Maximilian I, the emperor at the heart of “The Last Knight,” armor was as much for propaganda as protection.
lead_paragraph: “War is a force that gives us meaning,” wrote the veteran foreign correspondent Chris Hedges — an adage he delivered with vicious irony. War can pick up the dull, lousy clay of your little human life, and refashion you into a hero or martyr. War muffles brute inequities of power and capital, and entrances you with blandishments of honor. War is a storyteller, with a tale so grand and corrupt that even death becomes beautiful.

headline: Freshness in a Changed Climate: High Altitudes, Old Grapes
abstract: In its wineries, Familia Torres, a global producer, fights climate change by lowering emissions; in its vineyards, the company tries to adapt.
lead_paragraph: This is the third of a four-part series on winemaking and climate change.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 30, 2019
abstract: What story does this graph about baseball, basketball and football ticket sales tell?
lead_paragraph: This graph of annual number of tickets sales for three sports — baseball, basketball and football — originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: Let’s Double Date. But Maybe Your Wife Could Stay Home?
abstract: A reader wonders whether it’s O.K. to tell a friend that his partner isn’t welcome at their next outing.
lead_paragraph: My husband has become close friends with a man he met through work. He and his wife live nearby, and we’ve gone out with them as a couple a few times. I like my husband’s friend, but my husband and I really dislike his wife. We’ve tried, but she’s cold, rude and a Debbie Downer. I have no interest in seeing her. The problem: My husband’s friend keeps inviting us to socialize with them as a couple. We keep saying we’re busy. But my husband is torn: He thinks we should tell his friend that we just don’t want to see his wife. I disagree. Thoughts?

headline: Fiber and Yogurt Tied to Lower Lung Cancer Risk
abstract: By promoting a healthy gut microbiome, a high-fiber diet and foods like yogurt may lower lung cancer risk, even among smokers.
lead_paragraph: Eating yogurt and fiber may lower the risk for lung cancer.

headline: Memes Made Spice Adams More Famous Than the N.F.L. Could
abstract: After nine years of playing in obscurity for the Chicago Bears and the San Francisco 49ers, Spice Adams has become ubiquitous for his memes.
lead_paragraph: In a bathroom at a WeWork in the Gramercy Park neighborhood, Anthony (Spice) Adams was transformed.

headline: The Astros Soared Into the World Series. Now They’re Reeling.
abstract: A controversy involving Houston’s assistant general manager and the stout hitting of the Washington Nationals have put the Astros on the defensive on and off the field.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few days later, it all seems too perfect: The Houston Astros clinched the American League pennant last Saturday with a home run in the bottom of the ninth inning by Jose Altuve, their leader and heartbeat. Minute Maid Park erupted in joy. The Astros would be hosting the opening games of the World Series for the first time, and they would have their best pitchers rested and ready.

headline: Is Cape Lookout an Omen for Other Barrier Islands?
abstract: We can’t keep spending billions to fortify these islands against more intense storms.
lead_paragraph: Along the increasingly crowded Eastern Seaboard, Cape Lookout National Seashore is a place apart — 56 miles of wide and mostly pristine beaches on barrier islands stretching from Cape Hatteras to Beaufort, N.C. No paved roads or resorts intrude. You can stand on the beach and have a sense of what it must have been like there centuries ago.

headline: Who’s Contending for the Heisman Trophy?
abstract: Quarterbacks again appear to have the inside track for college football’s top award.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough enough to follow in the footsteps of one Heisman Trophy winner. Try two.

headline: After This Fungus Turns Ants Into Zombies, Their Bodies Explode
abstract: The life cycle of Ophiocordyceps is like something from a sci-fi movie: “You think, where the hell did that come from?”
lead_paragraph: Evolutionary biologists retrace the history of life in all its wondrous forms. Some search for the origin of our species. Others hunt for the origin of birds.

headline: Swoon Installation at Fine Art Print Fair
abstract: It’s “a celebration of printmaking,” the artist said of the 24-foot work featuring paper cutouts, etching and block printing.
lead_paragraph: The artist known as Swoon has used a variety of mediums to create whimsical worlds and captivating portraits throughout her work, both for the street and the museum. But her latest large-scale installation, which is on view  at the Javits Center in Manhattan, centers on one method the artist is well acquainted with: printmaking.

headline: ‘Western Stars’ Review: Bruce Springsteen and Broken Cowboys
abstract: This concert film, directed by the singer and Thom Zimny, puts Bruce in a barn with an orchestra to make some magic.
lead_paragraph: “You can get a little too fond of the blues,” Bruce Springsteen sings in “Hello Sunshine.” It’s a song about the seductiveness of melancholy, one that warns, “You fall in love with lonely, you end up that way.”

headline: American Held in Russia on Spying Charge Must Stay in Prison
abstract: Paul H. Whelan, a Marine veteran arrested last December, said in court that a prison guard had assaulted him. He said he had been framed and that Russia held him hostage to be exchanged.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — An American accused of spying in Russia will spend the rest of the year in a Moscow prison, a judge ruled on Thursday, in a brief court session where the defendant said he had been assaulted by guards and denied medical care.

headline: Always Building, From the Garage to Her Company
abstract: Jeri Ellsworth started as a self-taught computer hacker and chip designer. In an industry dominated by men, she’s the head of a company focusing on augmented reality.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a new series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: It’s More Than Pay: Striking Teachers Demand Counselors and Nurses
abstract: School strikes have put teachers in the spotlight. But demands for more counselors, nurses and psychologists are growing.
lead_paragraph: In a typical week, Adrienne Vaccarezza-Isla, a school counselor in Chicago, might help a dozen eighth graders apply to high schools across the city. Or try to convince a mother that her daughter, who had seen her get shot years earlier, should join a group for students dealing with trauma. Or work with sixth and seventh graders on time management.

headline: Officials Called It a Heart Attack. Inmates Saw a Bloody Beating.
abstract: John McMillon was a 67-year-old inmate who was looking forward to his parole hearing. He never made it there.
lead_paragraph: After spending nearly a quarter-century behind bars, John McMillon was counting down to the day that he would be eligible to be released on parole.

headline: Psychobros
abstract: We examine the portrayal of masculinity as mental illness in “Joker,” “Succession” and “Fight Club.”
lead_paragraph: We revisit “Fight Club” on the 20th anniversary of its release, and consider how the trope of the “psychobro” is showing up onscreen — in the new blockbuster “Joker” and HBO’s critically acclaimed series “Succession” — and off.

headline: Mourners Remember Atatiana Jefferson: ‘Our Montgomery Moment’
abstract: To the nation, the woman shot by a Fort Worth police officer became a symbol of the need for police accountability. To her family, she was “Tay”: an aspiring doctor and hands-on aunt.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — In death, she became a national symbol: a rallying cry for police accountability and a reminder of the long-fraught relationship between black residents and the Fort Worth Police Department.

headline: The Black-and-White World of Big Tech
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg presented us with an either-or choice of free speech — either we have it or we’re China. Tech leaders have a duty to admit it’s much more complicated.
lead_paragraph: So, sort of free speech.

headline: Hoping for a Spooky Halloween? We Have Some Suggestions
abstract: Writers, directors and other creators share recommendations for how to spend the scariest night of the year.
lead_paragraph: You’d think that Elvira, Mistress of the Dark, would have plenty of advice on how to spend Halloween. After all, she’s made a career out of highlighting the spooky and macabre.

headline: Kibbe and More in Williamsburg
abstract: At Sakib, the menu reads like an exhaustive listing of street food from the Levant.
lead_paragraph: At Sakib, the menu reads like an exhaustive listing of street food from the Levant.

headline: Spinach Pies, and Other Reasons to Linger at Sakib
abstract: At this restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, dips, kibbe and the puffy filled treats called fatayer round out a full menu.
lead_paragraph: Sakib, a restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, looks like the sort of place you would pop into for a takeout order of freshly shaved shawarma piled over yellow rice. But if you did that, you wouldn’t get to taste the assortment of dips, the crisp and meaty kibbe and the trays of puffy pies shaped like small pyramids, or open-faced boats that emerge from the kitchen’s imposing oven, imported from Jordan.

headline: A Ratmansky Premiere Highlights American Ballet Theater’s Season
abstract: The company will celebrate its 80th anniversary in spring with some of its oldest and most recent repertory, and Alexei Ratmansky’s “Of Love and Rage.”
lead_paragraph: “Of Love and Rage,” a new evening-length ballet by Alexei Ratmansky, will have its New York premiere during American Ballet Theater’s spring season, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: National Dance Institute Starts Teacher Training Program
abstract: The organization will offer intensive on-site instruction for teachers and consulting services for dance education groups.
lead_paragraph: National Dance Institute will continue spreading its holistic dance education method with a new teacher training program. The organization, founded in 1976 by the distinguished New York City Ballet dancer Jacques d’Amboise, announced the establishment of the N.D.I. Collaborative for Teaching and Learning on Thursday.

headline: Your Job Will Never Love You Back
abstract: TBH it’s pretty rude that your work causes you endless stress and never even goes to couples’ therapy with you.
lead_paragraph: This is Megan Greenwell’s last week as your Work Friend. A newer, shinier Work Friend will debut in two weeks. Send questions to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: China Holds #MeToo Activist Who Wrote About Hong Kong Protests
abstract: She spoke critically of China’s restrictions on free speech. Now the authorities are accusing her of “provoking trouble.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have detained a journalist who was a leading figure in the country’s #MeToo movement and had recently written about the antigovernment protests in Hong Kong, her friends said on Thursday.

headline: Turkish and Kurdish Forces Said to Clash in Syria
abstract: Military forces maneuvered for position after an American withdrawal, apparently violating a United States-brokered cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkish forces and Turkish-backed militias appeared to have clashed with the Kurdish-led militia and its new allies, the Syrian government, in northeastern Syria on Thursday, raising the temperature in an already volatile area where multiple players are maneuvering for position after the abrupt pullout of American troops.

headline: The Man Who Feeds Ants
abstract: And other tales of pollution in Karachi.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Walking along the beach recently, I met a man who was feeding ants. When I spotted him bending over a bush throwing some powdery stuff, I assumed he was spreading poison to kill rats. Then I thought: I have seen people do odd things on Karachi’s beaches, but nobody bothers killing anything. There is enough poison in the sea.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I’m on my way to Austin, to talk literature with the excellent graduate students at the Michener Center for Writers and then to take part in the rejuvenating extravaganza of the Texas Book Festival, with its happy collisions of readers and authors and crusty book critics thrown together in a kind of literary particle accelerator. Quarks will fly. (I’ll be interviewing Benjamin Dreyer and Mary Norris about the wonders of language, and keeping a hopeful eye out for Raina Telgemeier, my 10-year-old’s fave.)

headline: Boris Johnson Calls for December Election in Push to Break Brexit Deadlock
abstract: Britain’s prime minister challenged lawmakers to approve a general election, but the opposition Labour Party reacted coolly to the idea.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson, stymied by Parliament on his plan to leave the European Union by the end of the month, challenged lawmakers on Thursday to approve a general election in December, hoping to win a popular mandate to carry out his vision of a swift Brexit.

headline: Trump’s Respite From Bad News Cycles: Medal of Freedom Ceremonies
abstract: He began giving out the award later in his presidency than his predecessors, but is doing so with increasing frequency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump enjoys a unilateral executive move. For trade negotiations, he has tariffs. For several of his political allies, he has pardons. And for a growing number of athletes, donors and assorted Friends of the White House, he has the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

headline: Russian Circus Bear Mauls Its Handler, Terrifying Crowd Just Yards Away
abstract: The circus manager said neither the trainer nor the bear were seriously injured, and blamed spectators for provoking the animal with flashes from cellphone cameras.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian bears, according to the Kremlin, “aren’t idiots,” so they never attack President Vladimir V. Putin when he takes to the wilderness for some relaxation. But ordinary folk, a Russian bear handler discovered this week when he was mauled during a circus performance, do not share the president’s aura of intimidating invincibility.

headline: Tim Ryan Ends His 2020 Presidential Campaign
abstract: Mr. Ryan, a congressman from Ohio, had argued that he could win back Midwesterners with a platform focused on the decline of traditional manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio dropped out of the presidential race on Thursday, ending a campaign that sought to champion Midwestern manufacturing workers but failed to gain traction.

headline: Update Complete: U.S. Nuclear Weapons No Longer Need Floppy Disks
abstract: The Defense Department has transitioned away from a 1970s-era nuclear command and control system that relied on eight-inch floppy disks. The “modernizing” effort was quietly completed in June.
lead_paragraph: Rest easy, people of Earth: The United States’ nuclear arsenal will no longer rely on a computer system that uses eight-inch floppy disks, in an update the Defense Department has cast as a step into the future but which some observers might be surprised to learn was required at all.

headline: Earthquakes Are Jolting the Netherlands. Gas Drilling Is to Blame.
abstract: Tremors from extraction are blighting 350 square miles. Thousands of homeowners claim damage, and production will end in 2022.
lead_paragraph: GRONINGEN, the Netherlands — Driving through fields of low-lying Dutch farmland you pass an occasional odd cluster of silvery pipes and tanks. They are the only visible sign that deep below this northeast corner of the Netherlands is one of the world’s largest natural gas fields.

headline: Umpire Joe West Files Defamation Suit Against a Former Player
abstract: The lawsuit accuses Paul Lo Duca, a former catcher, of falsely stating on a podcast that West borrowed a pitcher’s car in return for an easier strike zone.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Joe West, a longtime umpire for Major League Baseball, has sued the former catcher Paul Lo Duca, accusing him of defamation for comments on a podcast that described West trading an expanded strike zone for the right to drive a pitcher’s classic car.

headline: Passed Over by Cubs, Joe Girardi Will Manage the Phillies
abstract: David Ross heads to Chicago, and San Diego picks Jayce Tingler. The Mets? They’re still shopping.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When Joe Girardi guided the Yankees to their 27th World Series championship, in 2009, he did it by beating the Philadelphia Phillies. He also wore No. 27, signifying the title the Yankees were chasing. Things are much different for him now.

headline: Republicans Fight Trump’s Impeachment by Attacking the Process
abstract: President Trump wants his party to defend him more aggressively. Senators instead are denouncing the House investigation.
