lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress struggled for a second consecutive day Thursday to defend President Trump against Democrats’ impeachment inquiry amid a steady stream of damaging revelations about his conduct, leveling another symbolic objection to a process they said was fundamentally unfair.

headline: ‘Black and Blue’ Review: A Cop Thriller for Our Age of Dread
abstract: Naomie Harris plays a rookie running from bad police officers and drug dealers in Deon Taylor’s violent, astute film.
lead_paragraph: A supremely stressful day in Alicia West’s life — she will be shot at, betrayed and hunted by ruthless men on both sides of the law — begins with a morning jog through a quiet New Orleans neighborhood. Head down, earbuds in, minding her business, Alicia is stopped and frisked by police officers because she “fits the profile.” In other words, because she’s black. But when one of the patrolmen runs her identification, he tells his partner to let her go because “she’s blue,” i.e. one of their colleagues on the force.

headline: A Menagerie of French Whimsy Takes Auction Prices ‘to the Next Level’
abstract: A Sotheby’s sale featuring the personal collection of the sculptors François-Xavier Lalanne and Claude Lalanne rakes in $53 million.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Two million!” screamed a voice from the crush of Sotheby’s staff members taking instructions from telephone bidders.

headline: ‘Synonyms’ Review: Brilliant. Relentless. Comic. Tragic.
abstract: In this scorching movie from Nadav Lapid, a young Israeli flees to Paris and tries to transform into a Frenchman. It goes badly.
lead_paragraph: When the young Israeli in “Synonyms” rushes through Paris, he keeps his head down. Intense and wary, he views beauty as a bribe that the city pays strangers to keep them from its heart. So he walks and talks, trying to find it, head bowed while he practices his French. It’s a habit that feels like a mania and looks like a defense. As he circles the city he’s building a wall, each French word a rebuke to the Hebrew he refuses to speak.

headline: ‘The Kill Team’ Review: Bullying on the Battlefield
abstract: Alexander Skarsgard stars in a film based on the murders of Afghan civilians by American soldiers nearly a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: In “The Kill Team,” the director Dan Krauss has made a dramatized version of his 2014 documentary of the same title; it explores the same events from a different angle, but with less impact. Both movies concern a case from about a decade ago in which five American soldiers were accused of murdering Afghan civilians. Calvin Gibbs, the staff sergeant whom the documentary presents as a driving force behind the killings, received a life sentence.

headline: Making Capitol History, Cummings Is Remembered as a ‘Master of the House’
abstract: Representative Elijah E. Cummings, who died last week, became the first African-American elected official to lie in state in the Capitol on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the powerful Democrat whose booming baritone and impassioned cries for decency reverberated through the halls of Congress for more than two decades, made history one final time on Thursday, as the first African-American elected official to lie in state in the United States Capitol.

headline: Joe Biden or Elizabeth Warren? New Polls Differ on Who’s Leading 2020 Race
abstract: Surveys released this week show varying, and sometimes conflicting, races unfolding nationally and in early primary states.
lead_paragraph: Just over three months before Iowans caucus for Democratic presidential candidates, four polls out this week present a muddled picture of a primary race that is unfolding in varying, and sometimes conflicting, ways nationally and in early-voting states.

headline: Colorado Fossils Show How Mammals Raced to Fill Dinosaurs’ Void
abstract: An unusually rich trove found in Colorado reveals the world in which our mammalian forebears evolved into larger creatures.
lead_paragraph: Some 66 million years ago, mammals caught their lucky break. An asteroid crashed into what is now Chicxulub, Mexico, and set off a catastrophic chain of events that led to the annihilation of the non-avian dinosaurs. That day began their furry ascension to the top of a brave new world, the one from which our species would one day emerge. But little is known about the time period directly after the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction, or K-Pg event, because the fossil record is lacking.

headline: At American Ballet Theater, New Romantics Can’t Beat a Greek God
abstract: The company takes a stab at love, but what stands out this season is the birth of an elegant Apollo: Calvin Royal III.
lead_paragraph: The dancers at American Ballet Theater often describe the company as a family. Sometimes I wonder: Is that good? Is it true? How is it reflected in the art?

headline: Foraging for Ocher in the Pacific Northwest
abstract: The artist and archivist Heidi Gustafson trawls beaches and abandoned quarries in search of one of the world’s oldest pigments.
lead_paragraph: The artist and archivist Heidi Gustafson trawls beaches and abandoned quarries in search of one of the world’s oldest pigments.

headline: The Woman Archiving the World’s Ochers
abstract: At her cabin in the woods of Washington, Heidi Gustafson is creating a many-colored library of one of mankind’s first pigments.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Gustafson has Whidbey Island’s Double Bluff Beach to herself. But she’s not sunbathing or scanning the waves for whales. Instead, she’s traveled to the northern end of Puget Sound in Washington to crouch, back to the ocean, foraging for ocher at the base of a cliff. Armed with a small magnet and a knife, she stoops low to assess the striations in the rock face, formed by glacial activity hundreds of thousands of years before.

headline: Film Club: ‘‘I’m Worried That I Will Die:’ Hong Kong Protesters Write Final Goodbyes’
abstract: What are you willing to fight for — even at the risk of being injured, or dying?
lead_paragraph: Teachers: Please note that this week’s film includes powerful and disturbing images — including violence between protesters and police. Be sure to review the film before screening with your class.

headline: Pence Says U.S. Companies Leave ‘Conscience at the Door’ Over China
abstract: In a speech on the United States’ China policy, the vice president said companies should adhere to American values. He criticized Nike and the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence criticized American companies on Thursday for trying to silence speech that expresses support for democratic, liberal values in order to maintain access to the Chinese market, saying the corporations should adhere to American principles while doing business with China.

headline: An Inmate Died After a Struggle With Guards. Here’s How We Found Out.
abstract: Our story about John McMillon, 67, who died in prison under questionable circumstances, started with tips from three inmates.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Is 15 Too Old to Trick-or-Treat? One City Said Yes
abstract: No one’s been arrested for the offense in almost 50 years in Chesapeake, Va., but the city changed its rules this year after an outcry turned it into the butt of jokes.
lead_paragraph: Are you too old to go trick-or-treating?

headline: Wait — Is Activated Charcoal a Scam?
abstract: Well ... it’s great if you work in an E.R.
lead_paragraph: [This is the weekly Styles newsletter. You can sign up for “Wait —” right here.]

headline: The Times’s ‘Obsessive’ Coverage of Hillary Clinton’s Emails
abstract: A reader calls on the newspaper to apologize. Also: Rudolph Giuliani and President Trump; America’s foreign wars; life in a Queens basement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ms. Monopoly Creates a World Where No One Wins
abstract: Games like this one attempt to have players reckon with social inequalities. But there’s a fine line between teaching and pandering.
lead_paragraph: For nearly as long as people have been playing games, we’ve used them as tools of moral and political education. An Indian folk game, created to teach about the ups and downs of karma, morphed into Chutes & Ladders. In the 19th-century Checkered Game of Life, virtues and vices like honesty and idleness became spaces on the board that could send you forward or backward on the path that eventually became The Game of Life.

headline: The United States Has Never Truly Been a Democracy
abstract: We haven’t yet perfected our system of government.
lead_paragraph: Between impeachment inquiries, questions about the security of our elections and the proliferation of books and articles announcing that democracy is dead, it’s clear that many people in the United States are disillusioned with democracy.

headline: G.O.P. Protest at Impeachment Inquiry: ‘Thuggish and Juvenile’
abstract: Readers criticize the protest as undignified and a “dangerous and undemocratic turn to mob rule.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ingo Maurer, Designer Known as a Poet of Light, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Maurer’s wonky fascination with technology led to lamps he made out of scribbled memos, tea strainers and incandescent bulbs with feathered wings.
lead_paragraph: Ingo Maurer, a  German lighting designer who was Promethean in his delivery of illumination — fashioning lamps out of shattered crockery, scribbled memos, holograms, tea strainers and incandescent bulbs with feathered wings — died on Monday in Munich. He was 87.

headline: Read the Trump Administration’s Warning Letter to Laura Cooper
abstract: The No. 2 Pentagon official told Ms. Cooper, the military’s Russia-Ukraine expert, not to talk to Congress. She did anyway.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has declared that the executive branch will not cooperate with the House’s impeachment inquiry, but some officials have nevertheless provided testimony to Congress about what they know about whether President Trump’s attempts to pressure the Ukrainian government into investigating his political rivals were a quid pro quo in return for aid.

headline: The Artist Painting Unwitting New York Subway Riders
abstract: At just 23 years old, the Bronx-born Devon Rodriguez is a finalist in this year’s prestigious Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition.
lead_paragraph: Devon Rodriguez’s bedroom in his grandmother’s South Bronx apartment looks like any 23-year-old’s space might: a flat-screen television hangs on the wall, a checkered duvet cover rests atop a lofted bed and black drapes dangle in the window, ready to hide the sunlight. But set up in the corner are the wooden easel and erstwhile nightstand, now a painter’s table, that Rodriguez uses to make the hyper-realist portraits of New Yorkers for which he is becoming recognized. A recent self-portrait (he has done one every year since 2010) called “Reflection” rests against the baseboard and shows the artist in a Metallica T-shirt, a tattooed arm by his side, the opposite hand holding a paintbrush. Next to it is “Jonathan” (2018), which depicts his cousin seated in a chair, his Keith Haring T-shirt in full view.

headline: Surprise, You Have Early Breast Cancer
abstract: I had no history of cancer in my family. At 41, getting a mammogram was just a thing to check off my to-do list.
lead_paragraph: When you find out you have breast cancer, you might be pulling ramen from water with a pasta fork. Your son might be watching “SpongeBob,” so you might hear that dull drone of Patrick Star the starfish in your mind as you fall.

headline: Brexit, China, Bangladesh: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Breaking the Brexit deadlock.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Extremist Content Online, Rivalries and Reflections
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the many robust conversations we’ve seen taking place in the comments section of our writing prompts lately, we’re posing a challenge for students this coming week:

headline: Amazon’s Profit Falls Sharply as Company Buys Growth
abstract: The company has been investing heavily to keep its giant core businesses growing at the expense of higher profits.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon is back in the business of buying growth.

headline: ‘Not Much Scares Me.’ Then She Entered the Haunted House.
abstract: Three very different Halloween adventures test a horror-film enthusiast with little experience visiting haunted houses.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve watched a few horror movies, you’ll recognize this scene: The cute teenager runs up the stairs instead of out the house to escape a ruthless killer. Or how about this one: A group of friends purposefully split up in an abandoned warehouse or a dilapidated cemetery or an overgrown forest while being chased by a maniac with an ax.

headline: Trump Cancels Subscriptions to The New York Times and The Washington Post
abstract: The White House also encouraged federal agencies to let their subscriptions lapse, saying that “taxpayer dollars will be saved.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump has called members of the press “enemies of the people,” deemed critical coverage “fake,” accused news organizations of treason and threatened to make it easier to sue journalists for libel.

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Very Special’ Victory in Syria
abstract: It’s certainly special for Erdogan, Putin and al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: In announcing a “permanent” cease-fire along the Turkish-Syrian border on Wednesday, President Trump smugly declared that “this was an outcome created by us, the United States, and nobody else.” The president, incapable of irony, was probably not referring to his own abrupt decision on Oct. 6 to stab Syrian Kurds in the back by giving Turkey a green light to attack them. Rather, he was giving credit to himself and to his vice president and secretary of state, who negotiated a partial cease-fire a week after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey sent troops across the Syrian border to drive out Kurdish forces he considers a threat.

headline: The Day the Trump Boom Died
abstract: Why has business confidence collapsed?
lead_paragraph: Last spring Donald Trump and the people around him probably thought they had a relatively clear path to re-election.

headline: Pete Buttigieg, Anna Wintour and Tiffany Haddish at God’s Love Benefit
abstract: “David Byrne’s American Utopia” opens in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: “David Byrne’s American Utopia” opens in Times Square.

headline: A Trump Applauds Buttigieg at God’s Love Benefit
abstract: And David Byrne headlines a dance party in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: God’s Love We Deliver held a starry awards dinner at Cipriani South Street on Monday night. Lupita Nyong’o was there, along with Marisa Tomei, Audra McDonald and Karen Elson.

headline: Vlatko Andonovski Set to Be Hired as U.S. Women’s Soccer Coach
abstract: Andonovski, 43, will replace Jill Ellis, who led the American team to victory in the last two Women’s World Cups.
lead_paragraph: Vlatko Andonovski has agreed to become the next coach of the United States women’s national team, according to two soccer officials familiar with the decision, and he will be introduced as the 10th coach in the program’s history early next week.

headline: ‘Tough Love: My Story of the Things Worth Fighting For,’ by Susan Rice: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from ‘Tough Love: My Story of the Things Worth Fighting For,’ by Susan Rice
lead_paragraph: My first contact with Barack Obama came in a phone call from him in the summer of 2004.

headline: Biden Campaign Drops Opposition to Super PAC Support
abstract: After ending the third quarter with less cash than four rivals, Joe Biden’s campaign reversed course to stop discouraging supporters from forming a super PAC to help him in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign effectively dropped its longstanding opposition to receiving the assistance of super PACs on Thursday, opening the door for wealthy supporters to spend unlimited amounts of money to try and lift him in the Democratic primary.

headline: Missing From Friday’s World Series Lineup in Washington: The President
abstract: The president won’t be at the first World Series game in D.C. since 1933. But he said he would go to Sunday’s game, if there is one, though he has no plans to throw out a ball.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All of red-shirt-wearing, baby-shark-clapping Washington will be at Nationals Park on Friday night as the nation’s capital hosts its first World Series in 86 years, or at least as much of the city as can squeeze into the stadium. But missing the action will be Washington’s most famous transplant resident.

headline: 7 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 18 Art Exhibitions to View in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

headline: 5 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: 6 Dance Performances to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 9 Things to Do With Your Kids in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 12 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: 5 Comedy Shows to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: A Climbing Ban at Uluru Ends a Chapter. But There’s More to This Australian Story.
abstract: While the ban on ascending the iconic rock is a once-unthinkable victory for an Aboriginal people, they still face material hardship and a measure of resistance.
lead_paragraph: ULURU, Australia — The creation stories of the Anangu people are sacred. Some can be shared only with men, some only with women. Some are revealed, layer by layer, as an Anangu grows and matures. Outsiders can be told only what a tjitji, or child, would hear.

headline: Brandon Taubman, Astros Executive, Is Fired Over Outburst
abstract: The Astros said interviews revealed that Taubman had indeed directed inappropriate comments at female reporters after a victory last weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Astros fired Brandon Taubman, their assistant general manager, on Thursday and apologized to the women Taubman had made inappropriate comments toward, as well as to the reporter who made those comments public.

headline: A Forecast for a Warming World: Learn to Live With Fire
abstract: The Kincade fire is burning more than 10,000 acres in California. Other areas of the country are experiencing drought so understanding fire is becoming ever more important.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facing down 600 wildfires in the past three days alone, emergency workers rushed to evacuate tens of thousands of people in Southern California on Thursday as a state utility said one of its major transmission lines broke near the source of the out-of-control Kincade blaze in Northern California.

headline: Woodie Flowers, Who Made Science a Competitive Sport, Dies at 75
abstract: His hands-on methods of teaching mechanical engineering at M.I.T. made him a star on campus (and on PBS) and led to student contests on a global scale.
lead_paragraph: Woodie Flowers, an innovative and flamboyant mechanical engineering professor at M.I.T. (he liked to roller-blade and ride unicycles through its august halls) who championed a hands-on learning philosophy that reshaped engineering and design education and turned him into something of a celebrity, died on Oct. 11 in Boston. He was 75.

headline: After Rebuking Daryl Morey, Rockets Owner Stays Quiet
abstract: Tilman Fertitta, the owner of the Houston Rockets, had never been shy about politics. Then China happened.
lead_paragraph: For Tilman Fertitta, the billionaire restaurant magnate, host of the CNBC television show “Billion Dollar Buyer” and owner of the N.B.A.’s Houston Rockets, silence is unusual.

headline: 16 Useful Gems in Apple’s New iOS 13
abstract: iOS 13, Apple’s new operating system for the iPhone, comes with tons of new tools under the hood. Here are some of the most helpful.
lead_paragraph: Every September, Apple offers the world a new update of its iOS software for iPhones. This year’s version, iOS 13, didn’t exactly have a graceful landing; since its release in September, Apple has produced no fewer than five follow-up versions intended to fill feature holes and fix bugs. A sixth version, 13.2, is in beta testing now.

headline: Need Costume Ideas?
abstract: Check out literature’s favorite bad guys, scary women and diabolical creatures.

headline: Can We Trust Facebook to Run a Bank?
abstract: A company that once promised to “move fast and break things” wants to transform the global economy.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Nene Pimentel, 85, Dies; Filipino Politician Stood Up to Marcos
abstract: Aquilino Pimentel Jr. helped end the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos as an organizer of the 1986 People Power Revolution.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Aquilino Pimentel Jr., a Filipino lawmaker who helped orchestrate the 1986 People Power Revolution that overturned more than a decade of martial law and ended the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos, died on Sunday in Manila. He was 85.

headline: How Impeachment Is Polling
abstract: Polls can tell us a lot about how the country is viewing impeachment. Here’s what we’ve learned this week.
lead_paragraph: I have a confession: When I realized that today was exactly 30 days from the start of the impeachment inquiry, I didn’t believe it.

headline: Your Halloween Costume Expires Sooner Than You Think
abstract: A brief history of wearing the zeitgeist, from the Rubik’s Cube to Minions.
lead_paragraph: The high heels were on the move. Dozens of New York teachers marched through the streets of Greenwich Village on Oct. 31, 1986, wrapped in fabric stilettos, to cheers and applause. It was a perfectly timely costume: The ladies were dressed as the infamous footwear collection of the freshly ousted first lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos.

headline: Brexit, California Wildfires, Floppy Disks: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: John Mbiti, 87, Dies; Punctured Myths About African Religions
abstract: A theologian and an Anglican priest, he argued that traditional African religions deserved the same respect as Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism.
lead_paragraph: John Mbiti, a prominent Christian theologian from Kenya who helped debunk entrenched ideas that traditional African religions were primitive, giving them equal weight with major world faiths, died on Oct. 5 at a nursing home in Burgdorf, Switzerland. He was 87.

headline: After 15 Years, Dream Mall Finally Becomes a Reality
abstract: The $5 billion development in the Meadowlands, formerly known as Xanadu and now called American Dream, will open on Friday. Sort of.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It has taken 15 years, three owners, two names and hundreds of millions of dollars worth of taxpayer incentives, but a giant mall built on a former swamp in the Meadowlands — and less than 10 miles away from the shopping haven of Manhattan — is finally opening on Friday.

headline: Trump’s Links to 2 Indicted Giuliani Associates: What We Know
abstract: The president was not mentioned in the indictment of Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman. But then came a federal court hearing.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against two associates of President Trump’s private lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, became explicitly connected to the president on Wednesday when a defense lawyer made a surprising argument that some of the evidence gathered in the investigation could be subject to executive privilege.

headline: Leyna Gabriele, 95, Dies; Soprano Who Sang in the First ‘Baby Doe’
abstract: Her performance in an opera about greed in the Old West won her a loyal following. She also sang for celebrities’ suppers at a nightclub in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Leyna Gabriele, a lyric coloratura soprano who became a fan-club idol for playing the title role in the first production of the tragic rags-to-riches-to-rags opera “The Ballad of Baby Doe,” died on Oct. 14 in Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: Citigroup Puts a Woman in Line to Be Its C.E.O.
abstract: Citi’s chief executive, Michael Corbat, named Jane Fraser president of the company and head of retail banking. She could be his successor.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup became the first giant United States bank to definitively tee up a takeover of its leadership by a woman on Thursday, when it named Jane Fraser, a 15-year veteran of the firm, as its president.

headline: Some Lab Chimps May Never Retire to a Sanctuary
abstract: A panel of veterinarians has determined that 44 chimpanzees at a New Mexico facility are too ill to be moved to a new home.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the National Institutes of Health decided to retire all the chimpanzees it owned. Since then, animal welfare groups have been pushing for quicker action, even as some of the facilities that once conducted experiments have urged caution, arguing that some chimps are too old and sick to be moved.

headline: Sisters! A New ‘Hocus Pocus’ Movie Is in the Works at Disney
abstract: Winifred, Sarah and Mary Sanderson, the centuries-old witches who for many millennials are synonymous with Halloween, may fly again on their broom, vacuum and mop.
lead_paragraph: In 1693, the townspeople of Salem tried to get rid of them. In 1993, a couple of teenagers and a cat named Thackery Binx tried, too. Now the Sanderson sisters are angling for another comeback.

headline: Citgo Gets a U.S. Lifeline in Holding Off Creditors
abstract: The Venezuelan-owned refining company faced a breakup as a bond payment loomed. By closing a sanctions loophole, the administration blocked action.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Trump administration moved Thursday to protect the Venezuelan-owned refining company Citgo from creditors by closing a narrow loophole on sanctions intended to topple the Venezuelan government.

headline: ‘What if They Went to Moscow?’ Review: Chekhov, Sliced and Spliced
abstract: Christiane Jatahy’s surgical adaptation of “Three Sisters” takes the audience from stage to screen.
lead_paragraph: A show for those who have wondered if they are in the wrong life or maybe just the wrong auditorium, “What if They Went to Moscow?” a theater-film hybrid by the Brazilian director Christiane Jatahy, presents Anton Chekhov’s “Three Sisters” in close-up. Twice.

headline: ‘It’s Definitely Pretty Empty’: Why Saving WeWork Will Be Hard
abstract: While expanding at a breakneck pace, the co-working company has struggled to turn a profit on millions of square feet of office space.
lead_paragraph: Even as WeWork was scrambling to secure a financial bailout last week, Sebastian Gunningham, one of its co-chief executives, made time to oversee the opening of Dock 72, an immaculate shiplike building on the Brooklyn waterfront that houses one of the company’s newest shared working spaces.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Two comedic and poignant favorite series return. A documentary about Mark Rothko debuts.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Why Is Democrats’ Impeachment Inquiry Out of Public View?
abstract: Republicans have railed against the secretive nature of the House impeachment inquiry, but that is typical of congressional investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans’ move to occupy the secure chambers of the House Intelligence Committee on Wednesday may not have succeeded in shutting down Democrats’ impeachment inquiry. But for a day at least, it shifted debate in the Capitol away from damaging testimony against President Trump to questions about how the inquiry itself is being conducted.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: A look at the White House’s struggle to organize its messaging around impeachment.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump’s hesitance to create an official arm of the White House to deal with impeachment-related material, like President Bill Clinton did, has caused some tension in the West Wing. I asked Annie Karni, who covers the White House, about what Mr. Trump and his advisers think they need.

headline: The Tipping System Is Immoral
abstract: (You should still generally leave 30 percent.)
lead_paragraph: For most of my life I’ve been glad that America is a society that relies heavily on tipping. First, tipping allows us to reward excellent service. Second, in a world of rising economic inequality, a 30 to 50 percent tip is a small but direct way to redistribute money to those who are working hard to earn a living.

headline: California Endures More Blackouts; PG&E Tower Gets Scrutiny in Fire
abstract: Utilities cut off power to keep their equipment from causing wildfires. But transmission lines were being investigated as a cause of one blaze.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of Californians endured blackouts on Thursday as the state’s utility companies sought to prevent their equipment from igniting wildfires.

headline: House Ethics Committee Opens Investigation Into Guam Delegate
abstract: The committee said it was investigating allegations that Michael F. Q. San Nicolas, a Democrat, had a sexual relationship with a congressional staff member and broke campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee said on Thursday that it was investigating allegations that a Democratic freshman, Delegate Michael F. Q. San Nicolas of Guam, had a sexual relationship with a congressional staff member, a violation of House rules, and broke campaign finance laws.

headline: Kelechi Osemele to Have Season-Ending Surgery Despite Jets’ Doubts
abstract: Team executives have fined Osemele for sitting out with a shoulder injury.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Kelechi Osemele, a Jets offensive lineman, will have season-ending surgery to repair a torn labrum in his right shoulder on Friday, even though the team has not authorized the procedure.

headline: Nate Diaz May Be Out of U.F.C. 244 After Positive Drug Test
abstract: The fighter said he did not know what substance he tested positive for, but claimed he would be unable to face Jorge Masvidal. Conor McGregor has volunteered to take Diaz’s place.
lead_paragraph: Nate Diaz, a popular and outspoken star of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, said that he would not fight next week at New York’s Madison Square Garden, as planned, because he had tested positive for a banned substance.

headline: Trump Golf Club May Lose Liquor License Over Fatal Car Crash
abstract: The New Jersey attorney general sent a letter to President Trump’s club in Colts Neck giving it 30 days to contest being stripped of its liquor license.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey officials are moving to revoke the liquor license at one of President Trump’s golf clubs, which they say continued to serve a man who was already intoxicated and got into a fatal car crash shortly after leaving the club in 2015.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Open Criminal Inquiry Into Its Own Russia Investigation
abstract: The move is likely to open the attorney general to accusations that he is trying to deliver a political victory for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than two years, President Trump has repeatedly attacked the Russia investigation, portraying it as a hoax and illegal even months after the special counsel closed it. Now, Mr. Trump’s own Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into how it all began.

headline: Vulnerable Senate Republicans Shrink From Defending Trump
abstract: Senate Republicans up for re-election in 2020, fearful of straying too far from Mr. Trump yet at pains to defend him, have adopted a strategy of saying as little as possible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans facing steep re-election races next year know the impeachment inquiry coursing steadily ahead on the other side of the Capitol will determine President Trump’s political fate. Their growing fear is that it will also determine their own.

headline: V.A. Office to Protect Whistle-Blowers Targeted Them Instead, Report Finds
abstract: A spokeswoman for the Department of Veterans Affairs said it had already taken action on many of the recommendations in the report by the inspector general.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials in an office in the Department of Veterans Affair formed to protect whistle-blowers repeatedly failed in that mission, and sometimes retaliated against them, a new report by the department’s inspector general found.

headline: ‘When It Happens to You’ Review: A Daughter’s Rape, a Mother’s Anguish
abstract: Tawni O’Dell set herself a bracing challenge: Writing and reliving her family’s trauma onstage. But it’s more than the novelist can pull off.
lead_paragraph: Can the truth of a story be enough to compensate for its telling? “When It Happens to You” opens with a simple statement from its playwright and star, Tawni O’Dell: “I’m not an actress here to perform for you. I’m a writer here to tell a story.”

headline: One Barneys Suitor Says Bid Accepted, but Chain Hopes for Another
abstract: Authentic Brands Group said it was the successful bidder, but Barneys is hoping a rival offer will come through to keep its stores open and save jobs.
lead_paragraph: A firm that has been bidding for the struggling department store Barneys New York said on Thursday that its offer had been accepted, though no deal had been completed.

headline: Conservatives Voice Support for Mulvaney
abstract: The acting chief of staff’s missteps have raised questions about his job security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of conservative activists voiced their support for Mick Mulvaney, the embattled acting White House chief of staff, telling President Trump in a letter that the “D.C. swamp is attacking him” and urging the president to permanently appoint him to the job.

headline: For Brian Cashman, Yankees’ Sad Ending Won’t Mean a Roster Reboot
abstract: “We failed in our final game, but it wasn’t a failed season,” the general manager said in a wrap-up news conference for the 2019 season. Manager Aaron Boone was less sanguine about the A.L.C.S. loss.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a week since Jose Altuve’s monster home run ended the Yankees’ season, and yet Aaron Boone hasn’t moved on. Images from Game 6 of the American League Championship Series are stuck in a painful loop in the manager’s memory bank: Aroldis Chapman’s hanging slider, Altuve sending it over the left-field wall and the Astros mobbing him at home plate, kicking off a party on Saturday that made it that much tougher for the Yankees to accept the stunning 6-4 loss.

headline: Chuck Schumer: A Bold Plan for Clean Cars
abstract: I have a proposal that is supported not just by environmentalists but also by labor and large automakers.
lead_paragraph: Scientists tell us that to avoid the most devastating effects of climate change, the world needs to be carbon neutral — to have net-zero carbon dioxide emissions — by midcentury. At the moment, we are not remotely on track to meet that target. We need to act urgently and ambitiously, which will require building diverse coalitions of political support.

headline: Cash for Carbon: Schumer Climate Plan Would Help Consumers Buy Electric Cars
abstract: A $450 billion climate change proposal from Senator Chuck Schumer would give consumers vouchers to buy American-made electric and hybrid cars and trucks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, is preparing a $450 billion climate change initiative that aims to replace about a fifth of the nation’s traditional gasoline-powered vehicles with hybrid, electric or hydrogen fuel-cell cars and trucks in the next 10 years.

headline: Does Australia Have to Bring Its Women and Children Home From Syria’s Camps?
abstract: How did the women and children end up in the camps? Is it true they were all forced or tricked? We answer your questions about the unfolding situation.
lead_paragraph: Early last week, I took a road trip from Melbourne to Canberra. In many ways, it was a normal Australian road trip: an eclectic playlist, dead kangaroos on the road, and, of course, a stop at The Dog on the Tuckerbox.

headline: Deandre Ayton Suspended 25 Games for Failed Drug Test
abstract: The Phoenix Suns center, who was the No. 1 pick in the 2018 draft, tested positive for a banned diuretic.
lead_paragraph: Deandre Ayton of the Phoenix Suns has been suspended without pay for 25 games for a violation of the terms of the N.B.A.’s drug program, the league announced on Thursday.

headline: Labyrinthine
abstract: John Guzzetta’s puzzle peppers us with affection.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE  — Deb’s taking a long weekend, so of course it had to coincide with a Friday puzzle that put me in a cold sweat. It doesn’t happen often — this isn’t a brag, I’m just grizzled — but I could not figure out the northwest corner of the John Guzzetta grid until I had walked it off, slept on it, ruminated, meditated and agitated. There were a couple of other spots that blew  my mind a little, but I’m not afraid to say that I, um, adored this construction.

headline: Corrections: October 25, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, October 25, 2019.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day: Who’s in the Stands? Not the President
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 25, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “He would be booed. However, every president is booed at baseball games. It’s part of the job.”

headline: Blackjewel Coal Miners to Get Millions in Back Pay After Train Blockade
abstract: Blackjewel went bankrupt in July and about 1,100 workers in central Appalachia lost several weeks of pay. In protest, coal miners blocked a train full of coal for months.
lead_paragraph: For two months this summer, out-of-work miners blocked a train full of coal from shipping out of an eastern Kentucky mine, demanding weeks of unpaid wages after their employer, Blackjewel, suddenly went bankrupt.

headline: Muslim Student Athlete Disqualified From Race for Wearing Hijab
abstract: Noor Alexandria Abukaram, 16, was disqualified from a high school cross-country race in Ohio because she did not have permission to run in her hijab. Officials said the rule might change.
lead_paragraph: Noor Alexandria Abukaram has played three high school sports since she began wearing a hijab in 2016. But she said that it was not until last weekend — after her seventh cross-country race of the season — that she learned she wasn’t allowed to run in her head scarf without special permission.

headline: Chinese Lease of Entire Island Is Deemed Illegal in Solomons
abstract: The sweeping deal, signed by the head of a provincial government and executives from a Beijing-based conglomerate, had shocked residents.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A Chinese company’s agreement to lease an entire island in the South Pacific has been ruled illegal by the attorney general of the Solomon Islands, reversing or at least delaying a major push into a location long prized for its strategic value.

headline: Rockets Fall in the Premiere of a Reunited Harden and Westbrook
abstract: The Bucks took the victory as the Rockets began their season with a new star duo at the helm and their general manager under the cloud of a political fracas with China.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After a lengthy silence, the Houston Rockets general manager, Daryl Morey, became an active social media user again on Thursday. He posted multiple promotional messages about his team on Twitter hours before its season opener against the Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: Betsy DeVos Is Held in Contempt Over Judge’s Order on Loan Collection
abstract: A federal judge said the education secretary had violated an order to stop collecting on loans owed by students from a now-defunct for-profit chain of colleges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday fined Education Secretary Betsy DeVos for contempt of court, ruling that she had violated an order to stop collecting on loans owed by students from a now-defunct for-profit chain of colleges.

headline: The Chicken’s in the Oven, My Husband’s Out the Door
abstract: The third Modern Love ever published — a 2004 account of a divorce the writer compared to a space shuttle exploding midflight — was the first to fill our inbox with reader emails.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate Modern Love’s 15th anniversary this month, we’re publishing a series of special features — three classic essays from the column’s early years and four conversations with writers whose stories were adapted for the television series that began streaming on Amazon Prime Video on Oct. 18.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Brexit, Ukraine, Earthquakes: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Are German Social Democrats Doomed?
abstract: They once dominated the country’s politics. But they can’t keep up with deep social changes.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday night in September, hundreds of German Social Democrats streamed past a statue of Chancellor Willy Brandt, who led the country in the 1960s and ’70s, into the party’s headquarters in Berlin. The bronze statue of Brandt, who headed the party from 1964 to 1987, holds one arm out wide, as if offering protection to his fellow party members.

headline: It’s North Versus South (Hemispheres) in the Rugby World Cup
abstract: New Zealand, the two-time defending champion, faces England, and Wales plays South Africa in the semifinals in Japan.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The Rugby World Cup will hold its semifinals this weekend, and the cream has risen to the top. The four semifinalists' results in the pool stage and quarterfinals have them rightfully ranked Nos. 1 through 4 on the official World Rugby rankings.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Dolemite Is My Name’ and ‘Maleficent’
abstract: A new biopic with Eddie Murphy hits Netflix. And “Maleficent” airs on TNT as its sequel plays in theaters.
lead_paragraph: DOLEMITE IS MY NAME (2019) Stream on Netflix. Eddie Murphy wears vivid suits and tilted hats and carries a weighty cane in this new biopic. The film casts Murphy as the comedian Rudy Ray Moore, who at the crest of the blaxploitation era self-financed “Dolemite,” a 1975 crime action movie in which he starred as a pimp out for revenge. The original movie became a cult hit. (A typical scene involves an F.B.I. agent being kicked into the trunk of a Cadillac.) The biopic charts the lead-up to and the making of that movie, with the help of an all-star cast: Tituss Burgess, Keegan-Michael Key, Da’Vine Joy Randolph, Craig Robinson and Wesley Snipes play some of Moore’s associates, and Snoop Dogg and Chris Rock each make cameos. The movie has a “loose, friendly, house-party vibe,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, and is intended as a comeback vehicle for Murphy. “I didn’t want to just pop back up,” he said in a recent interview with The Times. “I wanted a funny movie to remind them that they liked me. This movie turned out so strong that I figured this is a great way to come back.”

headline: Word + Quiz: vignette
abstract: This word has appeared in 131 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard Won’t Seek Re-Election to Congress in 2020
abstract: The decision to focus on her presidential campaign, despite low polling numbers, is likely to fuel speculation that she may be preparing a third-party bid.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, who has remained in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination even as her bid has failed to gain much traction in polls, announced Friday that she would not seek a fifth term in Congress.

headline: Strange Cuisine
abstract: Have you ever created an unusual food or snack?
lead_paragraph: Do you like to get creative in the kitchen or at snack time? Have you ever made a unique food or drink concoction that excites or repulses your friends or family? Is there a food you love that many others can’t stomach?

headline: After Fatal Shooting, City Pays $5.5 Million and Promotes Detective
abstract: It wasn’t the first time he had killed someone in the line of duty.
lead_paragraph: John Collado was on his way to buy groceries one September afternoon in 2011 when he spotted a neighbor and a stranger fighting on his block and pulled them apart.

headline: He Got a Bike for His 8th Birthday. He Was Killed Riding It.
abstract: The boy’s death comes at a time when biking fatalities across New York City have surged. So far, 25 cyclists have been killed in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The bicycle was a present two years ago for Dalerjon Shahobiddinov’s eighth birthday. He chose the model himself: It was bright orange, sprinkled with black and white dots.

headline: New York’s Race to Build Monuments Runs Into Friction on the Ground
abstract: The city’s plan to commemorate women, people of color and others overlooked in the past is leading to fights over who should be honored and how.
lead_paragraph: A vote this month over one of New York City’s new, more inclusive monuments became so combative — with audience members shouting “How dare you!” — that the acclaimed artist who won the commission walked away from the job.

headline: Late Night Eagerly Awaits the Nebraska Coast Guard
abstract: After President Trump said there’d be a border wall in Colorado, hosts speculated about what might be next.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: This Week’s News Quiz: Google, Chile, Blue Origin
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘From Chile to Lebanon, Protests Flare Over Wallet Issues’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the causes of this recent wave of dissent across the globe — and consider the question, why do people protest?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “From Chile to Lebanon, Protests Flare Over Wallet Issues”

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Fats, Blood Pressure and Cosmetic Surgery
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Pairs Well With Weed
abstract: The first marijuana restaurant in West Hollywood, Calif. is a branding exercise. What does it mean for the industry?
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California here.]

headline: Should Family Members See Patients Die in the I.C.U.?
abstract: Studies suggest that relatives don’t distract the medical team or interfere with decision-making when a patient is in cardiac arrest.
lead_paragraph: On one recent intensive care unit shift, I admitted a man whose heart had stopped earlier that day. By the time I met him, it seemed clear that he wasn’t going to live. So when he went into cardiac arrest for what I suspected would be the last time, I headed out of the unit to find his wife.

headline: A New Biography of Janis Joplin Captures the Pain and Soul of an Adventurous Life
abstract: Holly George-Warren’s “Janis” follows the singer from her painful early years in a conservative Texas oil town to the fame she achieved with her powerful and unusual voice.
lead_paragraph: Had she not died at 27 of an accidental heroin overdose, Janis Joplin would be 76 — two years younger than Paul Simon and four years younger than Mavis Staples. Singers with scorched voices sometimes settle more deeply into them. (Have you heard the most recent Marianne Faithfull album?) One wonders at the body of recordings Joplin might have made.

headline: 7 Combat Deployments in 6 Years, Then a Bullet Nearly Killed Him
abstract: Jeffery Dawson wasn’t supposed to be on the mission that nearly killed him, but the Army’s failure to recruit enough bomb-disposal technicians for his unit meant there was no one else to go.
lead_paragraph: When a bullet tore through Sgt. First Class Jeffery M. Dawson’s torso on July 20, the Army bomb technician’s seventh combat deployment in six years came to a sudden end. Dawson was already a legend in the small, tight-knit world of bomb-disposal soldiers, having received the Distinguished Service Cross — a medal ranked second only to the Medal of Honor for combat valor — for an earlier mission with Army Rangers in Afghanistan, and was scheduled to try out for the elite Delta Force in West Virginia after returning home. But now, lying on the ground, his mission that night as part of a small C.I.A. Omega Team leading Afghan commandos was over — and maybe his military career as well.

headline: New French Fiction: From Farm to Table, With Feasting in Between
abstract: Jean-Baptiste Del Amo’s “Animalia” follows a rural family while Marie NDiaye’s “The Cheffe” charts a career in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: ANIMALIA

headline: Considering Love, Loss and Jeanette Winterson
abstract: In Jeanette Winterson’s 1993 novel “Written on the Body,” the narrator (whose name and gender are never specified) navigates a consuming affair with a married woman.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Lotz reviews Jeanette Winterson’s latest novel, “Frankissstein,” in this week’s issue. In 1993, Jim Shepard wrote for the Book Review about “Written on the Body,” Winterson’s novel about an affair between the narrator (whose name and gender are never specified) and a married woman..

headline: How Can People Be Persuaded to Eat Less Meat?
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Browns of California’ and ‘The Far Field.’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE BROWNS OF CALIFORNIA: The Family Dynasty that Transformed a State and Shaped a Nation, by Miriam Pawel. (Bloomsbury, $20.) Pawel traces four generations of the Brown family and their 24-year political domination of California, recounting the two-term governorships of Edmund (Pat) Brown and his son, Edmund (Jerry) Brown Jr. Our reviewer, Lisa McGirr, found the book “fascinating.”

headline: Are You a Worrier?
abstract: Do you generally believe things will work out? Or are you constantly thinking about what could go wrong?
lead_paragraph: How much of a worrier are you? Do you generally believe things will work out? Or are you constantly thinking about what could go wrong?

headline: Houses Where Friends Used to Live
abstract: On Halloween we’ll ring doorbells, doors opening to new faces inside those houses that helped raise my children.
lead_paragraph: This Halloween, my daughters will don their wigs and wands and, holding out their plastic pumpkins, knock on the doors of houses where friends used to live.

headline: Oliver and Elio Are Back
abstract: With “Find Me,” André Aciman has written a surprising sequel to “Call Me by Your Name.”
lead_paragraph: FIND ME By André Aciman

headline: Justin Hartley of ‘This Is Us’ Meditates on His Rolexes
abstract: The former soap opera star goes watch shopping at Wempe Jewelers on Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: “See that hand?” said Justin Hartley, pointing to the second hand on his Rolex Daytona as it skimmed the black-and-champagne face. “That hand is going so slow. And it never speeds up.”

headline: Diamond Doris, the Bourbon King and Other Stars of True Crime
abstract: Marilyn Stasio takes time off from her crime fiction column to guide readers through some real-life chronicles of violence, madness and appalling misbehavior.
lead_paragraph: People tend to think of crime and mystery stories as “escapist” literature, a way to hide from the atrocities and absurdities of real life. But crime fiction is my reality. So whenever I want some escapist entertainment, I pick up a book about an actual crime. Lucky for me, people can be reliably wicked, so there are always plenty of these true-crime chronicles of violence, madness and appalling misbehavior.

headline: The Miraculous Revival of the Last Fire Watchtower (Built in 1856)
abstract: The 47-foot-tall, cast-iron structure in Harlem is the last of its kind in the city.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago things were not looking good for the Harlem fire watchtower.

headline: The Talented Patricia Highsmith’s Private Diaries Are Going Public
abstract: The writer’s estate is releasing hundreds of pages from her personal diaries as a book.
lead_paragraph: “No writer would ever betray his secret life,” the novelist Patricia Highsmith wrote to a friend in 1940. “It would be like standing naked in public.”

headline: Who Is Don McGahn, the Lawyer Behind Trump’s Court Makeover?
abstract: As White House counsel, Don McGahn helped reshape the federal judiciary for a generation.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans may not know Donald F. McGahn II’s name, but they’ll likely live with his legacy for decades to come.

headline: The C.E.O. Taking On the Gun Lobby
abstract: Ed Stack bought Dick’s Sporting Goods from his cantankerous father. He has now turned it into an unlikely force in the gun debate.
lead_paragraph: Ed Stack didn’t set out to be an activist.

headline: A Dutch Golden Age? That’s Only Half the Story
abstract: Museums in the Netherlands are ditching historical terms and names, and updating their collections as they grapple with the legacy of slavery and colonialism.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Elisabeth Samson, an 18th-century freeborn black woman, made millions as a coffee planter and exporter using slave labor in the Dutch colony of Suriname. She was one of the wealthiest women of the era, but few people have ever heard her story.

headline: Pentagon, With an Eye on China, Pushes for Help From American Tech
abstract: Talks over how U.S. companies can ensure future supplies of advanced computer chips have taken on more urgency.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pentagon officials have been holding private discussions with tech industry executives to wrestle with a key question: how to ensure future supplies of the advanced computer chips needed to retain America’s military edge.

headline: Alyssa Milano, Celebrity Activist for the Celebrity Presidential Age
abstract: The actress is trying to stay just famous enough to still get invited to Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alyssa Milano was on Capitol Hill in a floral dress and black Dr. Martens combat boots, her hair pulled into a tight bun atop her head. This is the look — the bun and the boots — that her best friend, Alaa Khaled, says signals to him that “we’re in for something.”

headline: George Soros Has Enemies. He’s Fine With That.
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Soros explained why he thinks the tide is turning back to “globalists” like him and what might happen in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: George Soros is a billionaire philanthropist, a former currency trader, a liberal champion and — in certain circles — a boogeyman. That last label seems to be a badge of honor.

headline: Can a Restored Pompeii Be Saved From ‘Clambering’ Tourists?
abstract: Not long ago, the ancient Roman site was neglected and crumbling. A multiyear restoration is winding down, but challenges — high costs and troublesome visitor behavior — remain.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to imagine lounging in the garden at the sprawling villa of Julia Felix, a savvy Roman business woman who lived in the ancient Roman city of Pompeii in the first century A.D. There would have been wine to drink, and fresh figs, apricots and walnuts to savor. The warm sea breeze would have blended the dry scent of cypress and bay leaves with the stench of rubbish and excrement from the street, and the gurgle of water in the baths would have been occasionally drowned out by cries from the crowd in the 20,000-seat amphitheater nearby.

headline: Jenny Slate Wrote a Book-Shaped Thing. What Is It?
abstract: “Little Weirds,” a new collection by the actress and comedian, isn’t the funny memoir you might have expected.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass. — The only piece of fiction in Jenny Slate’s new book, “Little Weirds,” describes a love that grew old in an un-air-conditioned house by the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Scientists Were Hunting for the Next Ebola. Now the U.S. Has Cut Off Their Funding.
abstract: Predict, a government research program, sought to identify animal viruses that might infect humans and to head off new pandemics.
lead_paragraph: In a move that worries many public health experts, the federal government is quietly shutting down a surveillance program for dangerous animal viruses that someday may infect humans.

headline: For Impeachment Witnesses, Testifying Can Cost $15,000 or More
abstract: Caught in a struggle between two branches of government, career government workers on civil-servant salaries are worried about how to pay for lawyers to guide them through.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a parade of State Department officials began trooping to Capitol Hill this month to testify in the impeachment inquiry imperiling President Trump, officials from the department’s employee association dispatched an appeal to its nearly 17,000 members.

headline: Are the Suburbs Turning Democratic?
abstract: The political dividing line in America used to be between Democratic cities and Republican suburbs. Now it runs through the center of the suburbs themselves.
lead_paragraph: EAST GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Dave Levitt became a Republican after getting his M.B.A. in 1990. Like him, Republicans valued fiscal conservatism, balanced budgets and free trade, “all the things you learn in business school that are good and help people,” Mr. Levitt said.

headline: In Mexico City, a Blossoming of All Things Japanese
abstract: Japanese-inspired businesses are sprouting up — from fashion labels and boutiques to a new hotel — along with new Japanese-influenced places to eat and drink.
lead_paragraph: On a summer afternoon  in Mexico City’s leafy Roma Norte neighborhood, a steady stream of customers filled the tiny coffee shop Raku, which means “joy” in Japanese. While they were drawn by the coffee, I was in the new spot to learn how the owner Mauricio Zubirats makes a cup of matcha tea.

headline: How The Astro Poets Spend Their Sundays
abstract: A macrobiotic lunch and a visit to a witch supply store prepare these astrology wordsmiths for whatever “emerges.”
lead_paragraph: The poets Alex Dimitrov and Dorothea Lasky met at a party in Brooklyn nearly a decade ago and bonded over astrology. Mr. Dimitrov, 34, a Sagittarius, and Ms. Lasky, 41, an Aries, went on to develop the Twitter account, Astro Poets. Now over half a million followers receive their weekly forecast and daily quips.

headline: Using Virtual Reality to Plan Your Actual Retirement
abstract: V.R. and online visual aids are giving workers a better idea of how much they need to save.
lead_paragraph: Picture this: You are in the country, on a trip through a pleasantly green, rolling landscape dotted with trees. It has a slightly dreamlike quality.

headline: The Met’s Herculean Task: 4 Operas in 48 Hours
abstract: With its new Sunday matinees, the Metropolitan Opera now mounts four productions between Friday and Sunday. It isn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: It was Friday afternoon, five hours before curtain, and a stylized Japan was taking shape on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera. A crew was untangling ropes of cherry blossoms to form the backdrop of Madama Butterfly’s house in Nagasaki.

headline: Carriage Houses in Clinton Hill
abstract: Stables and garages along Waverly Avenue have seen a variety of uses over the years.
lead_paragraph: Stables and garages along Waverly Avenue have seen a variety of uses over the years.

headline: The Many Lives of a Carriage House
abstract: A modest Clinton Hill street filled with former stables and garages has been home to steeds and Studebakers, but also artists, restaurants and maybe even a speakeasy.
lead_paragraph: When Lisa Radcliffe bought a tumbledown, neo-Georgian-style garage in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn in 1999, she made an intriguing discovery. The interior of the original structure, built in 1916 to house three cars for a chocolate magnate, was unadorned, its ground-floor walls lined with glazed white brick.

headline: The American Dream Mall, Wegmans and Nordstrom Finally Open
abstract: Friday: You can shop at the giant supermarket on Sunday. A behemoth mall is also opening  nearby in New Jersey. Sort of.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Botswana Election Won by President, Despite Rift with Predecessor
abstract: President Mokgweetsi Masisi will serve another term after taking controversial steps to lift a ban on elephant hunting and usher in the decriminalization of homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Voters in Botswana re-elected a president who had received international attention for lifting a ban on hunting elephants and overseeing the decriminalization of homosexuality.

headline: ‘All of Them Are Thieves’: Iraqis Defy Security Forces to Protest Corruption
abstract: Demonstrations resumed despite government offers of new jobs, more money for housing and a crackdown on corruption. At least 30 people were reported killed.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD —  Rebuking their prime minister, Iraqi protesters demanding jobs and official accountability defied security forces Friday to throng central Baghdad and other cities, confronting the government with perhaps its biggest challenge since the chaotic aftermath of the American invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein 16 years ago.

headline: California, Tulsi Gabbard, Betsy DeVos: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: It’s Not Easy Being Evil
abstract: In Sarah Jean Horwitz’s ‘The Dark Lord Clementine,’ a girl born into a family of Dark Lords struggles to do what’s right, er, wrong.
lead_paragraph: To maintain your status as a Dark Lord of the Seven Sisters, you have to submit sufficient evidence of dastardly deeds to the Council of Evil Overlords. Those include poisonings, unfortunate transfiguration, a racket (tennis equipment not acceptable), murder, kidnappings, plague and/or enhanced weather phenomena. In Sarah Jean Horwitz’s THE DARK LORD CLEMENTINE (Algonquin, 329 pp., $17.99; ages 10 and up), a hilariously heartwarming magical adventure, that’s not as easy as it sounds.

headline: Two Parts of a ‘Quantum Entanglement’
abstract: Marissa Maier and Wes Lau are in sync on many things. But he had to “think about it,” which almost ruined everything.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Maier, who grew up in a TriBeCa loft in the early ’90s, didn’t have a regular bedtime or even a regular wardrobe. She mostly wore costumes. Her mother, Kathleen Russo, was a talent agent for dancers, actors and writers, and there were always theatrical people coming over for dinner or putting on impromptu performances.

headline: Facebook Calls Truce With Publishers as It Unveils Facebook News
abstract: The social network introduced a new section of its mobile app dedicated to news content, offering stories from a mix of publications.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook and the publishing industry have long been frenemies: Occasionally they teamed up, but mostly they competed.

headline: Those College Students Who Used the N-Word Shouldn’t Have Been Arrested
abstract: They were guilty of vulgarity and ignorance, but “ridicule” is not a crime.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if the cast members of “The Book of Mormon” could be arrested and prosecuted for ridiculing Mormons. Preposterous, you say?

headline: The Original ‘Dolemite’ Is Bad, Very Bad. But It Matters.
abstract: The 1970s genre of blaxploitation was polarizing for black audiences. Eddie Murphy’s Rudy Ray Moore biopic invites viewers to just appreciate it.
lead_paragraph: This article includes minor spoilers for “Dolemite Is My Name.”

headline: ‘A Prophet’: The Zeal of Bernie Sanders Supporters
abstract: As the candidate returns to the campaign trail, Democratic Party leaders are asking whether his supporters are loyal to the party, or just to him.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Lynching’
abstract: The president lives to celebrate his own victimhood. What’s Lindsey Graham’s excuse?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is reckless with words and careless with actions. There’s no evidence that he thinks deeply about anything. Which is why I was not shocked when he condemned the House impeachment inquiry as a “lynching” earlier this week.

headline: Why Doesn’t Mark Zuckerberg Get It?
abstract: The Facebook co-founder’s speech at Georgetown was a profile in cowardice.
lead_paragraph: If Facebook were a religion, it would be the world’s largest faith, with just under a third of the planet, 2.4 billion people, tied into a network controlled largely by one man. It’s a business, of course, with a business model that makes much of its money by channeling tidings of sludge around, often to great harm.

headline: ‘Let the Viejos Play’: In the World Series, Age Is an Asset
abstract: The Nationals have the oldest team in the majors by average age. The Astros are third. It might not be a coincidence that they’re contending for the title.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — There is a nickname that the more experienced players on the Washington Nationals use to describe themselves: Los Viejos. In Spanish, it means the Old Ones.

headline: George Soros Says Wall Street Won’t Decide the 2020 Election
abstract: The billionaire philanthropist and former trader offered his views on next year’s elections, taxing the rich and putting Wall Street in its place.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers like Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, the Obama administration adviser Valerie Jarrett and Brian Chesky of Airbnb. Apply to attend here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: In a Quiet Corner, an Old Afghan Poet Polishes ‘the Heart’s Mirror’
abstract: For more than 50 years, Haidari Wujodi’s desk in a Kabul library has been a stop for those seeking escape from the violence outside.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For more than 50 years now, a mystic poet has kept a quiet window desk at the Kabul Public Library. His seat overlooks the hustle and bustle of the Afghan capital city, all but unrecognizable from the day he arrived as a young library clerk — one with a dreamy mind and stammering speech, but fine calligraphic handwriting that helped land him his day job.

headline: For the Warriors, New Arena, New Players and a Shaky New Start
abstract: Stephen Curry is adjusting to life with fresh teammates.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The prevailing feeling has been one of newness for the Golden State Warriors. New season. New arena. New city. And even a new roster, or at least one that has undergone a significant makeover since the team stuffed its championship banners into moving vans and made its way across the Bay Bridge from Oakland a few months ago.

headline: ‘Maleficent: Mistress of Evil’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Joachim Ronning narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The director Joachim Ronning narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Which Kind of Witch Should She Be?
abstract: In Emma Steinkellner’s graphic novel “The Okay Witch,” a teenager descended from famous witches faces bigotry, not to mention her mother’s opposition.
lead_paragraph: Moth Hush, the protagonist of Emma Steinkellner’s THE OKAY WITCH (Aladdin, 272 pp., $20.99; ages 10 and up), is a typical 13-year-old girl living with her single mother in the fictional town of Founder’s Bluff, Mass. During a Halloween-themed lesson at school, Moth (dressed in a witch costume, naturally) learns the history of the Founder’s Bluff Witch Hunt, a centuries-old Salem-like event that pitted the town’s founding settlers against outsiders thought to possess evil magic. The knowledge triggers something deep within Moth, and she starts to experience supernatural powers beyond her control. When bullies come for her after class she is able to take their voices away. Frightened, she turns to her mother, who reveals the secret she’s kept from Moth her entire life: They are really a family of witches. And not just that, they are descendants of the very witches driven out of Founder’s Bluff.

headline: How Angelina Jolie Casts a Spell in ‘Maleficent: Mistress of Evil’
abstract: The director Joachim Ronning narrates a sequence featuring Jolie and Elle Fanning.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: China’s Response to Pence Speech: ‘Sheer Arrogance’
abstract: In a lengthy denunciation of the vice president, an official said he was trying to distract from American failings by criticizing Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After Vice President Mike Pence excoriated China and American companies that he accused of selling out their principles to do business there, a sharp response from Beijing was to be expected. But perhaps not this sharp.

headline: Elijah Cummings’s Funeral Draws Presidents and Thousands of Mourners
abstract: Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton spoke Friday at the service for the longtime Maryland congressman.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Two former United States presidents and a throng of powerful American leaders joined thousands of everyday people in Baltimore on Friday to bid farewell to Representative Elijah E. Cummings, a towering African-American presence in Washington who was praised for his integrity, his character and, in his final months, his unwavering challenges to President Trump.

headline: The Week in Arts: Sleater-Kinney, Paul Taylor and ‘Synonyms’
abstract: Corin Tucker and Carrie Brownstein go on tour; the company Taylor founded honors him; and a French film our critic loved opens in New York.
lead_paragraph: Oct. 30-31; ticketmaster.com.

headline: Mystery of 39 Bodies in Truck Leads to More Arrests in U.K.
abstract: As officials tried to piece together clues from Belgium, Britain, Bulgaria, China and Ireland, a Vietnamese woman’s relatives said they feared she might be among the dead.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two more men and a woman were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and manslaughter after 39 people were found dead in a refrigerated trailer in southeastern England, the British police said on Friday, the first indication from officials that the deaths were linked to human smuggling.

headline: Congratulations, Mr. President
abstract: You’ve outdone your predecessors. Even Andrew Johnson.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: A Bigger Role for Women in the Catholic Church? 185 Men Will Decide
abstract: Discussions at the Synod of Bishops for the Amazon have acknowledged that women must get recognition of some sort. But few expect real change.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Vatican’s extraordinary three-week meeting of bishops from the Amazon region, which ends this weekend, has generated intense debate within the church over the possibility of ordaining older, married men in remote areas.

headline: Even in Strong Economy, Most Families Don’t Have Enough Emergency Savings
abstract: A new report recommends setting aside six weeks of take-home pay to ride out gyrations in income and expenses. But two-thirds of families don’t have that buffer.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks of take-home pay.

headline: The Week in Tech: Google’s Quantum Leap
abstract: The company can run esoteric calculations on exotic new hardware faster than is possible on a supercomputer. It’s an achievement of little practical use, but still important.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Ronald Feldman, Risk-taking Gallerist, Retires After Nearly 50 Years
abstract: “We’re going to continue to try to push boundaries, and continue Ron’s legacy,” his eldest son, Mark Feldman, said.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Feldman, the pioneering contemporary art dealer, has stepped down from his role of director at the Ronald Feldman Gallery after nearly 50 years at the helm, for health reasons.

headline: N.F.L. Week 8 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Aaron Rodgers and the Packers will take on the Chiefs, minus Patrick Mahomes. That and Drew Brees’s potential return make for an interesting week.
lead_paragraph: Drew Brees is likely to come back for New Orleans after five weeks away but Patrick Mahomes needs at least one week to recover after dislocating his kneecap in Week 7. The Packers and the Saints — with Brees or without him — will look to continue their hot streaks, while the Patriots and the 49ers will try to stay undefeated. And don’t forget about the Bills, whose defense has them 5-1, with their only loss coming against New England.

headline: A Cabin With a Literary Pedigree
abstract: A television executive has turned his weekend house in the Poconos into an artists’ retreat for the likes of Frank McCourt and Colum McCann.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Pa. — Charlie Chaplin slept here. So did Sarah Bernhardt, Mary Pickford, Lillian Gish, Franz Liszt, Warren Harding, Andrew Carnegie, Thomas Wolfe, Cloris Leachman and Arlene Dahl. Likewise, D.W. Griffith, who, in 1912, shot two movies — “A Feud in the Kentucky Hills” and “The Informer” — in this dot of a town in the foothills of the Poconos.

headline: A Twin Threat as Fires Burn Across California
abstract: Friday: PG&E warns of more power outages as hot, windy conditions continue into the weekend. Also: Representative Katie Hill threatens legal action.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Lucy Liu, Tyler Cameron and Jennifer Hudson on the Gala Circuit
abstract: Benefits were held for Hudson River Park, Harlem School of the Arts and the Alzheimer’s Association.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were held for Hudson River Park, Harlem School of the Arts and the Alzheimer’s Association.

headline: Galas Galore
abstract: Benefits were held for Hudson River Park, Harlem School of the Arts and the Alzheimer’s Association.
lead_paragraph: The fall social season is in full swing: A dozen high-profile benefits took place on Monday night alone. Hudson River Park held a fund-raiser dinner on Oct. 17 at Cipriani South Street. Harlem School of the Arts held a mask ball on Oct. 21 at the Plaza. And Jennifer Hudson performed at the Alzheimer’s Association gala at the Rainbow Room on Oct. 22.

headline: Elijah Cummings Is Remembered as ‘a Great Man, a Moral Leader and a Friend’
abstract: At the funeral for Representative Elijah E. Cummings, former president Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton were among the prominent politicians who spoke.
lead_paragraph: At the funeral for Representative Elijah E. Cummings, former president Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton were among the prominent politicians who spoke.

headline: ‘This Is Who We’ve Been Waiting For’: A Diva on the Precipice
abstract: The soprano Julia Bullock is on the verge of an unconventional career.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Julia Bullock had a cold.

headline: ‘Moonlight’ Unlocked the Door. Naomie Harris Charged Through It.
abstract: The British actress made a name for herself in James Bond and Pirates of the Caribbean movies, but it was a little indie that changed her career.
lead_paragraph: Naomie Harris often says her breakout role was in the 2003 post-apocalyptic thriller “28 Days Later” with Cillian Murphy, but that is not exactly true.

headline: What Generations of Gay Men Hand Down in ‘The Inheritance’
abstract: The professional and personal have blurred for young cast members of Matthew Lopez’s play, which offers a communion with victims of the AIDS crisis.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t imagine what those years were like,” says a young gay man named Eric, contemplating the worst of the AIDS crisis. “I can understand what it was. But I cannot possibly feel what it was.”

headline: Pete Buttigieg Is Running Strong in Iowa. Does He Have Room to Grow?
abstract: The mayor of South Bend, Ind., has opened more offices in Iowa than any other Democratic presidential candidate. Polls suggest his strategy has begun to pay off.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: G.M. Workers Approve Contract and End U.A.W. Strike
abstract: After the voting by 49,000 members of the United Auto Workers, operations could start to resume Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The longest nationwide strike against General Motors in half a century ended on Friday after a solid majority of the company’s union members delivered their support for the four-year contract hammered out by their leaders.
