headline: Indonesian Report on Lion Air Crash Finds Numerous Problems
abstract: Design flaws in the Boeing 737 Max led to the disaster last year, but an investigator said that without other factors “the crash would not have happened.”
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The first officer told the captain that he had been called at 4 a.m. and told to work the flight, which was not on his original schedule. The captain replied that he had the flu. He coughed 15 times in the hour before takeoff.

headline: Desserts Over Darkness
abstract: Prepare plenty of treats for Diwali, or fire up the oven for baking treats against the nip in the air.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Diwali, the Indian festival of lights, is celebrated on Sunday. Technically a Hindu celebration of the triumph of good over evil, it is has become something of a cultural event in America, as Priya Krishna reported in The Times this week. “It’s a symbolic holiday that unites us as a diaspora,” Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, Democrat of Illinois, told her.

headline: The Weird World of ‘Haunted’ eBay: ‘Purchase With Caution’
abstract: An artist’s obsession with listings for the cursed, doomed and otherwise unexplained.
lead_paragraph: An artist’s obsession with listings for the cursed, doomed and otherwise unexplained.

headline: December Democratic Debate Will Be in Los Angeles, With Higher Thresholds
abstract: The sixth debate, hosted by PBS NewsHour and Politico, will be held at U.C.L.A. on Dec. 19.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee announced on Friday that the sixth Democratic primary debate would be held in December at the University of California, Los Angeles, while ratcheting up the polling and donor criteria for candidates to qualify for a coveted spot onstage.

headline: California Fires Update: Thousands Evacuated; Governor Declares State of Emergency
abstract: The Tick Fire is one of a dozen fires in the state propelled by strong winds.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARITA, Calif. — A fire that forced the evacuation of 50,000 people spread through canyons north of Los Angeles on Friday, jumping a freeway and threatening thousands of homes.

headline: Trouble in Paradise: Chile’s Inequality Explodes
abstract: The social reforms agenda presented by President Sebastián Piñera to ease the Chileans’ discontent is insufficient.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — In the past week Chile has been gripped by a wave of fury and indignation. Chileans of all ages have poured into the streets armed with kitchenware, banging pots to demand reforms — Latin America’s traditional cacerolazo form of protest. Demonstrations have been both violent and peaceful, leading the government to declare a curfew in some parts of the country and a state of emergency. Troops have been deployed to restore order for the first time since Chile returned to democracy 30 years ago. At least 18 people have died so far and thousands have been arrested. The illusion of Chile as an oasis in a convulsed region has cracked.

headline: Making ‘Mrs. Fletcher’: Arguing. Futzing. Spanking. Agreeing.
abstract: Tom Perrotta wanted to be the showrunner of the HBO series based on his novel about a woman with a pornography obsession. He learned a few things.
lead_paragraph: Porn is a complex cultural force, a tool of exploitation, degradation and perhaps self-discovery that, in our age of constant connectivity, is rarely more than a few clicks away.

headline: A Pancake That’s Ready for All the Vegetables in Your Fridge
abstract: Pajeon, Korean scallion pancakes packed with vegetables, make for an easy, vegetarian weeknight meal with a kimchi kick.
lead_paragraph: Pajeon, those crisp-edged, scallion-filled Korean pancakes, are delectable in any weather. But it’s on rainy, blustery days, when the skies seem bleak and the air feels damp, that the chef Sohui Kim craves them the most.

headline: Your Uber Driver Is ‘Retired’? You Shouldn’t Be Surprised
abstract: Older Americans are taking nontraditional jobs in greater numbers. Economists aren’t sure that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Dave Zarrow, who lives in Reston, Va., figures he spends about 20 hours a week in his 2017 Camry driving for Uber, the ride-hailing company.

headline: 8 Years After ‘The Night Circus,’ Erin Morgenstern Has a New Novel
abstract: In “The Starless Sea,” stags carry lit candles on their antlers, and the smells of smoke and honey waft through stone corridors.

headline: Too Many Blowouts, Not Enough Competition
abstract: A Champions League group stage overrun by routs feels a little more worrisome than usual. So give thanks, then, for the Bundesliga’s competitive balance while you can.
lead_paragraph: What was your favorite moment of the Champions League this week? Was it Paris St.-Germain putting five past Club Bruges, away from home? Maybe you were delighted by just how easily Manchester City swatted aside Atalanta, or perhaps you were enthralled by just how many goals Tottenham could score against Red Star Belgrade. It probably would not have been Liverpool’s win at Genk: after all, the reigning European champions only scored four. A disappointing night’s work, really.

headline: How Do You Impersonate Judy Garland? Ask a Drag Queen
abstract: While Renée Zellweger plays the star onscreen, a host of cabaret performers pay homage to the gay icon night after night onstage.
lead_paragraph: Half a century after Judy Garland died and 80 years after “The Wizard of Oz” made her famous, she remains the rare golden-age performer whose popularity and mythology reach beyond Las Vegas and the Turner Classic Movies channel.

headline: Elijah Cummings Funeral: Bill and Hillary Clinton Urge Defense of Democracy
abstract: Comparing the congressman to a biblical prophet, the former secretary of state said Elijah Cummings “stood against the corrupt leadership of King Ahab and Queen Jezebel.”
lead_paragraph: Speaking at the funeral of Representative Elijah E. Cummings, former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, offered a forceful defense of democracy and compared the late congressman, a leader in the impeachment inquiry into President Trump, to the prophet Elijah.

headline: Imagining the World of Nazi Hunters
abstract: Joseph Kanon’s novel “The Accomplice” takes readers on a quest to find a former Nazi doctor who bears a striking resemblance to Josef Mengele.
lead_paragraph: THE ACCOMPLICEBy Joseph Kanon

headline: Cunning, Damaged and Deranged: The Latest Thrillers by Women
abstract: From seasoned experts to debut authors, these authors write female-focused crime fiction like you’ve never seen before.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a more exciting or challenging time for women who write and read thrillers and crime novels. Our bodies and our actions — from the medical to the moral — are on trial every day, which can make it difficult to immerse oneself in books that touch on the further brutality of women. And yet, women crime novelists have utterly captured the genre, pushing its boundaries in important, exciting and creative ways. Writers such as Megan Abbott, Laura Lippman, Alafair Burke and Tana French, to name just a few, give us powerful female characters who upend the stereotypes of their gender. Some of them are cunning, others damaged or deranged. These characters appear on all sides of investigations as victims, investigators and even criminals, reinvigorating the genre as they break down its barriers.

headline: A Sympathetic Look at Spiritualism Past and Present
abstract: Mira Ptacin’s encounters with psychics and mediums in “The In-Betweens” raises large questions about human existence and life’s meaning.
lead_paragraph: THE IN-BETWEENSThe Spiritualists, Mediums, and Legends of Camp EtnaBy Mira Ptacin

headline: Bernie Sanders Almost Won Iowa in 2016. He Knows He Can’t Slip Now.
abstract: Every top Democrat is making calculations to try to win Iowa’s first-in-the-nation caucuses. But for Mr. Sanders, the political pressure and personal stakes are unique.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — On a trip to Iowa in June, Senator Bernie Sanders confided in aides about a central gamble of his second bid for the White House.

headline: If the Choice Is Warren or Trump …
abstract: David Brooks decides that a “bad option is better than a suicidal one” and would vote for Ms. Warren. Readers offer their reactions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In One Afghan District, the Same Promises of Victory, 32 Years Apart
abstract: A Times reporter visits Baghlan Province, where, three decades ago, a Russian journalist documented the same assurances of peace offered to local residents by foreign commanders.
lead_paragraph: [At War is a newsletter about the experiences and costs of war. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday.]

headline: Why Does Only One Party Play by the Rules?
abstract: Thanks to Trump’s deepening dependence on “alternative facts,” the assertion of reality is now a viable campaign strategy for 2020 Democrats.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of the campaign season when some Democrats are starting to feel — as President Jimmy Carter might have put it — malaise. They’re staring at their 2020 lineup and wondering whether it’s a guaranteed recipe for buyer’s remorse. Joe Biden is too old, Pete Buttigieg is too young, Kamala Harris is too uncertain, Bernie Sanders too unpalatable, Elizabeth Warren too unelectable.

headline: In Criminal Justice Speech, Trump Belittles Obama’s Efforts for Black People
abstract: President Trump, speaking at Benedict College in South Carolina, said he had done more for black voters than any other president.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — President Trump, speaking to a handpicked audience of supporters at a historically black college here on Friday, belittled the Obama administration’s record on racial equity and claimed that his own administration had helped African-Americans beyond anything “in the history of our country.”

headline: U.S. to Deploy Hundreds of Troops to Guard Oil Fields in Syria, Pentagon Officials Say
abstract: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper said the American strategy remains unchanged, although President Trump has said American forces are withdrawing,
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States will deploy several hundred troops to guard eastern oil fields in Syria against the Islamic State, defense officials said Friday, another lurch in President Trump’s zigzagging military policy in the country.

headline: In the Van With the ‘Juicers’ Who Round Up and Recharge Lime Scooters
abstract: Los Angeles streets are dotted with Skittles-colored scooters and e-bikes that have one thing in common: They’re electric, and they need juice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Michelle and Gonzalo Cabezas begin their nightly scavenger hunt at 10. That’s when they start looking for the Lime scooters that people rent and ride by the minute — and leave wherever they please.

headline: How Europeans See America
abstract: We asked young, ordinary Europeans to take a look at U.S. policies on everything from food to guns. As they discover facts about America, they’re not impressed.
lead_paragraph: We asked young, ordinary Europeans to take a look at U.S. policies on everything from food to guns. As they discover facts about America, they’re not impressed.

headline: Maps: California Fires, Evacuation Zones and Power Outages
abstract: Detailed maps show the current fire extents, power outage zones and areas under evacuation orders.
lead_paragraph: Detailed maps show the current fire extents, power outage zones and areas under evacuation orders.

headline: Profit From Art Isn’t Dirty. It Means: Make More Art.
abstract: Are you an artist who dislikes dealing with the financial part of your work? Think of profit as a form of permission.
lead_paragraph: If you are lucky enough to create art that people are willing to pay for, I have a concept to share that had an enormous impact on me: Profit equals permission.

headline: A Truly Exceptional Sheet-Pan Meal
abstract: Clever, delicious and autumnal, Melissa Clark’s sausages with grapes and onions is perfect in a baguette, or paired with farro and green salad.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Some personal news: After months of languishing on a wait list, I have finally been able to join an elite bean-delivery club — elite not because membership is carefully controlled or restricted, but because, as I understand it, there are only so many spots, and pounds of beans. I can’t wait for my first quarterly shipment to arrive.

headline: Clinton Praises Cummings: ‘He Stood Against Corrupt Leadership’
abstract: In her remarks at the funeral for Representative Elijah E. Cummings, Hillary Clinton honored him as a fighter for democracy.
lead_paragraph: In her remarks at the funeral for Representative Elijah E. Cummings, Hillary Clinton honored him as a fighter for democracy.

headline: Have Passport, Can’t Travel
abstract: In this week’s Tripped Up column, Sarah Firshein investigates that pesky recommendation that travelers have passports with expiration dates at least six months past their proposed travel.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, when my family arrived at Dulles International Airport for our flight to Amsterdam, I was informed by a KLM agent that I couldn’t travel abroad because my passport was set to expire in four months. I already had a return ticket.

headline: Marine Veteran Is Deported to El Salvador
abstract: Jose Segovia-Benitez, who has been convicted of several felonies, was sent out of the United States this week and is now in hiding in El Salvador, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: A Marine Corps veteran who served in Iraq and Afghanistan was deported to El Salvador this week after several failed attempts to stay in the United States, where he had lived since he was 3 and had been convicted of several felonies, his lawyer and immigration officials said.

headline: Felicity Huffman Is Released Early
abstract: The actress is one of 35 parents who have been charged in a sweeping college admissions scandal.
lead_paragraph: The actress Felicity Huffman was released early on Friday from the minimum-security prison camp outside San Francisco where she had been serving her 14-day sentence in the college admissions case, according to a Bureau of Prisons spokeswoman.

headline: Trumps Put Their Washington Hotel on the Market
abstract: President Trump has drawn frequent criticism for ownership of the hotel because it hosts foreign diplomats and corporate executives with business before his administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is the most visible and potent symbol of the ethics debate that has dogged President Trump as he has served simultaneously as the nation’s chief executive and real estate developer with a chain of luxury hotels. And now it is for sale.

headline: A Brief History of the Song Cycle in Two Recitals
abstract: The tenors Christoph Prégardien and Ian Bostridge offered New Yorkers a selection of the earliest known song cycle to the genre’s latest addition.
lead_paragraph: The beginnings of things can be fuzzy. But someone tends to get credit for being the first, and in the case of the song cycle, that person is Beethoven.

headline: Review: The White Light Festival Opens With a Journey to the East
abstract: Jordi Savall’s latest program traced a 16th-century missionary’s travels to share his interest in musical traditions from Europe, Africa and Asia.
lead_paragraph: Wherever Jordi Savall wishes to travel, an audience will follow. This early-music master’s fervent community of admirers is the result of both the consistently gorgeous playing of Hespèrion XXI — the ensemble he conducts and plays in — and Mr. Savall’s ceaseless pursuit of unfamiliar repertoire, often presented as evening-length events that draw inspiration from diverse cultures.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg: Facebook Can Help the News Business
abstract: Advertising revenue that used to support journalism now goes to companies like mine. We have a plan to help fix that.
lead_paragraph: When reporters at The Minnesota Star Tribune discovered that infant deaths had significantly increased in the state’s child care facilities, they published a series of articles that ended up driving changes in the law. They won a Pulitzer Prize in 2013 — and within months the infant mortality rate had dropped. As someone married to a pediatrician and committed to investing in solving health challenges, I found this to be a powerful example of how journalism can help us make progress on our biggest issues.

headline: A Brexit Logjam, in Three Dimensions
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the Labour Party and the European Union are all waiting for the other to make the next move. Meanwhile, Britons seethe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he will not do business with Parliament until the opposition Labour Party agrees to a general election. Labour says it will not agree to an election until the European Union decides how long an extension to grant Britain to leave. And European leaders say they will not make that decision until the deadlock in London is broken.

headline: Marta Kurtag Dies at 92, Sundering a Profound Musical Partnership
abstract: She worked closely with her husband, the composer Gyorgy Kurtag, as a performer, muse and critic and was also deeply involved in his writing.
lead_paragraph: Marta Kurtag, a pianist and teacher who shared a 72-year collaboration with her husband, the prominent avant-garde composer Gyorgy Kurtag, profoundly influencing his work and joining him in dual recitals that acquired a legendary reputation in their later years, died on Oct. 17 in Budapest. She was 92.

headline: Review: Mark Morris Fits Houston Ballet to a ‘V’
abstract: Celebrating its 50th anniversary at City Center, the company presents a mixed bill with mixed results, but a winner in Mr. Morris’s “The Letter V.”
lead_paragraph: Houston Ballet, in town for its 50th anniversary, lured me in with the promise of a real dance: That’s what Mark Morris makes. “The Letter V,” which he choreographed for the company in 2015, is better than that. It’s gorgeous.

headline: Maurice Nadjari Dies at 95; Crusading, and Criticized, Prosecutor
abstract: He was hailed by many for zealously pursuing corruption in New York’s criminal justice system, but others, including the courts, said he often went too far.

headline: Kellyanne Conway and Newspaper Face Off Over Warning to Reporter
abstract: Ms. Conway told the reporter for The Washington Examiner that if she was going to cover her personal life, “then we’re welcome to do the same around here,” according to an audio recording.
lead_paragraph: Kellyanne Conway, a counselor to President Trump and one of his fiercest defenders, found herself in a standoff on Friday with a conservative-leaning newspaper after it accused her of threatening to investigate a reporter’s personal life.

headline: Federal Budget Deficit Swelled to Nearly $1 Trillion in 2019
abstract: The Treasury Department said the deficit, which came in at $984 billion, will top $1 trillion in 2020.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States federal budget deficit jumped 26 percent in the 2019 fiscal year to $984 billion, reaching its highest level in seven years as the government was forced to borrow more money to pay for President Trump’s tax and spending policies, official figures showed on Friday.

headline: Maria Butina, Russian Who Infiltrated Conservative Circles, Is Deported
abstract: The covert Russian gun-loving agent who tried to infiltrate Republican circles during the 2016 presidential campaign heads back to her country after serving more than a year in prison.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maria Butina, the young firearms advocate and covert Russian agent who tried to infiltrate conservative Republican circles during the 2016 presidential campaign, is headed back to her home country after serving 15 months in prison for conspiring to act as a foreign agent.

headline: In Tribute to Cummings, Obama Hints at Rebuke of Trump
abstract: The former president said that Representative Elijah E. Cummings showed that “you’re not a sucker to have integrity.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Barack Obama, who has remained largely silent amid the convulsive impeachment debate now gripping the nation, offered a tribute to a late Democratic congressman on Friday that sounded to some listeners like an implicit rebuke of President Trump.

headline: Harold Bloom, Toni Morrison and the ‘Canon Wars’
abstract: Readers weigh in on a literary divide. Also: Brave Americans who come forward.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Love Letter: Like Your Friend, Hate His Husband
abstract: Is there anything you can do if you dislike your pal’s partner?
lead_paragraph: Love Letter is a weekly email about relationship highs, lows and woes. Sign up here to receive it in your inbox every Friday.

headline: The Playlist: Frank Ocean’s Pillow Talk, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Leonard Cohen, the Bad Plus, Selena Gomez and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: What the California Fires Look Like, Up Close and From the Sky
abstract: Peak fire season is far from over in California. The Tick Fire and the Kincade Fire are among several blazes in the state, forcing thousands of evacuations.
lead_paragraph: Peak fire season is far from over in California. The Tick Fire and the Kincade Fire are among several blazes in the state, forcing thousands of evacuations.

headline: Olive Kitteridge Isn’t One to Brag, but She’s on the Best-Seller List
abstract: When Elizabeth Strout saw her iconic character walking with a cane, she stopped and took a closer look. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: In the first chapter of Elizabeth Strout’s “Olive, Again,” which debuts at No. 6 on this week’s hardcover fiction list, the man who will become Olive’s second husband writes, “Dear Olive Kitteridge, I have missed you and if you would see fit to call me or email me or see me, I would like that very much.”

headline: Thar Be Witches, and Us
abstract: Scotland’s violent persecutions far outstripped those in Salem, Mass., but were nearly forgotten. That should scare us.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Tucked around a corner facing Edinburgh Castle is a modest memorial to accused witches, so unobtrusive that most tourists walk right past on their way to the larger attraction. Made in 1894, the Witches’ Well is the only such remembrance in town. A plaque shows the profiles of two women, one angry, one mild, and a snake circling them both. Beneath is a small basin that holds not water but a few flowers.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: De Niro and Pacino. Alyssa Milano. Flea. Taste-testing plant-based burgers. The sunless world of immigrants in Queens. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. The impeachment inquiry. The wildfires in California. A quantum breakthrough by Google. I guess there’s no such thing as a slow news week anymore. Here are some great stories I’m sure you meant to read, so take some time and do it!

headline: Los Angeles Has a New Comedy Clubhouse: Dynasty Typewriter
abstract: Filling the void left by the closure of two other spaces, the club (named for a family business) has quickly established itself as a draw for young Angelenos seeking unconventional work.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The small triangular greenroom is typically decorated with artificial vines over a soothing woodland backdrop. Earlier this month it was also crowded with friends, agents, publicists, producers, makeup artists and hair stylists, all hovering around the stand-up Esther Povitsky.

headline: Two Pianists Offer Contrasting Paths of Exploration
abstract: Mark-André Hamelin explored a Russian wild side, while Paul Lewis hewed to core repertory. Yet both were adventurous in their way.
lead_paragraph: Classical music is overly beholden to traditional concert formats and standard repertory. So it’s important, and often exciting, for artists to be adventurous. There are different ways to do so, as two pianists demonstrated in completely contrasting programs this week in New York.

headline: ‘I Want to Be Heard’: Adult Sex-Abuse Victims Demand New Rights
abstract: Adult victims often have little legal recourse. A bill in New York would give them a “look-back window” to revive claims in civil court.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — An immediate warning sign, she now realizes, should have been evident in their first conversation.

headline: Trump Again Defends Rudy Giuliani
abstract: “He’s been a great crime fighter,” President Trump said of his personal lawyer. “He looks for corruption wherever he goes.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday defended his personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is under investigation by federal prosecutors for his dealings in Ukraine, as “a great crime fighter.”

headline: Bill Traylor’s Outsider Art Veers Into the Mainstream
abstract: A show at David Zwirner Gallery, with the William Louis-Dreyfus Foundation, argues for a more inclusive vision of American art.
lead_paragraph: The actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus remembers her father, William Louis-Dreyfus, swearing on the phone in the 1990s as he almost got outbid on a painting by Bill Traylor, the Alabama artist born into slavery who took up drawing around age 85.

headline: 5 Ballot Proposals for New York
abstract: Vote yes on Questions 1, 2, 3 and 4; no on 5.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Charter is essentially the city’s constitution, laying out the structure and separation of powers of a municipal government that serves more than eight million people. From Oct. 26 to Nov. 5, voters in New York City can change it.

headline: How to Get Rich by Buying a Franchise (Really)
abstract: It’s promoted as a way to gain independence and build wealth, but entrepreneurs need to know what they are getting into first.
lead_paragraph: Dan Gagne has been a plumber for three decades, but it has been years since he held a wrench.

headline: My Family Cared for My Sick Aunt. Who’s Caring for Us?
abstract: Too many people have no choice but to reconfigure their lives around a loved one’s disability.
lead_paragraph: When I was 12, my mother’s 32-year-old sister Emily experienced a berry-aneurysm rupture, which caused a stroke. One day she had a headache that she said felt like being hit with a two-by-four. She went on with life, and then collapsed the next week.

headline: Troubled M.I.T. Media Lab Food Project Closes, for Now
abstract: M.I.T. has mostly shut down the project known as OpenAg. It had been accused of misleading sponsors and the public.
lead_paragraph: The once-celebrated M.I.T. Media Lab micro-greenhouses were supposed to grow food under virtually any conditions. In the end, they worked under almost none. And now, M.I.T. has turned off the lights, possibly for good.

headline: They Know What You Watched Last Night
abstract: While viewers stream their favorite shows, companies are gathering their personal data to sell it to advertisers — and privacy experts are alarmed.
lead_paragraph: A spate of streaming services are on their way from major tech and entertainment companies, promising viewers a trove of binge-worthy new shows and movies.

headline: New Video Shows That Fresno Officer Shot Teen as He Fled
abstract: The footage has raised concerns about why a routine encounter in California escalated so rapidly, and whether lethal force was justified.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — New video footage shows the final moments before a Fresno police officer shot and killed an unarmed teenage boy whom the police had been trying to question about a homicide, raising concerns about whether lethal force was justified.

headline: Government Watchdogs Demand Justice Dept. Withdraw Whistle-Blower Ruling
abstract: Dozens of inspectors general warn that the ruling could chill government workers from alleging wrongdoing in the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government’s inspectors general sharply criticized a Justice Department ruling from last month that determined that the whistle-blower complaint about President Trump’s call with Ukraine’s leader should not go to Congress.

headline: Impeachment Inquiry Is Legal, Judge Rules, Giving Democrats a Victory
abstract: The finding came in an order directing the Justice Department to hand over secret grand jury evidence from the Mueller investigation to House impeachment investigators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge handed a victory to House Democrats on Friday when she ruled that they were legally engaged in an impeachment inquiry, a decision that undercut President Trump’s arguments that the investigation is a sham.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres Just Bought a Vintage Rolex. It Only Cost Around $750,000.
abstract: And she has a new watch friend in Amsterdam. Ain’t life grand?
lead_paragraph: In the vintage watch market, few timepieces are more coveted than a late-1960s gold Rolex Daytona. So how much was obtaining one worth to Ellen DeGeneres, the watch-collecting chat show host and comedian?

headline: Alber Elbaz Opens Up on Plans for His New Fashion Brand
abstract: The former Lanvin designer said he has signed a deal with Richemont.
lead_paragraph: Alber Elbaz is ready for his comeback.

headline: Russian Conscript Kills 8 Soldiers in Shooting in Siberia
abstract: Officials identified the suspect as a private serving in a remote area along Russia's border with China, and blamed a “nervous breakdown.”

headline: 67 Killed in Ethiopia Unrest, but Nobel-Winning Prime Minister Is Quiet
abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, this year’s winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, was in Russia when the protests broke out and has yet to publicly comment on the violence.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Weeks after receiving the Nobel Peace Prize, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed is coming under harsh criticism over his silence in the face of protests this week that police said had resulted in the deaths of 67 people.

headline: Timothy Egan Makes Room for the Holy Spirit
abstract: The “lapsed but listening” Catholic traveled from Canterbury to Rome to figure out what he believes. In “A Pilgrimage to Eternity,” he shares his findings.
lead_paragraph: A PILGRIMAGE TO ETERNITYFrom Canterbury to Rome in Search of a FaithBy Timothy Egan

headline: In Canada’s North, Art Emerges In the Face of Difficulty
abstract: Catherine Porter discusses the time she spent reporting in Cape Dorset, a place that struggles despite producing more artists per capita than big cities.
lead_paragraph: Hi, this is Catherine Porter and I am filling in for Ian Austen.

headline: The Long, Complicated Road to Nationals Fever
abstract: For older Washington fans, baseball came and went — for a long time. A Times editor who grew up in Washington reflects on the old teams and developing passion for the Nationals.
lead_paragraph: So, what do you do when your hometown baseball team goes to the World Series for the first time since 1933?

headline: Kanye West Releases His Gospel-Themed Album ‘Jesus Is King’
abstract: After announcing, then missing, his deadlines, the rapper put out his ninth LP and an Imax film capturing one of the Sunday Service concerts that inspired it.
lead_paragraph: For some artists, a blown deadline is a problem. For Kanye West, it is a marketing opportunity.

headline: ‘My Grandchild Is Not a Terrorist’
abstract: A reporter spends time with families fighting to bring home the wives and children of ISIS fighters.
lead_paragraph: This week, Melbourne-based reporter Livia Albeck-Ripka worked with producer Lynsea Garrison to make a two-part series about the relatives of ISIS fighters. You heard the story of Kamalle Dabboussy, whose daughter and grandchildren are detained in Syria. But there are many others. We asked Livia to tell us about her experience meeting these family members:

headline: Astros Hold Off Nationals to Win Game 3 of the World Series
abstract: Zack Greinke and a series of Houston relievers held the Nationals’ potent lineup to just one run as the Astros avoided a three-game deficit in the Series.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In baseball, as in many team sports, plane rides are so much more than transportation. They can be critical incubators for things like team bonding and strategy sessions, where players can work through important issues.

headline: Hear Them Roar
abstract: Two new anthologies immortalize women writers and their iconic subjects.
lead_paragraph: I USED TO BE CHARMINGThe Rest of Eve BabitzEdited by Sara J. Kramer

headline: John Lithgow on His Satirical Poems
abstract: The actor talks about “Dumpty: The Age of Trump in Verse,” and Leigh Bardugo discusses “Ninth House.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Applications Open for the 2020 New York Portfolio Review
abstract: Apply now for the free three day event for photographers on March 27, 28 and 29.
lead_paragraph: We are again bringing together 110 talented photographers with 75 top photo editors, publishers, curators, gallery owners and video producers, for the 8th annual New York Portfolio Review on March 27, 28 and 29 in New York City. Applications are now open for the free New York Portfolio Review, which is produced by The New York Times photo department, the Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at the City University of New York and United Photo Industries. Participation is open to anyone over 18 years old, and all types of photography will be considered. The deadline is Tuesday November 19, 11:59 p.m. Eastern Time.

headline: Yannick Nézet-Séguin Takes Over the Met’s Young Artist Program
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s new music director will lead its prestigious training program, which is recovering from a scandal with his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: The conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, who became the music director of the Metropolitan Opera last season, said on Friday that he had decided to take on a larger role nurturing its next generation of talent by leading the company’s prestigious young artist program.

headline: California Emerged From Drought and Is Still Catching Fire
abstract: California's eight years of drought officially ended in March, but wildfires are still engulfing parts of the state. Here are three major contributions.
lead_paragraph: California residents hit a milestone in March: for the first time in eight years the state was officially out of a drought. That drought, atop years of record breaking temperatures, had helped spur the creation of enormous wildfires. Many wondered if 2019 would be a quieter wildfire season.

headline: General Motors, California, World Series: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Emilio Nicolas Sr., 88, a Creator of Univision, Dies
abstract: Mr. Nicolas and four other investors expanded a single San Antonio television station into what became a Spanish-language broadcasting juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: Emilio Nicolas Sr., who built a struggling Texas television station into the company that became the Spanish-language broadcasting juggernaut Univision, died on Oct. 12 at his home in San Antonio. He was 88.

headline: Halloween: Nooses and Blackface Decorations Prompt Backlash
abstract: “You’re in a community that is predominately black, yet you don’t know what the noose symbolizes?” a Brooklyn parent asked.
lead_paragraph: Depictions of children hanging from nooses were displayed across the street from an elementary school in Brooklyn. An empty noose swung from a home on Long Island. And in Rockland County, N.Y., three black pumpkins with white eyes, noses and mouths sat on the steps of a small law firm.

headline: In Fire-Scarred California, ‘If You’re Told to Go, You Go’
abstract: As wildfires raged across the state this week, tens of thousands of residents were ordered to evacuate their homes out of an abundance of caution.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California.]

headline: Bernie Parrish, All-Pro Cornerback Who Took on the N.F.L., Dies at 83
abstract: A hard-hitting player who defended players’ rights, Parrish suffered from a cognitive decline late in life, presumably from concussions.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Parrish, an All-Pro defensive back for the Cleveland Browns in the 1960s who in retirement tried to organize N.F.L. players into a Teamsters-backed union and wrote a book critical of the league, died on Wednesday at his home in Springfield, Mo. He was 83.

headline: Microsoft Wins Pentagon’s $10 Billion JEDI Contract, Thwarting Amazon
abstract: Amazon was considered a front-runner for the cloud computing project before President Trump began criticizing the company’s founder, Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Department of Defense on Friday awarded a $10 billion technology contract to Microsoft over Amazon in a contest that was closely watched after President Trump ramped up his criticism of Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos, and said he might intervene.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: House investigators are in talks to secure the testimony of an unlikely star witness.
lead_paragraph: Impeachment investigators are in talks with a lawyer for John Bolton about bringing the mustachioed former national security adviser in for a closed-door deposition. I talked to my colleague Peter Baker, who is writing a story on Mr. Bolton’s potential role in the impeachment inquiry, about what could make him a valuable witness.

headline: Leroy Johnson, Barrier-Breaking Georgia Politician, Dies at 91
abstract: In 1962, he became the first black candidate elected to the State Senate since Reconstruction. But his influence extended farther, as Muhammad Ali found out.
lead_paragraph: Leroy R. Johnson, a prominent Georgia politician who in 1962 became the first black candidate elected to that state’s Senate since Reconstruction, died on Oct. 24 in Atlanta. He was 91.

headline: Lebanon Battles to Be Born at Last
abstract: One million Lebanese protesters are demanding change. Hezbollah has other ideas.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Lebanon was ahead of the game on civil war and now is last to the Arab Spring, or at least an Arab something — a vast, united exhalation of disgust at the thievery, corruption and nepotism that has caused widespread misery across this wounded land.

headline: PGA Tour, With Tiger Woods in Tow, Tries to Win Over Japan
abstract: This week’s Zozo Championship is the first official PGA Tour event in Japan, where golf’s popularity has dipped in recent years.
lead_paragraph: INZAI, JAPAN — Yasuo Shiina left his home in Tokyo at dawn Thursday to get a spot at the 10th tee of the Accordia Golf Narashino Country Club, about 90 minutes away. Shiina plays a round or so a month and watches lots of golf on television. But he has never seen the likes of Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy and Jason Day up close.

headline: Morales Averts Runoff in Bolivia, Officials Say, but Anger and Doubt Remain
abstract: The election board’s finding incensed the opposition and raised international skepticism about a race dogged by allegations of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Bolivia’s electoral tribunal announced late Friday that President Evo Morales had won this week’s presidential election by a margin large enough to avoid a runoff, a finding that incensed the opposition and raised international doubts about a race that has been dogged by allegations of fraud.

headline: Has M.L.B.’s Ball Lost Its Juice? Some Players Think So
abstract: The baseball seemed to fly faster than ever this regular season, but some have noticed a slowdown in October.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robinson Chirinos, the Houston Astros catcher, has the best vantage point during games to evaluate every play. So trust his judgment in joining a chorus of people befuddled about how the baseballs themselves are behaving this postseason.

headline: Giuliani, Overheard Talking About Need for Cash, Mistakenly Calls NBC Reporter
abstract: “The problem is we need some money,’’ Mr. Giuliani says on the call. Then he adds: “We need a few hundred thousand.’’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer and a key figure in the impeachment inquiry, managed to inadvertently telephone an NBC News reporter at 11 p.m. one night this month and leave a lengthy voice message filled with snippets of an overheard conversation.

headline: E.A. Carmean,Who Forsook a Life in Art for the Church, Dies at 74
abstract: An expert on European and American modernism, he was most notably the founding curator of the National Gallery’s department of 20th-century art.
lead_paragraph: E.A. Carmean Jr., a museum curator and director and modern art expert who, responding to a higher calling midway through his career, entered a seminary and became an Episcopal canon, died on Oct. 12 at his home in Washington. He was 74.

headline: Don Valentine, Founder of Sequoia Capital, Is Dead at 87
abstract: Mr. Valentine’s venture capital firm, established in 1972, helped cement Silicon Valley as a hub for technology companies.
lead_paragraph: Don Valentine, a venture capitalist who founded Sequoia Capital, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm that helped cement the area’s rise as a technology hub, died on Friday at his home in Woodside, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Why Will Breitbart Be Included in ‘Facebook News’?
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg can’t be understood in terms of partisan politics. It’s all about growth.
lead_paragraph: With a presidential election looming, it seems everyone is trying to get inside Mark Zuckerberg’s head.

headline: Giuliani Is Drawing Attention to Hunter Biden’s Work in Romania. But There’s a Problem.
abstract: Hunter Biden worked to help a Romanian executive facing corruption charges. But so did the former New York mayor — and a former F.B.I. director.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, signaled this month that he planned to open a new front in his attacks against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. — work done by Mr. Biden’s son Hunter Biden for a wealthy Romanian business executive facing corruption charges.

headline: ‘Swing Set Susan’ Threatened to Arrest Hispanic Teens. Instead, She Was Charged.
abstract: A video of a Texas woman berating and threatening to arrest a group of Hispanic teenagers for playing at a park was widely shared last week.
lead_paragraph: A white woman from Texas who was seen berating and threatening to arrest a group of Hispanic teenagers for playing at a park in a widely shared video was charged this week with impersonating a public servant, the police said.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Wants to Lose Your Vote
abstract: Those with plans for everything prove only that they can’t be trusted to plan for anything.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, it was conventional wisdom that the world would soon start running low on oil and that the United States would henceforth be at the mercy of the inexorable trend. Then the fracking revolution came about, and the U.S. resumed its long-lost place as the world’s No. 1 oil and natural gas producer.

headline: Women Get an Unwanted Surprise by Mail: You’re Pregnant! (They’re Not.)
abstract: A company’s attempt to recruit pregnant customers reached many who were not.
lead_paragraph: Chelcie Gette’s mother called her early Tuesday morning to tell her she had gotten something in the mail. The two went on FaceTime and opened it together. “It was a cute little card congratulating me for my soon-to-be baby,” Ms. Gette, 27, said.

headline: For the Nationals, a Former Bat Boy Mixes Numbers and Tradition
abstract: Sam Mondry-Cohen, Washington’s 32-year-old assistant general manager, used his field-level understanding of baseball’s culture to modernize the club’s approach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His job was to make life easier for the best baseball players in the world. For seven seasons, starting at age 16, Sam Mondry-Cohen worked in the visitors’ clubhouse in San Francisco, shining cleats, hauling equipment, filling coffee orders. At game time he would be the bat boy, in full uniform, as he was for the Washington Nationals the night Barry Bonds broke the career home run record in 2007.

headline: Hot Spots?
abstract: Step right up and take a crack at Sam Trabucco’s Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I’m not going to lie, I needed this after yesterday’s nail-biter. Sam Trabucco always makes very elegant, whimsical puzzles, and today’s is no exception. That didn’t mean it was humdrum, but it was extremely smooth and clean and a fairly swift solve for me.

headline: Key Witness in Impeachment Inquiry Asks Federal Court to Rule Over Testifying
abstract: The move raises new doubts about whether President Trump’s closest aides will be able to cooperate with the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A key witness in the impeachment investigation filed a lawsuit Friday asking a federal judge to rule on whether he can testify, a move that raises new doubts about whether President Trump’s closest aides, like the former national security adviser, John R. Bolton, will be able to cooperate with the inquiry.

headline: Corrections: October 26, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 26, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Federal Budget Deficit Is Projected to Surpass $1 Trillion Next Year
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 26, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “The current levels of debt are unprecedented in peacetime during a growing economy, and the consequences of this irresponsible spending are unknown.”

headline: Trump Administration Cuts Flights to Most Cuban Airports
abstract: Looking to punish Cuba over its support for President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, the United States will ban airlines from servicing all cities besides Havana.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Transportation Department announced Friday that it would suspend flights from the United States to nine airports in Cuba beginning in December. The policy will sever air service to every international airport there except the one in Havana.

headline: Nets Edge Knicks in First New York Matchup of the Season
abstract: The Nets held off the hot-shooting Knicks to grab their first win of the season.
lead_paragraph: In the season’s first installment of the N.B.A.’s answer to the Subway Series, the Nets held off the Knicks, 113-109, on Friday night.

headline: Rachel Maddow Confronts Her NBC News Bosses Live, on the Air
abstract: Her remarks came during an episode of her MSNBC show with her former colleague Ronan Farrow as a guest. Mr. Farrow praised her for “speaking truth to power.”
lead_paragraph: The MSNBC anchor Rachel Maddow publicly confronted the leadership of her own network on Friday night, declaring live on air that she and other NBC News employees had deep concerns about whether the organization had stymied Ronan Farrow’s reporting on the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein.

headline: Brooklyn Shooting: Police Kill Man After He Critically Injures Officer
abstract: A police officer was in a medically induced coma after being hit in the head with a metal chair during an altercation in a nail salon.
lead_paragraph: The police fatally shot a Brooklyn T-shirt vendor in a nail salon on Friday after he used a chair to hit an officer who was trying to arrest another man, officials said. The officer, who was hit on the head during the altercation, was hospitalized in critical but stable condition, officials said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘BoJack Horseman’ and ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: “BoJack” embarks on its final season, and Chance the Rapper hosts and performs as the musical guest on “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: BOJACK HORSEMAN Stream on Netflix. This talking horse has certainly had his ups and downs over the course of this series, often sabotaging his own success with drugs, alcohol and other destructive behaviors. But as the show enters its final season, BoJack (Will Arnett) seems to be on the path toward accepting responsibility by entering rehab. Elsewhere in Hollywoo, Diane (Alison Brie), Princess Carolyn (Amy Sedaris), Todd (Aaron Paul) and Mr. Peanutbutter (Paul F. Tompkins) grapple with their own definitions of happiness as their brightly colored animated world changes around them. The show, a sendup of Hollywood, will also tackle film franchises, mergers and unionization efforts. These eight episodes serve as Part 1 of the final sixth season, with Part 2 coming Jan. 31.

headline: How a Rooftop Meadow of Bees and Butterflies Shows N.Y.C.’s Future
abstract: A Greenpoint building is part of a push to combat climate change and make the city more welcoming to wildlife.
lead_paragraph: Tall grasses glow in the afternoon sunlight. The last bees and butterflies of the season hover over goldenrod and asters. Silver orbs that look like alien spacecrafts shimmer nearby.

headline: Panic in Pakistani City After 900 Children Test Positive for H.I.V.
abstract: Health workers say the reuse of syringes drove the outbreak in the city of Ratodero.
lead_paragraph: RATODERO, Pakistan — Nearly 900 children in the small Pakistani city of Ratodero were bedridden early this year with raging fevers that resisted treatment. Parents were frantic, with everyone seeming to know a family with a sick child.

headline: ‘Hitler or Höcke?’ Germany’s Far-Right Party Radicalizes
abstract: In elections on Sunday, the AfD is set to make another strong showing in eastern Germany. Its local leader, Björn Höcke, is considered an extremist by the intelligence service.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was a stunt but it was revealing. Lawmakers of the far-right Alternative for Germany were read quotations and then asked: Were these penned by Björn Höcke, the party’s most notorious far-right firebrand — or by Hitler?

headline: Nate Diaz Passed Drug Test and Can Fight Next Week, U.F.C. Says
abstract: Despite what the fighter himself suggested on Thursday, officials said he had not violated antidoping policy.
lead_paragraph: A day after Nate Diaz said he would not fight in his upcoming Ultimate Fighting Championship bout at Madison Square Garden because he was told he had tested positive for a banned substance — an allegation that he made public and vehemently denied in a single tweet — officials said he was all clear.

headline: In Hungary, Viktor Orban Showers Money on Stadiums, Less So on Hospitals
abstract: The Hungarian prime minister has created what critics call a semi-autocracy at the heart of democratic Europe. But he has largely ignored his country’s health care system.
lead_paragraph: FELCSUT, Hungary — The Pancho Arena stands about 20 yards from the country home of Viktor Orban, Hungary’s prime minister. The professional soccer stadium has a heated pitch, a museum, a spotless medical clinic and 3,814 seats, double the population of the surrounding village.

headline: While California Fires Rage, the Rich Hire Private Firefighters
abstract: A small but growing number of wealthy people are hiring their own teams.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You can now add firefighting to the list of the ways that the wealthy are different from the rest of the world.

headline: Warren’s Education Plan, and Why High-Stakes Testing Seems Here to Stay
abstract: Her K-12 proposal includes ending such testing, but there’s less than meets the eye.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts released a plan for K-12 education. It is expansive and expensive, calling for hundreds of billions of dollars in funding for impoverished children, aggressive efforts to promote racial integration, and sharp limits on federal support for charter schools.

headline: Symbol of ’80s Greed Stands to Profit From Trump Tax Break for Poor Areas
abstract: The financier Michael Milken is a major investor in a property that became eligible for a federal tax break — after his longtime friend, Steven Mnuchin, intervened.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — In the 1980s, Michael Milken embodied Wall Street greed. A swashbuckling financier, he was charged with playing a central role in a vast insider-trading scheme and was sent to prison for violating federal securities and tax laws. He was an inspiration for the Gordon Gekko character in the film “Wall Street.”

headline: Secret Deal Helped Housing Industry Stop Tougher Rules on Climate Change
abstract: The  arrangement, in place for years, guarantees industry representatives a bloc of  seats on two powerful committees that recommend building codes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A secret agreement has allowed the nation’s homebuilders to make it much easier to block changes to building codes that would require new houses to better address climate change, according to documents reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: The Impeachment Inquiry This Week in 6 Developments
abstract: Details of a quid pro quo. Enter the “Deep State.” Steve Bannon is back. Revenge of the Republicans. And more.
lead_paragraph: More damning testimony. A Republican resistance emerges and so does the “Deep State.” Steve Bannon is back and so is Anonymous. So many developments … so little time. It’s O.K., we’ll recap the week for you.

headline: Running Away, and Finding Solace in Art
abstract: George Nkrumah Meizah moved to New York from Ghana when he was 17. When he ran into problems at home, he found hope, and purpose, in art therapy.
lead_paragraph: When George Nkrumah Meizah was growing up in Ghana, he would watch American movies and wonder what it would be like to live in the United States.

headline: It’s One of Autumn’s Best Scents, but Not Everyone Smells It
abstract: Foliage is lovely, but so is the odor of the katsura, also known as the “caramel tree.”
lead_paragraph: Sugar, red and Japanese Maples: You can drive up and down America’s east coast to enjoy their fiery pyrotechnic shows each fall. Along the way, you may want to hop out of the car, take a deep breath and hope you catch a whiff of the katsura tree’s sweet scent.

headline: Memorializing Tragedy at a Pittsburgh Synagogue Through Faith, History and Good Works
abstract: The three congregations that shared the Tree of Life synagogue are taking different approaches one year after a mass shooting left 11 worshipers dead.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In early September, James Young, an international expert in public memorials, came to speak to the local Jewish community.

headline: Donald Trump’s Gift to Mitt Romney: Relevance
abstract: It’s not how he wanted to get to Washington, but now that he is here the junior senator from Utah is trying to make the most of it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I don’t feel that there’s a need to be careful at this stage of my life,” said Senator Mitt Romney, who seems intent on proving as much these days.

headline: Kickball Umpire Sues South Carolina Mayor, Saying He Was Fired Over a Call
abstract: A lawyer for the umpire is calling for the governor and the state attorney general to open a misconduct investigation into Michael A. Lockliear, the mayor of Moncks Corner.
lead_paragraph: The home team, trailing 5-1 in a recreational league kickball game for adults, had put runners on first and second with two outs in the bottom of the eighth inning.

headline: Thanksgiving Getaway: Going Someplace Other Than Grandmother’s House
abstract: There’s no place like home for the holidays. But there’s also no place like a half-empty beach resort in shoulder season, or a European city right before Christmas.
lead_paragraph: For millions of Americans, Thanksgiving means Dad’s famous gravy, tryptophan-fueled naps and chance encounters with former high school classmates. For others, Thanksgiving means tropical cocktails and butter-soft sand.

headline: ‘We’re Asking You to Dig Deep’: Biden Seeks to Steady Finances as Allies Fret
abstract: Joe Biden’s presidential campaign is spending more money than it is taking in, unlike his top 2020 rivals, and showing an inability to galvanize big financial backers or energize many online donors.
lead_paragraph: Steve Ricchetti, one of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s closest confidantes, is reaching out to wary donors to shore up support. The Biden presidential campaign is watching costs — some staff members are sleeping at homes of volunteers — and facing criticism for spending on chartered jets. Mr. Biden’s team is also urging allies to redouble fund-raising efforts before the calendar turns to 2020 and he has fewer days to devote to the money trail.

headline: Tim Ryan Out, Polls at Odds: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Here’s a rundown of what happened in the Democratic primary this week.
lead_paragraph: And then there were 18, which was still larger than the presidential field in any other year.

headline: In Afghanistan’s War and Peace, WhatsApp Delivers the Message
abstract: WhatsApp has proliferated in the highest echelons of the Afghan government — as well as among the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When hundreds of Taliban fighters surrounded the district center of Bala Murghab in western Afghanistan in early April, the Afghan troops stationed there knew they were in peril. They couldn’t reach their own commandos. American air support was their last hope.

headline: Real Wedding Day Looks
abstract: A selection of outfits worn by men and women, most of whom were featured in our announcements.
lead_paragraph: A traditional aso oke for a Nigerian wedding. A kimono for a Japanese tea. A red lehenga for a Hindu ceremony. The men and women featured in our wedding announcements (and other couples) wore outfits that told many stories, some of personal style and others of cultural traditions. Here is a selection of photographs from their weddings, with details on their purchases.

headline: Bonding Over Politics, Religion and a Dog Named Henry
abstract: Her phone call got the relationship started after the couple met in January 2016 at a fund-raiser in Indianapolis.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Elizabeth Brown and Jared Michael Bond were married Oct. 26 at the Indiana Statehouse in Indianapolis. The Rev. Matthew R. Barnes, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: In the Heart of America, a Long-Distance Love
abstract: Kirsten Milliard and Jesus Osete met in Kansas City, Mo., on the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel. She thought he lived in town.
lead_paragraph: Kirsten Lynn Milliard and Jesus Armando Osete were married Oct. 26 at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Lenexa, Kan. The Rev. Gerard Alba, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rugby World Cup: England Upsets New Zealand in Stunner
abstract: The All Blacks, the defending champions, lost 19-7, and England will face either Wales or South Africa in the World Cup final.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — One of the first questions put to England Coach Eddie Jones after his team dominated the near-unanimous favorite to win a third Rugby World Cup semifinal in succession was where England’s victory over New Zealand ranked in its rugby history.

headline: Getting Ready for the New York City Marathon
abstract: Special events for marathon weekend.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Maria Butina, Deported to Moscow, Is Defiant: ‘Russians Don’t Give Up’
abstract: Ms. Butina, who befriended prominent Republicans during the 2016 election, served time in a Florida prison as an unregistered foreign agent.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Maria Butina, the gun-loving Russian who befriended prominent Republicans during the 2016 presidential campaign and ended up imprisoned in Florida, landed in Moscow on Saturday, a day after she was deported.

headline: Pan Am Remains Grounded. In Culture, That Is.
abstract: On Oct. 26, 1958, the airline made a historic flight from New York to Paris that helped usher in the jet age.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 26, 1958, Pan American World Airways made the first commercial nonstop flight from New York to Paris. A marching band played John Philip Sousa as guests boarded the plane, where 111 passengers supped on cuisine from Maxim’s in Paris. Twenty-five years later, the airline commemorated the voyage by inviting celebrities like Eartha Kitt and the boxing champ Floyd Patterson to Paris in one of the original Boeing 707 jets. Once there, the crew was feted at a party.

headline: PG&E Shuts Off Power in Northern California as Residents Flee Fires
abstract: Winds were forecast to reach 80 miles per hour on Saturday night near the Kincade fire in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: HEALDSBURG, Calif. — Popular downtown boutiques and farm-to-table restaurants were deserted in Healdsburg, Calif., by Saturday afternoon. Traffic ground to a halt in downtown Windsor, where lines for gas stations spilled into gridlocked roadways. The county fairgrounds in Santa Rosa once again morphed into a disaster base camp.

headline: Pocketbook Woes Drive an Unlikely Comeback in Argentine Presidential Race
abstract: President Mauricio Macri rose to office with a promise that free markets would wrest Argentina from its boom-and-bust cycle. But with the country in recession, voters may now turn to an archrival.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Four years ago, Mauricio Macri persuaded working class Argentines like Hugo Taboada that it was time to end 17 years of economic mismanagement and brazen graft by the country’s leftist leaders, a shift that propelled him to an upset victory as president.

headline: Noise Complaint: The Bar Downstairs Blasts Music All Night!
abstract: When the business on the ground floor of your building answers to the co-op board, you have more power than it might seem.
lead_paragraph: Q: After moving into a fourth-floor apartment in a Washington Heights co-op, we discovered that the innocuous-looking bar on the ground floor turns into a raging nightclub from midnight until 4 a.m. Nothing drowns out the bass — not ear plugs, not white-noise machines, not even the soundproof windows we installed. We’ve complained repeatedly to management, which tells us they are “sending notice,” but nothing changes. The board president recently said nothing could be done. But the bar is a tenant of the co-op. Doesn’t the board have a say over its tenant’s behavior?

headline: A Racist Attack Shows How Whiteness Evolves
abstract: An assault at a New Jersey high school football game had an unexpected cast of characters.
lead_paragraph: Two 17-year-old boys accused of harassing four African-American middle schoolgirls — using racial slurs and urinating on one of the victims — are facing charges including bias intimidation and lewdness.

headline: Economic Incentives Don’t Always Do What We Want Them To
abstract: On their own, markets can’t deliver outcomes that are just, acceptable — or even efficient.
lead_paragraph: At least since Adam Smith and his famous B’s (“It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker that we expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own self-interest.”), a fundamental premise of economics has been that financial incentives are the primary driver of human behavior. Over the last few decades, this faith in the power of economic incentives led policymakers in the United States and elsewhere to focus, often with the best of intentions, on a narrow range of “incentive-compatible” policies.

headline: Boris Johnson Is Heading for a Scorched-Earth Election
abstract: The soul of Britain’s Conservative Party — and the country itself — is at stake.
lead_paragraph: News update: On Tuesday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson won a vote to hold a general election on Dec. 12.

headline: Zack Greinke Lays the Foundation for an Astros Comeback
abstract: Greinke battled the Nationals for nearly five innings to help Houston avoid a three-game deficit, giving the Astros new life in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is rare for a World Series to go three games without a win by the home team. That is how it stands now, after the Washington Nationals won twice in Houston, then squandered nearly all of their chances at home on Friday in a 4-1 loss to the Astros in Game 3.

headline: Official Says Attempts to Rally Top State Officials Behind Ukraine Ambassador Failed
abstract: Philip T. Reeker offered additional details on the unexpected ouster of the ambassador to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top diplomat told impeachment investigators on Saturday that he repeatedly pressed top State Department leaders, in vain, to defend the United States ambassador to Ukraine in the face of false attacks that he said were orchestrated by the president’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: 11 New Recipes You Don’t Want to Miss
abstract: Fluffy Cheddar biscuits, peanut butter-miso cookies and more.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, make peanut butter-miso cookies (above), citrus-glazed pork chops, fluffy Cheddar biscuits or any of the new recipes in the collection below.

headline: Even Eagles Have Data Roaming Limits, Researchers Find
abstract: When one bird being tracked by Russian scientists flew to Iran, its transmitter sent a flood of text messages that ate up the tracking budget.
lead_paragraph: Frequent fliers often find themselves with hefty phone bills, and global travelers can drain their roaming data allowance. But eagles?

headline: Michael Milken’s Career
abstract: After college, he joined the firm that would become Drexel Burnham Lambert.
lead_paragraph: “Greed, for lack of a better word, is good. Greed is right. Greed works.” Those are the words of Gordon Gekko, a character in the 1987 film “Wall Street,” who was partly inspired by Michael Milken. Mr. Milken, who became known as the billionaire king of junk bonds, was the face of avarice in the 1980s. After serving time in prison, he has gone on to other ventures.

headline: Thanks, Whistle-Blower, Your Work Is Done
abstract: Virtually every assertion he made has been corroborated on the record by the administration or other officials and witnesses.
lead_paragraph: Virtually every assertion he made has been corroborated on the record by the administration or other officials and witnesses.

headline: A Corner of Washington, United by the Nationals (and Blue Sharks)
abstract: As the World Series returned to the nation’s capital for the first time since 1933, many in the city rallied around the Nationals and their unofficial shark mascot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours before the World Series officially returned to this city for the first time in 86 years, the roiling red waves rolled in.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon get reflective.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is by a modern comedic actress and writer I would call beloved, Mindy Kaling, from her “Why Not Me?” memoir. Ms. Kaling is famous for the American version of “The Office,” as well as her own show, “The Mindy Project,” various other series and movies, and a few best sellers. She’s a quintessential Everywoman trying to make her way in an appearance-obsessed society, to humorous effect.

headline: Waiting for Bolton: A Capital Speculates on What He Will Say
abstract: As the House impeachment inquiry enters its second month, there may be no witness investigators want to question more than John R. Bolton, the president’s former national security adviser.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The message that John R. Bolton, President Trump’s former national security adviser, sent supporters of his newly reopened political action committee last week raised as many questions as it answered in a capital consumed by impeachment.

headline: The E.P.A., on Asbestos
abstract: Andrew Wheeler, the current administrator, takes issue with two former administrators. Also: “New Sounds”; what the economics profession needs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Could Trump Serve a Second Term if Ousted? It’s Up to the Senate
abstract: Everyone knows the Senate can remove a president, but a second, lesser-known vote could disqualify someone from future office altogether.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With chances rapidly increasing that President Trump will be impeached by the House and tried in the Senate, an intriguing question has reared its head: Could he be ousted only to try to return to the White House in 2020 in a Trumpian bid for redemption and revenge?

headline: World’s Largest Treehouse Burns to the Ground
abstract: Horace Burgess built the castle-like structure after a vision from God. It took less than 15 minutes to destroy it.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, Harold Burgess, the creator of the world’s largest treehouse, has been taking calls from mourners all over the world who had made pilgrimages to the 97-foot-tall wooden structure in Crossville, Tenn.

headline: Hong Kong Protests Spread to U.S. Colleges, and a Rift Grows
abstract: Officials face the challenging task of supporting free expression without alienating the largest demographic of international students on American campuses.
lead_paragraph: For much of the year, Frances Hui followed the Hong Kong demonstrations from her dorm room at Emerson College, feeling guilty that she was safe in Boston while clashes grew increasingly violent for her fellow Hong Kongers.

headline: U.K. Truck Driver Charged With Manslaughter in Deaths of 39
abstract: Maurice Robinson, 25, has been held for questioning since the grisly discovery of the bodies in a truck in Essex, England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 25-year-old man was charged on Saturday with manslaughter and a trafficking conspiracy in connection with the deaths of 39 people whose bodies were found in a refrigerated truck in southeastern England, the Essex Police said.

headline: Democratic Candidates Rebuke Trump at Criminal Justice Forum
abstract: One day after President Trump hailed his own record on criminal justice and belittled Barack Obama’s, Democrats hit back at his record and history of racial demagogy.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — One day after President Trump claimed he had done more for black voters than the Obama administration had, several Democratic presidential candidates spoke at the same historically black college on Saturday and issued a blistering rebuke of both the president and the event’s organizers — whom they accused of giving Mr. Trump an undeserved platform.

headline: Choosing to Be Vulnerable With My Patients
abstract: Doctors don’t like to let their guard down. But sometimes good things happen when they do.
lead_paragraph: When I was a third-year medical student in Baltimore, one of my first patients was a 20-something intravenous drug user. Thin and unkempt, an orange Orioles cap shadowing his heavily-tattooed face, he had a serious infection and needed to stay in the hospital for several days. It was not his first time being hospitalized.

headline: Who Is Bill Barr?
abstract: The attorney general? Trump’s protector? Both?
lead_paragraph: The attorney general? Trump’s protector? Both?

headline: Against the Superhero Regime
abstract: In the Martin Scorsese and “Joker” controversies, hints of resistance to the rule of comic books.
lead_paragraph: Two interesting things have been happening in the world of film over the last month. A relatively low-budget, no-special effects movie that places Batman’s Joker in a version of Martin Scorsese’s decaying 1970s-era New York City has become one of the most successful American movies of the year — with clouds of political outrage trailing in its wake. And everyone on the internet is yelling at, about, or in defense of Scorsese himself, because the aging director told an interviewer that superhero movies aren’t real cinema.

headline: We’re Less and Less a Christian Nation, and I Blame Some Blowhards
abstract: Some intolerant conservative evangelicals have tainted the faith.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps for the first time since the United States was established, a majority of young adults here do not identify as Christian.

headline: Extra, Extra! Prez Won’t Read All About It
abstract: Snowflake Trump wants us off his lawn.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — My first job in journalism was as a clerk at The Washington Star. I fielded a lot of calls from readers threatening to cancel their subscriptions — including, on occasion, my mom.

headline: IoG: Internet of Ghouls
abstract: Streamline your frights with SmartGhoul technology!
lead_paragraph: Pours rings of salt around your bed at night when it detects spikes in paranormal activity. Available in pairs of two, four and 666.

headline: ‘Human Scum,’ ‘Lynching’ and Trump’s Tortured English
abstract: The president needs a thesaurus and a therapist, though not necessarily in that order.
lead_paragraph: You campaign in poetry, according to a popular saying, and govern in prose.

headline: Catholic Bishops Back Ordination of Married Men as Priests in Amazon Region, a Milestone
abstract: It was the first time a summit of bishops convened by a pope has endorsed such a historic change to the tradition of a celibate priesthood. The final decision will be up to the pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A summit of Roman Catholic bishops meeting at the Vatican recommended on Saturday that Pope Francis allow the ordination of married men as priests in the Amazon region, which would lift a roughly 1,000-year-old restriction and potentially revolutionize the priesthood.

headline: Kelly Says He Told Trump a ‘Yes Man’ as His Successor Would Lead to Impeachment
abstract: Mr. Kelly’s comments appeared to pin the blame for the inquiry on the president’s embattled acting chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John F. Kelly, the former White House chief of staff who during his tenure made it clear he detested the job, expressed regret on Saturday about leaving and implied that he could have helped stave off the impeachment inquiry now threatening Mr. Trump’s presidency.

headline: Pyongyang’s Retro Sci-Fi Architecture
abstract: The world’s most repressive city is also home to a bizarre array of museums, halls and skyscrapers.
lead_paragraph: In July 2015, the two of us stepped off a plane at the newly opened airport in Pyongyang, North Korea. It was our first time in the country. As architects based in Beijing, we were well acquainted with the world’s cities and skyscrapers, but North Korea was a dark spot in our mental map — filled in, as it was for most people, by preconceptions and stereotypes that rendered the so-called Hermit Kingdom in black and white. We had tried to leave those ideas behind, but we didn’t expect that this first visit would leave us with such a sense of confusion, one where the difference between what was real and genuine was muddled by what was ostensibly staged or faked.

headline: ‘Clueless’ and ‘Saved by the Bell’ Are How We Got Trump
abstract: How ’90s pop culture convinced a generation of would-be earnest activists that caring was uncool.
lead_paragraph: I remember sitting in physics class on the first day of the World Trade Organization protests in Seattle in 1999. I was a senior, still 17, and we’d been hearing for weeks that a huge and bad anarchist riot was coming to destroy our town, with tanks and bricks and garbage fires and naked bicyclists and people dressed as turtles. Turtles! The Gap was on high alert!

headline: California Fires Updates: Up to 2.7 Million Will Lose Power
abstract: The intentional shut-off, the largest in the state’s history, comes as extreme weather conditions heighten the threats of wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas and Electric expanded its power blackout zone to include 940,000 customers on Saturday, as the extreme weather conditions heightened the risk that sparks from its equipment could ignite wildfires throughout the utility’s service area.

headline: ‘Keep the Oil’: Trump Revives Charged Slogan for New Syria Troop Mission
abstract: After dismissing Syria as a land of “sand and death,” Mr. Trump is redeploying American troops around its oil fields. But how the U.S. might benefit from them is unclear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has offered several justifications for an American withdrawal from Syria. He has dismissed the country as nothing but “sand and death,” discounted its American-backed Kurdish fighters as “no angels,” and argued that he is winding down “endless wars.”

headline: How the Astros Won Game 4 of the World Series
abstract: The Nationals could do little against Jose Urquidy and Houston’s relievers, and an Alex Bregman grand slam helped tie the series at two games apiece.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alex Bregman held his bat in the air with his left hand and walked five paces down the first-base line, his head turned to watch the final landing spot of a baseball he had launched toward Capitol Hill.

headline: How Sweet it Is!
abstract: Michael Paleos reminds us that it’s always a good day to treat yourself.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle with pinstripes, titled “How Sweet It Is!,” is not about “The Honeymooners.” Instead, Michael Paleos has provided us with a tightly-constructed but extravagant confection, lighthearted and riffy, until you take a closer look and realize how much choreography is really behind it.

headline: The ‘Deep State’ Exists to Battle People Like Trump
abstract: A merit-based system for hiring federal employees was created in reaction to the rampant corruption of the Gilded Age.
lead_paragraph: For the last two weeks, diplomats have been walking through secure doors in the basement of the United States Capitol, defying the objection of their politically appointed superiors as they answer questions from members of the House impeachment inquiry.

headline: A Player With Shoulder Pain, and a League Happy to Turn Its Back
abstract: Kelechi Osemele’s staredown with the Jets over a painful injury pulled back the curtain on the ugly reality of a league that views athletes as commodities.
lead_paragraph: The Jets are their usual dispiriting mess on the field, but in the executive suites their leaders sound testosterone-infused, insisting that their players manifest the manly virtues of playing through pain.

headline: Iraqi Protesters Flood Baghdad Square Despite Violent Crackdown
abstract: A day after dozens were killed in antigovernment protests, the security forces shut off power in a central Baghdad square and launched barrages of tear gas and sound bombs.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Masked and black clad security forces fired barrages of pepper spray, tear gas and sound bombs into crowds of antigovernment protesters in a central Baghdad square for hours on Saturday evening, timing their assault at one point to a shutdown of electricity that left the area enveloped in darkness.

headline: Pilots Watched Video Feed of Lavatory From Cockpit, Flight Attendant Says
abstract: Renee Steinaker and her husband, who is also a flight attendant, filed a lawsuit against Southwest Airlines last year. The airline now says there was never a hidden camera.
