lead_paragraph: When a Southwest Airlines flight attendant entered the cockpit during a flight and saw an iPad showing what appeared to be live footage from the plane’s lavatory, one of the pilots assured her it was a “top secret security measure,” according to court documents. Now, the airline denies there was ever a camera at all.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Panic in Pakistani City After 900 Children Test Positive for H.I.V.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “It seems it is God’s affliction on us. How could so many of our children have such a terrible disease?”

headline: ‘No Regrets’: Hong Kong’s Protesters Test China’s Limits
abstract: Hard-line demonstrators and the embattled authorities are locked in an impasse.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Fat Boy is a college dropout with a youthful blush of acne who excels at playing video games and lives with his mother. He is also a wily commander who leads a ragtag band of protesters willing to risk injury and arrest as they face off against the police.

headline: Liana Rowe, Justin Kamen
abstract: The couple, who met online, were married at the Pavilion at Sunken Meadow in Kings Park, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Liana Rowe and Justin Kamen were married Oct. 26 at the Pavilion at Sunken Meadow in Kings Park, N.Y. Valerie Rowe, the bride’s mother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Josephine Cash, Nicholas Cassin
abstract: The couple met in New York and had their first date at the Hudson Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Josephine Lee Cash and Nicholas Collinge Cassin were married Oct. 26 at Grace Church in New York. The Rev. Julia Macy Offinger, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Kaytlin Bailey, Tre Jones
abstract: The couple met in 2001 as members of the debate team at William G. Enloe High School in Raleigh, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Kaytlin Helen Bailey and Archie Valejo Jones III were married Oct. 26 in Mocksville, N.C. The Rev. Archie Jones Sr., a Baptist minister and the paternal grandfather of the groom, performed the ceremony, with Leah Piper, a friend of the couple, taking part at Brantley Farms, an organic beef farm owned by the groom’s family.

headline: Teresa Gianotti, John Bohrer
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, while working on the “Up with Steve Kornacki” morning show.
lead_paragraph: Teresa Mildred Gianotti and John Robert Bohrer were married Oct. 26 at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Kevin M. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lily Huang, Evan Chase
abstract: The couple met in 2011 while they were interns at the Zhong Lun Law Firm in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Lily Shiran Huang and Evan Schmidt Chase were married Oct. 26 at Villa Del Lago in Austin, Texas. Gregory W. Chase, the groom’s father and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Stephanie Manor, Robert Linn
abstract: The couple met in 2016 while working at the Detroit Land Bank Authority. They were married by Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Kay Manor and Robert Arthur Albert Linn were married Oct. 25 at the Coleman A. Young Municipal Center in Detroit. Mike Duggan, the mayor of Detroit, officiated.

headline: Danielle Tell, Hart Comess-Daniels
abstract: The couple met in 2015 at the rehearsal dinner that preceded the wedding of mutual friends.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Sarah Tell and Hart Gabriel Comess-Daniels are to be married Oct. 27 at the Calhoun Beach Club in Minneapolis. The groom’s father, Rabbi Neil S. Comess-Daniels, is to officiate.

headline: Special Operations Raid Said to Kill Senior Terrorist Leader in Syria
abstract: The identity of the target was not confirmed, but President Trump was scheduled to make a statement on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States Special Operations commandos carried out a risky raid in northwestern Syria on Saturday against a senior terrorist leader there, two senior administration officials said late Saturday.

headline: Samantha Chassin, Alexander Meyer
abstract: The couple met in law school at Case Western Reserve University.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Lynne Chassin and Alexander Little Meyer were married Oct. 26 at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, a restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Paula L. Feldstein officiated.

headline: Dagney Pruner, Carlos Gómez del Campo Neme
abstract: The couple met in 2017 through a mutual friend at a bar in Austin, Texas.
lead_paragraph: Dagney Devlin Pruner and Carlos Gómez del Campo Neme were married Oct. 25 in a civil ceremony at the Cipriani restaurant in Mexico City, in a ceremony led by Judge Juana Emilia Soler. On Oct. 26, the Rev. Ramón A. Hevia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed a nuptial mass in the chapel at Colegio de San Ignacio de Loyola Vizcaínas, a preparatory school in Mexico City.

headline: Audrey Almy, Sean Hawks
abstract: The couple met on Match.com, and went to the movies for their first date in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Audrey Ellen Almy and Sean Edmund Hawks were married Oct. 26 at the Arctic Club, a hotel in Seattle. Elaine M. Way, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Patricia Hurtado de Mendoza, Alexis Abril
abstract: The bride is the press secretary to Carlos Giménez, the mayor of Miami-Dade County; the groom offers mentoring and sales executive courses.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Hurtado de Mendoza and Alexis Augusto Abril were married Oct. 25 at the Islamorada Fish Company, an events space in Islamorada, Fla. The Rev. Steve Vetter, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Nadia Sirota, James Lemkin
abstract: They would stay up until the wee hours discussing the state and future of classical music.
lead_paragraph: Nadia Sirota and James Benjamin Lemkin were married Oct. 22 at the Post Ranch Inn in Big Sur, Calif. Soaring Starkey, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary of New York City, officiated.

headline: Sara Wahlberg, Michael Kurth
abstract: The couple met in New York in 2011 at the birthday party of a mutual friend.
lead_paragraph: Sara Kathleen Wahlberg and the Rev. Michael Benjamin Evington Kurth were married Oct. 26 at Christ’s Church in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Andrew A. Kryzak, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Catherine Wiener, Riley Ford
abstract: The couple met in 2010 at Yale. She was visiting colleges and he was the current student with whom she had an interview.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Diktynna Talbot Wiener and Riley Scripps Ford were married Oct. 26. Associate Judge Rowan D. Wilson of the New York Court of Appeals officiated at the New York Public Library. Anne Fadiman, a college mentor of the groom, gave a reading.

headline: Tony Plohetski, Wroe Jackson
abstract: They once lived in the same apartment complex and went to the same pool on Sundays, but didn’t meet until they were connected by a dating app.
lead_paragraph: Tony Plohetski and Steven Wroe Jackson were married Oct. 26 at the Headliners Club in Austin, Texas. Judge Robert Pitman of the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, a friend of the couple, officiated, with the Rev. Dr. Chuck Treadwell, an Episcopal priest, participating.

headline: Renée Brutus, Ibrahim Yusuf
abstract: The couple met through Match.com, and had their first date in 2016 at a hotel bar in Manhattan
lead_paragraph: Renée Aisha Brutus and Ibrahim Olanrewaju Yusuf were married Oct. 25 at the Foundry, an events space in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, officiated, with Imam Shair Abdul-Mani taking part.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Mrs. Fletcher’ and ‘The Witch’
abstract: Kathryn Hahn stars in this story of sexual rediscovery on HBO, and Robert Eggers’s Puritan nightmare is available to stream.
lead_paragraph: MRS. FLETCHER 10:30 p.m. on HBO. This series is based on Tom Perrotta’s novel “Mrs. Fletcher,” which was published in 2017 and tackles themes of misogyny, sexuality and female empowerment. Like the book, the limited series follows Eve Fletcher, a divorced mom (Kathryn Hahn) in her mid-40s, and her son Brendan (Jackson White), an entitled jock starting his freshman year at college, as they embark on respective journeys of sexual enlightenment. While Brendan struggles to connect with his political-minded peers and confronts conversations about consent, Eve indulges in her newfound freedom by going down an internet pornography rabbit hole. “‘Mrs. Fletcher’ is a very right-now show,” Margaret Lyons wrote in her review for The New York Times. “It’s one of many short-run half-hour dramedies about a woman entering a new phase of her life who discovers new vectors of sexuality and self-actualization while also being treated shabbily.”

headline: Leah Ko, Jann-Lim Lau
abstract: The couple met in 2015 through a mutual friend and had their first date in New York at a Korean barbecue restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Leah Gail Ko and Jann-Lim Lau were married Oct. 25 at St. Paul’s Basilica in Toronto. The Rev. Edward Joseph Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

headline: Brian Focarino, Brian Shea
abstract: On their first date, they went to a taping of “Maury,” where they correctly predicted the results of every paternity test.
lead_paragraph: Brian Joseph Focarino and Brian Jeremiah Shea were married Oct. 25 at Boston City Hall. Patricia A. McMahon, the city registrar, officiated. On Nov. 3, Jason C. Focarino, a brother of Mr. Focarino, is to lead the couple in their vows in Yelapa, Mexico.

headline: Blair Green, Jason George
abstract: The couple met at Stanford, from which the bride graduated, and each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: Blair Kristen Green and Jason Skylar George were married Oct. 26 at Grayhawk Golf Club in Scottsdale, Ariz. Statia Hendrix, an associate city judge of Scottsdale, officiated.

headline: ‘I Kept Myself From Saying I Knew the Other Boroughs Pretty Well, Too’
abstract: Meeting fellow New Yorkers abroad, confronting a litterbug and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1.5 Million Packages a Day: The Internet Brings Chaos to N.Y. Streets
abstract: The push for convenience is having a stark impact on gridlock, roadway safety and pollution in New York City and urban areas around the world.
lead_paragraph: An Amazon order starts with a tap of a finger. Two days later — or even in a matter of hours — the package arrives.

headline: It’s Overreaction O’Clock: Very Early Takeaways on the N.B.A. Season
abstract: Have you seen the Minnesota Timberwolves? And other things to keep an eye on in this new N.B.A. season.
lead_paragraph: We are approximately 2 percent of the way through the N.B.A. season.

headline: ‘SNL’: Chance the Rapper Hosts as Bill Clinton Crashes a Trump Rally
abstract: Chance also did double duty as the musical guest, and several more surprise guests stopped by the rally.
lead_paragraph: O.K., folks, you know the drill by now: The “Saturday Night Live” opening sketch is a space for the cast and its alumni to run through their various political and celebrity impressions, and this week the setting was a rally for President Trump (played by the increasingly rare Alec Baldwin) held in Albuquerque, N.M. Or, as Baldwin called it, “the great city of Albacore, tuna capital of the United States.”

headline: Hong Kong Police Brawl With Protesters Outside Luxury Hotel
abstract: Demonstrators were expressing support for South Asians in the city, a week after the police sprayed stinging dye at a mosque.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Police officers in Hong Kong on Sunday fired tear gas and fought with angry demonstrators outside a luxury hotel, another sign of fraying civility in a financial hub roiled by nearly five months of protests.

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: The Book Review’s annual Halloween issue, Patricia Highsmith’s diaries, visiting Lee Child and more.
lead_paragraph: We take the weekend to highlight recent books coverage in The Times:

headline: Planning for the Unexpected by Taking Charge of Her Finances
abstract: Lauren Edwards was born with sickle cell anemia and had a peripatetic childhood. Now she is getting a handle on her student debt and pursuing a career in money management.
lead_paragraph: For years, change was all Lauren Edwards knew.

headline: On a Greek Island, a Bookstore With Some Mythology of Its Own
abstract: Atlantis Books on Santorini has become a popular tourist attraction and one of Europe’s most enchanting bookshops. Just don’t believe everything you hear.
lead_paragraph: SANTORINI, Greece — On a wall above rare first editions, old maps of this volcanic island and a stained linen lampshade, a painted timeline traces the evolution of Atlantis Books from a wine-drenched notion in 2002 into one of Europe’s most enchanting bookstores.

headline: Lab-Grown Meat That Doesn’t Look Like Mush
abstract: In their quest to make a lab-grown steak, researchers devised a form of scaffolding made with gelatin.
lead_paragraph: The alt-meat industry has created quite a sizzle, promising delicious burgers, steaks and even sushi that is grown from animal cells in the lab.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Before Deadly Crashes, Boeing Pushed for Law That Undercut Oversight
abstract: The government has been handing over more responsibility to manufacturers for years. The new law makes it even harder for regulators to review Boeing’s work.
lead_paragraph: With a few short paragraphs tucked into 463 pages of legislation last year, Boeing scored one of its biggest lobbying wins: a law that undercuts the government’s role in approving the design of new airplanes.

headline: Impeachment, California, Halloween: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Zuckerberg Gets Grilled, and Boeing Goes from Bad to Worse
abstract: Plus, the Fed seems poised to cut interest rates again.
lead_paragraph: Allow us to interrupt your candy corn munching to bring you the week’s top stories in business and tech, including more fallout at Boeing and Mark Zuckerberg’s awkward visit to Washington. What’s scarier: Facebook’s cryptocurrency project or finding out that the United States was using floppy disks to protect its nuclear arsenal up until this year? Happy Halloween. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Jose Urquidy Emerges as the Astros’ Unlikely World Series Savior
abstract: Urquidy, a 24-year-old who was in the minor leagues just weeks ago, did what Justin Verlander, Gerrit Cole, and Zack Greinke could not: earn a win in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gerrit Cole, Justin Verlander and Zack Greinke have combined for 17 All-Star selections, 524 victories, roughly 7,000 strikeouts and more than $500 million in career earnings. All were among the best pitchers in the majors this season, so they started the first three games of this World Series for the Houston Astros.

headline: Bros to Pros: The N.F.L.’s Quinnen and Quincy Williams
abstract: The Williams brothers learned from each other growing up and now chase their shared dream of football stardom at the highest level.
lead_paragraph: Quincy Williams would be the running back. Quinnen Williams, the younger but bigger brother, would be a defensive lineman.

headline: ISIS Leader al-Baghdadi Is Dead, Trump Says
abstract: President Trump said in a nationally televised address that American forces targeted Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of the Islamic State, in an operation in Syria this weekend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced on Sunday that a daring American commando raid in Syria this weekend culminated in the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, after a five-year international manhunt, claiming a significant victory even as American forces are pulling out of the area.

headline: Shooting in Texas Leaves 2 Dead and at Least 14 Wounded, Officials Say
abstract: One day after a gunman opened fire on a homecoming party attended by hundreds near Greenville, Tex., a suspect was arrested.
lead_paragraph: Two people were fatally shot and at least 14 others were injured when a gunman opened fire at a crowded homecoming party in Greenville, Tex., early Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley,’ Darker Than Ever, Captures the Bleak Mood of Tech
abstract: In its final season, the HBO satire asks the big questions: Can good coexist with greed? Does money ruin everything — and how much does that matter, if we’re talking billions?
lead_paragraph: When “Silicon Valley” premiered on HBO in 2014, Silicon Valley hadn’t yet ruined the world. Those were the salad days for the titans of tech: Digital billionaires were superheroes feted on magazine covers and in the White House, not super villains hauled before Congress for fixing elections, sowing genocide, undermining truth and monopolizing all the globe’s commerce.

headline: Canned Elegance
abstract: Tejal Rao has a supermarket-elegant recipe for cannellini-bean beurre blanc that manages to be basic and deluxe all at once.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I write from Martha’s Vineyard, in Massachusetts, where I’m with my colleague Carolyn Ryan to visit with colleagues at the Vineyard Gazette and address friends new and old at the Martha’s Vineyard Wine and Food Festival. (Missed the Derby, sadly, but was excited to learn they’re moving toward catch-and-release competition.) It’s beautiful here, typing with a dog at my feet.

headline: Half a Million May Lose Power in Another Round of California Blackouts
abstract: Driven by gusty winds, the Kincade fire north of San Francisco was still growing on Sunday. PG&E officials said some customers may not have their power restored before more intentional blackouts on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 29: Read the latest on the California fires, and sign up here for our California Today newsletter.

headline: If You’ve Ever Dreaded a Play Date Invitation
abstract: This NYT Parenting roundup is for you.
lead_paragraph: About half of parents have turned down a play date because they didn’t feel comfortable leaving their child with other parents, according to a poll published this week. Our reporter, Christina Caron, looked into why there’s so much play date anxiety and how to manage it. Also new to NYT Parenting, Natasha K. Sriraman M.D., an associate professor of pediatrics at Eastern Virginia Medical School, explored why so many breastfeeding mothers with perinatal mood disorders still go untreated, Carla Bruce-Eddings wrote about her daughter’s finger-sucking habit and you gave us excellent tips for maintaining a relationship after kids.

headline: Rugby World Cup: South Africa Edges Wales to Reach Final
abstract: With a 19-16 semifinal victory, the Springboks will get a chance at their third title. England stands in their way.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — South Africa will seek its third Rugby World Cup title after defeating Wales, 19-16, in the semifinals on Sunday.

headline: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, ISIS Leader Known for His Brutality, Is Dead at 48
abstract: President Trump announced the death of al-Baghdadi, who transformed the Islamic State into a global terrorist network that conquered territory the size of Britain and directed horrific attacks in the West.
lead_paragraph: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the cunning and enigmatic black-clad leader of the Islamic State who transformed a flagging insurgency into a global terrorist network that drew tens of thousands of recruits from 100 countries, has died at 48.

headline: Rebuilding America’s Infrastructure
abstract: A reader says the wealthy and corporations should be taxed more heavily to help pay for updating the country’s highways, airports and so on. Also: On hiring more women and minorities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Transcript of Trump’s Remarks on the Death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi
abstract: “He died like a dog. He died like a coward. The world is now a much safer place,” the president said.
lead_paragraph: This is a transcript of the statement by President Trump about the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi:

headline: New Mexico’s Oil Boom: Bounty for One of the Country’s Poorest States
abstract: A frenetic oil boom is revealing a sharp divide between the region producing the oil and those deciding how to spend the wealth.
lead_paragraph: LOCO HILLS, N.M. — At the diner she manages in the heart of New Mexico’s oil country, Joni Moorhead talks to roughnecks all day long about potholed roads, cramped lodging camps, soaring rents — and state politics.

headline: Review: Zeffirelli’s ‘La Bohème’ Returns, Brighter and Better
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera restages the director’s 1981 production with a winning cast and no scrim to impede the singers.
lead_paragraph: As general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb has steadily been replacing productions by Franco Zeffirelli, the unabashed emperor of extravagance, with new ones he deems more contemporary and effective.

headline: Trump’s Syria Troop Withdrawal Complicated Plans for al-Baghdadi Raid
abstract: President Trump’s abrupt decision to pull forces from northern Syria forced the Pentagon to press ahead with a risky night operation that killed the ISIS leader, military officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump knew the Central Intelligence Agency and Special Operations commandos were zeroing in on the location for Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, when he ordered American troops to withdraw from northern Syria earlier this month, intelligence, military and counterterrorism officials said on Sunday.

headline: Sacrificing Profits for the Public Good
abstract: Two readers discuss an Op-Ed calling on America’s business leaders to rethink capitalism and focus more on social purposes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: As Pete Buttigieg Courts Black Voters, His Sexuality Is a Hurdle for Some
abstract: A Buttigieg campaign memo that surfaced last week suggested “being gay was a barrier” to support from some black voters in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — Addressing a conference of African-American church congregations in this vote-rich city, Pete Buttigieg quoted scripture on Sunday morning and extolled his “Douglass Plan” to combat racial inequities in America, one of several attempts this weekend to confront his strikingly low support among black voters.

headline: How U.S. Forces Bombed ISIS Leader’s Compound
abstract: This video shows the bombing attack on the compound where Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of the Islamic State, died in northwestern Syria.
lead_paragraph: This video shows the bombing attack on the compound where Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of the Islamic State, died in northwestern Syria.

headline: The California Wildfires in Pictures
abstract: New York Times photographers are on the ground documenting the destruction and the fight to contain the fires.
lead_paragraph: A series of wildfires have torn across California over the last week, destroying hundreds of homes and forcing nearly 200,000 residents to evacuate. Millions were without power for several days.

headline: When Poor People Are Beaten for Seeking Help
abstract: An investigation reveals a troubling pattern of abuse against one of New York’s most vulnerable populations.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Purnell struggled for breath in the doorway of a city welfare office on West 14th Street, begging for help as officers kicked him and beat him with batons. His oxygen tank lay just out of reach.

headline: Cimabue Painting Discovered in French Kitchen Fetches Nearly $27 Million
abstract: “The Mocking of Christ” is the first work believed to have been painted by Cimabue to sell at auction in living memory.
lead_paragraph: SENLIS, France — A medieval painting that hung for years near the kitchen of an older Frenchwoman before being recognized as a work by the Italian artist Cimabue was auctioned on Sunday in France for $26.8 million.

headline: Kanye West, Heretic by Nature, Finds God
abstract: On “Jesus Is King,” his ninth album, the rapper turns to gospel music, suggesting a shift in his public image that’s actually not much of a change at all.
lead_paragraph: It may appear disorienting that Kanye West, at age 42, has made a hard turn toward worship music. But West has always been making worship music, both in his literal embrace of religious themes and iconography, and also in his belief that songs should be a vehicle for moral tugs of war, philosophical reckoning and ecstatic praise. The only thing that has changed is the packaging.

headline: ‘Joker’ and ‘Maleficent’ Tussle for Box Office Lead
abstract: Studio estimates show “Joker” with a slight edge over “Maleficent” in ticket sales this weekend, but the race is too close to call for now.
lead_paragraph: A pair of holdovers had a photo finish this weekend, as “Joker” and “Maleficent: Mistress of Evil” jockeyed for first place at the box office.

headline: Steal This Archive? Abbie Hoffman’s Papers Become a College Collection
abstract: Thousands of letters and other artifacts from the life of the radical prankster of the counterculture are sold to the University of Texas at Austin.
lead_paragraph: There are notes and letters from other icons of the 1960s. Cards from John and Yoko. A letter from Allen Ginsberg, the poet, offering to help him raise defense money. A plea by Norman Mailer to the governor of New York, seeking executive leniency on his behalf.

headline: Al-Baghdadi Is Dead. The Story Doesn’t End Here.
abstract: President Trump boasts of defeating the Islamic State. He’s only showing how ignorant he is.
lead_paragraph: The killing of the founder and leader of the Islamic State by United States commandos operating in Syria should certainly further weaken the most vile and deadly Islamist movement to emerge in the Middle East in the modern era.

headline: Yet Another Unsolved Murder Stirs Corsica Against Its ‘Mafia’
abstract: On a Mediterranean island of jagged beauty, obscure criminal gangs are blamed for everything from overdevelopment to the drug trade. But those who speak out place themselves at risk.
lead_paragraph: CARGÈSE, Corsica — Calmly, the dead man’s father recounted his son’s killing: The assassin with the telescopic sight hid in those scrubby bushes over there, his son opened the kitchen doors to his restaurant here, the fatal bullet struck right here, and Massimu Susini fell on the beach there, 30 feet away, after a last desperate lunge.

headline: With al-Baghdadi Raid, Trump Makes the Made-for-TV Announcement He Has Long Wanted
abstract: Aides convinced President Trump that waiting until Sunday morning to announce Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi’s death would dominate the talk shows.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the moment President Trump learned that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, had been killed in a commando raid in Syria, he handled the news in an unusual way.

headline: How Commandos Could Quickly Confirm They Got Their Target
abstract: American officials identified the body of the Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi swiftly, even after he blew himself up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump announced on Sunday morning that a Special Operations forces raid had resulted in the death of the Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, he said two things that might have sounded contradictory.

headline: See Where the Raid on al-Baghdadi Took Place in Syria
abstract: The compound where the Islamic State leader was said to have died was far from the terrorist group’s former stronghold.
lead_paragraph: The compound where the Islamic State leader was said to have died was far from the terrorist group’s former stronghold.

headline: John Conyers Jr., Longest-Serving African-American in Congressional History, Dies at 90
abstract: One of the most liberal members of Congress, he resigned after two women accused him of making unwelcome sexual advances.

headline: Alex Bregman’s Hitting Returns for Astros, Along With His Swagger
abstract: Feeling slighted after the Nationals walked a batter to load the bases for him in Game 3 of the World Series, he savored his payback, a grand slam, in Game 4.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 40 minutes after Game 4 of the World Series, Alex Bregman was still in his dirty uniform, his jersey untucked as he strolled through the tunnels of Nationals Park, dissecting his breakout performance.

headline: How the Astros Won Game 5 of the World Series
abstract: Joe Ross pitched decently for Washington in place of the injured Max Scherzer, but the Astros’ Gerrit Cole dominated the Nationals’ hitters all night to tilt the series in Houston’s favor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Washington Nationals returned home last week after winning two straight games in Houston, riding a wave of optimism that they might be the ones to bring their city its first World Series win on home soil in 86 years.

headline: Corrections: October 27, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, October 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS & LEISURE

headline: In Argentina Election, Leftists Savor Victory Over Incumbent
abstract: President Mauricio Macri was defeated by a ticket that included former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner in the No. 2 spot.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentines on Sunday entrusted leftists to steer the nation as it reels from a deep recession, electing as president Alberto Fernández, a longtime political operative who toiled behind the scenes most of his career.

headline: Leader’s Death Will Damage ISIS, but Not Destroy It
abstract: Before the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State had decentralized, allowing followers and franchises to carry out its violent ideology on their own.
lead_paragraph: He had been hunted for more than a decade, and the organization he had built was designed partly on the assumption this day would come.

headline: Election in Germany Helps Far Right Tighten Its Grip in the East
abstract: The Alternative for Germany party doubled its share of the vote in Thuringia, where it is led by the party’s most notorious ideologue.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The far-right Alternative for Germany party on Sunday celebrated a strong showing in the former Communist East, more than doubling its support in a state election held two weeks after an attack on a synagogue that some tied to the party’s use of hateful language.

headline: ‘Macbeth’ Review: A Decent Man Turns Murderous Tyrant
abstract: A bracingly lucid Corey Stoll embodies Shakespeare’s thane who, step by step, cedes his soul to his own darkest impulses.
lead_paragraph: What a team player Macbeth is at the start. On the battlefield, he’s a brutal warrior, sure; that’s his job. But off it? He’s a sweetheart. Decent, funny, humble, this guy is a straight arrow, beloved of his king and colleagues.

headline: Trump Says ‘Beautiful’ and ‘Talented’ Dog Injured in al-Baghdadi Raid
abstract: The president said the dog was chasing Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in a darkened tunnel and was hurt when a suicide vest was detonated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last moments of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi’s life were spent being chased down a dark underground tunnel by military dogs. The dogs that sprinted after him, President Trump said about the Islamic State leader’s death on Sunday, were only deterred by a suicide bomb that detonated inside Mr. al-Baghdadi’s vest, killing him and several children.

headline: Sheer Delight
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel offers us a nice Monday mix-up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, all! This is the associate puzzles editor Sam Ezersky here filling in, as Our Beloved Wordplay Columnist Deb Amlen has disappeared for the day. You may have seen my name float around Wordplay from time to time, though perhaps you know me best for the crossword puzzles I create or the Spelling Bee and Letter Boxed games I edit.

headline: Tiffany Shares Surge on LVMH Takeover Bid
abstract: The French luxury conglomerate is interested in adding the 182-year-old luxury jeweler to its stable of brands.
lead_paragraph: LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton is already one of the world’s biggest luxury goods empires. Now it is interested in adding yet another high-end name to its coterie of brands: Tiffany, the famous seller of engagement rings and other jewelry.

headline: Philadelphia Police Inspector Charged in Sexual Assaults of Officers
abstract: At least three women filed complaints against Chief Inspector Carl Holmes, who has been suspended.
lead_paragraph: A senior Philadelphia police official has been charged with assault and suspended after three female officers accused him of forcing himself on them, according to prosecutors.

headline: Wegmans Opens in Brooklyn; Fans Wait in the Rain, and Rejoice
abstract: The beloved suburban grocer, which has attracted a cult following, opened its first New York City store at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: When Alexis Grafakos moved to a small town in western New York in 2013, she couldn’t find empanada dough anywhere.

headline: Period-Tracking Apps Say You May Have a Disorder. What if They’re Wrong?
abstract: Apps like Flo and Clue are shifting from just tracking your health data to using it to make evaluations about your health risks. Their tools may not always be accurate.
lead_paragraph: Flo and Clue, two popular period-tracking apps, recently introduced health tools that evaluate a woman’s risk for the hormonal imbalance known as polycystic ovary syndrome.

headline: With Whipping Winds and Power Down, Californians Flee Fires
abstract: Power outages and fires combined over the weekend to push the state’s disaster response capabilities to the brink.
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 28: Read the latest on the fires, and sign up here for our California Today newsletter.

headline: Review: Crystal Pite’s Disjointed ‘Body and Soul’ in Paris
abstract: Audiences seem to love this uneven piece, which can be lyrical in places and bemusing in others.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Body and Soul,” Crystal Pite’s new full-length work for the Paris Opera Ballet, opens in sepulchral gloom, with two Beckettian figures obeying instructions (“right, left, right, left”) from a disembodied voice. It ends with 40 black-latex-clad and masked dancers with insectlike prosthetic arms and protuberances, performing synchronized marches to a hard-driving rock song by Teddy Geiger, while a hairy-headed creature in gold sequined trousers gyrates wildly in the middle.

headline: Likely Successor to Dead ISIS Leader Also Reported Killed
abstract: Abu Hassan al-Muhajir, spokesman of the Islamic State, is believed to have been killed a day after the American raid that left the group’s leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi dead.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A day after an American raid killed Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, a separate attack killed the man who was considered his likely successor, according to the leader of a Syrian Kurdish  militia and a Syrian activist.

headline: A Way Out for the Supreme Court on DACA
abstract: A narrow ruling would put the ball back in the president’s court and let the justices avoid politics.
lead_paragraph: In two weeks, the Supreme Court will consider President Trump’s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals policy, better known as DACA. Many expect a sharply divided decision in the spring, just as the presidential campaign picks up steam. But a different path would better serve both the court and the country.

headline: The Most Pressing Issue for Our Next President Isn’t Medicare
abstract: The 2020 campaign is obsessed with the wrong issue.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Clinton became president, his top legislative priority was health care. When Barack Obama became president, he first had to prevent a depression, but then he too turned to health care.

headline: On ‘60 Minutes,’ Biden Questions Trump’s Legacy While Emphasizing His Own
abstract: In first major network sit-down since President Trump’s attacks on his family, Joe Biden called himself the Democratic front-runner and expressed fear that the Trump administration would cause lasting damage.
lead_paragraph: In a wide-ranging “60 Minutes” interview that aired Sunday, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared himself the Democratic front-runner, defended his son’s foreign business dealings and explained why it was critical for the country’s future to defeat President Trump in 2020.

headline: Watching the Raid Was Like a Movie, the President Said. Except There Was No Live Audio.
abstract: Surveillance video provided a dramatic portrait of action outside the al-Baghdadi compound, but could not show what happened in an underground tunnel where the ISIS leader died. For that, Mr. Trump would have to hear from Delta Force, or their commanders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In describing the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi on Sunday, President Trump used dramatic, even cinematic language to portray the daring American commando raid that brought down the Islamic State leader who, the president said, died “screaming, crying and whimpering.”

headline: Max Scherzer’s Neck Pain Gives Nationals’ Joe Ross a Surprise Start
abstract: Scherzer, one of the most durable pitchers in baseball, woke up with extreme discomfort on Sunday, forcing the Nationals to use Ross as their starter in his stead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This has been a decade of extraordinary achievement for Max Scherzer of the Washington Nationals: He has more wins and strikeouts in the 2010s than any other pitcher in the majors, and three Cy Young Awards. His final start before the 2020s was supposed to be on Sunday, in Game 5 of the World Series against the Houston Astros. But his neck would not allow it.

headline: How Early-Career Setbacks Can Set You Up for Success
abstract: Failure is just part of the process.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Pittsburgh Marks a Massacre’s Anniversary With Prayers and Projects
abstract: One year after an anti-Semitic gunman killed 11 people at the Tree of Life synagogue, the city’s Jews and their neighbors commemorated the day with service and calls for change.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — It was a scene that would have infuriated the man who set off a whole year of pain and sorrow. Men and women, Jewish, Muslim, Christian, crowded elbow to elbow around tables at the Jewish Family and Community Services building, making blankets for refugees and packing bags of crayons and coloring books for the young and undocumented.

headline: Moving Closer to Trump, Impeachment Inquiry Faces Critical Test
abstract: Investigators have been building their case rapidly. But the closer they get to the president, the more complicated their work will become.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House impeachment investigators are speeding toward new White House barriers meant to block crucial testimony and evidence from the people who are closest to President Trump — obstacles that could soon test the limits of Democrats’ fact finding a month into their inquiry.

headline: Katie Hill Will Resign From Congress Amid Ethics Investigation
abstract: The Democrat from California, who was accused of violating House rules by having a sexual relationship with a member of her congressional staff, apologized to “the people who have been hurt.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Katie Hill, Democrat of California, said on Sunday that she would resign after less than 10 months in office as she faced a House ethics investigation into allegations that she had a sexual relationship with a member of her congressional staff, a violation of House rules.

headline: Al-Baghdadi Raid Was a Victory Built on Factors Trump Derides
abstract: The president cast the death of the ISIS leader as validation of his disengagement strategy. But it required intelligence agencies and allies he has spurned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The death of the Islamic State’s leader in a daring nighttime raid vindicated the value of three traditional American strengths: robust alliances, faith in intelligence agencies and the projection of military power around the world.

headline: Trump’s Black College Spectacle
abstract: He was honored on the issue of criminal justice, where his record is shameful.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump at Benedict College was beneath contempt.

headline: Tiger Woods Ties Sam Snead’s Career Wins Record in Japan
abstract: Woods got his 82nd PGA Tour  victory at the Zozo Championship.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods was 6 years old the first time he crossed paths with Sam Snead, who played a two-hole exhibition in Southern California with Woods and said afterward, “If the kid doesn’t burn out, he’ll be the greatest golfer the world has ever seen.”

headline: Disney Is New to Streaming, but Its Marketing Is Unmatched
abstract: The company’s synergistic approach — think trailers playing on TVs in 22,000 Disney World hotel rooms — has made Disney Plus known to millions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tom Bergeron, the host of the ABC reality show “Dancing With the Stars,” looked into the camera at the start of a recent Disney-themed episode and made a forceful sales pitch. Disney Plus, a new streaming service, was arriving on Nov. 12, he told the seven million people watching at home. With his voice rising, he added, “It’s available for you to pre-enroll right now!”

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 28, 2019.

headline: Review: In Zawe Ashton’s ‘for all the women,’ the Price of Uprooting a Life
abstract: This convoluted play chronicles the breakdown of a conflicted, displaced East African woman in the cosmopolitan West.
lead_paragraph: It’s raining metaphors in “for all the women who thought they were Mad,” Zawe Ashton’s densely poetic play about racial alienation in the big city. As to whether it’s actually raining — or burning hot, with a sun that sears the skin — is a moot point in this production, which opened on Sunday at Soho Rep.

headline: ‘Watchmen’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: American Hero Story
abstract: Among the show’s accumulating mysteries, this episode adds another: Who was Judd Crawford?
lead_paragraph: Toward the back half of this week’s episode, “Watchmen” finally offers a glimpse of its show-within-a-show, “American Hero Story: Minutemen,” which doubles as a backdoor adaptation of the graphic novel that creator Damon Lindelof is writing around (or “remixing,” as he has put it). What stands out first is the hyper-reality of the sequence, a notch or two more comic book-like than the “Watchmen” series itself — an effect that Lindelof, his co-writer Nick Cuse and the director Nicole Kassell imply is what happens when history gets transformed into art. Everything is more vivid and intense.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 10 Recap: Movement Is Life
abstract: Sometimes it takes a crisis — or multiple crises — to put things in their proper perspective.
lead_paragraph: Just before he flees for his life, Noah Solloway adopts a mantra. What better time is there to adopt a mantra, anyway?

headline: The World Is Fighting More Than ISIS
abstract: Al-Baghdadi’s death is profoundly important. But the jihadi movement will continue without him.
lead_paragraph: The death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, is profoundly important. He was a powerfully inspirational figure, more formidable and perhaps more evil than Osama bin Laden.

headline: One Week Before Breeders’ Cup, Another Horse Dies at Santa Anita
abstract: The track’s death toll since December rises to 36.
lead_paragraph: As the Breeders’ Cup World Championships approaches next weekend, another horse died at Santa Anita Park — the event’s host — on Sunday, bringing the track’s death toll to 36 and renewing anxiety over whether the landmark California racetrack is safe enough to welcome the world’s best racehorses and host North America’s richest days of racing.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 4, Episode 4 Recap: Into the Woods
abstract: Dom’s most lurid dreams aren’t much stranger than her and Elliot’s reality.
lead_paragraph: Agent Dom DiPierro is having a nightmare before Christmas.

headline: For Trump, No Joy in Mudville
abstract: In his first appearance at a Major League Baseball game since taking office, the president was booed at Game 5 of the World Series at Washington’s Nationals Park.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He started the day with cheers and ended it with jeers. Hours after announcing the death of one of the world’s most notorious terrorists, President Trump found little love at the World Series.

headline: The Advertising Industry Has a Problem: People Hate Ads
abstract: Ad-blocking consumers and cost-cutting clients make for “dangerous days for advertisers,” according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: In the predigital days, advertising agencies were ruled by swaggering creative directors who gorged on lavish client contracts and sometimes created campaigns that set the cultural agenda and captivated the public.

headline: Aramco’s I.P.O. Will Be Less Gigantic Than Promised
abstract: The state-owned oil giant is expected to announce soon that it plans to go public. But the stock sale will fall short of Saudi Arabia’s ambitions.
lead_paragraph: When Mohammed bin Salman announced in 2016 that he would list one of his country’s crown jewels — the state-owned oil giant Saudi Aramco — on the stock market, he set some audacious goals.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Deuce’ Series Finale and an Early Hitchcock
abstract: David Simon and George Pelecanos’s series about the pornography industry wraps up after three seasons. And an early Hitchcock streams on Criterion.
lead_paragraph: THE DEUCE 9 p.m. on HBO; Stream on HBO platforms. David Simon’s breakout show “The Wire” articulated how the lives of ordinary people are shaped by the institutions they find themselves caught up in. “The Deuce,” which Simon created with George Pelecanos, has a similar theme. For three seasons the series has shown how changes in the pornography industry in the United States affected the people involved in it. The show’s final season, which concludes Monday, jumped  to the mid-1980s, when VHS technology made it possible for people to watch erotic films easily at home. Some of the show’s characters, like Candy (Maggie Gyllenhaal), who went from prostitute to pornographic film director, seem to have prospered amid these changes, while others, like Frankie (James Franco),  have clearly suffered. But for the most part the message is clear: Everyone is trying to get by in a world controlled by forces stronger than any individual.

headline: Word + Quiz: ignominy
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: WeWork Falls Furthest in a Year of Clipped Wings for Hot Startups
abstract: Across Wall Street and in Silicon Valley, a reckoning is battering the companies that everyone was once so eager to buy.
lead_paragraph: WeWork, Lyft, Uber, Peloton: To their early backers, these are companies that would transform the way the world works, works out or gets around.

headline: Ranked Choice: What if New Yorkers Pick Their Top 5 Candidates?
abstract: New Yorkers may soon have a way to vote for more than one choice.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Read the election results from New York and New Jersey.]

headline: A New $6 Billion Subway? Great, as Long as Rents Don’t Rise
abstract: East Harlem residents welcome a plan to extend the Second Avenue Subway, but they’re worried it might change the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Maribel Burgos barely has time to change into her uniform before she has to clock in at the McDonald’s in Lower Manhattan where she works, even though she gives herself 90 minutes to commute from her home in East Harlem.

headline: Dave Chappelle, Subversive and Charming, Wins Mark Twain Prize for Comedy
abstract: The awards show, which gives out what is considered to be the top prize in comedy, testified to how far-reaching Mr. Chappelle’s influence has been by drawing a range of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dave Chappelle, in the words of Jon Stewart, a former Comedy Central colleague, is the “black Bourdain.”

headline: As China’s Troubles Simmer, Xi Reinforces His Political Firewall
abstract: With China mired in a trade war, economic slowdown and Hong Kong unrest, Xi Jinping will use an elite meeting to focus more on increasing his control over the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Slowing economic growth. A rancorous trade war. Recalcitrant protesters in Hong Kong. A mass die-off of pigs and surging food prices. The frustrations are piling up for China’s leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: On These Astros, Who Isn’t the M.V.P.?
abstract: Bottomless depth has lifted Houston to three straight road victories and put it on the cusp of its second World Series title.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five different teams have won the World Series in the last five seasons. Four of them — the Giants, the Royals, the Cubs and the Red Sox — missed the playoffs this year. Each team was felled by a different malady: a weak farm system in San Francisco, an exodus of stars in Kansas City, a stale core in Chicago and a glut of injured pitchers in Boston.

headline: How Thom Yorke Learned to Stop Worrying and (Mostly) Love Rock Stardom
abstract: “It has been good for me getting out of the bubble and understanding how, for some people, the work that I’ve done is important.”
lead_paragraph: “It has been good for me getting out of the bubble and understanding how, for some people, the work that I’ve done is important.”

headline: Should Your School Day Start Later?
abstract: If it did, would students get more sleep? Or would they just stay up later?
lead_paragraph: Do you get enough sleep during the school year? If not, what keeps you from being well rested?

headline: The Joy of Kooky
abstract: My long and guilty love affair with an astrology book.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, Joost Elffers, a successful Dutch book packager, met an American expatriate living in Amsterdam named Gary Goldschneider.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Days Defending Big Corporations
abstract: As Ms. Warren ascends toward the head of the Democratic presidential pack, her critics have seized upon her bankruptcy work for big corporations to question her progressive bona fides.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren had never taken on the federal government before.

headline: Fiber in Fruits and Grains Protects Against Diverticulitis
abstract: Our diets are overly refined. Eating more whole fruits, especially apples, pears and prunes, can help our digestive health.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, Michael Valenti of Woodstock, N.Y., suddenly developed severe pain in the lower right side of his abdomen. He had a slight fever and thought he had appendicitis. So did his doctor, who sent him to the emergency room, where an M.R.I. revealed not appendicitis but diverticulitis, an infection in an outpouching of his colon he never knew he had.

headline: It’s Halloween. Beware Urban Legends (and Cars).
abstract: It’s the risks to costumed little pedestrians that should worry parents, not tainted candy or razor blades in apples.
lead_paragraph: American children are more likely to be hit by cars on Halloween than on any other night of the year.

headline: How Modernity Came to Europe
abstract: Orlando Figes’s “The Europeans” focuses on three people to recount the enormous changes in European society and culture during the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: THE EUROPEANSThree Lives and the Making of a Cosmopolitan CultureBy Orlando Figes

headline: ‘Retaliation, a Culture of Fear’: Councilman Is Suspended for 30 Days
abstract: Andy King, a Democrat, also used city funds for a retreat in the Virgin Islands just as his wife’s daughter was getting married there.
lead_paragraph: Just what do you have to do to get kicked off the City Council?

headline: Jason Reynolds Is on a Mission
abstract: The best-selling writer of more than a dozen children’s books wants black teenagers and kids to know that he sees them.
lead_paragraph: When the writer Jason Reynolds speaks to young people, he rarely starts by talking about books.

headline: A Clinton Hill Apartment With a Party Attached
abstract: A two-bedroom gets handed down to friends, along with the annual party that celebrates the New York City Marathon and its runners.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton Hill apartment that Patrick Sandefur shares with his wife, Sarah Grace Holcomb, has a history tightly entwined with the New York City Marathon and those who lived there before them.

headline: Leaving Prison at 72
abstract: For nearly two decades, Geneva Cooley assumed she would die in prison for nonviolent drug crimes. Then a judge reduced her sentence and changed her fate.
lead_paragraph: WETUMPKA, Ala. — In the pink-walled dormitory of the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women, nearly all of the inmates had risen before dawn. Some sat on one another’s beds, applying makeup and sipping instant coffee. Geneva Cooley sat alone, having just put on her white uniform for the last time.

headline: The Wreaths for the Marathon Winners Come From My Grandmother’s Backyard
abstract: And it has been this way for almost 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Jane Muhrcke tends to walk slowly and carefully these days. Wearing a hard-plastic medical boot on one foot, she has a common injury for runners, a stress fracture on her second metatarsal. But she has never run a mile.

headline: Michael Stipe on Working While He Sleeps and Savoring Mistakes
abstract: The artist and musician discusses his new photography book, “Our Interference Times,” and his unusual daily routine.
lead_paragraph: On the way to get a coffee around the corner from his studio in Lower Manhattan, Michael Stipe catches sight of a piece of paper among the contents of a split-open garbage bag: a child’s school assignment, the large and loping letters suggest. He picks it up. On the way back, the musician and artist pauses again — this time to investigate an unusual fruiting plant growing out of the sidewalk. “My boyfriend tells me I have no hierarchy of image,” Stipe says, back in the studio, referring to his partner, the photographer Thomas Dozol. “I’ll see something and think of it as insanely beautiful, and it might be not at all something that would attract a regular thinking person. And I’ll put it next to something from Versailles — to me, they make sense together.”

headline: Savoring the Taste of Memories in Northern India
abstract: An Indian-born chef explores the foods and culture of Himachal Pradesh, where Punjabi and Tibetan flavors meet.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child in India, we were the first family on our street to get a television: a huge black and white affair. Occasionally, we’d have neighbors and friends round to watch Bollywood movies filmed in Shimla, the Himalayan city that was once the summer capital of India. With its stunning colonial architecture, snow-capped mountains and rolling green meadows, it looked like paradise.

headline: He Killed Their Son, but They Want to Stop His Execution
abstract: A Texas prosecutor told a jury that the victim’s parents wanted their son’s killer to be put to death. The parents say that was false.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after the 10th anniversary of the 2006 murder of Jonas Cherry, his parents made a video. They wanted to stop the execution of the man who killed their son.

headline: 40 Days, Thousands of Jobs: The G.M. Strike From the Picket Lines
abstract: Our photographer spent the last month with autoworkers in Flint, Mich., who went on strike for better wages and job security. Here’s what she saw.
lead_paragraph: When it began, people rallied in parking lots, their fists thrust in the air.

headline: Children of Poor Immigrants Rise, Regardless of Where They Come From
abstract: A pattern that has persisted for a century: They tend to outperform children of similarly poor native-born Americans.
lead_paragraph: Immigration to the United States has consistently offered a route to escape poverty — if not for poor immigrants themselves, then for their sons.

headline: Chinese Investment Pits Wall Street Against Washington
abstract: Lawmakers and Trump officials want to stop federal employee retirement funds from flowing to Chinese companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rivalry between the United States and China has spread to a fight over financial ties between the countries, pitting Washington security hawks against Wall Street investors.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million in California
abstract: A house on the coast in Big Sur; an 1876 Greek Revival in Santa Rosa; and a showplace for art in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: A house on the coast in Big Sur; an 1876 Greek Revival in Santa Rosa; and a showplace for art in Sacramento.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A house on the coast in Big Sur, an 1876 Greek Revival in Santa Rosa and a showplace for art in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: Robert Carver, an architect based in Carmel who works extensively on the Monterey Peninsula and in the San Francisco Bay Area, designed this property as a retreat with broad ocean and mountain views. It is in the Coastlands area, less than five minutes from the Post Ranch Inn resort and its Sierra Mar restaurant, and about 10 minutes from Pfeiffer Beach. San Francisco is about three hours up the coast.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Peru?
abstract: Can you find Peru on a map? What else do you know about this South American nation with about 32.5 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Peru on a map? What else do you know about this South American nation with about 32.5 million people?

headline: How Your Amazon Delivery Helps to Clog the Streets
abstract: Monday: Box-crowded sidewalks, traffic congestion and mushrooming warehouses are symptoms of New Yorkers' growing addiction to deliveries.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: What We Learned in N.F.L. Week 8
abstract: With convincing victories all around, the 49ers, the Patriots and the Saints made it clear they are the N.F.L.’s best teams.
lead_paragraph: It was a week of confirming things we mostly knew. The San Francisco 49ers and the New England Patriots dominated the competition — and stayed undefeated — and the red-hot New Orleans Saints, as expected, got even better with the return of quarterback Drew Brees. Week 8 also saw Adam Vinatieri rise to the occasion and Eddy Pineiro fail to do the same.

headline: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, California, Katie Hill: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Daring Helicopter Rescue After Rebels Capture a Ferry in Myanmar
abstract: The scale of the abduction suggests that the rebel group, the Arakan Army, is using increasingly brazen tactics to demand an independent state.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — When the ferry pushed off from a dilapidated pier in western Myanmar, few of the passengers could have predicted how dangerous the journey would turn out.

headline: Johnson Loses First Attempt to Call Election in Latest Brexit Maneuver
abstract: After the European Union extended the deadline for Britain’s departure to Jan. 31, Prime Minister Boris Johnson lost another vote in Parliament.

headline: The Promise and Peril of Vaping, Part 1: A Mystery in Nebraska
abstract: How one man’s death is changing our understanding of vaping and its consequences.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: The Way We Measure the Economy Obscures What Is Really Going On
abstract: By looking mainly at the big picture, we are missing the reality of inequality — and a chance to level the playing field.
lead_paragraph: Every quarter, we look to the federal Bureau of Economic Analysis for new data on the total income and output of the economy. The nation’s topline indicator of economic performance is gross domestic product — the sum total of all that’s produced in our economy. If you pay attention to that indicator only, it would certainly seem like we’re now in the best of times: Gross domestic product has grown for 124 straight months, and we are now officially in the longest economic expansion in recorded American history.

headline: Tennessee’s Dangerous Waters
abstract: The Tennessee River is one of the most ecologically diverse rivers in the world. It is also one of the most polluted.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — From a distance, a river looks less like a feature of the terrain than like a massive, mysterious animal. A river is a sleek, writhing being, and even the verbs we use to describe it evoke animation. A river runs through it. A river climbs its banks. A river empties itself into the sea.

headline: How Trump Is Helping Russia Help Trump Again
abstract: The efforts by presidential associates like Rudy Giuliani in Ukraine are helping set up a 2020 disinformation campaign.
lead_paragraph: Washington is consumed by the impeachment inquiry that has followed the release of the whistle-blower complaint in late September alleging that Trump administration officials and associates sought to coerce Ukraine into politically motivated investigations. Meanwhile, in a parallel effort that appears designed to undermine the integrity of the Mueller report, Attorney General Bill Barr recently traveled to Italy (at least twice) and Britain to gather information as part of his review of the origins of the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

headline: Early to Bed, Early to Rise Makes Me Exhausted, Depressed and Sick
abstract: What it’s like living with a chronic circadian rhythm problem.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It’s hard to feel normal when you wake up at 4 p.m. every day.

headline: The Luxury Battle Brewing Over Tiffany
abstract: LVMH of France has offered to buy Tiffany, the famous jewelry seller, for $14.4 billion. But will that be enough?
lead_paragraph: Good Monday. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers including Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, Dennis Muilenberg of Boeing and Makan Delrahim, the Justice Department’s antitrust chief. Apply to attend here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Syria Peace Talks to Open After a Long, Strange Month
abstract: A United States pullout, a Turkish invasion and a newly strengthened Syrian leader have reshaped the board for negotiations in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The first United Nations mediator who tried to broker peace in Syria declared it “mission impossible” and abandoned the effort. That was seven years and hundreds of thousands of deaths ago.

headline: Charlottesville Lawsuit Puts Rising Intolerance on Trial
abstract: The lawsuit against the organizers of the notorious 2017 white power march in Charlottesville, Va., rests on chat room conversations and a 19th-century civil rights law.
lead_paragraph: The most sweeping lawsuit against the promoters of the Charlottesville white power rally has been churning toward trial for two years, ever since hundreds of white supremacists and Nazis staged a torch-lit march that set off a weekend of violence.

headline: AT&T C.E.O. to Stay Another Year After Challenge From Activist Fund
abstract: Randall Stephenson, the chief executive, will remain in place for another year as the company sets out a three-year business plan to increase revenue and profit.
lead_paragraph: AT&T has joined the fight in the streaming wars, vying to carve out a digital swath with its planned HBO Max service. At the same time, it has been in an intense skirmish with an activist hedge fund that doubted its move into Hollywood.

headline: Fears of More Extreme Weather as Kincade Fire Swells
abstract: Up and down the state, wildfires are driving residents from their homes. The fire threatens 90,000 buildings across an expanding evacuation zone.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here for our California Today newsletter.

headline: What Survivors of ISIS Carnage Say About al-Baghdadi’s Death
abstract: Those who lived under the Islamic State greeted the news about the group’s leader with grim satisfaction at best. “He deserves a worse and more abhorrent death,” one said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In the Islamic State strongholds in Syria and Iraq where Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and his allies lived, there was bitterness at the news that the head of the Islamic State had died — not that it had happened, but that it had not happened sooner.

headline: With Mahomes on the Sideline, Chiefs Lose to Aaron Rodgers
abstract: The version of the Chiefs that lost, 31-24, to Green Bay is formidable and yet a modest imitation of what they thought they were.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — So, there was this quarterback playing at Arrowhead Stadium who zipped sidearm passes and evaded defenders and completed throws that peers wouldn’t even consider trying. And it vexed the Kansas City Chiefs.

headline: A Horror Genre Where Dresses (and Fridges) Can Kill
abstract: Movies like “In Fabric” explore the bizarre world in which evil is everywhere, even in tires and cookies.
lead_paragraph: In horror films, it isn’t always a maniac who has a thirst for blood. Sometimes it’s a tomato.

headline: Driver in Case of 39 Bodies in Truck Appears in U.K. Court
abstract: Maurice Robinson was charged with 39 counts of manslaughter, conspiracy to traffic people, conspiracy to assist unlawful immigration and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The driver of a truck in which 39 bodies were found in southeastern England made his first court appearance on Monday to face criminal charges related to the deaths and suspected human trafficking, even as the authorities were working to establish the identities of the victims.

headline: After Foster Care, Dancing Her Way to Independence
abstract: Araya Manning spent four years in New York City’s foster system. Now 24, she is studying social work at Hunter College and has found an outlet in dance.
lead_paragraph: At least three days a week, Araya Manning takes the subway from her apartment on the Upper West Side to a studio in Chelsea, where she loses herself in dance. It could be a dancehall lesson one day, Afrobeats or soca the next.

headline: Medicare Mania
abstract: Enough already.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘I Was a Low-Income College Student. Classes Weren’t the Hard Part.’
abstract: Students learn about the challenges many low-income and first generation college students face, then consider how well learning institutions address their students’ needs beyond academics.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “I Was a Low-Income College Student. Classes Weren’t the Hard Part.”

headline: Why San Jose’s Mayor Wants Customers to Own PG&E
abstract: Monday: ‘Dramatic measures are needed,’ he said. Also: Updates on the Kincade Fire and widespread blackouts.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A National Title Is Hard. Is an SEC Title Harder?
abstract: After beating Auburn, the Tigers took over the top spot in the A.P. Top 25 poll and will next play No. 2 Alabama in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — There was a palpable feeling of anxiety hanging over Tiger Stadium when Louisiana State quarterback Joe Burrow danced away from pressure in the shadow of his own end zone and took off toward the first-down marker on the first play of the second quarter.

headline: World Series Crowd Boos Trump
abstract: President Trump was booed at Game 5 of the World Series in Washington on Sunday. This was his first appearance at a baseball game since taking office.
lead_paragraph: President Trump was booed at Game 5 of the World Series in Washington on Sunday. This was his first appearance at a baseball game since taking office.

headline: LeBron James Evacuates His Family From Fire in Western Los Angeles
abstract: The N.B.A. star said he and his family had to drive around looking for a place to stay after fires prompted mandatory evacuations.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James said Monday that he was one of the tens of thousands of people who were forced to flee their homes in Northern and Southern California in the face of wildfires that have cut power to millions and sent the state into crisis.

headline: You Need These Pancakes
abstract: These Korean pajeon, vegetable pancakes from the chef Sohui Kim, are just the thing to kick off the week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My meat consumption’s dropping, I’ve noticed. Mostly this is because I’ve been serving less of it. Sometimes I don’t serve it at all, which those who know me well regard with some suspicion, even alarm. I’ve generally been the guy who orders a veal Parm to accompany the steak. I think the proper number of sausages to accompany two eggs over easy is three. I like a little nugget of sizzling lamb fat a lot more than I do, say, a radish.

headline: Miranda Lambert Doesn’t Mean to Offend. She’s ‘a Little Too Honest.’
abstract: The country singer and songwriter on her new album, “Wildcard,” scooping the tabloids and her life as a teenage goody-goody.
lead_paragraph: One night not long ago, Miranda Lambert was drinking wine on her porch in Nashville with a friend who’d planned to drive home. Lambert discouraged her from getting behind the wheel: “You’re way too pretty for prison,” she said. The next day, Lambert and three other songwriters turned that phrase into a song.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would take a formal vote on the impeachment investigation later this week.
lead_paragraph: The Times has obtained a copy of the opening statement that Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, the top Ukraine expert on the National Security Council, plans to deliver to House impeachment investigators on Tuesday. Here are four highlights:

headline: How Europeans See America
abstract: We asked young, ordinary Europeans to take a look at U.S. policies on everything from food to guns. As they discover facts about America, they’re not impressed.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s useful to get an outside perspective. In the Video Op-Ed above, Europeans are shocked to learn that the American government does not guarantee social protections that citizens in other advanced economies take for granted.

headline: Sugary Drink Ban Tied to Health Improvements at Medical Center
abstract: Workers at the University of California, San Francisco, lost belly fat and showed metabolic benefits after a ban on sugary drinks went into effect.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, hospitals and medical centers across the country have stopped selling sugar-sweetened beverages in an effort to reduce obesity and diabetes.

headline: What Jim Mattis Really Thought of Donald Trump
abstract: Guy M. Snodgrass details Jim Mattis’s continuing struggles with Donald Trump up to the time of his resignation as secretary of defense.
lead_paragraph: HOLDING THE LINEInside Trump’s Pentagon With Secretary MattisBy Guy M. Snodgrass

headline: How to Really Make the Death of ISIS’s Leader Bigger Than Bin Laden’s
abstract: If the U.S. plays its cards right, it could fundamentally weaken the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump announced the death of the Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi following a raid in northwestern Syria this weekend, he made sure to take the opportunity to one-up his predecessor: Mr. al-Baghdadi’s death, Mr. Trump said, was bigger than Osama bin Laden’s. Mr. al-Baghdadi was “the biggest there is,” the president said, “the worst ever.”

headline: Impeachment Does Not ‘Overturn’ an Election
abstract: The founders were extremely clear about the importance of dealing with the abuse of executive power.
lead_paragraph: As House Democrats ramp up their impeachment investigation into President Trump, an increasingly vocal charge from the president’s supporters (and the White House) is that the House is attempting to “overturn” the results of the 2016 election.

headline: The Brutal Politics of Brazil’s Drug War
abstract: Police violence in Rio de Janeiro’s slums follows a strategy that kills innocent civilians: Fight carnage with carnage, rather than lift people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the first quarter of 2019, the police killed an average of seven people a day in this city, the second most populous in Brazil. That’s the highest number in two decades. Even more atrocious is the fact that state security forces are responsible for 38 percent of the violent deaths in the city.

headline: How a Month of Impeachment Ads Foreshadow the 2020 Ad Wars
abstract: From depictions of a far-left conspiracy to attacks on freshman legislators, the escalating messaging provides a preview of the political advertising to come.
lead_paragraph: Two minutes after Speaker Nancy Pelosi had announced an official impeachment inquiry, the Trump campaign placed a new ad on Facebook, dropping $12,000 on an “Impeachment Poll” for its supporters.

headline: Explosion at Gender Reveal Party Kills Woman, Officials Say
abstract: Family members at the party, where expectant parents were announcing the sex of their baby, inadvertently created a pipe bomb that killed a woman in Iowa, a sheriff said.
lead_paragraph: A woman in Iowa died during a gender reveal announcement on Saturday after flying debris from an explosion from what amounted to a homemade pipe bomb struck her, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Searching for a Rectangular Sun Above the Arctic Circle
abstract: As polar winter sets in during an expedition on a research vessel, a reporter hopes she’ll catch a glimpse of a brilliant mirage.
lead_paragraph: Low on the horizon, the sun casts an eerie light on the icy sea. For several hours, the glow transforms the colorless terrain into shades of pink as the sun does not rise or set, but edges to the side — traveling in a semicircle before slowly sinking one last time.

headline: Meet the Bloodsuckers
abstract: Vampires get all the attention at this time of year, but bloodthirsty leeches, insects and birds are just as compelling — and they’re real.
lead_paragraph: It has been a big year for leeches. A new species was discovered near Washington and announced in August by Anna Phillips, who may have the world’s best job title: curator of parasitic worms at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History.

headline: How to Be a Better Friend
abstract: Friendships are an essential ingredient in a happy life, so it’s time to give them the care and attention they deserve.
lead_paragraph: Friendships are an essential ingredient in a happy life, so it’s time to give them the care and attention they deserve.

headline: Do the Celtics Spark Joy? Early On, Yes
abstract: Brad Stevens doesn’t think his players are underdogs. Whatever they are, they sure seem happy. Unlike last season.
lead_paragraph: Don’t call these Boston Celtics underdogs in front of their coach, Brad Stevens. He bristles. As much as his mild-mannered nature will allow him to, anyway. And don’t suggest the expectations are different from last year, either, just because the team lost Kyrie Irving and Al Horford to free agency and because their bench is stocked with rookies.

headline: Stock Market Record Surprises Skeptics Yet Again
abstract: The S&P 500 is at a record, after climbing about 6 percent from its August lows.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in the United States climbed to a record on Monday, building on a three-week run that’s been fueled by hopes for a trade deal with China and another cut in interest rates that could keep the economy growing.

headline: The Secret Ingredient That Improves Meat Every Time
abstract: You may love it. You may hate it. But a smear of mayonnaise before cooking makes beef, pork, chicken and fish better as if by magic. J. Kenji López-Alt explains.
lead_paragraph: For the past couple of years, I’ve been seeing a trend among the online community of sous-vide cooking enthusiasts: rubbing meat with mayonnaise before searing it. A parallel trend has also been hitting the grilled cheese forums (there’s a message board for everything), where folks are slathering their bread with mayonnaise before griddling, insisting that mayonnaise produces a golden-brown crust that’s superior to the one you get with butter.

headline: Sotheby’s Switches C.E.O.s Two Weeks Before Auction Season
abstract: Charles F. Stewart, a communications and media executive, will replace Tad Smith.
lead_paragraph: New bosses generally bring in their own people. Nevertheless, the art world was surprised to learn on Monday that the new owner of Sotheby’s, Patrick Drahi, had named Charles F. Stewart as his new chief executive officer, replacing Tad Smith just two weeks before the start of the fall auction season.

headline: After Spike in Deaths, New York to Get 250 Miles of Protected Bike Lanes
abstract: The city will build the lanes as part of a $1.7 billion street safety plan to be adopted by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council.
lead_paragraph: Riding a bicycle in New York City is often a harrowing journey across a patchwork of bike lanes that leave cyclists vulnerable to cars. The dangers came into focus this year after 25 cyclists were killed on city streets — the highest toll in two decades.

headline: Post Malone Returns to No. 1 Before Kanye West Hits the Chart
abstract: “Hollywood’s Bleeding” is the first album to spend four weeks at the top since the soundtrack to “A Star Is Born.”
lead_paragraph: Post Malone returns to the top of the Billboard album chart this week for a fourth time. But in the music industry, all eyes are on Kanye West, who appears to have a strong lead for next week’s chart with his new (and long-delayed) gospel-influenced album.

headline: Is Crispr the Next Antibiotic?
abstract: In nature, the gene-editing tool Crispr protects bacteria against viruses. Now it’s being harnessed in the fight against superbugs and the flu.
lead_paragraph: For decades, scientists and doctors have treated common bacterial and viral infections with fairly blunt therapies. If you developed a sinus infection or a stomach bug, you would likely be given a broad-spectrum antibiotic that would clear out many different types of bacteria. Antiviral drugs help treat viral illnesses in much the same way, by hindering the pathogen’s ability to reproduce and spread in the body.

headline: Former Boston College Student Charged in Boyfriend’s Suicide after Thousands of Texts
abstract: Inyoung You is accused of involuntary manslaughter in the suicide of her college boyfriend, who died on his graduation day.
