lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A former Boston College student has been charged with involuntary manslaughter in connection with the suicide of her college boyfriend on his graduation day, prosecutors announced on Monday.

headline: Texas Father Says 7-Year-Old Isn’t Transgender, Igniting a Politicized Outcry
abstract: A bitter custody battle grabbed the attention of Gov. Greg Abbott, Senator Ted Cruz and other conservative lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: A bitter custody battle in Dallas that centers on the gender identity of a 7-year-old child provoked an outcry among conservatives this month.

headline: George Gascon Enters Race for District Attorney in Los Angeles
abstract: Mr. Gascon, the former district attorney of San Francisco, is promising to reduce incarceration rates.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California here.]

headline: Dissent Erupts at Facebook Over Hands-Off Stance on Political Ads
abstract: In an open letter, the social network’s employees said letting politicians post false claims in ads was “a threat” to the company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The letter was aimed at Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and his top lieutenants. It decried the social network’s recent decision to let politicians post any claims they wanted — even false ones — in ads on the site. It asked Facebook’s leaders to rethink the stance.

headline: For Many Widows, the Hardest Part Is Mealtime
abstract: New attention is being paid to the role of food and cooking in grieving for a lost partner.
lead_paragraph: GLEN ELLYN, Ill. — When her husband, Bill, died six years ago this month, Michele Zawadzki squared her shoulders to the grief.

headline: Read the Letter Facebook Employees Sent to Mark Zuckerberg About Political Ads
abstract: Hundreds of Facebook employees signed a letter decrying the decision to let politicians post any claims they wanted — even false ones — in ads on the site.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Facebook employees recently signed a letter to Mr. Zuckerberg and other leaders of the social network, decrying the company’s decision to let politicians post any claims they wanted — even false ones — in ads on the site.

headline: A Storied Collection of Ancient Sculpture Will Finally See the Light
abstract: The Torlonia family assembled one of the world’s most important private collections of statuary. It will go on display in Rome in March, a prelude to a grand tour.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Several of this city’s finest museums bear the names of the aristocratic families who once built majestic palazzi and stuffed them full of priceless art: the Borghese, the Barberini, the Doria Pamphilj, and more still.

headline: Firefighters Race to Contain Blazes Across State
abstract: A forecast of powerful winds and low humidity was expected to worsen conditions for the fires that are burning in Northern and Southern California.
lead_paragraph: A forecast of powerful winds and low humidity was expected to worsen conditions for the fires that are burning in Northern and Southern California.

headline: Barr Rejects Complaints That He Is Bolstering Trump’s Personal Agenda
abstract: The attorney general sought to play down his role overseeing the criminal inquiry into the origins of the Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Attorney General William P. Barr pushed back on Monday on criticism that the Justice Department is investigating the origins of the Russia inquiry to help President Trump settle personal legal and political scores, insisting that he does not serve as the president’s personal lawyer.

headline: When Your 200-Month-Old Can’t Sleep Through the Night
abstract: The biology of adolescent sleep leads to a later sleep onset time, which doesn’t pair well with early school start times.
lead_paragraph: Sleeping through the night is a hot topic in pediatrics, so it was no surprise that there was a standing-room-only crowd for a lecture on it at the national conference of the American Academy of Pediatrics in New Orleans over the weekend.

headline: Democrats Move Toward Bringing Impeachment Inquiry Public
abstract: House Democrats, who have resisted a floor vote on the impeachment inquiry for weeks, are planning to hold one Thursday to lay out rules for the investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats moved quickly on Monday to bring their impeachment case against President Trump into the open, saying they would forgo court battles with defiant witnesses and would vote this week on procedures to govern nationally televised hearings.

headline: Robert Evans, a Maverick Producer of Hollywood Classics, Dies at 89
abstract: He was a force behind masterworks like “The Godfather” and “Chinatown,” and his own story — of unlikely success and drug-fueled decline — was the stuff of legend.

headline: Elena Ferrante’s Next Book Is Coming in English Next Year
abstract: “The Lying Life of Adults,” by the Italian novelist who wrote “My Brilliant Friend,” is coming out in June.
lead_paragraph: Elena Ferrante, the Italian writer whose Neapolitan quartet of novels have sold more than 11 million copies worldwide and inspired last year’s HBO series “My Brilliant Friend,” has a new book slated for publication in the United States next year.

headline: Kay Hagan, Former North Carolina Senator, Dies at 66
abstract: A Democrat, she served one term after defeating Elizabeth Dole. She was found to have a tick-borne virus in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Kay Hagan, a former Democratic senator from North Carolina who served one term in Washington after defeating Elizabeth Dole, a Republican, in 2008, died on Monday at her home in Greensboro, N.C. She was 66.

headline: Popeyes Chicken Sandwich Returns, but Will the Hype?
abstract: The company poked fun at a competitor in its announcement about the sandwich, which previously proved so popular that it sold out.
lead_paragraph: And you thought the chicken sandwich wars were over.

headline: Finger-Pointing Over Haiti’s Worsening Crisis
abstract: The country’s foreign minister blames opposition politicians, while a Haitian journalist and a medical NGO weigh in. Also: Health coverage for children; maintaining forest ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Terrorist Is Defeated. Trump Is Jeered. We’ve Been Here Before.
abstract: Morning found the president on TV reliving a victory of the Obama years and evening, reliving one of its humiliations.
lead_paragraph: The breathtaking thing about baseball is how drastically the momentum can shift in a single at-bat.

headline: BBC Paid Him £3,000 an Episode; She Got £465
abstract: Samira Ahmed, a BBC presenter, has brought a case that raises concerns yet again about a gender pay gap at the British broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For years, Samira Ahmed has presented a weekly, 15-minute program on BBC television that allows viewers to question the broadcaster’s executives about its shows. She’s never been paid more than £465, or $598, per episode.

headline: ‘The Michaels’ Review: Dance as Life in Upstate New York
abstract: In this delicately wrought portrait of a dying choreographer and her family, Richard Nelson’s play considers the redemptive powers of art in fractious times.
lead_paragraph: They’re speaking more softly in Richard Nelson’s Rhinebeck these days, as if a raised voice might upset a tenuous balance. Not that any of the previous seven (and wonderful) family dramas written by Nelson during the past nine years, all set in the Hudson River town of Rhinebeck, N.Y., have ever involved much shouting.

headline: Trump Says Past Presidents Should Have Killed ISIS Leader al-Baghdadi
abstract: In a freewheeling speech to police chiefs, President Trump also railed against impeachment, Jussie Smollett and Chicago’s violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump told a gathering of police chiefs in Chicago that his predecessors should have killed the murderous Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who blew himself up during an American raid on his compound in Syria on Saturday.

headline: Intelligence From al-Baghdadi Raid, Including 2 Prisoners, Could Reveal Trove of ISIS Clues
abstract: Officials cautioned that the intelligence was unlikely to generate leads for quick follow-up strikes on the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Delta Force commandos took two Islamic State fighters as prisoners and a trove of intelligence from the now-destroyed compound where Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the world’s most wanted terrorist, had been hiding, officials said Monday.

headline: 2020 Democrats at J Street Conference Reflect New Tone on U.S.-Israel Relations
abstract: J Street, a liberal pro-Israel advocacy group, hosted five of the Democratic presidential hopefuls at its meeting on Israel and the future of American foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pete Buttigieg on Monday compared Israel’s relationship with the United States to that of a close friend — one who needed and should accept more guidance. Bernie Sanders put it in starker terms, saying the United States should demand more from Israel.

headline: F.C.C. Plans Vote to Restrict Huawei and ZTE Purchases
abstract: Rural carriers have raised concerns about moves to crack down on Huawei gear, saying it will cut them off from a supply of affordable equipment.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission will vote in November on whether to bar cellular providers from using government subsidies to buy equipment from Huawei and ZTE, two Chinese companies, because of security concerns.

headline: One of Opera’s Great Directors, Binge-Worthy in Berlin
abstract: Over a long weekend recently, you could see three Komische Oper productions by Barrie Kosky, including a new staging of Henze’s rarity “The Bassarids.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Barrie Kosky may be the most interesting opera director of the past decade.

headline: Extinction Rebellion Is Creating a New Narrative of the Climate Crisis
abstract: In London, activists are taking to the streets to eschew hopelessness in favor of repair.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody knows the boat is leaking, everybody knows the captain lied,” Leonard Cohen once sang. In spite of decades of scientific data proving human-caused climate change, we are still spellbound by a story of enlightened progress. Our high-carbon culture is underpinned by a belief system that tells us we are in control of nature and can fix any problem with our superior technology.

headline: U.S. Extends Temporary Work Permits for El Salvador Immigrants
abstract: Those who have Temporary Protected Status will have another year to work legally in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Eager to seal a deal with El Salvador to curb a surge of migrants to the southwestern border, the Trump administration on Monday agreed to special legal protections that would allow an estimated 250,000 Salvadorans to stay and work in the United States for an additional year.

headline: John T. Tate, Familiar Name in the World of Numbers, Dies at 94
abstract: Many of his explanations of fundamental ideas now bear his name, a much-honored one among mathematicians.
lead_paragraph: John T. Tate, a mathematician who explained many fundamental ideas in the theory of numbers, many of which now bear his name, and who won the 2010 Abel Prize, a top math award modeled after the Nobels, died on Oct. 16 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 94.

headline: James Holzhauer and Emma Boettcher Will Return to the ‘Jeopardy!’ Stage
abstract: The sports gambler who dominated the game and the librarian who ended his streak could meet next month in a late round of the Tournament of Champions.
lead_paragraph: James Holzhauer, the professional sports gambler who captivated “Jeopardy!” viewers this year with his 32-game winning streak, will be back on television next week for the game show’s Tournament of Champions, giving him the chance to add to his winnings and prolong his stardom for a bit longer.

headline: The Death of al-Baghdadi, the ISIS Leader
abstract: Readers praise the U.S. special forces and intelligence agencies, criticize the president’s “self-aggrandizing announcement” and chide The Times for its “acid comments” about the president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Brexit, ISIS, India: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Brexit is ... well, you can guess.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Climate Change Could Shift California’s Santa Ana Winds, Fueling Fires
abstract: Recent research suggests that as the climate warms, Santa Ana winds may become less frequent. Coupled with precipitation changes, that could mean more intense fires later in the year.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, humans have experienced the fierce, hot and dry winds that are fanning California’s recent spate of wildfires. Known as Santa Anas in the southern part of the state and Diablos in the north, they arrive regularly in the fall.

headline: Greg Walden, Veteran Republican Representative, Won’t Seek Re-election in 2020
abstract: Mr. Walden is now the fourth lawmaker who serves as the top Republican on a prominent House committee to announce his retirement this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Greg Walden of Oregon, a senior Republican on an influential House committee, said on Monday that he would not seek re-election, joining the growing ranks of Republicans rushing for the exits as they take stock of a grim political landscape ahead of the 2020 election.

headline: Yankees Part Ways With Larry Rothschild
abstract: Rothschild, the team’s pitching coach since 2011, will not return next season as the Yankees seek a new voice for their pitchers.
lead_paragraph: After a 103-win season, the Yankees dismissed their longtime pitching coach, Larry Rothschild. The team announced the move on Monday, simply saying that Rothschild was not returning for the 2020 season. He had a year remaining on his contract.

headline: At the Governors Awards, the Oscars Double Down on Diversity
abstract: As Geena Davis, David Lynch, Wes Studi and Lina Wertmüller accepted their honors, the primary topic was solving inequality in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lina Wertmüller made history when she became the first woman to earn a best-director Oscar nomination for her 1975 film “Seven Beauties.” On Sunday night, when the 91-year-old Italian director took the stage at the Governors Awards to receive an honorary Oscar, she suggested another shake-up.

headline: Google, in Rare Stumble, Posts 23% Decline in Profit
abstract: Alphabet, Google’s parent, said its profits fell after a sharp increase in spending for research and development.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Alphabet, the parent company of Google, said on Monday that its quarterly profit fell 23 percent after it sharply increased spending, in a rare financial stumble by the tech giant.

headline: Why Did It Feel So Good to See Trump Booed?
abstract: When he goes low, Democrats are supposed to go high. Except, it turns out, going low feels wonderful.
lead_paragraph: Most weeks my Mondays unfold in a well-practiced routine: brush teeth, wash face, walk dog. This morning, I added a new step: spend 15 minutes scrolling through Twitter to see whether anyone had synced that delicious footage of President Trump’s face falling on Sunday — as the World Series crowd is booing him — with the R.E.M. song “Everybody Hurts.”

headline: Boeing C.E.O. to Tell Congress: ‘We Know We Made Mistakes’
abstract: Dennis Muilenburg will face the Senate on the first anniversary of the crash of Lion Air Flight 610. The 737 Max remains grounded seven months after a second crash.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s chief executive, Dennis A. Muilenburg, will acknowledge some of the company’s failings on Tuesday when he appears before a Senate committee investigating the crashes of two 737 Max jets that killed 346 people.

headline: California Air Quality: Should You Wear a Face Mask for Wildfire Smoke?
abstract: Residents in the Bay Area and Los Angeles complained of poor air quality. The best thing to do about it? “Stay indoors.”
lead_paragraph: With wildfires raging up and down the state of California on Monday, smoke filled the air in many places, ash fell from the sky, and residents were once again left to wonder whether the very air they were breathing was safe.

headline: The Trump Campaign Is Seeking ‘Hidden’ Women Voters. Impeachment Won’t Help.
abstract: The campaign wants to retain supporters and find new ones as the president rages against impeachment. High-profile campaign officials like the president’s daughter-in-law are leading the effort.
lead_paragraph: St. PAUL, Minn. — Lara Trump thinks that her father-in-law, President Trump, could use some extra support at this particular stage of his presidency. So along with Karen Pence, the second lady, Ms. Trump traveled to this (slimly) blue state with a message for women who support him: Don’t be afraid to speak up — and by all means, please speak up.

headline: Vladimir Bukovsky, Revered Soviet Dissident and Putin Critic, Dies at 76
abstract: Even in exile, a former Soviet prisoner kept up his attacks on the Kremlin under both the Communists and Putin. But disputed child pornography charges marred his reputation.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir K. Bukovsky, a revered Soviet dissident who, after his release from the gulag, spent the second half of his life in Britain, denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin with the same fervor he had directed at the Kremlin’s Communist leaders, died on Sunday in Cambridge, England. He was 76.

headline: What Do Young People Really Think?
abstract: A year before the election, we asked teens and 20-somethings about the issues on their minds.
lead_paragraph: A year before the election, we asked teens and 20-somethings about the issues on their minds.

headline: What Makes a Person Patriotic?
abstract: A year before the election, we spoke to people in the Midwest about all kinds of American pride.
lead_paragraph: A year before the election, we spoke to people in the Midwest about all kinds of American pride.

headline: What Makes a Tradition American?
abstract: A year before the election, we spoke to people about food, faith and freedom.
lead_paragraph: A year before the election, we spoke to people about food, faith and freedom.

headline: Suspect in Capital Gazette Shooting Pleads Guilty
abstract: Jarrod Ramos, who is accused of killing five people in a Maryland newsroom last year, will pursue an insanity defense at trial.
lead_paragraph: A man charged with killing five people in a Maryland newsroom last year changed his plea to guilty on Monday but will still pursue an insanity defense that argues he should not be held criminally responsible, the authorities said.

headline: What Does Community Mean to Black Americans?
abstract: A year before the election, we drove through the South, meeting with religious leaders, small-business owners, educators, farmers and local representatives to talk about what brings us together.
lead_paragraph: A year before the election, we drove through the South, meeting with religious leaders, small-business owners, educators, farmers and local representatives to talk about what brings us together.

headline: A Taco Truck in Buffalo Served Lunch to ICE Workers. Then Came the Backlash.
abstract: A request to park a food truck outside a federal detention center thrust a small company into the national debate over immigration.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a standard request for the Lloyd taco truck, a local favorite in Buffalo. Last week, a building on the outskirts of the city asked the truck to park outside around midday so its employees could have Mexican food for lunch.

headline: President Trump Came to Chicago With Insults. For Chicagoans, the Feeling Was Mutual.
abstract: In his first visit as president to the nation’s third-largest city, Mr. Trump called Chicago’s police superintendent’s values a “disgrace.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “He’s not welcome in our city,” said Pam Capraro, 65, as she walked along the Chicago River to join a chanting, singing, sign-waving, occasionally sousaphone-playing crowd outside the Trump International Hotel & Tower. “He represents everything that Chicago isn’t — racism, sexism, xenophobia.”

headline: Robert Provine, an Authority on Laughter, Is Dead at 76
abstract: A psychology professor, he set about trying to understand what triggers giggles and guffaws and wrote a definitive book on the subject. He could also make you laugh.
lead_paragraph: Robert Provine was studying nerve cells for eight hours a day in a windowless lab when he made a keen observation that would alter his life, and the shape of social science: I am getting tired of this.

headline: State Court Bars Using North Carolina House Map in 2020 Elections
abstract: A state court found that North Carolina’s congressional districts were drawn with gerrymanders designed to benefit Republicans that violate the State Constitution.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina state court effectively threw out the state’s map of congressional districts on Monday, saying critics were poised to show “beyond a reasonable doubt” that it was an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander favoring Republicans.

headline: Running Into the Night — and Traffic
abstract: Running in New York City is about far more than the marathon. Each week, a growing group of running enthusiasts takes to the streets in an act of running rebellion.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost midnight in Gowanus and 236 of New York City’s fastest runners are lined up in the rain on a dark street. There are runners who have qualified for the Olympic Trials and track champions blocking the way of any vehicle out at that hour, as well as plenty of workaday running enthusiasts.

headline: General Motors Sides With Trump in Emissions Fight, Splitting the Industry
abstract: Along with Toyota and Fiat Chrysler, the auto giant backed the administration in its clash with California over pollution standards.
lead_paragraph: Breaking with some of their biggest rivals, General Motors, Fiat Chrysler and Toyota said Monday they were intervening on the side of the Trump administration in an escalating battle with California over fuel economy standards for automobiles.

headline: Wildfires, Impeachment, Facebook: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Debt, Doomsayers and Double Standards
abstract: Selective deficit hysteria has done immense damage.
lead_paragraph: So the federal budget deficit just hit $1 trillion (actually $984 billion, but close enough). That’s about $300 billion more than the Congressional Budget Office was projecting in the summer of 2017, before the Trump tax cut was enacted. And basically everybody yawned.

headline: Military Officials Say Tell-All About al-Baghdadi Raid Team Unlikely
abstract: Unlike their brethren in SEAL Team 6, Delta Force commandos are known for flying under the radar when it comes to public exposure of their efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is unlikely to be a tell-all book or movie based on firsthand accounts of the Delta Force commandos who assaulted the compound of the Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and chased him into a dead-end tunnel, prompting him to blow himself up, military officials say.

headline: ‘You Promised You Wouldn’t Kill Me’
abstract: Atatiana Jefferson, Natasha McKenna and the other black women we forget.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — On Thursday, I went to the funeral of Atatiana Jefferson, 28, who was shot to death by a police officer from outside her bedroom window this month. My companion there was Rhanda Dormeus, whose daughter Korryn Gaines was also killed by the police in her home. As we watched people file by the coffin, we thought, “This can’t keep happening.”

headline: Pentagon Can’t Confirm al-Baghdadi ‘Whimpering’
abstract: Some White House officials echoed Pentagon assertions that President Trump may have spoken with commanders or Delta Force team members for a description of the ISIS leader’s last moments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The country’s top military officer said on Monday that he does not know where President Trump got his information that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, died “screaming, crying and whimpering.”

headline: As Putin Meddles Abroad, He Cracks Down at Home
abstract: The Russian leader is not too busy in Ukraine and Syria to ignore growing disaffection with his government.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s popularity among Russians may not be what it once was, but despite a slowing economy he still enjoys unchallenged popular support. Why, then, do his security forces deem it necessary to crack down on the most obscure instances of perceived dissidence? Why accuse a little-known freelance journalist of “inciting terrorism” over an article about a teenager’s suicide? Why arrest and send to Siberia a self-styled shaman who was walking across Russia to “exorcise” Mr. Putin?

headline: Paul Barrere, Longtime Member of the Band Little Feat, Dies at 71
abstract: A guitarist and singer, Mr. Barrere also wrote or co-wrote some of the critically acclaimed band’s best-known songs.
lead_paragraph: Paul Barrere, a guitarist, singer and songwriter best known for his long tenure with the rock band Little Feat, formed in 1969 and known for its distinctive blend of musical influences, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: Trump Shares Photo of ‘Wonderful’ Dog in ISIS Raid, but Not a Name
abstract: The dog “is still in theater, returned to duty,” said Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. But the name is still classified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump shared a photograph on Monday of the “wonderful” dog who participated in the raid against Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, but said the dog’s name remained classified.

headline: The Revenge Porn Debate Reaches Washington
abstract: Representative Katie Hill, who is resigning, says she is the victim of an abusive husband.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox.

headline: Wegmans Feels Like Family, Even if It Isn’t Mine
abstract: Now that the supermarket has moved to Brooklyn, I know why people have been awed by my last name.
lead_paragraph: “Are you a Wegman Wegman?”

headline: California Wildfires: Share Your Photos and Videos
abstract: The New York Times would like to see photos and videos from people in California affected by wildfires up and down the state.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires up and down the state of California are driving people from their homes. As of Monday, the Kincade fire, in the heart of Sonoma County, had consumed 66,000 acres and was only 5 percent contained. Gov. Gavin Newsom said that 880,000 people were without power in the state.

headline: Microsoft Says Russians Hacked Antidoping Agency Computers
abstract: The Russians were supposed to turn over their own computer data to avoid further penalties. Then they went on the offensive.
lead_paragraph: Russian state hackers attacked the computer networks of at least 16 national and international sports and antidoping organizations, Microsoft said Monday. The attacks are the latest in a series of brazen Russian cyberattacks on foreign politicians, sporting officials and antidoping regulators.

headline: Possible Impeachment Trial Could Complicate Congress’s Spending Debate
abstract: The uncertainty could further muddle the already fraught process of trying to prevent another government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When virtually all legislative activity ground to a halt during the impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton in 1999, senators had already resolved the most pressing item on their agenda: fully funding the government.

headline: California Blackouts Hit Cellphone Service, Fraying a Lifeline
abstract: As power is cut to reduce the wildfire risk from electrical wires and towers, a primary source of emergency communication is put in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: California’s recent power shut-offs, meant to reduce the risk of potentially catastrophic fires, have had an unwelcome side effect. The blackouts have also cut power to many cellphone towers, blocking the main communications source for many in harm’s way.

headline: Vlatko Andonovski, the New U.S.W.N.T. Coach: ‘I Can’t Wait to Start’
abstract: Replacing Jill Ellis, who led the team to two World Cup titles, might seem daunting, but Andonovski knows what is expected of him.
lead_paragraph: Vlatko Andonovski, the new coach of the United States women’s soccer team, knows the place that the team occupies in its sport. He knows that it is expected to win every game, and to dominate every tournament. He knows its performances have long been the gold standard in women’s soccer, and he knows that the expectation is that nothing he does will change that.

headline: A Lineman Became a Doctor, but Dementia Made Him Retire. He’s Only 42.
abstract: T.J. Abraham’s career ended when his brain began to fail. His doctors blame football, and he is pushing for change.
lead_paragraph: ERIE, Pa. — T.J. Abraham is a block of a man with a tree-trunk neck and a lantern jaw. He played football at a top Catholic high school outside Pittsburgh and then traveled downtown to Duquesne University, where he played another three years.

headline: With California Ablaze, Firefighters Strain to Keep Up
abstract: While crews tried to save homes from the Getty fire near Los Angeles, other workers cleared the ground around the Kincade fire in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: [Read the latest about the California fires, and sign up here for our California Today newsletter.]

headline: Iraqi Antigovernment Protests Grow, Part Battle Lines and Carnival
abstract: The protests veered quickly from boisterous street party to treatment at a makeshift medical station, as Iraqi forces tried to bar demonstrators from Baghdad’s Green Zone.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi government announced a midnight-to-dawn curfew in Baghdad on Monday, as it struggled to contain growing antigovernment protests that have gained support around the country, including from a leading Shiite cleric who has called for early elections.

headline: No, the Nationals Are Not Cursed by an Early Plan to Celebrate
abstract: Major League Baseball staged a routine rehearsal of a World Series title celebration before a game had been played in Washington. Then social media erupted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a routine dress rehearsal, not an inflammatory prediction. A stage was set up in the Nationals Park last week so that Major League Baseball could practice for a trophy presentation as the World Series shifted from Houston with Washington holding a two-games-to-none lead.

headline: Sotheby’s Has a Wine Label of Its Own
abstract: The auction house now sells 12 styles of wine, with price points many can afford.
lead_paragraph: The notion of wine at Sotheby’s brings to mind rare, top-of-the-line collections up for auction. But that doesn’t apply to the auction house’s new line of wines bearing its own label and sold in its wine shop and online. It sells 12 wines, each a well-crafted, almost textbook example of a particular varietal, category and region, without suggesting great age-worthy distinction. They are for dinner, not special occasions, and priced from $16.95 to $39.95. Sotheby’s wine experts, led by Jamie Ritchie, the company’s wine chairman, contacted producers with whom they were familiar and arranged to have some of their wines bottled with the Sotheby’s label. There’s blanc de blancs grand cru Champagne, Prosecco, Sancerre Blanc 2018, Bourgogne Blanc 2016, Sonoma chardonnay 2018, Sancerre rosé 2018, Langhe nebbiolo 2017, Sonoma pinot noir 2017, Bourgogne Rouge 2016, St. Émilion 2017, Pessac-Léognan 2017 and Haut Médoc 2010.

headline: In Praise of ‘Human Scum’
abstract: It’s not easy to turn your back on political comrades.
lead_paragraph: I’m often incredulous at Republican servility to Donald Trump. I’ve struggled to understand how people who’ve spent a lifetime chest-beating about patriotism can be so willing to burn liberal democracy to the ground to protect a man they wouldn’t trust to sell them a used car. So I’ve tried to envision a situation in which I might be tempted to do the same.

headline: A Chocolate Bar With a Golden Blockchain Token
abstract: The Other Bar lets the snacker decide how to give back: help a farmer or plant a tree.
lead_paragraph: Some high-end chocolates carry the fair trade label from companies that work closely with farmers and support them. But they represent a small percentage of worldwide chocolate production. Now, with the participation of the United Nations Development Program, the FairChain Foundation based in Amsterdam has introduced the Other Bar, made with fine Ecuadorean chocolate, which sells for $2.99 for a package of two. Some of the profits are given back to the farmers. The bars are good quality, with 72 percent cacao for the dark, 50 percent for the milk. In each package there’s a blockchain token you can scan. Use it to make a donation to the farmers, save up four tokens to fund a tree or get 25 cents off your next purchase.

headline: 2 Photos of Tense White House Moments: Note the Differences
abstract: President Barack Obama watched from the Situation Room as commandos went after Osama bin Laden. Eight years later, President Trump watched a raid unfold against Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two images, one filled with tension and action, one static and posed, depict the country’s commanders in chief at significant, and parallel, moments in their presidencies — overseeing missions to capture and kill terrorists long sought by the United States.

headline: The Baltic States Get Their Culinary Due
abstract: In Simon Bajada’s new “Baltic” cookbook, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania’s food cultures are explored.
lead_paragraph: Nordic cuisine has garnered interest recently, but the nearby Baltic States, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, also deserve attention. They rely on similar ingredients like fish (especially smoked), potatoes, caraway, cabbage, dairy, and foraged and fermented products. This new, beautifully photographed book that explores their cuisines fine-tunes the character of each. Estonia is the most Nordic of them, there are Russian influences in Latvia, and Lithuania, once an empire, is more diverse, with a Jewish component. The book offers dishes like hearty soups, a hotpot of smoked fish with potatoes and cream, stuffed cabbage, yeasted potato bread, a kugel-like shredded potato dish from Lithuania and Latvian butter seasoned with toasted hemp seeds. Come spring I plan to try fresh cucumbers with honey.

headline: Flavored Salts From Momofuku
abstract: The seasonings, buoyed by Sichuan peppercorns, chiles and mushrooms, boost savory dishes.
lead_paragraph: Flavored salts are not significant in my culinary wardrobe, though occasionally some come along that tempt me, like this set of three developed by Momofuku. A kosher salt blended with crushed Sichuan peppercorns, called Tingly, was the star. The amount of the piquant, palate-numbing spice is well-balanced in the salt, so it does not overwhelm what you season. A ruddy orange salt called Spicy is fueled with several chiles and gives a nice finish to beef and pork. The one labeled Savory blends salt and pepper with umami-rich components like kelp, mushrooms and tamari.

headline: Cookbook Authors Discuss Jewish Cuisine
abstract: Adeena Sussman and Leah Koenig sit down next month to talk about the particulars of Jewish food in Israel and the Diaspora.
lead_paragraph: The cookbook authors Leah Koenig and Adeena Sussman will discuss the particulars of Jewish cuisine in Israel and the Diaspora at Symphony Space. Gabriella Gershenson, a food writer, will lead the conversation.

headline: An Alternative to the Salad Spinner
abstract: The Salad Sling lets cooks dry their greens while getting a bit of exercise.
lead_paragraph: I own salad spinners, but I prefer to dry my greens by rolling them up in a terry cloth towel. Obviously, Jill Visit, an entrepreneur from Austin, Tex., is of like mind: She has created the Salad Sling, a 30-inch triple-layer square of absorbent Kelly green fabric. Gather up your washed greens in the sling, grasp the handles in the corners and, holding it closed like a knapsack, swing it around vigorously so the moisture on the leaves gets wicked off and settles into the fabric. It works quite well, though I found that a second swing is sometimes needed. The fabric is easily rinsed and is machine washable and dryable.

headline: Army Officer Who Heard Trump’s Ukraine Call Reported Concerns
abstract: The top Ukraine expert at the White House will tell impeachment investigators he twice reported concerns about President Trump’s pressure tactics on Ukraine, acting out of a “sense of duty.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House national security official who is a decorated Iraq war veteran plans to tell House impeachment investigators on Tuesday that he heard President Trump appeal to Ukraine’s president to investigate one of his leading political rivals, a request the aide considered so damaging to American interests that he reported it to a superior.

headline: What the U.S. Withdrawal Cost the Kurds
abstract: Mass funerals, wounded children, displaced families. This is what we found in northeast Syria after the U.S. withdrew its troops and Turkey attacked.
lead_paragraph: Mass funerals, wounded children, displaced families. This is what we found in northeast Syria after the U.S. withdrew its troops and Turkey attacked.

headline: As Kurds Tracked ISIS Leader, U.S. Withdrawal Threw Raid Into Turmoil
abstract: Trump’s decision to pull troops from Syria upended a 5-year alliance and threw the plans against al-Baghdadi into disarray.
lead_paragraph: QAMISHLI, Syria — When the international manhunt for Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, zoomed in  on a village in northwestern Syria, the United States turned to its local allies to help track the world’s most-wanted terrorist.

headline: Deadly Earthquake Strikes Southern Philippine Island
abstract: The magnitude-6.6 earthquake on Mindanao sent people fleeing in panic from their homes and caused significant structural damage to buildings.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A magnitude-6.6 earthquake struck the southern Philippine island of Mindanao on Tuesday, sending people fleeing from their homes in panic, causing structural damage to buildings and killing at least seven people.

headline: ‘Seared’ Review: For a Pompous Chef, Comeuppance on the Menu
abstract: Raúl Esparza faces the realities of the restaurant business in Theresa Rebeck’s energetic but formulaic art-versus-commerce comedy.
lead_paragraph: If you can’t stand my creative, manly heat, get out of my kitchen: This could be the unofficial motto of Harry, the temperamental chef at a tiny Brooklyn restaurant. But it’s O.K. for him to be a jerk because Harry — played by Raúl Esparza with knife-wielding, cocky charm — is not a cook, he is an artist.

headline: Like Quality Eggs
abstract: Evan Mahnken celebrates a celebrity with more celebrities.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — A brief one today, as I ease my way back into the solving week. A round of applause for the surprisingly dangerous Caitlin Lovinger and the extremely dapper Sam Ezersky for taking the wheel while I indulged in a bit of R&R.

headline: Why You Should Find Time to Be Alone With Yourself
abstract: Don’t confuse loneliness with time by yourself.
lead_paragraph: Being lonely hurts — it can even negatively impact your health. But the mere act of being alone with oneself doesn’t have to be bad, and experts say it can even benefit your social relationships, improve your creativity and confidence, and help you regulate your emotions so that you can better deal with adverse situations.

headline: Brexit, ISIS, Tuberculosis: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Corrections: October 29, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, October 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Taco Truck Served Lunch to ICE Workers. Then the Backlash Came.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “We make tacos — not war.”

headline: Testing Cars That Help Drivers Steer Clear of Pedestrians
abstract: As pedestrian deaths climb, collision-avoidance systems could reduce that toll, but new tests show significant differences in how well they work.
lead_paragraph: Almost 6,300 pedestrians were killed in 2018 in the United States, the highest number since 1990, federal officials said this month. Collision-avoidance systems on many new vehicles could reduce that toll, but there are significant differences in how well they work, according to new tests.

headline: Hong Kong Bars Joshua Wong, a Prominent Activist, From Seeking Election
abstract: Mr. Wong, a leader of the 2014 Umbrella Movement, had planned to run for a district council position amid widespread public anger with the government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong authorities on Tuesday barred Joshua Wong, a prominent democracy activist, from running in district council elections next month, a blow to the protest movement’s efforts to convert deep anger toward the authorities into electoral gains.

headline: New TB Vaccine Could Save Millions of Lives, Study Suggests
abstract: There are 10 million new cases each year of tuberculosis, now the leading infectious cause of death worldwide. Even a partly effective vaccine could help turn the tide.
lead_paragraph: In what may be a watershed moment in the fight against tuberculosis, the world’s most lethal infectious disease, an experimental new vaccine has protected about half the people who got it, scientists reported on Tuesday.

headline: Jeff Sessions Considers Run for His Old Alabama Senate Seat
abstract: The former attorney general, who previously held the seat for 20 years, would seem to be a formidable candidate. But President Trump’s antipathy toward him could complicate the picture.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Sessions, the former attorney general whom President Trump came to loathe for his recusal from the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election, is considering running for his former Senate seat from Alabama, people familiar with his thinking said.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: Rob Zombie’s ‘Halloween’ and ‘Haxan’
abstract: Catch Rob Zombie’s unmasking of Michael Myers, and stream an experimental silent film about the history of witchcraft.
lead_paragraph: HALLOWEEN (2007) 9 p.m. on AMC. In his New York Times review of John Carpenter’s 1978 slasher film “Halloween,” Jason Zinoman wrote that Michael Myers isn’t like other movie monsters: “He never speaks and offers no hint of a motivation for his killing spree. He is not a character so much as an absence of one, an abstraction in the middle of a mundane slice of suburban life.” But this take on that film, directed by the heavy metal singer Rob Zombie, upends that idea by exploring Myers’s back story and unmasking his motive to kill. It follows his childhood as a socially awkward, bullied boy with a stressful home life, which fuels his rage, leading him to enact his first murderous rampage on Halloween night at just 10 years old. He’s then locked away in a mental institution and breaks out 15 years later in an attempt to reconnect with his younger sister, who’s now a teenager. In his review for The New York Times, Matt Zoller Seitz wrote that “the case study part of the film re-establishes Mr. Zombie’s status as modern American horror’s most eccentric and surprising filmmaker.”

headline: 2-Year-Old Dies After Being Trapped in Well for Days
abstract: Rescuers in southern India used a drilling rig and ropes to reach the toddler, but were only able to recover his body.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — More than three days after a 2-year-old boy slid some 100 feet into a tiny borehole in southern India, setting off a panicked round-the-clock mission to rescue him, his body was pulled from the opening early Tuesday morning.

headline: Word + Quiz: factotum
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Small Talk
abstract: Do you have the gift of gab?
lead_paragraph: Are you good at small talk? Or do you find yourself at a loss for words when trying to make conversation with strangers and acquaintances?

headline: $7.5 Million ‘Down the Drain’: The Demise of the Bouncing Bridge
abstract: Squibb Park Bridge in Brooklyn, designed to bounce underfoot, has been demolished. A less-springy replacement is on the way.
lead_paragraph: It became a 450-foot-long boondoggle, a pedestrian bridge that bounced more than expected. It also cost more than expected. A lot more.

headline: Nationals Believe They Have Another Comeback in Them
abstract: Washington has been on the brink before this season. Losing three World Series games in row hasn’t put a dent in the team’s positivity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the Washington Nationals, the trick to winning so much this year was staying loose.

headline: ‘A New Message’: Russia Trains Its Propaganda Machine on Africa
abstract: Many of the players who drove Moscow’s campaign for influence in the West are now backing Putin’s African charm offensive.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Jose Matemulane said he left his native Mozambique nearly two decades ago, spent years studying in St. Petersburg and saw the Russian soul. Now he’s in the vanguard of Russia’s new foray onto his home continent, where he is spreading the word that working with Moscow to reduce the influence of Americans and other Westerners is in Africa’s best interests.

headline: At Cigar Smoking Worlds, the Best Always Finish Last
abstract: A trip to the Cigar Smoking World Championship confirms that competition, regardless of the discipline and the contestants, remains just a state of mind.
lead_paragraph: SPLIT, Croatia — The smoke machine seemed redundant.

headline: Stephen Colbert Thinks Trump has al-Baghdadi Issues
abstract: “You know how I know that killing bin Laden was a big deal? Because Obama never had to say that killing bin Laden was a big deal,” the “Late Show” host said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Survivors of ISIS Carnage Feel Little Relief at al-Baghdadi’s Death’
abstract: In this lesson, students learn what the Islamic State leader’s death means for the future of the organization and Syrian civilians.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Survivors of ISIS Carnage Feel Little Relief at al-Baghdadi’s Death”

headline: India Finally Lets Lawmakers Into Kashmir: Far-Right Europeans
abstract: India’s own members of Parliament have been kept out of the locked-down region for months, as have journalists and an American senator.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After months of denying journalists, Indian lawmakers and an American senator access to the locked-down Kashmir region, the Indian government on Tuesday allowed a visit by mostly far-right members of the European Parliament, representing anti-immigration parties with histories of anti-Muslim rhetoric.

headline: How the Trump Cabinet’s Bible Teacher Became a Shadow Diplomat
abstract: Ralph Drollinger is on a mission to extend the influence he has in Washington around the world. Is he representing Jesus, the administration — or himself?
lead_paragraph: Ralph Drollinger, who has spent much of the last three years teaching the Gospel to President Trump’s cabinet, dresses like a man of the world. One morning this summer, during a layover at Miami International Airport, he was the very picture of American business — a friendly-looking, dark-suited, jowly man in his late prime. The woman sitting beside him, looking just as exactingly appropriate in her black pantsuit and white shirt, was his wife, Danielle. She quietly scrolled through her iPad as Drollinger explained why the trip they were about to embark on to Managua, Nicaragua, had him uncharacteristically worried.

headline: Should I Tell the Children Why My Marriage Broke Up?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to tell your adult children about the affair that led to your divorce and more.
lead_paragraph: I am a middle-aged woman. Several decades ago I had an affair with a woman I met in a writing class at a prestigious university’s continuing-education program. I was at a very fragile and vulnerable point in my life. My husband and I and our young children had recently moved to a new town where I knew no one. My children were both in school — I’d quit my job to raise a family — and I was lost, insecure, unhappy in my marriage and deeply depressed. (I was later put on antidepressants, which I continue to take to this day.) Not only did this woman think I was special and build my ego up as no one had ever done, but she also thought my writing was amazing. She had impressive credentials (she was published; she was enrolled as a graduate student in another program at the university and so on) so her support and encouragement made me feel as though I could accomplish anything.

headline: When Will a Reckoning on Racism Catch Up With Reality TV?
abstract: From “Real Housewives” to “Vanderpump Rules,” Bravo shows offer a complicated wealth of diversity.
lead_paragraph: “The sun always shines on Beverly Hills, but not on everyone,” Camille Grammer says in the opening line of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” which premiered on Bravo in 2010. For the majority of its first nine seasons, the reality show shined its light on a certain type of woman: rich, opinionated and white.

headline: The Famous, Feuding Siblings Who Helped Shape Modern China
abstract: “Big Sister, Little Sister, Red Sister,” by Jung Chang, reconstructs the lives of the politically connected Soong sisters, uncovering idealism, intrigue and greed.
lead_paragraph: BIG SISTER, LITTLE SISTER, RED SISTERThree Women at the Heart of Twentieth-Century ChinaBy Jung Chang

headline: ‘But Mom, Video Games Are My Job’
abstract: The challenges for parents trying to limit screen time in the age of the millionaire gamer.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Giersdorf is 16 years old. He’s a junior at Pottsgrove High School, about half an hour from my home in suburban Philadelphia. In July, he won the first-ever Fortnite World Cup, earning $3 million.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Show Caves
abstract: Want to encounter the sublime beneath the surface of the earth? That’ll be $21.95.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, driving south down Interstate 81 in no real hurry to get from New York to Georgia, I began to notice somewhere around central Virginia that I was surrounded by caves. It seemed strange how aggressively advertised they were in this part of the world. Their names tended toward the bombastic: Lost World Caverns and Endless Caverns and Forbidden Caverns and Lost Sea Adventure. They were the predominant genre of roadside attraction, their billboards jostling for space with those for nearby truck stops or for grim sentiments along the lines of “Lust Drags You Down to Hell.”

headline: In Kevin Wilson’s New Novel, Rageaholic Twins Spontaneously Combust
abstract: The 10-year-old siblings at the heart of “Nothing to See Here” have a little problem: Whenever they experience intense emotion, they burst into flames.
lead_paragraph: NOTHING TO SEE HEREBy Kevin Wilson

headline: It’s Halloween. Here’s What’s Haunting the Runways.
abstract: Aliens, demons and other shady creatures are invading social media — and being co-opted by the world of style.
lead_paragraph: Salvjiia is a beautiful fright. The Instagram persona of Lilith Morris, she is posed in a recent post as a mutant, her eyes dark pits, her wheat-colored hair cascading to the floor, her torso fused with the fur-covered legs of a deer.

headline: The Border Between Red and Blue America
abstract: With suburbia now split in two parts, we needed a more precise method to distinguish them.
lead_paragraph: The suburbs are up for grabs.

headline: Classical Music and Fetishes Unite in Historical Center of Gay Culture
abstract: Folsom Europe, a five-day festival of concerts and street parties, celebrates gay life, the leather scene and hard-won freedoms in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A hush fell over the hundreds of kinksters gathered in the pews of the Twelve Apostles Church in Berlin when the cellist, clad in head-to-toe black leather, took a seat in front of the altar and began to play Rachmaninoff.

headline: ‘Tone Down Your Gayness’: Police Sergeant Is Awarded $20 Million in Discrimination Case
abstract: The sergeant, who is gay, had said the St. Louis County Police Department failed to promote him based on sex stereotyping and retaliated against him for filing a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A jury in St. Louis has awarded a gay police sergeant nearly $20 million in a discrimination case involving claims that the department failed to promote him based on sex stereotyping and retaliated against him for filing a lawsuit.

headline: How to Make Your Travel Clothes Pop on Instagram
abstract: “On Instagram we are selling a fantasy, and we want it to look like we have these amazing lives,” one stylist says. “But it can’t feel forced; it has to look easy.”
lead_paragraph: Our travel tips column has shown you how to pack (edit ruthlessly, use packing cubes) and how to take vacation photos (remember to take advantage of the golden hour). But which outfits both travel effortlessly and make for enviable posts on social media? The answer combines color coordination, personal style, destination mindfulness and knowing what pops on Instagram.

headline: The Far-Right Group Said They Were the Victims. The Videos Showed Something Different.
abstract: The Proud Boys claimed self-defense last year when a video showed them kicking and punching black-clad protesters. But I saw footage that showed a clear aggressor — and eventually, so did jurors.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: ‘OK Boomer’ Marks the End of Friendly Generational Relations
abstract: Now it’s war: Gen Z has finally snapped over climate change and financial inequality.
lead_paragraph: In a viral audio clip on TikTok, a white-haired man in a baseball cap and polo shirt declares, “The millennials and Generation Z have the Peter Pan syndrome, they don’t ever want to grow up.”

headline: It’s a Big Week for Economic News, With Implications for the 2020 Race
abstract: New data about the strengths and weaknesses of the economy could shape the discussion on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know what the economic backdrop to the 2020 elections is likely to be, pay close attention to some of this week’s headlines.

headline: Democrats Have the Most Racially Diverse Field Ever. The Top Tier Is All White.
abstract: Trailing in the money race, tripped up by their own missteps and perceived by some as less electable, nonwhite candidates find themselves well back of the leaders.
lead_paragraph: When the Democratic primary contest began last winter, it featured the most racially diverse field in history, with two black senators, a Latino former cabinet secretary, an Asian-American businessman and the first American Samoan elected to Congress. But 10 months later, the Democratic field has a top tier of four white candidates, three of them men.

headline: Meet Alexander Vindman, the Colonel Who Testified on Trump’s Phone Call
abstract: He fled Ukraine at age 3 and became a soldier, scholar and official at the White House. That’s where, he told impeachment investigators, he witnessed alarming behavior by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The twin brothers were 3 when they fled Ukraine, then a Soviet republic, with their father and grandmother, Jewish refugees with only their suitcases and $750, hoping for a better life in the United States.

headline: The Nightly Feasts of Little Guatemala, Los Angeles
abstract: Catering to the largest Guatemalan community outside of the country, a market serves regional specialties and turns frying into an art.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Using the edge of a carbon-steel razor blade, Antonio Morales scrapes pieces of browning onion from a wide, sizzling flat top.

headline: She Doesn’t Want Her Daughter’s Killer To Be Put To Death. Should the Government Listen?
abstract: A white supremacist was convicted of horrible crimes. But victims’ family members, the prosecutor and the judge have all said the death sentence was too arbitrary to justify.
lead_paragraph: HECTOR, Ark. — In early December, if nothing else changes, Daniel Lewis Lee will be the first federal prisoner put to death in nearly two decades. He was sentenced 20 years ago after being convicted — along with another man, both white supremacists on the hunt for guns and cash — of taping bags over the heads of a husband, wife and 8-year-old girl, tying rocks around them and throwing them into a bayou.

headline: Don’t Sleep on Tunis, a City That’s More Awake Than Ever Before
abstract: The 52 Places Traveler visits the Tunisian capital, where the Arab Spring began, and finds artists, entrepreneurs and activists creating the future.
lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Sebastian Modak, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2019 list. His last dispatch was from Gambia, where he found a country confronting its past.

headline: Boeing C.E.O. Knew About Pilot’s Warnings Before Second Crash
abstract: Boeing’s chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, testified before Congress for the first time since the crashes of two 737 Max jets that killed 346 people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Boeing’s chief executive faced the grieving relatives of two deadly crashes of its 737 Max jet at an emotional congressional hearing on Tuesday, as senators pummeled him with questions about whether the company should have grounded the plane before the second accident. At times looking shaken, the executive, Dennis A. Muilenburg, said that if he could do it over again, he would have acted after the first crash, off the coast of Indonesia last October. “If we knew everything back then that we know now, we would have made a different decision,” he testified. He said Boeing officials had asked themselves “over and over” again why they didn’t ground the plane sooner.

headline: Aasif Mandvi’s Delicately Negotiated Décor
abstract: “This is the first apartment I’ve lived in that my family doesn’t walk in and go, ‘We need to fumigate, we need to build bookshelves,’” said Mr. Mandvi, a star of the new CBS drama “Evil.”
lead_paragraph: “This is the first apartment I’ve lived in that my family doesn’t walk in and go, ‘We need to fumigate, we need to build bookshelves,’” said Mr. Mandvi, a star of the new CBS drama “Evil.”

headline: Housing Works Is Cast in Unusual Role: Corporate Overlord
abstract: Workers say the nonprofit has resisted their unionization efforts. Housing Works says that it isn’t anti-union, but that a union wouldn’t solve workers’ concerns.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Charles King has made it his business to fight for vulnerable New Yorkers, much of that time leading Housing Works, a nonprofit organization created in 1990 to find housing for homeless people who had H.I.V.

headline: Why the Economy Might Not Sway 2020 Voters
abstract: Views of the economy are starkly split along partisan lines, and have barely budged as growth has slowed. That could make the economy matter less in 2020 than in past elections.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ views of the economy have become so hardened along partisan lines that the economy may matter less in next year’s presidential election than in the past.

headline: A Quintessential New York Apartment for a Star of ‘Evil’
abstract: When Aasif Mandvi first saw his home, he thought it was the kind of place “where Gordon Gekko stands and looks out over the skyline.”
lead_paragraph: Aasif Mandvi is here to tell you that experience richly deserves its reputation as the best teacher. Mr. Mandvi’s own particular experiences as a renter in New York taught him lessons enough to fill a column.

headline: Why 250 Miles of Bike Lanes Are Being Built
abstract: Tuesday: The mayor and the City Council have agreed on a bill after a spate of cyclist deaths.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Impeachment, California, Robert Evans: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Amazon Turns to More Free Grocery Delivery to Lift Food Sales
abstract: The company announced free two-hour food delivery for Prime members in about 20 major metropolitan areas.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon has yet to find the key to unlocking huge grocery sales. Now, the company is trying a new tack: free delivery for more people.

headline: The Overstated Collapse of American Christianity
abstract: Three reasons the narrative of rapid secularization is incomplete.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, many observers of American religion assumed that secularization would gradually wash traditional Christianity away. Twenty years ago, Christianity looked surprisingly resilient, and so the smart thinking changed: Maybe there was an American exception to secularizing trends, or maybe a secularized Europe was the exception and the modernity-equals-secularization thesis was altogether wrong.

headline: I’m the Comedian Who Just Confronted Harvey Weinstein. Here’s Why I Spoke Up.
abstract: Survivors of sexual assault shouldn’t have to explain their experiences — or stand in a room with Harvey Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday night, I walked into a bar to perform stand-up, and noticed Harvey Weinstein sitting in the room. I didn’t know what to say, but I wanted to say something, so I made a joke that questioned why the event organizers had invited him to the show. Some people booed and one person told me to “shut up.” I let the room know that I have been raped, and cursed at the monster I wasn’t making eye contact with. The next day my world blew up when a video I had posted went viral.

headline: No, President Trump, It’s Not ‘Importing the Terrorism.’ It’s the Right Thing to Do.
abstract: We can’t reverse the reckless decision that unraveled northeastern Syria and sent America’s allies fleeing for their lives. But we can grant those partners asylum.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt withdrawal of American forces from northeastern Syria generated a rare moment of bipartisanship in Washington, though not the kind the Trump administration wanted. Reactions ranged from confusion to outrage. But agreeing on the disastrous consequences of the pullout is easier than figuring out how to manage them.

headline: There Is Nothing This Man Can’t Wreck
abstract: Does Trump’s path of destruction include the Democratic Party and its presidential candidates?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Bad news: The White House has canceled its subscriptions to The Times and The Washington Post. Will our business survive? Will the Republic?

headline: The Life and Death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi
abstract: While the leader of ISIS is dead, his legacy of extremism and brutality may live on in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Google Misled Consumers Over Location Tracking, Australia Says
abstract: The company did not disclose the need to disable two different Android settings to stop data collection, regulators said in a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian regulators on Tuesday accused Google of misleading consumers about its collection of their personal location information through its Android mobile operating system, the latest government action against a tech company over its handling of vast quantities of user data.

headline: What to Expect When Boeing’s C.E.O. Faces Congress Today
abstract: Dennis Muilenburg will appear before Congress for the first time since the crashes of two 737 Max jets mired the company in crisis.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers including Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, Reed Hastings of Netflix and Dara Khosrowshahi of Uber. Apply to attend here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: A Show That Laughs at Boris Johnson, and May Have Aided His Rise
abstract: The prime minister’s early appearances on “Have I Got News For You,” a comedy show, helped endear him to the British public.
lead_paragraph: BOREHAMWOOD, England — There are many theories about how Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, and Jacob Rees-Mogg, another politician leading Britain’s exit from the European Union, rose to power.

headline: Democrats’ Secret Plan to Kill Third Parties in New York
abstract: The state party chairman, an ally of Gov. Andrew Cuomo, wants to quintuple the number of votes that a political party needs to secure a ballot line.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the New York State Democratic Party is pushing a proposal that would essentially neuter almost all third parties, crippling one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s biggest political nemeses but also potentially helping conservatives.

headline: U.K. to Hold Election in December, Opening New Phase in Brexit Odyssey
abstract: The vote throws back to the British people the bedeviling issue of how, or even if, their country should leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, in the boldest gamble of his high-wire political career, won backing on Tuesday to hold a general election on Dec. 12, throwing back to the British people the bedeviling issue of how, or even if, their country should leave the European Union.

headline: Grenfell Tower Report Faults Fire Brigade’s Response
abstract: Fewer people might have died in a 2017 fire in a London high-rise if they had not been told to stay put, a government analysis concluded.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some of the 72 people who died in the Grenfell Tower fire in 2017 would have survived if firefighters and emergency operators had not told them to stay in their apartments, according to a government report to be released on Wednesday.

headline: What Grievances Do You Have With Your Local Community?
abstract: What daily frustrations do you experience living in your town or city? How would you address them?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been late to school because of traffic? Or seen your city’s streets littered with trash? Or wondered why your neighborhood doesn’t have more bicycle lanes?

headline: Strong Winds Fan California Fires, Prompting Severe ‘Red Flag’ Warnings
abstract: As the weather worsens on Tuesday, the Kincade and Getty fires are straining the resources of fire departments across the state.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here for our California Today newsletter and read our Live Briefing following today’s developments in the California fires.

headline: Bears Ears and Notre-Dame Named to 2020 World Monuments Watch
abstract: The World Monuments Fund’s biennial selection of 25 at-risk cultural heritage sites also includes Easter Island in Chile and the Sacred Valley of the Incas in Peru.
lead_paragraph: The Notre-Dame de Paris, which suffered a devastating fire earlier this year, and Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, which is the subject of a legal battle with implications for the future of protected public lands across the United States, have been named to the 2020 World Monuments Watch, a biennial list of cultural heritage sites that are in urgent need of conservation.

headline: Strike Will Cost G.M. Nearly $3 Billion in 2019 Earnings, Company Says
abstract: The bigger financial effect is expected to be reflected in the current quarter, as the walkout halted North American production for most of October.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has offered its first accounting of the financial toll from a six-week strike. And its preview of the months ahead reflected why it was willing to endure the walkout.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Raid in Syria, California Fires, Google
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: The Color of Protest
abstract: Banning the import of black clothing to Hong Kong misses the point when it comes to clothing and opposition.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world where you couldn’t wear black.

headline: How to Put On a Show
abstract: See how Audemars Piguet’s “Beyond Watchmaking” exhibition came to life. Set in Tokyo, it tells the story of how modern art and design come together in celebration of craftsmanship, innovation and the nature of time.
lead_paragraph: See how Audemars Piguet’s “Beyond Watchmaking” exhibition came to life. Set in Tokyo, it tells the story of how modern art and design come together in celebration of craftsmanship, innovation and the nature of time.

headline: ‘Public Sentiment Is Everything’
abstract: Impeachment’s next stage.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Australia Proposes Face Scans for Watching Online Pornography
abstract: As a government agency seeks approval of a facial recognition system, it says one use for it could be verifying the age of people who want to view pornography online.
lead_paragraph: The Australian government has proposed using a facial recognition system it is developing to verify that people who seek to watch pornography online are of legal age.

headline: Wildfires Are Pushing Californians Out of the State: ‘If It’s Gone, We’re Gone’
abstract: Tuesday: More updates from the Kincade and Getty fires; and how to help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Read Alexander Vindman’s Opening Statement on Trump and Ukraine
abstract: He twice reported concerns about President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine, according to a draft statement.
lead_paragraph: He twice reported concerns about President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine, according to a draft statement.

headline: The Often-Familiar Streets of Cheviot Hills
abstract: When there is a flurry of activity in the neighborhood. it’s sometimes because are crews shooting TV shows like “The Goldbergs” and “Modern Family.”
lead_paragraph: When there is a flurry of activity in the neighborhood. it’s sometimes because are crews shooting TV shows like “The Goldbergs” and “Modern Family.”

headline: Cheviot Hills, Los Angeles: Quiet Affluence Amid the Urban Hustle
abstract: There is little to disturb the peace in this neighborhood of winding streets and single-family homes, which you might recognize from TV or the movies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nancy and Howard Shapiro were looking for a fresh start in 2018, and for good reason. Their daughter, Elysa, now 8, had spent the past two years battling leukemia, and the Shapiros were beginning to feel like they were spending more time at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center than they were in their $2 million Cheviot Hills home.

headline: World’s 14 Highest Peaks in 6 Months: Nepali Smashes Climbing Record
abstract: The fastest previous ascent of all the mountains over 8,000 meters took nearly eight years, but Nirmal Purja did it in little more than six months.
lead_paragraph: A Nepali climber has reached the summit of the world’s 14 highest mountains in just over six months, setting a record for a feat that took other climbers years to complete.

headline: Duane Michals Searches the Morgan and Finds Himself
abstract: The photographer’s Odyssean journey led to a dialogue with the museum’s treasures.
lead_paragraph: Duane Michals, the pioneer of still-image, multiframe sequences that introduced storytelling to modern photography, stood in the conservation lab of the Morgan Library & Museum one recent autumn day discussing his two-year treasure hunt through the institution’s vast collection of works, and their relevance to his own.

headline: Giancarlo Esposito Didn’t Get to Keep His ‘Star Wars’ Weapons
abstract: The actor, best known as Gus Fring on “Breaking Bad,” discusses his role on the new sci-fi spinoff series “The Mandalorian.”
lead_paragraph: Power just seems to suit Giancarlo Esposito, and he has wielded it memorably in his best known television roles, whether he is playing Gus Fring, the devious drug lord of “Breaking Bad” and “Better Call Saul,” or the pioneering civil rights leader Adam Clayton Powell Jr. on “Godfather of Harlem.”

headline: Advice for Running the Paul Taylor Company? ‘Keep Them Laughing’
abstract: The artistic director Michael Novak talks about balancing heritage and new, bringing in audiences and making sure there’s enough fun.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Taylor asked Michael Novak to take over his organization after he buzzed off — that was the way Taylor put it — both knew what a challenge the job would be.

headline: Lebanon’s Prime Minister, Saad Hariri, Steps Down in Face of Protests
abstract: With no clear alternative to the current leadership and the economy veering toward collapse, his resignation only threw the country into  further political uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon offered his resignation on Tuesday, bowing to a demand of the enormous antigovernment protests that have consumed the country and suspended daily life for nearly two weeks.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: A White House official said he tried to correct missing words in the transcript of a call between President Trump and Ukraine’s president.
lead_paragraph: Colonel Vindman’s testimony is significant not just because he’s the first witness who listened in on the July 25 call, but also because of his background: He’s a refugee from Ukraine who fought in the Iraq War. I talked to my colleague Sheryl Gay Stolberg, who wrote today about Colonel Vindman.

headline: Finding a Niche in the U.S. Was Hard. Then She Found a Career Path.
abstract: Vivinasviyanty Polanco moved to the United States for a fresh start. After her daughter was born, a job training program helped her discover fulfillment and financial security.
lead_paragraph: Vivinasviyanty Polanco was just 17 when her mother died of a heart attack. Her father died five years later, when she was in college.

headline: Murray Energy Is 8th Coal Company in a Year to Seek Bankruptcy
abstract: The company, led by a political ally of President Trump, is the latest casualty of a switch by utilities to natural gas and renewable energy sources.
lead_paragraph: Murray Energy, once a symbol of American mining prowess, has become the eighth coal company in a year to file for bankruptcy protection. The move on Tuesday is the latest sign that market forces are throttling the Trump administration’s bid to save the industry.

headline: The Nature of Time Reimagined
abstract: See how the artists Mathieu Lehanneur, Dan Holdsworth, Ryoji Ikeda and Alexandre Joly use photography, sound, sculpture and data to create unique worlds for Audemars Piguet’s “Beyond Watchmaking” exhibition in Tokyo. All have been inspired by the notion of time and the watchmaker’s origins in Switzerland’s Vallée de Joux.
lead_paragraph: See how the artists Mathieu Lehanneur, Dan Holdsworth, Ryoji Ikeda and Alexandre Joly use photography, sound, sculpture and data to create unique worlds for Audemars Piguet’s “Beyond Watchmaking” exhibition in Tokyo. All have been inspired by the notion of time and the watchmaker’s origins in Switzerland’s Vallée de Joux.

headline: Dos and Don’ts of Thank-You Notes
abstract: Etiquette experts and professional card writers offer advice for making the process easier and even go a little faster.
lead_paragraph: In the afterglow of a wedding or honeymoon, sitting down to write personalized thank-you notes can be a daunting, and often dreaded, task for most couples, especially those couples who have had large weddings.

headline: Re-Enter the ‘Data-Verse’
abstract: Ryoji Ikeda’s audiovisual trilogy, which launched at the Venice Biennale earlier this year, takes viewers on an immersive journey from the microscopic to the human, to the cosmic. Commissioned by Audemars Piguet, the second piece was unveiled at the Maison’s exhibition “Beyond Watchmaking” in Tokyo, which explores the topics of time, complexity and precision.
lead_paragraph: Ryoji Ikeda’s audiovisual trilogy, which launched at the Venice Biennale earlier this year, takes viewers on an immersive journey from the microscopic to the human, to the cosmic. Commissioned by Audemars Piguet, the second piece was unveiled at the Maison’s exhibition “Beyond Watchmaking” in Tokyo, which explores the topics of time, complexity and precision.

headline: Brexit Coins Head for Scrap Heap After Deadline Is Extended
abstract: The 50-pence pieces emblazoned with “Oct. 31, 2019” will be recycled. (So will those with “March 29.”)
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledged that Britain would leave the European Union on Oct. 31, “do or die,” the government was so confident of the timeline that it minted thousands, possibly millions, of commemorative 50-pence Brexit coins including that date.

headline: The Arepas That Transport One Venezuelan Performance Artist Back Home
abstract: Migguel Anggelo shares the recipe for a dish he ate growing up on his family’s farm.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: The House That Porterhouse Built
abstract: Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn serves a nearly unchanging menu that revolves around broiled porterhouse steaks, available in portions for one, two, three or four people.
lead_paragraph: Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn serves a nearly unchanging menu that revolves around broiled porterhouse steaks, available in portions for one, two, three or four people.

headline: Peter Luger Used to Sizzle. Now It Sputters.
abstract: The famed restaurant, which once defined the New York steakhouse experience, has lost its way.
lead_paragraph: I can count on Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn to produce certain sensations at every meal.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From John le Carré to Adam Rippon
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE SECRET COMMONWEALTH, by Philip Pullman, read by Michael Sheen. (Listening Library.) The Welsh actor narrates the second installment of Pullman’s best-selling fantasy trilogy “The Book of Dust.”

headline: Trump’s Deficits Are an Existential Threat to Conservatism
