abstract: A movement built around limiting the burden that government places on citizens could be crushed by staggering debt.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Treasury Department announced that the federal deficit was just shy of $1 trillion in the 2019 fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. The Congressional Budget Office expects deficits to exceed that mark every year going forward.

headline: Stories From Slavery, Shared Over Generations
abstract: We asked readers of The 1619 Project to share photographs and stories of their enslaved ancestors.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers of The 1619 Project to share photographs and stories of their enslaved ancestors.

headline: Opioids Are an Equal-Opportunity Killer
abstract: The crisis brings misery to all races, parties and classes. My son died after taking a Xanax pill laced with fentanyl.
lead_paragraph: It’s become a depressing fact that American politics is so polarized. That’s also true about where we live and work. We rarely interact with people from the hated other party, except maybe an outcast relative at Thanksgiving.

headline: Alabama Abortion Ban Is Temporarily Blocked by a Federal Judge
abstract: The Alabama law, which would have forbidden abortions in almost every instance, was scheduled to take effect on Nov. 15.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked a near-total ban on abortions from taking effect next month in Alabama, ensuring the procedure remains legal and available in the state while the case winds its way through the courts.

headline: Seeing ‘Oklahoma!’ One More Time? She Cain’t Say No
abstract: Tricia Tait has attended the Tony-winning musical revival 55 times so far. At the 50th, the cast gave her a standing ovation.
lead_paragraph: Legs splayed and eyelashes batting, the comic cowboy Will Parker was flirting with a woman seated in the front row at “Oklahoma!” The audience whooped as her neighbors squirmed. Tricia Tait cackled from across the theater, clearly in on the joke. “I’ve been in that gal’s seat before,” she whispered.

headline: John Legend Updates ‘Baby, It’s Cold Outside’ for the #MeToo Era
abstract: Legend and Kelly Clarkson replaced lyrics that some considered an allusion to date rape. Gone: “Say, what’s in this drink?” New: “It’s your body, and your choice.”
lead_paragraph: For those who have deleted the holiday classic “Baby, It’s Cold Outside” from their festive playlist in recent years, this one’s for you.

headline: Before You Fill That Prescription, You May Want to Read These Books
abstract: Antibiotics are lifesavers — but there’s another side to the story.
lead_paragraph: When antibiotics first came to market barely 70 years ago, they were clear evidence of modern medicine’s power. These days, they are equally potent evidence of its limitations. Experts warn that we’re entering a “post-antibiotic era” full of microbes that eat our puny drugs for breakfast while fomenting new infections that are as untreatable as infections were centuries ago.

headline: 10 Reasons Washington Is a Great Restaurant City
abstract: The capital’s dining scene has gotten a bad rap as stodgy, status-driven and lacking a strong identity. These restaurants prove otherwise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2016, Andrew Knowlton, then the restaurant editor of Bon Appétit, proposed that the magazine name Washington its restaurant city of the year. It was a difficult argument to make, even to the magazine’s editor, Adam Rapoport, a Washington native.

headline: Plane Crash: Cardiologist Dies as His Cessna Hits N.J. Home
abstract: The plane crashed through the roof and into the basement of a home in Colonia, causing a fire that also engulfed two adjacent homes.
lead_paragraph: A small plane piloted by a prominent cardiologist heading toward New York City for a lecture was spotted flying unusually low just before 11 a.m. on Tuesday.

headline: A Sun God? A Cyborg? No, It’s a George Condo Creation
abstract: The artist’s new sculpture at Lincoln Center Plaza has eye-popping dazzle. And it makes faces.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Lincoln Center Plaza may be dazzled or disoriented by the light bouncing from the 24-karat-gold-leaf surface of George Condo’s new sculptural spectacle, rising more than 13 feet on the terrace of the Metropolitan Opera’s facade.

headline: Rising Seas Will Erase More Cities by 2050, New Research Shows
abstract: Scientists devised a better way to calculate land elevations and their findings are dire: Far more cities will be inundated by climate change than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Scientists devised a better way to calculate land elevations and their findings are dire: Far more cities will be inundated by climate change than previously thought.

headline: Joel Quenneville Brings His Stanley Cup Pedigree to Florida
abstract: Quenneville, who won three championships in Chicago, was hired by the Panthers to coach them out of mediocrity.
lead_paragraph: Joel Quenneville wanted to make it clear: He did not take the job as coach of the Florida Panthers because  he wanted to be closer to South Florida’s many golf courses.

headline: Notorious Killer’s Bid for Parole Reopens Old Wounds in Belgium
abstract: A court allowed a new psychiatric exam of Marc Dutroux, who was given a life sentence for murders and rapes that shocked the country in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Marc Dutroux is one of Belgium’s most reviled criminals, serving a life sentence for the abduction, rape and murder of several girls and young women in the 1990s.

headline: Recall of Generic Version of Xanax Is Announced by F.D.A.
abstract: The manufacturer, Mylan Pharmaceuticals, said a batch of alprazolam tablets distributed in July and August might contain a foreign substance.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has announced a nationwide recall of a batch of alprazolam, a generic version of Xanax, because of potential contamination.

headline: An East Village Wine Bar Cruises the Adriatic
abstract: A lounge from the team behind Black Tap Craft Burgers, a bar for beer lovers, and more restaurant news.

headline: Sadako Ogata, First Woman to Lead U.N. Refugee Agency, Dies at 92
abstract: Appointed to the position in 1991, she oversaw refugee operations at a time of ravaging conflict in the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda, Iraq and other regions.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sadako Ogata, the first woman to be named the United Nations high commissioner for refugees and the first Japanese national to hold that position, died on Oct. 22 in Tokyo. She was 92.

headline: Till Seth Do Us Part
abstract: Get out your Ouija boards, pilgrims, for the return of a mysterious ’60s spirit.
lead_paragraph: ELMIRA, N.Y. — Off the main street of this small upstate city, there is a crumbling three-story mansion with an overgrown lawn and peeling paint. The roof droops. The banisters are splintered.

headline: Searching for a Democratic Savior
abstract: Readers put forth names of people they’d like to see enter the race.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fans Were Surprised to Get More Gang Starr. They Almost Didn’t.
abstract: The rap duo’s last album was released in 2003. After the death of its M.C., Guru, and an ongoing dispute between the producers DJ Premier and DJ Solar, a posthumous release is on the way.
lead_paragraph: The last time DJ Premier saw Guru, his partner in the influential 1980s and ’90s rap group Gang Starr, it was March 2010. Gang Starr hadn’t dropped an album in seven years, and the duo had stopped communicating entirely. But the time to make amends had come too late: The 48-year-old rapper was in a medically induced coma at Good Samaritan Hospital in Rockland County, N.Y., living out his last days with multiple myeloma, a rare form of cancer.

headline: Meyer Ackerman, 96, Whose Theaters Were Loved by Cinephiles, Dies
abstract: His single-screen cinemas in and around New York brought foreign and other hard-to-find films to hungry audiences.
lead_paragraph: Meyer Ackerman, whose movie theaters brought hard-to-find films to audiences in and around New York City in the decades before home video and the internet made hidden cinematic gems easier to access, died on Oct. 21 in White Plains, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘She Was Too Cool to Wear a Costume’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years into our friendship, when we were finally both single, Angie and I met for a screening of “Harold and Maude” in San Francisco’s Dolores Park. I waited at her door wearing a faux-leather miniskirt, a midriff-bearing top and platform boots. She came out in a button-down shirt, a tie, dark jeans and men’s Italian loafers. Instantly, we knew that, in different ways, we had each dressed for a date. Two children later, we still differ in many things: how to load the dishwasher and enforce bedtimes, but also, most importantly, how to lure each other back in. — Elizabeth Stark

headline: Fall’s Boldest Men’s Wear, Photographed in Vietnam
abstract: Headwear, sweaters and bags in graphic patterns and shapes stand out from the crowds in bustling Ho Chi Minh City.
lead_paragraph: Dressing for autumn can feel like an exercise in putting on just enough garments to further prolong breaking out one’s parka. This season, though, layers are anything but modest. Photographed in and around the bustling street markets of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, headwear, sweaters and bags in graphic patterns and shapes stand out from the crowds. Below, a cast of the city’s young motorcyclists model fall’s most vibrant pieces at the Cholon, Cho Ben Thanh and Cho Ba Chieu markets.

headline: Afghan Government Demands Cease-Fire Before Any Taliban Talks
abstract: The new precondition is likely to complicate any revival of the peace negotiations called off last month by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government said on Tuesday that it would not take part in negotiations with Taliban unless a cease-fire had first held for at least a month, a demand that is likely to face resistance from the insurgents and complicate the revival of peace efforts that were upended by President Trump.

headline: Where to Stay, and Where to Eat Noodle Soup, in Ho Chi Minh City
abstract: A guide to the shopping malls and street food of Vietnam’s largest, most exhilarating, metropolis.
lead_paragraph: For a place with so much history — decades of wartime and occupation have left their scars — Ho Chi Minh City (still often referred to as Saigon) feels surprisingly new. The metropolis is constantly reinventing itself, and when you consider that the U.S. trade embargo was lifted only 25 years ago, and that the majority of the city’s population is under 35 years old, you begin to understand why.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The electrical measurement known as the AMPERE, or “amp,” has appeared in the New York Times Crossword 103 times, yet many solvers missed this entry in the Tuesday, Oct. 22 crossword puzzle. Let’s take a closer look at it and the way it might be clued so solvers are more likely to get it next time.

headline: New Curator of Old Musicals: Lear deBessonet Is to Lead Encores!
abstract: She will succeed Jack Viertel, the longtime artistic director of this popular City Center series, which revives shows of the past.
lead_paragraph: Lear deBessonet, a theater director who grew up in Baton Rouge, La., didn’t see a professional production of a musical until she was 17, when her school choir, on a trip to New York, got seats to “Rent” and “Les Misérables.”

headline: After Vindman’s Testimony Went Public, Right-Wing Conspiracies Fired Up
abstract: Just before the Purple Heart recipient spoke to House impeachment investigators, a host at Fox News and right-wing internet figures questioned his patriotism.
lead_paragraph: Prominent right-wing media commentators have sought for weeks to cast aspersions on the House impeachment inquiry into President Trump, echoing the president’s repeated cries of “witch hunt!” and framing the investigation as motivated by political bias.

headline: California Fires: The New Normal?
abstract: A high school student says she should not have to worry about air quality or whether her power will be shut off.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Brazil Is Burning, and We’re Just Performing a Lot of Abstract Gestures’
abstract: The choreographer Bruno Beltrão is challenging the conventions of hip-hop while grappling with his country’s volatile politics.
lead_paragraph: This summer, as fires scorched portions of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil, and the country’s president, Jair Bolsonaro, dismissed international outrage about it, the choreographer Bruno Beltrão wondered whether dance could make a meaningful contribution to his country.

headline: Harry Dunn’s Parents Say They Will Sue Trump Administration
abstract: The parents of a teenager killed in a motorcycle crash in Britain are also taking legal action against the American woman thought to be driving the car that struck him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The family of Harry Dunn, the teenage motorcyclist who was killed in a crash in Britain in August, is suing the Trump administration for “lawless misconduct,” a spokesman for the family said on Tuesday.

headline: At MoMA, a Musical Pioneer’s Rainforest Squeaks and Chirrups
abstract: David Tudor’s installation “Rainforest V (variation 1)” is coming alive through performances by the artists who helped make it.
lead_paragraph: Since the Museum of Modern Art reopened this month, it has devoted its fourth-floor Studio space to a strangely wonderful, interactive installation: David Tudor’s “Rainforest V (variation 1).” Throughout the room hang about 20 mundane objects, including a metal barrel, a wooden box, a lampshade, a reflective disc, a glass jar, a vintage computer’s hard drive and more. Collectively they become a kind of urban jungle, suspended like Calder mobiles with the anti-utilitarian aesthetic of Duchamp readymades.

headline: N.J. Home Bursts Into Flames After Small Plane Crash
abstract: A Cessna crashed into a house in Colonia, N.J., on Tuesday morning. Only a pilot was aboard the plane and no one on the ground was injured, a local official said.
lead_paragraph: A Cessna crashed into a house in Colonia, N.J., on Tuesday morning. Only a pilot was aboard the plane and no one on the ground was injured, a local official said.

headline: Producers of ‘Game of Thrones’ Quit ‘Star Wars’ to Focus on Netflix
abstract: David Benioff and D.B. Weiss, who have a deal with Netflix to create TV shows and feature films, reportedly said they felt they “could not do justice to both” their Netflix projects and the “Star Wars” films they had previously signed on for.
lead_paragraph: The “Star Wars” universe lost two super producers before they could even get a project onto the silver screen.

headline: Convicted Rapist Released From Georgia Prison ‘in Error’
abstract: The authorities were carrying out a manhunt for the inmate after he walked free, apparently by accident, the state Department of Corrections said.
lead_paragraph: A manhunt is underway in Georgia for a convicted rapist and child molester who is serving a life sentence and was released “in error,” the authorities said.

headline: ‘Redoubt’ Review: Diana the Huntress Manifests in Idaho
abstract: Breathtakingly beautiful and with little spoken dialogue, Matthew Barney’s film is a western that reaches for the cosmic.
lead_paragraph: As has been noted in other reviews of his work, the artist Matthew Barney does not make films via Hollywood or its indie arm. The multimedia artist produces them with art-world money, and often uses them as portions of larger gallery work. The movies are beautifully made, with high-gloss visuals and production values. They’re often provocative, with depictions of explicit sex and, in 2015’s “River of Fundament,” persistent consideration of fecal matter.

headline: When a Crowd Boos Trump, Is It O.K. to Revel?
abstract: One reader says “you betcha!,” the president absolutely deserved it, while another worries that it just increases partisan animosity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Stars Return to Saudi Investment Conference a Year After Khashoggi
abstract: A year after boycotting after the killing of a dissident journalist, the big names of business and politics return to Riyadh.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — World leaders and business executives converged upon the palatial Ritz-Carlton hotel on Tuesday, putting concerns about Saudi Arabia’s role in the 2018 murder of a dissident journalist behind them and returning unabashedly to deal-making.

headline: WhatsApp Says Israeli Firm Used Its App in Spy Program
abstract: In a federal lawsuit, the messaging service said 1,400 WhatsApp accounts were targeted, including those of 100 journalists and human-rights activists.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — WhatsApp sued the Israeli cybersurveillance firm NSO Group in federal court on Tuesday, claiming the company’s spy technology was used on the popular messaging service in a wide-ranging campaign targeting journalists and human-rights activists.

headline: Debunking 4 Viral Rumors About the Bidens and Ukraine
abstract: As lawmakers examine whether President Trump pushed Ukraine to investigate the Biden family, here are some of the most prominent falsehoods that have spread online and an explanation of what really happened.
lead_paragraph: Accusations that President Trump shaped American policy toward Ukraine for his own political gain exploded into a crisis for the White House in September after a whistle-blower complaint. Lawmakers have been examining how Mr. Trump pushed the Ukrainians to investigate the hacking of the Democratic National Committee in 2016 and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son Hunter, a lawyer and former lobbyist. Those questions are now at the center of the House’s impeachment inquiry.

headline: Grandfather Charged in Toddler’s Fatal Fall From Cruise Ship
abstract: Salvatore Anello, who dropped his granddaughter from a cruise ship window in July, was charged with negligent homicide in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: The grandfather of a child who fell to her death as he held her near a window on a cruise ship has been charged with negligent homicide, the Puerto Rico Department of Justice announced on Monday.

headline: Al Bianchi, Pro Basketball Coach and Knicks G.M., Dies at 87
abstract: He made his N.B.A. debut as a player in 1956, oversaw a promising but short-lived revival of the Knicks in the 1980s and remained active into the 21st century.

headline: Mumbai’s Midnight Gardeners
abstract: Meet the people who keep their city running while the rest of the world sleeps.
lead_paragraph: Meet the people who keep their city running while the rest of the world sleeps.

headline: Just How Bad Are the Miami Dolphins?
abstract: Monday night’s loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers looked bad, as did the six before it. But are the winless Dolphins the N.F.L.’s worst team?
lead_paragraph: The Miami Dolphins lost on Monday night. Again. That makes them 0-7 on the season.

headline: ‘In the Dream House’ Recounts an Abusive Relationship Using Dozens of Genres
abstract: Carmen Maria Machado follows up her acclaimed collection of stories, “Her Body and Other Parties,” with a memoir about her frightening relationship with another woman while in graduate school.
lead_paragraph: All ornate appearances to the contrary, the gothic is a thrifty form. Its first, and essential, ingredients, according to the scholar Mary Ann Doane, are simply “woman plus habitation.” No special effects needed; the horror of a woman finding fear where she expected safety is enough to power an entire genre.

headline: The Midnight Gardeners of Mumbai
abstract: Meet the people who keep their city running while the rest of the world sleeps.
lead_paragraph: Mumbai is to India what New York is to the United States — a gateway to the world and a world within itself, bursting with life, holding the dreams of millions. Many of these Mumbaikers work at night, part of a vast economy that keeps the city running. Because they’re on the job while much of the city is asleep, their efforts go unseen and unnoticed.

headline: Kentucky Governor’s Race Tests Impact of Impeachment in States
abstract: Matt Bevin, the unpopular Republican incumbent, has strongly aligned himself with President Trump and invoking impeachment as a cudgel against his opponent, Andy Beshear.
lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Ky. — Addressing a group of Democratic activists last week, Kentucky’s attorney general and nominee for governor, Andy Beshear, flayed his Republican opponent, Gov. Matt Bevin, for his record and his incendiary conduct to argue why voters should oust the incumbent. In the audience here a lawyer wore an oversized “IMPEACH” button, but Mr. Beshear made clear that his concerns were strictly local.

headline: Pierre Delecto, QAnon and the Paradox of Anonymity
abstract: In 2019, it’s somehow both easier and harder than ever to be anonymous.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $5.75 MILLION

headline: Democrats Unveil Proposed Rules for Public Impeachment Proceedings
abstract: The resolution, which is scheduled for a House vote on Thursday, would require the production of a public report and allow for due process rights for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s lawyers would be allowed to present a formal defense of him and cross-examine witnesses once the House Judiciary Committee begins debate over whether to impeach him, under proposed rules House Democrats unveiled on Tuesday to begin the next, more public phase of their inquiry.

headline: Brexit, Climate Change, Boeing: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Britain heads into a general election.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: N.C.A.A. Considers Loosening Rules for Athletes Seeking Outside Deals
abstract: The governing body for college sports appeared to soften its long-held stance that athletes should not profit from their fame. But it gave no details and said any rule changes required much more discussion.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The N.C.A.A. Board of Governors, under increasing pressure from legislatures around the country, voted Tuesday to pave the way for college athletes to profit off their fame, but the decision came with an elephant-size caveat: Any  policy changes must maintain clear distinctions between amateur athletes and professional ones.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Says Recalled Baby Powder Doesn’t Have Asbestos
abstract: The F.D.A. had said it discovered evidence of the carcinogen in a bottle.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that it did not find asbestos in multiple tests of a bottle of baby powder that the Food and Drug Administration said contained trace amounts of the carcinogen.

headline: Navy Reduces Punishment for SEAL in War Crimes Case
abstract: Edward Gallagher was demoted by a single rank, not all the way to the bottom, but his conviction on a minor count will stand, the Navy’s top admiral said.
lead_paragraph: The Navy SEAL at the center of one of the highest-profile war crimes cases in years had his punishment drastically reduced Tuesday by the Navy’s top admiral, sparing the SEAL from the most serious consequence he still faced, a steep demotion that would have cost him hundreds of thousands of dollars in retirement pay.

headline: A New Twist on Vancouver’s Skyline
abstract: The look of the city, known for its ‘Vancouverism’ design, is changing as the real estate market adapts to the spread of luxury housing and a tech-fueled office boom.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A pioneer in high-density urban development, Vancouver is famous for its approach to city planning, heavy on tall glass towers perched atop low-rise podiums interspersed by parks and low-rise buildings.

headline: ‘Bars and Measures’ Review: Notes From Jail
abstract: Jazz unites two brothers, one accused of plotting terrorism, in Idris Goodwin’s play.
lead_paragraph: Across the table from each other in a jail’s visiting room, the brothers are scatting, their vocal jam making sweet jazz in a cold, hard space where instruments are not allowed.

headline: Deadspin Editor Fired Amid Pushback Over ‘Stick to Sports’ Memo
abstract: Deadspin, a sports news site, is the latest blog in the G/O Media universe involved in an escalating conflict with its new owner.
lead_paragraph: A popular sports website was told to stick to sports — and staff members revolted.

headline: Can PG&E Survive the California Wildfires?
abstract: Hedge funds, fire victims and public officials all have a stake in what becomes of the giant utility, now in bankruptcy. And Warren Buffett’s name is being invoked.
lead_paragraph: California’s Pacific Gas & Electric problem isn’t going away.

headline: What If Netflix, but Twice as Fast?
abstract: Twice the speed could help you get double the Bojack.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has confirmed and also downplayed a report that it is testing a feature on cellphones that allows users to speed up (or slow down) its videos.

headline: Readers Respond to the Pete Wells Review of Peter Luger: ‘Finally’
abstract: Our readers by and large delighted in our critic’s takedown of a popular Brooklyn steakhouse.
lead_paragraph: When our restaurant critic Pete Wells’s zero-star review of Peter Luger Steak House published on Tuesday, New York Times readers celebrated: At last, someone said it.

headline: Nationals Overcome Astros in Game 6 to Extend World Series
abstract: Home runs from Adam Eaton, Juan Soto and Anthony Rendon, along with a stellar outing by Stephen Strasburg, helped Washington force a Game 7.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They started the year together at the same spring training site in West Palm Beach, Fla., went their separate ways for a long regular season and reconvened half a year later in the World Series. Now their long, circuitous journeys will end in Game 7 of the World Series.

headline: HBO Max, Out in May, Will Cost More Than Netflix
abstract: The streaming service will offer some 10,000 hours of programming, including a “Game of Thrones” prequel in place of one that was scrapped earlier in the day.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — WarnerMedia executives took the stage on Tuesday to formally introduce the streaming service HBO Max, the future exclusive online home for “Game of Thrones,” “Friends,” “The Big Bang Theory,” the Harry Potter films and movies centered on DC Comics superheroes like Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman.

headline: The Arab Spring Rekindled in Beirut
abstract: The Lebanese government falls to a popular uprising as Iran’s role across the Middle East is questioned.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Eight years after the Arab Spring, massive street protests over corruption, sectarianism and official contempt for the citizenry have brought down the Lebanese government of Prime Minister Saad Hariri. The sources of Arab rage have not changed.

headline: Abused, Addicted, Biracial and Queer: Jaquira Díaz Is Anything but ‘Ordinary’
abstract: Her debut memoir, “Ordinary Girls,” recounts her rise from troubled youth to literary success.
lead_paragraph: ORDINARY GIRLS A Memoir By Jaquira Díaz

headline: In Another Bipartisan Rebuke of Trump, House Votes for Sanctions Against Turkey
abstract: House Republicans broke from President Trump en masse for a second time this month to condemn his foreign policy in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to impose a series of sweeping sanctions on Turkey over its brutal assault on the Kurds in northern Syria, dealing its second bipartisan rebuke to President Trump this month for pulling back American forces to allow for the Turkish incursion.

headline: Can California Save Itself From Burning?
abstract: Wildfires are creating a chronic emergency for the state — and it’s only getting worse.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Chou Wen-chung, Composer and Calligrapher in Sound, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Chou taught the leading Chinese composers of the day and was an assistant to the modernist master Edgard Varèse, whose legacy he tended.
lead_paragraph: Chou Wen-chung, a composer, teacher and cultural diplomat who taught a coterie of celebrated and award-winning Chinese composers and who tended to the legacy of Edgard Varèse, the linchpin of American modernism, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Detentions of Child Migrants at the U.S. Border Surges to Record Levels
abstract: Detentions have surged as the Trump administration’s aggressive policy toward migrants has collided with an exodus of children fleeing Central America.
lead_paragraph: TENOSIQUE, Mexico — The United States has detained more children trying to cross the nation’s southwest border on their own over the last year than during any other period on record, surpassing the surge of unaccompanied minors that set off a crisis during the Obama administration, according to new figures released Tuesday.

headline: 13 New York City Steakhouses That Are Not Peter Luger
abstract: A look at some classic steakhouses, as reviewed by our restaurant critics.
lead_paragraph: This week Pete Wells reviewed the classic New York steakhouse Peter Luger, demoting it from two to zero stars. Here are some of the other steakhouses that our critics have reviewed through the years.

headline: Huang Yong Ping, 65, Dies; His Art Saw a World of Power Struggles
abstract: His startling conceptual pieces (in one case using live creatures) commented on humanity, challenged conventional notions of art and sought to erase the artist’s ego.
lead_paragraph: Huang Yong Ping, a Conceptual artist and pioneering figure of China’s post-Cultural Revolution avant-garde, whose controversial work often depicted the world as a Darwinian power struggle, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Paris. He was 65.

headline: Impeachment, California Fires, Peter Luger: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Warren’s One TV Ad
abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s presidential campaign has aired just a single TV spot so far, costing $27,000.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Thomas Kaplan, and I cover Elizabeth Warren on the campaign trail.

headline: U.S. Blames Drug Shortages on Low Prices and a ‘Broken Marketplace’
abstract: A government task force suggested that providers pay more for lifesaving generics and that drug makers receive quality ratings.
lead_paragraph: Chronic drug shortages that threaten patient care are caused by rock-bottom prices for older generic medicines and a health care marketplace that doesn’t run on the rules of supply and demand, among other factors, according to a federal report published on Tuesday.

headline: Make Go-Go D.C.’s Official Music
abstract: New legislation would cement the sound’s rightful place at the center of this gentrifying city’s culture.
lead_paragraph: African drums have been criminalized around the world for centuries. Even as freedom from slavery was on the horizon, the drums were irritating white power structures. In the summer of 1838, a white Presbyterian minister living in Jamaica complained that enslaved people had organized a “ball” and that their “singing and drumming and dancing disturbed the neighborhood,” according to an account unearthed by the historian J.R. Kerr-Ritchie in “Rites of August First.”

headline: Trump, Zuckerberg & Pals Are Breaking America
abstract: Not in the Cold War, not during Vietnam, not during Watergate did I ever fear more for my country.
lead_paragraph: If America’s worst enemies had spent years designing a plan to erode our greatest strengths, they could not have done better than what some of our fellow citizens are doing to the country every day for short-term financial or political gain.

headline: Being Gay Hurts Mayor Pete. It Helps, Too.
abstract: America’s need for a savior outweighs any interest in what he or she does in bed.
lead_paragraph: Pete Buttigieg vaulted into the top four of a crowded Democratic presidential field because he has an agile intellect, is fiercely articulate and both espouses and embodies a fresh perspective that many voters of all stripes crave.

headline: Samantha Power: A Belated Recognition of Genocide by the House
abstract: For too long, Turkey bullied America into silence. Not anymore.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, by a vote of 405 to 11, the House of Representatives defied the Turkish government’s intimidation and, for the first time in 35 years, passed a resolution that recognized the Armenian genocide.

headline: ‘Fear’ Review: 3 Men in a Shed, 1 Missing Girl on Their Minds
abstract: A tepid thriller from Matt Williams leaves too much time to ponder the holes in its plot.
lead_paragraph: Suspense,  done well, captures the attention so there’s no time to notice plot holes or preposterous coincidences. Only when the story ends do you realize that you’ve been bamboozled; Lee Child’s best-selling Jack Reacher series, for example, brilliantly distracts readers from realizing the novels totally rely on absurd happenstance.

headline: A Dreary World Series Bursts to Life in Game 6
abstract: This series had largely been defined by what had happened off the field, but that changed with big performances by Stephen Strasburg and Anthony Rendon on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They call it the Fall Classic, but the name does not always apply. The World Series can be lopsided, as most of the games have been in the 115th version this year. It needed a night like Tuesday, when the Washington Nationals and the Houston Astros staged a thriller that officially made this a World Series unlike any other.

headline: Despair for Many and Silver Linings for Some in California Wildfires
abstract: Natural disasters are another prism through which California’s vast income inequalities can be viewed.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — After a wildfire razed his spacious suburban home in the Sonoma hills two years ago, Pete Parkinson set out to rebuild. This time it would be an even better one. He reoriented the house toward vistas of a nearby mountain and designed a large kitchen with hickory floors and 16-foot windows under vaulted ceilings.

headline: House Passes Resolution Recognizing Armenian Genocide
abstract: It is the first time that a chamber of Congress has officially designated the 1915 slaughter of an estimated 1.5 million Armenians as a genocide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to formally recognize the Armenian genocide and denounce it as a matter of American foreign policy, a symbolic vindication for the Armenian diaspora made possible by a new torrent of bipartisan furor at Turkey.

headline: 72 British Lawmakers Condemn ‘Colonial’ Coverage of Meghan
abstract: Dozens of women in Britain’s Parliament from across the political spectrum expressed solidarity with Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-two women in Britain’s Parliament condemned the “outdated, colonial undertones” of newspaper coverage of Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, in an open letter released Tuesday that echoed attacks made by Prince Harry against British tabloids this month.

headline: A Robbery Ring Targeted Indian-Americans. Its Leader Got 37 Years in Prison.
abstract: Chaka LeChar Castro led a string of armed home invasions against Indians and other Asian groups in Georgia, Michigan, New York, Ohio and Texas.
lead_paragraph: There was a method to the robberies: One crew member, usually a woman, would knock on the door. Then others, donning bandannas and brandishing firearms, would storm the home when someone answered and corral its occupants.

headline: Toyota’s Support of Trump Emissions Rules Shocks Californians
abstract: Toyota’s support of the Trump administration in its fight with California over auto emissions shocked consumers in a state known for its environmental activism.
lead_paragraph: Toyota usually has a soft spot for California. The automaker has promoted its Prius hybrid in ads as “redesigned, CA style,” and shown its sedans weaving through verdant Golden State scenery as a Beach Boys song plays.

headline: Why New York Can’t Pick Up Its Trash
abstract: And what the City Council is about to do to change that.
lead_paragraph: How bad is New York’s trash nightmare? So bad that, back in 2013, officials frantic to subdue the growing rat population attempted to slip the rodents birth control. But without a little seasoning, they wouldn’t touch it. Raised on New Yorkers’ rich and putrefying leavings, the rats knew they had more delectable options available to them. Researchers added flavor to the drugs to tempt the fattening critters to bite before romancing one another.

headline: White House Ukraine Expert Sought to Correct Transcript of Trump Call
abstract: Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman, who heard President Trump’s July phone call with Ukraine’s president and was alarmed, testified that he tried and failed to add key details to the rough transcript.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman, the top Ukraine expert on the National Security Council, told House impeachment investigators on Tuesday that the White House transcript of a July call between President Trump and Ukraine’s president omitted crucial words and phrases, and that his attempts to include them failed, according to three people familiar with the testimony.

headline: Corrections: October 30, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, October 30, 2019.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS

headline: Quotation of the Day: Democrats Have Diverse Field, but the Top Tier Is All White
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 30, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve had lots of crazy things said to me, like, ‘Is America ready for another black president?’ And I’m confident it’s never been asked of a white candidate, ‘Is America ready for another white president?’”

headline: ‘Tricks’ Creatures Use
abstract: David Steinberg is hiding things from us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — You know those computer-generated works of art that require you to relax your eyes to see the image? They’re called “Magic Eye” pictures or stereograms. To solve David Steinberg’s puzzle, we may have to do something like that.

headline: White House Finds Loophole in Search for Homeland Security Secretary
abstract: Officials who lead agencies in the department and echo the president’s language on immigration were initially thought to be ineligible under a federal law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has found a way to bypass a federal statute that dictates who can fill secretary positions, potentially allowing President Trump to choose whomever he wants to lead the Department of Homeland Security, according to an administration official. The route may run through an office established to counter weapons of mass destruction.

headline: Family of Antwon Rose, Teenager Killed by Police, Settles Suit for $2 Million
abstract: Antwon, an unarmed black teenager, was fatally shot last year by a white officer during a traffic stop in East Pittsburgh, Pa.
lead_paragraph: A $2 million settlement has been reached in the federal civil rights lawsuit filed by the family of Antwon Rose, an unarmed black teenager who was killed last year by a white police officer during a traffic stop in East Pittsburgh, Pa., a lawyer for the family confirmed Tuesday night.

headline: Brexit, Impeachment, Russia: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Reading Scores on National Exam Decline in Half the States
abstract: The results of the test, which assesses a sample of fourth- and eighth-grade students, will inevitably prompt demands for policy change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —  America’s fourth and eighth graders are losing ground in their ability to read literature and academic texts, according to a rigorous national assessment released Wednesday that is likely to fuel concerns over student achievement after decades of tumult on the educational landscape.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Bronx, USA’ and ‘Baroness von Sketch Show’
abstract: A documentary about the Bronx airs on HBO. And a Canadian sketch-comedy show returns on IFC.
lead_paragraph: THE BRONX, USA (2019) 9 p.m. on HBO. “Ahh, that’s the sound I used to sleep to,” the show business manager George Shapiro says in this documentary. He’s walking down a street in the Bronx with a Brooklyn Dodgers cap on his head and a smile across his face. The soothing sound he’s talking about? It’s the clang of an aboveground subway. Shapiro, who grew up in the Bronx in the 1930s and ’40s and went on to have a storied career working with comedians like Jerry Seinfeld and Carl Reiner, hosts this love letter to the Bronx, which collects interviews about the borough with a number of its famous natives. Among them are Reiner, the actor Alan Alda, the author and photographer Arlene Alda (Alan Alda’s wife), the hip-hop artist Melle Mel, the singer-songwriter Melissa Manchester, the graffiti artist John Matos and the former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. The documentary also includes interviews with members of DeWitt Clinton High School’s class of 2017, who graduated 68 years after Shapiro did. They speak to recent changes in the Bronx and to the borough’s enduring character.

headline: Word + Quiz: petulant
abstract: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Late Night Pokes Holes in Fox News’ Attempts to Discredit Decorated Soldier
abstract: “He has a Purple Heart and he has a Harvard degree,” Jimmy Fallon said of Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman. “Or as Trump put it, ‘Psh, who are you going to believe: him or me?’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

abstract: What do you think this image is saying?
lead_paragraph: In a recent article, The Times reports:

headline: Where a $5 Million War Rages Between Airbnb and the Hotel Industry
abstract: A high-stakes clash, accusations of misinformation and residents who have had enough.

headline: Britain Hasn’t Named 39 Dead in a Truck. But in Vietnam, They Know.
abstract: For the poor in Vietnam, human smuggling offers a chance at a better life. “If an electrical pole had legs, it would go too.”
lead_paragraph: YEN THANH, Vietnam — Across the village, the altar tables have already been set up.

headline: How the New Syria Took Shape
abstract: Russia, Turkey and Bashar al-Assad carved up northern Syria as the Americans retreated.
lead_paragraph: Russia, Turkey and Bashar al-Assad carved up northern Syria as the Americans retreated.

headline: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot Parent Are Expected to Merge
abstract: With the auto industry under extraordinary pressure in the shift to electric and self-driving cars, joining forces may be the best path to survival.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler and PSA of France are not exactly an automotive dream team. They lack a strong presence in China, lag in electric cars and rely heavily on the sputtering European market for sales.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘With California Ablaze, Firefighters Strain to Keep Up’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the challenges firefighters face in dealing with the raging wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “With California Ablaze, Firefighters Strain to Keep Up”

headline: Caught in U.S.-China Crossfire, Eastman Orchestra Cancels Tour
abstract: The renowned music school decided to cancel a tour of China after facing pressure from students and alumni upset over Beijing’s denial of visas to three South Korean students.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The list of American entities caught in rising tensions between China and the United States is growing: Nike, Apple, Gap and the National Basketball Association, to name a few.

headline: Why Did the Young Mother Have Searing Head Pain and a Racing Heart?
abstract: The obvious cardiac tests revealed nothing. It wasn’t until one doctor thought creatively that the culprit was found.
lead_paragraph: “Please find something wrong with me,” the 28-year-old woman pleaded. For nearly a year, she’d been looking for a reason for the strange symptoms that now dominated her life. Dr. Raphael Sung, a cardiologist specializing in finding and fixing abnormal heart rhythms at National Jewish Health hospital in Denver, was surprised by her reaction to the news that her heart was normal. Most patients are happy to get that report. For this patient, it seemed like just one more dead end.

headline: A Filmmaker Bared His Soul. It Ruined His Life.
abstract: Caveh Zahedi’s abject, self-defeating, ethically questionable, maddeningly original approach to documentary.
lead_paragraph: On the fifth episode of Caveh Zahedi’s “The Show About the Show” — a metadocumentary series that is sort of like if “Scenes From a Marriage” were crossed with “Synecdoche, New York” and then filtered through reality TV and the cheerful low-budget atmosphere of public-access cable but also a completely sui generis work of art that is nothing like any of those things and doubles as a deranged social experiment — Zahedi’s wife, Amanda Field, pleads with him to leave something on the cutting-room floor. The context is a little hard to explain; it involves the question of whether reimbursing an actor for the cocaine he snorted is as illegal as buying cocaine for yourself. But Field is upset and wants it out.

headline: Tom Brokaw Recalls His Time Covering Watergate
abstract: The broadcast journalist and best-selling author talks about his new book, “The Fall of Richard Nixon.”
lead_paragraph: Near the start of his new book, “The Fall of Richard Nixon: A Reporter Remembers Watergate,” Tom Brokaw writes that he has been “reflecting on the enduring lessons, high drama and historic consequences of that fateful year.” Brokaw, then in the early stages of his broadcasting career, was NBC’s White House correspondent during the scandal that ended Nixon’s presidency. In recounting what he saw then, Brokaw keeps the “enduring lessons” to general terms; his book makes just one sly mention of President Trump, otherwise sticking to the historical record and not wading into the current moment’s impeachment news. Below, Brokaw talks about his path to becoming a writer as well as a broadcaster, the breakneck pace of news gathering today and more.

headline: The Chocolate Cake That Saved My Vacation
abstract: This simple and bold cake brought me back to my senses after I was robbed in Lisbon. It’s proof that chocolate has the power to heal.
lead_paragraph: I don’t see how it’s possible to rack up frequent-flier points without racking up mishaps too. There will inevitably be delayed flights, bad meals, drivers who take the long way around town, lost scarves or hours spent wandering in a jet-lagged daze because your room’s not ready. Despite these annoyances — all of which I know well (I still miss the hand-knit gloves I bought in Copenhagen and left on the flight to Stockholm) — I’d always thought of myself as a lucky traveler. Until Lisbon. That’s where, earlier this year, I was felled by hubris, the tragic flaw of Macbeth and many of us who were raised in New York City.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Halloween Costume, Past or Present?
abstract: Are you planning to dress up this year?
lead_paragraph: Do you like to dress up for Halloween? Why or why not?

headline: Apple Enters Show Business With a Black-Carpet Premiere
abstract: Apple TV Plus arrives Friday with “The Morning Show,” starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston, as its flagship streaming program.
lead_paragraph: After all that — the billions spent, the deals with Big Bird, Oprah and Spielberg, the firing of a key producer, the secrecy, the breathless speculation — the moment is here. Apple is ready to take on Netflix, Amazon and Disney in the increasingly crowded entertainment industry.

headline: Billionaire’s Ugly Divorce Ignites Battle Over Spectacular Art Trove
abstract: First Harry Macklowe installed a giant photo of his new wife on the side of a building. Now he’s feuding with his ex-wife over nearly $1 billion in art.
lead_paragraph: There is the $72 million apartment, so large it runs the full length of one side of the Plaza Hotel, with windows overlooking Central Park. A second Manhattan apartment is high up in one of the tallest buildings in the Western Hemisphere, along the so-called Billionaires’ Row.

headline: How Walking Might Affect Our Sleep
abstract: Among middle-aged men and women who took about 7,000 steps a day, covering even a little extra ground was tied to better sleep.
lead_paragraph: Taking more steps during the day may be related to better sleep at night, according to an encouraging new study of lifestyle and sleep patterns. The study, which delved into the links between walking and snoozing, suggests that being active can influence how well we sleep, whether we actually exercise or not.

headline: A Preview of the Fed Meeting
abstract: Investors will be watching for any hint at what comes next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is widely expected to lower interest rates on Wednesday for a third, and potentially final, time this year. What comes next is less clear.

headline: There’s No Halloween Like a New York City Halloween
abstract: Far from the porch lights and front walks of the suburbs, trick-or-treating in the city is its own thing.
lead_paragraph: First, we needed a plan: Start at the top floor and work down. We lived on four and the building had 23 stories, but getting to the penthouse was a whole thing. So we started on 22. If the elevator was slow to arrive, you could always walk down a flight.

headline: How Americans Split on Health Care: It’s a 3-Way Tie
abstract: Despite the lack of consensus, a new survey finds that almost two-thirds of the public favors Democratic approaches.
lead_paragraph: When Americans are asked whether they support a “Medicare for all” system that would replace all current insurance with a generous government program, a majority often say yes. But when they’re asked follow-up questions, they often reveal that they’re not familiar with the details of that plan — or that they would also be happy with other Democratic policy proposals.

headline: The Best Places to Watch the New York City Marathon
abstract: With 26.2 miles stretching across the five boroughs, you’ve got plenty of options.
lead_paragraph: Training for a marathon can be a deeply solitary exercise, generally requiring runners to grind out miles multiple times a week to little fanfare.

headline: Tired, Hot or Hungry? We Found the Apps for You
abstract: The sharing economy has made it possible to be even more demanding, on demand. We tested apps for when you need a swim, a nap, a boat or a foodie experience.
lead_paragraph: Mobile travel apps, particularly those for “experiences,” are proliferating these days. Just a few searches and the tap-tap-tapping of credit card numbers into your cellphone seem to yield whatever you want, whenever and wherever you want it. But do they deliver?

headline: Is Georgetown’s $400,000-a-Year Plan to Aid Slave Descendants Enough?
abstract: University officials described the decision as one step in a dialogue with the descendants, who are seeking $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Joining a wave of American institutions moving to offer a measure of restitution for their ties to slavery, Georgetown University announced on Tuesday that it would raise about $400,000 a year to benefit the descendants of the 272 enslaved people who were sold to help keep the college afloat nearly two centuries ago, officials said.

headline: Local TV Revives a Bygone Tradition: Airing the National Anthem
abstract: Broadcasters bringing back “The Star-Spangled Banner” as a daily feature say they are encouraging unity, but the song can also be a dividing line.
lead_paragraph: It is one of popular culture’s generational divides: whether you are old enough to remember when television stations concluded the night’s programming with “The Star-Spangled Banner.” Decades ago, viewers would see a slide show of American imagery, perhaps a mountain range or frothy shoreline and then — hours of static.

headline: ‘A Very Unwelcome Feeling’: The First Women at Yale Look Back
abstract: A new survey and book show that for organizations to diversify, it’s not enough to let new people in. The institutions have to change, too.
lead_paragraph: When the first undergraduate women to be admitted to Yale arrived on campus 50 years ago this fall, they were outnumbered seven to one. To prepare, Yale installed full-length mirrors in the women’s dorm rooms and, to the dismay of many men, banned nudity in the gym. But there were no women’s studies classes, no women’s competitive sports and little idea how to support women at a place that was, in 1969, the oldest all-male college in the country.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Gun Laws Enacted in Wake of Pittsburgh Synagogue Massacre
abstract: The city had sought to regulate firearms after a gunman killed 11 people at the Tree of Life synagogue last year. It said it would appeal the Pennsylvania judge’s decision.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday struck down three gun control ordinances enacted by the City of Pittsburgh after the mass shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue last year, saying that state law prevented the city from regulating firearms.

headline: John Bolton Is Summoned to Testify in Trump Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The former national security adviser is said to have been deeply alarmed by what he perceived as a campaign by the president’s inner circle to manipulate Ukraine policy for political gain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House impeachment investigators on Wednesday summoned John R. Bolton, President Trump’s former national security adviser, and two top White House lawyers to testify next week in their inquiry into Mr. Trump’s pressure campaign on Ukraine, closing in on critical witnesses as they prepare to go public with their investigation.

headline: The Many Ways That Joe Biden Trips Over His Own Tongue
abstract: Digressions. Mix-ups. Mistakes. Joseph R. Biden Jr. has a choppy speaking style that could undermine his message at a time when he needs to attract more voters and donors.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, Iowa — Joseph R. Biden Jr. was making an impassioned case for protecting undocumented immigrants one recent Sunday when he abruptly stopped himself.

headline: Amazon Tests ‘Soul of Seattle’ With Deluge of Election Cash
abstract: Amazon is flexing its financial power in Seattle’s City Council elections, putting an innovative program meant to combat such influence at risk.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In 2015, Seattle voters approved a plan to foil corporate political contributions, creating “democracy vouchers” that allow residents to assign public campaign funds to local candidates of their choice.

headline: The Parks That Made the Man Who Made Central Park
abstract: Frederick Law Olmsted’s tours of English parks shaped his vision of landscape design. You can see his inspiration in three dimensions by touring five of them.
lead_paragraph: When Frederick Law Olmsted stepped off a ship in Liverpool in 1850, he was a gentleman farmer on Staten Island and intellectual, eager to embark on a walking tour of England. When he left, he had the makings of perhaps the greatest American landscape architect of all time.

headline: ‘Succession’ Knows How to Toy with Your Class Rage. Hence the Chicken.
abstract: The HBO show draws drama and comedy from the plutocrats who order so much of American life. But it’s just as deft at manipulating its viewers’ feelings.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, the professional class has soothed its Sunday-night dread with prestige television’s tales of striving, scheming, anguish, greed and office politics. Underneath all those encomia to the acting and writing on “The Sopranos” or “Mad Men” or “Game of Thrones” was a baser pleasure: the gleeful catharsis of watching someone who isn’t us get crushed under the wheel. What better way to steel oneself for the workweek?

headline: It’s Bong Joon Ho’s Dystopia. We Just Live in It.
abstract: If you want to know why his biting “Parasite” is the film of the year, look at the director’s body of work, a deeply humane vision of rotting humanity.
lead_paragraph: “It’s so metaphorical!” Kim Ki-woo exclaims early in “Parasite,” Bong Joon Ho’s new film. Ki-woo is the college-aged son of one of the two families — the impoverished Kims and the wealthy Parks — whose fates entwine with horrible and hilarious results. He uses the phrase a few times, most notably with reference to the large, decorative “landscape rock” that is a gift from a better-off friend. In the interpretation of “Parasite” that emphasizes the movie’s fairy-tale aspects, the stone brings good fortune to Ki-woo, his sister and their parents, even as, like so many magical objects, it also curses them. (Spoilers follow, for “Parasite” and other Bong movies.)

headline: Ready. Set. Write a Book.
abstract: The National Novel Writing Month event challenges people to crank out 50,000 words in 30 days. Here are the digital tools to help you make a go of it.
lead_paragraph: This year marks the 20th anniversary of the National Novel Writing Month project, which challenges people to write a 50,000-word novel in November. NaNoWriMo, as it is known, is a nonprofit that supports creative writing and education. Those who sign up for the group’s free annual event get community support, progress tracking and motivational advice to complete a book draft.

headline: A Photographer’s ‘Surreal’ Access to ISIS Prisons
abstract: Ivor Prickett reported from two Kurdish-run facilities in Syria. “In those situations, it’s about making yourself very obvious,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Living In ... Sea Cliff, N.Y.
abstract: Unlike other parts of the North Shore of Long Island, this Nassau County village isn’t flashy. Homes are close together, and a car isn’t a necessity.
lead_paragraph: Unlike other parts of the North Shore of Long Island, this Nassau County village isn’t flashy. Homes are close together, and a car isn’t a necessity.

headline: These Refugees Escaped Congo, but Trump’s Policies May Strand Loved Ones
abstract: In the coming days, President Trump will finalize the lowest annual cap in the refugee program’s history. In Missoula, Congolese refugees are facing the repercussions.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — On his first day in this small college town cradled between the Flathead and Lolo national forests, Funugo Nsanzinfura made sure to submit the paperwork necessary for his daughter, Faith, and her mother, Ayingeneye, to join him in the growing community of Congolese refugees here.

headline: Sea Cliff, N.Y.: A Close-Knit, Walkable Village
abstract: Unlike other parts of Long Island’s North Shore, this Nassau County village isn’t flashy. Homes are close together, and a car isn’t a necessity.
lead_paragraph: Clichés about Long Island don’t hold much water in Sea Cliff.

headline: Rex Tillerson Testifies in Exxon Climate Change Case
abstract: The former Exxon  chief executive Rex Tillerson  testified Wednesday in a case that accuses the company of committing shareholder fraud over climate change.
lead_paragraph: The shareholder fraud lawsuit brought by the New York attorney general against Exxon Mobil has entered its second week, and on Wednesday a star witness took the stand: Rex Tillerson, the company’s former chief executive and a former secretary of state in the Trump administration.

headline: That Peter Luger Review and Other Restaurants That Got Zero Stars
abstract: Wednesday: The steakhouse seemed to represent a way of life. A Times restaurant critic just gave it zero stars.
