headline: Shooting at Long Beach, Calif., Halloween Party Kills 3
abstract: The motive for the attack, which left nine others wounded on Tuesday night, was not immediately clear, the authorities said. The gunman was still at large on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Three men were fatally shot and at least nine other people were injured in an attack at a Halloween house party in Long Beach, Calif., on Tuesday night, the authorities said.

headline: An H.I.V. Outbreak Puts Spotlight on Pakistan’s Health Care System
abstract: After the reuse of syringes infected hundreds of children in a small city, health workers say the entire system needs to be revamped.

headline: Militants Kill 5 Laborers in Kashmir, Expanding Threat to Civilians
abstract: Many Kashmiris are afraid to go back to work, fearing attacks by militants intent on halting trade to punish the Indian government.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Militants in Kashmir pulled five construction workers from their apartment, lined them up outside and shot them dead, witnesses and officials said on Tuesday, in the deadliest single attack on civilians since the Indian government revoked the disputed region’s autonomy nearly three months ago.

headline: The Promise and Peril of Vaping, Part 2: The Story of Juul
abstract: They pledged to help people stop smoking. Instead, Juul created a new generation of nicotine addicts — and a public health scare.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Found in Boston, Someone New
abstract: Dating a fresh face wasn’t easy in the older gay community for Marty Martinez. “You start to know everyone,” said Mr. Martinez, a city official. And then he met Matthew Hall.

headline: Are You a Moderate? Think Again
abstract: A lack of moral imagination can make deeply ethical actions seem like crimes.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “Letter From Birmingham Jail” was written as a response to a group of “white moderate” clergy members who claimed to be supportive of the civil rights movement — but who had also called Dr. King’s activism both “unwise and untimely.” For these moderates, civil rights activists were not courageous adversaries of a horribly unjust society, but lawless “outside agitators” threatening the tranquillity of the status quo. And so, rather than commending these activists, they condemned them and blamed the outbreak of violence on their resistance to Jim Crow rather than on Jim Crow itself.

headline: Coping in Black and White
abstract: A woman living with anxiety learns how to temporarily quiet her mind by solving crossword puzzles.
lead_paragraph: It seems strange to begin therapy in tandem with college, but that’s exactly what I did. When it felt like all the other 18-year-olds in the world were mastering the art of losing themselves in the jungle of frat parties and all-nighters, I was practicing self-help for the first time in my life.

headline: Impeachment Is Not a Coup
abstract: And no matter what Trump thinks, the president does not embody the will of the people.
lead_paragraph: In his letter denouncing the impeachment investigation, Pat Cipollone accused Democrats of waging an “illegitimate” effort to “overturn the results of the 2016 election and deprive the American people of the president they have freely chosen.”

headline: Here’s How to Compensate College Athletes
abstract: Athletic departments and schools should also benefit from students’ sports celebrity.
lead_paragraph: A month ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation that will allow college athletes in the state to profit from their sports celebrity by promoting products and companies. Other states quickly moved in the same direction, and on Tuesday the N.C.A.A., the governing body of college sports, bowed to the inevitable after long opposing the move.

headline: Fiat Chrysler’s Second Shot at a Merger
abstract: This time the automaker is in talks to combine with Peugeot, just months after its attempts to join with Renault failed.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday. This year’s DealBook Summit will feature speakers including Bill Gates, Hillary Clinton, Ginni Rometty of IBM and the Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom. Apply to attend here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Israeli Soldier Gets One-Month Sentence Over Killing of Gaza Teenager
abstract: It was the first conviction of a soldier in connection with the shootings of Palestinians during mass protests along the border.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli soldier who shot and killed a plainly unarmed Palestinian boy during mass protests along the Gaza border fence last year has been sentenced to a month in military prison and demoted.

headline: Shalane Flanagan Was Not Surprised by Alberto Salazar’s Ban
abstract: One of America’s greatest marathoners has retired to become a coach and a television commentator, and she is speaking her mind about her sport and her top sponsor.
lead_paragraph: Shalane Flanagan, the four-time Olympian and winner of the New York City Marathon in 2017, called it quits on her running career in October — sort of.

headline: Economy Grew at 1.9% Rate in Quarter, Hit by Trade Fight and Global Weakness
abstract: Consumer spending remained solid, but business investment declined.
lead_paragraph: Dogged by uneasiness over trade frictions and weak global growth, the American economy’s growth inched lower over the summer.

headline: Why Google’s Quantum Supremacy Milestone Matters
abstract: The company says its quantum computer can complete a calculation much faster than a supercomputer. What does that mean?
lead_paragraph: Google officially announced last week in the journal Nature that it achieved the milestone of “quantum supremacy.” This phrase, coined by the physicist John Preskill in 2012, refers to the first use of a quantum computer to make a calculation much faster than we know how to do it with even the fastest supercomputers available. The calculation doesn’t need to be useful: much like the Wright Flyer in 1903, or Enrico Fermi’s nuclear chain reaction in 1942, it only needs to prove a point.

headline: Stephen Strasburg Rewards Nationals for Their Trust
abstract: The Nationals drafted him first over all in 2009 and once kept him out of the playoffs to protect his arm, all because they believed there would be games like Tuesday night’s.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — This setting, this moment, this pitcher. The patient, painstaking construction of an ace — it was all leading to Game 6 of the World Series on Tuesday at Minute Maid Park, when the Washington Nationals needed a savior and turned to Stephen Strasburg. They trusted him because that is what they do.

headline: Who Alexander Vindman Really Is
abstract: ‘A great American patriot.’
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: The Great World Series Interference Debate
abstract: The game simply halted, lost in one of those Talmudic debates that enthrall hardball devotees and mystify everyone else.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Somewhere in the long night’s journey into baseball that is a World Series game I turned my back on the leather-lunged fans who hung over a rail behind me and screamed ceaselessly, and I peered at home plate and tried to remind myself who was batting, which team was ahead and if it was really possible this Game 6 had just come to a dead stop.

headline: Grenfell Tower Inquiry Criticized for Faulting Fire Brigade
abstract: Survivor groups and firefighters said the investigation into the high-rise blaze that left 72 people dead should instead have begun by focusing on unsafe conditions in the building.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Survivors of the Grenfell Tower fire and firefighters reacted angrily on Wednesday to an official inquiry into the disaster for focusing first on the shortcomings of the emergency services’ response to the 2017 blaze, not on the dangerous conditions that fed it.

headline: The Worst Kind of Mom Guilt
abstract: It’s coming from inside the house.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow is Halloween or, as I like to call it, preschool Mardi Gras, because it includes costumes, screaming and loud music; and I once saw a 3-year-old vomit spectacularly on the sidewalk while wearing a three-piece suit. It’s not my favorite occasion, in part because I’m a complete washout at creating costumes for my kids.

headline: Scenes From a Burning State: The California Wildfires
abstract: Wednesday: The latest on major fires, wind danger and power shut-offs. Also: A fire recovery guide for native plants.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Fires Threaten Reagan Library and Getty Museum
abstract: Dangerous Santa Ana winds sent burning embers through the air in Southern California, igniting new fires.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here for our California Today newsletter and follow the latest developments in our California fires live briefing.

headline: There’s No Business Like Art Fair Business for Sanford Smith
abstract: Modern pieces, Outsider Art, Americana. You name it, he hunted it down, then he sold it and moved on.
lead_paragraph: When Sanford Smith talks about working in “show business,” he’s not referring to Broadway or Hollywood. Over the last four decades he has produced some 130 fairs nationwide, bringing together dealers in art, design and antiques.

headline: What You Get for $2.2 Million
abstract: A late 19th-century Carpenter Gothic estate in Rome, Ga.; a midcentury-modern home in Newton, Mass.; and a neo-Georgian house in Upper Nyack, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A late 19th-century Carpenter Gothic estate in Rome, Ga.; a midcentury-modern home in Newton, Mass.; and a neo-Georgian house in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

headline: $2.2 Million Homes in Georgia, Massachusetts and New York
abstract: A late 19th-century Carpenter Gothic estate in Rome, a midcentury-modern home in Newton and a neo-Georgian house in Upper Nyack.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, the owner, a commercial builder, renovated what was then a dilapidated home surrounded by virgin woods outside his hometown, Rome, 90 minutes northwest of Atlanta. The gated property backs onto the 311-acre Marshall Forest Preserve and is about a mile southwest of Rome, a city of about 36,000 built on seven hills (hence its name).

headline: Epstein’s Autopsy ‘Points to Homicide,’ Pathologist Hired by Brother Claims
abstract: The New York City medical examiner strongly disputed the claim that evidence from the autopsy suggested strangulation.
lead_paragraph: A forensic pathologist hired by Jeffrey Epstein’s brother disputed the official finding in the autopsy of his death, claiming on Wednesday that the evidence suggested that he did not take his own life but may have been strangled.

headline: John Witherspoon, Actor in ‘Friday’ and Other Movies, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Witherspoon, who started out as a stand-up comedian, was best known for his role as Ice Cube’s father in the “Friday” franchise. He was also seen on “The Wayans Bros.” and many other TV shows.
lead_paragraph: John Witherspoon, an actor and comedian who was best known for his role in the “Friday” movie franchise and also seen on television series including “The Wayans Bros.” and “The Tracy Morgan Show,” died on Tuesday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 77.

headline: A Rustic Sanctuary Outside Cape Town
abstract: This six-bedroom home in the awe-inspiring foothills outside Cape Town, South Africa, is on the market for $1.7 million.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom home in the awe-inspiring foothills outside Cape Town, South Africa, is on the market for $1.7 million.

headline: House Hunting in … South Africa
abstract: In the Cape Town region, the bumpy market is now oversupplied, generating attractive deals for buyers of all kinds.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom, six-and-a-half-bath house is in Constantia, a leafy suburb of Cape Town, South Africa, in the foothills of Table Mountain National Park, near the Atlantic coast.

headline: Documents Show Safety Concerns at Boeing Before Deadly Crashes
abstract: The chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, faced a second day of questions from Congress over the 737 Max crashes.
lead_paragraph: One Boeing employee worried the 737 Max might be “vulnerable.” A company document said if pilots didn’t respond to a new automated system within seconds it would be “catastrophic.” A plan to include an alert for the system, known as MCAS, was considered but scrapped.

headline: Michael Cohen’s Ex-Partner Gets Probation After Turning on Him
abstract: Evgeny A. Freidman, once known as New York’s Taxi King, cooperated in the federal investigation of Mr. Cohen.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — When federal prosecutors unveiled charges last year against Michael Cohen, President Trump’s former lawyer, they accused him of hiding more than $1.3 million in income he received from a man identified only as Taxi-Operator 2.

headline: The 1619 Project at the Smithsonian
abstract: Watch a conversation about how history is defined — and redefined — featuring historians, journalists and policymakers.
lead_paragraph: Four hundred years ago, a ship carrying 20 to 30 enslaved Africans arrived at Point Comfort in the English colony of Virginia. Though the United States did not even exist yet, their arrival marked its foundation, the beginning of the system of slavery on which the country was built.

headline: Juul Knowingly Sold Tainted Nicotine Pods, Former Executive Says
abstract: In a lawsuit, a former senior vice president claims that he was fired for raising safety concerns and that the company’s C.E.O. said customers are “drunk and vaping” and wouldn’t notice the quality of the pods.
lead_paragraph: A former top executive of Juul is alleging that the e-cigarette giant sold at least one million contaminated mint-flavored nicotine pods — and refused to recall them when told about the problem in March.

headline: Don’t Worry About Stephen Curry and the Warriors
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein calms the panic about Golden State and forecasts which soon-to-be free agent could take over next summer.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: From Annie to Tina Turner, and Trained to Go the Distance
abstract: Singer, dancer, athlete, fan: how Adrienne Warren learned to stop fighting herself and interpret the musical role of a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: “There is only one.”

headline: How Many Christmas Movies Is Too Many Christmas Movies?
abstract: In two years, the number of those formulaic cozy romances has soared on some TV outlets. Don’t expect a slowdown anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Nighy sang “Christmas Is All Around” in “Love Actually” 16 years ago, he could have been discussing the state of holiday movies in 2019. Among this year’s nearly 100 new releases, viewers can choose to celebrate “Christmas in Rome,” “Christmas in Montana,” “Christmas in Louisiana,” “Christmas at Dollywood,” “Christmas at Graceland,” “Christmas Under the Stars” or “Christmas at the Plaza.”

headline: Five Holiday Movies Worth Bingeing This Season
abstract: These tales usually involve a busy modern lead, a quaint snowy village and an available love interest. Here are titles that find magic in that formula.
lead_paragraph: There are literally dozens of new seasonal movies to watch from your sofa. These titles stand out from the pack.

headline: Russia Tests New Disinformation Tactics in Africa to Expand Influence
abstract: Facebook said it removed three Russian-backed influence networks aimed at African countries. The activity by the networks suggested Russia’s approach was evolving.
lead_paragraph: Russia has been testing new disinformation tactics in an enormous Facebook campaign in parts of Africa, as part of an evolution of its manipulation techniques ahead of the 2020 American presidential election.

headline: Fear and Sport Imperil Lebanon’s Striped Hyenas
abstract: Poisoned, run over and shot on sight, the country’s national animal finds itself threatened by frightened humans and dated myths.
lead_paragraph: KFAR TOUN, Lebanon — Close to midnight, Mounir Abi-Said sat on the roof of his bright yellow Land Rover and shined a spotlight across the landscape, looking for striped hyenas. Warm fog swirled in the headlights. A bat detector crackled as it picked up sonar. Some years ago, when Dr. Abi-Said, a conservation biologist and striped hyena expert at Lebanese University in Beirut, was conducting his Ph.D. research, he developed a trap that, in the dead of night, as he waited alone in his tent, caused a dangling red light to shake and swing when a hyena was caught. “It looked really very scary,” he said.

headline: ‘Like a Golden Ticket’: A MetroCard Helped Him Get Back on Track
abstract: When Lucas Carvalho was struggling, his aunt helped him get a fresh start. Having overcome anxiety and depression, he is pursuing his dream of becoming a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: For Lucas Carvalho, adulthood arrived suddenly.

headline: Rolando Panerai, Renowned Baritone and Callas Collaborator, Dies at 95
abstract: In a career that spanned more than six decades, he appeared in landmark performances and made classic recordings with Maria Callas and other opera legends.
lead_paragraph: Rolando Panerai, an Italian baritone who sang more than 150 roles at leading international opera houses, made many classic recordings and appeared frequently with the celebrated soprano Maria Callas in her prime, died on Oct. 22 at his home outside Florence, Italy. He was 95.

headline: Kanye West’s ‘Jesus Is King,’ From the Gospel Perspective
abstract: Gospel music insiders on the rapper’s turn to religious music and how his album relates to contemporary holy hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Kanye West released his ninth album, “Jesus Is King,” and an Imax film of the same name. They were the culmination of several months of dalliances with religious music, consisting largely of weekly performances he calls Sunday Services, with a full gospel choir, near his California home.

headline: J. Kenji López-Alt’s Secret Ingredient
abstract: Use mayonnaise, as he does, to make mighty marinades for chicken and steaks, or to encourage browning on fish or grilled cheeses.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt is back in our pages this week with a smart look at his favorite secret ingredient: mayonnaise. You can smear it on fish to encourage browning in the pan; you have to try it on the exterior of a grilled cheese sandwich, for similar reasons. Kenji uses mayonnaise on steaks cooked sous-vide, so that when he sautés them in a pan they develop the most marvelous crusts. And he cuts mayonnaise with all sorts of concoctions to make mighty marinades — with teriyaki sauce, curry paste, pesto, barbecue sauce. Try his mayo-marinated chicken with chimichurri (above) for dinner tonight, and you may find yourself a convert.

headline: The Designer Reimagining America’s Most Iconic Accessory
abstract: Rodney Patterson reworks classic Western hats into avant-garde creations for his own line, Esenshel, and for entertainers including Billy Porter and Lizzo.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in mid-South Side Chicago in the late 1970s and early ’80s, Rodney Patterson often dreamed of making avant-garde clothing like the fashion designers Rei Kawakubo and Jean-Paul Gaultier. While a career creating high-end clothes might have been seen as a long shot at that time for a black man from the Midwest, Patterson expressed his love of fashion through his own personal style — especially his hats. After moving to New York in the late ’80s — where he worked as a visual merchandiser by day and designed Judy Jetson-like dresses for his own independent women’s wear label at night — he would punctuate his outfits with exuberant headwear: the exaggerated Philip Treacy fedora popularized by Boy George, with its slanted brim and angular crown, or Vivienne Westwood’s dramatically oversize Buffalo hat.

headline: Rachel Maddow Takes On the Oil Industry
abstract: Maddow’s “Blowout” details the political problems caused by our reliance on fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: BLOWOUTCorrupted Democracy, Rogue State Russia, and the Richest, Most Destructive Industry on EarthBy Rachel Maddow

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: House Democrats requested interviews with three major witnesses, including John Bolton, who said he would not appear voluntarily.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the House will take a vote to set out rules and procedures for the impeachment inquiry. The Democrats produced the resolution after weeks of complaints by Republicans about the lack of such a vote. Here’s what will look new about the investigation:

headline: Is a Donald Trump Mask Scary?
abstract: This Halloween, the line between almost scared and truly terrified is thinner than ever.
lead_paragraph: It was funny, I guess, when Moynihan came after me with the chain saw. I hadn’t seen him approach, just the flash of his cape in the corner of my eye.

headline: On One Issue, Americans Are United. Too Many Are Behind Bars.
abstract: Civil discourse and bipartisanship in America aren’t dead. At least when the subject is criminal justice reform.
lead_paragraph: In modern times, the United States has never been as polarized and partisan as it is now. The two parties cannot work together and have stopped talking to each other, and many of their members barely see people in the other party as human. Adversaries become enemies; disagreement is seen as treason.

headline: Melbourne’s Most Exciting Restaurants Are Wine Bars
abstract: The energetic wine scene has resulted in serious chefs cooking delicious food in small, laid-back spots.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — On a mild October evening in Carlton North, the crowd outside Gerald’s Bar radiated early springtime exuberance. Like the residents of many cities with long dark winters, Melbournians tend to explode onto the streets in joyous droves, crowding parks and sidewalk cafes and even grassy median strips, once the scent of jasmine begins to waft on warmer air.

headline: ‘Parasite' | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Bong Joon Ho narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The director Bong Joon Ho narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Chile, Rocked by Unrest, Withdraws From Hosting Climate and Trade Summits
abstract: President Sebastián Piñera said on Wednesday that his country, which has been rocked by a wave of recent protests, was not in a position to host the meetings.
lead_paragraph: President Sebastián Piñera of Chile said on Wednesday that his country, which has been rocked by a wave of recent protests, would back out of hosting two important international events: a United Nations climate change meeting and a major Asia-Pacific trade summit later this year.

headline: How ‘Parasite’ Handles a ‘Mission: Impossible’ Moment
abstract: The director Bong Joon Ho discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Convicted Ex-Trump Adviser May Run for Katie Hill’s House Seat
abstract: George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser who was convicted of lying to federal authorities, has filed to run for Congress as a Republican in California.
lead_paragraph: George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser who pleaded guilty two years ago to lying to the F.B.I. about his Russian contacts during the 2016 presidential election, has filed paperwork signaling that he will run for Congress in California as a Republican to replace Representative Katie Hill.

headline: Jordan-Israel Ties Strained by Detentions
abstract: Israel is holding two Jordanian citizens without charges on vague security grounds; Jordan has detained an Israeli and recalled its ambassador for consultations.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Jordan has recalled its ambassador to Israel for consultations and detained an Israeli citizen who it says crossed the border illegally amid a sharpening dispute over Israel’s weekslong detention of two Jordanian citizens on suspicion of vague security violations.

headline: Foie Gras, Served in 1,000 Restaurants in New York City, Is Banned
abstract: Animal cruelty concerns led the City Council to approve the ban, which takes effect in 2022. One chef’s reaction: “What’s next? No more veal?”
lead_paragraph: Lutèce served it seared, with dark chocolate sauce and bitter orange marmalade. Le Cirque offered it in classic terrine form, but also served it with rabbit and bacon and made it the scene-stealer in a ravioli dish.

headline: Southern California Fire Danger Intensifies With Powerful Winds
abstract: A new fire broke out in Southern California, where powerful winds threatened to worsen conditions. In Northern California, the Kincade fire is now 45 percent contained.
lead_paragraph: A new fire broke out in Southern California, where powerful winds threatened to worsen conditions. In Northern California, the Kincade fire is now 45 percent contained.

headline: ‘The Irishman’: What to Read About Martin Scorsese’s Netflix Mob Drama
abstract: The movie is opening in theaters Friday before moving to Netflix. Wherever you decide to watch it, these articles will sate your curiosity.
lead_paragraph: “The Irishman,” the director Martin Scorsese’s latest crime epic (truly, at three and a half hours), premieres Friday in movie theaters around the country before reaching Netflix on Nov. 27. The film, about a hitman (Robert De Niro), a Mafia boss (Joe Pesci) and the never-solved death of the Teamsters leader Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino), has been rapturously reviewed and is already a leading contender for this year’s biggest Oscar categories. Here are a few reviews, interviews and features to check out if you’re planning to watch it this weekend.

headline: Review: Mahler, Distilled by Classical Music’s Greatest Duo
abstract: The baritone Christian Gerhaher and the pianist Gerold Huber brought a sublime evening of song to Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: Mahler’s music wouldn’t be possible without peace and quiet.

headline: The Truth Is, ‘Cats’ Is as Inscrutable as That Trailer
abstract: Why was the musical a sensation? What’s with the plot? Based on what we know of the show, here’s our guide to this unlikely mash-up of C.G.I. and T.S. Eliot.
lead_paragraph: “Now and Forever,” the old Winter Garden Theater posters used to read. Loosely translated, that means you’ve had the equivalent of forever to see “Cats” in one incarnation or another. But maybe, despite everything, you never got around to it, or maybe you saw it so long ago that you no longer recall what all the fuss was about.

headline: Erdogan’s Dismissive Retort on Armenian Genocide Shows How Low U.S. Ties Have Sunk
abstract: The Turkish leader said the House of Representatives had no moral standing to adjudicate on the murder of 1.5 million Armenians.
lead_paragraph: When Pope Francis acknowledged the Armenian genocide four years ago, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey was so furious he recalled the ambassador to the Vatican. When German lawmakers made the same acknowledgment a year later, he not only recalled his Berlin envoy but warned that their decision would “seriously affect” German-Turkish ties.

headline: Plane Crashes Into Building in DeKalb County, Georgia, Killing 2
abstract: The plane, a Piper PA-28, crashed into a townhome complex shortly after taking off in an Atlanta suburb. The homes damaged in the crash were declared “unsafe,” the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A small plane crashed into an apartment complex in DeKalb County, Ga., on Wednesday morning, killing two people in the plane, according to  the DeKalb County Department of Communications.

headline: NBC’s Digital Journalists Say They Are Forming a Union
abstract: Discontent over how the network handled Ronan Farrow’s reporting on Harvey Weinstein and allegations against Matt Lauer played into their decision.
lead_paragraph: Employees of NBC’s digital news division announced on Wednesday that they intend to form a union representing about 150 workers, saying it would allow them to fight for better job protections as well as publicly criticize NBC News executives without fear of retaliation.

headline: Michael Kiwanuka Felt ‘One Step Away.’ Now He Has a Seat at the Table.
abstract: The London-born son of Ugandan immigrants on alienation, getting married and his self-assured new album, “Kiwanuka.”
lead_paragraph: Around the summer of 2016, shortly after his second album, “Love & Hate,” was released, Michael Kiwanuka started getting texts from Russell Crowe. The texts were friendly — compliments about his music, invitations to get a beer, enthusiastic updates about works in progress — but felt strangely portentous, like being invited behind a velvet rope. After all, Crowe, the Academy Award-winning star of “Gladiator,” was seeking out and befriending Kiwanuka, an acclaimed but relatively obscure singer-songwriter who still felt grateful for more than a few hundred likes on Instagram.

headline: Jho Low Will Give Up as Much as $900 Million in Assets in 1MDB Scandal
abstract: The deal will not grant Mr. Low special treatment in the criminal case against him involving a looted Malaysian fund.
lead_paragraph: The mysterious Malaysian financier at the center of an international money laundering scandal that toppled a prime minister and rocked Goldman Sachs has given up his claim to hundreds of millions of dollars in luxury apartments, yachts, jets and artwork that prosecutors say were bought with stolen money.

headline: Kanye West and Kim Kardashian West Honor Rick Owens
abstract: And a documentary on Ralph Lauren premiered at the Met museum.
lead_paragraph: And a documentary on Ralph Lauren premiered at the Met museum.

headline: Kanye West Sings Another Designer’s Praises
abstract: And Ralph Lauren’s life is perfect, at least on HBO.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that Kanye West gushes about anyone besides himself. But there he was last Thursday, paying homage to Rick Owens, the avant-garde designer from California, at the Fashion Group International’s Night of Stars gala.

lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

abstract: Readers praise the colonel who gave testimony before Congress as a patriot and hero.

headline: Review: ‘Zauberland’ Pairs Schumann With a Syrian Refugee
abstract: The show, which weaves new songs into the classic “Dichterliebe,” arrived at the White Light Festival starring the soprano Julia Bullock.
lead_paragraph: When the composer Bernard Foccroulle approached the soprano Julia Bullock about the project that became “Zauberland,” she felt some initial trepidation. With Martin Crimp, Mr. Foccroulle had written 19 songs about a pregnant Syrian refugee who leaves her husband and family in Aleppo for a new life in Germany. And the new music would be woven into Schumann’s 1840 song cycle “Dichterliebe.”

headline: Mnuchin Says China Deal Is Likely to Be Signed in November
abstract: Chile’s cancellation of the APEC summit could alter plans for a meeting between President Trump and President Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Wednesday that the United States and China were on track toward signing the first phase of a trade agreement next month, offering fresh optimism that the long-awaited deal may finally materialize.

headline: South African Police Use Force to Disperse Refugee Sit-In After 3 Weeks
abstract: After a wave of violence against immigrants, hundreds had camped outside a United Nations refugee agency office, asking for help leaving the country.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South African police clad in riot gear on Wednesday forcibly broke up a group of refugees who had occupied a square in central Cape Town for three weeks, pleading for help in leaving a country plagued by anti-immigrant violence.

headline: 12 Men Found Alive in Refrigerated Truck After Deadly Smuggling Case
abstract: A truck driver transporting fruit and vegetables across Belgium became suspicious and alerted the police.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twelve men were found alive in the refrigerated trailer of a truck in Belgium, the federal police said on Wednesday, in an echo of a similar, but deadly, case a week earlier.

headline: New York Galleries: What to See Right Now
abstract: Elisabeth Kley and Tabboo!’s botanical beauties; Mike Cloud’s “hanging and beheading paintings”; Karl Lagerfeld’s sculptural works; and Janine Antoni’s symbolic images.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s and early ’80s, a fledgling art movement called Pattern and Decoration arose, thanks to the work of artists like Miriam Schapiro, Kim MacConnel, Robert Kushner and Faith Ringgold. And then it faded — overshadowed by the onslaught of American and European Neo-Expressionist painting. But P&D, as it was called, a reaction to the austerities of Minimalism and the limits of high art, never really went away. Most of the artists kept working, and the questions they raised about decoration, craft, function and (even) beauty — and the frequently pejorative connotations of those words — hung around. These issues also mutated in the work of artists as various as Jean Lowe (who is married to Mr. MacConnel), Philip Taaffe, Rudolf Stingel and Laurel Sparks.

headline: Christie’s Auctioned a $40 Million Diamond. Was It Stolen?
abstract: The diamond was bought by a member of the Qatari royal family, but the descendants of an Italian politician say it belongs to them. They have sued the auction house and its client, a gems dealer.
lead_paragraph: Update Oct. 31, 2019: A New York appellate court on Thursday put the case on hold while it hears an appeal filed by the defendants.

headline: How Do We Sing Our ABC’s? L-M-N-O-Please Not Like That
abstract: What happens if you alter the alphabet song so that you don’t have to condense the 12th through 16th letters into a single breath? Some people get angry.
lead_paragraph: This week, the people of the internet rallied to the defense of the elemenopee.

headline: Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates for Third Time in 2019
abstract: The quarter-point cut comes as the economy continues to show signs of slowing, but the Fed signaled that it may pause to weigh incoming data before adjusting rates again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday for the third time this year, reversing nearly all of 2018’s rate increases as uncertainty from President Trump’s trade war and slowing global growth continue to pose risks to the United States economy.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in 2016 Uber and Lynda.com Hacks
abstract: Guilty pleas to charges of hacking and an extortion conspiracy cap a legal saga that ensnared the tech companies in data breach scandals.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two men pleaded guilty in federal court in San Jose, Calif., to charges of computer hacking and an extortion conspiracy on Wednesday, capping a thorny legal saga that ensnared tech companies like Uber and LinkedIn in data breach scandals.

headline: Beetlejuices, Beetlejuices, Beetlejuices, All Over Broadway
abstract: Costumed fans have flocked to the Winter Garden Theater for a weekly contest that colors the audience black and white and deathly green.
lead_paragraph: Inside an upscale corporate office building in Midtown Manhattan, Amaryllis Ruiz, a legal assistant, watched the clock strike 5 p.m. She grabbed her electric green wig and a smattering of neon cockroaches, dashed to the office bathroom and got to work.

headline: Why Children (and Pregnant Women) May Want to Eat More Fish
abstract: There is some evidence that eating fish may make children smarter.
lead_paragraph: Does fish make children smarter? There is some evidence that it might.

headline: A Very Modern Emily Dickinson (Twerking Included)
abstract: Jane Austen and zombies? Ho-hum. A new series gives us Emily Dickinson, millennial angst and sexual fluidity — and some scholars are here for it.
lead_paragraph: Hear the name Emily Dickinson, and you’ll probably think of the virginal woman in white, the reclusive Belle of Amherst who died with her “letter to the world” — as she wrote in one of her enigmatic poems — unsent.

headline: What Could Go Wrong With Boris Johnson’s Scheme? Everything
abstract: Brexit delayed, again, new elections called, again. When does this merry-go-round stop?
lead_paragraph: Since becoming prime minister in July, Boris Johnson has pursued two goals: exiting the European Union by Oct. 31 (“do or die”) and an early general election. He failed fairly decisively on the former, stymied by the same political stalemate that bedeviled his predecessor, but on Tuesday he got the elections, which will be held Dec. 12. The question is whether this will resolve or deepen the impasse over Brexit.

headline: A Greater Understanding of Race and Identity Through Tech
abstract: Podcasts featuring inmates. The evolution of social media. The writing of Stephen Hawking. All are routes to thinking about race and identity, says Lauretta Charlton, editor of Race/Related.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Lauretta Charlton, editor of the Race/Related newsletter, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline: Two Disputed Judicial Nominees Could Help Trump Reach Milestone
abstract: With a batch of nominees being considered Thursday, the president could soon have appointed a quarter of all federal appeals court judges.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is nearing a milestone in his push to overhaul the federal judiciary with conservative judges. If the Senate confirms a batch of nominees now working their way through the approval process, a quarter of the nation’s 179 appeals court judges — those sitting just below the Supreme Court — will be appointees of Mr. Trump.

headline: It’s the End of California as We Know It
abstract: The fires and the blackouts are connected to a larger problem in this state: a failure to live sustainably.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — I have lived nearly all my life in California, and my love for this place and its people runs deep and true. There have been many times in the past few years when I’ve called myself a California nationalist: Sure, America seemed to be going crazy, but at least I lived in the Golden State, where things were still pretty chill.

headline: Prosecute Boeing Executives
abstract: A reader says they should be criminally liable for the deadly crashes. Also: A new capitalism; gender transition and loss; America’s overstay in Afghanistan; being alone isn’t bad.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nationals Win Their First World Series With One Last Rally
abstract: After trailing for much of Game 7, Washington mounted a comeback and overcame the Houston Astros to win the franchise’s first title.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — During the worst part of the Washington Nationals’ season, when they were playing terrible baseball and had lost 31 of their first 50 games amid speculation that the manager would be fired and several players traded, the team held a meeting in the coaches’ conference room at Nationals Park.

headline: Ed Cray, Biographer of Woody Guthrie and Earl Warren, Dies at 86
abstract: A folklorist and journalism professor at U.S.C., he also profiled George C. Marshall, Levi Strauss and the serial killer Juan Corona.
lead_paragraph: Ed Cray, a journalist and educator who explored a broad spectrum of Americana with well-regarded biographies of Woody Guthrie, Chief Justice Earl Warren, the California serial killer Juan Corona, George C. Marshall and the bluejeans maker Levi Strauss, died on Oct. 8 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Mediterranean Diet May Help Ease Some Symptoms of Depression
abstract: A diet high in fruits, vegetables, fish, olive oil and nuts and low in sugar and saturated fat boosted mood in college students prone to depression.
lead_paragraph: A healthy diet may help relieve the symptoms of depression.

headline: Top State Department Official Confirms Smear Campaign Against Ousted Ukraine Envoy
abstract: John Sullivan, the deputy secretary of state, told lawmakers he believed the president’s personal lawyer was involved in the plot to remove the ambassador to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Sullivan, the deputy secretary of state, said on Wednesday that President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani was involved in a smear campaign to oust the ambassador to Ukraine, publicly confirming a key part of the saga behind the impeachment inquiry.

headline: Democrats, Once Wary of Partisan Impeachment Inquiry Vote, Unite as Politics Shift
abstract: Members who have long resisted a formal floor vote are now solidly behind the idea. The change reflects Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s close hold over her caucus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Speaker Nancy Pelosi polled Democrats privately about taking a formal floor vote on the impeachment inquiry into President Trump earlier this month, the idea was scuttled by nervous moderates who feared a backlash from voters in their Trump-friendly districts.

headline: A Long-Lost Lou Reed Tape With a Surprise: Andy Warhol Lyrics
abstract: The cassette, discovered at the Andy Warhol Museum, finds the Velvet Underground musician performing snippets from his mentor’s 1975 book.
lead_paragraph: It is one of rock’s most famously fraught relationships: Lou Reed and Andy Warhol, who managed Reed’s groundbreaking 1960s band, the Velvet Underground, for a couple of years before an acrimonious split. Warhol’s ideas on art, pop culture and hard work loomed over Reed for the rest of his career, though the two never worked together again.

headline: If Progressives Don’t Try to Win Over Rural Areas, Guess Who Will
abstract: I’ve been out there organizing for 20 years. I have never seen this level of public activity by white supremacist groups.
lead_paragraph: This summer I visited a bunch of small towns across the country, and I saw signs that white nationalists are becoming more active. Just drive by the town square in Pittsboro, N.C., at 5 p.m. on any given Saturday and you are likely to see white nationalists rallying to protect a Confederate monument.

headline: Denmark Approves Route for a Controversial Russia-German Pipeline
abstract: Nord Stream 2, a major Russian natural gas pipeline that bypasses Ukraine and Poland, can finish construction.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Denmark gave permission on Wednesday for a natural gas pipeline from Russia to Germany to pass through waters in its exclusive economic zone, meaning that the project, Nord Stream 2, can be completed despite sharp criticism from the United States, Ukraine and Poland.

headline: Trump Tweets Faked Photo of Hero Dog Getting a Medal
abstract: The joke photo appeared to use an image from a 2017 Medal of Honor ceremony. The medal recipient was amused.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Wednesday shared an altered photograph of himself placing a medal around the neck of the dog injured in the raid last weekend that led to the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State’s leader.

headline: Review: In ‘Monsoon Season,’ a Marital Squall Turns Ugly
abstract: Bad things happen to bad people in Lizzie Vieh’s comedy, set in Arizona, about a couple who break up, crack up and make up.
lead_paragraph: Some people show love through gifts, through kind words, through time and touch. Helping your estranged spouse cover up a murder? That works, too.

headline: Judge Says Sheriff Can’t Post Sex Offender Warning Signs on Halloween
abstract: A federal judge filed a preliminary injunction on Tuesday preventing a sheriff in Georgia from placing signs at three sex offenders’ homes, saying it violated their constitutional rights.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a sheriff in Georgia from placing signs at three registered sex offenders’ homes that warn trick-or-treaters on Halloween, saying that the action violated their constitutional rights.

headline: ‘The Godfather’ Was a Huge Risk. Robert Evans Said Yes Anyway.
abstract: The former Paramount Pictures executive wasn’t an artist, but he recognized artistry (and commercial potential) in others.
lead_paragraph: Appraising the contribution of the former Paramount Pictures executive Robert Evans is an act complicated not, as some may argue, by the well- and less-known facts and rumors of his private life — the cocaine, the women, the murder of one of the investors in a movie Mr. Evans produced, “The Cotton Club” (he was not charged) — but by the very complicated definition of “producer.” A producer and friend once told me, “The producer is the person who would do anything to get the movie made — and does.”

headline: Kamala Harris Campaign Cuts Staff in Effort to Keep Up With Top Rivals
abstract: The California senator’s fund-raising struggles are prompting her to reboot her campaign with a focus on Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris of California took her most drastic action yet on Wednesday to salvage her once-promising, now-languishing presidential bid, laying off staff members at her Baltimore headquarters and elsewhere, and redeploying others to Iowa, where she is looking to rejuvenate her campaign.

headline: This Guy Thought He Beat Facebook’s Controversial Political Ads Policy
abstract: “Apparently, it’s only O.K. to lie on Facebook if you don’t tell them you’re lying,” said Adriel Hampton, who is running for California governor in protest of the site’s reluctance to fact-check politicians.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Facebook has been assailed for a policy that allows politicians and their campaigns to post nearly whatever they want, including false and misleading claims. Critics have included Democratic presidential candidates and several hundred Facebook employees.

headline: Kashmir, Vietnam, Jho Low: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Kashmir officially loses its autonomy.
lead_paragraph: In August, the Indian government revoked the limited autonomy of Jammu and Kashmir, splitting it into two territories and bringing them under federal control. That move officially takes effect today.

headline: In the Fight Against Climate Change, Not All Forests Are Equal
abstract: A new study on the carbon impact of forest loss suggests a new target: preserving forests where deforestation and degradation haven’t yet begun.
lead_paragraph: Forests are a great bulwark against climate change, so programs to reduce deforestation are important. Those efforts usually focus on stopping the destruction in areas where it is already occurring.

headline: Overlooked No More: How Olive Morris Fought for Black Women’s Rights in Britain
abstract: In the 27 years she was alive, Morris raised awareness of inequalities by traveling, writing, organizing protests and setting up support groups.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Lindsay Peoples Wagner on Her First Year as Editor of Teen Vogue
abstract: How she got there, what she’s learned and why she is upending things.
lead_paragraph: “Every day feels like: ‘Don’t mess this up,’” said Lindsay Peoples Wagner, the editor in chief of Teen Vogue, this past spring. She was in her 25th-floor office at One World Trade Center, where the walls were lined with photographs and a publicist hovered.

headline: Twitter Will Ban All Political Ads, C.E.O. Jack Dorsey Says
abstract: The social media company’s action is a stark contrast to that of Facebook, which is taking a hands-off approach to political advertising.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter said on Wednesday that it would ban all political ads, putting a spotlight on the power and veracity of online advertising and ramping up pressure on Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to reverse his hands-off stance.

headline: Lyft Focuses on Profitability as Cash-Burning Companies Lose Luster
abstract: Lyft had said that it would lose record amounts of money, but it changed its tune as the sentiment toward prominent technology start-ups has soured.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Lyft on Wednesday emphasized a new mantra — profitability — over and over again.

headline: Review: Apple’s ‘Morning Show’? Wait for the Upgrade
abstract: The marquee offering of the tech giant’s new streaming service comes in a shiny package, but the parts don’t quite mesh.
lead_paragraph: “The Morning Show,” the flagship offering of the new Apple TV Plus streaming service that arrives Friday, looks like good TV. Directed by Mimi Leder, it gleams on the screen.

headline: Facebook’s Earnings and Revenue Jump, Topping Forecasts
abstract: The company’s financial performance is a regular bright spot for the social giant, which has been embroiled in scandals in recent years.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has been targeted by lawmakers over its treatment of political ads and has been misused by Russians to spread disinformation. But on Wednesday, the social network showed those challenges had little effect on its business.

headline: Germany Moves to Tighten Gun and Hate Speech Laws After Far-Right Attacks
abstract: The country will increase background checks for gun buyers and requirements for reporting online hate speech.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Prospective gun buyers in Germany would have to undergo background checks to ensure they have no ties to extremism and social media companies operating in the country would be required to report suspicious posts under a series of proposals advanced Wednesday by Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government.

headline: Apple Offers Upbeat Forecast While Profit Continues to Fall
abstract: The company said its profit dropped 3.1 percent from a year ago, but there are early hints that new iPhones are selling well heading into the holidays.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple said on Wednesday that its profit shrank for the fourth consecutive quarter — the longest such streak since 2016 — but it forecast that better days were ahead.

headline: Did Storming Area 51 Teach Us Anything?
abstract: No good meme goes unpunished.
lead_paragraph: When Bob Lazar, the original Area 51 “whistle-blower,” emailed me late last month to tell me his thoughts on the Storm Area 51 meme, he wrote that he was “glad my information has reached so many people.”

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Regina King Reads ‘Let’s Meet Again in Five Years’
abstract: The “Watchmen” star reads an essay about finding the right person — and the right time.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: A Physics Magic Trick: Take 2 Sheets of Carbon and Twist
abstract: The study of graphene was starting to go out of style, but new experiments with sheets of the ultrathin material revealed there was much left to learn.
lead_paragraph: In the universe of office supplies, pencil lead — a mixture of graphite and clay, which does not include any lead — appears unexceptional beyond its ability to draw dark lines.

headline: ‘Terminator: Dark Fate’ Review: It’s Hasta la Vista All Over Again
abstract: Linda Hamilton and Arnold Schwarzenegger return for another chapter in everyone’s favorite time-traveling killer-android franchise.
lead_paragraph: There are a number of reasons to like “Terminator: Dark Fate” — Linda Hamilton’s scowl, Arnold Schwarzenegger’s stubble, MacKenzie Davis’s athleticism — but my favorite thing about this late addition to a weary franchise is how little it cares about timeline continuity.

headline: How Contaminated Stool Stored in a Freezer Left a Fecal Transplant Patient Dead
abstract: The doctors who treated him, and another patient who fell ill, detailed the mistakes in a paper published Wednesday in a renowned medical journal.
lead_paragraph: In a frank and public act of self-examination, a group of doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital published an article Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine detailing the missteps that led to the death of a cancer patient who received a fecal transplant as part of an experimental trial. The man who died, and another who became severely ill, had received fecal matter from a donor whose stool turned out to contain a type of E. coli bacteria that was resistant to multiple antibiotics.

headline: In This World Series, It Was All About Home-Field Disadvantage
abstract: For the first time in World Series history, all seven games were won by the visiting team.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The home field is supposed to be an advantage in sports. Players sleep in their own beds. They keep their normal routines. Umpires might be friendlier. Whatever quirks exist on the playing field are familiar. The fans cheer you, not your opponent.

headline: New York City Council Calls for Grubhub to Refund Restaurants
abstract: More than 30 members of the Council sent a letter to Grubhub criticizing it for charging restaurant owners for phone calls that never led to orders.
lead_paragraph: The food-delivery giant Grubhub is having a difficult week: disappointing quarterly earnings, a declining share price, even talk of growing skepticism among investors about the broader food delivery market.

headline: Who Leaked Cuba Gooding Jr.’s Mug Shot? Detective Is Suspected
abstract: A decorated investigator in the Special Victims Division was put on desk duty after the actor’s arrest picture appeared on a website.
lead_paragraph: Less than two days after Cuba Gooding Jr. surrendered to the police in New York in June to face groping charges, his official mug shot appeared on an entertainment website, apparently having been leaked in violation of Police Department policy.

headline: California, the Fed, World Series: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: White House Pressed Car Makers to Join Its Fight Over California Emissions Rules
abstract: Monday’s surprise move by G.M., Toyota and other car makers to back President Trump in his fight with California over pollution rules followed calls from the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Monday’s surprise move by General Motors, Toyota and other auto giants to back President Trump in his fight with California over pollution rules came after days of White House pressure to support one of the administration’s biggest efforts to weaken climate regulations.

headline: ‘I Thought It Was Me’
abstract: What was it like for “a kid from Ohio” to run for president? More money would have helped.
lead_paragraph: Another one down, 17 to go.

headline: New Al-Baghdadi Raid Footage Is Released by Pentagon
abstract: The Pentagon on Wednesday released new footage showing the assault by U.S. Special Operations forces on the compound where the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was hiding.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon on Wednesday released new footage showing the assault by U.S. Special Operations forces on the compound where the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was hiding.

headline: ‘Devil Winds’ Drive Southern California Fires
abstract: The winds, known as the Santa Anas, loom large over the collective psyche of the region.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The downsloping gusts that begin inland and blow toward the ocean in autumn and winter bring with them warmth and dread in equal measure. They howl through the canyons of Santa Monica and whip the palm trees that line the streets of Los Angeles, driving up dust and fraying nerves.

headline: The Worst Trump Cabinet Member? You Picked a Real Winner
abstract: The vote wasn’t even close.
lead_paragraph: The results are in, people, and it’s a landslide. Your choice for Worst Trump Cabinet Member is …

headline: He Helped Make Dave Chappelle Dave Chappelle
abstract: Tony Woods has never broken into the mainstream the way his protégé did, but a recent set shows why he has been so influential.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Sunday, when Dave Chappelle accepted the Mark Twain Prize, the most prestigious honor in comedy, the first person in the star-packed audience (Jon Stewart, Tiffany Haddish, Sarah Silverman) he singled out in his speech was Tony Woods, a stand-up whom few outside comedy circles had heard of.

headline: Catholic Bishops Agree: Anything but a Woman
abstract: The push to allow married men to serve as priests isn’t progress. It’s another form of misogyny.
lead_paragraph: The modern Catholic Church is beset with serious problems. Among them is that not enough men want to be priests. Over the past three weeks, 184 bishops gathered at a Vatican summit to seek solutions for the Amazon region in particular, singled out because of myriad crises it is facing, including environmental devastation, violence and a shortage of priests to serve the needs of the faithful there.

headline: The Magic of Linus and ‘The Great Pumpkin’
abstract: His unwavering belief in the Halloween deity has drawn me to the 1966 “Peanuts” special year after year.
lead_paragraph: Pop culture can feel like religion when you’re a kid, a shared set of heroes and poses, attitudes, moods and jokes. For my father, who was born in 1933, it was a tone set by the two Franks — Sinatra and Capra. In my formative years, which ran from the mid-1970s to the mid-’80s, my general outlook on life, though fueled by David Letterman and Bruce Springsteen, was anchored by “Peanuts,” the world drawn by the cartoonist Charles Schulz.

headline: ISIS Leader Paid Rival for Protection but Was Betrayed by His Own
abstract: The world’s most wanted terrorist, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, was so worried about security that he only trusted a handful of aides and family members. One of them betrayed him.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: After this article was published, questions were raised about the authenticity of the documents upon which it was based.

headline: Goodbye Barneys, Hello Cheap Luxury Handbags for Christmas
abstract: The potential liquidation of the famed retailer could put a glut of discounted luxury merchandise on the market just as the holiday shopping season arrives.
lead_paragraph: It’s D-Day for Barneys New York — and, potentially, the entire high fashion retail world.

headline: The Rules of Impeachment
abstract: Democrats get serious about the next phase of inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office in 2017, President Trump and his administration have sought to remove — and in some cases, destroy — many of the guardrails of precedent and tradition surrounding the conduct of the executive branch.

headline: Iraq Prime Minister Pressed to Quit as Protests Clog Streets
abstract: A powerful Shiite cleric, Moqtada al-Sadr, is playing a leading role in negotiations to name a new Iraqi leader.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Under pressure from a growing number of protesters, Iraq’s prime minister appeared likely Wednesday to step down in the coming days, although exactly when is the subject of negotiations between two powerful Shiite Muslim leaders.

headline: Hundreds of U.S. Troops Leaving, and Also Arriving in, Syria
abstract: Once the comings and goings are done, the number of U.S. forces in Syria is expected to reach about 900 — close to the 1,000 troops on the ground when President Trump ordered the withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every day in northeastern Syria, waves of American troops are pulling out under President Trump’s order this month that paved the way for a Turkish offensive that included assaults on the Pentagon’s allies, the Syrian Kurds.

headline: Stick to Sports? No Way. Deadspin Journalists Quit en Masse.
abstract: At least eight writers and editors resigned on the day after the firing of the interim editor in chief.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the journalists at the freewheeling website Deadspin were instructed by its owners to stick to sports. On Tuesday, the site’s interim editor in chief, Barry Petchesky, was fired for refusing to obey that order. On Wednesday many longtime staff members quit in protest, hurling Deadspin into chaos.

headline: Georgia Plans to Purge 300,000 Names From Its Voter Rolls
abstract: Voting rights advocates described the removals as troubling, saying it was just the beginning of efforts to suppress the vote in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: A coming purge of Georgia’s voter rolls has raised alarms among advocacy groups in the state and nationwide, many of whom see the issue of who gets to cast a ballot re-emerging with next year’s election, particularly in battleground states.

headline: How to Eat Alone (and Like It)
abstract: Table for one? It’s not as bad as it sounds. Here’s how to dine by yourself and enjoy every bite.
lead_paragraph: When the ancient Roman politician Lucius Lucullus noticed his night’s menu looking dull, he gave instructions to his cook to prepare a lavish, multiple-course feast. When the cook asked what type of guests to expect, he responded with indignation: “Dost thou not know that today Lucullus dines with Lucullus?”

headline: Was That the Best Subtweet Ever?
abstract: Twitter will no longer allow political advertising, a move that places Twitter and Jack Dorsey in stark contrast to Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg.
lead_paragraph: That’s one small step by @jack, one giant leap for tweetkind.

headline: The Clintons and Justice Ginsburg on Judicial Nominations, Then and Now
abstract: Things have changed, they agreed, since President Bill Clinton’s 1993 nomination of the justice was approved by a vote of 96 to 3.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bill Clinton, who put Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court in 1993, joined the justice on Wednesday for a public conversation. So did Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, who might have named Justice Ginsburg’s eventual successor had she won the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Ford and U.A.W. in Tentative Contract Deal
abstract: ‘It appears both parties took a sane approach and avoided a painful strike that would have benefited neither of them,’ an economist said.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after ending its strike against General Motors, the United Automobile Workers union said on Wednesday night that it had reached an agreement on a tentative labor contract with Ford Motor Company.

headline: Philippines Struck by Second Big Earthquake in Three Days
abstract: The magnitude-6.5 earthquake hit about 25 miles southwest of Davao, a regional capital of 1.6 million people.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A strong earthquake struck the southern Philippine island of Mindanao on Thursday, killing at least five people and rattling an area still unsettled from a quake that killed at several people two days before.

headline: Kind of Experiment
abstract: Ezra Brauner makes his New York Times Crossword debut, ably assisted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Happy Halloween! I hope you’ll help the constructors — Ezra Brauner (who makes his debut) and Jeff Chen — as well as the crossword editors celebrate the Festival of Frights.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Take Stargazing
abstract: Go out and see something spectacular.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Each week we email readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Michigan Man Sentenced for Rock Throwing That Killed Another in 2017
abstract: Kyle Anger was sentenced to more than three years in the death of Ken White, who was killed when a six-pound rock smashed through his windshield.
lead_paragraph: A Michigan judge sentenced a 19-year-old man this week to more than three years in prison for his role in a 2017 rock-throwing game that killed a man as he drove home from work, according to prosecutors.

headline: Interior Department Grounds Chinese-Made Drones Amid Review
abstract: The grounding is the latest precaution taken against Chinese drones being used in federal government work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department announced on Wednesday that all drones in its fleet that were manufactured in China or contained Chinese-made parts would be grounded as part of a review of the department’s drone program.

headline: Corrections: October 31, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, October 31, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day: Foie Gras, Served in 1,000 Restaurants in New York City, Is Banned
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 31, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “What’s next? No more veal? No more mushrooms?”

headline: ISIS, Germany, Twitter: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Convicted Rapist Is Captured After Being Released From Georgia Prison ‘in Error’
abstract: Tony Maycon Munoz-Mendez, who is serving a life sentence, was taken into custody in northern Kentucky on Wednesday, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A convicted rapist and child molester who was set free by accident last week from a Georgia prison where he had been serving a life sentence has been captured, the authorities said.

headline: Anxious and Cooped Up, 1.5 Million Kashmiri Children Are Still Out of School
abstract: With soldiers and militants claiming the streets, and most schools simply shuttered, education has been on hold through months of crisis in Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: KAPRAN, Kashmir — Every day, Aliya Khan, a fifth-grader in Kashmir, steps out of her house and walks down a dirt lane lined by tall maple trees to check on what’s happening at her school.

headline: Is Angela Merkel Still in Charge?
abstract: The chancellor of Germany no longer shows the vision and courage to lead her country.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Two things make Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany look like an exemplary head of government: Donald Trump and Boris Johnson. Measured against the poorest of benchmarks, Ms. Merkel’s chancellorship, even after 14 years in office, appears stable, wise and exemplary. Measured against the leadership Germany and Europe need, it lacks all of the above.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: The Original ‘Halloween’ and More Scares
abstract: John Carpenter’s formative slasher movie airs on AMC, alongside lots of other creepy Halloween offerings.
lead_paragraph: HALLOWEEN (1978) 7 p.m. on AMC. “This is an evil that makes no facial expression, doesn’t have a voice, moves slowly but kills with a vengeance,” Jamie Lee Curtis said in an interview with The New York Times last year, answering a question about why the creepy killer Michael Myers has remained a compelling figure for four decades. This is the original John Carpenter slasher movie that spawned a franchise. “Halloween” introduced both Curtis (it was her film debut) and her character, Laurie Strode, a teenage babysitter who is stalked by the masked psychopath Myers (Nick Castle). “This is a universal terror that you combine with a woman representing everyone,” Curtis added, “and you have a recipe for people going to the movie over and over again.”

headline: The Nationals Stayed in the Fight, Then Delivered a Knockout
abstract: For a team that overcame a terrible start to the year and fought through a trying postseason, it was fitting that the Washington Nationals’ first World Series title required all seven games.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Late Tuesday night, after the Washington Nationals had forced the 40th winner-take-all game in World Series history, reliever Sean Doolittle considered their journey. The first 50 games of their season had been a sinkhole, with 31 losses and untold angst for a team synonymous with letdown.

headline: Stephen Curry Breaks Hand in Warriors’ Loss to the Suns
abstract: Golden State has lost three All-Stars to serious injuries within its last six games, extending to last season.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Word + Quiz: sycophant
abstract: This word has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Two Histories of Financiers Profiting From Real Estate While Homeowners Go Belly Up
abstract: “Homewreckers,” by Aaron Glantz, and “Race for Profit,” by Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor, may be focused on different eras, decades apart, but they tell similarly troubling stories.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Glantz knows that he’s living the dream — the good guy who does well in the morality play of American real estate.

headline: Pakistan Train Catches Fire, Killing More Than 70
abstract: Passengers jumped to escape the blaze, which officials said was caused when a cooking stove exploded.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 72 people were killed in central Pakistan on Thursday morning after a cooking stove being used on a train exploded, officials said. Witnesses said that some desperate passengers began jumping off the burning train while it was still moving.

headline: Passport
abstract: What story could this image tell?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: 49ers Try to Keep Win Streak Alive in Arizona
abstract: A rotating cast of characters contributes as San Francisco tight end George Kittle and the defense dominate.
lead_paragraph: The rest of Week 9’s N.F.L. matchups will be published Friday.

headline: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot Planned Merger: A Big but Imperfect Union
abstract: The deal would bring together car companies with similar weaknesses, yet have the advantage of size.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler and PSA of France announced on Thursday that they planned to merge to create the world’s fourth largest automaker, a company that would produce slightly more cars than American icon General Motors.

headline: Stephen Colbert on Trump’s Transcript: ‘Comma for Comma, Quid for Quo’
abstract: The White House’s version of the Ukraine call reminds Colbert of the gap in Nixon’s Watergate tape — “if Nixon had left in all the bad stuff.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Shuri Castle, Historic Tourist Draw in Japan, Is Destroyed by Fire
abstract: The World Heritage site, a symbol of the southern island of Okinawa, was once the seat of a kingdom that spanned 450 years.
lead_paragraph: A devastating fire on Thursday destroyed most of Shuri Castle, a top tourist destination on the Japanese island of Okinawa and a World Heritage site that was once the seat of a kingdom that spanned 450 years.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘After This Fungus Turns Ants Into Zombies, Their Bodies Explode’
abstract: In this Halloween-themed lesson, students trace the evolution of a mysterious zombifying fungus.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “After This Fungus Turns Ants Into Zombies, Their Bodies Explode”

headline: Straws
abstract: Does big, sustainable change have to feel like grasping at straws?

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Unpeeled Eggs
abstract: The shells might be a good source of calcium, but does that make it O.K.?
lead_paragraph: Karlee writes: My husband eats hard-boiled eggs whole, shell and all. He says they’re perfectly fine to eat and even good for you, because they have a lot of calcium. I argue that he can get calcium through less horrifying means. Please order him to stop eating like a raccoon and peel the egg properly like a human.

headline: How to Build a Moat
abstract: Anticipate sedimentation. Keep the water fresh. Cut any trees by the edge yearly.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing about a moat is easy,” says Hendri Meendering, the general manager of Fort Bourtange, a small fortress in the Netherlands surrounded by a star-shaped moat first built in 1593. Prepare to spend time and money. By the 1970s, the fort was mostly ruined and the moat dry, when the local government began excavating the canals and rebuilding; the project took 25 years and went way over budget. “The canals must be deep and wide,” Meendering says: Try eight feet deep and 20 to 40 feet wide. Consider geology and its potential effects on sedimentation. Plan a route across; Bourtange has five wooden drawbridges, but they’re too heavy and dangerous to pull up. Don’t expect your moat to stop swimmers not wearing armor. “A person can easily swim across within a minute if they want,” Meendering says.

headline: ‘Walmart Feels Like Home Now’ for These Fire Evacuees
abstract: As the Kincade fire blazes on, dozens of evacuees have taken refuge in a shopping center in Rohnert Park, Calif.
lead_paragraph: As the Kincade fire blazes on, dozens of evacuees have taken refuge in a shopping center in Rohnert Park, Calif.

headline: They Wanted River Views They Could Afford. Which Home Did They Choose?
abstract: After a quiet decade in Maine, a couple return to New York to be near their new grandchildren — and the Hudson River. Here’s where they wound up.
lead_paragraph: After a quiet decade in Maine, a couple return to New York to be near their new grandchildren — and the Hudson River. Here’s where they wound up.

headline: How Good Are You at Spending Time Alone?
abstract: Do you like spending time by yourself? Or do you fear being bored or lonely?
lead_paragraph: A long, solitary walk in which you think through a complicated situation, an hour spent sitting quietly at home when everyone else is out — do you seek out these opportunities? Or do you avoid them at all cost?

headline: André Aciman Would Like to Demote Virginia Woolf From the Canon
abstract: The novelist and Proust scholar, whose new book is “Find Me,” calls “Mrs. Dalloway” an “overrated novel that I don’t find particularly gripping or interesting. I’m not even sure it’s well written.”
lead_paragraph: The novelist and Proust scholar, whose new book is “Find Me,” calls “Mrs. Dalloway” an “overrated novel that I don’t find particularly gripping or interesting. I’m not even sure it’s well written.”

headline: Americans Trust Local News. That Belief Is Being Exploited.
abstract: A growth in impostor local news that promotes ideological agendas.
lead_paragraph: The nature of the news misinformation problem may be changing. As consumers become more skeptical about the national news they encounter online, impostor local sites that promote ideological agendas are becoming more common. These sites exploit the relatively high trust Americans express in local news outlets — a potential vulnerability in Americans’ defenses against untrustworthy information.

headline: Why ‘Medicare for All’ Could Both Raise Taxes and Lower Costs
abstract: A crucial difference between a single-payer plan and more moderate Democratic proposals is how much spending would shift to the federal budget.
lead_paragraph: A crucial difference between a single-payer plan and more moderate Democratic proposals is how much spending would shift to the federal budget.

headline: A Defense of Clowns
abstract: As the mother of a child with special needs, I found that clowns helped lighten the mood in the hospital when my son and I most needed a laugh.
lead_paragraph: Joaquin Phoenix’s murderous clown in the film “Joker” has stirred up serious concerns about violence this fall. And for many people, the role of a clown as supervillain bolsters a long-held conviction that double-faced clowns are evil.

abstract: And why are millennials turning to the occult?

headline: 13 Books to Watch For in November
abstract: A long-awaited new novel from the author of “The Night Circus,” essays from Lydia Davis and a tell-all by an anonymous White House official.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t the memoir you might expect from the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ bassist: Flea doesn’t offer a retrospective of the band’s trajectory and fame, focusing instead on everything leading up to their rise. His tumultuous friendship with Anthony Kiedis, the lead singer of the band, forms the emotional core of the book, but he also evokes the Los Angeles of the 1970s and ’80s, and the creative influences that shaped him.

headline: At 14, He Stayed Away From Trouble. But a Bullet Flew 100 Yards.
abstract: A boy and a dream crumpled to the concrete on a basketball court in Queens.
lead_paragraph: He was a 14-year-old boy playing basketball at dusk before curfew. Just another night, on his usual court, focused on the game he envisioned as his future.

abstract: Facebook isn’t defending free speech, it’s assaulting truth.
